headline: A Modest Decline of Homicides in Mexico
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Violence caused by the drug war in Mexico may be abating, making it the first decline in six years, according to figures released by the government this week.
lead_paragraph: Violence caused by the drug war in Mexico may be abating, according to figures released this week by the government. The data showed a modest decline in homicides in 2012, the first in six years. Mexico’s census agency, compiling reports of murders from the 32 federal entities, said there were 26,037 homicides last year, a 4.3 percent decline from 27,213 in 2011, which was the most in recent years. The homicide rate was 22 per 100,000 residents, a decline from 24 per 100,000 the previous year. The homicide rate in the United States is 4.7 per 100,000 people, according to United Nations figures, but Mexico’s rate was far lower than several other countries in the hemisphere. A number of analysts believe this data provides a good barometer of overall violence, which had surged because of infighting among criminal gangs and the government’s efforts to suppress them. In 2007, there were 8,867 homicides, the lowest number in the last six years.

headline: León Ferrari, Provocative Argentine Conceptual Artist, Dies at 92

headline: Abortion Law Is Blocked in North Dakota
abstract: A state judge on Wednesday temporarily blocked enforcement of a law requiring doctors who perform abortions to have admitting privileges at nearby hospitals.
lead_paragraph: A state judge on Wednesday temporarily blocked enforcement of a law requiring doctors who perform abortions to have admitting privileges at nearby hospitals. The law is similar to measures promoted by anti-abortion groups and blocked by courts in other states, including Mississippi and Alabama. It would have forced North Dakota’s only abortion center, the Red River Clinic in Fargo, to close because it uses out-of-state doctors who have been refused admitting privileges at local hospitals. Medical experts say such requirements do not improve patient safety since hospitals will accept and treat emergency patients regardless. The North Dakota lawsuit that resulted in Wednesday’s temporary injunction was brought on behalf of the clinic by the Center for Reproductive Rights, based in New York.

headline: The Ticktock of the Death Clock
abstract: I recently found myself at DeathClock.com, “the Internet’s friendly reminder that life is slipping away … second by second.” Then, not allowing myself to wallow one grain of sand longer, I decided to quit my day job.
lead_paragraph: With every new silver hair sprouting from my scalp, I can’t help but think of the shortening arc ahead of me. Now in my mid-50s, for the first time I’m no longer looking up, over and beyond. Rather, my trajectory points downward at the approaching horizon. In this frame of mind, I recently found myself at DeathClock.com, the “Internet’s friendly” — if not scientific — “reminder that life is slipping away … second by second.” After I completed the short questionnaire, the Death Clock’s algorithm quickly did the math, concluding: “Your personal day of death is Wednesday, April 23, 2031.”

headline: A Rare Sight in Pittsburgh as the Pirates Enter August in First Place
abstract: With a sweep of a single-admission doubleheader over the visiting Cardinals on Tuesday, the Pirates reclaimed the N.L. Central lead from St. Louis.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — In the sixth inning of the nightcap of Tuesday’s doubleheader, a black bat circled above the seats just behind the Pirates’ third-base on-deck circle and ultimately settled high on the fans’ side of the screen. There it remained for the duration, utterly immobile and impervious to those who soon rocked the sold-out stadium in celebrating the Pirates’ twin-bill sweep of the St. Louis Cardinals that reclaimed the National League Central division lead from the visitors.

headline: ArcelorMittal Reports 2nd Quarter Net Loss of $780 Million
abstract: The results for the world’s largest steel company were hurt by continued losses in Europe, which continues to be a challenging environment.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — ArcelorMittal, the world’s largest steel company, reported on Thursday a net loss of $780 million for the second quarter, compared with net income of about $1 billion in the same period a year earlier. The company also reported $1.7 billion in earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, the commonly used metric in the steel industry, a figure that was in line with analysts’ consensus forecasts.

headline: How Not to Talk About Poverty in India
abstract: The callous lexicon India’s politicians deploy to describe the challenge of poverty.
lead_paragraph: Growing up, I remember seeing young couples munching peanuts, idly walking past the banks of Dhakuria Lake, across the expanse of the open fields, in the heart of Kolkata, as dusk settled in. “Poor man’s romance” ran the wry joke drawing attention to the city’s severe economic plight and the benighted Calcuttan couple’s dwindling purchasing power. Predictably, the city’s peanut-munching, hand-holding subaltern lovers featured in many Bengali films, with Bengals’ joblessness and ubiquitous impoverishment at the heart of the narratives.

headline: A Sea Change for the America’s Cup
keywords: ["AMERICA'S CUP", 'Sailboats and Sailing', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Photography']
abstract: Yachts are becoming faster, and this competition is getting gnarly.
lead_paragraph: There is a moment when the yachts racing in this year’s America’s Cup go from being mere boats to something more like flying machines. It happens at around 17 knots, or 20 miles per hour, when both hulls of the carbon-fiber catamarans rise out of the water and the entire craft skims over the surface on a thin hydrofoil beneath the downwind pontoon. Free of the water’s drag, the vessels accelerate to speeds as great as 50 miles per hour.

lead_paragraph: Young people sometimes look at the world with brash certainty, seeing only absolutes — stark blacks and bright whites. But time and experience teach us that life exists mostly in nuanced gray, and that ambiguity often provides insight.

headline: At Bayreuth, Boos and Dropped Jaws

lead_paragraph: BAYREUTH, Germany — It has become almost an expected part of the Bayreuth Festival tradition that the audience boos when the director of a radical new production takes a curtain call. But there is booing, and then there is the kind of demonstration that happened here on Wednesday night at the end of “Götterdämmerung.” The occasion was the fourth, and final, installment of the festival’s new production of Wagner’s “Ring,” the most anticipated event of the international celebrations for Wagner’s bicentennial.

headline: Help! I’m Not a Numbers Person! (Part 2)

But then we ran the numbers, and much to her surprise, it looked as if she was actually making a profit. “But I don’t have any money!” she responded.

It was then that 28,000 men lost their lives in the Battle of Towton, the most ferocious battle for the crown between the Houses of York and Lancaster during the Wars of the Roses.

headline: 36 Hours in Portsmouth, N.H.
abstract: This small waterfront town, settled in 1623, boasts a range of options to fill a weekend, from brews to books to boats.
lead_paragraph: Settled in 1623, Portsmouth lays claim to the title of third-oldest city in the nation, but at 21,000 inhabitants, it’s no metropolis. And that’s just fine. With a rich fishing, shipping and brewing past, and a still active working port, Portsmouth and its pleasures are smaller scale. They’re also best approached on foot. Visitors will find no end of brick sidewalks to stroll, boutiques to pop into, and Colonial, Federal and Georgian houses to tour. Then there’s the food: Portsmouth is blessed with an absurd selection of restaurants, cafes and ice cream parlors to ponder. After a long day’s shopping, gallery hop or boat ride, visitors seem to end up at a new favorite waterfront watering hole. Once installed at the bar or patio, raise a mug of frosty ale to this surprising little city of contrasts: touristy and local, cultured and blue collar, historically preserved and scrappy.

headline: History in the Making, and in the Dark
abstract: The L.P.G.A. star Inbee Park could win an unprecedented Grand Slam and still cause barely a ripple.
lead_paragraph: In case you missed it, and we know you have, an athlete stands on the brink of history. There is a reason everybody talks about the Grand Slams in golf, but never about the Grand Slam, winning all four of them in one year. That’s because no one has ever done it since golf gave up persimmon shafts and amateurism. Few even wander into the neighborhood. And yet, here we have Inbee Park, three major tournament victories in hand this year and favored to win a fourth (she shot a 69 in the first round of the women’s British Open on Thursday), and almost no one knows this is happening.

headline: Enough Resilience to Fill an Arena
abstract: Beyoncé’s “Mrs. Carter Show” tours top at the Izod Center was no tribute to wifely self-effacement, but a celebration of a high-achieving Everywoman balancing love and independence.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — At first it seemed that Beyoncé was taking one of her pop-star nicknames, Queen Bey, all too seriously. Her show at the Izod Center here on Wednesday night opened with a bombastic orchestral dirge and a video presenting her as a Marie Antoinette figure in a Gothic palace, receiving a crown. But as the queen’s female retinue — wearing white unitards and hoops without skirts — reappeared onstage, the dirge segued into the martial beat of “Run the World (Girls).” Beyoncé, shaking the epaulets on her shoulders and flipping her hair, was taking power not for herself but for her entire gender. The set that followed was not about aristocratic aloofness, but about energy, empathy and a beaming smile.

headline: Music and Moonshine in the Mellow Ozarks
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Budget Travel', 'Folk Music', 'Liquor', 'Canoes and Canoeing']
abstract: In Part 3 of his summer road trip, the Frugal Traveler hops between Missouri and Arkansas, dropping in on a fiddle jam, sipping spirits and tuning into the region’s relaxed groove.
lead_paragraph: Dinnertime comes early in the Ozarks, even during the long days of summer. So after I lingered over smoked trout, fried chicken liver and blackberry cobbler at Rockbridge Trout and Game Ranch’s friendly restaurant, wandered around its barn-red 19th-century grist mill and drove off to look for a motel, there was still daylight to spare. At 8 p.m., as I reached the utterly rural intersection of Missouri Routes 5 and 95, the sun had still not quite yet set. It was what photographers and filmmakers call the golden hour, when the last light of the day gives whatever land it falls on a temporary visual upgrade. So I stopped, parked, and sat on the hood of my car. Sloping pastures glinted and cattle grazed halfway to the horizon, beyond them purplish pink clouds hovered over barely distinguishable low-slung hills. The Ozarks were, finally, stunning.

headline: The Cellphone Gets Its Close-Up
abstract: “The Canyons,” Paul Schrader’s new film, written by Bret Easton Ellis and starring Lindsay Lohan, is a dispiriting work that addresses the dirty business of making movies.
lead_paragraph: “The Canyons” — directed by Paul Schrader, written by Bret Easton Ellis and starring Lindsay Lohan — is a dispiriting, unpleasurable work punctuated with flashes of vitalizing vulgarity. It isn’t a good movie in terms of the conventional norms (acting for starters), but it also exhibits a crude integrity. If you take the characters seriously or at their word, a mistake for such a dissembling, venal group, you may think that this is just another story about the dirty business of making movies. Hollywood types have been rolling around in the muck about as long as there’s been an industry (that’s what made Sammy run); the twist here is that no one here seems to care anymore.

abstract: Legislation that bans promoting homosexuality in Russia has some gay rights advocates calling for protests or a boycott of the 2014 Olympics in Sochi.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia’s minister of sports, Vitaly L. Mutko, said on Thursday that foreign athletes traveling to Russia for the 2014 Olympics in Sochi would be expected to obey a new Russian law banning “homosexual propaganda” or face criminal prosecution.

headline: Many a Twist on a French Classic
abstract: Creperies in New Jersey are stuffing the thin pancakes not only with classics like Nutella, but with spicy pork, too.
lead_paragraph: Fans of crepes don’t have far to go to indulge their cravings these days; like cupcakes, the thin, French pancakes with assorted fillings seem to be having a moment.

headline: Yves Klein’s ‘Monotone’ Symphony Is Headed to New York
abstract: In a re-creation of a legendary 1960 art event, the dealer Dominique Lévy has arranged a performance of Yves Klein’s “Monotone-Silence” Symphony.
lead_paragraph: On March 9, 1960, 100 people, all in black tie, gathered in a Paris gallery to see the artist Yves Klein conduct a 10-piece orchestra in a performance of his first sound composition. Called the “Monotone-Silence” Symphony, it consisted of a single chord played for 20 minutes straight, followed by 20 minutes of silence. At the same time, Klein directed three female models (whom he called his “living brushes”) to roll themselves in blue paint and press their bodies against sheets of paper lining the walls and floors. When the music stopped, the models froze.

headline: Fox Signals How ‘Glee’  Will Handle Monteith Death
abstract: The network plans to address the death of Cory Monteith, one of its star actors, from a drug overdose, in the third episode this season.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Fox network and the producers of “Glee” have devised a plan to address the unexpected death last month of one of the show’s stars, Cory Monteith, with a direct treatment of the issue of drug addiction, Kevin Reilly, the chairman of entertainment for Fox, said on Thursday.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Zimbabwe and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Zimbabwe, Israel, Ohio and Canada.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Zimbabwe, Israel, Ohio and Canada.

headline: Objectively Stylish
abstract: The NYTimes iOS team has been working on our style guide for over a year and we finally decided that it’s time to share it with the Objective-C community.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times has a long history of publishing style guides. We first released The New York Times Manual of Style and Usage in 1950 so that reporters inside and outside The Times could have a definitive resource for our somewhat quirky rules. In 2002, we published an update to that guide, and NYTimes journalists and editors use a frequently updated online reference version every day.

headline: ‘If This Were Your Mother, Doctor…’
abstract: A common question helps family members make sense of the confusion, desolation and powerlessness that so often defines the hospital experience, but leaves a newcomer to clinical medicine feeling vulnerable and violated.
lead_paragraph: The other residents and I sat in our blue scrubs with our attending physician in the windowless family meeting room just outside the intensive care unit. We had gathered around one end of the ovoid table with the family of the patient, two daughters and a son, at the other.

headline: Advocates for Immigrants Up the Ante in a Capitol Sit-In That Brings Arrests
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Organized Labor', 'Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Supporters of an overhaul are stepping up their tactics as lawmakers begin an August recess.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Seeking to send a message to lawmakers as they leave to face their constituents over the August recess, 41 leaders of groups supporting an overhaul of the immigration system held a noisy but peaceful sit-in on Capitol Hill on Thursday and were arrested, in an escalation of their tactics.

headline: Mets’ Harvey Remains Winless Against a Lineup That’s Usually Hapless
abstract: Matt Harvey, the Mets’ ace, is 0-1 with a 3.52 earned run average in four starts against the Marlins this season. In his latest, he lasted only five and two-thirds innings.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Matt Harvey has mystified plenty of hitters throughout his All-Star season.

headline: Shanghai For Strivers
abstract: “Five Star Billionaire,” Tash Aw’s latest novel, is set in a rapidly changing China.
lead_paragraph: Tash Aw’s estimable third novel, “Five Star Billionaire,” takes its title from a fictional self-help book, and its mantras function as chapter titles: “Move to where the money is”; “Reinvent yourself”; “Cultivate an urbane, humorous personality.” Some of these mantras are touching, like “Know when to cut your losses.”

headline: Two Good Guys (or So They Seem) Behaving Badly
abstract: The Baltasar Kormakur buddy film “2 Guns” turns on a pair of seemingly bad guys who may be good, out to rob a drug cartel’s money from a bank.
lead_paragraph: Big bangs and fast talk are the name of the genre game in “2 Guns,” a slick, slippery thriller that taps into the anarchic playfulness that made the best American action flicks of the 1980s and ’90s pop. Directed by Baltasar Kormakur, riffing on the cheerful irreverence of Shane Black and the hyperbolic style of Tony Scott, the movie turns on a pair of seemingly bad guys who may be good. A reissue of the five-part comic series on which it’s based sets the scene nicely: “Two guys walk into a bank. It goes badly.” It does in the movies as well, although now the duo spring off the page courtesy of Denzel Washington and Mark Wahlberg, one of the better odd couples to bond and bicker since Mel met Danny.

headline: Ex-Chairman of Freddie Mac Nominated to Lead I.R.S.
abstract: John A. Koskinen, who managed a bankrupt Freddie Mac at the height of the financial crisis, is President Obama’s choice to lead the troubled Internal Revenue Service.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama said on Thursday that he would nominate John A. Koskinen, a widely respected manager who took charge of a bankrupt Freddie Mac, to head another troubled institution, the Internal Revenue Service.

headline: Nostalgic Finale, With Latin Touch, for a B-Boy Original
abstract: Crazy Legs and his Rock Steady Crew presented the premiere of “Ghetto Made,” a hip-hop history lesson of sorts, at SummerStage on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: What do you call a B-boy when he’s a middle-aged man? Richard Colón was 13 in 1979, when he joined the two-year-old Rock Steady Crew. He wasn’t much older when, under the descriptive moniker Crazy Legs, he became world famous for spinning on his back. By then he was president of this group, and decades later he still is. For a long time he was the only original member performing. On Wednesday at Central Park SummerStage, he danced his final show.

headline: Novel Approach
abstract: The essayist David Rakoff’s final work is fiction in verse about a group of interlocking characters.
lead_paragraph: There’s an absolutely essential video available on YouTube, of a 2012 segment from the public radio program “This American Life,” in which the writer and frequent guest David Rakoff walks onstage with his left hand tucked into his pocket. Rakoff has recently undergone surgery, his “fourth in as many years” for cancer, he explains, and now possesses a “flail limb.” Aside from “being able to shrug talmudically,” he says, “I can neither move nor feel my left arm.”

headline: One Tough Cookie
abstract: Tate’s Bake Shop, in Southampton, N.Y, is known for its award-winning cookies, but the story of its owner, Kathleen King, proves to be worth the trip, too.
lead_paragraph: WHEN my friend Kathleen moved back to New York a few weeks ago, after living on the West Coast for 18 months, I wanted to welcome her home in style. I remembered reading that Tate’s Bake Shop, based in Southampton, N.Y., had opened its own gluten-free kitchen in April, and since Kathleen has a gluten sensitivity, I figured I would stage a dessert jamboree.

headline: Ride the Giant Dipper
abstract: Ride the Giant Dipper at Santa Cruz Beach Boardwalk.
lead_paragraph: Ride the Giant Dipper at Santa Cruz Beach Boardwalk.

headline: Requiem for the Living
abstract: Juan Gabriel Vásquez’s new novel, built on Colombia’s tragic history, features the cold, bitter poetry of Bogotá and the hushed intensity of young married love.
lead_paragraph: The author of this book is from Colombia, but he is nothing like Gabriel García Márquez. Juan Gabriel Vásquez’s brilliant new novel rejects the vivid colors and mythical transformations of his older countryman’s Caribbean masterpiece, “One Hundred Years of Solitude,” in favor of the cold, bitter poetry of Bogotá and the hushed intensity of young married love. In “The Sound of Things Falling,” we are closer to the noir palette of the Uruguayan genius Juan Carlos Onetti, whose fiction was apt to be set in a bankrupt shipyard or to feature a desperate writer striving to raise money for his wife’s cancer surgery.

headline: Steinem Makes a Video for Quinn
abstract: As part of a drive to win women’s votes, Christine C. Quinn distributed a video of Gloria Steinem saying her election as mayor would inspire girls.
lead_paragraph: Seeking to capitalize on the historic nature of her candidacy, Christine C. Quinn sent out a video on Thursday of the feminist icon Gloria Steinem lauding Ms. Quinn and saying her election as mayor would inspire young women. Ms. Quinn, the City Council speaker, would be the first woman elected mayor of New York.

headline: In Store | A Berlin Boutique That Pays Tribute to New York Creative Culture
abstract: Rats, named for the Big Apple’s unofficial mascots, offers a curated selection of products from the city’s coolest designers and artists.
lead_paragraph: As any New York denizen knows, the rat is both the city’s unofficial mascot and the ruler of its underground domain. That’s why the artist Keren Richter and the art director Gabriel Kuo chose Rats as the name for their new curated pop-up shop in Berlin, which pays tribute to the underground creative culture of the Big Apple.

headline: Two Climate Analysts Fault Gas Leaks, but Not as a Big Warming Threat
abstract: Two global warming researchers say natural gas leaks are a problem, but not a big part of the climate problem.
lead_paragraph: Two prominent analysts of human-driven global warming have offered fresh criticisms of the way Anthony Ingraffea, a Cornell University engineering professor, has been portraying the contribution of natural gas leaks to climate change.

headline: Being on the Rebound Never Felt So Good
abstract: James Ponsoldt’s new film, “The Spectacular Now,” is a tale of a teenager and the speed bumps at the end of high school.
lead_paragraph: Sutter Keely is a teenager with the gift of gab, able to flip the mood of an encounter with brash good will. You run into guys like this in teenage dramas or comedies, the charm often backed up with sarcasm or a pretty face. But Sutter has genuine heart, and his cheer masks closely held fears, an ambivalence about the future and an insecurity over his separated parents’ past.

headline: Ring Around the Collar at 535 Park Avenue
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Cooperatives', 'Restoration and Renovation']
abstract: The Upper East Side building, completed in 1910, is whitening its soiled terra-cotta base.
lead_paragraph: The trim elegance of 535 Park Avenue, unusual because it was built by its future owners instead of a developer, has long been marred by the fractured and soiled glazed terra cotta on two lower floors. Now the refined building, completed in 1910, is taking a radical approach to a longtime problem.

headline: Receiver With Ties to Eagles’ Coach Gets Last Shot
abstract: David Ball, 29, who broke Jerry Rice’s Division I-AA record for touchdown receptions, played college football at New Hampshire under Eagles Coach Chip Kelly.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — When Coach Chip Kelly sent David Ball a text message last week to ask him if he was free to join the Eagles at their training camp, Ball packed his gear and took an immediate sabbatical from his day job as a high school football coach in Vermont.

headline: Senate Easily Approves Obama’s U.N. Nominee
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Samantha Power received the Senate’s approval as the next ambassador to the United Nations without the partisan acrimony of other recent nominations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Thursday approved the nomination of Samantha Power as the next ambassador to the United Nations, a relatively smooth and quiet process that lacked the partisan acrimony of other recent confirmations.

headline: Seafood in a Skipper’s House
abstract: The Captain Daniel Packer Inne is housed in a 1754 Dutch colonial with a typically antique interior but a menu that isn’t fusty.
lead_paragraph: The Fort Rachel section of Mystic comprises a warren of hilly lanes with trim Colonial-era frame houses, views of sailboats bobbing in the harbor, and the 1754 Dutch colonial that is the Captain Daniel Packer Inne. The restaurant is currently run by Allison Kiley Nasin, the daughter of the couple who painstakingly restored the building and opened it 30 years ago.

headline: Increase in Urine Testing Raises Ethical Questions
keywords: ['Tests (Drug Use)', 'Pain-Relieving Drugs', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Laboratories and Scientific Equipment', 'Doctors']
abstract: The growth of tests for painkillers has led to concerns about their accuracy and whether some companies and doctors are exploiting them for profit.
lead_paragraph: As doctors try to ensure their patients do not abuse prescription drugs, they are relying more and more on sophisticated urine-screening tests to learn which drugs patients are taking and — just as important — which ones they’re not.

headline: Jailed Pussy Riot Activist’s Defiant Speech at Parole Hearing
abstract: The literary journal n+1 published an English translation of the Pussy Riot activist Nadezhda Tolokonnikova’s defiant statement at a parole hearing in Russia last week.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague Melena Ryzik reported, the two members of the Russian activist collective Pussy Riot who remain imprisoned were both denied parole last week. At separate hearings, Maria Alyokhina and Nadezhda Tolokonnikova were judged to be insufficiently repentant for the “punk prayer” they performed in a Moscow cathedral last year, calling on the Virgin Mary to “send Putin packing!”

headline: Banks as Bookies
abstract: The security that Fabrice Tourre helped to create while he worked at Goldman Sachs was a pure gamble. One side bet that the mortgage market would collapse; the other bet it would not. What’s the difference between that and betting on a football game?
lead_paragraph: Why did Fabrice Tourre’s security exist?

headline: New York State Investigates Disqualification of Customers by Banks
abstract: The attorney general sent letters to six banks seeking information about the use of databases that disqualify people seeking to open checking or savings accounts.
lead_paragraph: New York State’s top prosecutor is investigating some of the nation’s largest banks in connection with their use of credit-reporting databases that disqualify people seeking to open checking or savings accounts — an inquiry that has gained urgency as the ranks of the unbanked has swelled in the aftermath of the financial crisis.

headline: Good to the Last Rocking Drop
abstract: Closing night at Maxwell’s offered a glimpse of the ghosts of the club’s past as the home of jangly, Britpop-inspired, postpunk indie rock.
lead_paragraph: HOBOKEN, N.J. — “THIS room was a bit more to us than a performance room,” Richard Barone of the Bongos said about halfway through the group’s set at Maxwell’s here on Wednesday evening. “It was also our practice space. And it still feels like a practice space.”

lead_paragraph: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: A Double Bill: 2 English Composers, 3 Centuries Apart
abstract: Mark Morris presented two dance dramas — Henry Purcell’s “Dido and Aeneas” and Benjamin Britten’s “Curlew River” — in a double bill at Tanglewood.
lead_paragraph: LENOX, Mass. — The coupling of Henry Purcell’s “Dido and Aeneas” and Benjamin Britten’s “Curlew River” — English music dramas composed almost three centuries apart — makes a superlative double bill. It’s not unreasonable to claim that Purcell and Britten are the two greatest English-born composers, and in this centenary year of Britten’s birth, it’s good to link him to a composer he often championed. More than that, these are two intricate, tragic masterpieces. Each houses death and violent emotional affliction within several outer shells that, paradoxically, make anguish at once more bearable and more inexorable.

headline: When a Poet’s Life and the Law Are at Odds
abstract: David Daniels is Oscar Wilde in “Oscar,” a new opera by Theodore Morrison that had its premiere at the Santa Fe Opera.
lead_paragraph: SANTA FE, N.M. — Press week at the Santa Fe Opera — when all five works in the season’s repertory are presented within five nights — got off to a head-spinning start, contrasting Offenbach’s frothy comedy “The Grand Duchess of Gerolstein,” on Tuesday evening, with Theodore Morrison’s pitch-black drama, “Oscar,” on Wednesday.

headline: Is It ’77 All Over Again?
abstract: This year’s New York City mayor’s race bears a lot of resemblance to the one 36 years ago, when Ed Koch, a little-known liberal, emerged to win the election.
lead_paragraph: It’s not just the psychiatrists and talk-show hosts. Political scientists are also watching Anthony Weiner’s downward spiral and shaking their heads, searching for analogs in the annals of N.Y.C. politics. But throughout the months I tracked this year’s race for City Hall, one historical parallel did keep cropping up: It’s ’77, all over again.

headline: Calming Words From a Vineyard’s Unlikely New Owner
abstract: With Charles Banks taking over, fans of Mayacamas Vineyards are feeling anxious.
lead_paragraph: YOUNTVILLE, Calif. — Lovers of Mayacamas Vineyards, the legendary purveyor of classically structured, age-worthy Napa Valley cabernet sauvignon, can be forgiven for shuddering when they learned in April that the longtime proprietors had sold it to Charles Banks, who at one time was an owner of Screaming Eagle, the cult cabernet that seems in so many ways the antithesis of Mayacamas.

headline: Homeownership: Where Single Women Prevail
abstract: Single women are buying homes at roughly twice the rate of single men.
lead_paragraph: The number of single people buying homes has dipped in the last few years, but single women remain better represented among buyers than single men. Today they are buying at roughly twice the rate.

headline: When Reality Triumphed Over Transcendence
abstract: “Winslow Homer: Making Art, Making History,” is really two narratives: that of Homer’s artistry, and the story of two people who collected his art, Sterling and Francine Clark.
lead_paragraph: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass. — Winslow Homer was America’s first great post-God landscape painter. Before the Civil War, successful artists like Frederic Church and Asher B. Durand made pictures of New World vistas bathed in transcendental light. Theirs was an art of religious theater. In that art, Nature was a colossal, purposeful moral consciousness; the human presence, if visible at all, an awe-struck speck.

headline: Finally, the A.T.F. Has a Permanent Director
abstract: What can he do to better enforce the nation’s gun laws?
lead_paragraph: It took seven long years and a tense last-minute drama replete with arm-twisting, vote-changing, a not very subtle Democratic threat to revisit filibuster-reform, and a cross-country race back to Washington by the final “yes” vote needed to reach 60. And who knows how things would have turned out if the National Rifle Association hadn’t decided to stay neutral.

headline: Assembled in Planned Jumbles of Found Creation
abstract: A pair of solo shows at Bard College illuminate different, and similar, perspectives on the ready-made.
lead_paragraph: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. — Exactly 100 years ago, Marcel Duchamp inverted a bicycle wheel, mounted it on a kitchen stool and anointed it as art. It was the first of his revolutionary ready-mades, so it is perhaps with that centenary in mind that the Center for Curatorial Studies at Bard College has come up with two substantial solo shows devoted to artists from different generations whose ties to the ready-made are complex and deep. Together their displays combust into a more than suitable celebration.

headline: Around Town for Aug. 2-8
abstract: A listing of walking tours, speaking engagements, cultural events and more in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: ‘The Fence’ in Brooklyn Bridge Park (through Oct. 1) When is a fence not a fence? When it is the backdrop for a free display of over 200 images of people, animals and daily life by 39 photographers from the United States and abroad. Presented for the second year by United Photo Industries, a Brooklyn arts cooperative, as a showcase for young photographers, the display consists of a 1,000-foot-long waterproof mesh banner superimposed with color and black-and-white photos. Among the shots are images, above, of working people in Hoboken, N.J., by John Delaney.

headline: Archaic to Cubist, He-Men on the March
abstract: “As I Went Out One Morning,” an exhibition at the Storm King Art Center, is devoted to exaggeratedly masculine sculptures by Thomas Houseago.
lead_paragraph: MOUNTAINVILLE, N.Y. — Poor Masculinity, he’s but a shell of his former self. He’s been in decline for a long time — since as far back as the Industrial Revolution, one might say, when people began turning into cogs. Lately, what with the shifts in gender roles and sex, and the moral undoing of so many male heroes, he finds his prerogatives challenged on every front. Since his loss of authority, he’s been acting out in all kinds of inappropriate ways. He needs therapy.

headline: Dick Kazmaier, a Heisman Winner Who Passed on the N.F.L., Dies at 82
abstract: Mr. Kazmaier, a Princeton halfback who won the Heisman in 1951, was drafted by the Bears but declined to join the team, or any other, saying he had achieved all he wanted in the sport.
lead_paragraph: Dick Kazmaier, a Princeton halfback who won the Heisman Trophy in 1951 as the nation’s outstanding college football player, but who rejected a career in the National Football League, saying he had achieved all he wanted in the sport and could make more money in business, died on Thursday in Boston. He was 82.

headline: A Go-Between as Intriguing as the 2 Men He Linked
abstract: “Angels, Demons, and Savages: Pollock, Ossorio, Dubuffet” pivots around the artist and collector Alfonso Ossorio, a go-between Jackson Pollock and Jean Dubuffet, who is fascinating in his own right.
lead_paragraph: WATER MILL, N.Y. — This summer, the Parrish Art Museum is hosting an all-too-rare meeting of Ab-Ex and Art Brut, one that sweeps away myths surrounding both movements and their central figures, Jackson Pollock and Jean Dubuffet, who never met but interacted through the artist and collector Alfonso Ossorio.

headline: All the Rage | An Ancient Japanese Hand-Dyeing Technique Makes a Comeback
abstract: Shibori, a craft technique said to have originated in the eighth century, is cropping up in a variety of clothes and home accessories.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps in response to the ubiquity of digital prints, hand-dyeing techniques have been regaining popularity, and none more so than shibori. It’s the Japanese answer to tie-dye, but a whole lot older — it’s said to date to the eighth century. The pattern is created by folding or twisting fabric, wrapping it around a pole or stitching it. The results are patterns that are once geometric and organic.

headline: High-Rises to Replace an East Side Eyesore
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Two high-rises are planned for an East Side site that has been vacant for years.
lead_paragraph: Countless New Yorkers have driven by the construction rubble that lines the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive from East 35th Street to East 41st. The eyesore has lingered there for more than a dozen years, the target of virulent community opposition, fraught City Council hearings and a lengthy approval process.

headline: Flares in Canada at the Thought of Verizon
abstract: Prominent ads have appeared across the country over the last few weeks denouncing any possible incursion by Verizon.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — While it remains far from certain that Verizon will enter the Canadian wireless market, just the idea has set off a near panic in Canada’s wireless industry.

headline: A Bit of Background Helps Frame Melodies
abstract: Jean-Efflam Bavouzet used stories and demonstrations to illustrate Debussy’s “Préludes” Book II on Wednesday at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: Musicians sometimes introduce the works on their programs, a welcome evolution in the concert format and one that adds an appealing element of intimacy. The superb pianist Jean-Efflam Bavouzet took a more unusual approach when, after beginning Debussy’s “Préludes” Book II at the Kaplan Penthouse on Wednesday evening, he stopped abruptly a few notes into “Puerta del Vino” and began an energetic discourse on Debussy’s aesthetic.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Smelly Texts, and Can Marissa Mayer Save Yahoo?
abstract: The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for important and peculiar items. Thursday’s selections include a story about a Japanese company that developed a way for phones to release scents based on certain actions and a long profile of Marissa Mayer a bit more than a year after she took over as Yahoo’s chief executive.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Sony Hires Rothman to Head Revived TriStar Unit
abstract: Tom Rothman, previously the chairman and chief executive of Fox  Filmed Entertainment, will head a venture at Sony that expects to make four films a year.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In a surprise move, Sony’s American-based film company said it would revive its semi-dormant TriStar unit as a movie and television joint venture in partnership with Thomas E. Rothman, who this year stepped down as chairman and chief executive of Fox Filmed Entertainment.

headline: This Week's Movies: Aug. 2, 2013
abstract: The New York Times movie critic Manohla Dargis on "2 Guns," "The Canyons" and "Our Children."
lead_paragraph: The New York Times movie critic Manohla Dargis on "2 Guns," "The Canyons" and "Our Children."

headline: Korean Fast Food, as Spicy as You Like It
abstract: So Gong Dong Tofu’s small menu spins variations on three basic entrees: soondubu jjigae, a tofu stew; bibimbap, sautéed vegetables and meat over rice; and barbecue.
lead_paragraph: Since opening three months ago, So Gong Dong Tofu has attracted an appreciative, mostly Korean-American clientele to a new breed of fast food, in boldly flavored, chili-sparked style.

headline: Inside the House of Captivity
abstract: Prosecutors on Thursday used a model of Ariel Castro’s house to illustrate how he held three women captive for 10 years.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors on Thursday used a model of Ariel Castro’s house to illustrate how he held three women captive for 10 years.

headline: A Redesign of the Subway Map, From One of Its Designers
abstract: John Tauranac, who led the committee that designed the map in 1979 that is the basis for the M.T.A.’s current map, said he is trying to correct “problems” dating back 40 years.
lead_paragraph: John Tauranac’s description of his new subway map mentions symbols like a little orange disc for outdoor stations, and a “no U-turn” icon that might be helpful if you overshoot a station and wonder whether you will have to pay another fare when you switch to a train heading back the opposite way.

headline: TransCanada Plans Pipeline to East Coast
abstract: The $12 billion pipeline could move as many as 1.1 million barrels a day to New Brunswick, to serve a region that relies on imported crude oil for most of its supply.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Faced with uncertainty over its proposed Keystone XL pipeline, which would link Canada’s oil sands with the American Gulf Coast, TransCanada said on Thursday that it would build a pipeline to eastern Canada.

headline: Denzel Washington and Diahann Carroll to Star in ‘A Raisin in the Sun’ on Broadway

headline: A Port, or Pub, in the Storm

lead_paragraph: On a balmy July evening, Main Street in Sag Harbor churned with a weekend crowd of locals, tourists and boating types who roamed the sidewalks, peering into the windows of packed restaurants. Feeling a little smug about our reservations, we breezed past a cluster of people waiting at the entrance to the Cuddy, which occupies a charming storefront in the heart of the village. With its rough-hewed interior softened by candlelight and a menu that leans toward hearty gastro-pub fare, it offered an appealing haven from all the activity outside.

headline: Iraq: 1,057 Killed in July, U.N. Says
abstract: The United Nations said July was Iraq’s deadliest month in more than five years, describing a series of bombings and shootings as an epidemic of sectarian-tinged violence.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations said Thursday that July was Iraq’s deadliest month in more than five years, describing a series of bombings and shootings as an epidemic of sectarian-tinged violence that had killed 1,057 Iraqis and wounded 2,326. The organization’s acting special representative for Iraq, Gyorgy Busztin, said in a statement that the severity of the mayhem was the worst since 2008, when Iraq verged on civil war after the American-led invasion that toppled Saddam Hussein and his Sunni minority from power. Many of the attacks in July were aimed at members of the Shiite majority that has dominated Iraq’s politics since the withdrawal of the American military at the end of 2011.

headline: A Household Grows, and Life Becomes Unbearable
abstract: As the size of a family grows in Joachim Lafosse’s film “Our Children,” stress rises to a dangerous level.
lead_paragraph: At once beautifully realized and brutally uncompromising, “Our Children” opens with a young woman weeping. She’s a lovely young thing, her features almost obscured by the grayness of her skin, the puffiness around her eyes and the oxygen tubes threaded into her nose. “You’ll bury them in Morocco,” she says to someone hovering nearby and then, as her tears begin to fall, she repeats her appeal. The intensity of the plea is a tug at the heart, a tug that turns into a jolt with a blunt cut to four little coffins being loaded on a plane.

headline: Sentencing Reform Starts to Pay Off
keywords: ['Cocaine and Crack Cocaine', 'Mandatory Sentencing', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Editorials']
abstract: The Fair Sentencing Act has had many benefits, including reducing the disparity in the way courts punished crack cocaine offenses versus powder.
lead_paragraph: In 2010, Congress passed the Fair Sentencing Act, which reduced the vast disparity in the way the federal courts punish crack versus powder cocaine offenses. Instead of treating 100 grams of cocaine the same as 1 gram of crack for sentencing purposes, the law cut the ratio to 18 to 1. Initially, the law applied only to future offenders, but, a year later, the United States Sentencing Commission voted to apply it retroactively. Republicans raged, charging that crime would go up and that prisoners would overwhelm the courts with frivolous demands for sentence reductions. Senator Charles Grassley of Iowa said the commission was pursuing “a liberal agenda at all costs.”

headline: The Slow Motion Inquiry Into Sandy Hook

lead_paragraph: Connecticut officials continue to keep the public in the dark about the state’s official investigation into the shooting massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary School in December, even as state and local police have been discussing it at forums across the nation, sometimes in graphic detail. Though the fullest possible report was promised after the tragedy, its release has been repeatedly postponed, with authorities advising patience while the public grows increasingly puzzled.

headline: Mr. Obama Moves on Chemical Plant Safety

abstract: Environmental regulators must adopt strong rules to reduce the risk of accidents and spills.
lead_paragraph: President Obama took an important step toward making America’s chemical plants safer on Thursday by directing federal agencies to update regulations, coordinate policies and share information with one another and state and local governments. If followed up by strong rules, his order could go a long way toward protecting millions of Americans who live near chemical plants from disasters like the explosion at a Texas fertilizer plant in April that killed 15 people. Across the country, more than 2,500 facilities produce, use or store toxic chemicals that put more than 10,000 people at risk.

lead_paragraph: A suspect in two assaults was charged on Thursday with the murder of Amy E. Lord, a 24-year-old South Boston woman found dead last week. The authorities said Ms. Lord was abducted near her apartment on July 23, forced to withdraw money from five nearby A.T.M.’s, and stabbed to death in a nature reservation in the city’s Hyde Park neighborhood. The suspect, Edwin J. Alemany, 28, was arrested July 24 and charged in connection with two nonfatal attacks around the same time. The authorities said he was linked to Ms. Lord’s murder by forensic and surveillance evidence. Mr. Alemany will be arraigned after a mental health evaluation.

headline: T.M.B. (Too Much Baby)

But when this happens every day from a specific acquaintance, is it a violation of the baby’s privacy? abstract: France’s award of merit is increasingly being given out like jujubes, causing some of the French to look down their noses at it. Americans, however, seem to love it.

abstract: Some adventurous buyers are mining the commercial market for residential space.
lead_paragraph: Looking for a way to sidestep the frenzied open houses and excruciating bidding wars that have become prevalent these days when buying a New York City apartment? Shop commercial.

headline: U.S. Envoy and Putin Aide Discuss Snowden
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: There were signs that the United States and Russia might try to contain the fallout over Russia’s decision to grant temporary asylum to Edward J. Snowden, the fugitive intelligence analyst.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Edward J. Snowden, the fugitive intelligence analyst, settled into a secluded, uncertain self-exile here on Friday amid signs that the United States and Russia might try to contain the diplomatic fallout over Russia’s decision to grant him temporary asylum.

headline: Fantasy Football: Spotting Undervalued Running Backs
abstract: Finding value at running back in the middle rounds of drafts could be the key to fantasy football success in 2013.
lead_paragraph: Running backs are being targeted early this season in the world of fantasy football with owners scrambling to gobble up two top runners in the first couple rounds of drafts. It seems like a sound strategy given that true workhorse running backs are becoming a scarce resource. As is the case in any marketplace, scarce commodities are valuable.

lead_paragraph: A colonial in Westchester and a contemporary home in Fairfield, each with six bedrooms and a pool.

headline: Court Rulings Blur the Line Between a Spy and a Leaker
keywords: ['First Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Pentagon Papers', 'Treason', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Disclosures made possible by digital media, government surveillance and unorthodox publishers have unsettled understandings of mass media’s place in American democracy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The federal government is prosecuting leakers at a brisk clip and on novel theories. It is collecting information from and about journalists, calling one a criminal and threatening another with jail. In its failed effort to persuade Russia to return another leaker, Edward J. Snowden, it felt compelled to say that he would not be tortured or executed.

headline: Liquidator to Sell $29 Billion in Anglo Irish Loans
abstract: The loan portfolio consists mostly of commercial real estate loans in Ireland and Britain but also includes residential mortgage loans in those countries as well as Irish corporate loans.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The nationalized Irish lender Anglo Irish Bank plans to sell $29 billion worth of loans as part of its liquidation, the bank’s special liquidator said on Friday.

headline: Big Ticket | A Floor With a Key to a Park for $15.175 Million
abstract: A floor-through residence with 4,207 square feet of space and 40 feet of frontage on Gramercy Park was the most expensive residential sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: The princely proportions of a floor-through residence at the repurposed 18 Gramercy Park South — previously a Salvation Army housing depot for as many as 300 women but now a sought-after destination with just 16 luxury condominiums — attracted a buyer with $15,175,000 to spend and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: The Tyranny of the Minority
abstract: A small change to Israel’s electoral rules may transform its political life.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — This week, the Knesset approved several changes to Israel’s election laws, including an increase, from 2 percent to 4 percent, in the minimum share of votes needed to get into Parliament. More debates and more voting are required before this decision becomes law, but it already shows that after many years of talking a lot and doing a little to reform the electoral system, change finally is afoot.

headline: Go East, Old Man: Duel in South Dakota
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Bison', 'Camps and Camping', 'Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters']
abstract: Through Yellowstone and on to South Dakota, a tiny Honda-riding Dexter Ford makes his way into the Harley haven of Sturgis, S.D.
lead_paragraph: Dexter Ford is traveling from Southern California to upstate New York along mostly obscure roads, on a motorcycle that, by American standards, is quite tiny. This is the third of his occasional reports from the paths less traveled.

headline: Ellen DeGeneres to Host Next Year’s Oscars
abstract: The show’s producers chose a popular television star to follow Seth MacFarlane, who received some harsh reviews.
lead_paragraph: Reaching back to television for a comedy star, the producers of the Academy Awards telecast announced Friday that Ellen DeGeneres would return next year to host the annual Oscar ceremony.

headline: Skyrocketing Numbers of Federal Workers on Forced Leave
keywords: ['Government Employees', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Working Hours']
abstract: This number of “involuntary part-timers” in the federal government jumped in July, to 199,000, nearly four times the number in recent years.
lead_paragraph: The latest jobs report showed that federal workers didn’t lose jobs in July, leading to some suggestions that the sequester hasn’t affected government employment. But the overall federal government jobs total doesn’t capture furloughs — that is, forced unpaid leave — because people who are being furloughed for say, one day a week, are technically still counted as being employed.

headline: Puzzling Weakness in Construction Work
abstract: There has been no net growth in construction employment since March, after picking up over the winter.
lead_paragraph: With the economy having added 162,000 jobs in July, it’s clear the pace of job creation has slowed. Before the report, the average monthly gain for 2013 was 202,000 jobs.

headline: What to Do When a Friend Pitches an Investment Idea
abstract: The decision to decline or invest requires an analysis of the offer and the person making it, and an assessment of the pain of losing a friend if the investment turns sour.
lead_paragraph: THE first question Elliot M. Liss asks when a friend walks up with an investment offer is, “Why me?”

headline: Getting Through the Dogged Days of Baseball
abstract: Waiting for the Biogenesis suspensions shoe to drop is the hardest part.
lead_paragraph: It is possible, with some avoidance strategies, to pretend baseball is still just a nice little summer sport. Granted, you have to squint kind of hard, avoid sports talk radio, avert your eyes every time you see the first few letters of Alex Rodriguez’s name and flee to a happy place every time friends start discussing why everyone is still discussing steroids. It’s tempting to do all, and glue some blinders on a pair of rose-colored glasses, after enduring a week of waiting for the Biogenesis suspensions shoe to drop

headline: The Week in Pictures, Aug. 2
abstract: A look back at the week’s events in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: A look back at the week’s events in New York City and the region.

headline: State Department Issues Global Travel Alert
abstract: The alert warned American citizens abroad of the potential for terrorist attacks, particularly in the Middle East and North Africa.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States issued a global travel alert to American citizens on Friday, warning of the potential for terrorist attacks, particularly in the Middle East and North Africa, carried out by operatives of Al Qaeda and their associates.

headline: Financial Sector Continues a Rebound
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The financial sector, hard hit in the financial crisis, continued a comeback in July, adding 15,000 jobs, including 6,000 in the securities industry.
lead_paragraph: The booming stock market isn’t just evident from brokerage statements and 401(k) updates.

headline: The Best Little Literary Paddle in Texas
abstract: A paddle as a literary relic? Yes, the one used by the writer John Graves, who died on Wednesday. It’s from a trip he made famous in “Goodbye to a River.”
lead_paragraph: John Graves, an author revered in Texas but relatively unknown beyond the borders of the state, died on Wednesday at 92. The New York Times obituary discusses his best-known work, “Goodbye to a River,” published in 1960. That book tells the story of a three-week trip down the Brazos River, from just below Possum Kingdom Lake to a spot near the town of Glen Rose, near where Mr. Graves built his home, which he called Hard Scrabble.

headline: New U.S. Policy Gives Equal Treatment to Same-Sex Spouses’ Visa Applications
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Visas', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: The secretary of state said the change, which takes effect immediately, is the result of a review after the Supreme Court’s decision on the Defense of Marriage Act.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The United States will treat the visa applications of same-sex married couples in the same manner as opposite-sex spouses, Secretary of State John Kerry said Friday, announcing a policy change set in motion in June, after the Supreme Court struck down a law against same-sex marriage.

headline: Gazpachos Minus the Bread
abstract: The unique texture of classic gazpacho comes from bread, but in these five varieties, you won’t miss it.
lead_paragraph: For years I insisted that gazpacho can’t be gazpacho if it doesn’t have bread as one of its ingredients. After all, bread is what gives classic gazpacho its unique texture. But this week I decided to forget about the bread and focus in on the combination of tomatoes, vinegar, olive oil, onion and garlic that is really behind the signature flavor of gazpacho. The new Spanish chefs have been reinterpreting this lively, low-calorie soup for over a decade now, so I felt free to experiment, too.

headline: Forwarding Multiple Messages in Outlook
abstract: Tips for Microsoft Outlook and using Java on Firefox.
lead_paragraph: Q. Instead of forwarding messages one by one in Outlook 2010, is there a way to send a bunch of separate e-mail messages as one big message?

headline: In Mongolia, the Skyline by the Steppes
abstract: Ulan Bator, the capital, is booming, offering tourists a crowded and charismatic entry point to the world’s least densely populated country.
lead_paragraph: In September the hills around Ulan Bator, the rough and roiling capital of Mongolia, are flecked with wildflowers. Below them, districts of gers, or yurts, encircle the city. The circular canvas structures, insulated with felt and supported by poles, have housed central Asian nomads since before the time of Genghis Khan — before there even was a Mongolia. Now, half of the nation’s population lives permanently in or near the capital. Look beyond the gers, to where the offices and condominiums rise, and you’ll see why: Ulan Bator is booming. Construction cranes spike the sky. Traffic — Hummers and Lexuses, jacked-up jalopies and crammed city buses — churns. It’s impossible to ignore the economic surge that copper, gold and coal mining have brought to the city in recent years.

headline: Chipotle Gazpacho
abstract: Chipotle contributes heat and smoke to this beautiful blender gazpacho.
lead_paragraph: I love the smoky heat of chipotles in this gazpacho. Cucumber and avocado are garnishes that are both cooling and soothing.

abstract: This week, Paul Rudnick talks about David Rakoff’s final book; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Juan Gabriel Vásquez discusses his new novel, “The Sound of Things Falling”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Paul Rudnick talks about David Rakoff’s final book; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Juan Gabriel Vásquez discusses his new novel, “The Sound of Things Falling”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
