abstract: This week, Paul Rudnick talks about David Rakoff’s final book and Juan Gabriel Vásquez discusses his new novel.
lead_paragraph: This week, Paul Rudnick talks about David Rakoff’s final book and Juan Gabriel Vásquez discusses his new novel.

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in Latrobe, Pa.; Germany; Italy
abstract: A weekly capsule of events around the globe curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Great American Banana Split Celebration, Latrobe, Pa. Latrobe, a small city 40 miles southeast of Pittsburgh that considers itself the birthplace of the banana split, will host a weekend celebration from Aug. 23 to 25 for the 109th anniversary of the famous triple-scoop dessert. In 1904, David Strickler, then a 23-year-old apprentice pharmacist at what became Strickler’s Drug Store, above, invented the sundae, which quickly became popular with students of nearby St. Vincent College, according to organizers of the Great American Banana Split Celebration. The three-day event will feature tastings, a banana-themed multimedia art show and street fair, era-themed events like a car rally and sock hop, and, of course, a do-it-yourself banana split bar. Most activities are free.

headline: Feeling For | An Old-School Hotel in the Berkshires That’s Perfect for Just Staying Put
abstract: When what you’re looking for in a weekend getaway is rustic comfort rather than stimulation and adventure, you can’t do better than the Wheatleigh Hotel in Lenox, Mass.
lead_paragraph: Sure, it’s fun to traverse a city in 36 hours or explore some far-flung land over a luxurious two weeks. But when it comes to vacations, sometimes it’s nice to just pick a spot and stay put. If that’s what you’re in the mood for, the Wheatleigh Hotel, in Lenox, Mass. is the place for you. It’s not new, or of the moment, or even remotely cool, and that’s exactly the point.

headline: Jobs Recovery in Europe Is Also Painfully Slow
abstract: The number of unemployed workers in the euro zone dropped in June, but by only 24,000 jobs, or 0.1 percent of the 19.3 million people out of work in May.
lead_paragraph: THE number of unemployed workers in the euro zone fell in June, the European Union’s statistical agency estimated this week.

headline: The Whistle-Blower’s Quandary
abstract: People who value fairness more than loyalty express greater willingness to blow the whistle.
lead_paragraph: IMAGINE you’re thinking about blowing the whistle on your employer. As the impassioned responses to the actions of whistle-blowers like Edward J. Snowden have reminded us, you face a moral quandary: Is reporting misdeeds an act of heroism or betrayal?

headline: Oregon Embraces ‘University of Nike’ Image
abstract: The University of Oregon’s Football Performance Center, paid for by Phil Knight, a founder of Nike, is luxurious enough to make N.F.L. teams envious.
lead_paragraph: EUGENE, Ore. — The Football Performance Center at the University of Oregon features rugs woven by hand in Nepal, couches made in Italy and Brazilian hardwood underfoot in the weight room that is so dense, designers of this opulent palace believe it will not burn.

headline: So Far, So Good
abstract: Some notable people at The Times share their favorite reading experience of the year.
lead_paragraph: With the year more than half over and sweltering weather encouraging us to stay inside and read, I asked some notable people at The Times for their favorite book (so far) of 2013. Unsurprisingly, some busy respondents are still catching up on 2012. Mark Thompson, C.E.O. of The New York Times Company, cited Robert Macfarlane’s perambulating travel book “The Old Ways.” Thompson praised it for “rooting the immediate felt experience of walking through a landscape in the deep context of culture and history. I’m an inveterate walker myself — now, thanks to Macfarlane, I know why I do it.”

headline: One Book In . . .
abstract: A 20-year search for a beloved children’s story.
lead_paragraph: Last year in the pages of the Book Review, Drew Gilpin Faust described her elation at finding her favorite childhood book in a rare-book store in London, after she had searched for it for decades. In the old days, devotion to such a quest would often fail, filed in a card catalog under “Unrequited Love.” But just as the Internet reunites old lovers, so too can it reunite readers with other fugitive objects of love, like the books of childhood, usually with happier outcomes. The Internet’s shared secrets, though, may also keep some grails tantalizingly out of reach, even as they are in sight.

headline: . . . One Book Out
abstract: Culling overcrowded shelves is never easy.
lead_paragraph: I’ve decided that books are my enemy, though they used to be my great love. They are taking over. They crowd my dining room, they double up in the bedroom, they make the attic floor sag. We even have a library in the bathroom: shelves and shelves of books where a normal person might have a vanity table or piles of towels.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Shirley Jones’s tell-all memoir, at No. 9 on the hardcover nonfiction list, makes clear that her off-screen life has been anything but prim.
lead_paragraph: COME ON GET HAPPY: The singer and actress Shirley Jones is best known for playing young innocents (Laurey in “Oklahoma!”), reserved prigs (Marian the librarian in “The Music Man”) and wholesome matriarchs (Shirley Partridge in “The Partridge Family”).

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE CASUAL VACANCY,  by J. K. Rowling. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $18.) Rowling’s first post-“Harry Potter” novel, a dissection of middle-class life in an outwardly idyllic English town, displays her keen powers of observation. After the sudden death of a parish councilor, a vicious political battle erupts over plans to redraw municipal boundaries and possibly shunt a nearby housing project to a different district.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THOSE ANGRY DAYS: Roosevelt, Lindbergh, and America’s Fight Over World War II, 1939-1941,  by Lynne Olson. (Random House, $30.) The savage political dispute between Roosevelt and the isolationist movement, presented in spellbinding detail.

headline: The Age Equation in Employment Numbers
keywords: ['Age, Chronological', 'Baby Boomers', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Some of the decline in the unemployment rate may be attributable to baby boomers’ reaching the end of their working years. But the picture remains weak for those in their prime.
lead_paragraph: The rosiest take on the jobs report is that the aging of the country’s population has made the employment statistics look worse than they really are.

headline: ‘Our Kind of People’
abstract: Louis Begley’s novel unfolds in the midst of high-WASP society.
lead_paragraph: In his engrossing novel “Memories of a Marriage,” Louis Begley gives us a chance to see into two different, often obscured worlds. One is the most private recesses of another couple’s marriage. The other is high-WASP society — though most people don’t usually even know where that particular unmarked door is, let alone get a chance to have it quietly shut in their faces.

headline: Every Cheese Has a Story
abstract: Michael Paterniti seeks out a ruined cheesemaker in a remote Spanish village.
lead_paragraph: You know those floridly descriptive little signs you find pinned into wedges of aging fromage at your local upmarket cheese shop? Those ­index-card vignettes that tell you Cheese A is made from the milk of black-­snouted Iberian sheep that merrily feed on yarrow and camomile, and Cheese B is dense, ornery and challenging, not unlike fusion-era Miles Davis?

headline: How Soon It May Be Too Late
abstract: Mathew Brady grew his business by making portraits of soldiers heading for the Civil War.
lead_paragraph: Death was early American photography’s killer app. Since the first pictures required long exposures, it was convenient to have a subject that held still. There was a psychological angle as well. A 19th-­century photographer reported that when he visited a town in upstate New York, all the residents welcomed him except the blacksmith, who at first reviled him as a swindler. But then the blacksmith’s son drowned — and the blacksmith came begging for an image of the boy.

headline: New Statesman
abstract: Philip Bobbitt examines “The Prince” and its author.
lead_paragraph: One expects a book by Philip Bobbitt to be over 900 pages (“The Shield of Achilles,” 2002) or just under 700 pages (“Terror and Consent,” 2008). Then how can he diet himself down to a mere 200 or so pages of text on Machiavelli? Bobbitt is a great systematizer in the Toynbee mold — “Shield” gave us six different state systems since 1500 (princely, kingly, territorial, imperial, national, ­market).

headline: Glory Days
abstract: In Ron Carlson’s novel, the members of a 1960s garage band reunite after 30 years.
lead_paragraph: The boys from Life on Earth — the garage band that rocked Oakpine High on homecoming night, 1969 — are back. They scattered in a hurry all those years ago, on an afternoon in June, after a run of “great” performances (admittedly, standards were low: they knew fewer than 10 songs). Thirty years later they’ve reassembled in Oakpine, Wyo., the fictional setting of Ron Carlson’s fifth novel, “Return to Oakpine.” Their hometown is sweetly, stubbornly sunk for all time in the “Leave It to Beaver” 1950s. Even in ’69 there was no hint of peace songs or race riots or long hair on the men. In ’99 the town seems to know little of manufactured drugs, the tech boom or Y2K. During high school football home games, Oakpine is “as deserted as a town in a movie about the end of the world, not a noise except for the train every two hours.”

headline: Inner Sins
abstract: A story collection charts the overlooked career of James Purdy.
lead_paragraph: James Purdy, who died in 2009, was so often declared an under­appreciated American genius on the basis of his first few novels that it is easy to forget about the later decades of his writing, which were often appreciated not at all. While the early stuff continued to attract admirers (including Jonathan Franzen, who called Purdy’s 1967 novel “Eustace Chisholm and the Works” “so good that almost any novel you read immediately after it will seem at least a little bit posturing, or dishonest, or self-­admiring”), he drew diminishing interest both from American publishers, who took on his later books only after they were published overseas, and from reviewers, who often ignored them entirely.

headline: Signs of Protest
abstract: Two Chinese dissidents explore the endurance of the human spirit in the face of state-sanctioned cruelty.
lead_paragraph: In exploring the darker aspects of Chinese life, Ma Jian and Liao Yiwu speak mostly to the outside world. The work of both writers has been banned in China, and neither lives in his native land. Ma Jian is a longtime resident of London. Liao crossed the border into Vietnam in 2011 and fled to Berlin, where he remains today.

headline: Rise and Fall
abstract: The history of empires as a record of political-economic blunders.
lead_paragraph: Of all the proponents of human agency against the constraints of geography, culture and historical experience, economists are the most incisive. They obey scientific rigor rather than mere civilizational tendencies. And while the laws of economics yield a determinism all their own, adherence to such laws and the limits they impose, Glenn Hubbard and Tim Kane suggest, will allow any state or people to avoid tragic outcomes, regardless of geographical or other limitations.

headline: Lush Life
abstract: Adam Fitzgerald’s debut collection encompasses everything from John Locke to “Buffy the Vampire Slayer.”
lead_paragraph: My heart aches, and a drowsy numbness pains my sense as the poet finishes his reading, but before I can reach for the hemlock, the older gentleman next to me says, “Is there a book that’ll help me understand this kind of poetry?” The poet had gone on for close to an hour, reading poems that were without charm, music, meaning — without people, really, since nothing in them seemed to come from or speak to our common humanity. I have taught and written about poetry for decades; if I was stunned, what chance had the older gentleman, a retired cleric who is a regular at this weekly series, a well-read and earnest listener who wanted so much to like poems that didn’t care at all for him? There’s no book that’ll help you, I told him. It’s not your fault. It’s the poems’ fault. And the poet’s. The ­poems are bad, and he shouldn’t have read them.

headline: Fiction Chronicle
abstract: New books by Kate Worsley, Elizabeth Kelly, Bill Cheng and Kent Wascom.
lead_paragraph: SHE RISES  By Kate Worsley  Bloomsbury, $26.

headline: Bring Up the Bodies
abstract: In John Dufresne’s “No Regrets, Coyote,” a crime-solving therapist investigates what appears to be a case of parental murder-suicide.
lead_paragraph: ’Tis the night before Christmas and all through the house not a creature is stirring in John Dufresne’s ghoulishly funny crime novel, NO REGRETS, COYOTE (Norton, $25.95). That’s because everyone in the Halliday house — father, mother and three little kiddies in pajamas — is dead, shot in what appears to be a case of parental murder-suicide. But Wylie (Coyote) Melville, a therapist who serves as a “volunteer forensic consultant” for the Everglades County Police Department, doesn’t buy that explanation. Although he’s only acting on intuition, Wylie has proved to be a gifted mind reader (“I just look, I stare, I gaze, and I pay attention to what I see,” he modestly explains), so people tend to put stock in his hunches.

headline: Newly Discovered Early Pavarotti Recording Will Be Released
abstract: The 1961 recording of “Che Gelida Manina” from “La Bohème,” was discovered by the tenor’s widow, Nicoletta Mantovani.
lead_paragraph: A recently discovered recording by Luciano Pavarotti from a 1961 performance at the Reggio Emilia Theater, in Italy, will have its first release in October, when Decca Records includes it on a new compilation of Pavarotti favorites. The company is releasing the set to commemorate the 50th anniversary of his British television debut on on “Sunday Night at the London Palladium,” a popular weekly variety show, as well as his Covent Garden debut the following month.

headline: The Sweet Spot: A Dark and Scary Craving
abstract: In this week’s episode, David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about the sociopathic characters on television we love to hate and love to love. Nice, huh?
lead_paragraph: In this week’s episode, David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about the sociopathic characters on television we love to hate and love to love. Nice, huh?

headline: The Sweetness of Time Off
abstract: A growing body of evidence suggests that vacation time fuels greater productivity and more sustainable performance, the author writes. The key is to choose something truly renewing.
lead_paragraph: The last several months have been, in many ways, the richest, most exciting and most creative period of my life. Still, as I prepare to take off most of the month of August, I’m feeling edgy, worn out and a bit overwhelmed.

headline: 30 Seconds With Matthew Berry
abstract: Before fantasy sports was a multibillion-dollar industry, Matthew Berry was finding his voice as the Talented Mr. Roto. Now he’s a leading voice as ESPN’s senior fantasy sports analyst.
lead_paragraph: Before fantasy sports was a multibillion-dollar industry, Matthew Berry was finding his voice as the Talented Mr. Roto. He wrote about his stat-driven obsessions for several fledging fantasy sports Web sites at the turn of the millennium, including his own starting in 2004.

headline: The Sweet Spot: A Dark and Scary Craving
abstract: David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about the sociopathic characters on television we love to hate and love to love.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s episode, David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about the sociopathic characters on television we love to hate and love to love. Nice, huh?

headline: House Votes to Bar I.R.S. Action on Health Law
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Government Employees']
abstract: The bill passed by the House, which has now voted about 40 times to repeal or roll back the 2010 health care law, has virtually no chance of approval in the Senate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In its last action before a five-week summer recess, the House took another jab at President Obama’s health care law on Friday, voting to prohibit the Internal Revenue Service from enforcing or carrying out any provision of the law.

headline: What I Love | Colin and Eric Jacobsen
abstract: Brothers and members of Brooklyn Rider, a string quartet, at home in Windsor Terrace.
lead_paragraph: Brothers and members of Brooklyn Rider, a string quartet, at home in Windsor Terrace.

headline: Music to the Rafters in Windsor Terrace
abstract: The brothers Colin and Eric Jacobsen, of the string quartet Brooklyn Rider, share a house in Windsor Terrace.
lead_paragraph: The Jacobsen brothers, Colin and Eric, are half the string quartet Brooklyn Rider. They’re also half the quartet occupying a three-story brick house in Brooklyn. They bought it almost two years ago for reasons they eagerly enumerate: the bones and the vibe were good, the ceilings were tall, the subway was right at the end of the block. Oh, and it scored high on the Vondelstraat and gezellig scales (more about this in a second).

headline: Who Abandoned the Health Insurance Credit
keywords: ['Federal Taxes (US)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Presidential Election of 2008', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: It wasn’t Congressional Republicans who moved the health care debate away from a proposal to extend coverage through a tax credit, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Phillip Swagel is a professor at the School of Public Policy at the University of Maryland and was assistant secretary for economic policy at the Treasury Department from 2006 to 2009.

headline: From North Korea With Love: A Tablet With No Internet Access
abstract: A tourist bought a North Korean tablet computing device and found it similar to other tablets, except for a lack of real Internet access. But it has “Angry Birds.”
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The Samjiyon tablet computer, it is safe to say, is no threat to the iPad.

headline: A Century in Their Shells
abstract: If you see a box turtle in New York, don’t pick it up and help it on its way; it probably already knows where it’s going.
lead_paragraph: A fortunate Eastern box turtle (Terrapene carolina carolina) can lead a very long life, very slowly. Records of individual turtles living well past 100 are not uncommon. One such creature was caught and marked on Martha’s Vineyard in 1861, and recaptured several times through 2006. It was a hatchling before the Civil War.

headline: British Plan on Taxing Gambling Annoys Many in Gibraltar
abstract: Territory officials are crying foul over Prime Minister David Cameron’s plan to impose a 15 percent tax on residents of Britain who place bets on any of Gibraltar’s Internet gambling sites.
lead_paragraph: GIBRALTAR — Gibraltar, the British territory at the tip of the Iberian Peninsula, has long been a political sore point between Britain and Spain. But now, in an Internet gambling dispute, it’s Briton vs. Briton.

headline: Enough to Make an N.F.L. Team Jealous
abstract: The University of Oregon recently unveiled its new, 145,000 square-foot football complex.
lead_paragraph: The University of Oregon recently unveiled its new, 145,000 square-foot football complex.

headline: Like a Nightclub, Only It’s Schubert
abstract: The next Little Night Music programs are coming right up.
lead_paragraph: A Little Night Music is the popular series of late-night concerts presented by the Mostly Mozart Festival in the intimate Kaplan Penthouse. The programs start at 10 p.m. and typically last an hour or less. The penthouse has picture windows with nighttime vistas of the city. Patrons sit at small round tables drinking complimentary wine. Only about 230 people can be accommodated; tickets go fast.

headline: Life Was Idyllic, Then Sis Arrived
abstract: The writer Chad Beguelin is largely known for lighter fare, so his domestic comedy “Harbor” offers a chance to see another side of him.
lead_paragraph: The writer Chad Beguelin is largely known for lighter fare like “The Wedding Singer” (book and lyrics) and “Elf” (lyrics), so his domestic comedy “Harbor” offers a chance to see another side of him. And there were some positive reviews of the play’s premiere at the Westport Country Playhouse last year, directed by Mark Lamos, so this first production of the 2013-14 Primary Stages season is worth a look.

headline: A Zumba Lesson With, Um, Perks
abstract: TLC brings us an instant-history look at a real-life case involving Zumba and prostitution out of Kennebunk, Me.
lead_paragraph: For producers of the kind of quickie docu-shows that certain cable outlets thrive on, seeing “Zumba” and “prostitution” in the same sentence has the feel of Christmas morning. And TLC brings us an instant-history look at a real-life case involving those two things out of Kennebunk, Me., when it broadcasts “Sex, Lies & Zumba” on Tuesday at 10 p.m.

headline: For Yankees, Little Bang for Their Buck
abstract: The Yankees’ highest-paid hitters have produced few hits this season. Compare hits and salaries across the league.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees’ highest-paid hitters have produced few hits this season. Compare hits and salaries across the league.

headline: The Basics and More, but Something’s Missing
abstract: The Nissan Versa Note, a hatchback version of the second-generation Versa, offers comfort, plenty of options and good mileage, but not much fun.
lead_paragraph: The Nissan Versa Note, a hatchback version of the second-generation Versa, offers comfort, plenty of options and good mileage, but not much fun.

headline: Crackling Wit of an Up-and-Comer
abstract: Having left the Mark Morris Dance Group only last year, John Heginbotham probably has a few years to go before we stop comparing him to Mr. Morris.
lead_paragraph: Having left the Mark Morris Dance Group only last year, John Heginbotham probably has a few years to go before we stop comparing him to Mr. Morris. In his 14 years with the company, this dancer turned choreographer clearly inherited some of Mr. Morris’s trademark musicality and wit. These qualities stand out in the repertory of his own troupe, Dance Heginbotham. Since its debut in 2012, critics have also noted a distinctively Heginbothian zaniness. And when was the last time Mr. Morris choreographed to Daft Punk?

headline: Sounds That Bridge Disparate Worlds
abstract: The Modern’s “Soundings” isn’t the only aural art show in town this month.
lead_paragraph: The Modern’s “Soundings” isn’t the only aural art show in town this month. Lisa Cooley, a Lower East Side gallery on the former site of Tonic, the experimental music club, has just opened “The String and the Mirror,” a group exhibition of sonic works by 19 artists. Organized by Justin Luke, director of the gallery Audio Visual Arts, and Lawrence Kumpf, artistic director at Issue Project Room, it includes a few veterans like Marina Rosenfeld and Rolf Julius but mainly focuses on emerging artists.

headline: Speaking Spanish to Win Votes in New York
abstract: Looking to bolster their popularity among Latinos, candidates are preparing advertisements and appearances aimed at Spanish-speaking New Yorkers.
lead_paragraph: Fans of Spanish-language news shows and telenovelas, get ready: The mudslinging and fist-fighting long associated with New York City politics will soon be invading your airwaves.

headline: The Man Who Fell Into Movie Acting
abstract: It’s the rare director who can transform the familiar into something brand new. Nicolas Roeg succeeded handsomely with “The Man Who Fell to Earth.”
lead_paragraph: It’s the rare director who can transform the familiar into something that feels as if it were being seen for the first time. The director Nicolas Roeg succeeded handsomely with “The Man Who Fell to Earth” (1976), part of the retrospective “Watch That Man: David Bowie, Movie Star” at the Walter Reade Theater. In adapting Walter Tevis’s 1963 novel about an extraterrestrial on a secret mission who uses alien technology to become a tycoon on Earth, Mr. Roeg takes Japanese Kabuki, New Mexico landscapes, corporate soullessness and America’s television-saturated culture and has us perceive them as an interstellar out-of-towner might.

headline: A World of Sounds at a D.J. Marathon
abstract: Seeking out raw beats from the world’s street-level sound systems is the knack and mission of Diplo, the producer and disc jockey at the core of Major Lazer
lead_paragraph: Seeking out raw beats from the world’s street-level sound systems is the knack and mission of Diplo, the producer and disc jockey at the core of Major Lazer. For more than a decade, Diplo has culled, adapted and often anthologized an international assortment of beats, from Jamaican dancehall to Brazilian baile funk to Angolan kuduro. Is it exposure, exploitation, networking, diluting, sensationalizing, mongrelizing, trend-surfing, cosmopolitanism? All of the above; it’s D.J. remix culture. Mad Decent is Diplo’s label, and he’s applying the brand to dance-party marathons in 13 cities headlined by Major Lazer, which is rooted in dancehall but hurls all kinds of bass-heavy beats.

headline: Compromise Should Salvage Dell Deal
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Letting the big buyout of the PC maker fade away would have hurt most shareholders, the board and the company’s founder.
lead_paragraph: A flawed compromise on the buyout of Dell Inc. will save faces all around.

headline: Mugabe’s Party Appears Headed for Parliamentary Victory in Zimbabwe
abstract: Early results from the vote, which observers gave a mixed report, showed ZANU-PF, President Robert G. Mugabe’s party, earning a big majority in Parliament. There was no word yet on the presidential race.
lead_paragraph: HARARE, Zimbabwe — The party of Robert G. Mugabe, Zimbabwe’s long-ruling president, appeared to be on track to win a huge majority in Parliament after Wednesday’s election, the Zimbabwe Election Commission announced Friday, allowing it to recapture parliamentary control from its main challenger, the Movement for Democratic Change.

headline: ‘War in the Land of Unculpsalm’
abstract: The forgotten history behind “The New Gospel of Peace,” one of the war’s hottest-selling satires.
lead_paragraph: I was in the book stacks of the Harry Ransom Center at the University of Texas when the title of an otherwise unassuming green volume, “The New Gospel of Peace,” caught my eye. I had been looking for an edition of Abraham Lincoln’s speeches to include in an exhibition tracing the King James Bible’s influence on literature and culture. Like many other major Civil War-era figures — Frederick Douglass, Harriet Beecher Stowe — Lincoln was beholden to the language and style of the King James Bible. But Lincoln would have to wait.

headline: Scores Killed in 2 Days of Clashes Between Afghan Police and Taliban Fighters
abstract: The fighting, in Nangarhar Province, started with the killing of a tribal elder by the Taliban.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Taliban fighters killed 22 Afghan police officers on Thursday in an ambush of their convoy in an eastern province bordering Pakistan, officials said Friday. It was one of the deadliest episodes in a power struggle between insurgents and the government that has intensified as American-led forces prepare to leave Afghanistan after more than a decade of war.

headline: Not Flying Rats, to Him
abstract: William MacLeod once disliked pigeons as much as most New Yorkers — now several of them are his pets, and he has trained them not to soil his suits.
lead_paragraph: William MacLeod says he was always in the “rats with wings” camp regarding New York City pigeons, until one day six years ago in Washington Square Park, where he spied a pair of chicks on the ground. He nurtured them for weeks and released them back into the park.

headline: Songs for the Club, the Faithful and the Economically Oppressed
abstract: New releases are coming from French Montana (“Excuse My French”), Weekend (“Jinx”), New Years Day (“Victim to Villain”), Kim Walker-Smith & Skyler Smith (“Home”).
lead_paragraph: French Montana

headline: East Midtown Rezoning: Still a Bad Idea
abstract: Scott Stringer offered his “conditional approval” of the plan — a disappointment for many New Yorkers.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael Bloomberg’s hurried plan to rezone a large section of midtown Manhattan got a surprising endorsement this week.  Manhattan Borough President Scott Stringer, who has found himself in a heated campaign with former Governor Eliot Spitzer for city Comptroller, offered his “conditional approval” of the proposal.  Mr. Stringer’s backing is advisory, but it will help Mr. Bloomberg and the real estate community in their quest to build new office skyscrapers around Grand Central Terminal.

headline: ‘Still Mine’ Adds to Movies on Aging
abstract: A spate of excellent movies about aging may reflect filmmakers’ dawning recognition of the way this global demographic shift affects all our lives.
lead_paragraph: “She has her good days and her bad days, that’s all,” Craig Morrison, who is in his late 80s, testily tells his son. It’s an intensely self-sufficient man’s warning to back off, a we-don’t-need-anyone’s-help declaration that will sound familiar to many readers here.

headline: Secrets Found Online, Shared Softly
abstract: The composer David Lang based “the whisper opera,” coming to Lincoln Center, on insights and confessions he distilled from the Web.
lead_paragraph: Opera and technology have long had an uneasy relationship. The one has always required the other — from the Baroque spectacle of 17th-century operas, with their deus-ex-machina gimmickry, to the stagecraft required to mount any contemporary production of Wagner’s “Ring” cycle.

headline: A Restless Creature on New Terrain
abstract: The dancer Wendy Whelan prepares for her project “Restless Creature,” which is made up of four dances by contemporary choreographers.
lead_paragraph: After 29 years with one of the world’s most demanding ballet companies, some dancers might start to feel worn out. Wendy Whelan, the New York City Ballet principal, has the opposite problem.

headline: Not for Followers
abstract: Sosh is often described as a concierge service; it picks out restaurants, bars and activities for the discerning New Yorker.
lead_paragraph: The rush of compelling ideas for new smartphone apps has slowed. In 2007, Twitter still seemed pretty revolutionary for the way it bridged the gap between public figures and private ones, between celebrity and anonymity. The most widely used new app these days, at least among my 20-something cohort, is Snapchat. It allows the bored user to send innumerable so-called selfies to any friend unlucky enough to have signed up, with the assurance that all pictures will disappear in the span of 10 seconds.

headline: Lonely Planet’s Plans to Make Up for Job Cuts
abstract: Lonely Planet plans to beef up its user-generated content and video in the wake of a restructuring that will eliminate 70 to 80 jobs.
lead_paragraph: After Lonely Planet announced last month that it was eliminating 70 to 80 positions in a staff of 450, eulogies by travelers who had used its guidebooks flooded Twitter with hashtags like #LPMemories.

headline: After the Doctor and a Prince, He’s a Cop
abstract: The actor David Tennant talks about his role in the BBC America crime drama “Broadchurch” and sometimes wishing he were Larry David.
lead_paragraph: The question at the center of “Broadchurch,” a British crime drama starting Wednesday on BBC America, is who killed a boy found dead on a beach in the picturesque seaside town of the title. Less of a mystery is why it stars David Tennant as Detective Inspector Alec Hardy. Though relatively unknown in the States, this wiry, energetic Scottish actor has long stood out on Britain’s stages and screens. When he starred in the Royal Shakespeare Company’s 2008 production of “Hamlet,” the critic for The Guardian proclaimed, “David Tennant is the greatest Hamlet of his generation.” And, while he is one of 11 actors to have played the titular centuries-old Time Lord on the long-running science-fiction series “Doctor Who,” his portrayal was among the most popular.

headline: The Breakup Album, 9 Months After
abstract: The folk-rock duo the Civil Wars have a new album mirroring the tensions that led to their split. Will the lack of a concert tour hurt sales?
lead_paragraph: A year ago, the folk-rock duo the Civil Wars seemed to be golden. Their 2011 debut album, “Barton Hollow,” had sold a half-million copies without a major label and won them two Grammy Awards. They had toured with Adele and Emmylou Harris and collaborated with Taylor Swift on a hit song. More success seemed certain.

headline: Classics on the Coast
abstract: Some highlights from the more than six decades of the Pebble Beach Concours d’Elegance and surrounding events.
lead_paragraph: Some highlights from the more than six decades of the Pebble Beach Concours d’Elegance and surrounding events.

headline: The Promise of More Than Perfection
abstract: Adding corn and whole spices to Basmati rice, which has a sweet fragrance and delicate texture, makes for a light meal on a sweltering day.
lead_paragraph: Even as a boy growing up in the Midwest, I was interested in food and cooking. Supermarket expeditions to the local A.&P. were entertaining, and so was racing along the aisles astride the shopping cart.

headline: Eagles Receiver Who Used Slur Takes Leave Amid Uproar
abstract: The Eagles did not say when Riley Cooper would return but indicated he would seek counseling to “help him understand how his words have hurt so many.”
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — As a furor escalated over the use of a racial epithet by Eagles receiver Riley Cooper, and Philadelphia’s mayor criticized the team for issuing no punishment beyond a fine, Cooper took an indefinite leave Friday to seek counseling.

headline: Image of the Day: August 2
abstract: Muslims breaking their fast at Jama Masjid, a mosque in Old Delhi.

headline: Celebrating a Bond With Britten
abstract: The tenor and blogger Nicholas Phan talks about Benjamin Britten, making a last-minute New York debut and the risks of social media.
lead_paragraph: Grecchinois, the name of Nicholas Phan’s engaging blog, reflects the Greek and Chinese heritage of this 34-year-old American tenor, who has fast made a name for himself as an expressive interpreter of the British composer Benjamin Britten. Raised Greek Orthodox in Ann Arbor, Mich., Mr. Phan, who initially studied the violin and played in a youth orchestra, discovered Britten when he played his “Young Person’s Guide to the Orchestra.” In college, as a gay man, he became fascinated with the relationship between Britten and the tenor Peter Pears, who lived together at a time when homosexual acts were illegal in Britain. He cites an experience performing Britten in a recital at Truman State University in Kirksville, Mo., around early 2006 as proof that the music, with its “beautiful combination of head and heart,” speaks to audiences everywhere.

headline: Onstage Together at Last
abstract: Two actors bond over the love of the theater and of roller coasters.
lead_paragraph: Everything about Annaleigh Ashford, a 28-year-old actress currently starring in “Kinky Boots,” the Broadway musical, is sunny and bright, like a new penny. Her hair is yellow; she often wears yellow dresses; her eyes shine like sequins.

headline: Forensic Art Expert’s Libel Case Against New Yorker Magazine Is Dismissed
abstract: A federal judge has dismissed a libel complaint against The New Yorker magazine for an article it published about a forensic art expert.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in New York has dismissed a libel suit brought against The New Yorker magazine and one of its writers by Peter Paul Biro, a forensic art expert who was the subject of a long article in July 2010.

headline: Odes to Heat-Struck New York
abstract: Readers write their own over-the-top odes to the temperature in response to an article about the summer heat that was published in this newspaper in 1852.
lead_paragraph: In last Sunday’s Metropolitan section, Benjamin Weiser exhumed an article about the summer heat that was published in this newspaper in 1852. No mere weather story, it combined meticulous detail, social commentary and references to art and literature — all rendered in spectacularly overwrought prose. We asked readers to write their own over-the-top odes to the temperature in response; a selection is below.

headline: Reborn Cosmos Return to the Field
abstract: After being dormant, but not forgotten for 29 years, the New York Cosmos of the N.A.S.L. return to play Saturday night.
lead_paragraph: They were the Galaticos in the alternate universe of American soccer in the late 1970s and early ‘80s.

headline: Summer on the Jersey Shore, After the Storm
abstract: A visit to the coast more than eight months after Hurricane Sandy reveals a range of recovery.
lead_paragraph: Seaside Heights historically embodied both the natural beach-encrusted splendors and the boozy, boardwalk MTV excesses of the Jersey Shore. That status was only enhanced after pictures of its half-submerged roller coaster, long a destination for families in search of fun, became a post-Hurricane Sandy metaphor in news reports for nature’s triumph over what man had wrought.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: Not Just the Flu, Solved!
abstract: Readers solve the case of a 59-year-old woman who’d been sick for over a week with what she thought was just the flu but then suddenly became deathly ill.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 12:53 p.m., Monday Aug. 5

headline: Answers
abstract: Answers to the Pop Quiz.
lead_paragraph: We asked educators to submit questions they’d llike to see on the SAT. Below, they explain their answers.

headline: George Clooney Rebuts Loeb’s Critique of Sony
abstract: The actor and producer took time during an interview with Deadline Hollywood — ostensibly to discuss his coming movie, “The Monuments Men” — to inveigh against the hedge fund manager and his campaign against Sony.
lead_paragraph: Daniel S. Loeb has been steadily ratcheting up his critique of Sony in recent days. But the conglomerate found a defender in a somewhat unlikely source: George Clooney.

headline: Testing, Testing
keywords: ['SAT (College Admission Test)', 'ACT (Examination)', 'Tests and Examinations', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Looking for every advantage, more students are taking — and retaking, and submitting — both the SAT and ACT. Does it help?
lead_paragraph: AS if applying to college isn’t taxing enough, the process seems to have been ratcheted up another notch. Ambitious high school students are no longer content with just one college admissions test. Not a single college requires it, but many applicants to the nation’s most selective colleges and universities are taking — and retaking — both the ACT and the SAT.

headline: What Would You Ask?
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'SAT (College Admission Test)', 'Tests and Examinations']
abstract: Educators write questions they would like to see on the SAT.
lead_paragraph: The College Board has announced plans for a fundamental redesign of the SAT, to be introduced in 2015. What should be on it? We invited educators to dream up a question they would like to see. Turn to the answers for an explanation of their choices.

headline: Owning Up
abstract: What students are saying on campus confessions pages.
lead_paragraph: THE idea of anonymous confessions went viral last semester, with Facebook pages popping up at campuses large and small. The confessions page out of the University of Wisconsin, Madison, which went up in late February, says it’s the nation’s largest, with about 500,000 weekly views during the school year.

headline: To Catch a Cheat
abstract: What’s the latest cut-and-paste technique?
lead_paragraph: FOR his recent MOOC, “Understanding Cheating in Online Courses,” Bernard Bull asked his students to share their stories. Cut-and-paste still rules, he found, but with a global twist that trips up plagiarism-detection software. Students are finding papers online in another language and running them through Google Translate.

headline: Skipping Class (All of Them)
abstract: A handful of companies have taken the essay mill to the next level.
lead_paragraph: You don’t even have to log in. A handful of companies have taken the essay mill to the next level. NoNeedtoStudy.com, WeTakeYourClass.com and BoostMyGrades.com, among others, will take an entire online course for you.

headline: Following the Money
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: What and where to study, based on graduates’ earnings.
lead_paragraph: FOR 18-year-old consumers, financial decisions escalate exponentially. Tall latte or a grande splurge? Lucky Brand or True Religion? State U. or N.Y.U.? Statistics or psych or maybe social work?

headline: Sneak Preview
keywords: ['SAT (College Admission Test)', 'ACT (Examination)', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Tests and Examinations']
abstract: The SAT is being overhauled — again — and the ACT is going digital. The test makers reveal what the exams might look like.
lead_paragraph: SAY farewell to vocabulary flashcards with arcane words like “compendious,” “membranous,” “mendacious,” “pugnacious,” “depreciatory,” “redolent,” “treacly” and “jettison.” In the new SAT, to be unveiled in 2015, David Coleman, president of the College Board, wants to get rid of obscure words that are . . . just SAT words, and replace them with more common words like “synthesis,” “distill” and “transform,” used in context as they will be in college and in life.

headline: The Costliest Colleges
abstract: Art and music schools top the government’s list of highest net prices.
lead_paragraph: SINCE 2011, the Department of Education has tried to shame colleges over costs. This summer’s data release shows that 7 of the 10 most expensive private nonprofit colleges (in terms of net price, or total cost of attendance minus average grant aid) are art and music conservatories. In defense: tiny endowments, small studio classes and expensive glassblowing equipment and audio mixers. On the other hand: these are watercolorists and musicians.

headline: Talking With Teachers
abstract: A student who met with almost every single faculty member.
lead_paragraph: FRESHMAN year at Hamilton College, in Clinton, N.Y., Bret Turner asked a music professor, “Why is music important?” Enthused by the passionate response, he decided to speak with every teacher on campus about his or her discipline. By the time he graduated, in May, he’d chatted with 200 of 223 faculty members, a half-hour to an hour each.

headline: Class Warfare Along Partygoer Lines
abstract: Questions for the co-author of “Paying for the Party.”
lead_paragraph: IN the fall of 2004, 53 young women arriving for their first year at a public research university found that one room on their dorm floor had a sign saying, “This room is occupied by sociology researchers studying college student social life.”

headline: Book Review Podcast: David Rakoff’s Farewell in Verse
abstract: Paul Rudnick discusses David Rakoff’s final book.
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, Paul Rudnick reviews “Love, Dishonor, Marry, Die, Cherish, Perish,” the final book by David Rakoff, who died of cancer last year at the age of 47. Mr. Rudnick said he was prepared to hate the book, “and not just because it’s so awful to contemplate a world without any more David Rakoff books, or any more David Rakoff.” He writes:

headline: An $18 Million Lesson in Handling Credit Report Errors
abstract: Despite a whopping judgment against Equifax, little is going to change for those who find mistakes in their credit reports, industry observers say.
lead_paragraph: Even after sending more than 13 letters to Equifax over the course of two years, Julie Miller could not get the big credit bureau to remove a host of errors that it inserted into her credit report.

headline: A Seventh Day, but Not a Day of Rest
abstract: Miriam Linna, a book and music collector who resells her finds, has been spending her Sundays salvaging stock damaged by Hurricane Sandy.
lead_paragraph: Stuff doesn’t stop for Sundays or holidays, and when you talk about Miriam Linna and her husband, Billy Miller, you’re talking about stuff. She collects paperbacks, with an emphasis on pulp fiction; they both collect records, the scruffier the better. Then they recycle the gems through their businesses. From their apartment in a converted school in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, she runs Kicks Books (recent titles include “Gone Man Squared” by the English beat poet Royston Ellis) and both run the resolutely lo-fi Norton Records. Since 1984, they have also made joyful noises with their garage rock band, the A-Bones, with Ms. Linna, 57, on drums, and Mr. Miller singing. Since Hurricane Sandy flooded their warehouse in Red Hook, they have been working to salvage records and books, including on Sundays. Roaming among their collections is their mixed-breed dog, Queenie.

headline: Beyond Dioramas: Nature’s New Story
abstract: The Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County has transformed its approach to evolution, culture, history and humanity.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The traditional natural history museum is powerful and familiar, but it is also strange. It is weighty, ponderous, pieced together from relics of lost worlds. It evolved in the 19th century, displaying the geological cataclysms that molded the earth’s surface, the creatures that clambered into habitats and the indigenous cultures that were once considered closer to nature. No other museum genre has changed so glacially.

headline: What Inspired You to Work in Video Games?
abstract: We want to hear from video game professionals about what inspired their careers.
lead_paragraph: This summer, The New York Times is publishing essays by its critics about the moments or works that prompted them to write about the arts, along with stories from readers about their own epiphanies. Previously we heard from readers who work in television, classical music, dance and pop music.

headline: Keep On Truckin’
abstract: A research report finds a surprising correlation between the pace of truck sales and the ability of stocks to outperform bonds.
lead_paragraph: The connection may sound obscure, but as David Bowers of Absolute Strategy Research in London notes, there is a surprising correlation between the pace of truck sales and the ability of stocks to outperform bonds.

headline: The Trouble With Lemonade Stands
abstract: No, you can’t have a lemonade stand — and we’re not shelling out a dollar for a few measly ounces of colored sugar water at the neighbors’, either.
lead_paragraph: Last night at dinner, I announced that I planned to write about lemonade stands and the challenges they present for me.

headline: For That All-Important First Tent
abstract: Gifts to make the outdoorsy couple comfy.
lead_paragraph: Gifts to make the outdoorsy couple comfy.

headline: Over Canned Octopus, a First Date
abstract: Maiden Lane, a seafood restaurant that has no kitchen and serves much of its food from cans, seemed an unusual place for introductions.
lead_paragraph: You should not judge Maiden Lane, a 28-seat wine bar and seafood spot that opened on Tompkins Square Park in April, by its kitchen. It doesn’t have one. Thus the concept: cold tins of imported mussels, octopus, sardines and other sea creatures, as well as smoked fish and cured meats for customers not ready to fork their dinner out of cans. The walls are exposed brick, the room not too loud. Wednesdays are theme nights, sometimes involving hot food made on the lone induction burner — this Wednesday will be a celebration of striped bass, featuring the fish in ceviche, crudo and soup.

lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Off the Tracks, Turmoil Aplenty
abstract: With the 2013 racing season at its midpoint, Formula One and Nascar are finding that it’s anything but business as usual as they deal with problems.
lead_paragraph: With the 2013 racing season at its midpoint, more or less, two of the biggest series are finding that it’s anything but business as usual. Each of those series, the Formula One world drivers championship and the Nascar Sprint Cup, have shown cracks in their armor in recent months.

lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Media Whirlwind Doesn’t Faze Park; Afternoon Gusts Do
abstract: Inbee Park of South Korea, who is seeking her fourth major title of the season, carded a one-over 73 in the second round of the Women’s British Open.
lead_paragraph: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — The storm passed through Friday morning, leaving puddles in its wake. The wind arrived later and tilted the Old Course in favor of the early starters. Inbee Park, who played in the afternoon in the toughest of the conditions, managed to identify the rainbow even as the clouds rolled in and darkened her path to history.

headline: Monterey’s Festival, Rich in Tradition
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Antique and Classic Cars', "Pebble Beach Concours D'Elegance (Car Show)"]
abstract: What started as a small meeting of sports car enthusiasts in 1950 has grown into the Pebble Beach classic-car extravaganza, which includes eight concours, five auctions and three days of racing.
lead_paragraph: The birth of this country’s classic-car Olympics took place at Pebble Beach, Calif., on the scenic Monterey Peninsula, in the simpler, quieter time of November 1950.

headline: Upwardly Mobile, but Not in Any Hurry to Get There
abstract: The 2014 Nissan Versa Note starts for less than $15,000, but it offers many features that can be found on more expensive cars.
lead_paragraph: It’s logical that the less money you spend on a car, the less car you should expect. But as I’ve heard repeatedly from automakers, small-car customers in this country have the same lofty expectations as other types of shoppers.

headline: ‘Baby BMW’ Takes On an Entirely New Meaning
abstract: Some baby strollers carry the brand names of automakers, including Aston Martin, BMW and Jeep.
lead_paragraph: Let’s make one thing clear: McLaren, the British maker of racecars and supercars like the new P1 is not the same company as Maclaren, the British manufacturer of premium baby strollers, known for its 1965 innovation of the folding umbrella model.

headline: Pebble Beach Stalwarts, Classics as Their Cause
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Antique and Classic Cars', "Pebble Beach Concours D'Elegance (Car Show)"]
abstract: Million-dollar cars are so common at Pebble Beach that they become like the spear-carriers in “Aida,” mere background for the real action.
lead_paragraph: When visitors new to the weeklong festival surrounding the Pebble Beach Concours d’Élégance see their first million-dollar car, they can’t help but be impressed. After all, there aren’t many like that back home. By the third day, million-dollar vehicles are like the spear-carriers in “Aida,” mere background for the real action.

headline: The Tappin’ Talkies, in a Movie Classic on Stage
abstract: An ingénue becomes a star as “Singin’ in the Rain” comes to the Patchogue Theater.
lead_paragraph: THOSE DANCING FEET are the stars of the show presented in Patchogue by the Gateway Performing Arts Center of Suffolk County — but the show is not “42nd Street.” This one is “Singin’ in the Rain,” a less felicitous translation of a dance-savvy movie into a tap-happy Broadway musical. It shares many of the same elements, including a showbiz setting and a plot involving the vagaries of young love, the machinations of a domineering female star and the rise of a bright-faced ingénue.

headline: The Life of Jesus: Reza Aslan Talks About ‘Zealot’
abstract: Mr. Aslan’s new book is a biography of the historical Jesus.
lead_paragraph: In a recent interview heard round the world (or at least, round influential Twitter feeds), the Fox News host Lauren Green spoke to Reza Aslan about his new book, “Zealot: The Life and Times of Jesus of Nazareth.” Ms. Green’s focus on why Mr. Aslan, a Muslim, would write about Jesus, created a stir on social media (and traditional media), bringing more attention to the book, which was already on The New York Times best-seller list.

headline: Video Shows Iran’s President-Elect Was Misquoted on Israel
abstract: Video of comments made on Friday by Iran’s president-elect, Hassan Rouhani, showed that he was misquoted by Iranian news agencies and had not called for the destruction of Israel.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, 6:46 p.m. | As my colleague Thomas Erdbrink reports from Tehran, Iran’s state media scrambled on Friday to correct comments wrongly attributed to the country’s president-elect, Hassan Rouhani, after he was incorrectly quoted calling Israel “a sore which must be removed.”

lead_paragraph: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y. — The young professionals were promising “All Cash” up front for a fast rental in the Hamptons. So the agency they contacted in April scrambled to get them into as many of the properties as it could.

headline: Meeting the Disapproving Mother

lead_paragraph: RUTHLESS MOTHERS of all degrees have long been a forceful presence in dramatic literature. Oscar Wilde’s Lady Bracknell, Tennessee Williams’s Amanda Wingfield and Gypsy Rose Lee’s mama are among the maternal monsters who command the stage.

headline: The Next Edition
abstract: Katharine Weymouth has lived much of her life in the shadow of two formidable women. Now, she has a chance to join their ranks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On the eve of the 2012 White House Correspondents’ Dinner, this city’s annual media-politico-Hollywood love fest, Katharine Weymouth convened the sort of Washington power dinner for which her grandmother, Katharine Graham, the pioneering publisher of The Washington Post, was famous.

headline: Textbook Funnies
abstract: A student catalogs humorous passages.
lead_paragraph: AS shipping and receiving coordinator at Bethel University’s bookstore, Karl Stavem delighted in flipping through textbooks, and always seemed to find humor – especially in word problems that involved implausible dating situations. Last year, Mr. Stavem started curating his collection on Tumblr.

headline: ‘Hello, Dolly!’ in Another Light
abstract: The production at Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam stars Klea Blackhurst in a down-to-earth version of the title role.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to the likes of Carol Channing, Pearl Bailey and Barbra Streisand, we tend to think of Dolly Levi as a flamboyant, stage-devouring diva. But before this exuberant busybody took to song and exclamatory punctuation in “Hello, Dolly!” she was simply “The Matchmaker” in the Thornton Wilder play — not low-key, exactly, but suited to more homespun character actresses like Ruth Gordon and Shirley Booth.

headline: A Cheap Spying Tool With a High Creepy Factor
abstract: A law student says fear of federal prosecution has kept him from fully carrying out an experiment he aptly calls “CreepyDOL,” which shows how cheap and easy it is for ordinary citizens to spy on each other.
lead_paragraph: Brendan O’Connor is a security researcher. How easy would it be, he recently wondered, to monitor the movement of everyone on the street – not by a government intelligence agency, but by a private citizen with a few hundred dollars to spare?

headline: Aaron Sanchez and John Besh Discover Haiti’s Evolving Food Culture
abstract: The celebrity chefs visited the impoverished Caribbean nation to find out about new sustainable farming practices and many delicious varieties of rice.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this week, the TV personalities and James Beard Award-winning chefs Aarón Sánchez and John Besh headed to Haiti on behalf of Oxfam’s GROW program, which seeks to promote sustainable practices for food production around the world. While there, they checked out urban gardens in Port-au-Prince, and new rice-growing techniques that require less water in the countryside. They also made headlines when they were turned away from a farmers market by a mayor who feared they would take unflattering pictures. In between their various activities, the duo — who happen to be best friends and are planning to open a Mexican restaurant together — cooked up local dishes alongside Haitian chefs, farmers and culinary students. Here, Sánchez and Besh share their adventures.

headline: Under a Coaster, a Dream, or Maybe a Nightmare
abstract: “Coney Night Maze,” featuring a monumental structure inspired by the underside of the Cyclone roller coaster at Coney Island, is on view at the Neuberger Museum of ArtPurchase.
lead_paragraph: In 1996, during an outing to Coney Island, Donna Dennis found herself unexpectedly captivated by the Cyclone roller coaster. But it wasn’t the thrill of the ride or the enthusiasm of the crowds that drew her; it was the strange landscape beneath.

headline: Prison Life, Real and Onscreen
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Television', 'Women and Girls', 'Smuggling', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Web-Original Programming']
abstract: The Netflix show “Orange Is the New Black” takes artistic license with many details of prison life.
lead_paragraph: The night before she reports to prison after pleading guilty to smuggling drug money, Piper Chapman, the protagonist of Netflix’s popular series “Orange Is the New Black,” frets about maintaining her blond hair and meticulously groomed eyebrows. She anticipates that at least she can use her incarceration to “get ripped,” read everything on her Amazon wish list, maybe even learn a craft. She asks her fiancé to keep her Web site updated, and when she walks into the penitentiary, she’s carrying a burrata sandwich.

headline: Tested by Water and Fire, Yet Staying Put
abstract: The summer after Hurricane Sandy destroyed about 350 homes in Breezy Point, Queens, things are quieter than usual, but not dead — signs of rebuilding are there.
lead_paragraph: Several decades ago, Katie Gallagher’s mother arrived in New York from County Kerry, Ireland, and secured work as a nanny with a prominent Manhattan family that spent the summers in East Hampton. Seduced by the beauty and serenity of the beaches of the ruling class, Ms. Gallagher’s mother thought to herself, “There must be a place like this for us,” her daughter told me. By “us” she meant people of comparatively meager circumstance, but she also meant the Irish. As it happened, there was a place on the shore for her far from the world of Further Lane, a place with its own codes and dignities and manner of exclusion on the western tip of the Rockaway peninsula called Breezy Point.

headline: When Lindsay Lohan Hijacks a Film, She Also Saves It
abstract: Whatever its critical reception, there’s a good chance that “The Canyons,” made on a $250,000 budget (most of it raised on Kickstarter), will end up being one of the most influential films in decades.
lead_paragraph: “The Canyons,” starring Lindsay Lohan, written by Bret Easton Ellis and directed by Paul Schrader, will open today in New York and on video on demand today and in Los Angeles on Aug. 9. This is no small victory for the filmmakers, considering that when the movie was completed, it was unclear whether it would make it to theaters at all. When Stephen Rodrick’s article, “Here Is What Happens When You Cast Lindsay Lohan in Your Movie,” was published in the magazine in mid-January, the film had been rejected by both Sundance and SXSW.

headline: Pursuing Elusive 59, Woods Falls a Bit Short
abstract: Tiger Woods shot a nine-under-par 61 in the second round of the Bridgestone Invitational, missing two short birdie putts down the stretch.
lead_paragraph: The pursuit of golf’s magic score of 59 has been a wild ride this year, with two minor tour players reaching it, a 16-year-old amateur carding one and Phil Mickelson leaving a putt hanging on the lip to barely miss the milestone.

lead_paragraph: Zoe Schneider was on the hunt for an affordable country house when her brother forwarded an ad to her from his Boerum Hill Listserv: a little place in the Catskills with a pool, basketball court and a playground. The price: $25,000.

Both works had as much to do with social issues as with artistic ones, and certain heavy-handed leanings were their downfalls.

headline: Snapshots From a Saint’s Fervid Gallop to Martyrdom
abstract: Walter Braunfels’s “Jeanne d’Arc,” presented at the Salzburg Festival, received an inspired performance.
lead_paragraph: SALZBURG, Austria — It always takes some mental adjustment to go from the Bayreuth Festival in Germany to the Salzburg Festival here, as I did on Thursday. Unless you are a resident of Bayreuth or a student at its university, there is only one reason for an outsider to visit that sleepy city: the Wagner festival. There are amenities for visitors but not much else to do.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Postal Service on Friday confirmed that it takes a photograph of every letter and package mailed in the United States — about 160 billion pieces last year — and occasionally provides the photos to law enforcement agencies that request them as part of criminal cases.

lead_paragraph: CAIRO — When Egypt’s first elected president, Mohamed Morsi, promoted Gen. Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi to defense minister nearly a year ago, sweeping away an aging cadre of generals, many saw it as a triumph for the Islamist president, and for a fledgling democracy.

headline: Fickle Nature, Taunting an Ensemble From the North
abstract: Ballets Jazz de Montréal’s program on Thursday at Celebrate Brooklyn! featured Benjamin Millepied’s duet “Closer,” Wen Wei Wang’s “Night Box” and Barak Marshall’s “Harry.”
lead_paragraph: Last year, when Les Ballets Jazz de Montréal was scheduled to perform in New York, Hurricane Sandy intervened. That run was rescheduled and went off without meteorological incident. But when the company returned on Thursday for a Celebrate Brooklyn! show under the Prospect Park Bandshell, the heavens opened up again.

abstract: Congress is heading home on recess after the Senate voted Thursday for two bills to streamline the licensing of hydroelectric projects. The bills are hardly radical, but Congress had not agreed on energy legislation in four years.
lead_paragraph: Congress is heading home for its August recess having passed the first significant energy legislation, aside from some tax changes, since 2009, after the Senate approved two bills on Thursday that clear the way for faster licensing of hydroelectric projects.

lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The fire that killed 362 people in a Honduran prison last year started accidentally in an upper bunk in one cell and rapidly spread through locked gates and past frightened police guards, according to a report released Friday by the Organization of American States.

headline: Ronnie Cutrone, a Man of Another, Cooler City

lead_paragraph: When the artist Ronnie Cutrone died late last month, at 65 and apparently of natural causes, a quirky and marginal figure slipped off the cultural stage, taking with him a large and vital hunk of late-20th-century New York history.

headline: Yesterday’s Style, Today’s Hits
abstract: On the album “Blurred Lines,” Robin Thicke, like other white-soul singers, seems more conservative than innovative, nostalgic for sounds that are decades old.
lead_paragraph: We first met Robin Thicke about a decade ago, zipping through the streets of Manhattan on a bicycle in his debut video, Jesus mane flowing behind him, then doing some sub-“Saturday Night Fever” moves in a freight elevator. The song was “When I Get You Alone,” and it sampled Walter Murphy’s “Fifth of Beethoven,” the 1976 disco-classical fusion, a hybrid of flash and seriousness that Mr. Thicke appeared perfectly comfortable with, even if few others were: wildly out of step with the sound of the time, his single never hit the American charts.

headline: Singer Files Suit Against Met Opera Over Fall

lead_paragraph: Updated, Aug. 5 | Wendy White, the Metropolitan Opera mezzo-soprano who was hospitalized in December 2011 after an eight-foot fall when a piece of scenery broke during a performance, is suing the Met for damages as a result of the accident. The lawsuit was filed on Thursday, but the Met will not be served with papers until Monday, Ms. White’s lawyer, Martin Edelman, said on Friday afternoon.

headline: Pressed on Syria, Hezbollah Leader Urges Focus on Israel

lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — In a rare public appearance on Friday, Hezbollah’s leader, Hassan Nasrallah, urged Arabs and Muslims to stay focused on opposing Israel despite bitter disagreements over the Syrian war, and declared that his Shiite followers would not bend in the face of rising anti-Shiite sentiment among those who oppose his support for the Syrian government.

lead_paragraph: Thanks for “My Mademoiselle Summer” by Meg Wolitzer (Sunday Styles, July 21). It brought me back 50 years to my days as a Mademoiselle guest editor in 1963. headline: Mexico: Blast Caused by Methane Gas, Report Says
abstract: The basement blast killed 37 people and injured more than 120 others at the headquarters of Petróleos Mexicanos, or Pemex, on Jan. 31.
lead_paragraph: The Mexican attorney general’s office said Friday that methane gas combined with vapors emitted by solvents caused the deadly explosion at the headquarters of Mexico’s state-owned oil monopoly, Petróleos Mexicanos, or Pemex, on Jan. 31. The basement blast killed 37 people and injured more than 120 others. In a statement summarizing the results of its investigation, the attorney general’s office said that hydrocarbons that had leaked into the ground decades before the building was constructed had contributed to the buildup of methane gas and that an electrical spark had probably ignited the combustible mix. Pemex is suffering from declining production and has long had a poor safety record. President Enrique Peña Nieto has said he hopes to win approval from Mexico’s Congress to open up the company to private investment before the end of the year.

headline: Repairs to a Storm-Damaged Tunnel Will Disrupt R Line Service for a Year

headline: Spain: Alarms Warned Train’s Driver Before Accident
abstract: The alarms went off inside the train that crashed last week in northwestern Spain moments before it derailed, prompting the panicked driver to activate the brakes three times, an examination revealed.
lead_paragraph: At least three alarms went off inside the train that crashed last week in northwestern Spain moments before it derailed, prompting the panicked driver to activate the brakes three times even as he talked on the telephone with another employee, an examination of the train’s two black boxes released Friday revealed. The driver, Francisco José Garzón Amo, had answered a ticket inspector’s call on his cellphone and was traveling at a permitted speed of 199 kilometers per hour, or 123 miles per hour, before the train switched to another track in a reduced-speed zone. During the call, an alarm went off in the driver’s cabin. The black boxes recorded Mr. Garzón screaming as he tried to activate the brake. The train’s speed dropped to 195 k.p.h., or 121 m.p.h., but another alarm sounded, 500 yards from the curve where the accident took place. Mr. Garzón activated an emergency brake three seconds later. A third alarm sounded, and 13 train cars started derailing. Mr. Garzón activated another emergency brake as the train careened from the tracks and then slammed into a wall at 153 k.p.h., or 95 m.p.h., nearly twice the speed limit. Mr. Garzón was arrested last week and charged with reckless homicide in the deaths of 79 people.

But for people who live here in the heart of central Appalachia, the Mutual Drug Cafeteria was a community hub, an extension of the family kitchen. It’s where residents could fill a prescription, pick up an oil lamp or a strawberry huller, find a plastic pirate sword for the school play and get a good cup of coffee with a plate of pork chops, soup beans, pickled beets and blackberry cobbler.

headline: Stephen Foster, the Wildebeest and Me
abstract: Or how I began a song about animal swarms that ended up being a song about songs.
lead_paragraph: The difference between the way a swarm or herd moves and the way, say, a crowd of panicked people disperses is this: individuals in a swarming herd have no need to understand why they’re running before they run. Each creature in the herd reacts to the movements of her immediate neighbors so that when one caribou tenses because she sees a wolf on the ridge, a ripple of tensing muscles travels through the herd, one caribou at a time, at lightning speed. They are all running before most of them have considered why they’re moving or where they’re going. This mad dashing makes for quick escapes, but it has drawbacks. The wildebeest herds sometimes gallop straight off a cliff and hundreds are dead before they can manage to come to a stop.

headline: Open Season on History
abstract: Archaeologists do not hunt objects. We hunt lost worlds. Sadly, those worlds are slipping away under the relic-hunter’s shovel, all for the sake of a few bucks.
lead_paragraph: CHESTER, Va. — FOR archaeologists like me, the Flowerdew Hundred Plantation near Williamsburg, Va., is our Woodstock, a sentimental spot where dozens of professionals earned their trowels. The farm’s incredible archaeological wealth ranges from 12,000-year-old Native American tools to a tree that shaded Union soldiers in June 1864.

headline: What’s On Saturday

lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (Cinemax) CHASING MAVERICKS (2012) Rick Hesson (Gerard Butler), a surfer in Santa Cruz nicknamed Frosty, teaches Jay Moriarity (Jonny Weston, above right, with Mr. Butler), a legend-in-the-making with a dream and a battered board, the way of the waves — specifically, the monster crushers in Northern California on a break known as Mavericks. Curtis Hanson and Michael Apted shared the directing duties on this film, based on a true story that begins in 1987 and is lent authenticity by the real-life surfers Greg Long, Peter Mel and Zach Wormhoudt. “When the movie works, its buoyancy can be infectious and persuasive, particularly in the surfing scenes and in the mesmerizing shots of the heaving, churning ocean and waves,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York York Times. “The movie captures the hypnotic quality of this watery landscape, with its steel blue undulations and the Freudian oceanic feeling it summons. It invites you to gaze into this watery abyss, to ponder its mysteries as well as those of the swimmer whose image brackets the movie and evokes John F. Kennedy’s observation: ‘We are tied to the ocean. And when we go back to the sea, whether it is to sail or to watch, we are going back from whence we came.’ ”
