abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines.
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Final Test for U.S. Solheim Cup Qualifying
abstract: The Women’s British Open is the last opportunity for players like Morgan Pressel and Michelle Wie to earn spots on the American Solheim Cup team.
lead_paragraph: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — Morgan Pressel stopped in the middle of an interview Friday to admire a reporter’s sequined sneakers. Pressel is as keen on fashion as she is on golf, and with career earnings of nearly $5 million, she can indulge in almost any wardrobe item her heart desires.

headline: Variety: Where Debs Sleep
abstract: Mixing it up with Mel Taub.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Well, of course I sleep in a bed. Moving right along.

headline: Jamaica Focuses on Farming
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Food']
abstract: The country has taken on a bold new strategy in the face of expensive food imports: make farming patriotic and ubiquitous.
lead_paragraph: The country has taken on a bold new strategy in the face of expensive food imports: make farming patriotic and ubiquitous.

headline: As Cost of Importing Food Soars, Jamaica Turns to the Earth
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Food']
abstract: Across the Caribbean, food imports have become a budget-busting problem, prompting one of the world’s most fertile regions to reclaim its agricultural past.
lead_paragraph: KINGSTON, Jamaica — The scent of coconut oil and fiery jerk spice blows through kitchens across this green island, but as the country’s food imports have become a billion-dollar threat to finances and health, Jamaica has taken on a bold new strategy: make farming patriotic and ubiquitous, behind homes, hospitals, schools, even prisons.

headline: Interpol Asks Nations to Help Track Terror Suspects Freed in Prison Breaks
abstract: The Interpol alert added to a climate of heightened concern set off Thursday when State Department officials spoke of possible terror plots against Western facilities overseas.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Interpol issued a global alert on Saturday asking member countries to help track hundreds of terrorism suspects who escaped in a wave of prison breaks over the past month — including in Iraq, Pakistan and Libya — and requesting assistance in determining whether any of the operations “are coordinated or linked.”

headline: Tunisian Islamist Finds Hope in Challenging Time
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: An Islamist leader in Tunisia expresses optimism for his movement despite setbacks in Egypt.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — In the tense weeks before the military took power in Egypt, the leader of Tunisia’s dominant Islamic party says, he tried to mediate between President Mohamed Morsi and his opponents in a last-ditch effort to salvage the region’s most important test of whether Islamist instincts could be reconciled with democracy.

headline: When Politics Catches Up With ‘Portnoy’
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Jewish politicians’ sex scandals are raising religious questions that could decide the outcome of races.
lead_paragraph: THE plots and details seem lifted from Philip Roth or the early work of Woody Allen. Anthony D. Weiner, the Brooklyn bar mitzvah boy and would-be mayor whose intimate anatomy has now become a matter of public broadcast. Bob Filner, proud son of Forest Hills, Queens, whose California dream of a life — history professor, congressman, San Diego mayor — was undone by so much alleged lechery that the city he governed established a hot line for victims.

headline: Aug. 3: Where the Candidates Are Today
abstract: The candidates’ daily campaign schedule at a glance.
lead_paragraph: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

headline: Rearranging the Furniture in Business Class
abstract: Depending on the types of aircraft they fly, airlines can customize cabin layouts differently.
lead_paragraph: Depending on the types of aircraft they fly, airlines can customize cabin layouts differently.

headline: The $4,000 Deal Gone Sour Behind the Doping Scandal
abstract: A disgruntled business partner gave a Florida newspaper files that led to scrutiny of Anthony P. Bosch, a clinic operator accused of supplying players with banned drugs.
lead_paragraph: In October, Anthony P. Bosch, a troubled businessman who had a permanent suntan and a white lab coat with his name embroidered on it — though he had no medical license — clashed with an investor in his small anti-aging clinic in Coral Gables, Fla.

headline: An Involuntary Union of Football Rivals for Philadelphia High Schools
abstract: With the closing of Philadelphia’s Germantown High, a victim of budget cuts, its football players have to set aside a long-held animosity to join rival Martin Luther King High.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The football players at Martin Luther King High School gathered in a semicircle like a tired and rain-soaked choir. They placed their arms around one another’s shoulders and began swaying to a call and response.

headline: In Need of a New Hip, but Priced Out of the U.S.
keywords: ['Hips', 'Medical Devices', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Implants', 'Series', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Michael Shopenn turned to a private hospital in Belgium after he was unable to find an affordable artificial hip in the United States.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW, Ind. — Michael Shopenn’s artificial hip was made by a company based in this remote town, a global center of joint manufacturing. But he had to fly to Europe to have it installed.

headline: Mets Place Wright on Disabled List
abstract: David Wright, the Mets’ captain and star player, will be out of action for at least 15 days, and possibly longer, with a strained right hamstring.
lead_paragraph: The Mets placed third baseman David Wright on the 15-day disabled list Saturday morning after a magnetic resonance imaging test revealed a Grade 2 strain in his right hamstring that they expect will sideline him for two to four weeks.

headline: A Great Manager Should Expect a Peaceful Vacation
abstract: Christopher J. Williams, C.E.O. of the Williams Capital Group, says that a manager whose vacations are interrupted should do a better job of developing the team.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Christopher J. Williams, C.E.O. of the Williams Capital Group, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Mugabe Wins Again in Zimbabwe, Leaving Rival Greatly Weakened
abstract: President Robert Mugabe won 61 percent of the vote, said the Zimbabwe Election Commission, defeating Morgan Tsvangirai, who denounced the election, saying it had been rigged.
lead_paragraph: HARARE, Zimbabwe — President Robert Mugabe, who has led Zimbabwe since it threw off white rule in 1980, won another term on Saturday as the official results were announced for last week’s hotly disputed election, defeating his main challenger with 61 percent of the vote and roaring back to secure his grip on power after having to share it for the past five years.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Can Suburbs Help Cities?
abstract: Readers discuss taking a regional approach to reviving Detroit.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss taking a regional approach to reviving Detroit.

headline: Elastic Numbers Make It Hard to Get a Handle on the Economy
abstract: Economic data that is later revised, like figures on the gross domestic product and unemployment, might be too malleable to get a true picture.
lead_paragraph: A TORRENT of economic numbers rained down from Washington last week. They provided a sharper historical perspective on the economy back to 1929.

headline: Clawbacks in Word, Not Deed
keywords: ['Executive Compensation', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Clawbacks, or money returned by an employee committing financial improprieties, are gaining support among investors and companies — though examples are rare.
lead_paragraph: WHAT good is a policy if it’s never enforced?

headline: Misery Goes Digital
abstract: For L.I.R.R. commuters, Penn Station has always been a feast for unhappiness. And new high-tech signs only make it worse.
lead_paragraph: In the evenings, the lowest and busiest level of Penn Station, the Long Island Rail Road concourse, becomes an earthly purgatory, where tens of thousands of souls wait quietly for deliverance to arrive, in the form of a train matched to a track number.

headline: Shark Fins or Champagne?
abstract: Stores in New York are whittling away their stocks of shark fins in advance of a state ban on their sale, a move intended to protect the sharks and the whole ocean ecosystem.
lead_paragraph: The sign at Chung Chou City in Manhattan’s Chinatown says “shark fin clearance” in bold Chinese characters. Nearby, in glass jars that are slightly out of reach, 10-inch fins go for $488 a pound, down from $580. For 13-inch fins, the price is now $638 a pound. Like other shops and restaurants in the city’s Chinese communities, this store is selling off its stock of shark fins.

headline: Of Courage and Cantaloupes
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Editorials']
abstract: While Congress is in recess, advocates are pressing Republicans in their home districts to act on immigration reform.
lead_paragraph: After the Senate passed a comprehensive immigration bill in June, hope for reform shifted to the House. That is where hope sits, on ice, getting freezer burn.

headline: Structural Humbug
abstract: Apparently everyone inside the Beltway knows what isn’t so.
lead_paragraph: OK, this is really depressing. The PBS Newshour isn’t always a good place to get the best analysis, but it’s a terrific place to take the pulse of Washington conventional wisdom — and as Dean Baker notes, that conventional wisdom has clearly swung to the view that our high unemployment is “structural”, not something that could be solved simply by boosting demand.

headline: Return of the Jesus Wars
abstract: Reza Aslan, Fox News and the Christianities that might have been.
lead_paragraph: BEFORE “The Da Vinci Code” and “The Gospel of Judas,” before Mel Gibson’s “Passion” and Martin Scorsese’s “Last Temptation,” before the Dead Sea Scrolls were unearthed and the Gnostic gospels rediscovered, there was a German scholar named Hermann Samuel Reimarus.

headline: Addicted to Prayer
keywords: ['Prayers and Prayer Books', 'Atheism', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: Prayer seems to have health benefits for people, even for atheists. But should everyone drop to their knees and pray?
lead_paragraph: AS evidence accumulates about the many health benefits of religious practice, prayer is looking better and better. Some atheists have even gone public with their own prayer-for-health’s-sake practice.

headline: Robert Mankoff
abstract: The New Yorker cartoon editor on how comedy — and certain sports — helps us cope with the world.
lead_paragraph: Robert Mankoff is a cartoonist and the cartoon editor for The New Yorker.

headline: The Trauma of Being Alive
keywords: ['Grief (Emotion)', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'Death and Dying', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: An undercurrent of injury and disaster runs through ordinary life.
lead_paragraph: TALKING with my 88-year-old mother, four and a half years after my father died from a brain tumor, I was surprised to hear her questioning herself. “You’d think I would be over it by now,” she said, speaking of the pain of losing my father, her husband of almost 60 years. “It’s been more than four years, and I’m still upset.”

headline: Who’s That Candidate in the Teal Toenail Polish?
abstract: Christine Quinn, who easily stands out in the race for mayor of New York City, is working to strengthen her connection with voters.
lead_paragraph: A WELL-DRESSED man at the West 72nd Street subway entrance stopped to take one of the fliers that Christine Quinn was handing out.

headline: How to Whitewash a Plague
abstract: A show at the New-York Historical Society about the early years of AIDS looks at them through rose-tinted glasses.
lead_paragraph: THE New-York Historical Society’s current exhibition “AIDS in New York: The First Five Years” accomplishes a neat trick: it takes a black mark in New York City’s history — its homophobic, apathetic response to the early days of AIDS in the early 1980s — and transforms it into a moment of civic pride, when New Yorkers of all stripes came together to fight the disease. It’s a lovely story, if only it were true.

headline: The Woman Who Ate Cutlery
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Emergency Medical Treatment', 'Psychiatry and Psychiatrists', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Our failure to provide adequate care to psychiatric patients affects us all.
lead_paragraph: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — M is a 33-year old woman who swallowed silverware. She wasn’t psychotic, or out of touch with reality. She knew it was not a good idea to swallow forks and knives and she wasn’t trying to kill herself. In fact, each time she ingested utensils, she went to the emergency room so that doctors could remove them from her esophagus and stomach. Then the hospital transferred M to the psychiatric unit, where she was assigned to my care.

headline: The Freak Show as Fable
abstract: Anthony Weiner is his own mini-series of political coarseness, an X-rated emblem of these tawdry times.
lead_paragraph: ONE young staffer on Anthony Weiner’s mayoral campaign saw a chance at bright lights and went after it, spilling secrets in return for a glamour shot on the front page of a major newspaper, determining that attention was worth whatever crassness it called for.

headline: I Am TOM. I Like to TYPE. Hear That?
keywords: ['Typewriters and Typewriting', 'Postal Service and Post Offices', 'Word Processing']
abstract: Close your eyes as you touch-type on a vintage manual typewriter and you are a blacksmith, shaping sentences hot out of the forge of your mind.
lead_paragraph: BECAUSE Mike McAlary started reporting on cops for the New York tabloids in 1985, Nora Ephron’s play “Lucky Guy,” which recently completed its run, featured word processors on the newsroom desks rather than typewriters. Too bad. We in the ensemble would have loved to pound on bulky desk-crowding typewriters for the sound alone.

headline: A Washington Riddle: What Is ‘Top Secret’?
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Cyberwarfare', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The government is stumbling in its efforts to protect its secrets in the Internet age.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — LESS than 24 hours after Pfc. Bradley Manning was convicted last week of handing off 250,000 State Department cables and defense documents to WikiLeaks, The Guardian published on its Web site the latest classified material from the leaker of the moment, Edward J. Snowden. That installment included the National Security Agency’s playbook for XKeyscore, a powerful surveillance program enabling the agency’s analysts to monitor and trace Internet searches around the globe.

headline: Crumbling American Dreams
abstract: A national economic, social and cultural whirlwind transformed the life chances of the children and grandchildren of those I graduated from Port Clinton High School with in 1959.
lead_paragraph: My hometown — Port Clinton, Ohio, population 6,050 — was in the 1950s a passable embodiment of the American dream, a place that offered decent opportunity for the children of bankers and factory workers alike.

headline: The DNA of Helping People
abstract: Indigo Triplett started out as a Marine and now runs her own consulting firm, Careers in Transition, in Tucker, Ga.
lead_paragraph: I GREW up in a suburb of Chicago and attended a predominantly white high school. We were at the tail end of the civil rights movement but I never experienced any unrest. However, my parents were not as lucky. When I was in elementary school, my mother came home early one day from her job at a manufacturing company. She said the Ku Klux Klan was meeting in the company cafeteria at 4 p.m. and that there was actually a meeting notice on a bulletin board.

headline: Older, Unemployed, and Landing the Job
abstract: Hiram Gonzalez, who was laid off from his reinsurance job at 59, got a new, full-time position after working as a consultant.
lead_paragraph: I WAS laid off four times in my career before I turned 50. But when it happened again two years ago, I had just turned 59. Getting laid off at that age is a different ballgame. I knew I could bring value to a company, but in moments of frustration during the job hunt, I wondered how long it would take to find another job, and there was always the chance I wouldn’t be able to find one.

headline: Public Pensions After Detroit
abstract: State and local governments should make prudent financial decisions without gutting retirement benefits.
lead_paragraph: Detroit’s bankruptcy and the problems facing its pension funds offer two important lessons to other communities. One is that state and local governments need to do a much better job managing retirement funds. The other is that they should not pre-emptively reduce hard-earned benefits at the first sign of trouble.

headline: Republican No-Shows in the Budget Wars
abstract: The House leadership made an embarrassing retreat from an austere transportation and housing bill after realizing they couldn’t get enough votes to pass it.
lead_paragraph: Amid the morass of Washington’s endless budget fights there was a moment of sweet revelation last week: House Republicans choked outright when they failed to muster support for the draconian dreams of Paul Ryan, the Wisconsin legislator and fabled budget hawk who last year ran for vice president on a program of unforgiving fiscal austerity that his colleagues suddenly found too politically risky.

headline: What the Nation Got for $800 Billion
abstract: The Federal Reserve has spent heavily to buy bonds to reduce long-term rates, but rates are actually higher than when it started.
lead_paragraph: SINCE last September, when the Federal Reserve announced its third round of quantitative easing, known as QE3, the central bank has spent $800 billion buying bonds. That’s a stupendous sum, more than the budget for the Department of Defense and more than twice what the federal government spends on welfare programs, including food and nutrition assistance, unemployment benefits and disability payments.

headline: Writers as Architects
abstract: Great architects build structures that can make us feel enclosed, liberated or suspended. Great writers, in devising their literary structures, do exactly the same.
lead_paragraph: Great architects build structures that can make us feel enclosed, liberated or suspended. They lead us through space, make us slow down, speed up or stop to contemplate. Great writers, in devising their literary structures, do exactly the same.

headline: Iran’s President Puts New Focus on the Economy
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: President Hassan Rouhani vowed Saturday to work with the outside world to lift the “oppressive sanctions” crippling Iran’s economy.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iran’s new president, Hassan Rouhani, vowed Saturday to work with the outside world to lift the “oppressive sanctions” crippling the Iranian economy, as he received the official backing of Ayatollah Ali Khamenei at a ceremony marking the start of his presidential term.

headline: For Obamacare to Work, Everyone Must Be In
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Because of the “adverse-selection problem,” a universal health insurance system must account for both healthy people and those with chronic or pre-existing conditions.
lead_paragraph: TWO beliefs continue to shape debate on Obamacare. First, pre-existing medical conditions shouldn’t prevent people from obtaining affordable health insurance. And second, people who don’t want health insurance shouldn’t be forced by the government to purchase it.

headline: Life in a Toxic Country
abstract: My wife and I worry about how China’s bad air and food will affect our child.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — I RECENTLY found myself hauling a bag filled with 12 boxes of milk powder and a cardboard container with two sets of air filters through San Francisco International Airport. I was heading to my home in Beijing at the end of a work trip, bringing back what have become two of the most sought-after items among parents here, and which were desperately needed in my own household.

headline: The Hipster Brewmeister of ... Beirut
abstract: How a former investment banker and airline executive started 961 Beer, a rare Middle East microbrewery.
lead_paragraph: LAST spring, at a public square in downtown Beirut, Lebanon, about 1,000 revelers attended a rock festival sponsored by 961 Beer, a very rare Middle East microbrewery. Acts included the Wanton Bishops, a band that would have been at home in Austin, Tex. In the front row were stylish women in sundresses beside men who showed a strong preference for black T-shirts and trendy eyewear.

headline: Helping Hollywood Players Hook Up
abstract: Slated, a free, members-only service, allows directors, producers, actors, sales agents and investors to communicate.
lead_paragraph: THE characters in an independent movie scheduled to begin filming this fall include a werewolf, a member of the band the Strokes and a cannibalistic yoga instructor. The plot? “It’s kind of a modern-day ‘Trainspotting’ set within a New York indie-rock backdrop,” says Noah C. Haeussner, the film’s producer and a senior vice president for financing and production at Union Entertainment Group.

headline: Obama Administration Overturns Ban on Apple Products
keywords: ['Inventions and Patents', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The Obama administration has vetoed a product ban that would have forced Apple to stop selling some iPhones and iPads in the United States.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration has vetoed a federal commission’s ban that would have forced Apple to stop selling some iPhones and iPads in the United States next week, a rare intervention by the White House and a victory for Apple in its heated patent war with Samsung Electronics.

headline: The Chatter for August 4, 2013
keywords: ['Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Fast Food Industry']
abstract: Notable quotes from business articles that appeared in The New York Times last week.
lead_paragraph: “We will continue to vigorously seek to hold accountable, and bring to trial when necessary, those who commit fraud on Wall Street.”

headline: Rodriguez Seeks Meetings With Baseball and Yankees
abstract: The intent of the meeting was to work out an agreement to mitigate baseball’s impending suspension of Alex Rodriguez, which was expected to come within the next day or two.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Despite a combative stand Friday night that seemed to set him on a collision course with Major League Baseball over his impending suspension, Alex Rodriguez reached out to the commissioner’s office Saturday, through the players union, and also contacted the Yankees directly to seek a meeting, according to two people briefed on the matter who were granted anonymity because they were not permitted to speak about it publicly.

headline: Scandal in South Korea Over Nuclear Revelations
keywords: ['Nuclear Energy', 'Tests and Examinations', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Falsification of Data']
abstract: Revelations about bribery and faked safety tests for critical equipment are causing jitters in South Korea.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Like Japan, resource-poor South Korea has long relied on nuclear power to provide the cheap electricity that helped build its miracle economy. For years, it met one-third of its electricity needs with nuclear power, similar to Japan’s level of dependence before the 2011 disaster at its Fukushima plant.

headline: Alex Rodriguez: A Continual Stir
abstract: Since Alex Rodriguez broke into the majors in 1996, he has been unable to escape the bizarre and controversial stories that seem to follow him on and off the field, the latest involving performance-enhancing drugs.
lead_paragraph: Since Alex Rodriguez broke into the majors in 1996, he has been unable to escape the bizarre and controversial stories that seem to follow him on and off the field, the latest involving performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: The Hacking of Michael Pettis
abstract: Is it really about the Viagra?
lead_paragraph: Oh, wow. I mentioned a couple of weeks back that when I tried to get to Michael Pettis’s essential blog on Chinese economics, I ran into Viagra ads. At the time I found it funny; but I took another look today, and find Pettis reporting not just that he was hacked, but that it took place repeatedly, and that the blog is on hiatus while they rebuild.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Aug. 4
abstract: A terror threat from al-Qaeda, Russian asylum for Edward Snowden, and Congress’s unfinished business dominate the Sunday television talk shows as lawmakers take a five-week break.
lead_paragraph: Congress left Washington this week as the national security community grappled with a new terror threat from Al Qaeda and the White House received news that Russia had granted temporary asylum to Edward Snowden. Sunday’s televisions talk shows examine the terror threat, Moscow-Washington relations, and lawmakers’ unfinished business on the economy, immigration and more.

headline: An Uneasy Football Merger
abstract: The nearly 100-year-old Germantown High School closed this year, leaving a community and its football team in flux.
lead_paragraph: The nearly 100-year-old Germantown High School closed this year, leaving a community and its football team in flux.

headline: After Late Clutch Hit, Mets’ Bats Fall Silent in Extra Innings
abstract: With David Wright on the disabled list, the Mets struggled to score against the Royals and lost on a pinch-hit homer in the 12th inning.
lead_paragraph: Fresh off a plane from Nashville after playing a Class AAA game, outfielder Mike Baxter arrived in the Mets’ clubhouse early Saturday morning — an early indication of the severity of David Wright’s injury the night before.

headline: Should I Call the Repairman?
abstract: Our Sunday puzzle fix, from Steven Ginzburg.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Things break. Then, if the universe is kind to us, someone eventually shows up — usually on the least convenient day of the week, sometime between 12:00 p.m. and 5:00 p.m., sorry, we can only give you a window, not an exact time — and fixes them.

headline: Coin of Realm in China Graft: Phony Receipts
abstract: Sales of counterfeit receipts, used to evade taxes and defraud employers, are becoming more sophisticated, putting considerable tax revenue at stake.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — To begin to comprehend China’s vast underground economy, one need only visit this city’s major transportation depots and watch as peddlers openly hawk fake receipts.

headline: Why Must Voting Be So Hard?
abstract: Despite the encouragement of those in politics and government, the act of registering and voting in Texas is no easy matter.
lead_paragraph: If they really wanted you to vote, they would make it easy.

headline: Finally, Thousands of Old Rape-Evidence Kits Are to Be Tested
keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'Sex Crimes', 'Forensic Science', 'State Legislatures', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Thanks to an $11 million budget appropriation, thousands of evidence kits collected from sexual-assault victims in Texas can now be analyzed.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of evidence kits collected from rape victims that have sat untested for years in Texas can now be analyzed, thanks to an $11 million budget appropriation earmarked for the Texas Department of Public Safety.

headline: Thais Cast a Wide Net for Diverse Tourists
abstract: Thailand has a government-sponsored campaign aimed at gay and lesbian travelers, and is also marketing itself to Muslims.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Tolerance, the Thais have learned, is good for business.

headline: Abbott Faces Questions on Turnabout and Fair Play
abstract: As Attorney General Greg Abbott runs for governor of Texas, some are asking about his advocacy of laws that make it more difficult for other accident victims to receive large financial settlements.
lead_paragraph: When Greg Abbott’s spine was crushed by a falling oak tree in 1984, he had no health insurance and no paycheck. But he had a good lawyer and access to a civil justice system that — back then — was generally hospitable toward plaintiffs. So Mr. Abbott sued.

headline: A Day’s Toil in the Suicide Bombers’ Graveyard
abstract: Khwaja Naqib Ahmad lays claim to one of the toughest jobs in the Afghan capital — burying the unclaimed dead, including suicide bombers.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — In a city with no shortage of hard jobs, Khwaja Naqib Ahmad lays claim to one of the toughest of all — burying the unclaimed dead.

headline: Hotter Than Ever, a Texan’s Handmade Barbecue Pits
abstract: Since 1960, A. N. Bewley Fabricators has been bending, slicing and welding steel for high-quality barbecue pits that can easily cost $20,000.
lead_paragraph: With the recent surge in barbecue’s popularity, the modern-day pit master is getting more attention than a grease fire in a barbecue pit. These smoked-meat craftsmen rely heavily on skill and experience, but their most important tool is a dependable pit.

headline: Pair’s Efforts Can’t Save U.S. From a Drubbing
abstract: The Chinese defeated the Americans, 101.5 to 48.5, at a showdown this month in Ningbo, China.
lead_paragraph: China walked away with a one-sided victory over the United States last month at an event in Ningbo, China.

headline: Kongar-ol Ondar, a Master of a Vocal Art, Dies at 51
abstract: Kongar-ol Ondar, a renowned master of Tuvan throat singing, was a superstar in his country and well-respected by musicians worldwide.
lead_paragraph: Kongar-ol Ondar, an internationally renowned master of Tuvan throat singing, the Central Asian vocal art in which a singer produces two or more notes simultaneously — and which to the uninitiated sounds like the bewitching, remarkably harmonious marriage of a vacuum cleaner and a bumblebee — died on July 25 in Kyzyl, Tuva’s capital. He was 51.

headline: Richard S. Thomas, City Ballet Soloist and Teacher, Dies at 87
abstract: Mr. Thomas founded the New York School of Ballet with his wife, Barbara Fallis, and was a mentor to dancers including Eliot Feld.
lead_paragraph: Richard S. Thomas, a prominent ballet teacher and a former soloist with the New York City Ballet, died on July 27 in a hospital near his home in Paintsville, Ky. He was 87.

headline: 16 Vying to Lead Troubled Detroit
abstract: With a state-appointed emergency manager at City Hall, the position of mayor is a once powerful job that now seems at best undefined, if not irrelevant.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — There are 16 candidates here for a job that is difficult to imagine anyone wanting: mayor.

headline: Other Agencies Clamor for Data N.S.A. Compiles
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: The National Security Agency’s dominant role as the nation’s spy warehouse has prompted turf fights with other federal agencies that want to use its surveillance tools for their own investigations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The National Security Agency’s dominant role as the nation’s spy warehouse has spurred frequent tensions and turf fights with other federal intelligence agencies that want to use its surveillance tools for their own investigations, officials say.

headline: Restraint Urged for Egypt’s Security Services
abstract: Egypt’s interim vice president said on Saturday that force could be used only as a last resort to disperse demonstrations held by supporters of Mohamed Morsi.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt’s interim vice president said on Saturday that force could be used only as a last resort to disperse demonstrations held by supporters of Mohamed Morsi, who was deposed by the military a month ago.

headline: 16 Candidates Running for Mayor of Detroit
abstract: Detroit will hold a primary on Tuesday that will narrow down the field of 16 candidates for mayor to two.
lead_paragraph: The 16 candidates running in the primary for mayor of Detroit:

headline: It’s Woods vs. Himself Entering Final Round at Bridgestone
abstract: Tiger Woods shot a two-under-par 68 in the Bridgestone Invitational to keep his seven-shot lead. Henrik Stenson stood alone in second after shooting a 67.
lead_paragraph: AKRON, Ohio — Many story lines over the years have involved Tiger Woods versus someone, whether an individual or a collective.

headline: Newsweek, Sold in 2010, Is Changing Hands Again
abstract: The weekly newsmagazine has suffered much of the same difficulties, as other print media as people moved to online news.
lead_paragraph: Newsweek, the once venerable 80-year-old weekly magazine that suffered a precipitous decline in recent years, has been bought by the digital news company International Business Times for an undisclosed amount.

headline: Jeter, Still Hobbled, Returns to Bench as Yanks Use Caution
abstract: Derek Jeter is sitting out the final two games of a series in San Diego with right leg pain that has made him look uncomfortable on the field.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Derek Jeter stood at his locker Friday night and insisted that he was healthy, that his legs — the left leg that had gone through a lengthy rehabilitation from a twice-broken ankle and the right one that sustained a quadriceps strain — were not bothering him.

headline: Red Sox Owner’s Purchase of Boston Globe Worries Journalists
abstract: The purchase of The Boston Globe by the Red Sox owner John Henry has presented a potential conflict of interest among journalists at the newspaper.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — As the list of potential purchasers of The Boston Globe leaked out, the newspaper’s longtime sportswriter and columnist Bob Ryan said his only thought was: please, let it be anyone but John Henry.

headline: First Ride: The Reborn 2014 Indian Motorcycles

headline: Granderson Stands Tall for Yankees, but Jeter Has to Sit Out Again

lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — It was good to be back, Curtis Granderson had said the night before, even though he had gone through a hitless evening in his return from a second stint on the disabled list, visits that have cost him all but a handful of games this season.

headline: Car Drives Onto California Boardwalk, Injuring 12
abstract: Two people were critically hurt in Los Angeles’s Venice Beach by a sedan that witnesses said had “moved purposefully.” The driver fled.
lead_paragraph: A hit-and-run driver sped onto the crowded boardwalk at Los Angeles’s Venice Beach on Saturday evening, striking at least a dozen people and injuring two critically, before fleeing, Los Angeles Fire Department officials said.

headline: Rodriguez Finishes Trenton Stint. Next Stop: Unknown.
abstract: Drawing cheers and a few heckles, Alex Rodriguez played another Class AA game with the hope of rejoining the Yankees on Monday, the same day he was expected to be suspended.
lead_paragraph: TRENTON — Flanked by two Trenton law enforcement officers, Alex Rodriguez walked past a quote on the wall outside the home clubhouse: “There are never ex-Yankees, their pinstripes ensure them an immortal presence.”

headline: Suspect in Crash on California Boardwalk Is Arrested
abstract: The suspect, Nathan Campbell of Los Angeles, turned himself in to the police after leaving the scene of the crash, which killed one person, on the Venice Beach Boardwalk, police said.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles police have arrested a man accused of ramming his car through a crowd of people on the Boardwalk of Venice Beach on Saturday, killing one person and injuring at least a dozen others.

headline: What’s on Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Discovery) AIR JAWS: COUNTDOWN TO SHARK WEEK 2013 This 26th-annual programming sensation returns with 11 new specials as well as a late-night talk show, starting with this search for the ultimate shark shot. In “Megalodon: The Monster Shark Lives,” at 9, the marine biologist Collin Drake tries to determine the creature responsible for attacking a fishing vessel off the coast of South Africa in April, killing everyone on board. And “Shark After Dark Live,” at 11, features celebrity guests, shark experts, survivors of attacks and highlights from the evening’s shows. In a first, the week will be punctuated by footage from a Shark Cam, a robot submarine that trails sharks in action. Above, a scene from the series.

headline: Putting the Taliban Back in Its Cage
abstract: America and Pakistan cooperate on the Taliban.
lead_paragraph: America and Pakistan cooperate on the Taliban.

headline: IVF, Embryos and Choices
abstract: When my daughter asked if I chose whether to make her and her sister siblings, or twins, I lied before I thought. Because along with a lot of other choices I never thought I’d have, that was a choice.
lead_paragraph: “Mommy, did you choose to make us twins or just sisters?”

headline: Aug. 4: Where the Candidates Are Today
abstract: The candidates’ daily campaign schedule at a glance.
lead_paragraph: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

headline: Is There Any Point To Economic Analysis?
abstract: Sad tales of conventional wisdom and actual policy.
lead_paragraph: A few further thoughts inspired by the sad revelation that Beltway conventional wisdom has settled on the proposition that high unemployment is structural, not cyclical, even though there is now a bipartisan consensus among economists that the opposite is true.

headline: The Great Fredini Dreams of a 3D Sideshow in Coney Island
abstract: Fred Kahl, a magician, sword-swallower, stuntman and interactive designer, is making replicas of sideshow performers with a 3D printer, hoping to recreate in miniature a Coney Island of the early 1900’s.
lead_paragraph: During his years as a member of the Coney Island Circus Sideshow, Fred Kahl, 48, performed as a magician, a sword-swallower, a stuntman who could hammer nails into his skull and light up lightbulbs with his bare hands, and an impresario who helped found the Burlesque at the Beach. That was when he acquired another name: the Great Fredini.

headline: Jennifer Lopez Nears Deal for ‘American Idol’ Return
abstract: Ms. Lopez, a judge on the show during Seasons 10 and 11, would join what is envisioned as a three-member judging panel.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Lopez, a judge on “American Idol” during Seasons 10 and 11, is closing a deal to return to the show. Deadline.com reported on Saturday that her return was expected to be announced in one to two weeks, once her contract is finalized.

headline: Syria Bans Use of Foreign Currencies for Business Deals
abstract: The ban, which carries fines and jail time for those who engage in such transactions without government approval, is an effort to prop up the Syrian pound, whose value has plummeted since 2011.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — President Bashar al-Assad of Syria on Sunday banned the use of foreign currencies in business transactions, part of the government’s effort to prop up the Syrian pound, which has plummeted to 200 pounds to the dollar from 47 to the dollar in March 2011.

headline: Denzel Washington Has Another Strong Movie Opening
abstract: “2 Guns,” starring Mr. Washington and Mark Wahlberg, took in an estimated $27.4 million in North American movie theaters.
lead_paragraph: A medium-budget star vehicle dominated North American movie theaters over the weekend, while an animated sequel arrived on tiptoe. “2 Guns” (Universal Pictures), which cost about $60 million to make and stars Denzel Washington and Mark Wahlberg, took in an estimated $27.4 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data.

headline: Victims to Again Face Gunman in Fort Hood Trial
abstract: Staff Sgt. Alonzo M. Lunsford Jr., who was shot seven times by Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan during an attack at the Fort Hood Army base in 2009, will confront his attacker during his testimony.
lead_paragraph: KILLEEN, Tex. — Staff Sgt. Alonzo M. Lunsford Jr. usually worked in the back of the Soldier Readiness Processing Center, giving smallpox shots to deploying and returning troops at the Fort Hood Army base here. But on Nov. 5, 2009, he was standing at the counter at the building’s entrance after 1 p.m., so that his colleagues could take a lunch break.

headline: Navigational Cells Located in Human Brains
abstract: Grid cells, which provide a sort of dead reckoning navigation, had until now only been recorded in some animals.
lead_paragraph: Scientists’ discovery that rodents, bats and nonhuman primates have a system in the brain for what amounts to dead reckoning navigation is one of the most important brain research developments of the past few decades.

headline: Charles Varnadore, Whistle-Blower at Lab, Dies at 71
abstract: In the 1990s Mr. Varnadore publicized questionable safety practices at Oak Ridge National Laboratory in Tennessee, which led to stronger laws protecting workers who complain about employers.
lead_paragraph: After Charles D. Varnadore complained about safety at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory in Tennessee, where he worked as a technician, his bosses moved him to an office containing radioactive waste. When an industrial hygienist recommended that either he or the waste be moved, he was put in a room contaminated with mercury.

headline: Computer-Brain Interfaces Making Big Leaps
abstract: We might not be far away from a day when scientists can use computer-manipulation of the mind for a host of different things.
lead_paragraph: Scientists haven’t yet found a way to mend a broken heart, but they’re edging closer to manipulating memory and downloading instructions from a computer right into a brain.

headline: Brooklyn, Where Exes May Lurk, Tests an Emotional Fugitive
abstract: Adelle Waldman’s debut novel, “The Love Affairs of Nathaniel P.,” scrutinizes the title character and the Brooklyn literary scene he inhabits with a patient, anthropological detachment.
lead_paragraph: Meet Nate Piven. Actually, if you’ve been anywhere near the Brooklyn literary scene in the last 20 years, you’ve already met him.

headline: In Germany, Union Culture Clashes With Amazon’s Labor Practices
abstract: Unions say the company has imported American-style business practices that stand at odds with European norms.
lead_paragraph: In the United States, technology giants like Amazon are often celebrated as fonts of innovation and jobs.

headline: Teenager Is Shot and Killed by Officer on Foot Patrol in the Bronx
abstract: A recent Police Academy graduate killed a 14-year-old boy who, the authorities said, had been chasing another man while brandishing a handgun that he fired at the fleeing man.
lead_paragraph: Just after 3 a.m. on Sunday, the pop of gunshots cut through the air. Two rookie police officers — barely a month out of the Police Academy, and now on foot patrol in the Bronx — hurried toward the sound.

headline: Wind Is at Lewis’s Back at British Open as Park Misses Record
abstract: Stacy Lewis backed up her pre-tournament words, and Inbee Park’s bid for her fourth major title of the year ended in a tie for 42nd at St. Andrews.
lead_paragraph: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — Stacy Lewis forecast the Women’s British Open better than the meteorologists. It’s not her fault that few people were paying attention.

headline: In Nursing Homes, an Epidemic of Poor Dental Hygiene
keywords: ['Elder Care', 'Hygiene and Cleanliness', 'Nursing Homes', 'Pneumonia', 'Teeth and Dentistry']
abstract: The lack of daily oral care in nursing facilities is almost universally overlooked, experts say, and studies suggest that it may contribute to pneumonia, a leading killer of institutionalized older people.
lead_paragraph: Katherine Ford visited her father, Dean Piercy, a World War II veteran with dementia, at a nursing home in Roanoke, Va., for months before she noticed the dust on his electric toothbrush. His teeth, she found, had not been brushed recently, so she began doing it herself after their lunches together.

headline: A Scottish Actor to Star in ‘Doctor Who’
abstract: Peter Capaldi becomes the 12th incarnation of the time-traveling character known simply as the Doctor.
lead_paragraph: When a science-fiction hero has lived for centuries, journeyed to the farthest reaches of the universe and been reincarnated multiple times, how much change can he undergo in 50 years?

headline: Former Envoy to Syria Said to Be Choice for Cairo Post
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry recommended Robert S. Ford, who most recently served as a link to the Syrian opposition in the civil war, officials said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John Kerry has recommended that Robert S. Ford serve as the next American ambassador to Egypt, American officials said Sunday, a critical role at a time of rising turmoil and anti-Americanism in the traditional Arab ally.

lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Hassan Rouhani was sworn in as Iran’s president during a ceremony in Parliament on Sunday, after which he presented a new cabinet dominated by technocrats who had previously served under a moderate former president, Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani.

abstract: As a young major leaguer, Alex Rodriguez talked about the effect of his missing father on his life.
lead_paragraph: The singular event in the life of Alex Rodriguez is not his imminent suspension, or the career home run record that now will never happen.

headline: Traveling Through Time and Memory, Thanks to Adès and Beethoven
abstract: The Calder Quartet played Adès and Beethoven at the Kaplan Penthouse Saturday; earlier, the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra offered a Beethoven piano concerto and symphony.
lead_paragraph: No music captures the time-crossing potential of the Mostly Mozart Festival quite like Thomas Adès’s “Arcadiana,” which the Calder Quartet played in a superb late-night concert at the Kaplan Penthouse on Saturday.

headline: No Show in Russia for Bloodhound Gang
abstract: An act of irreverent humor by the American rock band Bloodhound Gang was seen as offensive by Russians and Russian authorities.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW – Memo to the Bloodhound Gang: In choosing acts of irreverent humor, keep in mind the next leg of your tour.

headline: Venerable Traditions Meet to Stimulate Eyes, Ears and Souls
abstract: The sights? Yellow and blue feathers, unusual instruments. The sounds? Straight from the bands that drive New Orleans parades and Brazilian carnivals, united for Lincoln Center Out of Doors.
lead_paragraph: Two carnival cultures converged by way of New York City on Friday night at Damrosch Park. A Lincoln Center Out of Doors concert hailed the African diaspora kinship of two venerable parade traditions: Mardi Gras Indians from New Orleans, represented by Big Chief Monk Boudreaux and the Golden Eagles; and the maracatu de nação (nation maracatu) of Pernambuco, in northeastern Brazil, with Maracatu Nação Estrela Brilhante (“Maracatu Nation Bright Star”), from Recife.

abstract: Excerpts from Muhammad Abu Hashem's interrogation by the Israeli police along with photos of his arrest.
lead_paragraph: Excerpts from Muhammad Abu Hashem's interrogation by the Israeli police along with photos of his arrest.

headline: Born Again in a Second Language
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Language and Languages', 'Philosophy', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: To abandon your native tongue and adopt another is to dismantle yourself, piece by piece, and then to put yourself together again in a different form.
lead_paragraph: In her exploration of the Catholic religion, “Letter to a Priest,” written the year before her death in 1943, Simone Weil noticed at some point that “for any man a change of religion is as dangerous a thing as a change of language is for a writer. It may turn out a success, but it can also have disastrous consequences.” The Romanian philosopher Emil Cioran, who was one such writer, talks of the change of language as a catastrophic event in any author’s biography. And rightly so.

headline: Whistle-Blower Has Inspired a Welsh Troupe
abstract: The National Theater of Wales staging of “The Radicalisation of Bradley Manning” opens a three-week run at the Edinburgh Festival, and the timing could hardly be better.
lead_paragraph: CARDIFF, Wales — “Bradley Manning is a traitor.”

headline: Mets’ Woes in the Field Look Ugly in Daylight

lead_paragraph: There was snow in Colorado, rain in Atlanta, a heat wave in July. Weather-related obstacles have seemed to trail the Mets all season.

The two-time defending champions were District 9, Florida: Warren Spector of Palm Beach, Michael Becker and David Berkowitz of Boca Raton, Gary Cohler of Miami, and Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell of Clearwater Beach. They faced District 24, New York City and Long Island: Jared Lilienstein, Michael Polowan, Brian Glubok, Sam Lev, John Hurd and Joel Wooldridge, all of New York City.

headline: U.S. Extends Closing of Some Diplomatic Posts
abstract: Nineteen diplomatic missions in the Middle East and North Africa will be shut down through at least Saturday because of continued fears of attacks by Al Qaeda and its allies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Nineteen American diplomatic outposts across the Middle East and North Africa will remain closed this week, the State Department said Sunday, despite what officials said was no new information about terrorist plots that they believe are in the works.

headline: ‘Buy Local’ Gets Creative
abstract: Community-supported art programs are popping up all over the country, demonstrating that the concept works just as well for art lovers as for locavores.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — For years, Barbara Johnstone, a professor of linguistics at Carnegie Mellon University here, bought shares in a C.S.A. — a community-supported agriculture program — and picked up her occasional bags of tubers or tomatoes or whatever the member farms were harvesting.

headline: A Sleeper Success Defines Novelist’s Debut and Legacy
abstract: This summer’s sleeper hit, “The Silent Wife,” a chronicle of a marriage gone wrong, is a Toronto author’s first published novel.
lead_paragraph: The blockbuster novel of last summer was “Gone Girl” by Gillian Flynn, a dark, psychological thriller about a broken marriage, told by warring spouses in alternating chapters. This summer, there is “The Silent Wife” by A. S. A. Harrison, a sleeper hit that happens to answer to the same description.

headline: In Any Language, Torture Debases the Abused and the Abusers
abstract: Based on an autobiographical essay by a South Korean dissident, “National Security” delves into the experiences of prison life and torture.
lead_paragraph: For almost all of the 106 minutes that “National Security” requires to make its pounded-home point, we are confined to the same ugly, airless interrogation room as Park Won-sang, the film’s much-abused star. By the time we are all released, Mr. Park is unlikely to be the only one looking fatigued.

headline: An Open-Air Stage for Feet and Wings
abstract: The Vail International Dance Festival in Colorado includes performances ranging from ballet to street.
lead_paragraph: VAIL, Colo. — The Vail International Dance Festival — this year celebrating its 25th anniversary — abounds in historic, daring and once-only conjunctions, partnerships, experiments. It seems only appropriate that hummingbirds and swallows are routinely seen during the early-evening walk from town, alongside a rushing stream, up to the Gerald R. Ford Amphitheater, that the open-air performances are surrounded by mountains, and that the walk back yields views of a night sky crowded with unusually large stars. This is my seventh summer visit here; I’ve learned to look forward to seeing wonders onstage and off.

headline: One Who Can’t Catch a Break
abstract: A way-out-there puzzle by Alan Arbesfeld.

headline: Mixed Blessings
abstract: Early detection of cancer helps some patients but not others.
lead_paragraph: Pity the poor patient who tries to make sense of federal advisory committee reports that appear headed in opposite directions. For at least three decades, Americans have been told that it’s best to detect cancers early, when they are theoretically most curable. So it was not all that surprising when an authoritative advisory group recommended that very heavy smokers get an annual CT scan to check for early signs of lung cancer. It was much more surprising, however, when a separate group of experts suggested that for several cancers — including potential lung cancers — early scans are detecting too many abnormalities that aren’t dangerous and should not be treated.

headline: What’s on Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10:30 P.M. (Showtime 2) 2 DAYS IN NEW YORK (2012) Julie Delpy directed and stars in this tale about 48 hours in the life of Marion, a high-strung photographer; her partner, Mingus (Chris Rock, above left, with Ms. Delpy, right, Talen Ruth Riley and Owen Shipman), a journalist and radio host; and their two children from previous relationships, as they all deal with the arrival of Marion’s Parisian family members, who proceed to drive the couple crazy. Marion’s father (played by Ms. Delpy’s father, Albert) is detained at the airport for trying to enter the United States with cheese and sausage taped to his body; her sister (Alexia Landeau) and her sister’s boyfriend (Alex Nahon) smoke weed in an elevator and have noisy sex in the bathroom, possibly involving Mingus’s electric toothbrush. “The driving crazy part is hilarious and persuasive, partly because Ms. Delpy and her cast depart from the usual caricatures of Frenchness while still engaging in broad, silly satire,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. And although Marion and Mingus “never quite seem like a credible, comfortable couple,” he added, the film’s best parts “are those that cast an affectionate, unsentimental eye on the city, which looks lived-in, real and nonmythical, the way that Paris often looks in French movies and New York rarely does in Hollywood confections.”

lead_paragraph: From the time she was a teenager, Jane Lotter, a lifelong resident of Seattle, loved to write — jingles for a greeting card company; news and features for a local real estate magazine; a weekly humor column in the now defunct Jet City Maven; and, most recently, a comic novel, completed shortly before her death last month.

headline: Navigating the Greenway: 1,200-Mile Journey in an Electric Bicycle-Car
abstract: Mark Stewart wanted a bicycle he could use during cold Massachusetts winters. He has ended up riding his Elf bicycle-car from North Carolina to Cambridge, Mass., this summer.
lead_paragraph: Mark Stewart is a bike guy. But Mr. Stewart, a 65-year-old bicycle enthusiast, likes his car, too. By his way of thinking, he can keep his beloved yellow 1998 Saab convertible for a longer time if he rides his bike more. Simple math, he says: drive the car less, and it’ll last longer.

headline: Nate Silver, Superstar

lead_paragraph: Over at Barry Ritholtz’s place, Bob Lefsetz argues that Nate Silver’s departure from the Times heralds a new age of journalism in which the individual journalist builds his or her own brand, and the middlemen — like newspapers — lose power. In fact, he compares Nate to Arcade Fire, who pioneered the modern indie rock movement by creating their own position rather than by relying on record companies.

Unions there say the company has imported American-style business practices — in particular, an antipathy to organized labor — that stand at odds with European norms, Nick Wingfield and Melissa Eddy report.

headline: The Road That Led to Telangana
abstract: The long road from Andhra Pradesh to Telangana.
lead_paragraph: The southern state of Andhra Pradesh was formed in 1956, with Hyderabad as its capital, on the principle of reorganizing Indian states on a linguistic basis. Andhra Pradesh combined the Telugu-speaking region of the former princely state of Hyderabad and the Telugu-speaking region of Seemandhra, which was part of the Madras Presidency. Hyderabad was a ruled by a princely ruler, the Nizam, and supervised by a British resident, and the Seemandhra region was ruled directly by the British authorities. The Seemandhra region includes four southern districts of Rayalseema region, and the nine districts of Coastal Andhra, along the shore of Bay of Bengal.

headline: A Focus on Greed in Tourre Case
abstract: The jurors in the S.E.C.’s case against Fabrice Tourre say their decision came down to what they saw as the letter of the law. | A revised agreement over Dell keeps the takeover effort alive. | Clawback policies, though a hot topic, are rarely enforced. | Bank of New York Mellon wins a gender bias case.
lead_paragraph: Tension mounted among the nine jurors in the federal courthouse in Lower Manhattan last week as they examined the nuances of the Securities and Exchange Commission’s case against Fabrice P. Tourre, a former Goldman Sachs trader. By 3:12 p.m. on Thursday, the jury had reached a verdict, deciding Mr. Tourre was liable on six of the seven counts. “Ultimately, the jurors said, their decision came down to what they saw as the letter of the law and, for some, a broader concern that Mr. Tourre’s actions underscored a fundamental problem with society: Wall Street greed,” Susanne Craig, Ben Protess and Alexandra Stevenson report in DealBook.

headline: Samuel Beckett at 59E59 Theaters
abstract: Trevor Nunn’s well-received 2012 stage adaptation of the  Samuel Beckett radio play “All That Fall,” starring Eileen Atkins and Michael Gambon, will be presented in New York at the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: Trevor Nunn’s well-received 2012 stage adaptation of the haunting Samuel Beckett radio play “All That Fall,” starring Eileen Atkins and Michael Gambon, will be presented in New York at the end of the year, following runs at two London theaters last fall. The show, a highlight of the coming season at 59E59 Theaters, features a deceptively simple plot: A woman heads to meet her blind husband at a train station. But this is Beckett, after all, and the story turns out to be more of a tragicomic meditation on life and death. Mr. Nunn’s production, because of restrictions set by the Beckett estate, is presented in the form of a live radio play, with actors holding scripts and using minimal props. The 2013-14 season at 59E59 Theaters, to be announced on Monday, is also to include “I Can See Clearly Now (The Wheelchair on My Face)” (Sept. 10 to 29), a solo show written and performed by Sonya Kelly, courtesy of the Dublin company Fishamble: The New Play Company; “Witnessed by the World” (Nov. 7 to Dec. 15), a play by Ronnie Cohen and Jane Beale, starring Tovah Feldshuh as a journalist fixated on the assassination of John F. Kennedy; Squonk Opera’s surreal meditation on the visualization of music, “Mayhem and Majesty” (Dec. 10 to 29); and “Beertown” (Jan. 30 to Feb. 16), about a town’s time capsule. “All That Fall” is scheduled to run Nov. 5 to Dec. 8 at 59E59 Theaters, which also produces the annual “Brits Off Broadway” festival, planned for April 1 to June 29.

headline: Alan Menken Goes for the EGOT (and the REGOT)

abstract: The composer Alan Menken, who recently received his first Emmy nomination, reflects on winning Grammys, Oscars, a Tony and a Razzie for his contributions to works like “The Little Mermaid,” “Aladdin” and “Newsies.”
lead_paragraph: Few composers are more decorated than Alan Menken, a winner of eight Academy Awards for the songs and scores he has helped create for the animated features “The Little Mermaid,” “Beauty and the Beast,” “Aladdin” and “Pocahontas.” He has 11 Grammys, too, for his work on those films and on “Tangled,” and a Tony for his score of Broadway’s “Newsies the Musical.” (The original film from which that show is adapted also nabbed Mr. Menken a Golden Raspberry Award — better known as a Razzie — for worst original song.)

headline: Sugary Beverages Linked to Higher B.M.I. in Young Children
abstract: Regular consumption of sugar-sweetened beverages has been linked to a higher body mass index in young children. Causation? Correlation? Does it matter?
lead_paragraph: It sounds like another page from the files of obvious research: a study published in the journal Pediatrics reveals a link between regular consumption of sugar-sweetened beverages (dubbed S.S.B.’s) and higher body mass index scores in 2- to 5-year-olds. Children who regularly drank sugar-sweetened sodas, sports beverages or fruit juice (as opposed to 100 percent fruit juice drinks) had both higher B.M.I.’s and “higher weight status” than those who drank them infrequently or not at all.

headline: G.M. Had a Version of OnStar in 1966
abstract: Before there were satellites and personal computers, General Motors’ researchers had set up a system that, using magnets, sensors and C.B. radios, did almost everything OnStar does today.
lead_paragraph: It has been nearly two decades since General Motors introduced OnStar. Since then, it has served as electronic emergency nurse, computerized auto theft detective and binary butler for millions of motorists. Sure, it’s had its problems – as when G.M. decided to make the switch to digital in 2008 and told all the analog customers their equipment would no longer work. But for the most part, it has been a functional system. It must be; OnStar has already cycled through nearly a dozen hardware and software updates over the years.

headline: Portraits by Bob Dylan to Be Shown at London’s National Portrait Gallery
abstract: “Bob Dylan: Face Value,” an exhibition of 12 pastel portraits made by the iconoclastic singer-songwriter, will be the first show of his work at a British museum.
lead_paragraph: Bob Dylan told us that everything would be different when he painted his masterpiece, but for this iconoclastic singer-songwriter, creating artwork and having it shown at internationally regarded institutions is becoming an increasingly regular experience. On Monday, the National Portrait Gallery in London became the latest museum — and the first ever in Britain — to announce that it will devote to Mr. Dylan’s (non-musical) work. This exhibition, called “Bob Dylan: Face Value,” will open on Aug. 24 and will display 12 pastel portraits made by him, the museum said.

headline: Listen Up | A Soulful Torch Song From the Brooklyn Vocalist Diane Birch
abstract: The first single from the singer-songwriter’s new album, which premieres here, features contributions from Questlove of the Roots and Adele’s producer Eg White.
lead_paragraph: The first song Diane Birch wrote for her forthcoming album, “Speak a Little Louder” (out Oct. 15), didn’t quite go as planned. “All the Love You Got” — which makes its world premiere here — is an irresistibly defiant, stirring anthem in the vein of Dusty Springfield and Diana Ross. But, “when I wrote this song, I was in the head space of the disco era, and early ’80s dance music,” explained the 30-year-old Brooklyn-based singer-songwriter. “It had a lot of Prince references, along with Madonna, Blondie and the music Nile Rodgers made with David Bowie. But then I realized it’s not a dance song — it had to be a ballad.”

headline: Gay Bashing Inside the Garden Ring
abstract: The Kremlin expands such resources on fanning hatred that there is no thing as a protected space for gays, lesbians or the otherwise different in Russia.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — After she got home at 5 a.m. Vera Kichanova wrote on Facebook,“I thought all those awful homophobia stories happened outside the Garden Ring,” referring to the avenue that circles central Moscow. “Inside the Garden Ring” is a geographic and social appellation: With its overpriced designer apartments, luxury boutiques and at least a couple of coffee shops on every block, the area is generally considered a world onto itself. Some use the term pejoratively, to indicate rich people who are out of touch with reality; others use it to denote a perceived protected space inside an increasingly reactionary country.

Its daily rhythms were defined by the twin activities of farming and fishing. But once Mahinda Rajapaksa, one of its native sons, became president in 2005, all that began to change.

headline: Icons of Cruelty
abstract: The stories behind two unforgettable images of the Civil War.
lead_paragraph: Two iconic photographs of former slaves documenting the torture inflicted on them by their owners were widely circulated during the Civil War as anti-slavery propaganda, and both appear in the current exhibit “Photography and the American Civil War” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Although the images were extensively reproduced and helped to turn public opinion against slavery, the stories of the two men in these shocking photographs are little known today.

headline: The Gray Line of ‘Confidential’ Information
keywords: ['Hedge Funds', 'Insider Trading', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: The insider trading case against an analyst who tipped off a trader at SAC Capital Advisors about Microsoft-Yahoo talks in 2009 is not typical because he also shared the information with others, possibly lifting the veil of confidentiality.
lead_paragraph: The insider trading case against SAC Capital Advisors seems to be all about the trading “edge,” a term the firm’s owner, Steven A. Cohen, once said he hated. Under the securities laws, proving a violation requires showing that the information used was nonpublic, which means it was not already available in the stock market — the edge that can make for lucrative profits and sidestepping big losses.

On Monday, NBC announced that Mr. Seacrest would be the host of “The Million Second Quiz,” an interactive game show that is taking over nearly two weeks of the network’s schedule in September.

headline: A Unique Collection Worthy of Framing (Pictures Not Included)
abstract: Diego Salazar, a collector of antique frames and an owner of three buildings, has a sharp eye for things most people overlook.
lead_paragraph: At a gallery in Long Island City, Queens, Diego Salazar displays his unique collection of art, which is as lovely as it is peculiar. About 250 pieces hang in his main gallery, stacked one inside the next like Russian dolls. Some are covered in cherubs or crosses, others are gilded, and a few are more than 400 years old.

headline: Qaeda Leader’s Edict to Yemen Affiliate Is Said to Prompt Alert
abstract: American officials said the head of Al Qaeda ordered the leader of the group’s affiliate in Yemen to carry out an attack as early as this past Sunday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration’s decision last week to close nearly two dozen diplomatic missions and issue a worldwide travel alert came after the United States intercepted electronic communications in which the head of Al Qaeda ordered the leader of the group’s affiliate in Yemen to carry out an attack as early as this past Sunday, according to American officials.

headline: ‘Leaning In’ to Lego Camp
abstract: I asked the camp counselors to make sure Lego camp worked for my outnumbered daughter. “She doesn’t want boys taking over her project. She doesn’t want to fight to be heard.”
lead_paragraph: When my daughter said she wanted to go to a Lego engineering summer camp, I tried to hide my excitement. I’ve had an eye on gender gaps in everything from government to the sciences since giving birth to Frankie. As far as I knew, though, she played with dolls, not Legos, on play dates. Frankie’s sudden interest in engineering felt like a win.

headline: ‘American Psycho’-Style Specs From Oliver Peoples and Miller’s Oath
abstract: The West Coast eyewear designer teamed up with the East Coast haberdashery for a new glasses collection that harks back to the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: Oliver Peoples frames were the preferred eyewear of the late-’80s business set (Patrick Bateman, of “American Psycho” fame, was a fan) because they were simply the best: carefully made, modern, low-key and refined. Now Larry Leight, the co-founder and creative director of the brand (now owned by Luxottica), is reaching back into his ’80s briefcase and issuing a capsule collection called Sir, which includes tortoiseshell versions of three iconic frames — the O’Malley, the Finley and the Kent — from 1987, the year Oliver Peoples came out with its first collection.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Kimball Gets First IndyCar Win
abstract: Charlie Kimball drives to IndyCar victory at Mid-Ohio, and Kasey Kahne squeaks a last-minute win at Pocono Raceway.
lead_paragraph: Charlie Kimball took the checkered flag at Sunday’s Mid-Ohio IndyCar series event, his first victory. Kimball took the lead with 18 laps to go in the 90-lap event, with a pass of Simon Pagenaud. Pagenaud, who didn’t give up easily, held on for a tenacious second place, followed by Dario Franchitti and Will Power. Helio Castroneves, the series points leader, finished sixth.

headline: Comparing Republicans With the Mainstream
abstract: There’s a disconnect between what the general population and G.O.P. voters want in a politician.
lead_paragraph: It seems like every week brings fresh evidence of the disconnect between Republicans and the mainstream. A Pew survey published last Wednesday indicated that 54 percent of Republicans think their ultra-conservative party is just not conservative enough. Today’s entry is a Quinnipiac poll that asked voters to rank politicians based on how they felt about them, from a cold zero to a hot 100. The gap between the general population and self-identified G.O.P. voters was vast.

lead_paragraph: Science giveth, but it also taketh away. This week, a “high status” medieval coffin was opened to reveal another coffin. And what was being called “the comet of the century” is shaping up to be an interstellar bummer. But look, here comes the “Fireball Champion.”

headline: ‘Gnarly’ Moments in the Life of an Extreme Photographer
abstract: Mike Escamilla doesn’t just jump out of planes; he takes stunning pictures of himself while doing it.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Mike Escamilla describes himself as a stuntman, professional BMX rider, actor, photographer, filmmaker, director, producer and designer. (He’s also a former X-Games competitor. In 2005 he set world records for the longest back flip and longest 360 on a BMX bike.) And he keeps an itinerary that would exhaust many photojournalists (and make many more envious); since May of this year he has been to Spain, Denmark, Sweden, Finland, Russia, Estonia, Latvia, Puerto Rico, Dominica, Ecuador, Germany, San Francisco and Colorado. When I came across his images on Instagram, it was clear that they were shot by someone with daring and an eye for unusual angles, giving new definition to Robert Capa’s famous advice to photographers: “If your pictures aren’t good enough, you aren’t close enough.”

headline: Slow Start for Taxi-Hailing Apps, City Data Show

lead_paragraph: They were billed as a game-changing way to hail taxis in New York City, upsetting the urban democracy of the outstretched arm and geographic savvy, and replacing it with a smartphone app.

headline: Can Immunity to the Common Cold Come With Age?
abstract: As immunity to different viruses builds up over time, it decreases the number of viral types that can make one sick, an expert says.
lead_paragraph: Q. My mother, who lived to be 92, never caught my sniffles in her later years, even though I was her sole caretaker. And now that I’m in my 60s, I notice that my colds are less severe. Is it possible to develop immunity to the common cold?

headline: MoMA Joins Tumblr to Reach Teens

lead_paragraph: The Museum of Modern Art in New York joined Tumblr on Monday with a new Web site aimed at teenagers, called MoMA Teens. Calder Zwicky, an associate educator at the museum, said they have been working on the site for the past nine months.

Twenge and one of her most prominent critics, Jeffrey Arnett, to debate “whether today’s emerging adults are excessively ‘narcissistic,’ ” as Dr. Twenge asserts. headline: A Library Where the Hush Is Over Its Very Existence
abstract: City Hall Library, like a sister unit, the Municipal Archives, is hidden inside the Surrogate’s Court building, living in obscurity despite housing 350,000 books, periodicals, journals and volumes of clippings.
lead_paragraph: Nothing on the street outside says that it is there. First-time visitors must push through a revolving door of a court building in Lower Manhattan on faith, and hear their footsteps echo across a vast marble lobby before they finally glimpse a set of wooden double doors near a staircase leading down to a goblin-dark basement.

headline: ‘Teen Beach Movie’ Gets Big Ratings for Disney

lead_paragraph: “Teen Beach Movie” is a certified smash. Disney Channel said on Monday that about 13.5 million people had watched the beach party musical, which had its premiere on July 19. That total includes the number of viewers who watched it live (8.4 million) and a week’s worth of DVR playback viewing, a standard industry measuring stick.

headline: A Return to the Lineup and a Fight to Stay
abstract: Alex Rodriguez was in the Yankees’ lineup on Monday night, and with an appeal almost certain, he could remain there for the rest of the season.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Alex Rodriguez sat in the far corner of the Yankees clubhouse Monday afternoon, staring at a computer screen displaying video images of Chicago White Sox pitcher Jose Quintana, whom he would soon be facing. A mere 30 minutes had passed since Major League Baseball had announced Rodriguez was being suspended for 211 games in connection with its months-long doping investigation, but Rodriguez, the 38-year-old third baseman, appeared unfazed.

headline: Bridges Under Construction at Newport Jazz
abstract: In its latest edition, which featured Chick Corea, Herbie Hancock, Esperanza Spalding and Amir ElSaffar, the Newport Jazz Festival showed that even as it spotlights the music’s older guard, it’s eager to restock with the new.
lead_paragraph: NEWPORT, R.I. — The Newport Jazz Festival, which ended Sunday at Fort Adams State Park here, is 59 now. It had early brilliance followed by middle-age aesthetic confusion, edging into pop and smooth jazz. Over the last nine years, it has corrected its course, entering a new period of steadiness and dignity as it seeks a new framing of jazz — and of its own audience.

headline: Nursing Homes’ Dental Problems

lead_paragraph: Catherine Saint Louis speaks about why daily oral care in nursing facilities is almost universally overlooked, and why that can lead to dangerous complications for residents.

headline: Fresh Memo From a Desk Full of Song
abstract: In a European summer of innovative opera productions, Stefan Herheim reimagines Wagner’s “Meistersinger” at the Salzburg Festival.
lead_paragraph: SALZBURG, Austria — The Salzburg Festival is celebrating Wagner’s 200th birthday with a fresh, charming and perceptive new production of “Die Meistersinger von Nürnberg,” which opened here at the Grosses Festspielhaus on Friday. The conductor Daniele Gatti, who won many new admirers for his performances of Wagner’s “Parsifal” at the Metropolitan Opera last season, drew a full-bodied and intriguingly intense performance of this composer’s sunniest score from the great Vienna Philharmonic. The cast over all was admirable, especially the distinguished German baritone Michael Volle, who brought the requisite gravitas and poignant vulnerability to his portrayal of the wise widower Hans Sachs, a shoemaker and the most beloved member of the guild of master singers in the medieval German city of Nürnberg, where the story is set.

headline: Small Troupe With Outsize Talent? You’re In
abstract: Ballet v6.0, a new 12-day festival opening on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater, creates an opening for small troupes that may lack the popular following for a full-week run.
lead_paragraph: In 1998, about a year after Jessica Lang had graduated from the dance division of Juilliard, she went back to ask Benjamin Harkarvy, then the division’s director, for advice. She was interested in choreography, she told him, and since the first piece she had created had been well received, she thought she should start her own troupe. “Just because you made one good work,” Mr. Harkarvy replied, “doesn’t mean you should have a company.”

headline: Florida to Execute a Paranoid Schizophrenic
abstract: John Errol Ferguson was convicted of murdering 8 people. He also saw himself as the “Prince of God” and believed he could “control the sun.”
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court has declined to stay the execution of John Errol Ferguson, who is scheduled to die at 6 p.m. Monday evening in Florida.

headline: In the Opera’s Shadow, Another Gem
abstract: The Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival attracts top musicians from around the country to perform and listen.
lead_paragraph: SANTA FE, N.M. — The Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival presents top-flight performers in attractive theaters in the historic heart of the city each summer and has a strong following among locals and tourists alike. Sadly, it is overshadowed in national awareness, by the Santa Fe Opera, with its spectacular open-air theater a few miles north of the city and its fancy productions. Critics flock to the opera, often without even bothering to see what is playing at the chamber festival.
