headline: A Reconsideration of Katue Kitasono, Japan’s Great Poet of Surrealism
abstract: A new show at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art examines the diverse legacy of a multifarious artist.
lead_paragraph: Until recently, Japan’s artistic reputation in the United States was limited mainly to the very old and the very new: Edo-period ceramics and paintings, and the manga-inspired “Superflat” movement of the 1990s that was ushered in by Takashi Murakami. Recently, however, American curators have been taking stock of Japan’s compelling postwar output with 2013 exhibits like “Tokyo 1955-1970: A New Avant-Garde” at MoMA, the Guggenheim’s “Gutai: Splendid Playground,” about the progressive art collective that operated in the Kansai region, and last year’s Yayoi Kusama pop art extravaganza at the Whitney.

headline: Cruise Lines Report Crime Statistics
abstract: Royal Caribbean Cruises, Carnival Corporation and Norwegian Cruise Line have posted on their Web sites the number of serious crimes reported on their ships, the first public airing of such statistics.
lead_paragraph: Three major cruise lines have posted on their Web sites the number of serious crimes reported on their ships, the first public airing of such statistics. The lines, Royal Caribbean Cruises, Carnival Corporation and Norwegian Cruise Line, released the figures in the wake of a Senate bill that would require all cruise lines that use American ports to report crime figures. (Currently, the Coast Guard reports crimes that are no longer under investigation by the F.B.I.)

Biden Jr. arriving this week for a vacation in Southampton. Former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton has rented a house for August here in East Hampton, the next township over.

abstract: Facing possible bankruptcy, Detroit has hired the auction house Christie’s to evaluate the value of part of its collection at the Detroit Institute of Arts.
lead_paragraph: The city of Detroit, which has filed for bankruptcy, has formally hired the international auction house Christie’s to appraise part of the city-owned art collection held by the Detroit Institute of Arts, the auction house said Monday.Any decision about whether to sell the art to satisfy creditors has not been made, city officials have said, though all the city’s assets are being evaluated in light of the situation in Detroit, the largest American city ever to file for bankruptcy.

abstract: One crew member was missing after a United States military helicopter crashed during a training exercise on Japan’s southern island of Okinawa on Monday, the Air Force said.
lead_paragraph: One crew member was missing after a United States military helicopter crashed during a training exercise on Japan’s southern island of Okinawa on Monday, the Air Force said. The three other crew members were in stable condition after the HH-60 helicopter crashed in an uninhabited training area on an American base, the Air Force said. No Okinawan civilians were injured, the local news media said. Still, Japanese officials in Tokyo expressed concern that the accident could stoke anger against the large American military presence on Okinawa. Defense Minister Itsunori Onodera demanded an investigation.

abstract: Mr. Suares, the first Op-Ed page art director at The New York Times, began a visual era for editorial illustrations that influenced many other publications.
lead_paragraph: Jean-Claude Suares, an illustrator who radically altered the way editorial illustration was used at The New York Times as the first art director of its Op-Ed page, died on July 30 in Engelwood, N.J. He was 71.

headline: Canada: Escaped Snake Kills 2 Children, Police Say
abstract: Two children were killed in their sleep by a python that escaped from a pet shop, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police said Monday.
lead_paragraph: Two children were killed in their sleep by a python that escaped from a pet shop, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police said Monday. The boys, 5 and 7 years old, were sleeping over at a friend’s apartment above the store in Campbellton, New Brunswick, when the snake apparently made its way in through a ventilation shaft. An autopsy will determine the exact cause of death, but a police spokeswoman said it appeared that the children had been suffocated. It was not immediately clear how the snake had escaped from the store, but police officers recaptured it.

headline: Dying Lawyer Asks Judge to Free Her From Prison

lead_paragraph: Lynne F. Stewart, the outspoken former defense lawyer and a polarizing figure in the criminal justice system, is fighting her final battle.

headline: New York Tells Online Lenders to Abide by State’s Interest Rate Cap
abstract: Letters are sent to 35 online lenders for charging more than New York State’s 25 percent interest rate cap.
lead_paragraph: Government authorities are homing in on a lucrative loophole that allows online lenders to offer short-term loans at interest rates that often exceed 500 percent annually, the latest front in a crackdown on the payday lending industry.

headline: Bankers’ Pay Deferrals Are Tougher in Europe
abstract: Compensation deferral was meant to give employees less incentive to take the kinds of short-term risks that led to the financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: Soon after the financial crisis, international regulators identified Wall Street’s lush pay packages as one of the culprits and proposed an overhaul that was meant to apply equally to employees of American investment banks and their big European rivals.

headline: Lawyers of Sound Mind?

Passing the exam, however, won’t guarantee them admission to the bar. They also have to demonstrate that they possess the requisite fitness and moral character for the practice of law.

headline: Striking Olympic Gold
abstract: The Winter Games in Sochi present a prime opportunity for the world to weigh in on Russia’s anti-gay laws.
lead_paragraph: Imagine this: it’s the opening ceremony of the 2014 Winter Games in Sochi, Russia. A huge television event, watched the world over. The American Olympians join the proud march of nations. They’re our emissaries, our exemplars. And as the television cameras zoom in on Team U.S.A., one of its members quietly pulls out a rainbow flag, no bigger than a handkerchief, and holds it up. Not ostentatiously high, but just high enough that it can’t be mistaken.

headline: Beyond the Airport: The T.S.A.’s VIPR Team
abstract: The Transportation Security Administration issued justification for conducting searches outside airports without probable cause, but an audit raised issues about the training and deployments of the VIPR teams.
lead_paragraph: The Transportation Security Administration issued justification for conducting searches outside airports without probable cause, but an audit raised issues about the training and deployments of the VIPR teams.

headline: Michael J. Morwood, Archaeologist Who Helped Find ‘New Human,’ Dies at 62
abstract: In 2003, Dr. Morwood and his team dug up remains of Homo floresiensis, or the little people of Flores who were nicknamed the hobbits, in an Indonesian island cave.
lead_paragraph: Ten years ago, Mike Morwood was a leader of archaeological excavations in a limestone cavern on the Indonesian island of Flores, about midway between the continents of Asia and Australia. That was when he had the experience of a lifetime, as he said many times, the discovery of what he called “a new human.”

headline: A Heisman Winner, and a Rule Book, Under Fire
abstract: Allegations that Texas A&M quarterback Johnny Manziel signed autographs for money has heightened public sentiment that is increasingly hostile over the N.C.A.A.’s amateurism rule.
lead_paragraph: The fallout from the latest episode in Johnny Manziel’s dizzying, TMZ-chronicled off-season extended beyond his inner circle and beyond the campus of Texas A&M and into the offices of the N.C.A.A. That organization, which governs college sports, said nothing about Manziel on Monday, and yet its silence did little to dim the continued criticism lobbed in its direction.

headline: Marilyn Monroe’s Star Still Shines in Ad Campaigns
abstract: More than 50 years after her death, Marilyn Monroe still attracts attention and sales.
lead_paragraph: FOR an advertising campaign that aims to appeal to women from 18 to 25, Sexy Hair, the hair care brand, did not hire a celebrity spokeswoman within that age bracket like Selena Gomez or Emma Watson. Rather, the brand is featuring an actress who, had she not died in 1962, would be 87 today: Marilyn Monroe.

headline: With No New iPad, Tablet Market Takes a Dip
abstract: Apple didn’t release a new iPad in the first half of the year, as it usually does, and guess what happened? Sales of tablets worldwide took a dip.
lead_paragraph: Last fall, Apple introduced both the fourth generation of its popular iPad tablet and a new, mini version. Tech industry researchers figured the double release would mean no new iPads to lift Apple’s sales in the first half of 2013, as had been the case in other years.

headline: Across Forbidden Border, Doctors in Israel Quietly Tend to Syria’s Wounded
abstract: As the Syrian civil war rages, scores of Syrian casualties have been discreetly spirited across the hostile frontier for lifesaving treatment in Israel, an enemy country.
lead_paragraph: NAHARIYA, Israel — The 3-year-old girl cried “Mama, Mama” over and over as a stranger rocked her and tried to comfort her. She had been brought from Syria to the government hospital in this northern Israeli town five days earlier, her face blackened by what doctors said was probably a firebomb or a homemade bomb.

headline: Art Donovan, a Behemoth of Modesty, Dies at 89
abstract: Donovan, a 300-pound tackle on the Baltimore Colts’ championship teams in 1958 and 1959, was known for his self-deprecating modesty.
lead_paragraph: Art Donovan, a 300-pound tackle for the Baltimore Colts whose nimble brutality helped propel him to the Hall of Fame and his team to two championships in the 1950s, and whose humor-laced tales about himself and the game won him an equal helping of celebrity, died on Sunday in Baltimore. He was 89.

headline: What Killed Theory? (Wonkish)
abstract: Memories, from trade and macro.
lead_paragraph: Noah Smith has an interesting note on the “death of theory” in economics. Obviously that’s an exaggeration, but there has been a measurable decline in the number of papers that offer theoretical innovations as opposed to empirical analysis, and also a harder to measure but unmistakable shift in the profession’s value structure, with empiricists reaping greater rewards and theorists valued less.

headline: What’s on Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 6:50 A.M. (Cinemax) MATCH POINT (2005) Chris (Jonathan Rhys Meyers), an Irish tennis player recently retired from the professional circuit, climbs the British social ladder after taking a job at a London club, helping its rich members polish their strokes. Soon, he has befriended Tom (Matthew Goode), an heir to a business fortune; has wooed his sister, Chloe (Emily Mortimer); and maneuvered himself into the family firm and into the family as Tom’s brother-in-law. But then Chris meets Tom’s fiancée, a scrappy American actress, Nola (Scarlett Johansson, above, with Mr. Rhys Meyers), and suddenly the temperature of his life increases from a polite simmer to a full sexual boil. “What passes between Chris and Nola is not only desire, but also recognition, which makes their connection especially volatile,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times, describing this drama as “a Champagne cocktail laced with strychnine.” He added: “As their affair advances, Ms. Johansson and Mr. Rhys Meyers manage some of the best acting seen in a Woody Allen movie in a long time, escaping the archness and emotional disconnection that his writing often imposes. It is possible to identify with both of them — and to feel an empathetic twinge as they are ensnared in the consequences of their own heedlessness — without entirely liking either one. But it is the film’s brisk, chilly precision that makes it so bracingly pleasurable. The gloom of random, meaningless existence has rarely been so much fun, and Mr. Allen’s bite has never been so sharp, or so deep. A movie this good is no laughing matter.”

headline: A Reunion With My Younger, Hitchhiking Self

The doors shut; the latch turned.

headline: Did We Waste a Recession?
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Economy', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)']
abstract: As the financial crisis nears its fifth anniversary, economists agree on one thing. Too bad nobody is really listening.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago this month, before Lehman Brothers imploded and the global economy lurched to a halt, Fannie Mae issued a report that encapsulated the financial system’s biggest problem. The mortgage-finance company, which was wobbling on account of rising defaults, tried to reassure investors that it had $47 billion in capital, which was considerably more than the $30 million required by law. At the time, the report’s authors seemed to fear that some investors might think Fannie was too cautious. In any event, a month later, that protection seemed like a joke. Fannie may have conformed to the rules, but the rules didn’t conform to reality. The lender and its brother company, Freddie Mac, were declared insolvent and handed over to the U.S. government.

headline: Another Bad Story Bites The Dust
abstract: Uncertainty? Never mind.
lead_paragraph: One of the remarkable things about the ongoing economic crisis is the endless search for explanations of something that’s actually quite simple — the sluggish pace of recovery. You have a large overhang of private debt; you have a still-depressed housing sector; and you have contractionary fiscal policy. Add to this the well-established fact that recovery tends to be slow after recessions caused not by tight money but by private-sector overreach, and there’s just no mystery that needs explaining.

headline: New York Comedy Festival Sets 2013 Lineup

The festival, which is now in its 10th year and is presented in association with Comedy Central and produced by Carolines on Broadway, will run from Nov. 6 through Nov. 10. Among the announced events is a performance by Ms. Sykes (of “The New Adventures of Old Christine”) on Nov. 7 at the Beacon Theater. Nov. 8 will see performances by Nick Swardson, Bill Burr, Kathy Griffin and Ms. Cummings; and on Nov. 9, Mr. Mulaney (of “Saturday Night Live”), Jim Jefferies, Bill Maher and Anthony Jeselnik will perform at spaces including Town Hall, Carnegie Hall and the Beacon Theater. The conversation between Mr. David, the creator and star of HBO’s “Curb Your Enthusiasm,” and Mr. Steinberg, the longtime comic and host of Showtime’s “Inside Comedy,” will take place at Town Hall on Nov. 10.

headline: The Cartes de Visite Craze
abstract: How these small, personal photographs helped change the way Northerners saw the Civil War.
lead_paragraph: The most indelible images of the Civil War show us the ditches of Antietam, the fields of Gettysburg and the ruins of Richmond. They tell us about modern photography and modern war, but the staple photographs of the home front were not the battlefield views we now know so well. Cartes de visite, the 2 1/2-by-4-inch portraits that dominated commercial photography in the 1860s, both unified and contested wartime visions of the nation.

headline: After Hours | Paulo Szot’s Outsize Broadway Grandeur
abstract: The mustachioed Brazilian baritone brings swashbuckling star power to a weeklong engagement at the Midtown supper club 54 Below.
lead_paragraph: A major swath of New York fell in love with Paulo Szot when he appeared in the 2008 Lincoln Center revival of South Pacific. The mustachioed baritone won a Tony for his gravitas-laden turn as Emile de Becque, the French plantation owner who captures the heart of young Navy nurse Nellie Forbush. Last night, in the high-class-bordello setting of the Midtown supper club 54 Below, Szot, kicking off a weeklong stint there, captured several more hearts… of a certain age. Szot, who has a booming operatic voice and is built like a massive rectangle, swashbuckled into the room from the back, schmoozing his way to a stage where a jazz trio awaited him. Even amid his opening number, a playful mash-up of “Summertime” and “Too Darn Hot,” many a well-heeled matron shrieked or moaned aloud for him.

headline: Republicans, White Voters and Racial Polarization
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)']
abstract: Would it be immoral and divisive for the G.O.P. to exploit liberalism’s white working class weakness?
lead_paragraph: This National Journal piece, the latest to misread Sean Trende’s columns on the “missing white voters” of 2012 as an argument that the G.O.P. should try to build a “whites-only” majority, reminds that I’ve been meaning to write about some of the various liberal responses to Trende’s argument. Not the responses saying that he’s factually or analytically wrong, but the responses that either imply or state that even if he were right that there are a lot of up-for-grabs white votes that the G.O.P. might pursue effectively, it would be immoral, tragic, and/or ruinously divisive if Republicans were to actually try to win this way.

headline: A Call for the Unofficial Mayors of New York
abstract: Tell us: Who is the unofficial mayor of your community?
lead_paragraph: Updated, November 18, 2013 | We are no longer accepting submissions for unofficial mayors in the city. We received more than 200 nominations and have selected nine men and women affecting change in their communities. You can read their stories here. Thanks to everyone who participated!

headline: UBS Agrees to Settle Federal Claims in Mortgage Case
keywords: ['Mortgage-Backed Securities', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: UBS, the giant Swiss bank, has agreed to settle federal accusations that it misled investors about a complex mortgage security.
lead_paragraph: UBS agreed on Tuesday to pay $50 million to settle federal accusations that it misled investors about a complex mortgage security, a transaction that loomed over the government’s recent legal battle with a former Goldman Sachs trader blamed for his role in creating a similar security.

headline: Wheelies: The Power of Pickups Edition
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks']
abstract: Ford adds a third shift at its Kansas City plant to keep up with demand for F-Series pickups, and Consumer Reports tops its best sedans list with the 2014 Chevrolet Impala.
lead_paragraph: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: In Season Short on Star Power, Rodriguez’s Return Lifts Ratings on YES
abstract: Curiosity about Alex Rodriguez’s 2013 debut and suspension attracted a high number of viewers to the Yankees’ broadcast.
lead_paragraph: Injuries have deprived the Yankees of nearly all of their star hitters for lengthy stretches this season. Power has been in short supply. And the starting pitching, most notably C. C. Sabathia, has largely underperformed.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Art in Hard Times
abstract: A former museum director discusses the money spent on art as cities struggle financially. Readers are invited to respond.

headline: Sony Brushoff Leaves Loeb With Few Options
abstract: There are some encouraging signs for the hedge fund tycoon Daniel S. Loeb: even after the latest sell-off, Sony shares are still 8 percent higher than when he started his campaign.
lead_paragraph: The tussle over Sony may be the most courteous shareholder battle ever. In May, the hedge fund manager Daniel S. Loeb respectfully suggested the company spin off a stake in its entertainment arm. Now, the Japanese group’s board has politely rejected the idea. But the activist appears to be digging in for the long haul.

headline: Bean Salad With Tomato Vinaigrette
abstract: What to do with summer’s oozing, overripe tomatoes? Make an intensely flavored vinaigrette.
lead_paragraph: What to do with summer’s oozing, overripe tomatoes? Make an intensely flavored vinaigrette.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Cloud Companies Face Fear-of-Spying Exodus
abstract: The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for important and peculiar items. Tuesday’s selections include an article about how foreign companies are now avoiding American cloud computing services because of concerns that the National Security Agency might spy on them. Plus, a sobering measure on the rise of Internet censorship around the world.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items. While much of the tech and media industries pondered Jeffrey P. Bezos’s deal to buy The Washington Post, Facebook released a feature that re-surfaces old, but what it deems relevant, posts in a user’s news feed. Here’s what else we noticed today:

headline: To Every Vegetable’s Season, Another Season
abstract: Is that vegetable young? Middle-aged? Older? You may want to adjust your cooking to match.
lead_paragraph: I was strolling with Christopher Boswell in the vegetable gardens of the American Academy in Rome, where he is the chef, when he saved me from a rookie mistake.

headline: Facebook Adjusts Its News Feed to Bump Up Older Posts
abstract: Facebook users will see important older items they missed mixed in with newer items as the company tweaks the formulas that drive its news feed. Other changes are also coming, as the company pledges to disclose more about the mysteries of the feed.
lead_paragraph: The Facebook news feed is getting slightly less mysterious — and perhaps more relevant, too.

headline: Art Imitates Life, as a Villain Haunts a Stateside Parking Lot
abstract: “Richard III,” presented by the Drilling Company’s Shakespeare in the Parking Lot, stars Alessandro Colla as the scheming villain.
lead_paragraph: The evil all but oozes from Alessandro Colla, who, as Richard III, shuffles across the asphalt in this year’s second offering from Shakespeare in the Parking Lot. The king’s body is damaged, of course. But, oh, his wicked mind: that’s always working.

headline: Fiona Shaw to Replace Deborah Warner in Directing Met Opera’s ‘Eugene Onegin’
abstract: Ms. Warner withdrew from the production because of “an unexpected surgical procedure,” the Metropolitan Opera said in a statement.
lead_paragraph: Deborah Warner, the British director who was to have overseen the Metropolitan Opera’s new staging of “Eugene Onegin,” has withdrawn from the production. The Met, in a statement, said that she bowed out because of “an unexpected surgical procedure and the expected recovery time.”

headline: Justice Dept. Sues Bank of America Over Mortgage Securities
abstract: The government accused the bank of defrauding investors by vastly understating the risks of the mortgages backing about $850 million worth of mortgage-backed securities.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department sued Bank of America on Tuesday, accusing the bank of defrauding investors by vastly understating the risks of the mortgages backing about $850 million in securities.

headline: Pennsylvania Gunman Feuded With Officials for Almost Two Decades Over Land
abstract: For almost two decades, Rockne Newell battled with town officials over his junk-strewn property, a feud that led to gun violence at a municipal meeting.
lead_paragraph: Angry that town officials in northeastern Pennsylvania took over his junk-strewn, wooded property at a sheriff’s sale last month, Rockne Newell opened fire at a township supervisors meeting on Monday night, killing three people and wounding two others before he was wrestled to the ground by two men, state police officials said on Tuesday.

headline: With Cooked Tomatoes, Stick With Cool Reds or Rosé
abstract: A wide range of wines can work to complement a mellow tomato crostata, though cool reds fare best.
lead_paragraph: Raw tomatoes, high in acid, demand high-acid wines. But cooked-tomato dishes like this crostata are altogether mellower, and so welcome a wider range of wines. A high-acid wine like an unoaked barbera from Asti or Alba would still go beautifully, but so would a Sicilian nerello mascalese from Mount Etna or a good Provençal rosé. Serve the reds cool. White wines would work well, too, like a falanghina or fiano di Avellino from Campania, or a good sauvignon blanc on the herbal side. Personally, because I imagine the flavors of this crostata as broad rather than sharp, I would probably stick with reds or rosé. Other red options include Beaujolais, lighter pinot noirs like those from Sancerre or the range of light reds from northern Italy, like teroldego, lagrein, grignolino and those from the Valle d’Aosta.

headline: Confessions of a ‘Composeress’
abstract: I’ve never considered myself a “woman composer,” but I suspect that over the years being female has helped more than it’s hurt.
lead_paragraph: What is the role of the ”woman composer” and why, after all these years, is she such a burning issue?

headline: A Murder Haunts a Rugged Coast
abstract: “Broadchurch,” an eight-episode series about a criminal investigation, comes to BBC America on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: “Broadchurch” comes to BBC America on Wednesday, riding a wave of good tidings. The ratings in Britain this spring were very strong — just shy of what “Downton Abbey” earned in its first season — and the reviews were rhapsodic. Fox announced last week that it would develop a version of the show, even though the original is getting its own highly publicized American run.

headline: MP Taverna Astoria
abstract: Inside Michael Psilakis’s unrestrained take on a Greek taverna.
lead_paragraph: Inside Michael Psilakis’s unrestrained take on a Greek taverna.

headline: Living in Lloyd Harbor
abstract: On Long Island’s north shore, a village with water views that come with a price.
lead_paragraph: On Long Island’s north shore, a village with water views that come with a price.

headline: Lloyd Harbor, L.I.: This Market Is No Wading Pool
abstract: A secluded waterfront village of 3,400 with expensive homes, strict zoning and no streetlights.
lead_paragraph: In May, after a dozen years in Manhattan, Brian and Kim Olson and their children left behind their Battery Park City rental for a meticulously renovated four-bedroom colonial they had bought for $1.775 million in Lloyd Harbor. Suddenly, the treks to the Hamptons that they had so consistently made from the city became a thing of the past. Mr. Olson, who grew up in this northwestern Suffolk County village an hour from Midtown, felt rejuvenated by his return, as if permanently on vacation.

headline: Indian Music Meets Jazz in Kipling’s Wild World
abstract: The director Mary Zimmerman takes an understated approach in her retelling of “The Jungle Book,” adapted from the Disney movie (and Kipling), at the Goodman Theater.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The flora and fauna of India shimmer with eye-filling allure in the inventive new stage adaptation of “The Jungle Book,” having its premiere at the Goodman Theater here. Adapted from the Disney movie (based on the Rudyard Kipling stories) and directed by Mary Zimmerman, this modestly scaled and refreshingly spectacle-free family musical seeks to kindle children’s imaginations by softly blurring the line between man and beast, relying on the talents of designers and performers to create illusions rather than dazzling the senses with elaborate effects.

headline: A Second-Generation Ode to Greece
abstract: In Queens, an unbridled take on a taverna from Michael Psilakis, poster-size menu and all.
lead_paragraph: If there are tweezers in the kitchen of MP Taverna Astoria, they are banned from all tasks except, perhaps, yanking bones from branzino fillets before they go on the grill. Tweezers are definitely not asked to airlift feathery microgreens onto plates that endeavor to be meditations on negative space.

headline: How Should Gay Couples Fend Off Pressure to Marry?
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Marriages', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Homosexuality']
abstract: Despite winning the right in some states to marry, not all gay couples want to. Not everyone accepts that.
lead_paragraph: Every other Tuesday, Steven Petrow, the author of “Steven Petrow’s Complete Gay & Lesbian Manners” (Workman, 2011), addresses questions about gay and straight etiquette for a boomer-age audience. Send questions for Civil Behavior to stevenpetrow@earthlink.net.

headline: Mayoral Race Is Awash With Clintons’ Friends
abstract: Bill Clinton told an interviewer that he and his wife count five candidates, including a Republican, as friends and won’t get involved in the race.
lead_paragraph: The race for mayor has been awkward for the Clinton family. Hillary Rodham Clinton’s close aide Huma Abedin is married to one of the contenders, Anthony D. Weiner, who has been damaged by his admission that he had a habit of sending sexually explicit messages and pictures to women over the Internet. And in all, Bill Clinton says, five people the family counts as friends are in the running for mayor.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Sudan and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Sudan, India, Pakistan and Argentina.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Sudan, India, Pakistan and Argentina.

headline: Deployment Factors Are Not Related to Rise in Military Suicides, Study Finds
keywords: ['Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Veterans', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: A study found that the forces underlying the jump in military suicides were similar to those in the civilian world: mental illness, substance abuse, and financial and relationship problems.
lead_paragraph: In the largest study of its kind, military medical researchers have concluded that deployments to war zones and exposure to combat were not major factors behind a significant increase in suicides among military personnel from 2001 to 2008, according to a paper published on Tuesday.

headline: Bloomberg Sees Higher Costs in a Union-Friendly Mayor
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Elections, Mayors', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Organized Labor']
abstract: The mayor urged would-be successors not to capitulate when negotiating workers’ pension and health care benefits.
lead_paragraph: Warning of the fiscal danger if New York City fails to rein in its spiraling pension and health care costs, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Tuesday challenged his would-be successors to take a tough line in negotiations with the city’s unions, while worrying aloud that whoever is elected will be too beholden to labor.

headline: In a Vivid Dream, the Old Folks Home Bristles With Life
abstract: A trip to an Italian retirement home associated with Verdi inspired the director of a new “Falstaff” staging to set the opera in the present-day facility, known as Casa Verdi.
lead_paragraph: SALZBURG, Austria — In the early 1890s, while working with the librettist Arrigo Boito on “Falstaff,” his final opera, Verdi was immersed in a plan to build a retirement home in Milan for singers and musicians who had fallen upon hard times. The architect was Camillo Boito, the brother of the librettist.

headline: As Detroit Flounders, Its Art Scene Flourishes
abstract: Though the city filed for bankruptcy last month, not everything is gloomy in Detroit these days.
lead_paragraph: The night of June 20 was the Detroit native and photographer Sebastian Sullen’s first art exhibition, a group show called “Art Ethereal: Beauty and the Beast,” named for his contradictory subject: his city’s majestic architecture and scarred urban blight. Part of a monthly event called Third Thursday, the show packed the Detroit Mercantile Company, a retro general store and event space. There were carrot cake, beer from a nano-brewery and, in the storefront, “You Gotta Save Art!” stickers ($2.50) and T-shirts ($25) for sale in support of the Detroit Institute of Arts.

headline: A San Francisco Museum, Reborn on the Bay
abstract: The Exploratorium science museum has drawn hundreds of thousands of visitors since opening in a new location in April.
lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon along the Embarcadero, San Francisco’s downtown waterfront boulevard, vintage streetcars packed with tourists clattered toward Fisherman’s Wharf, joggers wove through pedestrian herds, and office workers in search of lunchtime sun camped out on every bench, chair and bayside perch. But as lively as this plein-air panorama might have been, it was downright dull compared with the hyperkinetic indoor action at Pier 15, where the new home of the Exploratorium science museum opened recently.

headline: Four Touches, and in the Net
abstract: The Red Bulls’ third goal against Sporting K.C. on Saturday, the eventual game-winner, was a thing of beauty.
lead_paragraph: The Red Bulls’ third goal against Sporting Kansas City on Saturday, the eventual game-winner, was a thing of beauty.

headline: New Tools Pinpoint Natural Gas Leaks, Maximizing a Fuel’s Green Qualities
abstract: The boom in natural gas production has raised concerns about a subsequent boom in leaks, although how much gas escapes remains a mystery.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Natural gas is hailed as green and safe, but its environmental benefits and ability to temper climate change are reduced by its tendency to leak into the air undetected. Now, laser technology, some of it borrowed from the telecommunications industry, is giving engineers and scientists crucial new tools to measure leaks and track them to their source.

headline: Can Parents Stay Friends With the Child-Free?
abstract: I have child-free friends, but I’m forced to admit that since being a parent became my primary non-work activity, more and more of the friends I’ve made have been parents as well.
lead_paragraph: Time magazine’s latest cover piece, “The Childfree Life,” posits a new divide among women. We’ve moved on, it says, from pitting working and at-home parents against one another to stirring up unrest between the child-ridden and the child-free — also known as the child-blessed and the childless, depending on your point of view. (You could say “women with children” versus “women without children,” but then your title would be too long and not nearly provocative enough.)

headline: Dan Silverman Named Chef at Loews Regency Hotel
abstract: The Regency dining room is best known for its power breakfasts, but Mr. Silverman predicted it would become a destination for lunch and dinner, too.
lead_paragraph: Headliner

headline: Copyright Lawsuit Targets Cover Songs on YouTube
abstract: A group of music publishers has sued Fullscreen, a leading supplier of videos to YouTube, saying that many of its videos infringe on their copyrights.
lead_paragraph: In the latest sign of friction over the licensing of online music, a group of music publishers has sued Fullscreen, one of the largest suppliers of videos to YouTube, saying that many of Fullscreen’s videos — particularly cover versions of popular songs — infringe on the publishers’ copyrights.

headline: The Voice of the Syrian Watchtower
abstract: Mudar Abu Ali is the eyes and voice not of one man in one place, but of many men scattered across the northern Syrian countryside.
lead_paragraph: Mudar Abu Ali is the eyes and voice not of one man in one place, but of many men scattered across the northern Syrian countryside.

headline: Melinda Sullivan’s ‘Gone’
abstract: Ms. Sullivan’s new work combines two schools of tap-dancing, one rooted in jazz and the other in musical theater.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Sullivan’s new work combines two schools of tap-dancing, one rooted in jazz and the other in musical theater.

headline: A Show That Marries Pure, Rhythmic Tap to Its Musical-Theater Cousin
abstract: The choreographer Melinda Sullivan has undertaken a difficult task in “Gone,” which is an attempt to intertwine two schools of tap.
lead_paragraph: In her program note to “Gone,” a new dance-theater work, the choreographer Melinda Sullivan identifies two schools of tap-dancing. One comes out of jazz and is rooted in improvisational solos, emphasizing rhythm over spectacle and story. The other swerved through Broadway and Hollywood, producing the choreographed routines of musical theater. Though the divergence can be overemphasized — with racial connotations that Ms. Sullivan’s note carefully acknowledges — the distinctions are still in force.

headline: Fake Comments Muddy a Debate in Dallas
abstract: Fake blog comments are the latest twist in the fight between the Nasher Sculpture Center in Dallas and its neighbor, the Museum Tower.
lead_paragraph: Many people have offered opinions in the long-running and literally heated battle between the Nasher Sculpture Center in Dallas and a next-door condominium called Museum Tower. The condominium stands accused of producing glare that has compromised the museum’s galleries and garden.

headline: Profit Flat at Disney, as ESPN and Parks Smooth   Setbacks in Film
abstract: Net income fell 36 percent in Disney’s fiscal third quarter, to $201 million, in part because of marketing expenses for the flop “Lone Ranger.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “The Lone Ranger” rode away with the Walt Disney Company’s growth in the last quarter and will force the entertainment conglomerate to take a write-down of up to $190 million in the current quarter.

headline: Obama's Ideas to Help Homeowners
abstract: The president outlined his plans to help responsible Americans own homes and addressed he bipartisan effort to overhaul the mortgage finance giants Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae.
lead_paragraph: The president outlined his plans to help responsible Americans own homes and addressed he bipartisan effort to overhaul the mortgage finance giants Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae.

headline: Scene City: Oprah Returns to the Spotlight
abstract: Oprah Winfrey, Forest Whitaker, Lenny Kravitz and other co-stars attended the premiere of Lee Daniel’s “The Butler.”
lead_paragraph: Oprah Winfrey, Forest Whitaker, Lenny Kravitz and other co-stars attended the premiere of Lee Daniel’s “The Butler.”

headline: Long Before Little Charlie Became the Face of Evil
abstract: In a new biography, Jeff Guinn provides a more probing view of the cult leader Charles Manson by delving deeper into his past and deeply troubled childhood.
lead_paragraph: “Little Charlie Manson was a disagreeable child,” Jeff Guinn writes in “Manson,” an otherwise brawny, deep-digging biography that’s much more riveting than might be expected. It’s no surprise that the Manson story no longer commands much attention. What a difference more than four decades make. Mr. Guinn is fascinating in his use of hindsight, and it allows him a more probing view of his subject than earlier biographers had. The book’s essential question is articulated in this opening quotation about the ’60s, which he attributes to Tom Hayden: “Over and over it came down to that question — what was reality in an unreal time?”

headline: Front Burner: A Biodynamic Wine Shop in Brooklyn, Hot Chocolate for Cold Sipping and More
abstract: Florence Fabricant’s recommendations for the week of Aug. 6.
lead_paragraph: To Shop: Selecting Wine That’s Biodynamic

headline: 10 Questions for Rand Paul
abstract: John Harwood of The Times and CNBC interviewed Senator Rand Paul for the NPR program “On Point,” produced by WBUR-Boston. What follows is a condensed, edited version of their conversation.
lead_paragraph: Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky has drawn more attention than most Republican politicians lately, as his party searches for a winning national formula. Clashing with the likes of New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie – a potential 2016 presidential rival – he has promoted a libertarian brand of Republican politics featuring a less aggressive foreign policy, a more tolerant social policy, and smaller government.

headline: From Winning to ‘Wow,’ Festival Fun Unfurls in Crisscrossing Acts
abstract: In cross-pairings of different troupes, artists performed relatively short pieces with bravura touches on Saturday at the Vail International Dance Festival.
lead_paragraph: VAIL, Colo. — A number of Romantic ballets have central scenes set in the woods. Far from the madding crowd, within the realm of nature, the hero discovers the otherworldly heroine who satisfies his longing as the women of his own milieu do not.

headline: In-Demand Artist, Now on View in Vegas
abstract: Works by James Turrell, who has three major museum shows, can now be seen at the Shops at Crystals in Las Vegas.
lead_paragraph: Much has been made of the light and space artist James Turrell’s hat-trick retrospective: three simultaneous major museum shows, including one now at the Guggenheim for which he’s created the largest-ever temporary installation in the museum’s history.

headline: The Moto X From Google, iPhone’s Latest Challenger
abstract: Google’s own Android phone offers five features that no phone has offered before, including a touchless mode.
lead_paragraph: It’s getting harder and harder to invent the iPhone Killer. Even for Apple.

headline: Gunfire at Board Meeting Traced to Eviction Dispute
abstract: The man arrested on homicide charges after three people were shot to death at a township meeting in Pennsylvania had faced eviction from his dilapidated property.
lead_paragraph: Rockne Warren Newell lived alone in the Pocono Mountains of eastern Pennsylvania in utter poverty. His house was on the verge of collapse. His bathroom was a bucket.

headline: 60 Seconds With Pogue: The Moto X Phone
abstract: The Times’s David Pogue examines the Moto X smartphone, Google’s collaboration with Motorola.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s David Pogue examines the Moto X smartphone, Google’s collaboration with Motorola.

headline: In Drums and Fans, the Spirit of Korea
abstract: Sounds of Korea treated New Yorkers to a program of traditional music and dance at Lincoln Center Out of Doors on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: There’s soul, and then there’s “S(e)oul.” On Sunday afternoon, Lincoln Center Out of Doors teamed up with the Center for Traditional Music and Dance to showcase “The S(e)oul of Korea,” a program with more to it than an embarrassing title. (What on earth were the presenters thinking?) This three-tiered presentation, which took place at Hearst Plaza, included two musical groups — the New York Korean Traditional Marching Band and Ensemble Sinawi — as well as the dance and music troupe Sounds of Korea.

headline: Modern Picnic Wares for Photo-Worthy Alfresco Dining
abstract: These artisanal products will upgrade late-summer outdoor dining experiences, from the backyard to the park.
lead_paragraph: Too often, picnic wares are an afterthought — cheap wicker baskets, plastic gingham blankets, throwaway utensils. Of course, the primary attractions of do-it-yourself alfresco dining are a lavish spread, a natural setting and good company. But now, thanks to a handful of artisans, there are attractive, handcrafted goods for a decidedly modern (and Instagram-friendly) outdoor culinary experience.

headline: In American Greetings Deal, Echoes of Larger Buyout for Dell
abstract: Both deals illustrate the rise of shareholder power, as well as the devilish issues that emerge when management tries to buy a public company.
lead_paragraph: This is a tale of two management-led buyouts.

headline: Even Before a Debate, an Unfriendly Exchange
abstract: A Republican candidate, George T. McDonald, objected to being patted on the chest by Anthony D. Weiner during greetings at an AARP forum. Things went downhill from there.
lead_paragraph: It was only a matter of time before the race for mayor developed its own personal feud.

headline: Sometimes, They’re Sort of Who They Say They Are
abstract: Four people pretending to be a family smuggle marijuana from Mexico to Colorado in “We’re the Millers.”
lead_paragraph: “We’re the Millers,” a loose, halfheartedly raunchy, occasionally hilarious new comedy, is about a lot of different things; it’s the usual grab bag of jokes about drugs and body parts. But what really drives the movie is its own search for something to make fun of, and for a comic style that can feel credibly naughty while remaining ultimately safe and affirmative.

headline: U.S. Charges Libyan Militia Leader in Benghazi Attack
abstract: The militia leader, Ahmed Abu Khattala, has denied any role in the attack on Sept. 11, 2012, which killed the United States ambassador to Libya and three other Americans.
lead_paragraph: Federal law enforcement authorities have filed murder charges against Ahmed Abu Khattala, a prominent militia leader in Benghazi, Libya, in connection with the attacks on a diplomatic mission there last Sept. 11 that killed the United States ambassador and three other Americans, according to senior law enforcement and United States officials.

headline: What a Hero Goes Through to Become a Healer
abstract: In “Percy Jackson: Sea of Monsters,” the Golden Fleece must be retrieved to save Camp Half-Blood.
lead_paragraph: Following the almost $226.5 million box office of the first Percy Jackson movie, the hero (Logan Lerman) has returned to save Camp Half-Blood, the training ground for Greek demigods and employer of the teacher-centaur Chiron (Anthony Head of “Buffy the Vampire Slayer,” at his Watcher-ly best, replacing Pierce Brosnan). When the magical tree that protects the camp is poisoned, Percy must retrieve the Golden Fleece to heal it.

headline: A Challenge in the Woods
abstract: In “Kid-Thing,” a young girl with little social skill faces a situation that tests her judgment.
lead_paragraph: The sparse, somewhat surreal “Kid-Thing,” a new feature from the Zellner brothers, is certainly disturbing. Whether it is anything more than that depends on how much time you want to invest in contemplating the fragments you’re given.

headline: Tapering of Stimulus Could Start as Soon as September, 2 Fed Presidents Hint
abstract: The leaders of two Federal Reserve banks indicated that the end of qualitative easing might come in early fall — depending, of course, on how the economy fares.
lead_paragraph: Two Federal Reserve regional presidents suggested on Tuesday that the central bank could ease its extraordinary efforts to stimulate the economy sooner rather than later, but stopped short of providing an exact time frame.

headline: Someone Hacked N.H.T.S.A.’s Servers
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles', 'Computer Security', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers']
abstract: When some public documents suddenly became unavailable on the N.H.T.S.A.’s Web site, it came to light that 10 of the agency’s servers had been hacked.
lead_paragraph: As it turns out, even highway safety regulators are vulnerable to the ravaging hand of cybercriminals. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration had some of its servers hacked last week, the agency confirmed on Tuesday.

headline: Back to School, With Perks
abstract: The North Atlanta High School, which opens on Wednesday, cost $147 million, the most expensive school in Georgia history.
lead_paragraph: The North Atlanta High School, which opens on Wednesday, cost $147 million, the most expensive school in Georgia history.

headline: Leader Says Taliban Will Sit Out 2014 Afghan Election
abstract: Mullah Mohammad Omar, the Taliban leader, said in a statement that participating in the Afghan presidential vote next year would be “a waste of time.”
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Despite efforts to broker a peace deal between the Afghan government and the Taliban, the insurgent group will not participate in the presidential election next year, its leader said in a statement Tuesday.

headline: 21st Century Fox Has 16% Jump in Revenue on Higher Cable Fees
abstract: Profits also soared in the latest quarter at the newly independent Fox entertainment arm.
lead_paragraph: The entertainment arm of Rupert Murdoch’s media empire, 21st Century Fox, on Tuesday reported a 16 percent uptick in revenue for the quarter ending in June, thanks in part to the higher subscriber fees for its cable channels.

headline: Chasing Milestones Near End of Road
abstract: The Yankees’ Alex Rodriguez will receive a $6 million bonus if he reaches one of baseball’s most famous numbers, 660, the career home run total of Willie Mays.
lead_paragraph: As Alex Rodriguez marched toward his career total of 647 home runs, he passed many of the greatest hitters to ever play.

headline: Advance Ad Sales for New TV Season Called Lukewarm
abstract: The five broadcast networks sold an estimated $9 billion worth of commercial time before the season starts, about the same or a little less than last year’s sales.
lead_paragraph: IT may be the right moment to add another item to the Meh List (“Not hot, not not, just meh”): the performance of the broadcast networks in selling commercial time ahead of the 2013-14 television season.

headline: In the Jets’ Other Quarterback Battle, the Loser Will Hand In His Playbook
abstract: Greg McElroy and Matt Simms feel the same pressure and train with as much intensity as the better-known Mark Sanchez and Geno Smith.
lead_paragraph: CORTLAND, N.Y. — Coach Rex Ryan opened his news conference Tuesday by announcing that Mark Sanchez would start the Jets’ preseason opener Friday night in Detroit, and then he went on to field eight consecutive questions about Sanchez and Geno Smith — their projected playing time and all that. It was as if Sanchez and Smith were battling for a job or something.

headline: National Push by a Local Immigration Activist: No G.O.P. Retreat
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In a broad populist campaign, a Georgia-based former insurance agent has joined forces with national leaders of groups pressuring Republicans to oppose a path to legal status for millions of immigrants.

headline: Florida: Exhumations Approved at Shuttered Reform School
abstract: Gov. Rick Scott and his cabinet on Tuesday voted to allow anthropologists to begin exhuming the remains of boys who were buried decades ago at the Dozier School for Boys.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Rick Scott and his cabinet on Tuesday voted to allow anthropologists from the University of South Florida to begin exhuming the remains of boys who were buried decades ago at the Dozier School for Boys in Marianna. The reform school, now shuttered, had a history of neglecting and abusing the boys in its care. Accusations of abuse spanned decades. A group of elderly “White House boys,” named for the building where they say they were beaten, have come forward in recent years to speak about the abuse. Anthropologists began identifying the graves in a portion of the school that had been set aside for black boys during segregation. Family members of some of the boys who died at the school have fought for more than a year to have the bodies exhumed, examined and reburied in cemeteries closer to home.

headline: Argentina: Gas Leak Causes Deadly Residential Blast
abstract: Twelve people died and at least 60 more were injured, officials said Tuesday, in an explosion in the center of Rosario, Argentina’s third-largest city, with 1.2 million people.
lead_paragraph: Twelve people died and at least 60 more were injured, officials said Tuesday, in an explosion in the center of Rosario, Argentina’s third largest city, with 1.2 million people. A gas leak from the ground floor of a residential building caused the blast on Tuesday morning, Mónica Fein, the mayor of Rosario, confirmed. Witnesses said it felt like an earthquake. “I woke up and there were no walls,” said Franco Járiton, who lived on the seventh floor. News channels showed that the middle block of the building, which was nine stories tall, had collapsed. There are fears that two adjoining blocks, which are badly damaged, will also fall. Fifteen people were missing. Neighbors said they had called the provincial gas company hours before the explosion, warning of a strong gas smell. The company, Litoral Gas, said it had not received any calls.

Maybe he was on to something 14 years ago, when, as Peter de Jonge wrote in an entertaining and still relevant cover story for the magazine, Bezos and his company were fostering a “forced and incongruous indifference to money” among Amazon’s work force. They had lots of morale-boosting mottos but a volatile stock price. (When de Jonge expressed skepticism about the company, one Amazon executive told him, “I can tell you’re not a believer.”) De Jonge imagined that being employed there must have been “a little like living in Pompeii 2,000 years ago.”

headline: Lincoln: War Management by Memo
abstract: Rarely longer than a tweet, the president’s “endorsements” were issued from his office often at a rate of several per day.
lead_paragraph: President Abraham Lincoln wrote great and powerful speeches. Lincoln’s gifts as an orator and a writer came in part from his ability to express even the loftiest, most complex of sentiments in just a few words. He rarely used two words when one would do. This is perhaps best illustrated in the daily task of managing the war. A high percentage of his official communications are not letters at all, but notes by him that appear on the back of letters written by other people, many addressed to his attention. These memos, called endorsements, show Lincoln as an unrivaled wartime commander in chief.

headline: The Scientism of Steven Pinker
abstract: In which an attempted rehabilitation of the term “scientism” actually vindicates scientism’s critics.
lead_paragraph: Steven Pinker has an interesting and revealing essay in The New Republic dismissing the charges of “scientism” that are often leveled by the philosophically, artistically and religiously-minded against certain authors, polemicists and science popularizers. “The term,” he writes, “is anything but clear, more of a boo-word than a label for any coherent doctrine,” which inspires him to try to reappropriate “scientism” as a positive descriptor — denoting, he suggests, a belief in the intelligibility of the world and a commitment to the difficult-but-necessary quest for real objectivity about its workings, both of which which should inform our understanding of non-scientific spheres as well.

headline: Magician of Light and Silver, Circa 1860
abstract: “Mathew Brady: Portraits of a Nation,” Robert Wilson’s new biography of the photographer, relates how his skill and charm made him the favorite of politicians and generals from the 1840s onward.
lead_paragraph: Salman Rushdie, in his novel  “The Ground Beneath Her Feet”  (1999), described what we see in a photograph as “a moral decision taken in one-eighth of a second.”In the early days of photography, those moral decisions took longer to process. When Mathew Brady, the Civil War-era photographer, took a portrait, the shutter remained open for 10 to 15 seconds or more, long enough for a bit of wind, or the hint of a smile, to ruin everything. His subjects often had their heads stabilized by an unseen vise.

headline: ‘Hotel Chelsea’ by Victoria Cohen
abstract: A photographer’s new book documents the artistic spirit of the Hotel Chelsea.
lead_paragraph: In 2011, when the photographer Victoria Cohen heard that the Hotel Chelsea — the talent-suffused West 23rd Street building that housed the likes of Virgil Thomson, Bob Dylan, Janis Joplin, Charles Bukowski, Arthur C. Clarke, Allen Ginsberg and Sid Vicious — was to be sold and gut-renovated, she set out to document the rooms. “It became a responsibility, not just an artistic endeavor to capture the essence,” she said. “I was not photographing empty rooms, I was taking portraits.” The images in her new book, “Hotel Chelsea” (Pointed Leaf Press, $95), are as vivid and haunting as characters in a Fellini film. Shot in natural light, they summon the ghosts of those who lived with blood-red walls, spartan corner sinks or broken-down beds. An exhibition runs from Sept. 17 to Oct. 25 at Third Streaming, 10 Greene Street (Canal Street); pointedleafpress.com.

headline: The Retro Breadbox Is Stale No More
abstract: With the breadbox poised for a revival, the MoMA Store brings back a classic.
lead_paragraph: Many baby boomers have fond memories of their parents’ kitchen gadgets: rotary egg beaters, electric percolators, Salton Hot Trays and various kinds of breadboxes. Countertop containers for baked goods were rife in the ’50s and ’60s, but they took on a minor role with the rise of commercially produced bread wrapped in plastic and loaded with preservatives. Now, with artisanal bread a staple in many homes, the breadbox is poised for a revival. Wesco, a German company, has reintroduced its Bauhaus-style Grandy model, designed in 1946 by Josef Neuhaus. Made of powder-coated steel, it has ventilation holes in the back, nonslip feet and a metal handle and hinges. The 16-inch-wide box comes in a glossy apple red from the Museum of Modern Art store, for $100. Available on Aug. 15 (orders starting Friday): (800) 851-4509 or momastore.org.

headline: Your Own Private Idaho
keywords: ['Hikes and Hiking', 'Wilderness Areas', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Mountains', 'Fishing, Sport']
abstract: In search of solitude? The Sawtooths offer natural splendor without the crowds — and you don’t even have to pitch a tent.
lead_paragraph: The “Entering Stanley, Idaho” sign seemed more like a friendly warning than a welcome. “Population 63,” it read, as if to say: Congratulations, you’ve made it to the middle of nowhere. Stanley is the entry point to the Sawtooth Valley, a time warp of a place with four saloons, five mountain ranges and not much else. My husband, Josh, our two children and I had driven three hours from Boise along an empty, winding two-lane scenic byway for a week of summer adventure. Still, as we strolled down deserted, dusty Wall Street looking for a lunch spot, it was hard not to wonder: Where is everyone?

Sewage from a United Nations camp contaminated one of Haiti’s largest rivers, the report said. The United Nations has steadfastly denied causing the epidemic, which has killed more than 8,000 people since it began in 2010, and has resisted paying any compensation. By not holding itself accountable to victims, the report stated, the United Nations is violating its obligations under international law.

headline: Times Reporter Seeks Subpoena’s Withdrawal
keywords: ['Subpoenas', 'News Sources, Confidential Status of', 'News and News Media']
abstract: A lawyer for James Risen, a reporter for The New York Times, has asked Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. to withdraw a subpoena requiring him to testify about a confidential source.
lead_paragraph: A lawyer for James Risen, an author and a reporter for The New York Times, has asked Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. to withdraw a subpoena requiring him to testify about a confidential source, in light of the Justice Department’s new guidelines for obtaining information from journalists in investigations. On July 19, a federal appeals court ruled that Mr. Risen must testify in the criminal trial of a former C.I.A. official, Jeffrey Sterling, who is charged with leaking classified information. The case involves material published in Mr. Risen’s 2006 book, “State of War.” The ruling came a week after Mr. Holder released a report on “significant revisions” to Justice Department policies intended to “strengthen protections for members of the news media.” The amended guidelines call for tactics like subpoenas to be treated as “extraordinary measures” to be used as a “last resort,” noted David N. Kelley, Mr. Risen’s lawyer, in a letter to Mr. Holder. “We urge you to apply those principles to this case,” Mr. Kelley wrote. A spokesman for the Justice Department said it was “examining the next steps in the prosecution of this case.”

headline: Crazy Pills

A policeman found me, and I ended up strapped down, hallucinating in a mental hospital for three days.

In the series’s first episode, Brodie struggles to balance the personal and professional as he tries to solve a case involving a girl who went missing 30 years earlier. “ ‘Case Histories’ is trying for something lighter (while remaining artfully blood soaked), and some mystery fans might find it a welcome change,” Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times when the series made its debut in 2011. headline: Part Ramones Biography, Part Dreamscape
abstract: Jim McCarthy and Brian Williamson’s new graphic biography, “Gabba Gabba Hey!,” details scenes from the Ramones’ lives filled in with some imagination.
lead_paragraph: In 1979, the Ramones were recording at a studio in Los Angeles with the producer Phil Spector, whose work with the Ronettes, the Righteous Brothers and the Beatles had earned him a reputation as both a musical genius and an exacting, combustible egomaniac. He hadn’t produced a hit since John Lennon’s “Imagine” in 1971, and the Ramones, who had released four critically acclaimed albums of exuberant punk rock, were still searching for a commercial breakthrough. The sessions for the resulting album, “End of the Century,” were tumultuous, and the opening pages of the new book, “Gabba Gabba Hey!: The Graphic Story of the Ramones,” written by Jim McCarthy and illustrated by Brian Williamson, details some of Mr. Spector’s more notorious moments: forcing the guitarist Johnny Ramone to play the opening chord to “Rock ’N’ Roll High School” more than 70 times; pointing a gun at the bassist Dee Dee Ramone.

The crash has been attributed to pilot error.

headline: By Design | Paris Restaurants, Cali Vibes
abstract: Weekends, an interiors firm run by a pair of California expats, is bringing a distinctly West Coast flavor to Paris’s flourishing cafe-bar scene.
lead_paragraph: A can-can kick away from the Moulin Rouge sits Le Dépanneur, a new restaurant in a corner of Pigalle, the red-light district in north-central Paris. The wraparound chrome siding suggests it’s an American-style diner, but the place, which opened last month after being shuttered for several years, has a different kind of stateside flavor. The clean palette, vast airiness and abundant flora creates a Palm Springs-by-way-of-Big Sur resort feel. On the main floor, a wealth of natural wood — slatted tables, floors painted with pastel geometric shapes, siding made of reclaimed timber and a polished bar — is complemented by potted succulents and painted white accents. Upstairs, there are hexagonal tables and vintage Modernist daybeds where guests can sip the restaurant’s agave cocktails and eat its organic burgers.

The show, which opens on Thursday at Circle in the Square, was still being tweaked, and because the rabbi, Shlomo Riskin, had known Carlebach, Mr. Wise wanted his opinion. As it turned out, Rabbi Riskin was impressed with the show’s star, Eric Anderson, a genial Californian who wears an untrimmed beard and has absorbed Carlebach’s moves and sound. Backstage, Rabbi Riskin complimented Mr. Anderson’s performance in phrases peppered with Hebrew. It was only when Rabbi Riskin left that Mr. Wise told him that Mr. Anderson is not Jewish.

headline: Politics in a Refugee Camp
abstract: Harriet Jacobs – former slave, memoirist, aid worker – and the challenges of Civil War humanitarianism.
lead_paragraph: By early August 1863, Harriet Jacobs – former slave, memoirist, journalist and now aid worker in Virginia – had been at her work among the “contrabands” in Alexandria the better part of a year. She first visited the refugee camps the previous summer while reporting for William Lloyd Garrison’s The Liberator, and by the end of 1862 she had committed herself to the burgeoning relief effort for the former slaves flooding the region around the capital.

headline: O’Keeffe at Lake George
abstract: A new exhibition features works that recall George O’Keeffe’s time in upstate New York.
lead_paragraph: A new exhibition features works that recall George O’Keeffe’s time in upstate New York.

headline: Before the Desert, a Greener Side
abstract: The Hyde Collection in Glens Falls, N.Y., has assembled five-dozen works by Georgia O’Keeffe from her years at Lake George, in a show titled “Modern Nature.”
lead_paragraph: GLENS FALLS, N.Y. — If you are a casual fan of Georgia O’Keeffe, you probably think of New Mexico when you think of her. After all, she lived there for decades and avidly explored the landscape in her work and her life, collecting stones and bones and accolades as one of America’s most celebrated painters.

headline: Study Says West Germany Engaged in Sports Doping
abstract: A new study revealed that West Germany began a government-financed plan in the 1970s to boost athletic achievement through the use of banned performance-enhancing drugs.
lead_paragraph: When the Berlin Wall fell in 1989, so did the secrecy around a pervasive, state-sponsored system of doping in communist East Germany known by the Orwellian euphemism of “Supporting Means.”

headline: The Worst Is Yet to Come
abstract: “Elysium,” the second feature from the director Neill Blomkamp, stars Matt Damon as a former thief living on a ruined Earth in 2154.
lead_paragraph: Not since Charlton Heston struggled to save humanity from itself have movies looked this grimly, resolutely fatalistic. The man who was Moses began fighting the fantasy good fight in 1968, battling damn dirty apes in “Planet of the Apes,” before going on to face zombie hordes in “Omega Man” and an overpopulated nightmare in “Soylent Green.” (Psst: It’s people!) Heston may be gone, but the zombie hordes have kept coming, along with other new and unusual annihilating threats, and now it’s back to the dystopian future with “Elysium,” a cautionary shocker from the director Neill Blomkamp about a Hobbesian war of all against all from which only Matt Damon can save us.

lead_paragraph: It is early evening, but the crowd at Oda House is ready for 3 a.m. Young women with undulating hair, dressed in black from shoulder to mid-thigh, are primed for fancier precincts than this subdued corner of Alphabet City. Older women at other tables occasionally lean over to dispense advice. What appears to be one vast family has colonized the seats by the front windows.

headline: Icahn Heads to Court With a Point About Dell
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: Carl Icahn is challenging the Dell board’s postponement of the annual meeting to elect directors to Oct. 17, contending that it is an undue delay under Delaware law. While the argument is a legal maneuver in his broader strategy, the law appears to support him.
lead_paragraph: Believe it or not, Carl C. Icahn has a case.

headline: Schindler Letter Headed to Auction
abstract: A 1944 letter from Oskar Schindler, the German businessman whose effort to save Jews from the Nazis was depicted in “Schindler’s List,” is being auctioned online.
lead_paragraph: The letter, dated Aug. 22, 1944, gives permission to relocate an enamelware factory from Krakow, Poland, to Czechoslovakia. What makes this otherwise routine correspondence special is that it is signed in blue pencil by Oskar Schindler, the German businessman whose effort to save 1,200 Jews from the Nazi death machine was depicted in the 1993 Academy Award-winning film “Schindler’s List.”

headline: Cut Emissions? Congress Itself Keeps Burning a Dirtier Fuel
keywords: ['Capitol Building (Washington, DC)', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Coal', 'Electric Light and Power']
abstract: The Capitol Power Plant, the largest single source of carbon emissions in Washington, offers a concrete example of the government’s inability to green its own turf.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As part of the climate change agenda he unveiled this year, President Obama made a commitment to significantly reduce the federal government’s dependence on fossil fuels. The government, he said in a speech in June at Georgetown University, “must lead by example.”

headline: Electric Stream Flow: Designing the BMW i3
abstract: BMW undoubtedly knew that it would have to start from scratch with the design of its electric i3 platform; putting batteries and motors onto a gasoline platform would not have been enough.
lead_paragraph: To develop an electric vehicle with the sporty performance expected of the Ultimate Driving Machine, BMW undoubtedly knew that it would have to do more than simply slap motors and batteries into an existing model. So they designed an entirely new platform with a singular shape, made from innovative materials.

headline: An American Coach in London
abstract: NBC begins carrying games from England’s Premier League on Aug. 17 and sent a “football coach” to work with Tottenham Hotspur.
lead_paragraph: A rap video starring the Manning brothers, the quarterbacks Eli and Peyton, may have gone viral on the Internet with the start of the exhibition season in the N.F.L. kicking in to high gear this weekend.

headline: Abortion in America and Europe
abstract: A response to critics on the lessons of Europe’s abortion laws.
lead_paragraph: My column two weeks ago on what other developed countries’ abortion laws tell us about the impact of abortion restrictions prompted a number of rebuttals, most notably from Scott Lemieux at The American Prospect and Katha Pollitt at The Nation. To my point that a number of European countries restrict second and third-trimester abortions without producing any obviously disastrous consequences for women’s health and professional advancement, both Lemieux and Pollitt argue that the European bans only work because the countries in question make first-trimester abortion more accessible and affordable than does the United States. Here’s Lemieux:

headline: Reince Priebus on Republican Debates
abstract: He wants to make sure the 2016 moderators will be “interested in the future of the Republican Party.”
lead_paragraph: Presidential debates have not been debates for a long time. In the primaries, they’re cattle shows where a half dozen or more would-be nominees recite talking points hoping for a sound bite that sticks for 24 hours. In the general election, they’re press conferences with two participants trying to avoid stepping on landmines. The most memorable moments have had less to do with substantive discussion than appearance, like President Obama sleepwalking through his first encounter with Mitt Romney in 2012.

headline: Echoes of Steve Jobs in Elon Musk

lead_paragraph: Elon Musk is beginning to exude hints of Steven P. Jobs, Apple’s late chief executive.

lead_paragraph: If you “like” this article on a site like Facebook, somebody who reads it is more likely to approve of it, even if the reporting and writing are not all that great.

lead_paragraph: The mezzo-soprano Elina Garanca has withdrawn from the performances she was scheduled to sing at the Metropolitan Opera during the 2013-14 season because she is pregnant. The child, Ms. Garanca’s second, is due in December.

abstract: Impatience had brought me to Jim; now it was time for me to practice the art of letting go.
lead_paragraph: On the cusp of 50, I paid $6,000 to find my next husband.

headline: The Vladimir and Estragon of Roadwork
abstract: In David Gordon Green’s offbeat film “Prince Avalanche,” two young men — one pompous, one slow on the uptake — take a job painting lines on a stretch of highway.
lead_paragraph: David Gordon Green, who is 38 and has directed eight feature films, is a relatively young man in no particular hurry. In a career that has ambled from sensitive regional realism (“George Washington”) to Southern Gothic (“Undertow”) to stoner comedy (“Pineapple Express,” “The Sitter”), he has shown a notable knack for taking his time, pausing to appreciate offbeat moments and unusual sights. He is a hard-working filmmaker — with some interesting television on his résumé as well — who rigorously communicates the pleasures of slacking.

headline: This Blog Has in Fact Published Stuff Other Than the George Saunders Graduation Speech
abstract: The 10 most popular blog posts in the history of The 6th Floor.
lead_paragraph: The first rule of going viral is that you should never plan to go viral. And with that rule in no way in mind — that’s the point! you can’t think about it! — Joel Lovell let a casual e-mail correspondence with George Saunders morph into a blog post that reached a level of Internet popularly normally reserved for Lindsay Lohan and counterintuitive arguments about yoga. His reproduction of Saunders’s graduation speech at Syracuse University was by orders of magnitude the most popular thing ever to run on The 6th Floor blog — which has, since its inception, been a strong believer in the first rule of going viral. As the magazine’s editor, Hugo Lindgren, wrote in his inaugural post in March 2011, “This blog is meant as a humble complement to the magazine — a place to let readers listen in on the conversations that happen in the office.” We never planned to be the fastest, nor the buzziest, nor to have the most cat GIFs (a staple of the second rule of going viral). We just planned to do the sort of stuff that magazine editors do — “allow our curiosity to wander and see where it leads,” as Lindgren put it — but do it a little more publicly.

abstract: Steampunk, which has encouraged artists and thinkers to move forward by going back, will be featured at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: Society once gave artists tacit license to shock the bourgeoisie, hoping that the artists would produce modern masterpieces.

headline: After Going All In During Mining Boom, BHP Cuts Its Ambitions
abstract: BHP Billiton, the world’s largest mining company, sits atop a sector that is deeply out of favor with investors, and it is aggressively curtailing its spending in hopes of winning them over.
lead_paragraph: BHP Billiton, the world’s largest mining company, was willing to spend big in early 2012. It was building new mines and upgrading old ones, at a cost of $18 billion. It considered a potential expansion of its copper and uranium mine, Olympic Dam, which could have cost as much as $20 billion. It proposed a deepwater extension of Port Hedland, its iron ore port, an estimated $10 billion or more.

headline: Breast-Feeding in the Airport? A New Lactation Station Solution
abstract: The airport in Burlington, Vt., installs a private place to nurse or pump. Will other businesses and facilities follow?
lead_paragraph: Many of us who have breast-fed a baby know quite keenly the obstacles involved in pulling off such an intimate task in public. Even with all the nifty tools meant to provide privacy — the nursing bras and tops, the capes, the scarves artfully draped over baby and breast — accomplishing a feed without exposing yourself to strangers can be a changing-into-your-bathing-suit-poolside-esque feat. Ta-da! Happy, drooly baby, and you didn’t see a thing!

lead_paragraph: Updated, Friday, 12:43 p.m. | The suicide of a Canadian teenager in April revived outrage that the police did not go far enough to investigate allegations that she was gang-raped in 2011, then bullied after images of the assault were shared and posted online.

abstract: The all-purpose shoe of the season is best in black but comes in a variety of styles to fit any attitude.
lead_paragraph: A crop of black, closed-toed, strappy flats — the pointy-toed big sisters to Mary Janes and T-strap sandals — is popping up to carry late-summer wardrobes into cooler fall temperatures. From patent leather (Casadei and Jimmy Choo) to suede (Armani) to lace (Erdem) to studs (Freda Salvador), there’s a style for everyone. And for the truly bold, there are even crystals (Tabitha Simmons) for a little extra vamp.

headline: Food Rituals

headline: Taken to Heart
abstract: The narrator of Javier Marías’s new novel carries on a friendship with the widow and the best friend of a murdered man.
lead_paragraph: When a writer chooses to express something in a particular way, all the other approaches he might have chosen are usually encouraged to disappear in the hope of creating an atmosphere of authority and precision. Javier Marías, the masterly Spanish novelist, follows the opposite policy and, even after he has filled a descriptive vacancy, continues to interview other candidates for the job. The rival formulations turn up one after another, in sub-clauses that offer everything from subtle qualification to flat contradiction. Here is the narrator of “The Infatuations,” Marías’s new novel, contemplating the memory of Miguel and Luisa, the husband and wife she grew to think of as the Perfect Couple, if only on the thin basis of observing them have breakfast each morning in the same cafe:

headline: Who Was T. E. Lawrence?
abstract: Historians have never known what to make of this scholar, writer, soldier and imperialist.
lead_paragraph: Among the many individual stories of World War I that will doubtless be told and retold for the centenary years between 2014 and 2018, that of T. E. Lawrence stands out from all the rest. As Scott Anderson says at the beginning of “Lawrence in Arabia,” “historians have never quite decided what to make of the young, bashful Oxford scholar who rode into battle at the head of an Arab army and changed history.”

lead_paragraph: Elisabeth Maxwell helped her husband run a multibillion-dollar business and a 53-room manor. Each year she made a scrapbook of press clippings about him; some years it tipped the scales at 60 pounds.

headline: Scenes From Italy’s Heel
abstract: Take a stroll around Lecce, a historical town in the Puglia region.
lead_paragraph: Take a stroll around Lecce, a historical town in the Puglia region.

headline: 36 Hours in Lecce, Italy
abstract: Stroll past churches, take a midday break at the beach and sip a glass of regional wine in the “Florence of the South.”
lead_paragraph: Thanks to dozens of mostly Baroque-era churches packing its maze of narrow streets, Lecce, the “Florence of the South,” dazzles with elaborately carved facades and interiors that erupt with symphonies of angels, cherubs, saints, saviors and Madonnas. But this small gem in Italy’s heel is far from a haven of monkish abstemiousness. A capital of southern Italian cooking, the city brims with rustic restaurants serving the hearty peasant cuisine and robust red wines of the Puglia (Apulia in English) region. Throw in a buzzing bar scene and nearby beaches of sun-bronzed bodies and you have a city fit for holy men and hedonists alike.

headline: Near Paris, a City of Flaubert and Joan of Arc
abstract: In Rouen, where Gustave Flaubert was born and Joan of Arc was burned, past and present create a layered texture.
lead_paragraph: Gustave Flaubert reportedly once said that he wrote his novels to resemble a particular color. “In ‘Madame Bovary,’ ” he remarked, “all I was after was to render a special tone, that color of the moldiness of a wood-louse’s existence.” He may well have achieved that with his depiction of illusory love in his novel. But Rouen, France — Flaubert’s birthplace and the setting for a good portion of “Madame Bovary” — evokes a different mood altogether.
