headline: After the Opt-Out Revolution, Asking: How’s That Working for You?
abstract: For women who stepped away from their career in order to spend more time at home with their family, there may be few fairy tales, but there’s little real regret.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago, Lisa Belkin (my predecessor here) wrote the article “The Opt-Out Revolution,” now a classic, for The New York Times Magazine. It spawned both a shorthand for the educated mother who has left a career to stay home and a backlash of complaint (statistically, the revolution was a blip at most, and limited to an economically fortunate few). It also informed thousands of conversations among women across generations about what it meant to “choose” career or motherhood, and what needed to change in order to allow us to more easily choose both.

headline: Gentlemen at Work
abstract: “Hothouse” is a biography of the literary publishing house Farrar, Straus & Giroux.
lead_paragraph: Boris Kachka’s “Hothouse” is a big wet kiss to the publishing house Farrar, Straus & Giroux. It does its mightiest to find a Platonic ideal in the very way that Farrar, Straus authors, editors and books put words to paper. Surely this is a house with a longer, grander history and greater commitment to serious literature than some other publishers can claim, but is there no such thing as overkill? It once put out an edition of Courtney Love’s diaries that, Mr. Kachka writes, were “meant to be purchased by Lord knows whom.” The same must be said of “Hothouse,” thanks to its fanzine breathlessness and tireless fawning.

headline: Deaf Patrons’ Suit Accuses Starbucks of Discrimination

headline: Milton Friedman, Unperson
abstract: What happened to the colossus of yore?
lead_paragraph: David Glasner has been making a series of posts on the legacy of Milton Friedman, some of them in response to Scott Sumner; they’re interesting if you want to delve into the intellectual history. I’m not personally big on such things — in general, what people thought Keynes or Friedman meant ends up being more important than what they turn out, on close reading, to (maybe, possibly) actually have meant. For what it’s worth, I think Glasner makes a good case that Friedman was indeed more or less a Keynesian, or maybe Hicksian — certainly that was the message everyone took from his Monetary Framework, which was disappointingly conventional. And Friedman’s attempts to claim that Keynes added little that wasn’t already in a Chicago oral tradition don’t hold up well either.

headline: A Seafood Salad From the Grill
abstract: This salad delivers lightly smoky swagger and is an excellent foil for the earthy-yet-fruity Sicilian frappato wines.
lead_paragraph: This seafood salad, sizzled on a grill (or in a grill pan or under the broiler), delivers lightly smoky swagger and, thanks to radicchio, a welcome edge of bitterness. It is an excellent foil for the earthy-yet-fruity and often-light Sicilian frappato and Cerasuolo di Vittoria wines. A substantial salad, it can be a curtain raiser or part of a buffet for summer dinner at home. It might even be carried to a picnic. But it begs to be served a bit warm, and the wine cool.

headline: From Sicily, Reds Worth the Hunt
abstract: A terrific selection from one of the most exciting wine regions in the world shows off the grace and energy of wines that showcase the frappato grape.
lead_paragraph: The transformation of the world of wine in the last 20 years has been simply astounding. Consumers have been blessed with a profusion of wonderful wines from sources that few would have predicted as recently as the turn of the century. Case in point: Sicily.

headline: Obama Urges Greece to Grow Its Economy
abstract: In a meeting in the Oval Office on Thursday, President Obama told Antonis Samaras, the Greek prime minister, that policies focused only on spending reductions would not help Greece return to economic prosperity.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Thursday urged Greece to find ways to grow its economy even as it continues to cut spending in an effort to recover from a debt-driven economic crisis.

headline: A Private Tour of the House of Krug
abstract: The cellar master of the legendary Champagne brand took T on a rare tour of its maison and nearby vineyard in the French town of Reims.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: New Sign of Stimulants’ Toll on Young
abstract: Federal health officials said the increase was fresh evidence of the unexpected consequences that can result from the wide use of medicines for conditions like attention deficit disorder.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The number of young adults who end up in the emergency room after taking Adderall, Ritalin or other such stimulants has quadrupled in recent years, federal health officials said Thursday, fresh evidence of the unexpected consequences that can result from the wide use of medicines for conditions like attention deficit disorder.

headline: Excerpt: 'Harbor'
abstract: Erin Cummings, Paul Anthony Stewart and Randy Harrison in a scene from Chad Beguelin's play at 59E59 Theaters.
lead_paragraph: Erin Cummings, Paul Anthony Stewart and Randy Harrison in a scene from Chad Beguelin's play at 59E59 Theaters.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Snowden’s E-Mail Service Shuts Down and the Future of E-Commerce
abstract: The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items. Thursday’s selections include a report that the Gmail alternative used by Edward J. Snowden has decided to shut down rather than hand over information to investigators. Plus, eBay’s chief executive spoke about the fusion of e-commerce and retailing.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items. Here’s what we noticed today:

headline: Quinn Leads Democratic Candidates for Mayor, Poll Finds
abstract: Christine C. Quinn has the support of 25 percent of voters polled, but that is not enough to avoid a runoff in the Sept. 10 primary election.
lead_paragraph: Christine C. Quinn is leading the crowded field in the Democratic primary race for New York City mayor, lifted by support among Manhattanites and higher-income voters, the latest New York Times/Siena College poll finds.

headline: Trying to Be Relevant in the AMC Shadows
abstract: “Hell on Wheels” is beginning its third season on AMC in the shadow of dramas like “Mad Men.”
lead_paragraph: It can’t be easy being the forgotten drama on a channel that has only six dramas, but that’s the fate of “Hell on Wheels,” which begins its third season on AMC on Saturday night.

headline: Out There on the Fringe, but Possibly Above the Fray
abstract: From the immense lineup of shows in the New York International Fringe Festival, staff members at The Times play some hunches and make some picks to see.
lead_paragraph: Every year the New York International Fringe Festival descends on the city with a dizzying array of shows. This year, the festival, which runs Friday through Aug. 25, features about 1,100 performances on 20 stages, presented by some 185 companies. (Schedule information: fringenyc.org.) How is a discriminating theatergoer to choose? Below, staff members at The New York Times discuss strategies and pick some productions they’re looking forward to. Of course, there are no sure bets — and half the fun is discovering previously unknown talents — but it’s worth noting that some shows pop up more than once here.

headline: Triple Play: Make Your Picks for Week 20
abstract: Put your predictive skills to the test each week of the baseball season.
lead_paragraph: The Bats blog again tests our readers’ predictive skills with three questions about the coming week. Feel free to lean on research, tea leaves, your gut instinct or maybe just dumb luck.

headline: From Balanchine to Lil Buck, a Small Price to Pay
abstract: The “Dance for $20” evening at the Vail International Dance Festival featured an impressive array of talent for $20.13.
lead_paragraph: VAIL, Colo. — Each year since 2008, the Vail International Dance Festival has had a “Dance for $20” evening. The audience is simply told who’ll dance, and all seats in the Gerald W. Ford Auditorium are offered at $20 plus the number of cents to match the current year. (Those who sit on the lawn at the back pay in dollars the final two digits of the year — $13 this summer. Nobody knows yet what will happen after 2020.)

headline: Vernacular Images
abstract: Two new exhibitions feature found photography.
lead_paragraph: Two new exhibitions feature found photography.

headline: Jazz Listings for Aug. 9-15
abstract: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Opera and Classical Music Listings for Aug. 9-15
abstract: A selected guide to classical music performances in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Tax-Free Accounts for Homes
keywords: ['Mortgages', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Federal Taxes (US)']
abstract: A coalition that includes developers and investors is floating the tax-free idea as part of reforms proposed to overhaul federally funded real estate programs.
lead_paragraph: Tax-free savings accounts help Americans stow away money for health care and college tuition. Why not a tax-exempt account for yet another major expense: the down payment on a mortgage?

headline: Dance Listings for Aug. 9-15
abstract: A selected guide to dance performances in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings for Aug. 9-15
abstract: A critical guide to the visual arts in New York and the region.
lead_paragraph: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Not for the Family Album
abstract: Two exhibitions of found photography — “Snap Noir” at the Pace/MacGill Gallery and “Photo Brut” at ZieherSmith — blur the line between art and document and between collector and artist.
lead_paragraph: Anonymous, found or outsider photographs, taken largely by, and of, people whose identities are long lost, exist in unfathomable numbers, like stars or grains of sand. Not surprisingly, this flood of visual culture, social and personal history and sometime art generates its own connoisseurs and collectors, as well as heated bidding on eBay.

headline: Women Inspired to Mix and Match
abstract: The 20 playful drawings in “Robert Pruitt: Women” at the Studio Museum in Harlem hint at the confusion between solo and group identity, and individual and collaborative action.
lead_paragraph: The subjects of “Robert Pruitt: Women,” his playful solo show at the Studio Museum in Harlem, look as if they’ve walked out of a street-style blog from a distant galaxy. One wears a track jacket, a feathered skirt and a Rubix cube perched on her head like a pillbox hat; another sports a tunic emblazoned with stars and planets and a spiraling headdress in the shape of Tatlin’s Constructivist “Monument to the Third International.”

headline: Spare Times for Aug. 9-15
abstract: A listing of walking tours, street fairs, parades and other cultural and recreational events in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: Around Town

headline: A Cuzco Hotel Gets a Luxury Upgrade
abstract: The Palacio del Inka in Cuzco, Peru, has undergone an extensive renovation and has opened under Starwood’s luxury banner.
lead_paragraph: After a $15 million investment, Palacio del Inka in Cuszco, Peru, has opened under Starwood’s Luxury Collection banner after 21 months’ construction.

headline: Sweet and Sour
abstract: Answers to questions about invitations to a child’s birthday party and a wedding, pre-date research and noisy neighbors.
lead_paragraph: We received a “save the date” card for a fifth birthday party for a boy my daughter knows. It was to be a Superhero Soiree. But shortly before the date, we were uninvited. The party is now just for boys because of its “masculine” theme, and my daughter was invited to a separate party for him just for girls. I don’t want to tell my daughter that she isn’t allowed to attend the real party, but she is going to want to know what happened. Something about this feels wrong. Should I mention it to the mother?

headline: All Those Voices: Can You Hear Her Now?
abstract: Lake Bell stars as an underused voice-over artist in her directing debut, the comic “In a World ...”
lead_paragraph: Reluctantly attending a party at the home of a big-shot voice-over artist, Carol Solomon, an aspiring voice-over artist in her own right, wanders off down a hallway where she discovers a secret door. Behind it is a room full of curious, exotic objects, an eccentric private museum that makes her smile in almost childlike wonder.

headline: Spare Times for Children for Aug. 9-15
abstract: A listing of noteworthy cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: ‘Playdate! With the Little Orchestra Society’

headline: Comedy Listings for Aug. 9-15
abstract: A selected guide to the stand-up and improv shows in New York.
lead_paragraph: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Why ‘Blurred Lines’ Won’t Go Away
abstract: Robin Thicke, Marvin Gaye, Hugh Masekela and other masters of the summer jam.
lead_paragraph: Robin Thicke’s “Blurred Lines” just notched its ninth week at No. 1 on Billboard’s Hot 100, suggesting not only that it’s the official summer song of 2013 — an argument that was actually settled weeks ago — but also that its dominance might extend well into the fall. What is it that’s giving this bouncy but seemingly lightweight track such staying power?

headline: Movie Listings for Aug. 9-15
abstract: A critical guide to movies playing in New York, including film series.
lead_paragraph: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: A Sister Shows Up, and Stereotypes Settle In
abstract: In the comedy “Harbor,” a gay couple’s household is shaken up when a family member moves in.
lead_paragraph: Family and children are on the playwright Chad Beguelin’s mind in “Harbor,” a comedy about a gay couple and the manipulative sister who came to stay.

headline: The Gastro-Pub Movement Sweeps In
abstract: Keenan House in Ossining has a large variety of craft beers on draft and in bottles and notes that it grinds (and smokes) its own meat and makes its own pastas.
lead_paragraph: “We’re a from-scratch restaurant,” said our server as she handed out the menus. “We grind our own meat, make our own pastas and have a smoker out back.”

headline: Pop and Rock Listings for Aug. 9-15
abstract: A selected guide to electro, roots, hip-hop and soul performances in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Theater Listings for Aug. 9-15
abstract: A guide to theater productions in New York, with a special note of shows in previews or about to open.
lead_paragraph: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Concert App WillCall Gets a $1.2 Million Investment
abstract: The app, which recommends concerts for the hipster crowd, received the investment from some big players in the music industry.
lead_paragraph: WillCall, a smartphone app that recommends concerts for the hipster crowd, has received a $1.2 million investment from some of the biggest players in the music industry, including Sean Parker, the Spotify board member and former Facebook president, and Coran Capshaw, who manages the Dave Matthews Band and controls a broad empire of concerts and artist management, WillCall announced on Wednesday.

headline: This Week's Movies: Aug. 9, 2013
abstract: The New York Times film critics on "Elysium," "Lovelace" and "Prince Avalanche."
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics on "Elysium," "Lovelace" and "Prince Avalanche."

headline: Killers Who Just Won’t Lighten Up
abstract: Thugs and detectives roam a dystopian, decaying Detroit in “Low Winter Sun,” a new crime drama on AMC.
lead_paragraph: Film noir doesn’t mean that every scene has to be shot in the dark.

headline: Chinese Invest in Queens Real Estate
abstract: Buyers from mainland China account for as many as half the purchasers at certain buildings in Flushing.
lead_paragraph: Quick, name a New York neighborhood that has investors from China buying properties. Midtown? TriBeCa? The Upper East Side?

headline: A Woman Who Showed It All Yet Hid Everything
abstract: “Lovelace,” starring Amanda Seyfried as Linda Lovelace, looks at the woman who starred in the film “Deep Throat.”
lead_paragraph: “Lovelace,” a movie about the chasm between public perception and private experience, pulls off a sly bait and switch. It’s inspired by the autobiography of one Linda Boreman, who when she was young, permed and under the spell of a violent pimp earned her place in hard-core history by suppressing her gag reflex in the 1972 film “Deep Throat.” With its “Boogie Nights” typeface and mustachioed dudes as slick and artificial as their Qiana threads, “Lovelace” promises the down-and-dirty best (or worst) with a snigger and pulsating beats. It delivers just as promised only to do a 180 in order to tell another, uglier story, this one involving beatings, rape and 24/7 terror.

headline: Teaching Ballet Language of Pop
abstract: The Ballet v6.0 festival at the Joyce kicked off this week with a triple bill from BalletX.
lead_paragraph: No one knows where ballet is headed. Onstage, it can’t be preserved as if in aspic. Many of us have already seen it change considerably in our lifetimes; it’s likely that more changes will follow.

headline: Take the Janeiac Quiz
abstract: A panel of Austen experts devised a quiz to separate the Lizzys from the Lydias, the true devotees from the casual admirers.
lead_paragraph: A panel of Austen experts devised a quiz to separate the Lizzys from the Lydias, the true devotees from the casual admirers.

headline: The Cultivation of Belief
abstract: In his documentary “The Gardener,” the Iranian filmmaker Mohsen Makhmalbaf debates the role of religion in holy sites of the Baha’i faith.
lead_paragraph: The Iranian filmmaker Mohsen Makhmalbaf opens “The Gardener” with the declaration: “I am an agnostic filmmaker.” From anyone else, this might seem like a simple statement, but not from the complex Mr. Makhmalbaf. In 1974, when he was 17, religious and involved in a guerrilla group, he stabbed a policeman, for which he received a bullet to the stomach and a prison sentence.

headline: Mobilizing to Feed Beachgoers
abstract: Seven Long Beach, N.Y., restaurants licensed a parking lot near the beach to try to bring life back to the waterfront after Hurricane Sandy.
lead_paragraph: Even before Long Beach reopened the first half-mile stretch of its rebuilt boardwalk on July 27, a group of food-truck vendors nearby, calling themselves Shoregasboard, had been helping to keep the spirit of summer alive in the city, which was badly battered by Hurricane Sandy.

headline: For a Crop-Duster, There’s More to Life Than Spraying the Fields
abstract: “Disney’s Planes,” an animated feature, is the story of a small plane who’s afraid of heights.
lead_paragraph: Not so long ago, if you bought a ticket to an animated children’s movie, you could expect to spend 90 minutes watching a princess slowly fall for a handsome young man, or some variation on that theme. These days, though, the odds are good that you will instead find yourself watching a race. There was “Cars” in 2006, followed by “Cars 2” in 2011. Last year’s engaging hit “Wreck-It Ralph” built to a big race, too. And just last month, “Turbo” brought us a speedy snail.

headline: Along the F.D.R. Drive, a Cliffhanger for a Darkly Romantic Wall
abstract: Rockefeller University proposes enlarging its campus by building another deck over the roadway.
lead_paragraph: Rockefeller University, seeking to enlarge its campus, has proposed building a deck over the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive from East 64th to East 68th Street. The project will darken yet another leg of what was once a sunny waterside stretch of twists and turns.

headline: Young Canadian Takes Spotlight at Rogers Cup
abstract: After a strong performance at Wimbledon, Eugenie Bouchard, a 19-year-old from Quebec, is becoming a household name, particularly in Canada.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — If there was any question about the face of women’s tennis in Canada, one only had to look up while entering the main gates at this week’s Rogers Cup. Emblazoned across the top of the Rexall Centre is the youngest entry at this week’s event, the 19-year-old Eugenie Bouchard.

headline: Taking the Fast Train to Win a Mob Princess
abstract: The Bollywood superstar Shah Rukh Khan plays a man kidnapped by hoods and taken to an Indian village in “Chennai Express.”
lead_paragraph: “Chennai Express” feels like a sumptuous meal with carefully chosen wine and tasty appetizers but a botched main course. Money and visual care have been lavished on this Bollywood action-comedy-romance and glossy stars engaged (Shah Rukh Khan and Deepika Padukone). But the movie chugs along for most of its 2 hours and 20 minutes searching for comedy and characters in a frantically overplotted story.

headline: Two Houses, Two Piano Masterworks
abstract: Paul Lewis took on Mozart and Schubert in one night at Avery Fisher Hall and the Kaplan Penthouse as part of the Mostly Mozart festival.
lead_paragraph: The Mostly Mozart festival provides shifts of perspective and scale swifter than anything else on New York’s musical calendar. I began Wednesday evening listening to the pianist Paul Lewis play Mozart with the festival’s house orchestra from the last row of Avery Fisher Hall, and two hours later I was just a few feet from him as he played Schubert, solo, in the Kaplan Penthouse.

headline: Two Brothers, Fighting Crime With Crime
abstract: Two fraternal detectives wrestle with murder and morality in Nick Murphy’s crime drama “Blood.”
lead_paragraph: Trying to cram a six-part BBC television series into a 92-minute movie means inevitable narrative tinkering, but “Blood” feels more damaged than most. Dark, airless and packed with psychological hurt that seems to spring from nowhere, this angry morality play, tucked inside a police procedural, suffers from a crippling lack of back story and characters whose relationships are fraught with unexplained complexity.

headline: N.C.A.A. to Quit Selling Memorabilia Online
abstract: Facing legal and public scrutiny over its business practices, the N.C.A.A. said it would stop selling player jerseys and other memorabilia through its Web site.
lead_paragraph: Facing legal and public scrutiny over its business practices, the N.C.A.A. on Thursday said it would stop selling player jerseys and other memorabilia through its Web site.

headline: Seafood With a Clam Shack Atmosphere
abstract: The third Fish Tale restaurant provides a no-frills, casual setting where patrons can order fried, baked or charbroiled seafood dishes.
lead_paragraph: The “79” emblazoned on servers’ T-shirts at the new waterfront outpost of Lenny and Joe’s Fish Tale at Long Wharf marks the year that the brothers Lenny and Joe Goldberg opened their first Fish Tale, a roadside clam shack with four picnic tables on Route 1 in Madison.

headline: A Hole in the Ground, Worshiped and Feared
abstract: In “Jug Face,” a pregnant teenager tries to flee a backwoods community when she learns that she may be sacrificed to a mysterious pit.
lead_paragraph: Shirley Jackson’s short story “The Lottery” has nothing on the grisly compulsory rituals of a backcountry settlement in Chad Crawford Kinkle’s handily made debut feature, “Jug Face.” Periodically, a designated potter creates a jug bearing the likeness of an unlucky villager, who is then sacrificed to appease a hallowed pit in the ground. The practice has been going on for ages, which might account for the village’s small population, but it takes just one person to jam the process.

headline: Jane, Plain No More: A Year of Austen Glamour
abstract: Here in the 200th birthday year for “Pride and Prejudice,” Jane Austen has become an insatiable cottage industry.
lead_paragraph: Oh, Jane. What a summer it’s been for your insatiable cottage industry — a cottage about the size of Darcy’s pile at Pemberley, at this point. Here in the 200th birthday year for “Pride and Prejudice,” it seems as if not a week goes by without new grist. Last month the Bank of England announced that it would feature Jane Austen on the £10 note, making Jane the only woman besides the queen and an obscure prison reformer to be honored on British currency; a Twitter war erupted, with the most extreme position taken by someone who tweeted rape and death threats against the woman who’d lobbied the bank to feature a woman.

headline: Margaret Pellegrini, 89, Munchkin From Land of Oz
abstract: Ms. Pellegrini danced in a flowerpot hat in the classic 1939 film and was a regular at “Oz” events in later years.
lead_paragraph: Margaret Pellegrini, one of the last three surviving Munchkins from the 1939 film “The Wizard of Oz,” died on Aug. 7 in Phoenix. She was 89.

headline: Woes of Detroit Hurt Borrowing by Its Neighbors
abstract: Two weeks after Detroit declared bankruptcy, cities, counties and other local governments in Michigan are getting a cold shoulder in the municipal bond market.
lead_paragraph: The Detroit Effect has rippled all the way to Wall Street.

headline: Baring Their Souls in a Film Audition
abstract: A documentary by Tinatin Gurchiani, from the former Soviet republic of Georgia, peeks into the lives of young people there and their yearning — for fame, family or just financial relief.
lead_paragraph: Standing before a concrete wall washed in peeling blue paint, the boy is shy but expectant. “What is your biggest dream?” the filmmaker Tinatin Gurchiani asks him, her voice gently prodding. The boy would like to be an actor, but the question is a Trojan horse. Answering it, he soon finds that more than dreams come tumbling out.

headline: Canada on the Rise
abstract: American men’s tennis is falling behind Canada’s.
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — Has American men’s tennis now fallen behind Canada?

headline: As Foreign Fighters Flood Syria, Fears of a New Extremist Haven
abstract: Extremists are carving out pockets of territory for Islamist militants, posing what intelligence officials say may become the greatest security threat in the world today.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — As foreign fighters pour into Syria at an increasing clip, extremist groups are carving out pockets of territory that are becoming havens for Islamist militants, posing what United States and Western intelligence officials say may be developing into one of the biggest terrorist threats in the world today.

headline: 16 Medal of Freedom Honorees Are Named
abstract: President Bill Clinton and Oprah Winfrey will be among the 16 recipients of the nation’s highest civilian honor.
lead_paragraph: Bill Clinton, Oprah Winfrey and 14 others will receive the Presidential Medal of Freedom this year. The White House announced Thursday that the president will bestow the nation’s highest civilian honor on a class that includes activists, athletes, musicians and scientists.

headline: Karen Black, Versatile Character Actress, Dies at 74
abstract: Ms. Black, who was nominated for an Academy Award for best supporting actress, later seemed to specialize in horror movies and thrillers.
lead_paragraph: Karen Black, an actress whose roles in several signature films of the late 1960s and ’70s included a prostitute who shared an LSD trip with the bikers played by Dennis Hopper and Peter Fonda in “Easy Rider” and a waitress unhappily devoted to the alienated musician played by Jack Nicholson in “Five Easy Pieces,” died on Thursday in Los Angeles. She was 74.

headline: Judge Denies Ex-Defense Team’s Bid to Limit Role in Fort Hood Suspect’s Trial
abstract: Former lawyers for Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, who has admitted being the gunman in the 2009 rampage, said that helping him achieve his death-sentence goal violates their ethics as defense lawyers.
lead_paragraph: KILLEEN, Tex. — The judge overseeing the military trial of the Army psychiatrist charged in a deadly shooting rampage at the Fort Hood base denied on Thursday his former lawyers’ request to limit their role in the case. The ruling came a day after the lawyers said they could no longer assist him because he was seeking the same goal as prosecutors — to be sentenced to death.

headline: Journey Across a Wide Spectrum
abstract: “The United States of Autism” follows Richard Everts, the director, whose son is autistic, as he journeys across the country to visit families affected by autism.
lead_paragraph: The spectrum of autism is wide, as the low-budget documentary “The United States of Autism” shows. Its host, Richard Everts (also the director and the father of an autistic son), introduces 20 families dealing with the disorder, visited during 40 days of road travel across the country. He meets the highly verbal, troubled only in social situations. He meets the nonverbal, whose physical struggles exhaust financial and emotional resources. He meets parents displaying pain or pride, or both, about their children.

headline: Jack Clement, Producer and Country Songwriter, Dies at 82
abstract: Mr. Clement worked with stars like Johnny Cash and Waylon Jennings, and had a long association with Charley Pride.
lead_paragraph: Jack Clement, whose career as a producer, engineer, songwriter and arranger began in the early days of rock ’n’ roll and included work with country stars like Johnny Cash, Waylon Jennings and Charley Pride as well as noncountry artists like U2, died on Thursday at his home in Nashville. He was 82.

headline: Walking Funny and Fast Puts Russia City on Map
abstract: Four of the five top-ranked female distance race walkers in the world are from Saransk, an otherwise unremarkable city of about 310,000 people 320 miles southeast of Moscow.
lead_paragraph: SARANSK, Russia — Their hips swinging, their arms pumping, the sports heroes of Saransk set out for their daily workout in a city park, followed by dozens of wide-eyed young admirers.

headline: New Jersey's $24 Million Election
abstract: A breakdown of the costs involved in the special election to choose a replacement for the late Senator Frank R. Lautenberg.
lead_paragraph: A breakdown of the costs involved in the special election to choose a replacement for the late Senator Frank R. Lautenberg.

headline: 30 Years Later, Reverberations of a Fatal Fight
abstract: A film by Jesse James Miller focuses on the boxer Ray Mancini, whose 1982 bout against the South Korean fighter Duk-koo Kim ended with Mr. Kim fatally wounded.
lead_paragraph: Jesse James Miller’s moving documentary “The Good Son” is like a brisk novel with a bigger-than-life protagonist. Boxing fans already know of Ray Mancini, a k a Boom Boom, former World Boxing Association lightweight champion: His 1982 bout against the South Korean fighter Duk-koo Kim ended with Mr. Kim fatally wounded. He died of a subdural hematoma, leaving behind a pregnant fiancée. But the film, beautifully shot by Ian Kerr (who evokes the era with photographs, yellowed newspaper clips and fight footage), peels back fresh layers that will captivate nonfans too.

headline: Rodriguez Hoping for an Unlikely Reception
abstract: Alex Rodriguez said he wanted a positive welcome from the fans in his 2013 home debut.
lead_paragraph: Alex Rodriguez tried many different ways — denial, platitudes, flattery — to answer persistent questions about what might he might face at Yankee Stadium on Friday night when he makes his 2013 home debut.

headline: Dolphin Deaths Off East Coast Worry Federal Wildlife Officials
abstract: Federal wildlife officials raised a formal alarm on Thursday over the deaths of bottlenose dolphins off the east coast, saying that a fast-spreading infection could be attacking them.
lead_paragraph: Federal wildlife officials raised a formal alarm on Thursday over the deaths of scores of bottlenose dolphins in waters off the east coast, saying that a fast-spreading infection could be attacking dolphin populations from New York to Virginia.

headline: Independent Agencies, Sometimes in Name Only
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Presidents generally choose the leaders of independent commissions, but the other members are picked on Capitol Hill, which means that the leaders can find it difficult to accomplish anything.
lead_paragraph: In 1985, President Ronald Reagan had to fill a Democratic slot on the Securities and Exchange Commission. He chose a young lawyer and economist, Joseph A. Grundfest.

headline: Opponents in New Jersey Senate Race Struggle to Match Booker’s Star Power
abstract: Democratic hopefuls complained about being overshadowed by the mayor of Newark in a special election.
lead_paragraph: PATERSON, N.J. — Were this a typical campaign, any of the candidates would be a strong contender to represent New Jersey in the United States Senate. There is the State Assembly speaker who has worked her way up through local politics and would be the first woman as well as the first African-American to represent the state in the Senate. The 13-term congressman endorsed as a “workhorse” by the family of the senator whose death opened up the seat. The eight-term congressman who has served on the House Intelligence Committee, in addition to being a nuclear physicist and a five-time “Jeopardy!” champion.

headline: Mismatch in Every Possible Way
abstract: In the comedy “I Give It a Year,” Rose Byrne and Rafe Spall are newlyweds whose family and friends are convinced that they won’t last.
lead_paragraph: In “I Give It a Year,” a smutty script and a passel of objectionable characters form an imperfect rom-com union — one that will, with any luck, fade from the mind long before its title suggests.

headline: Savory Afghan Fare, and Belly Dancing, Too
abstract: Dishes at 3 Olives, in Raritan, N.J., are prepared as the chef’s mother used to prepare them in Kabul.
lead_paragraph: We knew there was belly dancing, because we entered 3 Olives restaurant through the bar, where a sign announced it. But, distracted by the conversation and the food, we had forgotten about it until the high-volume Arabic music began. The server was apologetic but firm — the dancer needed loud music — but told us it would not last long.

headline: Food-Safety Microscope on High-End Kitchens

lead_paragraph: President Obama urged Greece on Thursday to find ways to build its economy even as it continues to cut spending in an effort to recover from a debt-driven economic crisis. In a meeting in the Oval Office, Mr. Obama told Antonis Samaras, the Greek prime minister, that policies focused only on spending reductions would not help Greece return to economic prosperity. Mr. Obama said after the meeting, “It’s important that we have a plan for fiscal consolidation to manage the debt, but it’s also important that growth and jobs are a focus.” Mr. Samaras echoed Mr. Obama’s concerns, noting that youth unemployment in his country had reached 60 percent. He said that Greece must reach for policies for “growth and the creation of new jobs.”

lead_paragraph: Two 19-year-olds who have been held on a criminal complaint in the investigation of the Boston Marathon bombings were indicted by a federal grand jury on Thursday on obstruction of justice charges. The two, Dias Kadyrbayev and Azamat Tazhayakov, attended the University of Massachusetts, Dartmouth, with Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who the authorities say worked with his brother, Tamerlan, to set off bombs at the marathon, killing 3 and wounding more than 260. The indictment says the teenagers, friends with Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, removed items including a laptop and a backpack with fireworks from his dormitory room and put them in trash in New Bedford, Mass. The two could face up to 20 years in prison, a $250,000 fine and deportation, as they are both Kazakh nationals. A third friend of Mr. Tsarnaev’s, Robel Phillipos, has been charged with lying to investigators.

headline: Dirty Petty Things

Over the last week, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s first and second picks for the job withdrew their names from consideration.

lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:51 p.m. | The beleaguered hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors is bracing for investors to pull virtually all of their remaining money, a humbling blow to a once-powerful firm hobbled by criminal insider trading charges.

headline: Suburban London Father Is Revealed as a Fugitive Italian Mobster
abstract: A London judge on Friday denied bail to Domenico Rancadore, wanted by the Italian police since 1999 to serve a seven-year sentence for extortion and other mob crimes.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — To the Italian police, he was Domenico Rancadore, or “the professor,” a Mafia boss on the lam as a dangerous fugitive for almost two decades, a onetime enforcer for the Sicilian Cosa Nostra. To those who lived near him on a leafy street in a bland West London suburb, he was Marc Skinner, a father of two, a former teacher and a good neighbor who spent contented hours buffing the paint jobs on his fancy cars.

A decision against Samsung by the commission would be another sign that Apple has the momentum in the patent disputes engulfing the mobile market, Nick Wingfield and Brian X. Chen report.

headline: S.E.C.’s New Tack in JPMorgan Inquiry
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission is seeking to extract a rare admission of wrongdoing from JPMorgan Chase. | SAC Capital Advisors agreed to keep most of its money in its fund while operating under a criminal indictment. | América Móvil offered to buy the stake in KPN it did not already own. | William A. Ackman urged J.C. Penney to speed up a search for a permanent chief.
lead_paragraph: S.E.C. SAID TO PRESS JPMORGAN FOR ADMISSION OF WRONGDOING  | The Securities and Exchange Commission is seeking to level civil charges against JPMorgan Chase and extract a rare admission of wrongdoing, as an investigation into last year’s multibillion-dollar trading loss enters its final stage, Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg report in DealBook. If JPMorgan concedes to some wrongdoing, such an admission would set an important precedent for the S.E.C., which for decades allowed defendants to “neither admit nor deny wrongdoing.” An agreement could come as soon as this fall, people briefed on the case said, adding that the agency had not threatened to charge JPMorgan executives.

abstract: Eric Bogosian will perform at Bank Street Theater Oct. 1-20 as part of the Labyrinth Theater Company’s 2013-14 season.
lead_paragraph: Labyrinth Theater Company announced on Friday that in October, as part of its 2013-14 season, the Obie Award-winning playwright Eric Bogosian would perform roughly 100 monologues from his popular one-man shows from the 1980s and ’90s. The monologues, culled from plays like “Sex, Drugs, Rock & Roll” and “Pounding Nails in the Floor With My Forehead,” will differ for each performance, which will run Oct. 1-20 at the Bank Street Theater.

headline: President Moves to Ease Worries on Surveillance
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)']
abstract: President Obama sought to take control of the surveillance debate, releasing a legal justification for domestic spying and calling for more scrutiny of National Security Agency programs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Friday sought to take control of the roiling debate over the National Security Agency’s surveillance practices, releasing a more detailed legal justification for domestic spying and calling for more openness and scrutiny of the N.S.A.’s programs to reassure a skeptical public that its privacy is not being violated.

headline: Fear Stalks Villages on Kashmir Border
abstract: Thousands of villagers are living in fear along the Line of Control, the disputed border between the two parts of Kashmir administered by India and Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: CHURUNDA, Jammu and Kashmir— On Tuesday morning, Abdul Rasheed Deedar, a 36-year-old laborer in Churunda village on the Line of Control, the disputed mountainous border dividing the Indian- and Pakistan-administered portions of Kashmir, rushed into a cave-like bunker dug into the gentle slope of the village mountain.

headline: Highlights and Analysis: P.G.A. Championship Second Round
abstract: Live updates from the second round of the P.G.A. Championship at Oak Hill Country Club in suburban Rochester, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: The soft and squishy course at Oak Hill Country Club offered up another day of birdies in the second round of the P.G.A. Championship, this suburban Rochester course soaked by rain and rendered defenseless by the contestants. This charge was led by Jason Dufner, who flirted with a major-record 62 before settling for a course-record-tying 63. It was still a mind-boggling number on a normally punishing course.

headline: U.S. Companies Thrive as Workers Fall Behind
keywords: ['Wages and Salaries', 'Corporate Taxes', 'Gross Domestic Product', 'Income', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: American companies are making more money than ever, but workers’ salaries have been at the lowest percentage of the gross domestic product since 1929.
lead_paragraph: AMERICAN companies are more profitable than ever — and more profitable than we thought they were before the government revised the national income accounts last week. Wage earners are making less than we thought, in part because the government now thinks it was overestimating the amount of income not reported by taxpayers.

headline: Phillip Lim’s Stylish Everyday Wardrobe for Target
abstract: The CFDA-award-winning designer is about to introduce an affordable collection of basics for the style-conscious big-box retailer, consisting of everything from socks to vinyl jackets.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 15, Philip Lim’s first collection for Target will hit stores — five days after his 3.1 Philip Lim runway show in New York and five years after the retailer initially approached him. “It’s kind of like dating,” Lim said about the process that led to the collaboration. “It’s been about a five-year courtship, and I wasn’t ready.” So why now? “Finally at this moment, we’re like, O.K., maybe we’re both mature enough and our expectations are more realistic of what we want from each other,” he explained.

This follows on Eric Cantor’s talk about “growing deficits”, when deficits are in fact shrinking.

headline: ‘Apple Family’ Changes Sister for Final Play
abstract: J. Smith-Cameron, who played Jane in the first three Apple family plays, will not return to the role.
lead_paragraph: The Apple family of Rhinebeck, N.Y., is breaking up. Well, sort of: The Public Theater announced on Thursday that its ambitious production of Richard Nelson’s four-part “Apple Family Plays” would not include the actress J. Smith-Cameron, who played the sister Jane in the first three. They had their premieres at the Public during the falls of 2010, 2011 and 2012; the fourth play, “Regular Singing,” will run in repertory this fall with the earlier plays, which drew widespread critical acclaim for their portrait of a politically disillusioned family of four siblings and their beloved uncle, whom they are slowly losing to dementia.

headline: ‘She Told Herself She Couldn’t Die Because She Had To Write His Story’
abstract: How a forgotten musical genius became one woman’s obsession — and she, in turn, became mine.
lead_paragraph: If his life had gone just a bit differently, Curt Boettcher might have been another Brian Wilson. Joseph Gordon-Levitt might be playing him in a modern-day biopic. College students would steal and hoard their parents’ copies of his records. As it stands, Boettcher — a pop-music producer whose heyday was the late ’60s — now survives in rock history mostly as a liner-note credit. He could have been, but never was. Yet he enjoys a godlike status among a select group of music fans, for whom obscurity is more enticing than fame.

headline: Who Made That Sippy Cup?
abstract: He wasn’t just a parent; he was also a mechanical engineer.

headline: Eternal Bragging Rights
abstract: A tradition based on fantasy is tested by reality.
lead_paragraph: Since 1991 I’ve competed in a fantasy football league with my college buddies, most of whom hail from the great state of New Jersey. Fantasy football leagues typically draft online, but we still conduct our business face to face, convening once a year, in late August, at a faded South Jersey hotel, thick with cigarette smoke. It’s a weekend filled with steaks, beer, Bruce Springsteen bootlegs and affectionately toothless insults; a weird alternate universe where I wash down Cool Ranch Doritos with Mountain Dew and occasionally sleep in my clothes.

headline: Harrison Ford on Fanboys and Fat Suits
abstract: And why you just can’t beat a good list on a piece of paper in your pocket.
lead_paragraph: Your new movie, “Paranoia,” is about corporate espionage and greed. Do you think we’ve seen the end of the days when Hollywood could make an upbeat movie about corporate life like “Working Girl”?  I shouldn’t think so. I think businesspeople are like every other type of character — they come in all varieties. And “Working Girl” depended on the glass ceiling for women, and what a pleasure it was to see someone break through. And it was funny. But now, I’m sure there’s more demand for movies about how corporations are dictating our lives in many ways.

headline: Help From Evangelicals (Without Evangelizing) Meets the Needs of an Oregon Public School
abstract: An Oregon church lends a hand at an urban public school, fulfilling needs all around while avoiding the tripwire of church-state separation.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — Four summers ago, on her first day as an administrator at Roosevelt High School here, Charlene Williams heard that the Christians were coming. Some members of an evangelical church were supposed to be painting hallways, repairing bleachers, that sort of thing. The prospect of such help, in the fervently liberal and secular microclimate of Portland, did not exactly fill her with joy.

headline: Post-Water-Cooler TV
abstract: The men and women who steer six of the best TV dramas talk about the challenges of making a show in the Twitter age.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — For decades, the TV viewing experience was much the same. Tune into your favorite show, week by patient week, all on the network’s schedule. Feedback was restricted to faceless Nielsen ratings and perhaps a plaintive letter or phone call to executives complaining about a favorite show’s cast change or cancellation.

headline: Thanks, but No Thanks
abstract: Some authors are less comfortable with prizes than others.
lead_paragraph: This week, Phillip Lopate writes about how authors deal with recognition — or with being ignored. Accepting his Nobel Prize in 1962, John Steinbeck struck a self-effacing note: “In my heart there may be doubt that I deserve the Nobel award over other men of letters whom I hold in respect and reverence — but there is no question of my pleasure and pride in having it for myself.”

headline: Aug. 9: Where the Candidates Are Today

lead_paragraph: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

headline: Seal of Approval
abstract: The spirited vision of Randolph Caldecott lives on in the picture books we prize today.
lead_paragraph: “It is deeply satisfying to win a prize in front of a lot of people.” E. B. White wrote these wise words with a pig in mind, in the closing pages of “Charlotte’s Web.” More than a decade earlier, librarians bet that the same principle might apply to illustrators when on June 24, 1937, a committee of the American Library Association met at the Pierre Hotel in New York to lay plans for an annual award honoring the year’s most distinguished contribution to children’s book illustration by an artist who is an American citizen or resident — the Randolph Caldecott Medal.

headline: Midlist Crisis
abstract: The seeming randomness of literary awards torments some writers, driving them into fits of paranoia.
lead_paragraph: There is nothing more becoming in an author than modesty. Regardless of what egotistic airs they may put on, most writers, I suspect, have a fairly accurate assessment of their own worth and achievement. Still, they — we — are dependent to an uncomfortable extent on the world’s judgment, perhaps hoping that by some fluke the world will rate us higher than we rate ourselves. The problem is not that the world so often ignores literary effort (though that is certainly the case), but that to the degree it breaks its silence it tends to distribute the rewards in a mystifyingly erratic manner.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: TOBY’S ROOM,  by Pat Barker. (Anchor, $15.95.) Barker has traced the psychic reverberations of World War I through a remarkable series of novels: the “Regeneration” trilogy, “Life Class” and now “Toby’s Room.” A sequel to “Life Class,” “Toby’s Room” portrays a group of students at the Slade School of Fine Art in London; at its center is Elinor Brooke, a painter who works as a medical illustrator while unraveling the mystery of what happened to her brother, Toby, a doctor serving at the front.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE SOUND OF THINGS FALLING, by Juan Gabriel Vásquez. Translated by Anne McLean. (Riverhead, $27.95.) This gripping Colombian novel, built on the country’s tragic history with the drug trade, meditates on love, fate and death.

headline: Trouble Followed
abstract: A family tragedy in the Arizona desert split Justin St. Germain’s world into before and after.
lead_paragraph: Justin St. Germain’s spectacular memoir, “Son of a Gun,” calls to mind two others of the past decade: J. R. Moehringer’s “Tender Bar” and Nick Flynn’s “Another Bull____ Night in Suck City.” All three are about boys becoming men in a broken world. All three feature disappeared fathers. And all three dig into the reality behind the facade of the American dream: namely, that there is no glory in being a blue-collar grunt in this country, that to be working class is to live a tenuous existence, one in which the authors and half the people they know are one misstep away from surfing garage-sale sofas in other people’s living rooms.

headline: Through a Lens Darkly
abstract: A BBC film crew struggles with making a documentary about an Indian prison village.
lead_paragraph: In discussing his film “The Thin Blue Line,” Errol Morris called the claims of cinéma vérité — the style of documentary that privileges direct and unobtrusive observation — “spurious.” “Style does not guarantee truth,” Morris said. “The use of available light and a hand-held camera does not mean that what you are doing is any more truthful than anything else. Truth is a pursuit, it’s a quest.”

headline: Patriotic Roar
abstract: Brenda Wineapple surveys a time of ferment and high passion.
lead_paragraph: So many histories of the Civil War era have been published that one would think writing another would be pretty much a matter of choosing a major political event — the Compromise of 1850, say, with its controversial Fugitive Slave Act — and then pressing cruise control. We drive on a familiar freeway that takes us through a deepening valley: the growing gulf between the North and the South during the 1850s. We view familiar scenery like the Lincoln-Douglas debates. Then, suddenly, we encounter a multicar pileup: the Civil War.

headline: The Ways of Abandonment
abstract: At an exclusive boarding school, a lonely voyeur becomes pruriently obsessed with a pair of star-crossed lovers.
lead_paragraph: As the writer Jeanette Winterson says, “Men have been writing about women forever.” This was in an interview in The Guardian with A. M. Homes, whom Winterson describes as “a woman writing dangerously.” What Winterson means is that Homes is fearless about writing from a male point of view. (Think of Harry, the narrator of Homes’s recent novel, “May We Be Forgiven.”)

headline: Today in Small Business: Amy’s Baking, Again
abstract: Why forecasters can’t forecast. Finding your break-even point. How small-businesses pay higher tax rates than big corporations.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: French Lessons
abstract: In Saira Shah’s novel, life goes terribly awry for a couple who move to the Languedoc region.
lead_paragraph: There’s an arresting photograph on the cover of the paperback edition of “The Storyteller’s Daughter,” Saira Shah’s memoir of her adventures in war-torn Afghanistan — an Afghan boy in a turban, regarding the viewer with a shrewdly inquisitive expression. The “boy” is Shah herself, the daughter of the celebrated Sufi fabulist Idries Shah. Born in England in 1964, she returned at age 21 to her father’s homeland, then under Soviet occupation. Disguised as a young man, braving frostbite and Russian missiles, she reported back to English newspapers and television on the American-backed mujahedeen, who were importing, as she put it, “a brand of extremist political Islam that . . . had been almost unknown inside Afghanistan.”

headline: Adam’s Rib, van Gogh’s Ear, Einstein’s Brain
abstract: A multidisciplinary dissection of the human body through art, science, literature and history.
lead_paragraph: For a species so pleased with its own brain, we are surprisingly ambivalent about the rest of our body. We tend to admire other people’s bodies, especially if they’re Olympians or shirtless Russian presidents, but most of us are constantly seeking to improve our own by starving or stuffing, injecting, waxing, straightening, piercing, lifting and squeezing. In 2010 in the United States alone, we spent $10 billion on cosmetic surgery, and that’s not including Brazilian Blowouts.

headline: Running the Asylum
abstract: The characters in this novel are patients and counselors at a treatment center.
lead_paragraph: A childhood swimming accident has rendered a young woman named Karly “mentally impaired,” unable to count coins or operate a washing machine. A young man named Mick, who can’t remember life before the onset of schizophrenia at age 17, has repeatedly failed to stabilize his medication between “ragging and dragging.” Their fellow patient Alonso’s main occupation is masturbation, while spooky Vex looks likely to bash someone’s head in at the slightest provocation.

headline: The Scene Also Rises
abstract: In this first novel, expats in early-90s Prague teach English, drink beer and search for meaning.
lead_paragraph: In the mid-90s, I told a woman I met at a party that I was moving to Prague.

headline: That First Bromance
abstract: In Mark Slouka’s novel, a close friendship offers two teenagers respite from their unhappy homes.
lead_paragraph: A familiar music beats throughout “Brewster,” Mark Slouka’s intense and elegiac novel about the friendship between two teenage boys during the late 1960s and early ’70s. The Beatles and the Stones are on every radio. Every cafeteria conversation finds a way to Muhammad Ali or Charles Manson, Kent State or the draft.

headline: Covert Losses
abstract: In Lea Carpenter’s novel, a mother awaits news of her son, missing in action.
lead_paragraph: Through the heart of Lea Carpenter’s earnest first novel, “Eleven Days,” courses the myth of a mother and son: the sea nymph Thetis and her warlike child Achilles. Thetis, so legend runs, submerged Achilles in the River Styx to inoculate him from harm but neglected to dip the back of the ankle by which she held him fast. The prophecy that Achilles would prove a warrior greater than his father, but would also die prematurely in his bid for fame, remained a burden to the vigilant Thetis, who did her utmost to circumvent this destiny.

headline: Raw Materials
abstract: A memoir, presented as a self-interview, by the Nobel laureate Imre Kertesz.
lead_paragraph: Two of the great pessimistic proclamations of 20th-century literature — Adorno’s “To write a poem after Auschwitz is barbaric” and Beckett’s “I can’t go on, I’ll go on” — have at least one thing in common. They both address the inadequacy of language to articulate reality. Better to say nothing, they both say, or at least that’s the first half of what they say. If Adorno leaves off the productive half of the equation — “I’ll go on” — other writers have supplied it for him, in the form of a very large body of work concerned with the Holocaust that is not only ethically accountable but also incredibly rich and inventive. In fact it is not too much to claim, of Holocaust literature, that the struggle to say what is unsayable has paradoxically yielded some of the most extraordinary literary works we have.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Liane Moriarty, whose novel “The Husband’s Secret” is on the extended hardcover list, has said her first kiss “blew my good little Catholic girl mind.”
lead_paragraph: PANDORA’S ENVELOPE: The Australian writer Liane Moriarty has won a devoted following for her novels chronicling the lives of “typical suburban mums,” but she’s never cracked the New York Times best-seller list. That may change soon, though — “The Husband’s Secret,” Moriarty’s fifth novel for adults, is hovering at No. 17 on the extended hardcover list after a wave of endorsements and strong reviews. The plot is, essentially, a version of Pandora’s box: a happily married woman finds an envelope from her husband with instructions to open it only after his death, and decides to peek ahead of time.

headline: In TriBeCa, Squeezing In Some Condo Pizazz
abstract: The 21-story condo, to be called Tribeca Royale, has refocused attention on an area where controversy stalled plans for a Muslim Community Center.
lead_paragraph: At three blocks between Broadway and Greenwich Street in TriBeCa, Park Place is a wisp of a road. But it has shown it can make big news.

abstract: How did MLK become an object of universal approbation?
lead_paragraph: John Holbo asks a very good question inspired by an in-flight magazine’s feel-good piece about Martin Luther King: how did public expression of racism become unacceptable?

headline: Lonely in the L.P.G.A.
abstract: Asian players have transformed women’s professional golf in the United States, but they face challenges that go far beyond the course. Some can find it difficult to adapt.
lead_paragraph: DAVENPORT, Fla. — Chie Arimura, a 25-year-old professional golfer from Japan, sat alone at a table for six in her rented home, her back so straight that her shoulders jutted out. Her fingernails, painted dark pink with sparkly gold on the ring fingers, clicked against the ceramic dishes as she set out a bowl of romaine and ham and a plate of fried salmon.

headline: ‘Finding Nemo’ Sequel Is Altered in Response to Orcas Documentary
keywords: ['AMUSEMENT AND THEME PARKS', 'ANIMATED FILMS', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Movies']
abstract: The ending of the “Finding Nemo” sequel has been rewritten in reaction to publicity surrounding the documentary “Blackfish.”
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. – “Blackfish,” the orcas-in-captivity documentary that has seared SeaWorld with negative publicity, prompted Pixar Animation Studios to rewrite part of its coming “Finding Nemo” sequel.

headline: Pardon My Spanish
keywords: ['Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: A scandal over the king of Morocco’s decision to release a pedophile from jail is testing the relationship between the crown and its citizens.
lead_paragraph: RABAT, Morocco — This year, like every year on Throne Day, King Mohamed VI of Morocco handed out royal pardons. With the occasion falling on July 30, during an official visit from King Juan Carlos I of Spain, it was announced that 48 Spanish citizens serving time in Moroccan prisons would be freed.

headline: Falcone Adds Defendants in Effort to Keep LightSquared
abstract: Just days after suing the satellite television mogul Charles W. Ergen and another hedge fund in a last-ditch attempt to maintain control of LightSquared, Philip A. Falcone has turned his focus on the GPS industry in another lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: The hedge fund billionaire Philip A. Falcone is in a litigious mood.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Who Was T. E. Lawrence?
abstract: This week, Scott Anderson talks about “Lawrence in Arabia”; Brenda Wineapple discusses “Ecstatic Nation”; Leonard Marcus on the life and work of Randolph Caldecott; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Scott Anderson talks about “Lawrence in Arabia”; Brenda Wineapple discusses “Ecstatic Nation”; Leonard Marcus on the life and work of Randolph Caldecott; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

abstract: This week, Scott Anderson, Brenda Wineapple and Leonard Marcus.
lead_paragraph: This week, Scott Anderson, Brenda Wineapple and Leonard Marcus.

headline: The Gun Report: August 9, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Often we express frustration in this space when a child dies accidentally at the hands of a gun and parents or guardians are not charged with reckless endangerment. So it’s heartening to see that authorities in Calhoun County, in the Florida panhandle, seem to take this as seriously as we do. But this case has an interesting twist.

headline: The Kid-Friendly Brunch Becomes a Kid Takeover
abstract: My friends’ children are welcome guests in my house — but being welcome doesn’t mean hogging the chairs, the food and the spotlight.
lead_paragraph: I had friends over for brunch a few weeks ago, and to my dismay guess who automatically climbed into  the chairs I had placed around the apartment? The kids. I had billed this event as kid-friendly, but it became a kid-takeover.

lead_paragraph: A seven-bedroom 1870 historic estate in West Orange and six-bedroom 1918 Dutch colonial in Great Neck.

abstract: Photos include former Gov. Eliot Spitzer in Queens, a campsite on Governors Island, and Playground 52 in the South Bronx.
lead_paragraph: Photos include former Gov. Eliot Spitzer in Queens, a campsite on Governors Island, and Playground 52 in the South Bronx.

lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "Prince Avalanche."

headline: A Getaway Apartment, in Your Own Building
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Securing a noncontiguous apartment in the same building as your home is a way to get private space away from it all, no transportation necessary.
lead_paragraph: Freddie Gershon lives with his wife, Myrna, and his dog in a penthouse duplex with a terrace in Midtown East. The space is plenty big, he concedes — 6,500 square feet.

headline: High Blood Sugar Linked to Dementia
abstract: HIgh blood glucose levels are tied to an increased risk of Alzheimer’s disease and vascular dementia in a new study.
lead_paragraph: People with diabetes face an increased risk of Alzheimer’s disease and other forms of dementia, a connection scientists and physicians have worried about for years. They still can’t explain it.

headline: Movie Review: 'Lovelace'
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "Lovelace."
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "Lovelace."

headline: Charges Fly in Feud Over Strategy at Penney
abstract: The hedge fund manager William A. Ackman stepped up his fight against fellow directors of J.C. Penney on Friday, publicly calling for the replacement of the chairman and reiterating a demand for a new chief executive.
lead_paragraph: William A. Ackman is known as an involved investor. But a public brouhaha with the board of J. C. Penney that sent letters and news releases flying on Thursday and Friday took his activism to new heights.

headline: Gallery | Portraits From the Service Window of Montauk’s Most Famous Food Truck
abstract: Grant Monahan’s book of photography documents the many customers he’s served at the beloved Ditch Witch, including Julian Schnabel and Jimmy Buffett.
