headline: Deadly Plane Crash in a Connecticut Neighborhood
abstract: There were conflicting reports on how many people died when a turboprop aircraft hit homes in East Haven, Conn.
lead_paragraph: Bill Henningsgaard took off in his small plane from Teterboro Airport in northern New Jersey with his son Maxwell on Friday morning to make the short hop to Connecticut, the latest leg of their tour of colleges. Maxwell was set to graduate in 2014, and they had flown across the country from the Pacific Northwest visiting campuses. Yale was next on the list.

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in Utah; Bangor, Me.
abstract: A weekly capsule of events around the globe curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Moab Music Festival, Utah, Aug. 29 to Sept. 9

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This week’s properties each have one bedroom. The first is in the West Village and has two fireplaces, the second is in a prewar Chelsea building, and the third, in Prospect Heights, includes a roof deck.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties each have one bedroom. The first is in the West Village and has two fireplaces, the second is in a prewar Chelsea building, and the third, in Prospect Heights, includes a roof deck.

headline: Cramming for Stardom at Korea’s K-Pop Schools
abstract: Private institutions have sprung up around the country to teach Korean pop music, and long-established music and dance schools have begun to get with the pop plan.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Kim Chae-young attends cram school five evenings a week, toiling deep into the night. But unlike most young South Koreans who spend hours at special schools to polish their English and math, she studies slide steps and bubbly lyrics.

headline: Sometimes Second-Best Makes a Better Role Model
abstract: Recent research suggests we may be choosing the wrong people to emulate, and that could be hurting us professionally.
lead_paragraph: RECENTLY the Yankee third baseman Alex Rodriguez, who was just suspended for 211 games for steroid use, proclaimed that he still wanted to be a role model, despite “all the noise.”

headline: The Washington Post That Was
abstract: The newspaper used to be better. But passionate journalists are still succeeding, not because of management but in spite of it.
lead_paragraph: TAKOMA PARK, Md. — WHEN I arrived in 1970, The Washington Post had just achieved escape velocity. The executive editor, Benjamin C. Bradlee, and the publisher, Katharine Graham, had launched a shabby local paper into the orbit of fame, hipness, power and phone-slamming Kennedy-style pugnacity. Watch out, New York.

headline: 30-Year Prison Sentence in Plot to Bomb U.S. Bank
abstract: Quazi Mohammad Rezwanul Ahsan Nafis, a Bangladeshi immigrant, received the minimum penalty after pleading guilty to attempting to use a weapon of mass destruction.
lead_paragraph: A Bangladeshi man who tried to blow up the Federal Reserve Bank in New York with what he thought was a 1,000-pound bomb, only to discover that the bomb was a fake and that he had been under constant federal surveillance, was sentenced to 30 years in prison on Friday.

headline: How a Passion for Steam-Powered Cars Led to Love
abstract: When Donald Davidson and Sarah Stanley met, their mutual love for Stanley Steamers heated up into a mutual love for each other.
lead_paragraph: While attending a steam car rally in Maine, Sarah Stanley, the great-granddaughter of Francis Edgar Stanley, co-founder of the Stanley Motor Company, found herself riding next to Donald Davidson, a mechanical engineer who had brought his 1913 Stanley Steamer Model 64 to the tour.

headline: The New Gazpachos
abstract: Gazpacho is perfect on a hot summer day. The Recipes for Health columnist Martha Rose Shulman offers five new ways to make it.
lead_paragraph: “Gazpacho is a summer soup, incredibly refreshing on a hot day,” writes Martha Rose Shulman in this week’s Recipes for Health. And with tomato season in full swing, it couldn’t be a better time. She writes:

headline: More On The Disappearance Of Milton Friedman
abstract: It’s the things he got right that conservatives can’t accept.
lead_paragraph: It seems that many people misunderstood my post on Milton Friedman. It was not intended as Friedman-bashing, as a claim that MF was a bad economist; in fact, I’m on record declaring Friedman a “great economists’ economist”. His work aimed primarily at a professional audience — the permanent income theory of consumption, the case for flexible exchange rates, the natural rate (even if it does break down at low inflation), the optimum quantity of money — was often, maybe even usually, brilliant, and will live on.

headline: What Inspired You to Work in the Visual Arts?
abstract: Next week, Holland Cotter will write about what set him on the path toward becoming an art critic for The Times. We want to hear from visual arts professionals about what inspired them, too.
lead_paragraph: This summer, The New York Times is publishing essays by its critics about the moments or works that prompted them to write about the arts, along with stories from readers about their own epiphanies. Previously we heard from readers who work in television, classical music, dance, pop music and video games.

headline: Big Ticket | $29 Million on Central Park West
abstract: A 3,173-foot condominium, with three bedrooms and floor-to-ceiling windows, is near the pinnacle of the 35-story tower portion of 15 Central Park West.
lead_paragraph: A sleekly appointed seven-room condominium at 15 Central Park West, the elaborate and exclusive limestone destination designed by Robert A.M. Stern, sold for $29 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Hollywood Director Takes On Texting While Driving
abstract: A documentary, called “From One Second to The Next,” explores the consequences of texting while driving.
lead_paragraph: As a toddler, Xzavier Davis-Bilbo loved to scramble around the house and yard. Nicknamed “X,” the boy imitated plays from his hometown Green Bay Packers. Then tragedy struck.

headline: After Post Sale, Spotlight Shines More Intensely on The Times
abstract: The New York Times, one of the last of the family-owned newspapers, is optimistic about staying competitive in an increasingly digital world. Should it be?
lead_paragraph: It’s surely not just coincidence that great journalism was pioneered, nurtured and celebrated at America’s great family-owned newspapers: The Wall Street Journal under the Bancrofts, The Los Angeles Times under the Chandlers, The Washington Post under the Grahams and The New York Times under the Sulzbergers.

headline: It’s a Duesie. The First, in Fact.
keywords: ['Automobiles', "Pebble Beach Concours D'Elegance (Car Show)", 'Antique and Classic Cars', 'Restoration and Renovation']
abstract: Duesenberg is often considered America’s most historically significant automotive brand and, now, after a three-year restoration, the first of the company’s cars sold to the public is to compete at the Pebble Beach concours.
lead_paragraph: Scotts Valley, Calif. — Nobody would have called the car a beauty. Impossibly high-waisted, cloaked entirely in black, with boxy hips and awkward lines, it stood primly erect on the shop floor, a lonely figure amid seductive shapes.

headline: The American Standard-Setter
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Antique and Classic Cars', "Pebble Beach Concours D'Elegance (Car Show)"]
abstract: Duesenbergs have won more Best of Show awards at Pebble Beach than any American marque. Indeed, they are regarded as so superior to their domestic peers that Duesenbergs compete in their own class.
lead_paragraph: “With its DNA in motorsports, its advanced engineering and coachbuilders like Rollston, LeBaron and Murphy, Duesenberg was the most impressive and important American car of its era,” said Sandra Button, chairman of America’s premier automotive judged competition, the Pebble Beach Concours d’Élégance.

headline: The No. 2 Duesenberg Is Also Pebble-Bound
abstract: The second Duesenberg sold to the public was found in Missouri and brought back to life by a team in California.
lead_paragraph: “We heard there was an early Model A Duesenberg for sale in Jefferson City,” Arnold Schmidt of Valencia, Calif., recalled. “So on a whim and a prayer, in 2007 Mike Hogan and I drove to Missouri to try and buy it.”

headline: Family Adapts to Coach’s Nomadic Career
abstract: Steve Hagen, the Jets’ new tight ends coach, has held 16 jobs, with 12 colleges and 2 N.F.L. teams. He and his wife tell their four children that moving is “a chance for a new adventure.”
lead_paragraph: CORTLAND, N.Y. — Steve Hagen has coached football in Illinois, Kansas and Arizona. And in Indiana, Nevada and Ohio. And in Iowa, California and North Carolina. And, now, New Jersey, with the Jets, the latest stop in his 30-year odyssey.

headline: Ethiopian Plane on Fire
abstract: Raw video of the scene at Mogadishu’s international airport, where a Ethiopian military cargo plane missed the runway and crashed, killing four of the six crew members.
lead_paragraph: Raw video of the scene at Mogadishu’s international airport, where a Ethiopian military cargo plane missed the runway and crashed, killing four of the six crew members.

headline: Toyota Recalls 342,000 Tacomas Over Seat Belt Problem
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Seat Belts']
abstract: Seat belt parts on the rear passenger compartment doors on Toyota Tacoma extended cab pickups have been coming loose, prompting the automaker to issue a recall.
lead_paragraph: Toyota will recall about 342,000 Tacoma Access Cab pickups from the 2004-11 model years because of a problem with the rear seat belts, the automaker has informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. According to a report on the agency’s Web site, Toyota says there is a problem with seat belts mounted to the short rear doors – which Toyota calls access doors – used to reach the rear passenger area.

headline: Embracing Technology and Each Other
abstract: A couple whose embrace of technology allowed them to bridge the final three blocks on their way to finding each other.
lead_paragraph: They grew up about 50 miles from each other; left their home state, Ohio, after reaching adulthood; and decades later — after a combined total of five marriages and eight children, a bevy of grandchildren and several lifetimes’ worth of adventure — landed three blocks apart in Santa Fe, N.M. But only the Internet could bring them together.

headline: From a Prominent Divorce in the Affluent Class, Lessons for All
keywords: ['Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Child Custody and Support', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: Rich people may have more assets at stake, but any couple with a broken marriage have to consider the same issues in a divorce.
lead_paragraph: IF all goes well, we’ll never hear much about Rupert and Wendi Murdoch’s divorce. The News Corporation chief executive and his wife will reach a settlement out of court for his third and her second divorce. If talks break down and the divorce goes to trial, however, we could be in for a round of sensational stories.

headline: Unemployed? No Food Stamps for You
abstract: The House G.O.P. wants to remove up to 4 million people from the food stamp program by cutting off those unable to find a job.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, Eric Cantor, the House majority leader, announced plans to rebrand the Republican Party, improving “health, happiness and prosperity for more Americans and their families.” In case you took any of that seriously, take a good look at the food stamp proposal Mr. Cantor unveiled a few days ago, one of the more brutal actions Republicans have taken against the poor since they took over the House in 2011.

headline: Artists Plan Their Sand Castles, Sponsorships Included
abstract: Creative Time sponsors its sand castle competition on Rockaway Beach in Queens, on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 6:24 p.m. | The drive-through window will be topped by a horseshoe crab, the menu board made of driftwood and the parking lot lined with seashells. That’s the vision that the artist Duke Riley has for his entry into Creative Time’s sand castle competition, which began on Rockaway Beach on Friday afternoon. If his design, a boxy building with a square turret, seems familiar – or hunger-inducing – that’s the point.

headline: Placing Products? Try Casting Them
abstract: The ill-fated, computer-animated “Foodfight!” took multiple food-brand corporate mascots and made them characters.
lead_paragraph: The brand managers at Georgia-Pacific were not about to budge. They agreed that Brawny Man, the plaid-shirted character adorning millions of paper-towel rolls, could come to life and share a moment with Mr. Clean. But their Angel Soft Baby, who had sold countless reams of toilet tissue, could never be displaced from her perch in the clouds.

headline: On Hot Days, Cold Noodles Are a Welcome Choice
abstract: Four salads and a cold noodle soup that make refreshing meals during warm weather.
lead_paragraph: Some people just don’t get hungry during a heat wave, but I’m not one of them. During the last run of hot weather I craved cold Asian noodles; I loved the way they were both cooling and filling, and the way they served as a vehicle for refreshing vegetables like cucumbers and crisp shredded cabbage. Asian noodles don’t need to be cooked al dente the way Italian pasta does, so they won’t suffer from being cooked ahead, tossed with a little sesame oil or dressing and refrigerated for a day or two. This is really helpful when the weather’s hot and you’re hungry. You reach into the refrigerator and grab a bowl of noodle salad that is no worse for wear from having been there for a day.

headline: When Andrew Johnson Freed His Slaves
abstract: Why Tennessee blacks celebrated Aug. 8, 1863 as Emancipation Day.
lead_paragraph: Eliza Johnson gathered her family’s slaves together at their East Tennessee farm on Aug. 8, 1863, to deliver the news. As one slave, William, remembered it, “She said we were free to go, or we could stay if we wanted.” With the dangers of continued Confederate military occupation and guerrilla war in the region, the slaves opted to stay put for the time being.

headline: A Ballerina in a New Realm
abstract: On Wednesday at Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival, Wendy Whelan unveils “Restless Creature,” a suite of duets.
lead_paragraph: Wendy Whelan has been a member of New York City Ballet since 1986, so it’s really no wonder that she’s feeling a little fidgety these days. On Wednesday at Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival, Ms. Whelan unveils “Restless Creature,” a suite of duets choreographed by and performed with Kyle Abraham, Joshua Beamish, Brian Brooks and Alejandro Cerrudo. In the show, which will appear beginning next March in several cities — including New York, at the Joyce Theater — Ms. Whelan, following the path of Mikhail Baryshnikov, is keen to stretch her limits.

headline: Sci-Fi Horror Fest With Nod to a Titan
abstract: Has it really been 17 years since Film Forum last hosted its late-summer extravaganza Son of Summer Sci-Fi, Fantasy & Horror?
lead_paragraph: Has it really been 17 years since Film Forum last hosted its late-summer extravaganza Son of Summer Sci-Fi, Fantasy & Horror, this year through Sept. 5? Well, it’s high time that this home of cinematic sophistication got its nerd on once again. And there’s no better way to mark the event’s return than with the family-friendly sub-festival Wild About Harryhausen, double features (for the most part) showcasing the stop-motion-animation giant Ray Harryhausen, through Sept. 8.

headline: Being Black in America
abstract: The timing is exactly right for the small, powerful retrospective show of paintings and drawings, “In the Tower: Kerry James Marshall,” at the National Gallery of Art in Washington.
lead_paragraph: With the 50th anniversary of the March on Washington coming at the end of the month, and the emotions generated by the trial of George Zimmerman in the killing of Trayvon Martin still crackling, the timing is exactly right for the small, powerful retrospective show of paintings and drawings, “In the Tower: Kerry James Marshall,” at the National Gallery of Art in Washington.

headline: Stravinsky Salute at Bard Festival
abstract: Each summer in the silver-roofed, Gehry-designed Fisher Center, the Bard Music Festival spotlights one composer.
lead_paragraph: Each summer in the silver-roofed, Gehry-designed Fisher Center, the Bard Music Festival spotlights one composer. The intense weekend lineups feature well-known and obscure repertory performed by rising and established musicians, as well as panels and talks by scholars. Stravinsky, whose “Rite of Spring” turns 100 this year, is being honored at the festival. Sunday’s afternoon lineup includes musicians like the pianist Alessio Bax, and works by Stravinsky, Debussy, Schoenberg, Ravel and Satie. That evening, Leon Botstein conducts members of the American Symphony Orchestra and soloists, including the tenor Nicholas Phan, in works by Milhaud, Poulenc, Satie and Stravinsky.

headline: The Hunted in Tanzania
abstract: Since 2006, more than 100 albinos have been maimed or killed for their body parts in Tanzania.
lead_paragraph: In his homeland, Josephat Torner is said to be a ghost. Born with albinism, Mr. Torner is among the 170,000 Tanzanians with the congenital disorder — an absence of pigment in the skin, hair and eyes — who have been hunted for their body parts, which are believed by traditional healers to bring riches to those who possess them. Since 2006, more than 100 albinos have been maimed or killed by men who hack off arms, legs, heads and genitals, forcing the government to open boarding schools to protect children and communities to build walled-in camps where families are guarded, making them refugees in their own country.

headline: Duesenberg Number One
abstract: A team of California craftsmen is restoring the first Duesenberg sold to the public to its original 1921 glory. It will compete at this year’s Pebble Beach Concours d’Élégance.
lead_paragraph: A team of California craftsmen is restoring the first Duesenberg sold to the public to its original 1921 glory. It will compete at this year’s Pebble Beach Concours d’Élégance.

headline: Nashville Singer Finds Her Voice
abstract: Maggie Rose’s debut album, “Cut to Impress” (RPM), is one of the year’s best country release, and she plays this week at the Emporium.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, a singer named Margaret Durante tried to have a go at Nashville. She released a tepid country cover of “Use Somebody,” the desperate Kings of Leon anthem — an uncommitted way to begin a career — and that was that. She kicked around the city for a while, jumping among independent labels, but only this year, remade as Maggie Rose, has she sounded anything like herself.

headline: Disorderly Conduct
abstract: New plays these days tend to come in slimmed-down sizes. But not the latest work from the Amoralists.
lead_paragraph: New plays these days tend to come in slimmed-down sizes, the better to accommodate the worrying economics of producing theater, both on Broadway and off, and at the country’s major regional theaters. The Amoralists, an exuberantly iconoclastic Off Off Broadway company known for a raw, aggressive, hypertheatrical style, is, naturally, running off in the opposite direction.

headline: The Grime Fighter: Brent Weingard Does Windows
abstract: A member of New York City’s intrepid corps of window washers has been at it for over 35 years.
lead_paragraph: The unforgiving pavement of Greenwich Street unspooled half a dozen stories below. But Brent Weingard, who had strapped himself into an olive-green harness and attached himself to a canvas belt that in turn was attached to a hook on the facade of No. 55, seemed oblivious to the fact that gravity was not his friend. Dangling outside the oversize double-hung window, the belt his only protection, Mr. Weingard didn’t bat an eye.

headline: Man on an Edge
keywords: ['Windows', 'Cleansers, Detergents and Soaps', 'Air Pollution', 'Restoration and Renovation']
abstract: Brent Weingard, of Expert Window Cleaners, has battled dirt and grime high above New York City for over 35 years.
lead_paragraph: Brent Weingard, of Expert Window Cleaners, has battled dirt and grime high above New York City for over 35 years.

headline: A New Trail at the Cliffs of Moher
abstract: A new walking trail allows visitors to get closer to the Cliffs of Moher in Ireland.
lead_paragraph: Icons of Ireland’s west, the Cliffs of Moher tower 702 feet above the churning Atlantic, and reign as the country’s most visited natural attraction. Now the intrepid can get even closer to the precipice on a new 12-mile walking trail that skirts the cliffs, linking Doolin in the north and Liscannor in the south.

headline: Able to Leap Identities in a Single Show
abstract: “Please Like Me,” a new comedy on the new cable network Pivot, stars the young Australian comic Josh Thomas.
lead_paragraph: Talk about a bad day: In 24 hours your girlfriend breaks up with you and says she thinks you’re gay; you kiss a boy (and decide that maybe she’s right); your mother tries to commit suicide; and you wind up moving in with her. All that, and you’re not yet 21. So begins “Please Like Me,” the series conceived by and starring the Australian comedian Josh Thomas on Pivot, a new cable network for millennials.

headline: Events in Westchester
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Stringer and Spitzer Go on Attack in First Debate
abstract: The candidates in the Democratic primary for New York City comptroller had an energetic exchange in a television studio for a broadcast to be shown on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: In their first face-to-face confrontation, Scott M. Stringer attacked Eliot Spitzer on Friday as a wealthy lawbreaker whom the voters should not trust with managing New York City’s money. Mr. Spitzer, in turn, described Mr. Stringer as a career politician who had accomplished little in his 20 years in elected office.

headline: Generations Past and Present, Tangled Up in Temptation
abstract: Musicians explore imaginary places and love lost in new releases from Washed Out, Diana and Buddy Guy.
lead_paragraph: Washed Out

headline: Obama Addresses Surveillance and National Security in News Conference
abstract: President Obama took questions from the news media on Friday afternoon, a day before beginning a weeklong vacation in Martha’s Vineyard that will be his last extended break from Washington before what is expected to be a contentious fall clash with Congress.
lead_paragraph: President Obama took questions from the news media on Friday afternoon, and Times reporters are providing live updates and analysis from the news conference.

headline: A Game of Catch, or Hot Potato?
abstract: Increasingly the traditional tossing of the wedding bouquet is being thrown out entirely.
lead_paragraph: It started like most, with a call from the wedding D.J. for the unattached to make their way to the dance floor. The group of women gathered slowly, in silk and taffeta, arms ceremoniously outstretched. The bouquet went flying, the California desert sky in the background. Then it fell, bounced and rested squarely at the group’s feet.

headline: Breaking Free, in Life and on Screen
abstract: The international film actress Golshifteh Farahani was a rebel growing up in Iran, and now she takes strength from her life in exile in Paris.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Growing up in Iran, Golshifteh Farahani was a rebel. She persuaded her classmates to go on strike because their school had no heat, and she lied to her parents so that her sister could spend time with her boyfriend.

headline: Cloaking an Opera in a New Identity
abstract: Ivan Fischer returns to the Mostly Mozart Festival with his second directorial effort: Mozart’s “Nozze di Figaro,” following his wildly successful “Don Giovanni” two years ago.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, a neophyte stage director, unknown among opera cognoscenti and untested in New York, scored a major triumph in his Lincoln Center debut. The opera he directed was a repertory staple, yet paradoxically a work that has stymied seasoned artists recently assigned to stage it at the Metropolitan Opera. This newcomer not only offered a vision unlike any seen previously in New York, but also pulled it off without any sets or props — or, for that matter, an opera house.

headline: Adventures in a Sinister Wonderland
abstract: “Then She Fell” derives its fractured narratives, its doppelgängers and mirror images, from “Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland” and “Through the Looking Glass.”
lead_paragraph: “Eat,” the White Queen barks, as you wonder what to do with the waferlike snack she has handed you. In the midst of this tumultuous feast, there’s no time for questions. Heaping bowls of fruit and diminutive cocktails materialize from who knows where, as she clambers onto tabletops and chairs, ricochets among cabinets and walls. A creaky lantern hangs from the ceiling; she reaches toward it and, with a brisk shove, sets it swinging on its precarious hinges. When Alice appears, our careening hostess gives her one drink, then another, luring the girlish visitor into a state as wild as her own.

headline: Reports See New Roles for Megyn Kelly and Alec Baldwin
abstract: Ms. Kelly and Mr. Baldwin are at the center of unconfirmed reports about planned programming changes at Fox News and MSNBC.
lead_paragraph: The Fox News anchor Megyn Kelly and the actor Alec Baldwin were at the center of unconfirmed reports this week about programming changes said to be planned at two of the cable news networks.

headline: A Team Player Becomes the Captain
abstract: David Lowery, having edited films for indie directors like Shane Carruth and Amy Siemetz, returns to the director’s chair for “Ain’t Them Bodies Saints.”
lead_paragraph: Even when David Lowery was a movie-mad teenager in Dallas, he was training himself to be a storyteller. Using the clumsy, now blessedly defunct method of VCR-to-VCR editing — record tape from one machine to the other, stop, rewind, repeat — he learned the basics of cinematic rhythm and narrative. “It’s just arduous enough that it forces you to think in advance about what you’re trying to do — about the big picture, and about how one shot is going to lead to the next,” he said. “I think a lot of my editorial tendencies were born out of that process.”

headline: Oprah Winfrey and the Handbag She Couldn’t Have
abstract: Oprah Winfrey said a saleswoman steered her away from a Tom Ford crocodile handbag in a locked case, priced at 35,000 francs, or about $38,000, while she was shopping at a luxury store in Switzerland.
lead_paragraph: When Oprah Winfrey, one of the most famous television personalities and wealthiest women in the United States, walked into a luxury store in Zurich last month, she spied an expensive Tom Ford crocodile handbag in a locked case. The price: 35,000 Swiss francs, or the equivalent of about $38,000.

headline: Ethiopian Air Force Plane Crashes in Somalia
abstract: An Ethiopian air force plane crashed in Mogadishu on Friday, killing four crew members and injuring two others.
lead_paragraph: An Ethiopian air force plane crashed in Mogadishu, Somalia, on Friday, killing four crew members and injuring two others.

lead_paragraph: The borough of Praga has been repairing its reputation, adding everything from bars and restaurants to a boutique hostel.

headline: Hollywood’s Biggest Bang for Its Buck
abstract: A look at which film genres have the biggest return on investment.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this week Forbes had an article on the return on investment on this summer’s films, noting that some have still not collected box office grosses that exceed their original production budgets. “R.I.P.D.,” for example, cost $130 million to make, but has earned shy of $50 million at the global box office, according to Box Office Mojo.

headline: U.N. Criticizes Vietnam’s Resumption of Executions
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Capital Punishment']
abstract: The United Nations called the execution of a convicted murderer in Hanoi after an 18-month pause in the use of the death penalty “a major setback.”
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The United Nations said Friday that human rights in Vietnam had suffered “a major setback” after the execution of a 27-year-old convicted murderer in Hanoi this week, ending an 18-month pause in the country’s use of the death penalty.

headline: Through the Eyes of the Maasai
abstract: A trip to Kenya to spend time among the Maasai people reveals questions of culture and the tension between judgment and an open mind.
lead_paragraph: In the market town of Narok, 90 miles west of Nairobi, I was buying a Kenyan SIM card for my cellphone when I heard someone behind me calling my name. He was wearing a bright red shuka, the traditional shawl of the Maasai people. Colorful beaded jewelry circled his neck, hung from his ears and ringed his wrists. At his waist, a short steel sword was sheathed in red leather. His feet were clad in sandals made from old tires.

headline: Portraits From Kenya

lead_paragraph: People and places encountered during a visit to Maasai country in eastern Africa.

abstract: The Movement for Democratic Change contends that the party of President Robert G. Mugabe rigged the election in order to claim a landslide victory.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — The main opponents in Zimbabwe’s national election filed a legal challenge to the country’s highest court on Friday, citing widespread irregularities and demanding that the election be nullified.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Visualizing Web Activity and Vine’s Resilience
abstract: The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items. Friday’s selections include a project that catalogs the immensity of activity that occurs on the Internet every second, and an argument for why Twitter’s short video service might have lasting power.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items. Here’s what we noticed today:

headline: En Garde! Dueling, Drinking and Laughing
abstract: D’Artagnan and his friends, united as ever, fight for honor and a comically played Louis XIII in Ken Ludwig’s adaptation of “The Three Musketeers,” now at the Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festival.
lead_paragraph: LOUIS XIII IS NOT as famous as his son Louis XIV (the Sun King) or his descendant Louis XVI (guillotine, Marie Antoinette), but he was quite a character in his day (1601-43). And Michael Borrelli makes him the comic star of the Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festival’s fun-filled production of “The Three Musketeers” at Boscobel House and Gardens.

headline: Marilyn King, Last of Singing Sisters’ Group, Dies at 82
abstract: Ms. King was the youngest of the sisters in the family. The King Sisters started as a trio and at one point included six members, all but one of them actual sisters, but for most of their career they were a quartet.
lead_paragraph: Marilyn King, the last surviving member of the singing King Sisters, whose performing career began in the early 1930s and continued into the 1980s, died on Wednesday in Laguna Niguel, Calif. She was 82.

headline: Harry Reid ‘Hopes’ It’s Not Racism
abstract: The Senate Majority Leader wondered today if Republican opposition to the president’s agenda had a racial component.
lead_paragraph: Despite all the politicians who call themselves straight talkers, there is little that makes official Washington queasier than straight talk. And so it was today when Senator Harry Reid, the Majority Leader, dared to suggest that there might just be a racial tinge to the Republicans’ wild-eyed outrage over just about everything President Obama says and their implacable opposition to just about everything he does or wants to do.

lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark demonstrates a grilling equivalent to the one-pot meal using chile-rubbed flank steak and a sweet, spicy tomatillo-pineapple salsa.

headline: August Showoffs: Steak and Salsa
abstract: Don’t let your summer grilling become routine. A little extra effort has a big flavor payoff.
lead_paragraph: I’ll admit that most of the grilled meals I make are about as basic as it gets. Throw some combination of protein and vegetables on the grill, set the table, open  the wine and call it a meal. Sauce is just a drizzle of olive oil and maybe some herbs from the deck. It keeps the kitchen cool, feeds the family and is about as easy as can be.

abstract: Ready to get muddy and wet while you cozy up to nature? Welcome to the swamp walk.
lead_paragraph: The immense cypress tree at mile marker 54.5 of the Tamiami Trail — the highway that cuts across the Everglades in southern Florida — looks like it belongs in a fairy tale. Draped in robes of Spanish moss, the tree stands above its mirror image, reflected in a pond.

lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Manhattan declined on Friday to order the release of Lynne F. Stewart, an outspoken former defense lawyer who is dying from cancer in a federal prison in Texas.

Sometimes, these readers can say some pretty mean things to writers and other people who comment on stories; all, strangely, in defense of a corporation.

headline: The Organization of Art
abstract: “Animal/Vegetable/Mineral: An Artist’s Guide to the World,” which was inspired by the Swedish botanist Carl Linnaeus, is on view at the Florence Griswold Museum.
lead_paragraph: The curator is a relatively new figure in the art world, but the practice of organizing objects into comprehensive categories for study or display is centuries old. Ben Colman, himself a new curator at the Florence Griswold Museum in Old Lyme, Conn. — he joined a year ago — has resurrected an 18th-century model for organizing “Animal/Vegetable/Mineral: An Artist’s Guide to the World,” an exhibition of 105 artworks.

lead_paragraph: FEELING good today? You are not alone. We’re approaching Aug. 11, which is, excluding Christmastime, the happiest day of the year in this country. Or at least the day with the lowest rate of depression, according to our Google searches.

lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Three Chinese workers were found dead under mysterious circumstances in an apartment in central Kabul on Friday, officials said, prompting the Chinese Embassy to urge the Afghan government to investigate to determine whether its citizens were specifically targeted.

headline: Would Daffy Approve? Perhapth
abstract: Dance Heginbotham presented the premiere of “Manhattan Research,” a work set to the music of Raymond Scott, at Lincoln Center Out of Doors.
lead_paragraph: You may have known his music all your life without knowing his name. In the 1930s, Raymond Scott was at the forefront of avant-garde jazz. Later, he was an early inventor of electronic music and instruments. But in the 1940s, his compositions, zany yet fastidious, were adopted as the soundtracks for Warner Brothers cartoons. Much as European modernism became the sound of horror films, Scott’s experimental music became associated with Bugs Bunny and Daffy Duck.

lead_paragraph: One was known as the “nickel empire” — a raucous place of thrill rides, sideshow amusements and cooling sea breezes reachable by a 5-cent subway ride.

abstract: In the exclusive club of four-door, six-figure performance cars, the BMW M6 Gran Coupe is even more rare for allowing buyers to opt for a manual transmission.
lead_paragraph: When you can’t get a manual transmission on a new Ferrari at any price — the 2012 599 GTB was the last car from Maranello to offer a stick shift — you know times are tough for gear rowers everywhere.

abstract: The odds of winning the top prize in Powerball or other big lottery is on a par with finding that needle in a haystack. A tall haystack.
lead_paragraph: When those exceedingly lucky people come forward to claim this week’s Powerball lottery jackpot, which swelled to $448 million on Wednesday, it’s hard not to think: Somebody is winning these things, right? It could be me.

headline: The Day Jerry Garcia Died
abstract: It’s been 18 years since Jerry Garcia died. Hard to believe.
lead_paragraph: We were driving down Knoxville Avenue in Peoria, Ill., on our way to the cleaners to pick up the dress — the wedding was 10 days off. I flipped on the radio, and was greeted with the Grateful Dead’s “Scarlet Begonias,” an unusual but much-welcomed selection from a station known more for playing Lynyrd Skynyrd and Bad Company. “Nice,” I said. “A good omen.” We were young and in love and getting married, and the sky was yellow and the sun was blue!

headline: Track Championships Add Layer of Scrutiny to Russia and Doping
abstract: Three of track’s biggest stars have tested positive for banned substances in recent months and will miss the world championships in Moscow, which begin Saturday.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Thirty-three years after the American high jumper Dwight Stones missed the Moscow Olympics because of a United States boycott, he was standing in front of the stadium in which he would have competed and answering questions about another proposed boycott of a Russian Olympics.

headline: Their Kind of Town, Always
abstract: The Chicago theater scene inspires a deep-rooted loyalty, and this summer, Michael Shannon and David Schwimmer, who went on to TV and film, have returned.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Even when they leave the city that nurtured them to pursue careers in Hollywood or New York, actors, writers and directors who first tasted success in Chicago tend to return here to work. The city’s fertile theater scene seems to inspire a deep-rooted loyalty in artists that never abates.

abstract: Aiming for visitors who pop in more than just once a year, Reeves-Reed Arboretum is offering an art exhibition and concert series, with more to come.

headline: A Summer Buffet Bursting With Vegetables and Fruit
abstract: It’s not until mid-August that most summer produce is available in magnificent abundance. Take advantage.

headline: Wireless Customers Should Thank the Justice Department
abstract: Two years ago the department sued to block the AT&T-T-Mobile merger. Now the latter company is thriving.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, the American wireless industry was well on its way to becoming a cozy oligopoly, split largely between Verizon and AT&T. The latter was trying to gobble up T-Mobile, and Sprint was doing so poorly some analysts speculated it too would become a takeover target. Thankfully, that scary scenario was averted when the Department of Justice sued to block the AT&T-T-Mobile deal. And now its intervention appears to be paying off for consumers in the way many of us had hoped.

headline: The Trip From Bountiful
abstract: At this time of year, if you get to the market early, it’s almost like picking vegetables straight from the field. Celebrate the abundance with a dinner party.
lead_paragraph: We are led to believe that summer produce is available all summer long, but in truth it arrives piecemeal. Yes, there are early ripening fruits and jump-started zucchini, new garlic and the first green beans that are in the market in June. But it’s really not until mid-August, at least in this part of the country, that simply everything appears in magnificent abundance.

headline: In a Theater Mecca, ‘Fringe’ Tends to Mean Choosy
abstract: The New York International Fringe Festival, which opened on Friday, relies on a jury of curators to assemble its lineup, which leads some critics to argue that it’s not exactly a “fringe” event.
lead_paragraph: Elena K. Holy refers to it as “the P.U. era,” for post-“Urinetown,” the time after that musical, a breakout success at the 1999 New York International Fringe Festival, went on to Broadway and became a hit there, too.

headline: Postal Service Is Still Losing Money, but Not Quite as Much
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Delivery Services', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Postal Service and Post Offices']
abstract: The Postal Service on Friday reported a net loss of $740 million in the third quarter, compared with a $1.9 billion loss in the previous quarter.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Postal Service on Friday reported a net loss of $740 million in the third quarter, compared with a $1.9 billion loss in the previous quarter, a better-than-expected performance for the agency, which has been shackled by falling revenues and a Congressional mandate that requires it to annually pay billions of dollars into a health fund for future retirees.

headline: Summer North American Championships
abstract: Several top seeds in the Spingold Knockout Teams in Atlanta were sidelined.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — At the Summer North American Championships here, several top seeds in the Spingold Knockout Teams were sidelined. On Wednesday, the two-time defending champions, Team Monaco (Pierre Zimmermann, Franck Multon, Fulvio Fantoni, Claudio Nunes, Geir Helgemo and Tor Helness) lost by 5 international match points to Mitch Dunitz, Ed Davis, Jill Levin, Jenny Wolpert, Ross Grabel and Howard Weinstein.

headline: Whistle-Blowers and Gangsters
abstract: New books delve into police misconduct, covered up; the success of gangsters in the Prohibition era; and the adventures of a sports enthusiast.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s numbers-driven anti-crime strategy takes a hit in “The NYPD Tapes: A Shocking Story of Cops, Cover-Ups and Courage” (Palgrave Macmillan, $27) by Graham A. Rayman of The Village Voice.

lead_paragraph: An American trade agency banned the import of some products made by Samsung Electronics, scoring another victory for Apple in its continuing patent feud with the South Korean company.

headline: In This Game of Thrones, Ladies Play Hardball
abstract: In the new Starz series “The White Queen,” three women are caught up in the tug of war over the throne in 15th-century England.
lead_paragraph: An endless, multisided battle for a throne in a premodern land, but without much actual battling or perversity. That describes “The White Queen,” a costume-heavy 10-part series that begins on Saturday on Starz. It’s as if someone concluded that the world needed a “Game of Thrones” tasteful enough that women would watch it.

headline: Eerily Normal, the Real Star of ‘Breaking Bad’
abstract: Most of the Albuquerque locales in “Breaking Bad” seem resistant to landmark status. But to fans, they have a certain je ne sais quoi.
lead_paragraph: Any list of great achievements credited to “Breaking Bad,” the darkly comic AMC series about a chemistry teacher turned meth-cooking gangster, must include the almost mythological resonance it has bestowed on its setting, Albuquerque. The show, whose final season of eight episodes begins on Sunday, has been shot in so many locales around this colorfully tatty city that a visit now seems like a jaunt through a studio backlot. And as mundane as those sites may appear, to a fan, they have acquired the patina of the hallowed.

headline: Working-Class Heroes
abstract: A new set of 12 stamps pays tribute to the nation’s industrial laborers, mostly featuring iconic photographs by Lewis Wickes Hine.
lead_paragraph: If “Made in America:  Building a Nation” seems a rather grandiose title for a set of stamps, a glance at the images chosen for the 12 new stamps issued last week by the Postal Service shows it is only fitting.

headline: Alex Kapranos of Franz Ferdinand: Where He’s Been; Where He’s Going
abstract: Alex Kapranos, the lead singer of the Scottish band Franz Ferdinand, slaps stickers on his ever-present suitcase as tokens of the various places his group has traveled.
lead_paragraph: Things often fail us — a foreseeable outcome, given our expectations that new possessions will transform our lives, or at least perform as advertised. But every so often, something special comes along, doing its job so well that it restores our faith in the material world (or at the very least, in capitalism).

headline: The Hamptons on the Hoof
abstract: Drawn by dreams of standing in the winner’s circle, the big money, some of it very new, heads to Saratoga for the races and auctions every August.
lead_paragraph: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — The bidders gathered by the back walking ring in the fading gold light of a summer evening. Around dinnertime last Monday, while throngs from the Saratoga Race Course were walking to their cars toting lawn chairs and coolers, another group gathered to indulge a devotion to the sport of kings.

headline: Irving Penn Photographs to Bolster Smithsonian Collection

lead_paragraph: On Friday the Smithsonian American Art Museum announced that it had received 100 images by the 20th-century photographer Irving Penn as a gift from the Irving Penn Foundation, significantly broadening its collection of his work.

headline: A Remake So Bad, It’s Outright Homage

lead_paragraph: When it came out in 1991, “Point Break” was a hit. And why not? Under the direction of the action expert Kathryn Bigelow, the film featured the rising star Keanu Reeves as the undercover F.B.I. agent Johnny Utah, on the trail of the beach-based gang leader Bodhi, played by a Patrick Swayze hot off “Ghost.”

headline: Time Moves On, but Blondes Still Get in Trouble

lead_paragraph: One of the lovely things about not having children (besides never having to counteract a toddler’s propensity for covering all surfaces with what experts call “sticky”) is that I will probably never need to stare down the barrel of teenage sexuality.

abstract: If teenage sleepovers have really become a question of when, not if, across the country, then things have changed — maybe for the better, but in ways my friends and I, slipping out of windows and parking out by the lake, could never have imagined.

headline: When Douglass Met Lincoln
abstract: What did the Great Abolitionist and the Great Emancipator discuss when they sat down at the White House?

Even worse, Confederate forces that captured black soldiers often either executed them or sold them into slavery.

headline: California: Senator Castigates San Diego Mayor
abstract: Senator Barbara Boxer published an open letter to Mayor Bob Filner of San Diego, asking him to step down amid more allegations of inappropriate conduct.
lead_paragraph: Senator Barbara Boxer published an open letter to Mayor Bob Filner of San Diego on Friday, asking him to step down amid more allegations of inappropriate conduct. This week, female veterans, including two women who were victims of sexual assault while in the military, claimed that Mr. Filner tried to use his position in public office to gain dates or intimate contact. Ms. Boxer, along with California’s other senator, Dianne Feinstein, had already called for Mr. Filner’s resignation, as have many other officials in San Diego and in Washington. In the letter, Ms. Boxer made a direct appeal to the mayor, a fellow Democrat. “The latest revelations regarding your behavior toward women recovering from sexual assault — women who desperately need our help – have shaken me to my core,” Ms. Boxer wrote in the letter posted on her Web site.

headline: Highly Anticipated Return of Rodriguez Is Met With Mixture of Boos and Cheers
abstract: Fans set on jeering Alex Rodriguez and those supporting him seemed evenly split inside Yankee Stadium, as he played his first game at the ballpark since October 2012.
lead_paragraph: In some instances, the boos would come first, boiling up from within the Yankee Stadium stands, eliciting an immediate rejoinder of cheers and applause. Other times, the order was flipped — cheers first, then boos. Whatever the exact sequence or proportion, the visceral responses to Alex Rodriguez on Friday were always loud, the dissonant noises intermingling.

headline: What’s On Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (CUNY) SPIES (1928) “Fritz Lang: Silent to Sound,” a five-film series, continues with this silent thriller, set to musical accompaniment, about a government agent (Willy Fritsch) trying to get the goods on a master criminal (Rudolf Klein-Rogge, above, with Gerda Maurus) with a vast network of spies. “Throughout the bewildering mass of scenes in the German production ‘Spies,’ there is always something to intrigue the eye, despite the fact that it is impossible to make head or tail of the story,” Mordaunt Hall wrote in The New York Times. “Its principal attributes are its excellent photography and its cleverly designed scenic effects. Its episodes are like a nightmare.” Still, Mr. Lang “handles his camera like a wizard.” Afterward Jerry Carlson, the host of “City Cinematheque,” interviews Geoffrey O’Brien, editor in chief of the Library of America.

headline: A Limping Cabrera Leaves Rivera Staggered

lead_paragraph: The world’s greatest hitter stepped to the plate against the world’s greatest closer with two outs in the ninth inning Friday at Yankee Stadium. The Detroit Tigers’ Miguel Cabrera had never gotten a hit off Mariano Rivera in six prior at-bats, postseason included, and on the first pitch, he lofted a pop-up toward the first-base dugout.

headline: Globalization and Keynesianism
abstract: Not such a big deal.
lead_paragraph: Looking at some of the comments on yesterday’s column, I see that a fair number of readers believe that Keynes is no longer valid because any increase in domestic demand will simply “leak” abroad. This is a widespread view, but it’s wrong. Globalization has been impressive, but it has not proceeded far enough to make Keynesian analysis irrelevant.

lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — In a one-run loss, hindsight tends to magnify the opportunities that fizzled.

headline: For Iraqis, Some Relief Amid Violence: It’s Only 108°
abstract: Amid deadly explosions, Iraqis see cooler weather — average highs fell to 109 degrees in July compared with 115 last year — as a small gesture from God.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — For many of the weary residents of this city, who have faced a bloody summer of explosions at soccer fields, cafes and open markets resulting in Iraq’s highest death toll in five years, there are only small things for which to be grateful. Like the weather.

headline: Variety: A Peaceful Acrostic
abstract: A peaceful acrostic from Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — The subject of peace and its broad application across all walks of human life is a complex one, requiring open and frank discussion among greater minds than mine, so you can imagine how surprised I was to see it covered here in the [Not peace. PEAS. –Ed.]

headline: Witnesses Relive Horror of Fort Hood Attack
abstract: Witnesses in the trial of Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan recounted for the first time in public the lengths the shooter went to kill as many soldiers as possible.
lead_paragraph: KILLEEN, Tex. — Sgt. First Class Maria Guerra crouched down on the floor of her office, put her back to the double doors and propped her feet on her desk, using her body to block the doors from swinging open. She told the two women she shared the office with to stay down and not stand up. She could hear screams beyond the doors.

headline: Sisters for Life

lead_paragraph: In October, a woman you haven’t heard of who died in 1955 will be inducted into the National Women’s Hall of Fame in Seneca Falls, N.Y., along with Betty Ford, Nancy Pelosi, Kate Millett and Julie Krone, the great jockey. She is Mary Josephine Rogers, also known as Mollie, also known as Mother Mary Joseph, founder of the Congregation of the Maryknoll Sisters of St. Dominic.

Only the Yankees’ Rodriguez has appealed his ban — his is for 211 games — and continues to play. Other players and many readers of The New York Times reacted to the penalties and their effect on the integrity of the game.

headline: Losing Games, but Not His Calm
abstract: Robin Ventura’s first season as the manager of the White Sox was a success. His second season has been a struggle.
lead_paragraph: When Robin Ventura first joined the Chicago White Sox, in 1989, the team finished last in its division. For the rest of his 16-year playing career, Ventura never finished in last place again, and as a rookie manager for the White Sox last season, he spent more days in first place than any other spot.

headline: Books to Have and to Hold
abstract: The books on our shelves continue to speak to us, unlike ephemeral e-books.
lead_paragraph: I finish reading a book on my iPad — one by Ed McBain, for instance — and I shelve it in the cloud. It vanishes from my “device” and from my consciousness too. It’s very odd.

headline: Marx’s Lesson for the Muslim Brothers
keywords: ['Socialism (Theory and Philosophy)', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Lessons for Egypt from the French Revolution of 1848.
lead_paragraph: KARL MARX wrote that history repeats itself, first as tragedy, then as farce. He had in mind the Revolution of 1848, when a democratic uprising against the French monarchy collapsed into a Bonapartist dictatorship just as the French Revolution had six decades earlier.

headline: When Doctors Discriminate
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Doctors', 'Medicine and Health', 'Psychiatry and Psychiatrists']
abstract: Are medical professionals biased against the mentally ill?
lead_paragraph: THE first time it was an ear, nose and throat doctor. I had an emergency visit for an ear infection, which was causing a level of pain I hadn’t experienced since giving birth. He looked at the list of drugs I was taking for my bipolar disorder and closed my chart.

headline: Thomas Lewis
abstract: The psychiatrist finds beauty in 1,000-plus pages of Mailer, has ears only for Springsteen and thinks opera and Facebook share a common denominator.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Lewis is a psychiatrist who is best known as an author of “A General Theory of Love,” which was published in 2001 and has been reissued twice and translated into eight languages. READING “Harlot’s Ghost” by Norman Mailer is tremendous, more than 1,000 pages, beautifully written and in a setting you’d think no one could ever use as a basis for literature. It tracks the career of a C.I.A. agent from 1955 to 1965. Also, “The Ocean at the End of the Lane” by Neil Gaiman. He’s kind of a macabre fantasist. I’ve only gotten to the part where the person actually gets to the ocean at the end of the lane, so I don’t know what happens after that.

headline: Changing Attitudes on Labor Color Bay Area Transit Dispute
abstract: The labor dispute at the Bay Area Rapid Transit system is taking place against a backdrop of changing attitudes toward organized labor in California.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — With the threat of a railroad shutdown looming, Alice Jorgensen was at the Bay Area Rapid Transit’s MacArthur Station here on a recent morning, waiting for the service she uses 8 to 10 times a week to run errands and go to the library. A strike, she said, would be “a real inconvenience.”

headline: Lawless Sinai Shows Risks Rising in Fractured Egypt
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: In the five weeks since Egypt’s military ousted the Islamist president, Mohamed Morsi, the endemic violence here has spiraled into something like an insurgency.
lead_paragraph: SHEIKH ZWAYD, Egypt — Every night at dusk, the streets of this desert town near the Israeli border empty out, and the chatter and thump of gunfire and explosives begin. Morning reveals the results: another dead soldier, another police checkpoint riddled with bullets, another kidnapping. In mid-July, the body of a local Christian shop owner was found near the town cemetery, his head severed, his torso in chains.

headline: What if Novelists Took Steroids?
abstract: What if there were a drug that could make me a better, faster storyteller? Would I take it?
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Miss. — WELL, Major League Baseball, you’re making me depressed. I can’t even revel in the satisfaction of the Braves having their longest winning streak since 2000 because every time I turn on “SportsCenter,” you’re there with your performance-enhancing drugs, with your suspensions, with A-Rod, Ryan Braun and then some more A-Rod.

headline: Better to Have Won Only Once ...
abstract: Twelve of the last 25 P.G.A. Championship titlists, including Shaun Micheel, the winner at Oak Hill in 2003, have not taken a second major.
lead_paragraph: PITTSFORD, N.Y. — The footsteps of champions are not erased when the tide goes out, which Rich Beem pointed out to Shaun Micheel on a rainy Friday the way one might call attention to a rainbow.

headline: Another Twist in the Saga of Henrietta Lacks
abstract: The restrictive agreement between the government and the family of the unknowing HeLa cells donor was welcome and long overdue.
lead_paragraph: When Henrietta Lacks was stricken with an aggressive cancer more than 60 years ago, doctors who treated her at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore took cells from her tumor without her permission or knowledge, as was common practice at the time. They soon learned that the cells were just as aggressive in a laboratory dish. Instead of dying quickly as previous cell lines had, they kept replicating at an astonishing rate, earning them the label “immortal” and making them immensely valuable to any scientist who wanted a stable base for experiments.

headline: A Clean-Car Boom

abstract: Having more hybrid and electric vehicles on the road will help reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
lead_paragraph: In a welcome development for the planet, the cars on American streets are becoming much more climate-friendly much sooner than many had expected. Consumers are increasingly buying fuel-efficient hybrid and electric vehicles thanks to breakthrough innovations and supportive government policies.

headline: California’s Continuing Prison Crisis

lead_paragraph: California has long been held up as the land of innovation and fresh starts, but on criminal justice and incarceration, the Golden State remains stubbornly behind the curve.

headline: Men of Few Words Are Talk of the Tournament
abstract: Jim Furyk made impressive putts on Nos. 17 and 18 to card a 68 and take a one-stroke lead over Jason Dufner, who settled for a one-over-par 71 at the third round of the P.G.A. Championship.
lead_paragraph: PITTSFORD, N.Y. — At the P.G.A. Championship on Saturday, the weather stopped fluctuating and the leader board began to rock back and forth. The third round at Oak Hill Country Club, played in abundant sunshine, low humidity and gentle breezes, turned into a seesaw ride with Jason Dufner and Jim Furyk taking turns going up and down.

headline: I Flirt and Tweet. Follow Me at #Socialbot.
abstract: Socialbots are being designed to sway elections, to influence the stock market, even to flirt with people and one another.
lead_paragraph: FROM the earliest days of the Internet, robotic programs, or bots, have been trying to pass themselves off as human. Chatbots greet users when they enter an online chat room, for example, or kick them out when they get obnoxious. More insidiously, spambots indiscriminately churn out e-mails advertising miracle stocks and unattended bank accounts in Nigeria. Bimbots deploy photos of gorgeous women to hawk work-from-home job ploys and illegal pharmaceuticals.

headline: After Guantánamo, Another Injustice
abstract:
When a prisoner asked for my
books, I learned his horrifying story.
lead_paragraph: ABOUT two months ago I learned that some of my books had been banned at Guantánamo Bay. Apparently detainees were requesting them, and their lawyers were delivering them to the prison, but they were not being allowed in because of “impermissible content.”

headline: When Leaning In Doesn’t Pay Off
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Women and Girls', 'Workplace Environment', 'Work-Life Balance']
abstract: Does “leaning in” pay off differently for men and women?
lead_paragraph: WHY do women not have as many leadership roles in the workplace as men do? Some have pointed to internal barriers, suggesting that the problem is partly attributable to something about women themselves — they are not “ambitious enough” at work (while pursuing meaningful family goals), or are deeply committed to work but too hesitant to climb leadership ladders in organizations. Others cite structural or institutional barriers, like bias, discrimination or inadequate work-family flexibility. Sheryl Sandberg, in her now famous phrase, would have women “lean in,” to be more assertive at work and not let biases keep them from pushing forward. By leaning in, women would obtain more authority.

headline: How to Read Afghanistan
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism']
abstract: American soldiers need help understanding the veiled meanings behind the stories of their allies and enemies.
lead_paragraph: ON a sunny, crisp November day in 2008, three American civilians joined a platoon of United States soldiers on a foot patrol in Maiwand District, a flat, yellow patch of earth crowned by black-rock mountains in southern Afghanistan. The civilians were part of the Human Terrain System, an ambitious, troubled Army program that sends social scientists into conflict zones to help soldiers understand local culture, politics and economics.

headline: Rays Try to Promote Way Out of Attendance Skid
abstract: Despite the Rays’ success, giveaways like Joe Gnome, which is modeled after Manager Joe Maddon, are the biggest draw for fans.

headline: Edgy Is the Crown of the Hit Kings
abstract: Ichiro Suzuki may soon join the 4,000-hit club. His first name, when translated into English, is “most cheerful boy,” but close watchers know that his demeanor is a little more complicated.
lead_paragraph: If one word can describe the members of baseball’s 4,000-hit club, it is determination. A close second is anger.

headline: High Culture Goes Hands-On
abstract: It’s no longer enough to just look at art — now we must experience it and interact with it.
lead_paragraph: THE quest for an experience has taken over giant portions of our lives. Everywhere, we are assaulted by endless opportunities and activities. We text and get texts wherever we are, even behind the wheel. We constantly post what we’re doing and where we are, letting friends know how active we are. We take part in ever more extreme sports. We work not on our own, but in teams and in social spaces, bullpens for offices, coffee shops for self-employed free agents. And when we go on vacation, we spend our time shopping, eating and seeking adventure. Even in Europe’s old cities of culture, some people might stop in at the Louvre or the Uffizi, but often just to snap a few pictures on their cellphones to prove they were there.

headline: Fatal Mercies
abstract: The assisted-suicide prosecution of a Pennsylvania woman who allegedly gave her father the morphine he requested seems both imprudent and inhumane.
lead_paragraph: FEW of us get anything approaching the degree of control we’d like over our lives. Must we also be denied a reasonable measure over our deaths?

headline: Help Thy Neighbor and Go Straight to Prison
abstract: Some old shotgun shells got a Tennessee man a 15-year sentence. Was it justice served or justice run amok?
lead_paragraph: IF you want to understand all that is wrong with America’s criminal justice system, take a look at the nightmare experienced by Edward Young.

headline: Kansas and Al Qaeda
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Environment']
abstract: How the drought in the Middle West is connected to the turmoil in the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: SALINA, Kan. — I’VE spent the last few months filming a Showtime documentary about how climate and environmental stresses helped trigger the Arab awakening. It’s been a fascinating journey because it forced me to look at the Middle East through the lens of Arab environmentalists instead of politicians. When you do that, you see the problems and solutions very differently. Environmentalists always start by thinking about the health of the “commons” — the shared air, soil, forests and water — that are the basis of all life, which, if not preserved, will undermine the whole society. The notion that securing the interests of any single group — Shiite or Sunni, Christian or Muslim, secular or Islamist — over the health of the commons is nuts to them. It’s as laughable as pictures of gun-toting fighters strutting on the rubble of broken buildings in Aleppo or Benghazi, claiming “victory,” only to discover that they’ve “won” a country with eroding soil, degrading forests, scarce water, shrinking jobs — a deteriorating commons.

headline: Madam President

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — PRESIDENT OBAMA proved himself a great segue artist Friday, as he smoothly glided from his previously unassailable position on the matter of surveillance to his new unassailable position on the matter of surveillance.

headline: How the Post Was Lost

lead_paragraph: MANY American newspapers were doomed to decline from the moment the Internet arrived on personal computers. But The Washington Post, just sold off unexpectedly to Amazon’s Jeff Bezos, was never really one of them.

headline: Hugh Martin, on the Importance of  Commitments
abstract: The C.E.O. of Sensity Systems doesn’t like the phrase “My goal is ... .” It’s far better, he says, to demonstrate total commitment to getting something done.
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Hugh Martin, chief executive of Sensity Systems, an LED lighting company, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Measuring the Sycamore
abstract: We may as well try to count its leaves, or weigh its blue shadow on a summer afternoon.
lead_paragraph: PERHAPS it is a search for order, for scale, for the rules of proportion, some impulse to keep track, but human beings seem hard-wired to take measure of the world around them. It’s why we record everything from rainfall and ice melt to temperature and bird arrival dates. It’s also why I found myself one morning, not long ago, in the meadow of my friends Alex and Blair, in Wallkill, N.Y., along with George Profous, a senior forester with the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation. He was there to measure the old sycamore tree.

headline: Car Bombings Kill Scores Across Iraq

headline: Roy Rubin, Who Led Record-Losing 76ers, Dies at 87
abstract: Mr. Rubin became the coach of the 1972-73 Philadelphia 76ers after a former assistant recommended him. He was fired after a 4-47 start, and the team finished 9-73.
lead_paragraph: The Philadelphia 76ers were pleading for help. In the spring of 1972, they ran advertisements in The Philadelphia Inquirer seeking applicants for their head coaching job. They had been N.B.A. champions in 1967, but poor trades and terrible draft choices had sent them plummeting, and they could not find anybody to fix things.

keywords: ['Executives and Management (Theory)', 'Careers and Professions', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Elderly']

He made sure I understood that I had a responsibility to give back and help make life better for others.

headline: The Pigou Effect (Double-super-special-wonkish)
abstract: Not really there.
lead_paragraph: Via Brad DeLong, Robert Waldmann weighs in on the contributions or lack thereof of Milton Friedman, arguing that much of what he said was already there in Samuelson and Solow 1960. Actually, I’d give him more credit than that; the S-S paper — very unusually for both men, and for Bob Solow in particular — is one of those pieces sometimes described as “rich”, with many points alluded to but not many takeaway lines; to the extent that people did take something away, it was the crude notion of a usable downward-sloping Phillips curve, which turned out to be wrong.

headline: Microsatellites: What Big Eyes They Have
abstract: By expanding Earth imaging, low-cost satellites could help many businesses keep track of their operations. But frequent updating of those images may also raise privacy questions.
lead_paragraph: PEOPLE already worried about the candid cameras on Google Glass and low-flying drones can add a new potential snooper to the list: cameras on inexpensive, low-orbiting microsatellites that will soon be sending back frequent, low-cost snapshots of most of Earth’s populated regions from space.

headline: The Pirate Bay Offers Web Browser to Avoid Censorship
abstract: The Pirate Bay announced that it was releasing PirateBrowser, a free Web browser that will give access to people in countries where the site is currently blocked.
lead_paragraph: The Pirate Bay, one of the largest and most famous piracy sites on the Web for illegally downloading copyrighted material, has been in a constant game of cat and mouse with legal authorities from around the globe for the past decade. Government agencies have often tried to shut the site down, or thwart people from reaching it — because people use it to download movies, music, digital books and other intellectual property — only to see the site retaliate with new doorways for people to access its wares.

headline: A Victim of Mass Incarceration
abstract: Readers comment on my column about mass incarceration, through the case of a man serving 15 years for possessing seven shotgun shells.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column looks at America’s failed policy of mass incarceration, through the case of a man who was recently sentenced to a mandatory minimum of 15 years in federal prison as an ex-felon in possession of seven shotgun shells. To me, it just seemed nutty. If he had burglarized storage containers, then state authorities should have prosecuted him for that. But 15 years in federal prison, at a cost of more than $400,000, for innocent possession of seven shotgun shells with no gun to go with them?

headline: What’s On Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (AMC) LOW WINTER SUN Frank Agnew (Mark Strong), a Detroit homicide detective with a tragic past, is persuaded by a colleague, Joe Geddes (Lennie James, above), to help him kill another cop, who he claims murdered a loved one of Frank’s. But as holes surface in Joe’s story, Frank starts to worry that he has been played in this new series, based on a 2006 British mini-series of the same title. Ruben Santiago-Hudson portrays the precinct commander, who assigns Frank to lead the investigation into the cop’s death. David Costabile is an Internal Affairs detective delving into corruption. And James Ransone is a thug who, with his wife (Sprague Grayden), and a police officer on his payroll, looks to set up a drug and prostitution business. “It’s a deadly serious drama, but some of the early scenes are so overwrought that they are almost laughable,” Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. The series, she said, “doesn’t need to overreach. It has an intriguing story, an aptly sinister setting and an excellent cast.” She added: “It’s inevitable for viewers to yearn for the kind of odyssey that series like ‘The Wire’ and ‘Breaking Bad’ provided. ‘Low Winter Sun’ isn’t that, but it’s an entertaining way station.” The fifth, and final, season premiere of “Breaking Bad” leads in at 9. “Talking Bad,” a companion show hosted by Chris Hardwick that analyzes the series’s last eight episodes, follows at 11.

lead_paragraph: Eydie Gorme, the lively singer with a remarkable range who performed a decades-long act with her husband, Steve Lawrence, that made them the sweethearts of mid-20th-century American pop music, died on Saturday in Las Vegas. She was 84.

headline: The Euro: A Pre-Mortem
abstract: A new survey.
lead_paragraph: Alan Taylor and Kevin O’Rourke have a very good analytical survey of the euro’s problems (pdf), putting it in historical perspective. I’d summarize their piece as saying that the euro suffers from all the problems euroskeptics warned about, plus one they didn’t — the dangers of lacking banking union. There’s a particularly good discussion of the problems of “internal devaluation”, with the demonstration that only in Greece, which is undergoing a full-blown depression, has there been any significant fall in wages:

headline: The Power of Incumbency, Health Care Edition
abstract: Here comes reform — and (don’t tell anyone) it’s going to be popular.
lead_paragraph: President Obama is finally making a strong case for his own health reform, mocking Republicans for their obsession with denying insurance to 30 million Americans. It’s about time; and many of us still feel that he did a remarkably bad job of explaining the reform in the past.

headline: Disruptions: As New Targets for Hackers, Your Car and Your House
abstract: Hackers and security researchers are exploring vulnerabilities to break through the high-tech security of homes or cause car accidents.
lead_paragraph: Imagine driving on the freeway at 60 miles per hour and your car suddenly screeches to a halt, causing a pileup that injures dozens of people. Now imagine you had absolutely nothing to do with the accident because your car was taken over by hackers.

headline: Autism’s Unexpected Link to Cancer Genes
abstract: As surprised researchers have discovered, some people with autism have mutated cancer or tumor genes that apparently caused their brain disorder.
lead_paragraph: Researchers studying two seemingly unrelated conditions — autism and cancer — have unexpectedly converged on a surprising discovery. Some people with autism have mutated cancer or tumor genes that apparently caused their brain disorder.

headline: New Israeli Housing Bids Raise Tensions Before Peace Talks
abstract: A plan to build houses in contested East Jerusalem and West Bank settlements intensifies the already charged atmosphere, three days before the resumption of Israeli-Palestinian peace talks.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel published bids on Sunday for the construction of more than 1,000 housing units in contested East Jerusalem and several large West Bank settlements. Hours later, the government announced the names of 26 Palestinian prisoners to be released this week as part of a deal for the resumption of Israeli-Palestinian peace talks here on Wednesday.

headline: ‘Elysium’ Tops Weekend Box Office
abstract: Ticket sales for the R-rated science fiction tale, about haves and have-nots, fell well short of expectations.
lead_paragraph: Neill Blomkamp’s “Elysium” was No. 1 at North American theaters, but ticket sales fell well short of expectations. An R-rated science-fiction tale about haves and have-nots, “Elysium” (Sony Pictures Entertainment) took in an estimated $30.5 million over the weekend. That’s a solid total, but the studio, which has had a rough summer at the box office, had hoped that the film would deliver opening-weekend ticket sales of $35 million to $40 million.

headline: Friedman and the Austrians
abstract: Atrophied and rigid, he said.
lead_paragraph: Still thinking about the Bloomberg Businessweek interview with Rand Paul, in which he nominated Milton Friedman’s corpse for Fed chairman. Before learning that Friedman was dead, Paul did concede that he wasn’t an Austrian. But I’ll bet he had no idea about the extent to which Friedman really, really wasn’t an Austrian.

lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — For four hours on Friday and two hours on Saturday, Walt Disney Studios gave fans gathered at a convention here an extensive look into its movie pipeline. And while the crowd was a friendly one, Disney left nothing to chance.

abstract: Although Usain Bolt had to strain more than usual for the victory, he reclaimed the world 100-meter title he lost in 2011.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — It will not rank as the most irresistible of Usain Bolt’s many major victories in the 100 meters. It presumably will not be the gold medal story he will tell first when he is old and gray and long retired in Jamaica.

headline: Reconstructing a Lost Time of Love and Literary Ambitions
abstract: In the novel “Necessary Errors” a Harvard graduate comes to post-Communist Prague with writerly ambitions but finds himself not writing at all.
lead_paragraph: “Oh, I’ve been to Prague,” the lead in Noah Baumbach’s 1995 film, “Kicking and Screaming,” says to his girlfriend, shortly bound for that city. “Well, I haven’t ‘been to Prague’ been to Prague,” he clarifies, “but I know that thing, that ‘stop shaving your armpits, read “The Unbearable Lightness of Being,” date a sculptor, now-I-know-how-bad-American-coffee-is’ thing.” His attempted put-down hints at how quickly the post-college stint in post-Communist Prague became, for a certain set of sophisticated liberal-arts types, a cliché.

headline: A Duo Whose Personas Have Personas
abstract: Jinkx Monsoon’s raucous drag show, “The Vaudevillians,” mixes drag, music and time travel.
lead_paragraph: It hardly seems fair, really. The simple conceit of “The Vaudevillians,” Jinkx Monsoon’s raucous drag show at the Laurie Beechman Theater, gives Ms. Monsoon and her sidekick, Major Scales, almost a century’s worth of songbook to draw from. That makes it criminally easy for them to hit the audience’s sweet spot again and again. Straight or gay, everyone leaves this show with sides aching from laughter.

headline: Hushed Tones That Grab Attention
abstract: “The whisper opera” is performed in hushed tones by a soprano and four musicians at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: The contemplative allure of “the whisper opera,” the new piece of lyric theater by the composer David Lang that had its New York premiere on Saturday night at Lincoln Center’s Clark Studio Theater, comes from its pervasive softness, stillness and intimacy. For just over an hour the soprano Tony Arnold, the closest this experimental work has to an actual character, walks atop a small platform stage amid white lace curtains, sometimes humming chants but mostly whispering cryptic sentence fragments and phrases. She was accompanied by four instrumentalists playing cello, percussion, various flutes and clarinets, all members of the International Contemporary Ensemble, known as ICE. And accompanied is the right word, since the musicians actually follow Ms. Arnold, stationing themselves in different corners of the platform, also whispering incomplete sentences and unanswered questions.

headline: I Give

headline: Time Magazine Branches Out Into Documentary Films
abstract: A new unit called Red Border Films will produce one 10-minute film a month, with longer projects planned twice a year.

Do they produce short, televisionlike broadcasts? Clips from the latest news events? Or do they try something more ambitious?
