headline: The A B C’s of Ballet, Getting Considerations and Updates
abstract: Ballet v6.0, featuring six small companies from around the nation, has programs with the Dominic Walsh and Company C troupes.
lead_paragraph: When in modern ballet should men and women dance alike, and when differently? When is it appropriate for women to dance on point? How can the pulled-up, stretched-out style of classical ballet be married to the body language of ordinary people and the popular dance styles of our age? How can stories of psychological complexity be told in ballet? What are the practical and expressive implications of same-sex partnering? How can ballet work when accompanied by silence, unusual soundscapes, pop and rock music, or classical music not written for dancing?

headline: New Challenge for Filmmakers: Adding Dimension to 3-D Movies

lead_paragraph: BAMAKO, Mali — In rain and mud, voters in Mali trickled into darkened polling stations on Sunday, hoping a vote for president will pull their country out of one of West Africa’s deepest government collapses since the colonial era.

abstract: American Express is set to announce a new sponsorship program and prepaid debit card that take aim at the millions of people who play the online video game League of Legends.
lead_paragraph: GETTING the attention of the so-called millennial generation is no easy feat for many advertisers. Try as they might to break through on television, social media and other digital platforms, their sales pitches are often ignored in favor of Netflix, Snapchat, Twitter and video games.

headline: Sanchez? Smith? Jets Don’t Pick Starter for Next Game
abstract: Although it seemed likely that the rookie quarterback Geno Smith would start next Saturday’s preseason game against Jacksonville, Jets Coach Rex Ryan said a decision had not yet been made.

headline: Technology Industry Extends a Hand to Struggling Print Media
abstract: Whether from a sense of obligation, responsibility or guilt, the technology elite has taken up the cause of helping print journalism adapt to change.
lead_paragraph: From classifieds to display ads to subscriptions, the digital age has broken the financial pillars of print journalism, leaving the industry struggling to stand on its own.

headline: Magazine Writing on the Web, for Film
abstract: Two top magazine writers, both of whom have optioned their nonfiction articles for movies, are starting a platform to enable other writers to do so as well.
lead_paragraph: To many writers, to almost anyone for that matter, Joshuah Bearman and Joshua Davis are living the dream. As accomplished practitioners of big, nonfiction magazine writing, they regularly publish articles in Wired, The New Yorker, Rolling Stone and many other A-list titles. Perhaps more important, they have, between them, optioned 18 of their articles for films, with two more in negotiation.

headline: To Stay Afloat, Bookstores Turn to Web Donors
abstract: For independent bookstores, crowdfunding has become the latest tactic for survival in a market that is dominated by Amazon and Barnes & Noble.
lead_paragraph: For years, independent bookstores have taken creative steps to fight off challenges from Amazon and the superstores by building in-house espresso bars, hosting members-only lunches with authors and selling birthday cards, toys and trinkets.

headline: A Dwindling Band Proudly Dons Rodriguez Jerseys

lead_paragraph: It was early enough Sunday that Michael McCann could have been one of the first fans to enter Yankee Stadium, take a seat and let his white jersey glisten in the sun. After 10 months of inactivity, it was dazzlingly clean and bright.

lead_paragraph: A case might be made that Bruce Goldstein, who has directed repertory programming at the Film Forum, now on Houston Street, for more than a quarter of a century, was destined to practice his craft the moment he first drew breath. He was born in Amityville, N.Y.

headline: Republicans and Democrats Both Miscalculated
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Taxation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy', 'Constitutional Amendments']
abstract: If we are to restore economic sobriety and intergenerational fairness to the budget, a more binding solution — a Constitutional amendment — may be needed.
lead_paragraph: TWO years ago, Adm. Mike Mullen, at the time the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said that debt was the “single biggest threat to our national security” — not some rogue nation, or terrorist group, but debt. What makes the threat of exploding debt especially dangerous is that it’s not like a faucet that can be easily turned down. Federal, state and city governments in the United States have lost their fiscal grip, and the saga of Detroit’s bankruptcy is just one example.

headline: Bill Thompson, the Anti-Weiner
abstract: In the mayor’s race, Bill Thompson makes the case for safe-and-boring.
lead_paragraph: ON issue after issue in the race to be the next mayor of New York, Bill Thompson is the Goldilocks candidate — not too hot, not too cold. And, as a result, not too exciting. This is especially apparent when, as at a forum I attended last week, he is seated next to Anthony Weiner, who plays the hyperbolic huckster with such enthusiasm that he seems to be auditioning for a summer-stock production of “Elmer Gantry.” Thompson is, in his demeanor and his approach to public service, the anti-Weiner — even-keeled, not self-aggrandizing, careful, decent. His favorite adjective seems to be “balanced.” His oratory rarely rises above a simmer. (“No one will ever accuse him of being inflammatory,” Chris Smith dryly observed in New York magazine.) It is easy to forget that in 2009 he ran a close challenge to the seemingly invincible Michael Bloomberg despite being outspent 14 to 1.

headline: Celebrity Weeklies Are Reveling in a Royal Baby, and Sales

headline: The Re-education of My Perineum
abstract: In France, one is entitled to 10 sessions of perineal re-education after giving birth. But I was American. My perineum was never educated in the first place.
lead_paragraph: Aude politely suggested that I insert the sonde, a tampon-like metal-and-plastic contraption with a long wire she would hook up to the computer. When I flinched, she reiterated the importance of perineal re-education. She delivered this practiced discourse with an air of utter professionalism, flicking through computer exercises with a mouse, her back pin straight. Thankfully. Because had she so much as cracked a smile, I wouldn’t have survived the ensuing psychic trauma.

headline: Born Again in Mississippi
abstract: Union General Lorenzo Thomas enjoyed asking those who opposed the enlistment of African Americans to step out of their ranks on the parade ground, then having them hauled off to the stockade.
lead_paragraph: Adjutant Gen. Lorenzo Thomas had assumed that General Ulysses S. Grant had lost his way. For two days, his small party of officers and orderlies had ridden around and across the same pair of bayous, making use of bridges and fords and sometimes swimming their horses. Caught in a terrific storm, they had spent a night on the ground — notwithstanding the distinguished guests in the company, General Thomas himself, on special assignment from Washington, and Congressman Elihu Washburne, Grant’s friend and patron from his home state of Illinois. Washburne later recalled with admiration how the commander traveled six days in May of ’63 with nothing more than a toothbrush, an example to his troops of military grit and mobility [1] .

lead_paragraph: It’s a classic moment in sports history. With less than 20 seconds left in Game 6 of the 1998 N.B.A. finals and the Chicago Bulls down by one, Michael Jordan goes one-on-one with Bryon Russell of the Utah Jazz. He pushes off (clearly!), Russell stumbles and the ball hits nothing but net. Game over. Bulls win.

headline: Assessing the Impact of Business Incubators

A reader in Austin questioned the effectiveness of incubators at creating successful companies in the long term. He compiled a list of the top 150 publicly traded software companies by top-line sales — his measure of success — and found that not one on his list had come out of an incubator.

headline: On View | The Hilarious, Poignant Humanity of eBay Auction Listings
abstract: “Sentimental Value,” an exhibition of garments purchased on eBay alongside stories the sellers shared in their listings, reveals the profound meaning we attach to our clothes.

It gathers some 40 of the more than 60 garments she has purchased on eBay and pairs them with revealing tales the sellers shared when they listed them.

When I was with another brand, I used to oversee 23 countries, and was traveling to five or six countries a month. One time I had to go to six countries in three days. Fortunately, I don’t have to do those kinds of whirlwind trips anymore, but I’m still flying all the time.

headline: Listen Up | Teenage Folk-Singing Sisters Hit the Big Time
abstract: On the strength of a YouTube video, the Indiana siblings who go by Lily and Madeleine have become an overnight sensation, with a debut album out this fall. The first single has its exclusive premiere here.
lead_paragraph: The Indianapolis-based sister folk duo Lily and Madeleine recorded their debut EP, “Weight of the Globe” (which came out in January), entirely on the weekends. That’s because on weekdays, they were too busy with high-school homework. “It’s weird that we’re, like, business partners now,” said Madeleine Jurkiewicz, 18, the older sister. Not long ago, she and 16-year-old Lily were anonymous bedroom singers; now they’re signed to Sufjan Stevens’ Asthmatic Kitty Records, with a namesake debut album on the way (on Oct. 29). “Devil We Know,” which makes its world premiere here, is the centerpiece of the record, an appealing back-country portrait comprised of a slow-rolling piano melody, deftly plucked acoustic guitar and the teens’ tender, swirling voices.

I’m using a vegetarian broth I make with dried mushrooms and kelp, adapted from a recipe in Deborah Madison’s “Vegetarian Cooking for Everybody.” You could also use chicken stock. The dish can include chicken or meat, or it can be vegetarian, as this version is, with tofu standing in for chicken. It can also be vegan if you omit the boiled eggs. headline: This Town and Its Newspapers
abstract: More on Politico’s rise and the Washington Post’s decline.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column argued that the proper context for understanding how the Washington Post ended up passing from the Graham family to Jeff Bezos isn’t just the disruptive effects of the online revolution writ large. It’s also the more specific revolution wrought by the ex-Postie founders of Politico, who seized a market and an audience — obsessive political coverage for the political class — that had long belonged naturally to the Post, and that the Grahams’ newspaper clearly needed, and still needs, to compete successfully in the more nationalized and competitive media marketplace that the internet ushered in.

headline: On the Verge | Yang Li’s Deliberately Imperfect Style
abstract: The 25-year-old London-based designer has drawn notice for a gothic streetwear style that is precisely executed, but disrupted with spontaneous flourishes.
lead_paragraph: Last spring, the 25-year-old London-based designer Yang Li debuted his first runway collection, a line of reimagined street-wear staples with a gothic influence. For someone so young, Li has accomplished quite a lot: after dropping out of Central Saint Martins, he interned for Raf Simons, and by the tender age of 23 had already caught the eye of Michèle Montagne, the in-demand French publicist and stylist who helped shape the careers of Ann Demeulemeester and Haider Ackermann. Li’s clothes are made in Italy, and finished with absolute precision — except when they aren’t. He loves an element of spontaneity, like slashing the two front pockets of a slim-cut classic bouclé jacket. “Art is not all clean lines, but has a human touch,” he said. “Same with fashion.”

headline: Kennedy, and What Might Have Been
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In a portrait of John F. Kennedy, Thurston Clarke argues that during Kennedy’s last few months, he finally began to realize his potential as a man and a president, with morality and emotion tempering ambition.
lead_paragraph: As the 50th anniversary this November of the assassination of John F. Kennedy looms on the horizon, the debates over his legacy and presidency continue: a procession of “what ifs” and “might have beens,” accompanied by contradictory arguments, and informed and not-so-informed speculation. Would Kennedy have avoided Lyndon B. Johnson’s tragic escalation of the war in Vietnam? Would he have found a way to propel his stalled tax-cut bill and civil rights legislation through Congress and start a war on poverty, or was Johnson able to achieve these historic goals only through a combination of his bare-knuckled, tactical knowledge of Congress; his personal relationships on Capitol Hill; and his ability to use the momentum of sentiment generated by Kennedy’s death?

abstract: A human rights envoy on Monday visited Rakhine days after the police opened fire on protesters seeking access to the body of a Rohingya Muslim fisherman.
lead_paragraph: A United Nations human rights envoy on Monday visited the state of Rakhine just days after the police opened fire on protesters seeking access to the body of a Rohingya Muslim fisherman. One person was killed and 10 others were wounded in the confrontation on Friday, said a government spokesman, Win Myaing. Over the past year more than 250 people have been killed in religious violence, most of them minority Muslims, and 140,000 have been forced to flee their homes. A United Nations special rapporteur on human rights, Tomás Ojea Quintana, is on an 11-day visit, including a stop in Rakhine, scene of some of the worst bloodshed. After the battered body of a fisherman washed ashore on Friday in Sittwe, rumors spread among Rohingya Muslims that he had been killed by the police. Mr. Win Myaing said the police fired into the air when 500 Rohingyas who were demanding access to the body attacked a police checkpoint. After more protesters gathered, the officers shot into the crowd, wounding at least 10, he said. One of the men died of his wounds, he said. (AP)

headline: Is It Nuts to Give to the Poor Without Strings Attached?
abstract: Or is it just good economics?

He has spent years working on and off as a day laborer, moving stones on construction sites, and commuting long distances over rough dirt roads. When he could find work, he made about $2 a day. When he couldn’t, his two sons sometimes went hungry. Then one morning last year, Omondi woke up to an unusual text message. “When I saw the message, I jumped up,” he recalled. “My wife said, ‘Bernard, what is it?’ ” He told her he had just been given $500 with no strings attached. “ It’s here! ” he said.

Mr. Modi has been remodeling himself as a pro-business, pro-development leader who can bring about economic growth and make difficult decisions. headline: The Civil War and Hawaii
abstract: Despite the 5,000 miles separating Gettysburg and Honolulu, the island kingdom played a surprising role in the conflict.
lead_paragraph: Almost 5,000 miles and half an ocean away from the killing fields of Gettysburg, Chickamauga, or Spotsylvania, Hawaii and Hawaiians might be assumed to have not played a role in the Civil War. Yet regardless of proud protestations of neutrality by the Hawaiian monarchy – the islands were not American territory at the time – many of the islands’ residents participated in the conflict, on both sides. And for good reason: though they lived on one of the most geographically isolated island chains in the world, Hawaiians kept abreast of international events, knowing that the outcome of the war could greatly affect Hawaii as well.

headline: Wines to Accompany Grilled Flank Steak
abstract: A fine piece of steak is an open invitation to a world of red wines to show their stuff.
lead_paragraph: A fine piece of grilled flank steak is an open invitation to a world of red wines to show their stuff. But what happens when you add chile’s heat, to say nothing of nomadic travelers in the wine world like tomatillo and pineapple? Not to worry. The char of the meat will still be the dominant flavor, though amplified and augmented by the additions. I recommend a dry Loire red, like one of the less-structured Chinons, Bourgueils or Saumur-Champignys. Unless they are too tannic, they seem to have an affinity for chiles. What’s more, their fruit, spice and acidity will take naturally to the fruitiness of the tomatillo, pineapple and, indeed, the chile. Other options: cru Beaujolais and West Coast gamays, if you can find them; lighter-bodied Ribeira Sacra and Bierzos, made from the mencía grape; and Austrian blaufränkisches and zweigelts.

lead_paragraph: All but forgotten today, in her time Toto Koopman shocked the world. As the first famous biracial model (she was half-Javanese, half-Dutch), Koopman posed for Chanel in Paris and appeared on the cover of French Vogue in the 1930s. She was fluent in six languages, which served her well when she later became a spy for the Italian resistance during World War II — until she was thrown in a Nazi concentration camp. In his new biography, “The Many Lives of Miss K.,” Jean-Noël Liaut likens the secretive Koopman to “a squid hiding behind its cloud of ink.” Though she was never monogamous — she took lovers into her 70s, including the actress Tallulah Bankhead, Winston Churchill‘s son Randolph and the press baron Lord Beaverbrook — she devoted the second half of her life to Erica Brausen, the visionary art dealer, who, with Koopman’s help, launched Francis Bacon’s career from her Hanover Gallery in London. The couple never concealed their relationship, even though homosexuality was a criminal offense in Britain at the time. “Being around them,” a friend recalled, “I really came to understand the meaning of freedom.”

headline: As She Tends, a Wife Starts to Find Herself
abstract: “The Patience Stone” is an Afghan tale about a young mother who takes care of her wounded, much older husband.
lead_paragraph: Life and death circle each other restlessly and then furiously in the Afghan-set movie “The Patience Stone.” Life takes the form of an unnamed beautiful young woman (the fine Iranian actress Golshifteh Farahani) who, when the story opens, is caring for her wounded, much older husband, also unnamed (Hamidrez Javdan), an immobilized Mujahedeen fighter with a bullet in his neck and the slender tube of a medical drip bag snaked into his mouth. They’re simply two people inside an austere room. Yet, as bombs shake the walls and she places a bloodied compress on his head, they are quickly transformed into a time-tested, outwardly reassuring vision of a woman heroically ministering to a wounded, possibly dying man.

headline: Tasting Triumph in Serving of a Heart

lead_paragraph: LENOX, Mass. — Within minutes of the premiere of George Benjamin’s “Written on Skin,” at the Aix-en-Provence Festival last summer, opera houses around the world jostled for production rights to this darkly erotic opera about a love triangle in medieval Provence, set to a searing text by Martin Crimp. In the past year, it has been staged in London, Amsterdam, Toulouse, Munich and Vienna, each time bringing audiences to their feet and leaving critics to pull out superlatives they hadn’t thought they’d ever use in the context of new opera.

headline: Stories Told With a Twirl Here and a Leap There
abstract: The Downtown Dance Festival opened on Sunday with several pieces performed in Battery Park City.
lead_paragraph: Battery Park, with its views across the harbor and the Hudson River, should be one of New York’s glories. Currently, however, it’s a mess and a maze, and, with its palings and barriers, it looks like a no man’s land. Trying to find the opening performance of the Downtown Dance Festival on Sunday proved so circuitous that I missed the opening troupe, Chapter Two. Once there, however, I sat contented for the remaining two and a half hours.

lead_paragraph: Lyndon Baines Johnson has long been recognized as a figure of Shakespearean dimensions, perhaps first in Barbara Garson’s 1967 blistering satire, “MacBird!” — in which Johnson was Macbeth and behind the murder of his leader, John Ken O’Dunc.

headline: Food Matters | Bodega Coffee Flavor, Brewed Right in Your Kitchen
abstract: The New York coffee company Vassilaros and Sons, whose coffee has been a staple in corner stores for nearly a century, is now selling its beans direct to consumers.
lead_paragraph: “I’ve been a salesman all my life,” said John Vassilaros, a third-generation coffee maker whose family company, Vassilaros and Sons, has been peddling its home-roasted, hand-blended beans around New York, New Jersey and Connecticut for nearly a century. “The trick to selling is don’t talk too much,” he added. “Just let them taste it.” He wouldn’t dream of leaving a pound of coffee behind for prospective clients to try later. Instead, he gets behind the counter to brew up Vassilaros and Sons’ trademark brew for side-by-side taste tests. He claims he usually wins. The proof is in the ubiquity of his familiar-tasting medium roast, a complex blend of South American beans prepared every Tuesday in Queens, which can be found in hundreds of New York City delis, bodegas and coffee shops, not to mention restaurants like the Boathouse Restaurant in Central Park.

headline: Another Banksy Mural to Go From Wall to Auction
abstract: When Banksy, the pseudonymous British street artist, paints a surface, that surface is increasingly likely to be dismantled and sold.
lead_paragraph: Under cover of night, in 2008, Banksy, the pseudonymous British artist, stenciled a mural on a wall of a gas station in Los Angeles: the silhouette of a girl holding a basket of flowers and peering up at a security camera. About nine months ago, that 5,000-pound, 9-by-8-foot chunk of brick wall was removed, and, in the latest of a string of controversial sales of Banksy street work, will soon be on the block. In December, Julien’s Auctions in Beverly Hills, Calif., will offer “Flower Girl,” the first Banksy street art to be sold in the United States, the auctioneers said.

headline: Art’s Future Meets Its Past

lead_paragraph: VENICE — What’s new in contemporary art? Old. We’re in an age of remake culture, an epidemic of re-enactment fever. Young painters are working in styles that were hot half a century ago. Yesteryear’s performance art is being re-performed. Exhibitions that have been done and done — on Matisse, Picasso, European abstraction — are being done again.

headline: Potent Memories From a Divided India
abstract: A project called the 1947 Partition Archive is recording the recollections of people who lived through the violent division of British India into independent India and Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — Growing up, Guneeta Singh Bhalla heard a terrifying story from her grandmother. In August 1947, as British India was being partitioned into independent India and Pakistan, her grandmother fled Lahore, in what was soon to become Pakistan, for Amritsar, in what was soon to become India. All around her was carnage. Clutching her three young children, she looked out the train window to see bodies strewed along the tracks. The memory haunted her until she died.

Friedman used to hang out at Tosca when he worked for the concert promoter Bill Graham, mixing with local power players like former Mayor Willie Brown and Gov. Jerry Brown. In fact, generations of cultural figures ranging from Hunter S. Thompson to Sam Shepard to Johnny Depp have gathered within Tosca’s muraled walls to swap stories and make deals, often over the “house cappuccino” — a variation on Irish coffee made with cocoa and brandy that was invented there during Prohibition. “There was always opera on the jukebox, and I remember the drinks being better than they actually were,” Friedman said. “From Sean’s text on, it was, ‘Let’s save Tosca from becoming a Subway shop or a whiskey bar.”

headline: In Defense of Reza Aslan
abstract: The latest historical Jesus bestseller isn’t very good, but it also could have been worse.
lead_paragraph: Since I wrote about the latest “real Jesus” bestseller two weeks ago, its author, Reza Aslan, has taken a fairly comprehensive beating in a variety of outlets. The Washington Post ran a skeptical piece about Aslan’s tendency to overemphasize his academic credentials even when he isn’t being cross-examined on Fox News, and his interpretation of Jesus’s life has been treated dismissively by a wide range of informed reviewers, from The Nation to The Jewish Review of Books. The consensus in these pieces is that Aslan’s book makes a hash of more careful scholarship on its way to preordained conclusions, and that his portrait of Jesus as a political revolutionary is just another predictable example of the way that the Nazarene’s contemporary biographers almost aways produce (as The Nation’s reviewer puts it) “theological Rorschach tests that tell us far more about those who create them than about the elusive historical Jesus.”

abstract: When a Web marketing and communications company discovered its hardware system was out-of-date, it set out on the giant — and ultimately successful — task of remaking the company.
lead_paragraph: It may be the most terrifying moment a business owner can face: the realization that what you have been doing successfully, possibly for years, no longer works. For Clint Smith, co-founder and chief executive of Emma, a Web-based marketing and communications company, that moment came three years ago when his team attended the annual South by Southwest Music and Media conference in Austin, Tex.

headline: In I.O.C., New Obstacles for an Expert at Clearing Them
abstract: Sergei Bubka, the onetime Soviet pole-vaulting champion, is trying to make the transition from world-class athlete to head of the Olympic movement.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — It is strange to see Sergei Bubka — the man who broke 35 world records — as an underdog.

lead_paragraph: Five years ago, Emily Rose had a summer internship at a television news organization. She lived in the Barnard College dorms.

lead_paragraph: For travelers eager to act on the promise of heaping piles of vegetables and colorful spices found in Moroccan markets, the Marrkesh boutique hotel El Fenn newly offers a hands-on opportunity to shop and cook with the chef in its restaurant kitchen.

headline: Gen. David C. Jones, Former Chairman of Joint Chiefs, Dies at 92
abstract: As chairman of the Joint Chiefs under Presidents Carter and Reagan, General Jones set in motion a sweeping reorganization of the nation’s military command.
lead_paragraph: Gen. David C. Jones, who as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff in the Carter and Reagan administrations helped set in motion a sweeping reorganization of the nation’s military command, died on Saturday in Potomac Falls, Va. He was 92.

headline: A Night at the Megachurch
abstract: A megachurch in Manhattan? Who knew such a thing existed?
lead_paragraph: “You’re not at a nightclub, you’re at church,” the minister said, welcoming a thousand or so churchgoers to Irving Plaza’s storied ballroom one Sunday night in April. I don’t know if the place was technically sold out — can a church sell out? — but the line to get in ran the length of Irving Place and then snaked halfway down 16th Street, and the place was packed. The crowd was young, beautiful and, it seemed, unattached. I saw almost no one over 40, and none had brought children.

lead_paragraph: This is a crumby situation. This is our son.

headline: Vive la Difference
abstract: The protagonists of “Digby Differs” and “Maude the Not-So-Noticeable Shrimpton” feel at odds with their environments.
lead_paragraph: It seems right that books about difference should be unusual themselves. That’s certainly true of “Digby Differs” and “Maude the Not-So-Noticeable Shrimpton,” both of which take as subjects protagonists who feel at odds with their environments. These books are out of the ordinary in appearance and tone, too, and suited, perhaps, not to the typical child (if such a person exists) but rather to older readers who sympathize with that feeling of disconnection.

headline: When It Comes to New York Wines, the Governor Likes Them All
keywords: ['Wines', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'New York Wine and Food Classic']
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo takes his political drawing power to the vineyards of the Finger Lakes region.
lead_paragraph: As the leader of a diverse dining-and-drinking state, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo doesn’t play favorites with the state’s wide variety of wines, so much so that when he is asked what his favorite one is, he mentions practically all of them. “It’s red, and white,” the governor said on Wednesday of his tastes. “And did I say rose?”

headline: Could Outmoded Phone Booths Become E.V. Charging Stations?
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)']
abstract: New York City is full of dormant, albeit still electrified phone booths. Some say the unused infrastructure could be repurposed for electric vehicle charging.
lead_paragraph: Consider New York’s public pay telephones. They may be outdated in the digital age, but they have telephone wiring and are often supplied with electricity. More important, they already occupy precious city real estate — and already have the permits necessary to stay there. Is it possible to imagine some of them seamlessly replaced with electric vehicle charging stations, with vital dedicated parking spaces?

headline: Wines of The Times: Albariños From Spain
abstract: Albariños are the bright and thirst-quenching signature white wines of the Rías Baixas region of Galicia, in northwestern Spain.
lead_paragraph: Albariños are the bright and thirst-quenching signature white wines of the Rías Baixas region of Galicia, in northwestern Spain.

headline: U.S. Puts a Helpful Face on Its Fraud Case
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: The Justice Department has learned an important lesson about putting on cases involving complex Wall Street financial machinations and has lined up a witness who can help explain its case to a jury.
lead_paragraph: The so-called London Whale, whose trading in credit default swaps ended up costing JPMorgan Chase more than $6 billion in losses, appears to have a new role as the linchpin of the government’s criminal case against two employees of the bank. His cooperation shows that the Justice Department has learned an important lesson about putting on cases involving complex Wall Street financial machinations that are said to have involved fraud.

headline: A Good Race Spoiled
abstract: The PGA Tour bans caddie races; Jason Dufner takes a victory lap; and the Miami Marlins offer $1 tickets to “die-hard” fans.
lead_paragraph: For golf fans, it already feels like autumn. No matter how much the PGA Tour wants you revved up for its “playoffs,” well, the final major of the year is over and the N.F.L. mandates that now we all become football fans and forget those lovely walks along golf fairways. So, Tuesday gave us one last chance to savor Jason Dufner with the sheer absurdity of his making the New York media rounds after his P.G.A. Championship victory, and the PGA Tour comes along and reminds us that fun must be eradicated from the game at all costs.

lead_paragraph: Spiked, studded and overscaled, these new takes on an old classic are worthy of a Dutch master.

lead_paragraph: As he explains in a small-business guide we have just published, Clint Smith, co-founder and chief executive of Emma, a Web-based marketing and communications firm, had a moment of realization three years ago when his team attended the annual South by Southwest Music and Media conference in Austin, Tex. Suddenly, Mr. Smith knew that Emma had to re-think its platform and its products.

headline: Lost In Cyberspace
abstract: We apologize for the temporary lack of diatribes.
lead_paragraph: In case you’ve been wondering, Chinese Viagra salesmen gremlins have apparently attacked the New York Times. Blog access went down first, so my attempts to post this morning failed; the regular paper is now back up, but so far we can’t do images, which makes posts that included charts not worth doing for the moment.

headline: The Civil Wars Top the Charts
abstract: The top ranking comes despite the fact that the members of the folk-rock duo may never tour again.
lead_paragraph: The Civil Wars may never tour again, given that the members of the folk-rock duo have been estranged for months, but their second studio album still topped the Billboard 200 chart this week, selling 116,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan.

headline: Turning to Your Phone for a Better Night’s Sleep
abstract: Apps can turn your mobile device into a white-noise machine, a personal bedtime storyteller and even a diagnostic tool to analyze your sleep patterns.
lead_paragraph: I’m terrible at sleeping. Over the years, I have tried various remedies and tricks, and they haven’t helped. I figured there wasn’t much I could do about my problem until I discovered sleep-aid smartphone apps.

headline: Doctors Without Borders to Pull Out of Somalia
abstract: The aid group said it could no longer endure the safety risks and would shut down all operations in the country after 22 years of working there.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — One of the world’s most tenacious humanitarian groups said Wednesday that it could no longer endure the risks that come with operating in Somalia, in a move that underscored the continued violence in the country despite recent steps toward stability.

headline: Hawks, Doves, and Ostriches
abstract: Unable to admit having been wrong.
lead_paragraph: More than four years ago Allan Meltzer issued a dire prediction: the Fed’s policy of expanding its balance sheet will lead to high inflation. We’re still waiting for that to happen. So it might behoove Meltzer to admit that he was wrong and ask where his analysis went wrong.

headline: The Great Recession Test
abstract: A little sympathy for those who were wrong.
lead_paragraph: A postscript to my Meltzer post: I actually feel some human sympathy for Meltzer (though not too much). After all, put yourself in his position: you’ve literally spent decades promoting yourself as an authority on monetary policy, co-founding the Shadow Open Market Committee to critique the Fed. And now comes your moment of glory. This time the Fed has really done it, adopting a policy you consider wildly irresponsible and inflationary. So you deliver your dire warnings of the doom ahead, and wait for vindication.

lead_paragraph: Josh Harris, the principal owner of the Philadelphia 76ers, will buy the Devils and assume the team’s lease at Prudential Center in Newark, according to two people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Manning, Facing Prison for Leaks, Apologizes at Court-Martial Trial
keywords: ['Sentences (Criminal)', 'Courts-Martial', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: Trying to gain leniency, the convicted private said that he had not understood the “broader effects” of his actions, but that he did so now.
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md. — Pfc. Bradley Manning, who is facing up to 90 years in prison for leaking 700,000 government files to WikiLeaks, apologized on Wednesday for the “unintended consequences of my actions.” He told the judge at his court-martial trial that while he “believed it was going to help people, not hurt people,” he now realized that what he did was wrong.

headline: New Ways With Ballet Vocabulary Are Mirrored in Relationships
abstract: Whim W’Him, a small Seattle troupe, brings a program of three works to the Ballet v6.0 festival at the Joyce.
lead_paragraph: Because the Seattle company Whim W’Him is straining against the orthodoxies of ballet, it made, on Monday and Tuesday, a usefully provocative addition to the Joyce Theater’s current Ballet v6.0 festival, which features small experimental ballet troupes. It challenges conventional ballet’s presentations of sociology, gender and music. That’s welcome. So I’m sorry that I don’t welcome the results in the three ballets that Whim W’Him showed here.

headline: This Time the Topic Is Movies
abstract: “Night Film,” Marisha Pessl’s follow-up to her first novel, “Special Topics in Calamity Physics,” focuses on a mad genius filmmaker.
lead_paragraph: Marisha Pessl’s first novel, “Special Topics in Calamity Physics,” was a maddening, twisty, eventual knockout of a book. It sparkled with showy erudition and the electricity of a true original. A prestigious, successful debut novel, it’s a tough act to follow.

headline: Your First Visual Arts Crush

A new essay will arrive each week, paired with stories from readers who work within the given discipline about their own cultural epiphanies.

headline: Predicting Who Will Vote in Mayoral Primary

lead_paragraph: With the New York City mayoral primary less than a month away, campaign strategists are focusing on an increasingly urgent question: Who will show up at the polls?

headline: Warm Welcome for Italian Conductor

lead_paragraph: In recent years the revitalized Mostly Mozart festival has given crucial exposure in New York to some important rising conductors, among them Lionel Bringuier and Pablo Heras-Casado. On Tuesday night at Avery Fisher Hall, though, the festival presented a significant conductor on the international scene, Gianandrea Noseda, in his Mostly Mozart debut.

headline: A Ballerina Glittering in Ascent
abstract: Performing Balanchine’s “Jewels” in London, the Bolshoi Ballet featured Olga Smirnova, a 21-year-old dancer of rare gifts, in the “Diamonds” section.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — What makes a star? What is the inner light that compels your eye toward one person on a stage and not another? Olga Smirnova, who is just 21 and ranked as a “first soloist” at the Bolshoi Ballet, has been the talk of the company’s three-week season here, only briefly eclipsed by the unexpected appearance of the troupe’s director, Sergei Filin, at the end of Monday night’s performance at the Royal Opera House.

headline: Times Says Web Site Failure Is Not a Result of Cyberattack
abstract: Officials said the site was off-line for about two hours during peak traffic hours because of a problem with regular maintenance of the site.
lead_paragraph: The Web site of The New York Times was off-line for about two hours on Wednesday in what company officials say was a failure during regular maintenance of NYTimes.com and not the result of a cyberattack.

headline: Poland Triumphs at Spingold Knockout Teams

lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — On Sunday evening here, the 64-board Spingold Knockout Teams final held the Bridge Base Online spectators on the edges of their seats. As the diagramed deal, Board 64, was played, they thought that Joe Grue of Las Vegas; Brad Moss of Denver; Jacob Morgan of Madison, Wis.; Leslie Amoils of Toronto; Peter Bertheau from Sweden; and Thomas Bessis from France were leading Bridge 24 (Wojciech Gawel, Rafal Jagniewski, Jacek Kalita and Michael Nowosadzki from Poland) by 9 international match points.

headline: Social Security at 78
abstract: Social Security means the difference between sufficiency and poverty for a large share of the nation’s elderly, and it is important to find ways to bolster it, not retreat, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

As the founders of Food52, a culinary Web site that last week introduced an e-commerce section called Provisions, they cook out of a kitchen in their Chelsea office, preparing as many as 15 recipes a day for photo shoots. headline: Got a Headache? This Cabinet Might Help

Those seeking something warmer might consider Think Fabricate Wall*nut medicine chests, which have walnut frames with gently rounded corners, brightly colored interiors and an asymmetrical composition of doors. headline: Food Matters | The Cookbook Not Meant for Home Cooks
abstract: The French chef Anne-Sophie Pic’s new collection of recipes features dishes that are meant to inspire more than instruct, like scallops topped with rose petals and crab topped with tea foam.
lead_paragraph: Only the fourth woman in history to be awarded three Michelin stars, Anne-Sophie Pic is routinely described as the best female chef in the world. That her culinary achievements are often qualified by gender might irk another chef, but the 44-year-old embraces the softer side of cooking. At La Dame de Pic, her year-old restaurant in Paris, the dishes are light and delicate, and each menu comes with a perfume strip to evoke the various flavors of the meal. In her new cookbook, ‘‘Le Livre Blanc’’ (her first in English, available Sept. 1), she features recipes like Normandy scallops topped with a ‘‘sunset’’ of rose petals and radicchio and crab topped with Chinese white-jasmine tea foam, which are accompanied by lovely, spare photographs. It’s as much an art book as a practical guide; Pic explained that she doesn’t expect home cooks to replicate her recipes — after all, who has gariguette strawberries in the fridge? ‘‘But,” she added, “I will be very happy if they were inspired by my associations of taste.’’

lead_paragraph: The lunch and dinner I enjoyed on a recent day in Iowa didn’t belong on the same planet, let alone in the same state. The first was a sandwich of loose ground meat on a workaday hamburger bun slathered with melted cheese, ketchup and mustard, served in a drab old building underneath a parking garage. The second, served in a reconstructed barn surrounded by miles of corn, was polenta-stuffed zucchini with kale, eggplant and squash, the vegetables raised on site and the polenta made from corn ground just 50 miles away.

headline: Fashion Tips on How to Wear Fall Pastels
abstract: Like macarons, without all the sugar.
lead_paragraph: If the sheer number of baby pinks and chalky blues on the fall runways was any indication, pastels will be making a big statement this fall. At the Céline, Rochas and Carven shows, among many others, designers sent out a startling array of garments in colors straight out of the nursery. There were boxy pullovers, just-below-the-knee skirts and, most unexpectedly, all manner of coats — tailored, mannish and often oversize. headline: Sandra Oh to Leave ‘Grey’s Anatomy’
abstract: Ms. Oh has played Dr. Cristina Yang since the show’s debut.
lead_paragraph: The future of ABC’s long-running prime-time medical soap, “Grey’s Anatomy,” got a little murkier this week when Sandra Oh, below, who has played Dr. Cristina Yang since the show’s debut, announced she was leaving the series (but not until the end of this season). Ms. Oh, who was nominated for five Emmy Awards as Dr. Yang, has played one of the show’s most consistently popular characters. Her decision to leave comes early, which should make it easier for the show’s creator, Shonda Rhimes, to write the character off the show. But there is a chance Ms. Oh will not be the only departure. Most of the show’s regulars, including Ellen Pompeo, Patrick Dempsey, Chandra Wilson and James Pickens Jr., have contracts that end after the coming season. ABC released a statement saying, “It’s our intention to have ‘Grey’s’ on the air for many years to come, with as many of the original cast as possible.” The network has good reason to push for further seasons: the series remains ABC’s highest-rated drama, though its numbers have fallen in recent years from its days as a prime-time phenomenon.

Under a ban in place since 1954, tax-exempt religious organizations may endorse political causes and legislation, but not candidates. In a report issued on Wednesday, the Commission on Accountability and Policy for Religious Organizations said the ban inhibits free speech, is confusing and is enforced inconsistently by the Internal Revenue Service. A minority report written by some of the 66 religious leaders advising the commission disagreed and supported keeping the prohibition. The commission was convened by Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, initially to recommend ways to prevent financial corruption in religious ministries investigated for misusing donations.

headline: What’s on Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 4:15 P.M. (Sundance) ORLANDO (1993) A beautiful young nobleman (Tilda Swinton, above) adored by an aging Queen Elizabeth I (Quentin Crisp) falls asleep one night in the 17th century and wakes up five days later as a woman. “Same person, no difference at all,” she says, unflustered. “Just a different sex.” She continues to learn about life through the centuries up until the present, pondering the differences between men and women — as well as their similarities — in this adaptation by Sally Potter of Virginia Woolf’s 1928 novel. Charlotte Valandrey plays Sasha, a wanton Muscovite princess with whom the male Orlando falls in love. Billy Zane is the American with whom Orlando’s female version has a more enduring if less sexually demanding relationship. “This ravishing and witty spectacle invades the mind through eyes that are dazzled without ever being anesthetized,” Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times. “Throughout Ms. Potter’s ‘Orlando,’ as in Woolf’s, there are a piercing kind of common sense and a joy that, because they are so rare these days in any medium, create their own kind of cinematic suspense and delightedly surprised laughter. ‘Orlando’ could well become a classic of a very special kind, not mainstream perhaps, but a model for independent filmmakers who follow their own irrational muses, sometimes to unmourned obscurity, occasionally to glory.” More than anything else, he added: “ ‘Orlando’ is Ms. Swinton’s triumph. With the firmest but lightest of touches, she has spun gossamer.”

headline: The Strange Ascent of ‘Strained Pulp’
abstract: A Riff Round Table on the high art of lowbrow pleasures.
lead_paragraph: In his 2012 review of the Steven Soderbergh film “Haywire” in The New York Times, A. O. Scott identified and named a new phenomenon in popular culture: strained pulp. “Nowadays,” he wrote, “everyone must love (or at least pretend to love) pleasures that were supposedly once disdained or taken for granted: dive bars, street food, trashy films. But knowing, sophisticated attempts to replicate those things often traffic in their own kind of snobbery, confusing condescension with authenticity. Movies like ‘The American,’ ‘Drive’ and now ‘Haywire’ offer strained pulp, neither as dumb as we want them to be nor as smart as they think they are and not, in the end, all that much fun.”

headline: August 16 (a Message on Love)
abstract: I don’t know why I saved one calendar entry of the many given to me by my wife, a lover of pithy sayings. Perhaps it was the promise it showed: golden years shared with a loving companion.
lead_paragraph: The calendar entry for Tuesday, Aug. 16, 2011, reads simply, “Love One Another.” My wife, Terry, handed me the entry, a leaf torn from a pad, that morning. A drawing beneath the caption depicts a late middle-aged couple embracing as they walk down the beach, eyes sparkling, mouths agape, sharing a hearty laugh. The sun is setting behind them, throwing glitter across the water. Since Terry gave it to me nearly two years ago, that calendar page has remained on my desk in our bedroom, placed so that I see it every time I pass by.

The collection uses two types of wood — black walnut and white oak — and includes subtle metal cleats and brass or copper trim, which will acquire a patina over time. There are customizable options as well: a chair’s slipcover and a daybed’s bolster come in organic materials like linen and shearling. How do the partners make decisions collaboratively? “We only make it if we want it ourselves,” Alonso said.

lead_paragraph: The annual United States Department of Agriculture numbers on the cost of raising a child are out for children born in 2012. (I love that it’s the Agriculture Department, which suggests that we raise children like we do cattle.) Not surprisingly, nearly everything has gone up: parents of children born in 2012 are projected to spend more on child care, education, health care and clothing than parents of kids born in 2011, with an estimated total of $241,080 ($301,970 adjusted for projected inflation) for middle-income families in two-parent households.

lead_paragraph: Howard Dean is returning to Iowa, the birthplace of his innovative 2004 presidential campaign — and the site of his amplified death wail.

keywords: ['Television', 'Cable Television', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: The agreement is believed to be the first of its kind between a major programmer and any of the technology giants that are trying to disrupt traditional modes of TV delivery.
lead_paragraph: In a deal that may signal the start of a new era of competition for entrenched cable and satellite providers, Viacom has tentatively agreed to let its popular cable channels — like Nickelodeon and MTV — be carried by an Internet TV service that Sony is creating.

lead_paragraph: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat through the festival’s close on Aug. 25. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.

headline: Tacos Two Ways, Garnished With Simplicity
abstract: Two taco spots in Manhattan — one Mexican style, one Texan style — please a Westerner’s taste buds.
lead_paragraph: We know: we can be insufferable. If you live on the East Coast and you have friends like me who have moved from the West Coast or the Southwest (even from ostensibly mellow pockets of California and Texas like Santa Barbara and Austin), you have probably learned that it is sensible to steer clear of the whole subject of tacos.

headline: Multiple Wildfires Raging in Western States
abstract: The so-called Elk complex fire in Boise National Forest in Idaho has been identified as a top priority, while other blazes in Utah, Oregon, Washington and Montana are also threatening to cause damage to acreage and homes.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of firefighters are battling large wildfires that have consumed more than 700,000 acres across several Western states, including blazes that have destroyed homes near mountain resort towns in Utah and Idaho, according to the National Interagency Fire Center.

headline: Now Screening | Forty Years of Love and Art and Chaos
abstract: The documentary “Cutie and the Boxer” tracks the tempestuous marriage and parallel careers of the New York-based Japanese artists Ushio and Noriko Shinohara.
lead_paragraph: “Cutie and the Boxer,” the debut feature-length documentary from Zachary Heinzerling, chronicles the four-decade marriage and careers of the New York-via-Japan painters and sculptors Ushio and Noriko Shinohara. But it’s anything but a dewy-eyed love story. The film, which won the Directing Award for best United States documentary at Sundance this year, shifts its focus from Ushio’s career to Noriko’s as she emerges from her husband’s shadow.

headline: Retiring the Therapy Couch
abstract: The limits of advice in marital strife, an apology full of crocodile tears and other pressing questions.
lead_paragraph: My husband and I are close friends with another couple. After years of dissatisfaction, the husband began an affair. He moved out of the house, but still returns almost daily for meals and laundry and to see the children. His wife wants to save the marriage and see a counselor. But the husband told us (though not his wife) that he will never reconcile with her. For months, they have sought no professional help. Instead, they come to us, separately and together, to vent and for advice. I told the husband he had to tell his wife the truth. He became upset, but nothing changed. At what point does our advice become unproductive interference?

headline: Patina Miller’s Broadway Workout
abstract: “The feeling that you get from being in control of your health and the way you look is a feeling like no other,” says the Tony Award-winning “Pippin” actress Patina Miller.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to Broadway, Patina Miller is in the best shape of her life.

headline: Magician of the Rolling Hills and Rocky Shore
abstract: “William Trost Richards: Visions of Land and Sea,” at the National Academy Museum, reclaims an American Pre-Raphaelite whose paintings were almost photorealistic in their detail.
lead_paragraph: William Trost Richards had a thing about ocean waves. He would wade in among them or stand on the beach, studying them for hours, “until people thought he was insane,” one of his children recalled. He was not crazy, though. He was an American Pre-Raphaelite, a follower of the English critic John Ruskin’s dictum of artistic truth to nature, the achievement of which should brook no compromise. The payoff for Richards’s observational extremism came in the form of landscape and maritime paintings and drawings of arresting, nearly photorealistic intensity, a selection of which can be seen in “William Trost Richards: Visions of Land and Sea,” at the National Academy Museum.

headline: 3 Brazilians Convicted of Gang-Raping American Student
abstract: The crime in Rio de Janeiro’s Copacabana tourist district shocked the nation and focused attention on a surge in rape cases in Brazil. The defendants were each sentenced to 49 years in prison.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — A Brazilian court has convicted three men of gang-raping an American student on a transit van, a crime in Rio de Janeiro’s Copacabana seaside tourist district that shocked the nation and focused attention on a surge of reported rape cases in Brazil.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Egypt, Bahrain, Lebanon and India.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Egypt, Bahrain, Lebanon and India.

headline: Shunning One Museum, Artist Heads to Another
abstract: Ed Ruscha, who quit the board of the Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles, is joining the board of the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art.
lead_paragraph: The California artist Ed Ruscha, who resigned from the board of the Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles, last year along with other artists to protest the institution’s leadership, has packed his trustee bags and headed north.

headline: Marching On
abstract: James McBride’s new novel, narrated by a freed slave boy who passes as a girl, is a romp about John Brown’s violent crusade against slavery.
lead_paragraph: Calling all comedy fans! The following scenes, set in the American slave era, were produced this year or last. Which is from a Hollywood blockbuster, which from a Comedy Central series, and which from a magnificent new novel by the best-selling author James McBride?

headline: The Long March
abstract: William P. Jones examines the events leading to the great civil rights demonstration of 1963.
lead_paragraph: The 50th anniversary of the 1963 March on Washington is bringing forth innumerable commemorations and reminiscences in all forms. But memories of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s “I Have a Dream” speech that Aug. 28 afternoon always threaten to overwhelm, if not obliterate, other aspects of what still remains the most famous mass gathering in American history.

headline: There Will Be Blood
abstract: How did a juvenile delinquent named Charles Manson become the notorious killer whose crimes still horrify us today?
lead_paragraph: I’ve never met Charles Manson, although I did meet one of his former cellmates in the late 1980s, at an ill-­begotten writers’ conference on the Oregon coast. He was the protégé of an elderly and naïve writing coach, and he leapt from her car, heading straight for me, probably because I was the only true-crime writer there. He waved a creased note and shouted: “Charlie gave this to me! See — there’s his signature. I know Charlie Manson personally!”

headline: On Location: A New England Village
abstract: Shelburne Falls, on the scenic Mohawk Trail in western Massachusetts, has become a quintessential small town in recent movies.
lead_paragraph: SHELBURNE FALLS, Mass. — UP in the highlands of western Massachusetts, a Brigadoon lies squirreled away in the dense forest.

abstract: A scene from the number “Sinnerman” from the new Broadway musical at Circle in the Square Theater.

headline: In Burgundy, Winemakers Who Don’t Own Land
abstract: Some wine merchants buy grapes or juice from others and create their own high-quality wines.
lead_paragraph: BEAUNE, FRANCE — Many vintages ago, the négociants, or wine brokers, were considered the big, bad guys of Burgundy. In their barrel rooms in this small city, they controlled the fortunes of hundreds of small growers, unilaterally setting the prices they would pay for wines or grapes. In some bad years or when the economy was depressed, they might decide to buy nothing at all.

headline: Dell’s Profit Declines 72% on Sluggish Sales of PCs
abstract: To keep sales up, the company cut prices for many of its products but sacrificed profit margins.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Decades ago, Dell gained fame as a maker of affordable, customizable computers. But it missed the industrywide shift toward smartphones and tablets.

headline: Getting a Close-Up of the Silent-Film Era
abstract: Preservationists, film buffs and the Web are keeping alive or resurrecting sites of the silent-movie era in the New York-New Jersey region.
lead_paragraph: FROM the days of Thomas Edison, the New York area has been a big part of the film industry, and now modern technology is turning some of the strip malls and storage sheds of New Jersey and New York into silent-movie shrines. With help from the Web, fans of those films can hike along parking lots, weedy streambeds and gritty alleys where early screen actors posed as American Indians, Confederate soldiers, Soviet spies, Dickens characters and escaped convicts.

headline: Seeing Hamlet With a Twist or Even a Raised Mug
abstract: “The Hamlet Project” version of the Shakespeare tragedy mixes drinking and comedy.
lead_paragraph: During my fifth beer, “The Hamlet Project” got even funnier.

lead_paragraph: The backwoods reality show “Duck Dynasty” drew 11.8 million viewers Wednesday night on A&E, the largest audience ever for a nonfiction telecast on cable television.

lead_paragraph: On Aug. 13, the Falcon 9 test rig, also known as Grasshopper, completed a successful lateral fight maneuver.

headline: Bringing Some of the Rust Belt to Sag Harbor
abstract: An artist who depicts life in the suburb of Cleveland where he grew up has a solo exhibition in the Hamptons.
lead_paragraph: The words “rust belt” aren’t heard together often in the verdant Hamptons, unless someone is chatting about a fashion accessory. It is just as unusual for a young former steelworker to have a solo exhibition there.

headline: The Virtual World Welcomes Toy Players
abstract: Video games and toys, which used to be separate industries, are merging again, led by Activision’s Skylanders, which combines toy figures with a virtual world, and the similar Infinity, a forthcoming game from Disney.
lead_paragraph: Many people still think of video games as the province of children, precisely because, at the moment of their mass-market origins in the 1970s, they were genuinely kids’ stuff. A December 1980 article in The New York Times Magazine reported that electronics was transforming the toy industry the same way that plastics had 30 years earlier. The article barely differentiated the video games made by Atari, Coleco and others from the electronic toys made by Texas Instruments and Milton Bradley, including the once-omnipresent color-coded memory game Simon.

headline: Triple Play: Make Your Picks for Week 21
abstract: Put your predictive skills to the test each week of the baseball season.
lead_paragraph: The Bats blog again tests our readers’ predictive skills with three questions about the coming week. Feel free to lean on research, tea leaves, your gut instinct or maybe just dumb luck.

lead_paragraph: China Institute Gallery

headline: Central Park South, the View That Sneaked Up on the City
abstract: Developers did not at first understand that Central Park South had fabulous views. Even the name was late to the game. West 59th Street, anyone?
lead_paragraph: Central Park South has long been a reservoir of apartment-house construction, the expansive north views as attractive in the 1870s as they are now. The sweep of its history runs from the long-gone Bradley of 1877 to the modernist 240 Central Park South of 1940 — by way of the original Plaza Hotel of 1882 and the artistic Gainsborough of 1908. But as it turns out, it took awhile for developers to arrive at a full appreciation of Central Park South’s dazzling prospect.

headline: The Soft Bigotry of Low European Expectations
abstract: One whole quarter of growth!
lead_paragraph: It really is kind of pathetic to see European leaders claiming vindication after one whole quarter of positive growth, at the thrilling annual rate of 1.2 percent. Just to say the obvious: when you’ve suffered a huge hit to output and employment, you’re supposed to have a long period of fast growth to make up the lost ground. Otherwise you’re making the definition of success way too easy.

headline: African Union and Somalia to Investigate Rape Accusation
abstract: A woman said she had been held hostage and raped by international peacekeepers, and the case could strain ties between the public and foreign troops in the country.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — The African Union and the Somali government said Thursday that they had set up a joint team to investigate allegations by a Somali woman that she was held hostage and gang-raped by international peacekeepers, in a case that has prompted local outrage and could strain ties between the public and foreign troops in the country.

headline: The Art of Marriage, or Marriage of the Art?
abstract: Zachary Heinzerling’s cleareyed and touching documentary, “Cutie and the Boxer,” examines the lives of an artist couple.
lead_paragraph: “Cutie and the Boxer” is a movie that makes you feel less like a spectator than a guest, a friend welcomed into the home of an odd and fascinating couple. Ushio and Noriko Shinohara, both from Japan, met in New York in 1973 — he was a 41-year-old painter and sculptor and she was a 19-year-old student — and have lived here together pretty much ever since. Their marriage is the subject of Zachary Heinzerling’s cleareyed and touching documentary, which uses their work as background for exploring a complex, sometimes volatile relationship.

headline: In Electric Moments, History Transfigured
abstract: “Rising Up,” a show at 80WSE Gallery at N.Y.U., is devoted to six striking murals by Hale Woodruff, depicting moments in African-American history, as well as other works by the artist.
lead_paragraph: There is nothing in American art quite like the elegant, urgent, boldly colored murals that Hale Woodruff painted between 1938 and 1942 for Talladega College, a historically black institution in Alabama. Clear in hue, form and narrative, these six canvases constitute the heart of “Rising Up: Hale Woodruff’s Murals at Talladega College,” a stunning exhibition at the 80WSE Gallery on the campus of New York University.

headline: 36 Hours in Monaco
abstract: You can give your wallet a wild ride in this diminutive constitutional monarchy, but there is also a world of affordable fun to be found.
lead_paragraph: Monaco, a constitutional monarchy on the Riviera measuring less than a square mile, evokes high-stakes gambling, multimillion-dollar yachts, Russian oligarchs, racecar drivers, James Bond films, spotless sidewalks and no public debt. Hotel suites with a view of the sea during the Grand Prix can cost thousands, even tens of thousands, of euros. A starter of pea soup with gnocchi goes for 76 euros (about $100) at the Louis XV, Alain Ducasse’s Michelin three-star restaurant at the Hôtel de Paris. Monaco is a place where high-priced female “escorts” with long legs and exotic accents decorate the nightclubs and hotel lobbies. Visitors can drop their dogs off at free kennels, and car owners feel safe enough to leave their keys in the ignition. Prince Albert II is pushing to make Monaco a family-friendly, environmentally correct vacation spot. Look hard enough and you will discover a world of art, natural beauty and good food and lodging at affordable prices.

headline: A Ballad for Those Lost in Love and in Pride
abstract: “Ain’t Them Bodies Saints,” a moody, western-ish crime drama, written and directed by David Lowery, stars Rooney Mara and Casey Affleck.
lead_paragraph: “This was in Texas,” a title at the beginning of “Ain’t Them Bodies Saints” tells us, but we would most likely have figured that out before too long. We are in a land of courteous lawmen and soulful outlaws, skinny women in plain dresses and squinty-eyed killers in black hats. These folks ride around in battered pickup trucks and peek out through the screen doors of peeling clapboard farmhouses. Occasionally one of them will aim a rifle or a pistol in another’s direction. An older fellow says “howdy.” What other state could it be?

headline: Teenagers With Guns, Supposedly Good Guys
abstract: Chloë Grace Moretz is back in the violent sequel to “Kick-Ass.”
lead_paragraph: There isn’t anything good to say about “Kick-Ass 2,” the even more witless, mirthless follow-up to “Kick-Ass.” Like the first movie, this one involves nerds who dress up as superheroes to fight crime. This setup once could have been read as an allegory for the tribulations endured by the presumptive audience for the comic-book series from which the movies sprang. These days, though, no Frank Miller fans walk their school halls fearfully clutching “Batman: Year One” while waiting for the next wedgie: They fly their freak flag proudly all the way to Comic-Con. The meek have already inherited the earth, or at least the culture industry’s attention.

headline: The Tales of Two Musicians
abstract: “Guitar Innovators: John Fahey and Nels Cline” is a slate of two documentaries, each looking at a different musician.
lead_paragraph: “In Search of Blind Joe Death: The Saga of John Fahey” isn’t very satisfying as a biography of Fahey, the steel-string guitar wizard, and it probably wasn’t supposed to be. But the film, by James Cullingham, does include plenty of Fahey’s signature playing. If you didn’t already admire his music, you may be searching for more of it after seeing this documentary.

headline: Egypt’s Blood, America’s Complicity
keywords: ["Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'United States International Relations', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: Until the legitimate government of President Mohamed Morsi is restored, American rhetoric about democracy will ring hollow.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — FOR millions of Egyptians still reeling from the shock of Wednesday’s state-led massacre, which killed at least 600 peaceful protesters and possibly many more, the questions are now very basic: How do you reconcile with people who are prepared to kill you, and how do you stop them from killing again?

abstract: The Pebble Beach Tour d’Elegance isn’t a race, but completion of the course can affect concours participants’ final scores.

headline: Could the Hyperloop Really Cost $6 Billion? Critics Say No
abstract: While physicists agree that technically, on paper, Elon Musk’s vision for the Hyperloop is possible, economists seem to agree that technically, on paper, the price tag of $6 billion is impossible.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk, a serial entrepreneur who was a co-founder of PayPal and the electric car company Tesla Motors, sent people in California into a tizzy on Monday when he released a white paper outlining a hypothetical high-speed transportation system called the Hyperloop.

headline: A High-Tech Mole Living the High Life
abstract: In “Paranoia,” which is adapted from Joseph Finder’s 2004 novel, a hotshot young techie allows himself to be recruited as a corporate spy.
lead_paragraph: The fitful spurts of energy that emanate from “Paranoia,” a sleek, silly corporate thriller, are supplied by Gary Oldman and Harrison Ford playing dueling titans of technology. These warring multibillionaires, Nic Wyatt (Mr. Oldman) and Jock Goddard (Mr. Ford), are former partners who will stop at nothing to destroy each other’s empires. When they meet face to face the size of their egos and the depth of their mutual hatred are signaled by the subzero frost of their sharklike grins.

headline: Freedom Is Tricky at This Festival
abstract: “Spark: A Burning Man Story” looks behind the popular carnival that is held in the Black Rock Desert in Nevada.
lead_paragraph: An oasis of creativity blooms in “Spark,” a documentary account of the preparations for, and realization of, the 2012 iteration of Burning Man, the annual weeklong burst of invention and eccentricity in the Black Rock Desert in Nevada around Labor Day. Sixty thousand people assemble for this carnival, bringing their own colorful accommodations and often creating giant art installations, which are either disassembled or — like the huge wooden totem that gives Burning Man its name — destroyed at the gathering’s close.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings for Aug. 16-22
abstract: A critical guide to the visual arts in New York and the region.
lead_paragraph: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Digging In to Generous Portions
abstract: Cottage Restaurant and Café has flourished in Plainville for 17 years despite one primary drawback — overly generous portions.
lead_paragraph: A restaurant that has flourished for 17 years must be doing something right. Cottage Restaurant and Café, in Plainville, does numerous things right, and its primary drawback — overly generous portions that some may find off-putting — is something many diners will enjoy.

headline: Feeling For | An Aperol Cocktail With a Tropical Twist
abstract: The Italian aperitif has gained popularity in spritzes and sours, but it also works well in more ambitious drinks like this one.
lead_paragraph: Aperol is here to stay. The Italian aperitif, which had a moment last summer, is best known for drinks in which it takes a starring role: topped with Prosecco and seltzer in an Aperol spritz or paired with simple syrup and fresh lemon juice in an Aperol sour. But lately it’s also become a valuable supporting act in specialty cocktails around New York City, showing up in the salty foam rim in the Paloma cocktail at The Butterfly in TriBeCa and alongside Old Overholt and Pamplemousse in the Sour Patch Rye cocktail at the Brooklyn location of Fatty Cue. The restaurant Brucie, in Brooklyn’s Cobble Hill neighborhood, even started an Aperol happy hour last month.

headline: In Want of a Spouse (Nay, a Life)
abstract: “Austenland,” directed by Jerusha Hess, is a comedy about an English resort that caters to women obsessed with Jane Austen’s novels.
lead_paragraph: Keri Russell’s neck does most of the heavy lifting in “Austenland,” and if you pay attention to its many undulations, you might just make it through this embarrassingly juvenile comedy without groaning aloud. Whether tilting delicately upward to allow its owner to converse with her towering co-star, Jennifer Coolidge, or contracting in tendon-tightening shame at each new insult suffered by Ms. Russell’s put-upon character, Jane Hayes, that neck — ruthlessly exposed by Regency frocks and updos — is a gift.

headline: Spare Times for Children for Aug. 16-22
abstract: A listing of noteworthy cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: ‘Shipwreck! Pirates & Treasure’

headline: A Strategist Is Mourned by the Names He Mentored
abstract: Bill Lynch, a potato farmer’s son who became known as the genius behind David N. Dinkins’s mayoral victory, died on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Bill Lynch was remembered on Thursday as a shrewd campaign strategist who was more interested in building movements for social justice than in electoral victory. For him, speakers at his funeral said, winning was merely the noble means to a higher end.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: The C.I.A.-Backed Start-Up and Facebook Blues
abstract: The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items. Thursday’s selections include a profile of the philosopher behind a data-mining start-up that helped find and kill Osama Bin Laden. Plus, new research showed that using Facebook erodes overall well-being.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items. On Thursday, The Washington Post said its Web site had been breached by the Syrian Electronic Army, a hacker collective that supports the Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Spare Times for Aug. 16-22
abstract: A selected guide to walks, talks, exhibitions, readings, dance-offs and other cultural events in New York.
lead_paragraph: Free Outdoor Yoga (Saturday, Sunday, and Tuesday through Thursday) As long as the weather cooperates, there are ample opportunities for yoga enthusiasts to practice their sun salutations under the sun. The setting for yoga on Tuesdays (at 10 a.m.) and Thursdays (at 6 p.m.), through Sept. 19, is Bryant Park, above, Avenue of the Americas, at 40th Street, (212) 768-4242, bryantpark.org. On Wednesday at 6:30 p.m., people will gather at Columbus Park, at Bayard, Baxter and Mulberry Streets in Chinatown, for a session sponsored by the city’s Department of Parks and Recreation; nycgovparks.org/programs/recreation/shape-up-nyc. Also on Wednesday, yoga is part of a lunchtime event at Lincoln Center, which next week includes music by the Dahka Band and Karikatura, from noon to 2 p.m. The series runs through Sept. 25; (212) 581-3774, lincolnsquarebid.org/news/views.

headline: Pancetta, Gnocchi, Shiitakes, Scottish Salmon
abstract: Giovanni’s Bistro, Bar and Catering in Berkeley Heights turns out what it calls “new American cuisine with Mediterranean and Italian influences.”
lead_paragraph: With fewer than 40 seats filling a storefront in a quiet patch of Berkeley Heights across the street from an abandoned movie theater, Giovanni’s Bistro, Bar and Catering is short on dazzle at first blush. Its pleasures creep up on you instead, starting with the warmth of the staff; the small, reasonably priced wine list; the fresh bread; the clean, crisp décor; and finally the polished cooking of Michael Metzner, the executive chef.

headline: A Vineyard and 2 Families Are at Stake
abstract: “You Will Be My Son” traces fractured father-son relationships on a vineyard in France.
lead_paragraph: Heaven help the son whose formidable father regards him as an unworthy keeper of his legacy. The object of paternal scorn in Gilles Legrand’s scorching family drama, “You Will Be My Son,” is Martin de Marseul (Lorànt Deutsch), the meek heir-apparent to a prestigious Bordeaux vineyard that has been in the family for 11 generations.

headline: New York City’s Jobless Rate Held Steady in July
abstract: The rate remained at 8.4 percent last month, despite a summertime surge in hiring on Wall Street, the State Labor Department reported.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s unemployment rate held at 8.4 percent in July, despite a summertime surge in hiring on Wall Street, the State Labor Department reported on Thursday.

headline: A Short Distance From Farm to Table
abstract: The menu at the Garden of Eve Cafe changes daily and is “90 percent” vegetarian.
lead_paragraph: At the Garden of Eve Cafe in Riverhead, the farm doesn’t have to travel far to make it to the table.

headline: A Place for Oysters in Summertime
abstract: Main is part of a complex that also includes two casual dining spots and a tasting room.
lead_paragraph: Main Restaurant and Oyster Bar is more than a promising new place to dine in Greenport. It is the hub of a complex called the Square, in Stirling Square, running perpendicular to Main Street, with a courtyard in the center and shops along each side.

headline: Portrait of the Artist Behind Apple
abstract: The historical record is stretched in “Jobs,” a biopic about Steve Jobs directed by Joshua Michael Stern and starring Ashton Kutcher.
lead_paragraph: It would drive Steve Jobs nuts to know that the new movie about his life has all the sex appeal of a PowerPoint presentation. It isn’t only that Microsoft PowerPoint has become synonymous with the dry, dreary, droning of corporate meetings, it’s also that Microsoft was itself a favorite target of Jobs. (“The only problem with Microsoft,” he said, “is they just have no taste.” Also: “They just make really third-rate products.”) Jobs, who died in 2011 at 56 from complications of pancreatic cancer, thought of himself as an artist, one who, in talking about the design of the Macintosh, said, “Great art stretches the taste, it doesn’t follow tastes.”

headline: Events in Connecticut

lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.
