lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Emily Sutton, Storm Chaser
abstract: Channel 4’s first female meteorologist has become a kind of celebrity in Oklahoma City.
lead_paragraph: Oklahoma City meteorology is its own world. My article in last Sunday’s issue about the May tornadoes focused on Gary England, the pioneering weatherman who is preparing to retire as chief meteorologist at Channel 9 after 42 years on the air. But I spent time with plenty of other memorable characters: the local rock star whose psychedelic residential compound got flooded in the storm, the scientific geniuses at the National Weather Service, the policeman who rushed into the storm to help rescue 20 people — including a teacher’s aide who had been impaled by a metal table leg — from the rubble of a second-grade classroom.

headline: This Week's Movies: Aug. 15, 2013
abstract: The New York Times film critics on “Lee Daniels’ The Butler,” “Jobs” and “Kick-Ass 2.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics on “Lee Daniels’ The Butler,” “Jobs” and “Kick-Ass 2.”

headline: CBS Blackout on Time Warner Cable May Last Until N.F.L. Season
abstract: The contract dispute is approaching the two-week mark with no hint of an imminent settlement.
lead_paragraph: More and more, it is looking like the blackout of CBS stations in more than three million homes subscribing to Time Warner Cable could last until the start of the National Football League season on Sept. 8, analysts who are monitoring the situation said this week.

headline: Looking Through the Lens of a Collector
abstract: An exhibition showcases photographs pledged by philanthropist Emily Fisher Landau at the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum.
lead_paragraph: “Legacy: Photographs from the Emily Fisher Landau Collection,” at the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum in Ridgefield, is a small show — 20 photographs in two galleries. But the roster of 17 artists is impressive, including Robert Mapplethorpe and Nan Goldin as well as names usually associated with practices other than photography, like Kiki Smith, Matthew Barney and Robert Longo (whose show of recent drawings is elsewhere in the museum). And the works themselves are important, not only as individual images, but as a representation of the transformative developments in artists’ uses of photography between 1980 and 2004, when all of the pieces were made.

headline: Russian Pole-Vaulter Backs Scrutinized Law
abstract: Yelena Isinbayeva, one of Russia’s most prominent athletes, said she supported a measure that has been criticized in the West as being antigay.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The intensifying debate over a new Russian law that has been criticized in the West as antigay moved into the realm of global sports on Thursday when one of Russia’s most prominent athletes publicly backed the measure even as competitors from other nations at the world track and field championships here criticized it.

headline: Each Couple Is Unhappy in Its Own Way
abstract: “The Happy Sad” features the stories of two couples with problems in and out of their bedrooms.
lead_paragraph: Romantic confusion and youthful insecurity drive “The Happy Sad,” a New York relationship roundelay as restless as the city itself.

headline: A Funny Thing Happens Once Again
abstract: A reprise at the Bay Street Theater of a comedic theatrical treasure, with Peter Scolari in the Zero Mostel role, has high-spirited antics and zany gags.
lead_paragraph: It might be hard to imagine how three large Roman houses could fit onto the small stage at the Bay Street Theater in Sag Harbor. But Michael Schweikardt, the set designer for “A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum,” has created an airy street of mini-mansions, each seemingly two stories high, with usable second-floor balconies. And Marcia Milgrom Dodge, the director and choreographer, has flooded the colorful stage with the high-spirited antics and zany gags that have made this show a theatrical treasure since it opened on Broadway in 1962 with Zero Mostel in the lead.

headline: When Taking Sides Isn’t Easy
abstract: Jacques Deval’s 1933 play “Tovarich,” about displaced Russian nobility, is a European screwball comedy, but it also is much more.
lead_paragraph: CHANGE IS hard. There is an economic recession, let’s say, and you have to give up Caribbean vacations, day spas and decent wines. Or there is a revolution, and you have to give up your royal title and wealth, leave the country and work as a servant, setting the table (such tacky china!) and polishing the boots of the Parisian bourgeoisie.

headline: Googling ‘Depression’: Clues, but Few Answers
keywords: ['Depression (Mental)', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD)', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing']

abstract: Gloria Feldt of Take the Lead, a movement for women’s leadership parity, writes that women are redefining power.

abstract: The superintendent of the Arcadia Unified School District in California responds to an editorial critical of its treatment of a student identifying as male.

headline: He Tackled Large Issues With Thin Lines
abstract: The documentary “Herblock: The Black & the White” tells the life story of the editorial cartoonist Herbert Block.
lead_paragraph: The all-star lineup of journalists who appear in “Herblock: The Black and the White” concur that Herblock (the editorial cartoonist Herbert Block, who adopted that pen name), was a rare talent: an incisive satirist, a prescient judge of character, a wielder of a sure graphic line and a class act to boot. Michael Stevens’s laudatory documentary trumpets all these qualities, engaging in the very sort of mythologizing that its subject might have punctured in his heyday.

headline: Amid Tribute to King of Pop, an Echo of Tiananmen Square
abstract: A Michael Jackson tribute show by Cirque du Soleil startled China’s capital with a brief flash of a censored 1989 photo of a man facing down tanks near Tiananmen.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The image flashed for only a few seconds on an enormous video screen, but it was enough to catch the attention of some concertgoers in the Chinese capital.

headline: Roadkill Gains Traction as a Home Menu Item
abstract: Under a new Montana law, people who come across dead deer, elk, moose and antelope — or strike them with their vehicles — may now haul the animals home for dinner.
lead_paragraph: As some Montanans see it, when it comes to the thousands of animal carcasses that litter the state’s roads and highways each year, there is only one logical thing to do: Eat them.

headline: The Illustrator Behind the Big Pictures
abstract: The illustrator Drew Struzan, who has created countless designs for famous films, is profiled in “Drew: The Man Behind the Poster.”
lead_paragraph: A poster is worth a thousand words. That’s the gist of “Drew: The Man Behind the Poster,” a documentary valentine to Drew Struzan, a semiretired top-tier illustrator whose promotional designs for countless movies — among them the “Indiana Jones,” “Star Wars” and Muppet franchises — have greatly defined their image in the collective consciousness. Mr. Struzan, a painter, used his nondigital medium to adapt photographic images and imbue them with a texture and polish that often make a production appear more magical than it is.

headline: $67 Million Awarded to Groups Helping With Health Law
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The administration had initially planned to spend $54 million on the effort, but transferred an additional $13 million from another fund.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Thursday awarded $67 million to 105 groups around the country that will serve as “navigators” to help the uninsured understand their options under the new health care law and sign up for coverage.

headline: A Meet With No Victories, but a Career With No Regrets
abstract: John Shirreffs, the former trainer of Zenyatta, is winless at Saratoga this season, but he is at peace after moving back to New York from California.
lead_paragraph: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — John Shirreffs is sitting on the duck, but he is still smiling. No horseman wants to go 0 for Saratoga and, as racetrack lore has it, have to snatch a duck from the pond in the infield so he can have something to eat. But Shirreffs has always been a glass-half-full kind of guy who trusts that fate works its magic in its own time.

headline: Tumi Ads Use Less Famous Faces to Underline Its Accessibility
abstract: In an effort to be deemed authentic, the luggage maker’s new campaign will feature less-well-known figures whose accomplishments seem more attainable.
lead_paragraph: DECADES ago, a man named Garry Davis provocatively renounced his American citizenship and declared himself a citizen of the world. Now, Tumi, which sells luxury suitcases, bags and other products for travelers, is proclaiming the arrival of the “global citizen.”

headline: Iran’s Parliament Grills, but Mostly Confirms, New President’s Cabinet
abstract: All of Hassan Rouhani’s key nominees were approved, most notably the foreign minister, an American-educated diplomat known for his understanding of the West.
lead_paragraph: The proposed cabinet of Iran’s new president, Hassan Rouhani, survived its confirmation hearings largely intact on Thursday after four days of grilling by the conservative-dominated Parliament, which accused some nominees of corruption or sympathies with the outlawed opposition.

headline: With Burst of Energy, Thompson Tries to Escape His Opponents’ Shadow
abstract: Although William C. Thompson Jr. finished strong in 2009, many voters say they still do not know much about him.
lead_paragraph: The clock had just rounded midnight when William C. Thompson Jr. rolled into a diner in Inwood, eager to shake a hand, anyone’s hand. Two hours later, he was meeting hospital workers and the head of the teachers’ union at a Dunkin’ Donuts in Brooklyn. By 3 a.m., he was in Harlem, holding a candlelight vigil for a young woman killed in a housing project. Then it was off to the Bronx, in an apron and hairnet, to inspect a meat processing plant in Hunts Point at 5 a.m.

headline: What Really Ails Detroit
abstract: Detroit’s collapse is indicative of a broader nationwide problem: United States manufacturing has been in trouble since its heyday in the 1950s.
lead_paragraph: IS Detroit’s collapse the story of one American city gone awry? Or is it indicative of a more profound nationwide problem? The facts point to the latter.

headline: Moment of Truthiness
abstract: Who will tell the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth on the budget deficit?
lead_paragraph: We all know how democracy is supposed to work. Politicians are supposed to campaign on the issues, and an informed public is supposed to cast its votes based on those issues, with some allowance for the politicians’ perceived character and competence.

headline: Bolt Problem Won’t Delay San Francisco Bridge’s Opening
abstract: Officials said drivers could use the bridge as workers continue with repairs, and a new part of the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge will open to traffic the first week of September.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The new eastern half of the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge will open to traffic the first week of September after all, state transportation officials announced Thursday, reversing an earlier decision to delay the opening for months after defective earthquake safety bolts were found.

headline: ESPN Challenger Will Try to Punch Above Its Weight
abstract: Fox Sports 1 appears to be the stiffest competition for ESPN because of the resources of its parent and ambitions of its chairman, but it has a long way to go to match the ESPN empire.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday at 6 a.m. Eastern, Fox Sports 1 will spring into existence, propelled by a portfolio of major events purchased over the past few years, a gaggle of studio shows and plenty of hype about being the “fun” alternative to ESPN.

headline: U.S. to Bring Gas Mileage Rules to Era of Hybrids
keywords: ['Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Labeling and Labels', 'Fuel Efficiency', 'Consumer Behavior']
abstract: The Environmental Protection Agency said it would update its labeling rules to resolve disparities among the growing number of hybrid and electric vehicles on the market.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Federal regulators are planning changes to vehicle fuel-economy ratings after the Ford Motor Company said Thursday that it was cutting the miles-per-gallon rating on one of its popular hybrid models.

headline: Pentagon’s Sexual Assault Policies Greeted With Care
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel said his department would extend a pilot program giving victims of sexual assault legal representation and would consider allowing them more influence in sentencings.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Members of Congress cautiously applauded new policies announced at the Pentagon on Thursday that are intended to improve the legal system for victims of sexual assault in the military, but the changes do little to alter the way those crimes are adjudicated.

headline: Syrian War Fueling Attacks by Al Qaeda in Iraq, Officials Say
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The Syrian war has proved to be a sanctuary for the group’s Iraq affiliates, drawing jihadi recruits and leading to a rise in suicide bombings in Iraq, American officials say.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The spiraling conflict in Syria has provided a sanctuary for leaders of Al Qaeda’s Iraq affiliate who are orchestrating attacks in Baghdad and other cities, posing a fresh challenge for efforts to maintain security there, American officials said Thursday.

headline: NBC Is Set to Showcase Elite Soccer
abstract: NBC Universal on Saturday begins the first season of its three-year, $250 million deal to carry games from England’s Premier League.
lead_paragraph: Two media giants will start new adventures Saturday.

headline: Parachutist From Olympics Dies in a Jump
keywords: ['Parachutes and Parachute Jumping', 'Olympic Games (2012)', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Mark Sutton, 42, a stuntman who portrayed James Bond in last year’s opening Olympic ceremony, hit a mountainside in the Alps while wingsuit-flying.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Though his name was never widely known, Mark Sutton gained fame last summer in the opening ceremony of the 2012 Olympic Games, when he parachuted from a helicopter, dressed as James Bond, alongside a colleague dressed as Queen Elizabeth II, above a raucous London stadium of 80,000, the real Her Majesty among them.

headline: Mark Green
abstract: Former public advocate and then the Democratic mayoral nominee against Mr. Bloomberg in 2001; he is the host of the national radio show “Both Sides Now.”
lead_paragraph: Former public advocate and then the Democratic mayoral nominee against Mr. Bloomberg in 2001; he is the host of the national radio show “Both Sides Now.”

headline: On Governors Island, a Blast of Gunpowder, With a Whiff of Toast
abstract: Since June, visitors at Governors Island National Monument have heard the roar of cannons during weekly firing demonstrations.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Melo listened as Michael Shaver, the supervisory park ranger at the Governors Island National Monument, explained what to expect when he gave the order to fire a replica of an 1841 cannon.

headline: Report Finds a City Incentive Is Not Producing Enough Affordable Housing
abstract: “Inclusionary zoning” is producing too few units for low-income New Yorkers, and developers should be required to build more of them, the report says.
lead_paragraph: For years, New York City has tried to create more affordable housing by encouraging developers to include apartments for low- and middle-income households in return for being allowed to construct bigger buildings.

headline: Vermont Sisters With Roots in News Embrace Small-Town Papers
abstract: Three twenty-something daughters of a 5th-generation newspaper family have thrown themselves into the business, and the papers they run have thrived.
lead_paragraph: MIDDLEBURY, Vt. — King Lear’s three daughters had their lands and loyalties to fight over. Jane Austen’s Dashwood sisters had the prospect of marriage to occupy them, and Anton Chekhov’s three sisters had local military officers to brighten their days.

headline: Youth Beaten to Death After Shooting at Group
keywords: ['Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Gun Control', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Gangs']
abstract: The Edenwald Houses in the Bronx is familiar with gang violence, but the immediate retribution of an attempted shooting was unusual in its sustained brutality.
lead_paragraph: At the sprawling Edenwald Houses, the largest housing project in the Bronx, memorials to the victims of gang violence are common. There were two on a recent day, one for a young man nicknamed Smooth who was shot to death a few years earlier.

headline: Court Favors Yale in Suit Involving Fake Degree
keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Yale mistakenly confirmed the credentials of a woman who had applied for a position at the prestigious Dongguk University but it was not liable for damages, a court ruled.
lead_paragraph: When Shin Jeong-ah, a rising star in the art world, applied for a job at South Korea’s prestigious Dongguk University in 2005, one credential stood out above the rest: a doctorate in art history from Yale.

headline: Under the Dome
abstract: Presidents should vacation outside their political comfort zones.
lead_paragraph: In Key West, Fla., where chickens and cyclists roam the town with willful lack of ambition, a concrete buoy marks the southernmost point of the contiguous United States. Lopez Island, Wash., in the opposite corner of the country, shares many of the same personality quirks, though with better seafood.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Philadelphia Borrows So Its Schools Open on Time
abstract: Philadelphia agreed at the last minute to borrow $50 million just to be able to reopen schools for the fall with minimum staffing.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Just a month after Detroit became the largest American city to file for bankruptcy, and with major cities like Chicago and Los Angeles struggling, this former manufacturing behemoth is also edging toward a financial precipice. But here the troubles are centered on the cash-starved public schools system.

headline: Let’s Go to the Tape: How Other Sports Handle Video Review
abstract: Baseball has joined other sports in embracing video review of officials’ calls, and the trend is toward more expansive use of the technology.
lead_paragraph: Technology is a review mechanism in most major sports. Now Major League Baseball is preparing to do even more, expanding video review to just about all calls except those involving balls and strikes. Here is a look at what other sports already do:

headline: One Queens Painter Created Forgeries That Sold for Millions, U.S. Says
abstract: An art dealer was arrested as part of a scheme to sell dozens of forged masterpieces by artists like Rothko, Pollock and de Kooning, the authorities say.
lead_paragraph: For 15 years, some of the art world’s most established dealers and experts rhapsodized about dozens of newly discovered masterworks by titans of Modernism. Elite buyers paid up to $17 million to own just one of these canvases, said to have been created by the hands of artists like Jackson Pollock, Willem de Kooning, Mark Rothko, Franz Kline and Robert Motherwell.

headline: Working-Class Cairo Neighborhood Tries to Make Sense of a Brutal Day
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: Many Egyptians say that the military had to crack down on pro-Morsi supporters and that the protesters were holding back the country with endless sit-ins.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — A man who sold eggs said the army had waited too long to attack the Islamists. An accountant said the police had stormed the protests with an efficiency he had not seen in years.

headline: Sanchez Will Start, for a Game at Least
abstract: Citing Mark Sanchez’s recent performance in camp and Geno Smith’s tender ankle, Coach Rex Ryan said Sanchez merited the start Saturday but revealed little else.
lead_paragraph: The Jets are certain of one thing, and perhaps one thing only, regarding their quarterback situation: Mark Sanchez will start Saturday’s preseason game against Jacksonville.

headline: Easy Credit Dries Up, Choking Growth in China
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Credit and Debt', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Growth has slowed, causing an increase in defaults on unconventional loans, chronic overcapacity in many industries and other problems.
lead_paragraph: SHENMU, China — As the Chinese economy boomed, few cities soared faster or higher than Shenmu, a community of nearly 500,000 in northwestern China.

headline: In Grim Aftermath, Calls for New Protests in Egypt
abstract: Supporters of the deposed president, Mohamed Morsi, called for demonstrations on Thursday, a day after security forces stormed two protest camps.
lead_paragraph: Supporters of the deposed president, Mohamed Morsi, called for demonstrations on Thursday, a day after security forces stormed two protest camps.

headline: Lisa Robin Kelly, Actress on ‘That ’70s Show’ Sitcom, Dies at  43
abstract: Ms. Kelly, who played a humorous promiscuous character on the popular Fox TV series, had struggled with substance abuse.
lead_paragraph: Lisa Robin Kelly, an actress best known for her recurring role on the hit sitcom “That ’70s Show,” died on Wednesday in Los Angeles. She was 43.

headline: Wolves Under Review
abstract: A scientific evaluation of the delisting plan for gray wolves has gotten tangled up in politics.
lead_paragraph: In June, the Fish and Wildlife Service prematurely proposed to end federal protection for gray wolves in the lower 48 states in the belief that wolves had fully recovered from near eradication in the early 20th century. This was politics masquerading as science. The Fish and Wildlife Service would love to shed the responsibility of protecting large carnivores, like the wolf and the grizzly bear, and hunters and ranchers throughout the Rocky Mountains would love to see wolves eradicated all over again.

headline: No Banker Left Behind
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Bankruptcies', 'Derivatives (Financial Instruments)', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Editorials']
abstract: The Detroit bankruptcy case provides another example of how Wall Street wins.
lead_paragraph: The Detroit bankruptcy case has been cast as a contest between bondholders and pensioners that can be resolved only by shared sacrifice.

headline: Insider Influence in the Commonwealth
abstract: Voters in Virginia face a governor’s election muddled by ethical issues.
lead_paragraph: For all the candidates’ pronouncements on the issues, the governor’s election in Virginia has morphed into a sorry lesson for voters in how political favoritism for insiders undermines public trust. After months of disclosures and controversy, Gov. Bob McDonnell is busy returning and repaying more than $150,000 in gifts and loans to a donor who enjoyed access to the statehouse and Mr. McDonnell’s support for his dietary supplement business.

headline: Is It Really Gluten Free?
abstract: An overdue standard from the Food and Drug Administration is good news for consumers with food allergies.
lead_paragraph: Most consumers understand that “lite” or “low in carbs” on food packaging labels are marketing descriptions, nothing more. But the label “gluten free” is a promise that is critical for the health of about three million Americans who can get ill if they eat the proteins that occur naturally in wheat, barley or other related grains.

headline: Florida: Sit-In Ends at Governor’s Office
abstract: The Dream Defenders, a group of students who have been occupying the governor’s office since July 16, called it quits on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The Dream Defenders, a group of students who have been occupying the governor’s office since July 16, called it quits on Thursday. The group was pushing for changes to the Stand Your Ground provision in Florida’s self-defense laws and wanted to secure a special legislative session on the issue. The students were also hoping to cast light on the state’s racial profiling practices and zero-tolerance rules in schools, which have led to increases in suspensions and expulsions. This week, the group won enough petitions by Florida lawmakers to poll the Legislature on the need for a special session. But the group was unable to secure the required 96 legislative votes. Gov. Rick Scott, a Republican, also rejected the idea of a session. Republican legislative leaders said it was time for the students to clear out. The Dream Defenders did persuade the House speaker, Will Weatherford, to hold a hearing on Stand Your Ground next month.

lead_paragraph: Gov. Pat McCrory vetoed a measure on Thursday that would have imposed a drug-testing mandate on some welfare applicants. The bill called for candidates to submit to screening if officials had “reasonable suspicion” of drug use. A recent arrest or conviction for a drug offense would have met that standard. Law enforcement agencies would not have received copies of test results. Governor McCrory, a Republican, described the proposal in a statement as “a recipe for government overreach and unnecessary government intrusion.” The legislature, which the G.O.P. controls, overwhelmingly approved the plan in July and could try to override the veto.

lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13) PARSIFAL Jonas Kaufmann sings the title role in this new production of Wagner’s opera about the knights of the grail, staged in a postapocalyptic setting of sun-baked earth and swirling mists by the French Canadian director François Girard, in his Metropolitan Opera debut. René Pape plays the wise knight Gurnemanz; Katarina Dalayman (on the ground above, next to Mr. Kaufmann and in front of Mr. Pape) is the wayward temptress Kundry; Peter Mattei is the wounded king Amfortas; and Evgeny Nikitin is the evil wizard Klingsor. Daniele Gatti conducts this coproduction with Opéra National de Lyon and the Canadian Opera Company, presented in two parts by “Great Performances at the Met.” “The gloominess of this production can become oppressive,” Anthony Tommasini wrote in a New York Times review in February. Still, “there is much to admire in Mr. Girard’s thoughtful and intrepid staging, full of striking imagery.” The Met, he added, “has assembled about the best ‘Parsifal’ cast available today,” while Mr. Gatti “draws diaphanous playing from the great Met orchestra and captures the shifting currents of this richly chromatic and complex score.” Part 2 will be broadcast next Friday at 9.

headline: Drama Unfolds at My Bus Stop
abstract: And I’m just a bit player.
lead_paragraph: I am in Brooklyn waiting for the bus the way most people wait for the bus: leaning dangerously over the curb, trying unsuccessfully to transform the white delivery truck in the distance into the B43. The two men driving the truck make their way down Graham Avenue, park next to me and start unpacking and eating sandwiches, while staring down the street past me.

lead_paragraph: Mark Leibovich’s stump-speech lessons; Mario Batali’s royal spritzer.

headline: Williamsburg-Appalachia- Country-Blues Goes Pop
abstract: Valerie June is trying to bring a little Memphis to the people.
lead_paragraph: Valerie June, the country-and-blues-ish musician, was exploring the vintage stringed-instrument store and repair shop RetroFret — a sprawling series of rooms accessible to the public only through a secret-feeling rooftop garden, which was itself up a flight of stairs and behind a nondescript silver door on an otherwise abandoned-seeming block in Brooklyn’s Gowanus neighborhood. A friend had introduced her to a luthier there for the purposes of repairing a 1920s-era banjo ukulele that she played the previous night at a gig in the East Village.

headline: Who Made That Water Bed?
abstract: How one groovy student made a mattress that hugs back.
lead_paragraph: In the late 1960s, a design student named Charlie Hall embarked on an independent project to explore the idea of comfort. He poured a cornstarch-based gel into an enormous vinyl bag, sealed it and climbed on top. He felt as if he were levitating, his body cradled in the gel that molded around him. But there were drawbacks: the chair began to stink after a few days, and it weighed 300 pounds. “Unless you had a forklift in your living room, it was an impossible piece of furniture,” he says. Hall switched to water as his filler. And he decided to build a mattress instead of a chair; since people rarely move their beds, the weight wouldn’t matter so much. Plus, he says,“It’s the piece of furniture you spend the most amount of time in.”

headline: Lee Daniels: ‘I Am Not Here to Just Tell Black Stories’
abstract: The director on casting the presidents and tormenting Mariah Carey.
lead_paragraph: Your new film, “Lee Daniels’ The Butler,” stars Forest Whitaker as a man who was a domestic servant in the White House from the 1950s through the 1980s. What did you think when you learned that there are butlers who serve the president?  It goes back to kings and queens. There are servers, and there are people that are served. There’s something contradictory about that in a democracy, certainly. But someone’s got to take care of them, too. And thank God, or else I wouldn’t have a movie.

lead_paragraph: A soft pink, a glowing red, even a cyanotic purple — millions of women and girls apply lipstick every day. And not just once: some style-conscious users touch up their color more than 20 times a day, according to a recent study. But are they also exposing themselves to toxic metals?

headline: Despite Drop in Commodity Prices, Farmland Values Rise
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Personal Finances', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: After the financial crisis, real estate was generally shunned. But global demand and other factors caused farmland prices to surge.
lead_paragraph: DAN LINDSTROM remembers looking at a piece of Nebraska farmland six or seven years ago that cost $3,300 an acre. Raised on a farm, he ran the numbers with his brother who is farming the family land and concluded that it was too expensive. He figured that with a 2 to 3 percent return, it made more sense to put the money into a dividend-paying stock and have his brother lease additional land.

headline: Banks and the Monetary Base (Wonkish)
abstract: It doesn’t matter whether the banks hold reserves.
lead_paragraph: Cullen Roche is unhappy with the way I treat monetary expansion in my old Japan paper (pdf); or actually he’s unhappy with the way I talk about it. I’m actually kind of reluctant to even get into this, because any discussion of these issue brings out the people who believe that they have discovered the hidden secrets of the monetary universe, somehow missed by generations of economists. But here goes anyway.

headline: Becoming the Parent With the Child in the Wheelchair
abstract: When your child is suddenly stricken with a devastating illness, you learn to navigate encounters with families who knew you before your lives changed.
lead_paragraph: As I pushed the wheelchair carrying my son down our neighborhood’s main street, a mini-van pulled up, the passengers waving. It was the same car I had passed while crossing the street two nights earlier. The driver had given me a familiar look — that sweet, half smile at our family’s misfortune — then, his face contorting, he looked again.

headline: Jesus Under the Microscope
abstract: Reza Aslan’s “Zealot” is a reminder that books on the historical Jesus have been popular for a very long time.
lead_paragraph: Reza Aslan’s “Zealot” reaching the top of the best-seller list is a reminder that books on the historical Jesus have been popular for a very long time. In 1846, George Eliot translated “Life of Jesus, Critically Examined,” by David Friedrich Strauss, from German into English. Nearly 150 years later, Evelyn Toynton, writing about “Jesus: A Life” for the Book Review in 1992, said A. N. Wilson’s study “does not pretend to add much to the scholarship on the subject.” According to Toynton’s reading, Wilson, like Aslan, argued that Jesus “never saw himself as anything but a Jew or desired any following among the gentiles,” and “was crucified as a terrorist, not as a religious figure.”

headline: A Tree Grows, and Grows

lead_paragraph: For more than half my life, I have been party to the ongoing burial of a literary reputation. Strangely enough, I don’t think my victim entirely deserves it.

lead_paragraph: Brie Larson could have been another teenage actor who never graduated to adult roles. After an early start in forgettable sitcoms, like the 2001 Bob Saget series “Raising Dad,” she began a side career in bubble gum pop music. She also played a rebellious wild child on three seasons of Showtime’s “United States of Tara” and in the movie “Scott Pilgrim vs. the World.”

headline: The Art of Passing for Them
abstract: A poem about admitting you’re a poet.
lead_paragraph: Please. Get back in your body. All I said was“I’m a poet.” I tried not to. We get along fineuntil then, talking about golf which I don’t play,and tennis which my friends pay menot to play, about how much you hate teachersbecause they ruined your life, left you hatingeverything, so all you can do is “make money,and know nothing. Nothing! Horrible people, teachers.Horrible! I hope you don’t know one,”and since I am one, I know I’m passing.It must be the pearls. The off-the-shoulder dress.

headline: Nickel and Dimed
abstract: Mitchell S. Jackson’s novel tackles poverty, addiction and the ravages of drugs.
lead_paragraph: In Mitchell S. Jackson’s powerful debut novel, “The Residue Years,” we know how things will end for Champ Thomas and his mother, Grace, before we know how they get there. In the prologue — one of the few I’ve read that is organic to the story that follows — a mother is visiting her son in prison. This imbues what follows with a sense of hopelessness that becomes ever sharper in contrast to the novel itself, which is, in its way, full of impossible hope.

headline: A Sporting Chance
abstract: A story of modern India, told through the ups and downs of one of its boldest enterprises: cricket’s Indian Premier League.
lead_paragraph: For two months in spring, the Indian Premier League is watched more than anything else on Indian television. Test cricket is played between nations over five days, without guarantee of a winner. I.P.L. matches last three hours and are played between Indian teams owned by businessmen and movie stars. Results are guaranteed.

headline: Underground Idol
abstract: A group of investigators pursues a horror auteur known for shunning the public eye.
lead_paragraph: The true believers come out at night. They meet in condemned buildings marked by the symbol of a stylized eye to watch a “night film” — one of the psychologically punishing horror pictures of Stanislas Cordova, a master filmmaker who has shunned publicity with a zeal that makes Thomas Pynchon look like a shameless attention hog. Adding to the mystique is a sense that Cordova might have retreated because he has something unsavory to hide. Bad things happen to those who try to pick his locked closet for a look at the skeletons. Consider the star reporter Scott McGrath, who plunged into disgrace after a preliminary investigation into Cordova’s secrets blew up in his face. McGrath has a score to settle, so when Cordova’s achingly gifted daughter turns up dead in a Manhattan ruin, it’s Take 2 for the unemployed journalist. Nor is McGrath the only one who wants to know what’s been going on behind the camera; in short order he’s joined by a shabby but smoldering drug dealer named Hopper and a breathless ingénue, Nora Halliday. Together, the three make an adorably awkward family of misfits, who will be even more appealing should George Clooney, Ryan Gosling and Alison Brie be cast for the movie adaptation.

headline: Digging Up Family Roots in Sicily
abstract: What started with curiosity and conversation ends with vivid discoveries on the Italian island.
lead_paragraph: As a writer I’ve always tended to seek out origins. My first book, about the search for the historical Jesus, was an attempt to get at the “real” story behind my Catholic upbringing. After living in Manhattan for several years, I wrote “The Island at the Center of the World,” a book about the Dutch settlement of New Amsterdam, the seed from which New York City grew.

headline: On Foreign Shores
abstract: In Paul Yoon’s novel, a Korean refugee arrives in Brazil seeking a fresh start.
lead_paragraph: A number of remarkable short novels have emerged in the recent past: “Tinkers,” by Paul Harding; “Train Dreams,” by Denis Johnson; “The Sojourn,” by Andrew Krivak; “The Buddha in the Attic,” by Julie Otsuka. Far from slight, they all deal with large themes and subjects that could easily fill 500-page books, yet have been compressed into poemlike works. Page count is one of the most prosaic ways to categorize a book, but it points to the fact that one approaches these works differently — the experience more akin to reading poetry or short fiction, where what is left out is at least as important as what remains. With “Snow Hunters,” Paul Yoon proves himself well suited to the short form.

headline: Service Jobs
abstract: The young men who narrate Saïd Sayrafiezadeh’s stories sign up to fight in a war as a way of escaping corporate servitude.
lead_paragraph: In his beguiling 2009 memoir, “When Skateboards Will Be Free,” Saïd Sayrafiezadeh recounted being raised by devout members of the Socialist Workers Party. His Jewish mother did the actual raising; his Iranian-born father abandoned the family for the cause. Both believed a workers’ revolution was imminent. It was a childhood, Sayrafiezadeh observed, devoted to “a peculiar set of rules” that were both ethically impeccable and entirely at odds with the dominant culture.

headline: In Istanbul, Seeing Art Through Two Lenses
abstract: As the city comes into its own as a contemporary art hub, looking at more established, and more subversive, players in this world.
lead_paragraph: The art scene in Istanbul has gradually shifted from a heavily traditional one that celebrates the city’s history to a contemporary one that prizes its upstarts. Less than a decade ago, the city’s Museum of Modern Art was inaugurated. Last year the contemporary art space SALT opened. This year a number of Istanbul galleries will be on hand at London’s Frieze (as they were at the Randalls Island New York version and at Art Basel in Basel and Hong Kong).

headline: Political Journalism Chronicle

lead_paragraph: THE CENTER HOLDS  Obama and His Enemies  By Jonathan Alter  Simon & Schuster, $30.

headline: Fruit of Knowledge
abstract: In examining the ways stories keep us company during crises, Rebecca Solnit creates links between seemingly disparate ideas.
lead_paragraph: Rebecca Solnit’s latest book, a series of essays loosely about story­telling, has a table of contents that sits on the page like a mountain tipped on its side. The essays’ titles mirror or refract one another, imparting symmetry. The summit, a chapter titled “Knot,” evokes another of the book’s metaphors, the bringing together of narrative threads. The tipped mountain shape resembles the traditional rise and fall of story structure. But this isn’t the only visual conceit. “Imagine all the sentences in this book as a single thread around the spool that is a book,” Solnit writes. You needn’t imagine it, though: One unspooled essay runs like a news ticker along the base of every page.

headline: Witness to War
abstract: Serving as nurses, two Australian sisters confront the horrors of Gallipoli and the Western Front.
lead_paragraph: Long before I could locate the peninsula of Gallipoli on a map, as a Briton I knew it as a place where we did something awful to the Australians. Down Under they have a clearer memory. Having fought bravely and loyally for king and empire in two world wars, they have never shaken the belief that they were used as cannon fodder when Britain (and France) launched a disastrous attack on this strategic outpost of the Ottoman Empire in 1915.

headline: King of the Jean Pool
abstract: We chart the success of Renzo Rosso, the co-founder of Diesel. Rosso, now worth an estimated $3 billion, was a farmer’s son who made his first pair on jeans on his mother’s sewing machine.
lead_paragraph: Thirty-five years ago, Renzo Rosso co-founded Diesel, the company that almost single-handedly incited the premium denim craze. Now 57 and worth an estimated $3 billion, the farmer’s son who created his first pair of jeans on his mother’s sewing machine has expanded his empire to include fashion brands like Maison Martin Margiela, Marni and Viktor & Rolf, all under the umbrella of his parent company OTB (short for his personal motto, Only the Brave). Despite these successes, Rosso’s life is in many ways very small. Case in point: the Italian businessman owns only one home, an 18th-century Palladian villa just an hour drive from his hometown of Brugine. Of course when he wants to go further, there’s always the private jet.

In her Pulitzer Prize-winning “Gulag” (2003), Applebaum documented the horror of Stalin’s Soviet terror machine. Now this remarkable sequel, drawn from newly opened archives and survivor interviews, shows how the Soviet Union imposed its totalitarian will upon Eastern European nations ravaged by World War II.

abstract: A Tennessee judge last week forcibly changed a baby’s name from Messiah to Martin. The case raises two questions, one legal and the other religious.

headline: Across the Cumberlands
abstract: In August 1863, the Union began to pierce through the Cumberland Plateau and into the Confederate heartland.
lead_paragraph: On Aug. 16, 1863, Henry Campbell recorded in his diary how his unit, the 18th Indiana Battery, had just climbed the front range of the Cumberland Mountains, which separate the fertile Cumberland Basin of middle Tennessee from the eastern part of the state. A rainstorm impeded their ascent, making the road “exceedingly steep, slippery, and winding.” As they labored upward, the soldiers were enveloped by a dense fog. Suddenly, as they approached the top of the mountain, they found themselves entirely above the clouds, looking down, Campbell wrote, on “one of the grandest sights I ever witnessed.” Bright sunlight poured through the rain, creating “hundreds of rain bows on the sides of the mountains beneath us.” The 18-year-old Hoosier struggled to convey in words a sublime spectacle “that no pen could describe.”

abstract: A weekly capsule of events around the globe curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: The Biswas House, Trinidad and Tobago The childhood home of V. S. Naipaul, above, the Nobel Prize-winning author, which is at the center of one of his best-known novels, “A House for Mr. Biswas,” has been converted into a literary museum that will open in October. Some sections of the property, in Trinidad and Tobago in the Port of Spain suburb of St. James, resemble how it would have looked in the late 1940s, when it was acquired by the Naipaul family. Many original furnishings and items, some described in the 1961 novel, will be on display.

headline: Good Deeds Gone Bad
abstract: Why does virtue sometimes beget more virtue but other times allow for vice?
lead_paragraph: ON your way to work today you may have paused to let another car merge into your lane. Or you stopped to give a dollar to a subway artist. A minute later, another chance to do the same may have appeared. Did your first act make the second more tempting? Or did you decide you had done your good deed for the day?

headline: Witness Accounts of Sectarian Attacks Across Egypt
abstract: Scores of churches have come under attack since the violent dispersal of two camps of supporters of the ousted Islamist president, Mohamed Morsi.

headline: Wait Ends for a Yiddish Version of ‘Godot’
abstract: “Waiting for Godot’ will be offered in what is being called its first production in Yiddish.
lead_paragraph: “Waiting for Godot,” Samuel Beckett’s signature, absurdist play, has a new twist: the New Yiddish Rep and the Castillo Theater are presenting what they bill as the first-ever production in Yiddish. The play, to run Sept. 20 to Oct. 13 at the Castillo Theater, presents the characters as Holocaust survivors. The boy who is Godot’s messenger is played by a young African-American actor.

headline: Video: The Eagles’ Elephant in the Room
abstract: Eagles players should take a stand against using the kind of language that Riley Cooper used that caused a recent controversy regarding race.
lead_paragraph: Eagles players should take a stand against using the kind of language that Riley Cooper used that caused a recent controversy regarding race.

headline: The Fig Now Yields Its Charms
abstract: The best fig is a perfectly ripe one (soft, yielding, bright and juicy), so, quick — take advantage of its season.
lead_paragraph: There’s a magnificent century-old fig tree on the farm my friend Bob Cannard has near Sonoma, Calif. It keeps giving fruit year after year. It’s a mammoth of a tree, with thick, gnarled, low branches that span outward, then twist to form a natural gazebo 20 feet in diameter. You don’t climb up the tree so much as step into it to find a place to perch.

headline: Judge’s Ruling Removes Hurdles to a Dell Takeover Bid
keywords: ['Boards of Directors', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Chancellor Leo Strine of Delaware’s Court of Chancery also defended the work by a special committee of Dell’s board, saying that its actions benefited shareholders.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 6:03 p.m. | A Delaware judge on Friday denied a bid by Carl C. Icahn to derail a vote on a nearly $25 billion takeover bid for Dell Inc., dealing a blow to his fight against the buyout offer.

lead_paragraph: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss new records by two hip-hop lieutenants who are making a move.

abstract: Pin oaks, occasionally found in the preserved pockets of urban woods that dot all five boroughs, are one of the most abundant trees in man-made environments.
lead_paragraph: Ask 5-year-olds to draw you a tree and they will unwittingly sketch you a pin oak.

headline: Before Saying ‘I Do,’ Define Just What You Mean
abstract: Writing vows is no longer rare, but before reaching the altar you had better think it through.
lead_paragraph: Writing your own vows, Lois Kellerman says, is like making homemade cookies.

headline: Every Cat Has Its Day: Hermitage Museum’s Mouse Catchers Are Immortalized in Portraits
abstract: Since the annual Day of the Hermitage Cat was apparently not enough, Hermitage Magazine commissioned portraits of the cats that patrol the basement of the museum.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — While it might seem risky to keep dozens of cats near some of the world’s most precious pieces of art, cats are regarded as treasured guardians of the State Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg, Russia, patrolling the basement for mice and rats and treated like furry royalty by doting staff members.

headline: Hotel Drinking Gets Specialized
keywords: ['ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Tequila', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Staff members at hotels are offering expertise in beer, cava and whiskey, among other spirits.
lead_paragraph: Bartenders are a mainstay at most upscale hotels, but some properties today have staff members who are specialists in just one type of alcohol.

headline: They’ve Come Back for One Last Pint
abstract: Edgar Wright, Nick Frost and Simon Pegg speak about their new comedy, “The World’s End.”
lead_paragraph: “The World’s End,” a new comedy directed by Edgar Wright and written by Mr. Wright and Simon Pegg, is a reunion movie in the most literal sense: it tells the story of a burned-out and reckless middle-aged man (Mr. Pegg) who reunites a gang of reluctant childhood friends (Nick Frost, Martin Freeman, Paddy Considine and Eddie Marsan) to complete the hometown pub crawl they couldn’t quite finish in their youth — only to discover some very sinister developments are afoot in their former stamping grounds.

headline: Stagflation, Stagnation, and Intellectual Asymmetry
abstract: A tale of two predictive successes.
lead_paragraph: Brad DeLong weighs in on the Friedman legacy, and notes that there have been two big successful sort of meta-predictions in macroeconomics over the past half-century. In the late 60s, Friedman and Phelps warned of the risk of stagflation, and were vindicated in the 1970s. In the late 1990s, some economists warned of the risk of Depression-type liquidity traps, and were vindicated in the Naughties. The first success led to Friedmam’s promotion to demigod status; the second success has not produced any comparable elevation.

headline: Despite Fears, King Memorial Is Ready for Anniversary
abstract: A problem was resolved on Thursday night when a crew from the Park Service’s preservation unit smoothed the area where an inscription had been removed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Repairs to the Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial have been completed, erasing doubts about whether the site would be ready for the 50th anniversary of the March on Washington and Dr. King’s “I Have a Dream” speech on Aug. 28.

headline: What Happens When the N.S.A. Gets Sloppy
abstract: When a vast, unsupervised organization makes a mistake, it can amount to a serious abuse of government authority.
lead_paragraph: All institutions make mistakes, but when an organization as vast and unsupervised as the National Security Agency gets sloppy, the mistakes quickly amount to a serious abuse of government authority. Barton Gellman’s article today in the Washington Post was remarkable not just because it showed widespread incompetence by the agency, but because it showed the real dangers in allowing the N.S.A. to exercise overly broad power with almost no oversight.

headline: A Kung Fu That Maims and Romances
abstract: With his latest film, “The Grandmaster,” set for release on Friday, the director Wong Kar-wai reflects on his history with kung fu movies.
lead_paragraph: Wong Kar-wai was recounting his research for “The Grandmaster,” the tale of the kung fu innovator who trained Bruce Lee. As he described crisscrossing the mainland to talk to aging martial artists, he could have been setting the scene for a movie.

headline: Closing the Proficiency Gap in New York Schools
abstract: The Gap App Challenge was designed to help public schools through technological innovation.
lead_paragraph: As befits a tech mogul, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has been a resolute supporter of digital initiatives in New York City, from hiring the city’s first chief digital officer, Rachel Sterne Haot, to strong patronage of the thriving Silicon Alley start-up community.

headline: Schroedinger’s Price Index
abstract: It’s both too high and too low.
lead_paragraph: Apparently Republicans are trying, once again, to extract chain-linking of Social Security benefits as the price of some kind of deal. I have no idea whether this will go anywhere; my guess, or maybe just my hope, is that Obama the Grand Bargainer has vanished from the scene.

headline: The Gun Report: August 16, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: The Gun Report began seven months ago, after I wrote a column that simply grabbed examples of gun violence from the week’s news. Since then, we have tried to document the awful range and scope of daily gun violence, from accidents involving small children who get their hands on guns, to drive-by shootings, to killings that transpire in a flash of anger. Now, however, the Gun Report is going to take a short break. We will be back after Labor Day.

headline: Artists on Artists | Chris Johanson on the Apocalyptic Machines of Kal Spelletich
abstract: The Southern California skateboarder-turned-street artist praises the kinetic sculptures of his fellow West Coast innovator.
lead_paragraph: After a two-year hiatus, the skateboarder-turned-art Chris Johanson is back in a major way, with his first comprehensive museum solo show, “Within the River of Time Is My Mind,” at the Museum of Contemporary Art Los Angeles (through Oct. 13) and a self-titled new monograph from Phaidon.

headline: A Prayer Before the Complaints Roll In
abstract: Sherone Lewis of Crown Heights, a call center manager for the city’s 311 line, seeks spiritual sustenance before reporting to a job that can be rather challenging.
lead_paragraph: Sherone Lewis works for the City of New York and loves her job — a common enough sentiment, you might say, but consider this: For the last 11 years, Ms. Lewis, 46, has worked for the city’s 311 line, managing the complaints and dissatisfactions of a populace that approaches them as Olympic events. Ms. Lewis started as a call center representative, or C.C.R., in December 2002, just as the Bloomberg administration was consolidating the city’s help lines into 311, and is now a call center manager. Sundays often find her working the evening shift downtown, commuting from her apartment in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, which she shares with her 25-year-old daughter.

headline: Can a Child Be Too Young for Shared Custody?
abstract: If you divorced with very young children, what do you know now that you wish you had known then?
lead_paragraph: A reader finds herself “abruptly” getting divorced, with two small children: 15 months and 5½ years old. The circumstances of the divorce aren’t happy ones, and she is angry and upset, but writes that she is trying “to protect the relationship my children have with their father while still providing them with the necessary stability for them to thrive.”

headline: Boop-Boop-a-Doo on Blu-ray
keywords: ['DVD (Digital Versatile Disc)', 'Cartoons and Cartoonists', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Movies']
abstract: “Betty Boop: The Essential Collection” features the Fleischer Brothers’ immortal animated song-and-dance star in remastered cartoons.
lead_paragraph: Betty Boop began her life as a floppy-eared dog and ended it as a happy homemaker dressed in an apron. But at her peak — roughly from 1931 to 1934 — she was a major figure in American movies, despite being, as her theme song put it, “made of pen and ink.”

headline: Gabriel Kreuther Will Leave the Modern
abstract: “It’s the dream of most of the chefs to open their own place someday and for me the moment is now,” the chef said.
lead_paragraph: Gabriel Kreuther is stepping down as executive chef at the Modern, where he has been since 2004. “It’s the dream of most of the chefs to open their own place someday and for me the moment is now,” he said. He probably will not leave before the end of the year, he said. In announcing the news, Union Square Hospitality Group, which runs the high-end restaurant at the Museum of Modern Art along with its cafe and private dining room, said it wished him the best and was “beginning a search for out next executive chef.”

headline: Bank of America May Merge Merrill Lynch With Parent
abstract: The move would simplify Bank of America’s organization and reduce costs but would not be noticeable to most outsiders.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America is still trying to get its arms around the big acquisitions it did amid the financial crisis.

headline: A Love Embraced, Some 35 Years Later
abstract: In 1978, Gay Cioffi and Mark Obenhaus had a summer fling in the Hamptons then lost touch. In 2012, they reconnected on Facebook and were married Aug. 3.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who has ever had one knows there is nothing quite like a perfect summer beach romance in the spring of life. But, like a great bottle of wine, once it is done it is done, its pleasures left only to memory.

headline: Duet for Composition and Software
abstract: Through its Opera of the Future project, M.I.T.’s Media Lab explores better sounds through technology.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — On a recent Tuesday afternoon, Tod Machover, a professor of music and media at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology’s Media Lab and head of the Opera of the Future group there, assembled his students in his glass-walled lab. The space was cluttered with computers, triangular-headed robots, colorful fabric-covered children’s toys and digital control tables. A large metal chandelier hung suspended from the ceiling, its swooping curves and fanned-out spokes giving it the look of a mathematically minded jellyfish.

headline: No Rest in Peace for the Wicked
abstract: Tuesday’s episode of “Rizzoli & Isles” on TNT gives fans of this reliable series another look at Charles Hoyt, one of the most memorable recurring characters the show has had.
lead_paragraph: “America loves a serial killer,” the detective Jane Rizzoli (Angie Harmon) says in Tuesday’s episode of “Rizzoli & Isles,” at 9 p.m. on TNT. So why not bring one back from the dead? The episode, “No One Mourns the Wicked,” gives fans of this reliable series another look at Charles Hoyt, one of the most memorable recurring characters the show has had since its debut in 2010. Hoyt was Rizzoli’s archnemesis until he was killed off in Season 2. Or was he?

headline: Release the Hounds of Memory
abstract: “Mr. Burns, a Post-Electric Play,” by Anne Washburn, tackles global disaster, adaptation and the peculiar power of stories passed down over generations.
lead_paragraph: This is not a comparison that any playwright wants to have to live up to, but Anne Washburn has always struck me as the American author most like Caryl Churchill. Like that justly hailed British playwright, Ms. Washburn (“The Internationalist”) writes formally daring, ominous and prickly dramas that urgently address topical issues while creating worlds that seem very foreign. In her new work, “Mr. Burns, a Post-Electric Play,” which drew raves in its run in Washington, she tackles global disaster, adaptation and the peculiar power of stories passed down over generations.

headline: Neighborhood Joint: Viand Cafe
abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has made Viand, just around the corner from his townhouse, a place for power breakfasts.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has made Viand, just around the corner from his townhouse, a place for power breakfasts.

headline: Spirit of Parker, Freely Inhaled
abstract: The Charlie Parker Jazz Festival, now in its 21st year, doesn’t always genuflect directly to its namesake.
lead_paragraph: The Charlie Parker Jazz Festival, now in its 21st year, doesn’t always genuflect directly to its namesake, the alto saxophonist and bebop paragon commonly known as Bird. But this year the lineage is clear. Two anchors of the lineup are Jimmy Heath, who earned the sobriquet “Little Bird” early in his career, and Lee Konitz, who became known in the same era for his stubborn independence from the Parker style. Mr. Heath, 86, will lead his big band in the premiere of a suite called “Bird Is the Word” on Friday night; Mr. Konitz, 85, will work with a quartet on Sunday afternoon.

lead_paragraph: The professor Tod Machover and his students work on building better sounds.

headline: In the Jungle, Eccentric at Work
abstract: The title of the Film Society of Lincoln Center’s Werner Herzog series, “Parables of Folly and Madness,” perfectly describes “Fitzcarraldo” (1982), a work of many-splendored obsession.
lead_paragraph: The title of the Film Society of Lincoln Center’s Werner Herzog series, “Parables of Folly and Madness,” perfectly describes “Fitzcarraldo” (1982), a work of many-splendored obsession. Fitzcarraldo — “a conquistador of the useless” — has a quixotic dream: to build an opera house in the middle of the Peruvian jungle.

headline: Rodriguez Denies Implicating Others
abstract: A report by the CBS news program “60 Minutes” cited two sources as saying that Alex Rodriguez implicated Ryan Braun and Francisco Cervelli in the Biogenesis doping scandal.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Alex Rodriguez arrived at Fenway Park on Friday to begin a three-game series against the Red Sox, bracing for an extended chorus of derision from Red Sox fans getting their first crack at him since baseball suspended him for 211 games. The punishment came after he was linked to a South Florida clinic that supplied players with performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: Fresh Pieces, Crisp Players
abstract: The International Contemporary Ensemble performs as part of the Mostly Mozart Festival this week.
lead_paragraph: Among the many changes that the Mostly Mozart Festival has instituted in recent years to shore up intrigue and innovation, few have stood out as sharply as this season’s residency by the International Contemporary Ensemble. A reliably persuasive new-music group, the ensemble opens the week with fresh pieces by Felipe Lara and Tyshawn Sorey  on Sunday, and by Maria Stankova and Nathan Davis  on Monday. On Tuesday, the ensemble celebrates the 80th birthday of the maverick composer Pauline Oliveros, collaborating with her in a range of chamber works. A final offering on Thursday pairs a premiere by George Lewis with Beethoven’s Septet in E flat.

headline: A Photographer’s ‘Tender Ardor’
abstract: Thirty-five of Julia Margaret Cameron’s photographs are the subject of an exhibition opening Monday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: In 1863, when Julia Margaret Cameron was 48, her daughter and son-in-law gave her a camera for Christmas. The British-born Cameron was a mother of six and religious. She was also a friend of many Victorian artists, poets and thinkers, many of whom she photographed in a dreamy, soft-focused manner that was often condemned by her contemporaries for its lack of craftsmanship. “From the first moment I handled my lens with a tender ardor,” she wrote, “and it has become to me as a living thing, with voice and memory and creative vigor.”

headline: A Classic, Outrageous Still
abstract: Martha Graham’s 1984 version of “Le Sacre du Printemps (The Rite of Spring),” Stravinsky’s disquieting ballet, is being revived by the Martha Graham Dance Company.
lead_paragraph: This year marks a century of ominous springtime shudders. “Le Sacre du Printemps (The Rite of Spring),” Stravinsky’s disquieting ballet about an ancient tribe’s spring sacrifice of a young woman to appease the gods, had its premiere in 1913. Many choreographers have tackled this score, among them Martha Graham, whose 1984 version is being revived by the Martha Graham Dance Company.

headline: Ford’s Big Payout on the C-Max Hybrid
abstract: After Ford’s fuel-economy downgrade on the C-Max Hybrid, the company will pay owners $550 each and lessees $325.
lead_paragraph: Dominic Franchella, owner of Stamford Ford Lincoln in Connecticut, has some satisfied C-Max hybrid customers. “We haven’t had one customer complain to us about not getting the mileage,” he said in a telephone interview.

lead_paragraph: It was only a matter of time, after Bushwick was given a featured role in the HBO show “Girls,” that the young creative types who established this gritty Brooklyn neighborhood as an artists’ enclave began to be priced out.

headline: Fantasy Football: Walking Through a 12-Team Draft
abstract: Everyone has a fantasy draft strategy. Some people stick to the same one each year, while others adapt. The writer has his own approach for the 2013 fantasy football season.
lead_paragraph: The following 12 team, 15 round draft primer is not an all-inclusive draft guide. Rather, it offers a couple of different approaches depending on where you are drafting from. It also contains a summary of opinions I have come to form over the years, and over the course of a very active mock draft season. The rules and the level of competitiveness will vary greatly from one person’s fantasy league to the next, and ultimately you will need to form your own draft day game plan as they relate to these deciding factors.

headline: The Petermann Glacier
abstract: Late July and early August, 2012: NASA satellites observed a giant chunk of Greenland’s Petermann Glacier gradually break off and then drift towards the open sea.
lead_paragraph: Late July and early August, 2012: NASA satellites observed a giant chunk of Greenland’s Petermann Glacier gradually break off and then drift towards the open sea.

headline: Muffins With Blackberries and a Buttery Crumb Topping
abstract: These muffins have more in common with a petite, rich and tender crumb cake.
lead_paragraph: There are muffins that aspire to be healthful, filled with the likes of whole grains, wheat germ and fruit purée. Then there are rich, chocolate chip-laden muffins that are more like cupcakes in disguise.

headline: The Rupee’s Decline
abstract: India’s currency fell sharply against the dollar. Inflation in the country remains high even as growth is slowing.
lead_paragraph: The economies of many emerging markets are struggling, as Nathaniel Popper pointed out in The Times earlier this week. In China, for example, credit has dried up so much that all but one of the car dealers in the once booming city of Shenmu in the northwest have failed. Perhaps the country the world should be most worried about is India. The country’s currency, the rupee, fell sharply against the dollar on Friday, briefly passing 62 to the dollar; it was at 55 to the dollar as recently as May. Inflation remains high even as growth is slowing.

keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Criminal cases against two former JPMorgan Chase traders who worked in an office building near the Thames River spotlighted federal authorities’ inquiry of bank executives on Park Avenue. And the Justice Department filed a lawsuit to block the creation of the world’s largest airline.
lead_paragraph: Criminal cases against two former JPMorgan Chase traders who worked in an office building near the Thames River spotlighted federal authorities’ inquiry of bank executives on Park Avenue.

headline: Allyson Felix Tears Hamstring in 200 Meters
abstract: Allyson Felix, 27, dropped to the track at the world championships with more than half the race left, and it was later announced that she had a tear in her right hamstring.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — On one side of the track in Luzhniki Stadium, Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce was celebrating her first major 200-meter victory with the Jamaican flag in hand and the Bob Marley song “Three Little Birds” playing over the loudspeakers.

headline: Killing of Strikers Alters South Africa Politics
keywords: ['Strikes', 'Mines and Mining', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: A year after the worst case of police violence since the end of apartheid, the killings have put the African National Congress on the defensive.
lead_paragraph: MARIKANA, South Africa — Had the memorial held on an outcropping of rock here on Friday taken place two decades ago, the African National Congress almost certainly would have led it.

headline: Near Seat of Government, Seats of Power
abstract: At City Hall, the power-lunch spot that opened near you-know-where in the late Giuliani years, sometimes the challenge is keeping the planets out of one another’s orbits, its chef and owner said.
lead_paragraph: At City Hall, the power-lunch spot that opened near you-know-where in the late Giuliani years, sometimes the challenge is keeping the planets out of one another’s orbits, said Henry Meer, the chef and owner. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg favors Table 41, a booth along the western wall — as do Raymond W. Kelly, the police commissioner, and Cyrus R. Vance Jr., the Manhattan district attorney. Representative Gregory W. Meeks typically takes Table 21, and the mayoral candidate Joseph J. Lhota’s regular spot is Table 23. Judges, lobbyists and officials have their turf. Though Mr. Meer tries to keep regulars at their regular tables, sometimes the powers’ lunch needs overlap. “In that case, I usually give the table to whoever called first,” Mr. Meer said.

headline: Libertarian Populism and Its Critics
keywords: ['Homosexuality', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Libertarianism (US Politics)', 'Marijuana', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Taxation']
abstract: How critics underestimate the hot new right-of-center idea, and how they get its weaknesses right.
lead_paragraph: Let me assume, one more time, the mantle of libertarian populism’s friendliest critic, and say something about the ongoing arguments that the concept has inspired. (The latest round-up includes Ben Domenech vs. Ezra Klein, Conn Carroll vs. Brian Beutler, Jonathan Chait vs. Will Wilkinson … and I could easily go on.) In particular, I’d like to address what seems like the core critique of the lib-pop idea, common to its left-wing, centrist and conservative critics alike, which is that it might call itself populist but it’s too, well, libertarian to ever be truly popular.

headline: G.M. Recalls 293,000 Chevrolet Cruze Models Over Braking Problem
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles', 'Brakes', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: G.M. said it was aware of 27 low-speed crashes associated with the safety defect.
lead_paragraph: Almost 293,000 Chevrolet Cruzes from the 2011-12 model years will be recalled for a braking problem, General Motors has informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. In a news release Friday, the automaker said it was aware of 27 low-speed crashes related to the problem, but it was not aware of any related injuries.

headline: The Impossible Mayor of the Possible
abstract: Three terms. 750,000 trees. 450 miles of bike lanes. 5 million police stops. And one failed soda ban. How the billionaire mayor reshaped New York.
lead_paragraph: The question was a trap, put to a novice politician who had only just been elected mayor and had no government experience whatsoever.

headline: Israel Keeps a Wary Eye on Turmoil in Egypt
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: Israeli officials have remained quiet in public about the bloodshed, but see the Egyptian military and a secular government as in Israel’s best interests.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Before the violence this week in Cairo, the Israeli government was quietly pleased with the overthrow of President Mohamed Morsi and the crackdown on the Muslim Brotherhood, which has always been hostile to Israel. But now the mass killings have left Israel in the uncomfortable position of being a spectator to the crisis unfolding in Egypt, though one with a huge stake in the outcome.

headline: Feeling For | Postcards With a Graphic Pop
abstract: Pattern Box, a set of 100 postcards by contemporary pattern designers, contains a wealth of imagery and makes a great, affordable gift.

headline: Trying to Make Google Glass Fashionable
abstract: Google Glass is being featured in a 12-page spread in Vogue’s September fashion issue. But that might not change the reality: while people who own Google Glass love the glasses for their technological prowess, they feel incredibly self-conscious when wearing them in public.
lead_paragraph: In the 2006 movie “The Devil Wears Prada,” with a high-end fashion magazine’s office as its backdrop, there’s a memorable scene when the character Miranda Priestly, played by Meryl Streep, is picking between two belts for a photo shoot that look almost identical. As she surveys them in her hand, her assistant, Andy Sachs, played by Anne Hathaway, starts to laugh quietly.

headline: Ivete Sangalo, a Brazilian Belter, Extends Her Reach
abstract: Ivete Sangalo, the most popular female vocalist in Brazil, is appearing in Newark on a United States tour that is part of a global marketing effort.
lead_paragraph: If Ivete Sangalo were an American singer, rather than the most popular female vocalist in Brazil, she would undoubtedly be described as a belter. Onstage, she is bold, brassy and boisterous, part of a lineage that includes Tina Turner, Janis Joplin and Bette Midler, and on her records she has often favored songs that allow her to emote loudly and dramatically.

headline: A Marriage of Economy and Serenity
abstract: The appeal of the 2013 Lincoln MKZ Hybrid is its impressive 45 miles per gallon rating and understated wood-and-leather ambience.
lead_paragraph: TESTED 2013 Lincoln MKZ Hybrid

headline: Chevrolet’s Cheap Minicar, the Spark, Is a Surprisingly Strong Seller
abstract: The four-door Spark, made in South Korea and sold in the United States since last year, starts at $12,170 and gets about 35 miles to the gallon.
lead_paragraph: The tiny Chevrolet Spark from General Motors is about as bare bones as cars come these days, with no floor mats and one of the smallest engines of any car. But to the surprise of even G.M. itself, which has traditionally struggled to sell small cars, the Spark has become an unlikely hit as many American buyers warm to a car that is cheap to buy and to operate.

headline: Plugging an Outbreak of Leaks
abstract: The latest technical service bulletins include problems with several vehicles, including Mazdas, Fords and Nissans.

headline: Move Over, CB Radio: Trucker Apps Are Helping to Haul the Load
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Trucks and Trucking', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Smartphones', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: While CB radio has not disappeared, truckers are now often connected to the Web with smartphone and tablet apps that provide diversions and lend a helping hand.
lead_paragraph: STRASBURG, VA. — If you’re old enough to remember 1970s trucker films like “Smokey and the Bandit,” “Convoy” and “White Line Fever,” you may think of truck drivers as free-spirited individuals tethered to the world by nothing more than citizens band airwaves. That depiction was a stretch even then, but today’s truckers are often as Web-connected as the technophiles occupying the local Starbucks. Even on the loneliest stretches of the Interstates, smartphones and tablet apps provide diversions and lend a helping hand.

headline: She Brings Out His Soft Side, but It’s Bad for Business
abstract: In “Once Upon a Time in Mumbai Dobaara,” a young woman comes between an underworld kingpin and his protégé.
lead_paragraph: In “Once Upon a Time in Mumbai Dobaara,” Shoaib (an effective Akshay Kumar) is a gangster to his core: he looks the part — sunglasses, slicked-back hair, sleek suits — and has a firm grip on Mumbai’s underworld. The character’s rise was told in the action-packed 2010 movie “Once Upon a Time in Mumbai,” but for this sequel, Milan Luthria, who directed both, wanted to show that his villain has a heart.

headline: A Big, Blingy Indian Love Song for a Brandy-Swigging Elephant
abstract: A music video for “The Lord of Beauty,” a pop song about a star elephant in Kerala, India.
lead_paragraph: In Sunday’s magazine, I write about the lives of famous elephants in the Indian state of Kerala – animals who have their own fan clubs, appear in movies and get trucked around the state for half the year to appear as the main attraction at temple festivals. One of the foremost chroniclers of Kerala’s elephant craze is a filmmaker named Sreekumar Arookutty, who was the creator, director, writer and host of a popular local TV show called “E4 Elephant.” Earlier this year, Arookutty wrote the lyrics to a pop song, “The Lord of Beauty,” in tribute to a star elephant named Thiruvambadi Shivasundar. “He is a jewel, the pearlstone of Kerala,” the song goes. “As beautiful as a poem carved in stone.” Arookutty also directed the music video below, starring Shivasundar himself, which provides about as vivid a taste of Kerala’s elephant-fan culture as could be hoped for.

headline: Sergeant Who Confronted Fort Hood Gunman Faces Him in Court
abstract: Sgt. Kimberly D. Munley, who as a civilian police officer shot Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan during his 2009 rampage, confronted him in court on Friday.
lead_paragraph: KILLEEN, Tex. — The last time Sgt. Kimberly D. Munley faced Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, they stood about eight feet apart, and each of them was holding a gun. It was shortly after 1 p.m. on Nov. 5, 2009, outside the building on the Fort Hood Army base where Major Hasan had waged a brief but deadly shooting rampage with a laser-equipped semiautomatic pistol.

headline: The Corrupt World of Then, So Similar to Now
abstract: “Last Tango in Berlin,” Ute Lemper’s new show at 54 Below, uses “The Threepenny Opera” as a starting and ending point.
lead_paragraph: “Last Tango in Berlin,” the title of Ute Lemper’s, dense, fiery new show at 54 Below, refers to the disappearance of European cabaret traditions under the relentless onslaught of pop. Berlin may be the cultural capital of Europe, observed Ms. Lemper, who was born in Germany in 1963, but today it is “almost without any memory.” Genres like the caustic, cynical cabaret of Germany’s Weimar period and the more romantic French chanson are all but forgotten.

headline: A Former Madoff Penthouse Goes Back on the Market
abstract: The seven-room duplex where Bernard L. Madoff once lived is listed for $17.25 million.
lead_paragraph: It would be criminal to tarnish an elegant 87-year-old New York City penthouse with guilt by association, unfair to imply that it is haunted by the ghosts of white-collar crooks or burdened by bad karma and negative vibes. But the classically proportioned seven-room duplex at 133 East 64th Street where the serial swindler Bernard L. Madoff once lived is poised to enter the marketplace yet again. He bought it for a song in 1984 compared with what his fellow financiers were spending on tonier Park and Fifth Avenues, and had lived there until 2009, when he traded his final weeks of high-end house arrest for a 150-year prison term in bucolic North Carolina.
