headline: By Design | The Kitchen Apron Gets a Stylish Upgrade
abstract: The upstart company Hedley & Bennett is outfitting L.A.’s top chefs (and other leading creative professionals) with smart new smocks.
lead_paragraph: If you ate only at the Los Angeles restaurants whose chefs sport Hedley & Bennett aprons, you’d be eating at some of the finest places the city has to offer. Jon Shook, Vinny Dotolo and Ludo Lefebvre use them at Trois Mec, the toughest reservation in town. Michael Voltaggio places a new order every week for Ink. Nancy Silverton sells a version of the one she uses at Mozza. And Michael Cimarusti proudly sports them at Providence, where Ellen Bennett, the aprons’ creator, works two days a week. (“I shucked 85 oysters yesterday!” she says.)

headline: Luke Bryan, the Leading Gentleman of Country
abstract: Luke Bryan is a country singer who sounds like anything but one, and his success mirrors country’s full-fledged arrival as an urban and suburban phenomenon.
lead_paragraph: The most uncomfortable Luke Bryan sounds on “Crash My Party,” his fourth album, is at the beginning of the second song. It’s called “Beer in the Headlights,” and it’s about a familiar kind of romantic infatuation. Mr. Bryan begins the ode by sketching out a magical rural night: “Honeysuckle in the air/Breeze blowing through your hair.”

lead_paragraph: MONTEREY, Calif. – A year ago, a one-of-a-kind 1928 Mercedes-Benz 680S Torpedo Roadster pulled up on the lawn at the Pebble Beach Concours d’Élégance to be crowned Best of Show. This week, it’s here again, although this time it’s headed for the auction block.

headline: A Haven for Wit and Whimsy Dusts Off Its Welcome Mat
abstract: A new 18,000-square-foot visitors’ center opens on Sunday at the Shelburne Museum in Vermont, capitalizing on the institution’s quirky holdings and expanding its educational mission.
lead_paragraph: SHELBURNE, Vt. — Don’t get the wrong idea when you encounter Manet’s “Grand Canal, Venice” (1875) at the inaugural exhibition of the new visitors’ center at the Shelburne Museum. Don’t get the wrong idea, either, from the solemn name of the 18,000-square-foot building: the Pizzagalli Center for Art and Education. Despite signs of aesthetic ambition, increased professionalization and expanded educational goals, this quirky, astonishing institution is not jettisoning its distinctive oddities.

headline: Invoking the Divine in Tiny Gestures
abstract: A two-hour concert on Thursday at the Erasing Borders festival at Battery Park featured five of the classical dance forms of India and one of its many folk forms.
lead_paragraph: Every year, the Downtown Dance Festival devotes one of its open-air lunchtime performances solely to Indian dance. This, organized by the Indo-American Arts Council as part of its Erasing Borders festival, serves as a rich sampler of the various Indian dance forms and has become one of the highlights of New York’s dance year.

headline: Modern Mothers’ Turn to Scratch an Itch
keywords: ['Parenting', 'Women and Girls', 'Marriages', 'Working Hours', 'Families and Family Life', 'Commuting']
abstract: In a culture that expects parents to be beholden to the needs of their children, some mothers are getting time away.
lead_paragraph: On a rainy August night when it seemed that most people in Manhattan had fled town, Jes Wade, a fashion designer and married mother of two, was lying in a 97-degree salted bath called a Flotarium, at Aire Ancient Baths in TriBeCa. Eyes closed, hands splayed by her side, in a crocheted black bikini, she seemed impermeable to stress. “This must be what it feels like to be in the womb,” she said.

abstract: Many Angelenos would sooner have their mug shots appear on TMZ than go a few steps without a motor vehicle.
lead_paragraph: Everyone in Los Angeles has a ridiculous story about driving somewhere when two feet would have worked just as well. Mine features a celebrity. I once interviewed John Travolta at Paramount Pictures for an entertainment magazine, and when it came time for us to move from his trailer to the shooting location, a limo was summoned. Estimated distance of our chauffeured, temperature-controlled, Evian-sipping road trip: less than 25 yards.

keywords: ['Electric Light and Power', 'Terrorism', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Power Outages and Blackouts', 'Cyberwarfare']
abstract: A primary goal of the drill, scheduled for November, is to explore how governments would react as the loss of the grid cripples the supply chain for everyday necessities.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The electric grid, as government and private experts describe it, is the glass jaw of American industry. If an adversary lands a knockout blow, they fear, it could black out vast areas of the continent for weeks; interrupt supplies of water, gasoline, diesel fuel and fresh food; shut down communications; and create disruptions of a scale that was only hinted at by Hurricane Sandy and the attacks of Sept. 11.

headline: Philippines: 24 Killed as Cargo Ship and Passenger Ferry Collide Off Coast
abstract: About 575 people were rescued by government vessels and small fishing boats by early Saturday morning, an official said.
lead_paragraph: At least 24 people were killed when a passenger ferry carrying nearly 700 people collided with a cargo ship and sank in the central Philippines on Friday night, officials said. About 575 people were rescued by government vessels and small fishing boats by early Saturday, Petty Officer Joy Villegas of the Philippine Coast Guard said in a phone interview. Hundreds of people were still thought to be missing. The ferry, St. Thomas of Aquinas, was not far from shore off the island of Cebu when it collided with the cargo boat Sulpicio Express 7. “The incident was visible from the shoreline, so it was easier to respond and conduct search and rescue,” Petty Officer Villegas said. Survivors interviewed on local television said that when the ferry began listing, panicked passengers raced to the deck and leapt into the ocean as it sank.

headline: Automatic System Warned Pilots Before Alabama Crash
abstract: Sixteen seconds before a U.P.S. cargo plane crashed on approach to the Birmingham airport, a system in the cockpit warned that the plane was descending too fast.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Sixteen seconds before a U.P.S. cargo plane crashed on approach to the airport in Birmingham, Ala., on Wednesday morning, an automated system in the cockpit warned that the aircraft, an Airbus A300, was descending too fast, a member of the National Transportation Safety Board said Friday.

headline: My Job Isn’t So Bad
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Landlords', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Careers and Professions']
abstract: I can’t help hoping at least one of my sons comes back to the family business.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND HEIGHTS, Ohio — GOOD news: unemployment fell to 7.4 percent in July — the lowest level since the end of 2008. But there’s bad news, too: most of the new jobs were low-wage, in retail and restaurants. They’re not the jobs that people want. I should know. No one wants my job, either. At least, nobody in my family.

Marvin Gaye’s 1977 hit “Got to Give It Up” was a clear inspiration for it, but were Mr. Thicke and his songwriting partners merely inspired by Gaye, or did they infringe on the copyright of the earlier song?

headline: The Warm Thrill of Confusion
abstract: People would ask who wrote which songs in Fountains of Wayne, and most often those who thought they had figured it out were wrong.
lead_paragraph: I used to carry around a little blue transistor radio at my grandmother’s house in Douglassville, Pa., holding it tight against my ear for “Brandy” by Looking Glass and “Go All the Way” by the Raspberries. I had no idea what either of those songs meant. I might have known there was a drink called brandy and I thought Eric Carmen was singing “go away.” I was 5, and that’s probably my earliest memory of being transfixed by music. In the way children understand these things, I guess I thought it was magic. No part of my brain could hear the different instruments as distinct from one another, nor did it cross my mind that someone sat down and decided to write about something.

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 7:30 P.M. (HBO) ANNA KARENINA (2012) Keira Knightley, above, stars as Anna, the bored wife of a virtuous government official (Jude Law) in mid-19th-century Imperial Russia, who travels from St. Petersburg to Moscow to calm a marital storm in the household of her philandering brother (Matthew Macfadyen) in Joe Wright’s stagy adaptation of the Tolstoy novel. Aaron Taylor-Johnson plays the man who captures her heart: Count Vronsky, a young military officer with the eyes of a poet and a domineering mother (Olivia Williams). And Alicia Vikander is Kitty, a lovely young woman adored by Levin, the gloomy rural landowner (Domhnall Gleeson) widely understood to be Tolstoy’s alter ego, with his idea of love — an ennobling union of souls — serving as a rebuke to the amorality festering in cities. “I assume you know that it ends badly, but Mr. Wright’s real interest, like Tolstoy’s, is in everything that happens in between Anna’s first meeting with Vronsky and her final encounter with the wheels of a train,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. And while Mr. Wright’s screen versions of Jane Austen’s “Pride and Prejudice” and Ian McEwan’s “Atonement” “remain trapped in literariness,” he added, “Mr. Wright’s ‘Anna Karenina’ is different. It is risky and ambitious enough to count as an act of artistic hubris, and confident enough to triumph on its own slightly — wonderfully — crazy terms. Pious Tolstoyans may knit their brows about the stylistic liberties Mr. Wright and the screenwriter, Tom Stoppard, have taken, but surely Tolstoy can withstand (and may indeed benefit from) their playful, passionate rendering of his masterpiece.” Jacqueline Durran won an Oscar for costume design.

lead_paragraph: TO veterans of Wall Street, the details that emerged in last week’s criminal complaints against two former JPMorgan Chase traders didn’t exactly shock. Over the years, countless traders have misrepresented the values of the securities they hold, hoping that a market move will reverse a looming loss.

headline: Clara Lippert Glenn, on Balancing Intensity and ‘Kumbaya’
abstract: The C.E.O. of the Oxford Princeton Program says her leadership style has evolved to emphasize “the importance of culture, environment and work-life balance.”
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Clara Lippert Glenn, the C.E.O. of the Oxford Princeton Program, which offers training for energy industry professionals, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Dear Emma...
abstract: A pen-pal friendship is pure, conjured serendipity — a random, unweighted connection with someone you never knew existed and would surely never meet.
lead_paragraph: I ARRIVED early. A stranger to Sydney, I was unsure how quickly I would find the bar she’d chosen, on the waterfront promenade below the Opera House.

headline: Leave ’Em Laughing, and Enlightened
abstract: A teacher of Buddhist principles, who once depended only on his students’ generosity, found a more sustainable income through his Buddhist-inspired comedy routine.
lead_paragraph: FOR as long as I can remember, I’ve searched for some meaning to existence. Maybe this can be traced to the fact that I was raised as one of the only Jewish children in a small Nebraska town, always wondering about my place in the scheme of things. This questioning was later fed by reading too many existential philosophers in college.

headline: Wendy Davis
abstract: The Texas state senator on Willie Nelson, “Out of Africa” and a sweetheart of a Lab.
lead_paragraph: Wendy Davis is a Texas state senator representing Fort Worth who came to national attention earlier this summer for her 13-hour filibuster of a bill, which ultimately passed, that will severely limit access to abortions in the state. She was a single mother living in a trailer park before attending college and Harvard Law School and embarking on her political career.

headline: The Name of War
abstract: How the War of Rebellion became the Civil War.
lead_paragraph: In 1881 the United States government published the first of many volumes of the official records of its war with the Confederate States of America. That massive resource has been a first port of call for historians, amateur and professional, since the moment of its publication; today digitization has made it even more widely accessible. Its shorthand nickname is the O.R., for Official Records. It can come as a surprise, then, to see that its full title is The War of the Rebellion: A Compilation of the Official Records of the Union and Confederate Armies. It was called that because the rebellion was what the people who actually fought the war, especially but not only on the Union side, were most likely to call it. Understanding why helps us to better understand how the war’s participants understood the conflict, and how they remembered it.

headline: Not All Industrial Food Is Evil
abstract: Tomato farmers and canners move toward sustainability — and fairness.
lead_paragraph: I’VE long wondered how producing a decent ingredient, one that you can buy in any supermarket, really happens. Take canned tomatoes, of which I probably use 100 pounds a year. It costs $2 to $3 a pound to buy hard, tasteless, “fresh” plum tomatoes, but only half that for almost two pounds of canned tomatoes that taste much better. How is that possible?

headline: When You Can’t Tell Web Suffixes Without a Scorecard
abstract: Plans to expand the number of top-level Internet domains beyond familiar ones like .com and .net have generated a rush of activity — as well as opposition.
lead_paragraph: ON the Web, there’s no place like .home.

headline: When No One Is on Call
keywords: ['Hospitals', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Medicine and Health', 'Nursing and Nurses']
abstract: Nurse understaffing is a growing problem in America’s hospitals.
lead_paragraph: We nurses all have stories — if we’re lucky, it’s just one — about the time we failed a patient. It’s usually a problem of being too busy: too many cases, too many procedures to keep track of until one critical step, just one, slips through our frenetic fingers and someone gets hurt.

headline: Why Innovation Is Still Capitalism’s Star
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Crowdfunding (Internet)', 'Capitalism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: An economist says his own experience in starting a business has helped shape his thinking on the subject of capitalism and culture.
lead_paragraph: CAPITALISM is culture. To sustain it, laws and institutions are important, but the more fundamental role is played by the basic human spirit of independence and initiative.

headline: Ta-Ta, London. Hello, Awesome.
abstract: Returning to the States after living in Britain for 17 years, a Times correspondent reflects on changes here and there.
lead_paragraph: EVEN after 18 years, I never really knew where I stood with the English. Why did they keep apologizing? (Were they truly sorry?) Why were they so unenthusiastic about enthusiasm? Why was their Parliament full of classically educated grown-ups masquerading as unruly schoolchildren?

headline: The Past’s Future Republican
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Chris Christie, Ted Cruz and Rand Paul may be grabbing headlines, but Jeb Bush shouldn’t be forgotten, least of all by Republicans concerned about the party’s health.
lead_paragraph: LET Rand Paul have his epic filibuster and Ted Cruz his scowling threats to shut down the government. Let Chris Christie thunder to a second term as the governor of New Jersey, his hubris flowering as his ultimate designs on the White House take shape.

headline: Crushed by the Cost of Child Care
keywords: ['Child Care', 'Day Care Centers', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Day care has become prohibitively expensive not just for the working poor, but for the middle class and upper middle class as well.
lead_paragraph: The difficulty of obtaining good, affordable day care is well known as a problem afflicting the working poor. But increasingly, middle- and upper-middle-class parents are finding that day care is hard to find or access and that even when it is available it is startlingly costly. Among the mothers I spoke to, one sent her daughter to a day care proprietor where the owner secretly had another woman mind all eight babies all day long; another signed up for a slot at a local day care when she was newly pregnant. Her daughter is now 5, and she is still on the wait list.

headline: Marty Adler, Curator of the Brooklyn Dodgers’ Legacy, Dies at 76
abstract: Adler, the founder of the Brooklyn Dodgers Hall of Fame, helped keep alive the legacy of Jackie Robinson.
lead_paragraph: Thirty years after Jackie Robinson broke the modern major league color barrier with the Brooklyn Dodgers, his legacy was honored in classrooms only a home run shot or so away from the housing development where Ebbets Field once stood.

headline: Covering Clinton’s Candidacy in Waiting
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'News and News Media', 'Public Editor (Times Column)']
abstract: The Times has assigned a reporter to cover the Clintons, particularly Hillary, full time. Do the readers benefit?
lead_paragraph: WHEN Hillary Clinton joined Twitter in June, her profile described her many roles — as the former first lady of Arkansas and the United States, former secretary of state and New York senator, and as “hair icon” and “pantsuit aficionado.”

headline: An Inventor Wants One Less Wire to Worry About
keywords: ['Cellular Telephones', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Wireless Communications', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Batteries']
abstract: In college, Meredith Perry wondered why wireless devices needed wires for recharging. That question has led to her work on a way to transmit electrical power via sound waves.
lead_paragraph: SOMETIMES, there is an actual eureka moment. For Meredith Perry, it was in late 2010, during her senior year studying astrobiology at the University of Pennsylvania. She was searching for an idea to enter into the college’s innovation competition.

headline: Rosy Earnings Forecasts, at Least at First
keywords: ['Company Reports', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: A new study shows that when analysts estimate company’s quarterly earnings a year in advance, they tend to be unrealistically optimistic.
lead_paragraph: IS the glass half full or half empty? For several thousand analysts who make a living assessing the value of publicly traded stocks, the answer depends on which week it happens to be.

headline: Let Our Client Go
keywords: ['Foreign Aid', 'United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: If we don’t cut off our aid to Egypt now, when would we?
lead_paragraph: IN a simpler, more reasonable world, the government of the United States would have enough leverage in Cairo to put an end to the Egyptian military’s brutal crackdown on its Muslim Brotherhood opponents. We are, after all, the longstanding patron of Egypt’s generals; they are among our best-financed clients. We are the world’s sole superpower; their country is a needy basket case. We’re supplying them with $1.5 billion in aid this year; they can certainly use the money.

headline: Money, Money, Money, Money, MONEY!
abstract: Why don’t the Clintons ever have enough cash?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — CLINTON nostalgia is being replaced by Clinton neuralgia.

headline: Why We Talk in Tongues
keywords: ['Prayers and Prayer Books', 'Language and Languages', 'Pentecostal Churches', 'Christians and Christianity']
abstract: Speaking in tongues might be a more effective way to pray — if one seeks the technique of detaching from the everyday world and everyday thought to experience God.
lead_paragraph: LAST month I was in Accra, Ghana, to learn more about the African version of the new charismatic Christian churches that have become so popular in the United States and are now proliferating in sub-Saharan Africa, especially Ghana and Nigeria. What struck me was how much people spoke in tongues: language-like sounds (usually, repeated phonemes from the speaker’s own language) thought by those who use them to be a language God knows but the speaker does not.

lead_paragraph: KINGSTON, Jamaica — Gunshots every night, burned-down businesses and corpses — up to a half-dozen a day — used to define the neighborhood of Mountain View on the eastern hillsides of Kingston, Jamaica’s capital. But not anymore.

lead_paragraph: The nation is emerging as a bright spot in the hub of the fight against drugs and organized crime that extends across South America and the Caribbean.

headline: A Brighter Line on Immigration Policing
abstract: Local law-enforcement agencies are rejecting the federal deportation dragnet.
lead_paragraph: Should the local police and sheriff’s deputies be doing more to help the federal government enforce civil immigration laws? For years the disturbing answer from the Obama administration and hard-line states like Arizona has been: absolutely. Each has tried in its own way to expand the role of local law enforcement in catching unauthorized immigrants and feeding the deportation pipeline.

headline: Justice at the Opera
abstract: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg is a fan of opera, which, like the court, wrestles with questions of crime and punishment, mercy and vengeance.
lead_paragraph: The bellowing voice tumbled down from the upper level of the theater, from an older gentleman of considerable girth, slight beard and apparently less-than-optimal hearing. “Madam Justice!” he declared in a High Dickensian boom. “Raise your head to the balcony please!”

headline: Tech Love Isn’t Forever
abstract: So, you think you and your iPhone are inseparable?
lead_paragraph: The news that BlackBerry is considering selling itself is a good reminder of the impermanence of technological dominance. Not too long ago, the thought that the company would be forced to even consider such a step would have struck financial analysts and consumers as outlandish — as outlandish, say, as the idea that people might stop using Google or Facebook.

headline: The Cash Committee
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Campaign Finance', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: Lawmakers are lining up for a chance to take money from the banks — and do their bidding.
lead_paragraph: The House Financial Services Committee has grown so large that a highly unusual fourth row of seats had to be installed in the committee room. Every term, scores of members, particularly freshmen, demand a seat on the panel — not because they have a burning interest in regulating banks and Wall Street, but because they know that they will be able raise much more money if one of the 61 seats has their name on it.

headline: Foreign Investment in Mexican Oil
abstract: Proposed changes could help revive Mexico’s energy sector and give its economy a much-needed lift.
lead_paragraph: President Enrique Peña Nieto of Mexico proposed ambitious constitutional reforms last week that would allow foreigners to invest in Mexico’s nationalized oil industry for the first time in 75 years. Such a change could help revive the country’s energy sector and give its economy a much-needed lift.

lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Most baseball players use their lockers for gear: mitts, bats and jerseys. Luke Scott, an outfielder and designated hitter with the Tampa Bay Rays, uses his to display a mounted boar’s head.

headline: Bodies on the Border

lead_paragraph: Forensics experts in Arizona struggle to identify the bodies of migrants who perished while attempting to cross illicitly from Mexico into the United States.

headline: ‘Bodies on the Border’
abstract: Forensics experts in Arizona struggle to identify the bodies of migrants who perished while attempting to cross illicitly from Mexico into the United States.
lead_paragraph: This summer, as discussions have advanced around a comprehensive immigration reform bill, I traveled to Arizona to film some people who have a unique perspective on border security. I followed Dr. Bruce Anderson, a forensic anthropologist with the Pima County Office of the Medical Examiner, who has worked to identify the remains of some 2,200 people found dead in the Arizona desert since 1990 — undocumented migrants who attempted to cross illicitly from Central America and Mexico into the United States. And I followed Robin Reineke, a University of Arizona doctoral student in anthropology who founded the Missing Migrant Project, a nongovernmental organization that helps families look for their missing relatives.

headline: Lawyer Says the Yankees Misled Rodriguez About His Injuries
abstract: Joseph Tacopina said the team had misled Alex Rodriguez about his injuries, in hopes of nullifying his contract, and suggested that the commissioner was out to get the player.
lead_paragraph: The new lawyer for Alex Rodriguez, opening a fresh defense for a player who sees himself as unfairly targeted by Major League Baseball and his team, said that the Yankees tried to hasten the end of his career by playing him when he was injured and that baseball’s commissioner is determined to brand Rodriguez as the “poster boy” for doping.

headline: War on the Border
abstract: The Border Patrol, the largest federal law enforcement agency, has become an expensive military apparatus deployed to police and capture immigrants.
lead_paragraph: THREE generations of Loews have worked the family’s 63 acres in Amado, Ariz. In the last 20 years, the Loew family harvested thousands of pounds of onions, garlic and pumpkins without incident. So Stewart Loew, 44, who was born and raised on the farm, was surprised when he went to irrigate his fields one night and found himself surrounded by federal agents.

headline: Bolt Completes a Double and Russian Women Break Through
abstract: Usain Bolt claimed a victory in the 200 meters and Russian women broke the American grip on the 4x400-meter relay at the world championships on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — It was a fine, upbeat night for Russia at the world track and field championships, and the good vibrations often came at the expense of its former archrival, the United States.

headline: Conservatives Are (Mostly) Not Libertarians
abstract: And they don’t really believe in limited government.
lead_paragraph: Mike Konczal has an interesting and useful essay over at Wonkblog on what conservatives don’t get — namely, their failure to appreciate that some problems are inherently public in nature, and require public solutions. Somewhat unusually, however, I think that Mike has somewhat missed the point, and engaged in a bit of wishful thinking. His essay is an excellent critique of libertarians; but most conservatives are not libertarians, even if they like to use libertarian rhetoric now and then.

headline: Inflation Nostalgia
abstract: The 70s were a long time ago.
lead_paragraph: David Glasner continues his meditation on Milton Friedman and all that, this time focusing on Friedman’s insight that nominal interest rates aren’t necessarily a good guide to the stance of monetary policy — basically because even a high nominal rate may amount to very easy money if expected inflation is even higher.

headline: A Lifer Stung by 47 Losses
abstract: Known for failure as an N.B.A. coach, Roy Rubin meant far more to the players he mentored at Long Island University, whose program he revived.
lead_paragraph: Nobody taught me more about life, or basketball, than Roy Rubin, who died Aug. 5 at 87.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Aug. 18
abstract: Senators John McCain and Lindsey Graham will appear on a couple of Sunday shows to talk about the turmoil in Egypt, which escalated after their recent visit.
lead_paragraph: As the violence escalates in Egypt, two Republican senators who recently visited the country — John McCain of Arizona and Lindsey Graham of South Carolina — will weigh in on Sunday talk shows. The two members of the Senate Armed Services Committee urged the new military-appointed government on Aug. 6 to move toward democracy or risk losing American aid.

headline: Expecting the Unexpected From Jeff Bezos
keywords: ['Newspapers', 'E-Commerce', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Book Trade and Publishing']
abstract: At Amazon.com, he has upended industries. Now he promises change at The Washington Post. If his history is a guide, he will have all the laughs.

headline: Hands in Many Pies

lead_paragraph: The man who is buying The Washington Post has put much of his wealth into a variety of investments and projects.

headline: Edginess

lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — You will never hear me accuse Elizabeth C. Gorski of incompleteness, and that’s a fabulous thing. Ms. Gorski not only comes up with some of the most visually and conceptually creative puzzles in the business, but she always ties up her ideas in a neat bow and gives us a complete idea. I’ll explain.

headline: Sectarian Attacks Return With a Roar to Iraq, Rattling a Capital Already on Edge
abstract: The drastic surge in violence from car bombs and security sweeps has a lent a new sense of Balkanization to Baghdad.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The black-masked soldier stood at the army checkpoint examining the identification cards of each passenger, denying entry to anyone who did not live in the Sunni district of Ameriya. One resident later said entering his neighborhood now felt like crossing the border into a different country.

headline: Radio Station Employee Is Shot Dead in Somalia

abstract: A technician for the state-run broadcaster Radio Mogadishu was killed by two armed men outside his home on Saturday, and another man was executed for killing a journalist last year.
lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia — A technician for the state-run broadcaster Radio Mogadishu was murdered on Saturday, the sixth media employee killed so far this year in Somalia. Separately, in the first such execution in Somalia, a man found guilty of killing a journalist last year was executed by firing squad.

headline: Some Worry Over a Law to Increase DNA Testing
keywords: ['DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Law and Legislation', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments']

lead_paragraph: In some Texas counties, it takes six months or longer to get DNA test results from the Department of Public Safety, says William Lee Hon, the Polk County criminal district attorney.

headline: No. 1 Over All, but Catching Up

headline: Ruth Asawa, an Artist Who Wove Wire, Dies at 87

lead_paragraph: Ruth Asawa, an artist who learned to draw in an internment camp for Japanese-Americans during World War II and later earned renown weaving wire into intricate, flowing, fanciful abstract sculptures, died on Aug. 6 at her home in San Francisco, where many of her works now dot the cityscape. She was 87.

headline: Haji, an Actress Featured in Cult Films by Russ Meyer, Dies at 67

lead_paragraph: Haji, a voluptuous actress who played one of three homicidal go-go dancers in Russ Meyer’s 1965 cult film “Faster, Pussycat! Kill! Kill!,” died on Aug. 9 in Southern California. She was 67.

headline: Bicycling for Thinner Texans and New Businesses
abstract: Bike lanes and the use of bicycles in general has recently exploded in Texas, which is a good sign for local business and for residents’ waistlines.
lead_paragraph: In Fort Worth, the mayor hosts occasional bicycle rides called Rolling Town Halls. The Dallas City Council may soon require new businesses to set aside space for bicycle parking. Over in El Paso, officials are developing plans for a bike-share system, which is expected to be the fifth such program in the state after Austin’s makes its debut this year.

headline: A Musical Switch From Self-Pity to Gratitude
abstract: The new album by Blue October, “Sway,” is less about the specifics of a band member’s recovery from addiction to alcohol and prescription pills than it is about hope.
lead_paragraph: Last May, Justin Furstenfeld’s pregnant wife offered him an ultimatum: drinking and drugs or their marriage. The next day Mr. Furstenfeld’s bandmates in the platinum-selling rock band Blue October came to his house in San Marcos and presented him with a similar choice.

headline: In Absence of New Revenue Bonds, Texas Universities Delaying Projects

lead_paragraph: The University of Houston-Clear Lake, which is scheduled to become to a four-year university in 2014, had sought support from the Texas Legislature for new science and academic support facilities that administrators hope to open in 2017.

lead_paragraph: BOSTON — When the Yankees won the opener of a three-game series against the Boston Red Sox on Friday night, their optimism soared. With one win against their rivals, the division leaders, already in the ledger, the Yankees were turning to Hiroki Kuroda, their best pitcher, for the middle game of the series.

headline: Christie’s Re-election Engine Gets in Gear for a Bigger Race
abstract: As Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey heads for what is expected to be an easy re-election, he is building an operation that could form the basis for a presidential run.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — He has hired specialists in microtargeting who worked for the presidential campaigns of Mitt Romney and George W. Bush. He has built a sprawling, 50-state fund-raising network, including major Republican players like Harold Simmons, the billionaire backer of a Karl Rove-led “super PAC” that spent $105 million in the 2012 race.

headline: A Slugger Fights for the Yankees, but Mostly Against Them
abstract: On Saturday at Fenway Park, Alex Rodriguez played for the Yankees while simultaneously trying to shred their integrity.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The worst scandal in baseball history, the one that threatened the very existence of the game, was the decision by several members of the 1919 Chicago White Sox to intentionally lose the World Series. Alex Rodriguez’s lawyer has accused the Yankees of committing a similar act of treason.

headline: Isner and Williams Advance to Finals

headline: D’Arnaud Makes Debut as Mets Showcase Future
abstract: The highly regarded young catcher Travis d’Arnaud, 24, became the sixth Mets rookie to make his debut this season.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — They have been rolling out incrementally this year, individual pieces to a puzzle that the Mets hope will take form next year to complete a winning baseball team.

headline: Los Angeles Neighborhood Tries to Change, but Avoid the Pitfalls
abstract: The transition in Boyle Heights has provided a jolt of energy and a transfusion of money, but it has also created friction with working-class residents.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When Juan Romero was a boy in the 1980s, people talked about his neighborhood, Boyle Heights, as a place to escape. The area was besieged by gangs, public schools were struggling, and a vast majority of residents were barely above the poverty line.

lead_paragraph: In the Los Angeles neighborhood of Boyle Heights young Latinos are trying to stave off gentrification with what they call gentefication by opening their own hip businesses.

headline: In All Flavors, Cigars Draw In Young Smokers
abstract: Cigarette sales are down, but tobacco critics say the gains are being offset by the rise of alternatives like cigars, whose flavored varieties are smoked overwhelmingly by young people.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — At Everest Greenish Grocery, a brightly lit store on a faded corner of this city, nothing is more popular than a chocolate-flavored little cigar. They are displayed just above the Hershey bars along with their colorful cigarillo cousins — white grape, strawberry, pineapple and Da Bomb Blueberry. And they were completely sold out by 9 one recent evening, snapped up by young people dropping by for a snack or stopping in during a night of bar hopping.

headline: Master’s Degree Is New Frontier of Study Online
abstract: The master’s degree offered by the Georgia Institute of Technology through massive open online courses has the potential to disrupt higher education.
lead_paragraph: Next January, the Georgia Institute of Technology plans to offer a master’s degree in computer science through massive open online courses for a fraction of the on-campus cost, a first for an elite institution. If it even approaches its goal of drawing thousands of students, it could signal a change to the landscape of higher education.

headline: With Stage to Himself, Sanchez Gives Boost to Understudy

Smith watched Mark Sanchez complete his first five passes, including a touchdown, just as he would watch Sanchez thwart a potential scoring drive with an interception in the end zone, just as he would watch the Jets fail to score after having first-and-goal from the Jacksonville 3 on Sanchez’s final series before halftime.

headline: What’s On Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13, 49) THE LADY VANISHES In this “Masterpiece Mystery!” movie, based on Ethel Lina White’s 1936 novel, “The Wheel Spins,” from which Alfred Hitchcock adapted his 1938 thriller, “The Lady Vanishes,” Iris Carr (Tuppence Middleton, above, with Tom Hughes), a beautiful young socialite, is befriended on a train by an older Englishwoman named Miss Froy (Selina Cadell), who then disappears — after which Iris’s fellow passengers deny she ever existed. Only Max Hare (Mr. Hughes), the infatuated engineer, pays heed to Iris’s conviction. Is it fair to compare this film with Hitchcock’s? Mike Hale asked in The New York Times. “It doesn’t really matter, because if you’ve seen the original, it’s impossible to do otherwise,” he decided. “This new ‘Lady Vanishes,’ directed by Diarmuid Lawrence (‘South Riding’) from a screenplay by Fiona Seres, is a perfectly adequate television mystery of the week. But it forgoes the crackling pace, light touch and surprisingly sophisticated sexual banter of the original, opting for melancholy, ominousness and sentimentality.”

headline: 42 Heavy-Metal Bands, 2,000 Fans, My Son and Me
abstract: When my son asked me to go on a heavy metal music cruise, I knew it wasn’t because he wanted to spend time with me. He needed a chaperon over 21. I was a necessary inconvenience. Of course I said yes.

This one was called 70,000 Tons of Metal, and it featured 42 heavy-metal bands and 2,000 metal fans. I did not like heavy-metal music, and I did not particularly like my son very much those days, either.

A biographical drama that cost roughly $30 million to make, “The Butler” was aggressively promoted by Ms. Winfrey, who plays an alcoholic wife in the film. Pent-up demand for more serious cinema also helped sales, as did enthusiastic reviews and a tempest-in-a-teapot fight over the film’s title.

headline: Unloading the Weightiness of Brahms With a Few Flicks
abstract: The conductor David Afkham made his debut with the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra in a performance of Brahms’s works at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: Sprezzatura is not a term usually associated with Brahms. Coined in 16th-century Urbino by Baldassare Castiglione, the author of the Renaissance blockbuster guide to courtly manners, the Italian word denotes an elegant lightness of bearing that masks the effort behind the composure. The music of Brahms? The opposite, surely, with quill-chewing, meticulous labor audible in every earnestly created bar.

abstract: In the Reelz movie “Delete,” a young man, a reporter, a hacker and an F.B.I. agent battle malevolent machines linked by the Web.

headline: Knocking the Crowns Off Pageant Winners
abstract: Francesca Harper’s dance-theater production “Art Prototype 2013” uses beauty pageants as its point of departure.
lead_paragraph: At the start of Francesca Harper’s “Art Prototype 2013,” a dance-theater production using beauty pageants as its point of departure, a woman slowly crossed the stage while trailing two long strips of white fabric. Another performer passed the other way, marking the stage with an X. The dancer Eriko Iisaku, her body both lissome and punctuated, dashed across and underneath the pieces of the fabric before landing on her rear; gradually, her legs splayed. Then, like much of what happened throughout this congested work, the moment was abandoned; it trailed off, leading to nowhere.

headline: Off to a Good Start
abstract: Jean O’Conor’s got plenty of definitions up her sleeve.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — In today’s puzzle, constructor Jean O’Conor riffs on the many meanings of one common English word by demonstrating the myriad ways it can be used. For a single four-letter word with only three unique letters, it’s got plenty of versatility – my edition of Webster’s spouts off 51 definitions – and the six examples that Jean uses show its diverse denotations in action. After all, it’s not readily apparent that there’s a verbal link between POPPY SEEDS and WALLPAPER.

headline: Theft Charges Reverberate in Connecticut Art World
abstract: Genteel towns in the Litchfield Hills of Connecticut are shocked by charges against Jasper Johns’s assistant.
lead_paragraph: For 16 years, William Morrison has watched the passing parade at his airy, contemporary Morrison Gallery in Kent, in northwestern Connecticut, where luminaries like Meryl Streep, Sam Waterston, Kevin Bacon and Kate Winslet, and far-flung artists great and small live the understated good life of the Litchfield Hills.

headline: Student’s Trip Ends; A Mystery Just Begins
abstract: In Gone Home, a college student returns from a year abroad and encounters a family mystery.
lead_paragraph: Gone Home, the first game from the Fullbright Company, is the greatest video game love story ever told and proof, in case any more were needed, that video games do not require shooting or punching or jumping or action of any kind to create gripping fiction.

headline: Ballerina Leaves Her Comfort Zone
abstract: Wendy Whelan of New York City Ballet stars in a program she devised of four modern-dance works at the Jacob’s Pillow festival in Massachusetts.
lead_paragraph: BECKET, Mass. — Entering the world of modern dance, as she does in her program “Restless Creature,” Wendy Whelan exhibits the same qualities of temperament she has shown for years as a principal dancer of New York City Ballet: She’s uncompromising, generous, bold, enthusiastic, adult, at the same time decisive and investigative. Few dancers in any genre show better that a work should be a process of self-discovery.

headline: John Hollander, Poet at Ease With Intellectualism and Wit, Dies at 83
abstract: Mr. Hollander branched out with ambitious work after making a name for himself with traditional forms.
lead_paragraph: John Hollander, a virtuosic poet who breathed new life into traditional verse forms and whose later work achieved a visionary, mythic sweep, died on Saturday in Branford, Conn. He was 83.

headline: A Heavy-Metal Narrative That Speaks in the Many Dialects of Music
abstract: Phil Anselmo, once the singer of Pantera, played with his new group, Philip H. Anselmo & the Illegals, at Gramercy Theater.
lead_paragraph: Phil Anselmo started his remarkable set on Friday night at Gramercy Theater by tenderizing the crowd on the subject of his new group, Philip H. Anselmo & the Illegals, bragging and downplaying, joking and turning serious. “I apologize ahead of time,” he said. His voice has lost most of its melody after three decades of nicotine and grandiose yelling, but it still works; even his apologies sound like commands.

headline: Resisting the Siren Call of the Screen
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: Three new books examine the search for balance in a wired world, especially for children growing up in the digital age.
lead_paragraph: My house may be like your house.

headline: Manifesta Curator Named
abstract: Kasper Konig, a Berlin curator who has defended art against censorship by conservatives, has been named chief curator of the 10th edition of Manifesta, the roving European contemporary art biennial.
lead_paragraph: Kasper Konig, a Berlin curator who has defended art against censorship by conservatives, has been named chief curator of the 10th edition of Manifesta, the roving European contemporary art biennial. This year the event is to be held in Russia for the first time, just as the country’s treatment of gay men and women is being criticized internationally. Manifesta 10 is to be held in St. Petersburg from June 28 to Oct. 31, 2014, with activities centered in the restored contemporary art wing of the State Hermitage, Russia’s most important museum, which is in the former Winter Palace of the czars. The museum will be celebrating its 250th anniversary, and Manifesta will be recognizing its 20th as a post-cold-war platform for cultural dialogue.

headline: Project in Moscow Loses Norman Foster
abstract: The British architect Norman Foster has resigned from a proposed expansion of the Pushkin Museum of Fine Arts in Moscow.
lead_paragraph: The British architect Norman Foster has resigned from a proposed expansion of the Pushkin Museum of Fine Arts in Moscow. The plan was to expand and modernize the 101-year-old institution and had an estimated cost of $670 million. The project was approved by the Russian government in 2009, but it stalled over disputes between Russian officials and preservationists, according to The Art Newspaper. The architecture firm Foster & Partners released a statement last week that said Mr. Foster, above, had sent a resignation letter in June to Irina Antonova, the former director of the Pushkin. “Foster & Partners took this action because the museum, for the last three years, has not involved us in the development of the project, which was being carried out by others,” the statement said. Ms. Antonova resigned in July as museum director, a post she held for more than 50 years. She was said to have supported Mr. Foster’s involvement.

headline: Mark Itabashi Wins Fishbein Trophy in Atlanta
abstract: The Fishbein Trophy is presented to the player who wins the most master points at the Summer North American Championships.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The Fishbein Trophy is presented to the player who wins the most master points at the Summer North American Championships. This year’s was awarded to Mark Itabashi of Murrieta, Calif. He won two major national championships, the von Zedtwitz Life Master Pairs and the Truscott/United States Playing Card Senior Swiss Teams to finish 45.69 points head of Jacek Kalita and Michal Nowosadzki from Poland.

headline: Azarenka Upsets Williams; Nadal Tops Isner for Title
abstract: Serena Williams fell to Victoria Azarenka in the women’s final of the Western & Southern Open, and Rafael Nadal beat John Isner to win the event for the first time.
lead_paragraph: MASON, Ohio — Losses have been rare in this chapter of Serena Williams’s career: her established power is now paired with consistency, making her perhaps an even more reliable favorite.

headline: A Summer of Troubles Saps India’s Sense of Confidence
keywords: ['Indian Rupee (Currency)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: A falling stock market and currency, and an explosion aboard a submarine, have contributed to doubts about India’s status as a dominant powerhouse of Asia.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — For the last 10 years, India seemed poised to take its place alongside China as one of the dominant economic and strategic powerhouses of Asia. Its economy was surging, its military was strengthening, and its leaders were striding across the world stage.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week of Aug. 19
abstract: Data to be released this week includes minutes from the Federal Reserve’s meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee in July, and the National Association of Realtors sales of existing homes for July.
lead_paragraph: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released this week includes minutes from the Federal Reserve’s meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee in July, and the National Association of Realtors sales of existing homes for July (Wednesday); the Conference Board’s index of leading indicators and the Labor Department’s initial weekly jobless claims (Thursday); and the Commerce Department’s new home sales for July (Friday).

headline: Death Row Improvises, Lacking Lethal Mix
abstract: States are scrambling to replace the drugs used for executions, raising fresh questions about how the death penalty will be carried out.
lead_paragraph: The decision by the Missouri Supreme Court to allow propofol, the same powerful anesthetic that caused the death of Michael Jackson, to be used in executions — coming at a time when Texas, Ohio, Arkansas and other states are scrambling to come up with a new drug for their own lethal injections — is raising new questions about how the death penalty will be carried out.

headline: Top Presidential Candidates Barred From Election in Madagascar
abstract: An electoral court has removed the president, the wife of his longtime rival and a former president from its list of candidates, officials said.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — A court in Madagascar has removed several prominent political leaders from a list of presidential candidates eligible to run in the country’s election, scheduled for Friday, which many in the region hope will settle the island nation’s long-running political crisis.

headline: Braced to Remake Itself, Detroit First Awaits Challenges to Bankruptcy Eligibility
abstract: Unions, creditors and retirees are expected to file formal objections to the city’s eligibility, setting the stage for a legal fight over whether the city should be allowed to proceed.
lead_paragraph: Before Detroit can start remaking itself in bankruptcy court, there is a basic question that stands in its way: Does it even qualify?

headline: Spanish Fishermen Protest Restrictions Off Gibraltar
abstract: An artificial reef made of concrete is the latest sore point in British-Spanish relations.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — About 40 Spanish fishing boats confronted British police vessels on Sunday in a dispute over access to the waters off Gibraltar, a British territory at the tip of the Iberian Peninsula that has long been a political sore point between Spain and Britain.

headline: Stringer’s Claim of ‘Money Laundering’ by Spitzer Starts a Legal Debate
abstract: Scott M. Stringer has made the accusation against Eliot Spitzer, his rival in the Democratic primary for city comptroller, but legal experts say he didn’t misuse funds to pay for prostitutes.
lead_paragraph: Among the accusations that political candidates sling at one another during debates, “money laundering” does not usually come up.

headline: Mets Get Glimpse of Bright Future and Dim Present
abstract: The Mets’ ace, Matt Harvey, threw six strong innings in teaming with the catching prospect Travis d’Arnaud for the first time, but the end result was a loss in San Diego.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Matt Harvey, the Mets’ ace, and Travis d’Arnaud, the organization’s promising young catcher, played together for the first time Sunday afternoon during the Mets’ 4-3 loss to the San Diego Padres, doing their small part to stoke hope for the club’s outlook.

headline: Feminists Ask for Protection After Attack in Ukraine
abstract: Two leaders of Femen, the women’s rights group known for staging bare-breasted political protests, were assaulted while on vacation in the Black Sea port city of Odessa.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Leaders of Femen, the Ukrainian women’s rights group known for staging bare-breasted political protests, demanded government protection on Sunday after two of them and a male associate were assaulted while on vacation in the Black Sea port city of Odessa.

headline: A Call for Aid, Not Laws, to Help Women in Italy
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Domestic Violence', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Attacks in the wake of an announcement of measures to counter domestic abuse have bolstered criticism from some who say stiffer penalties alone are not enough to protect women.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Responding to the persistent problem of violence against women, Prime Minister Enrico Letta this month announced “very harsh, very tough” measures to counter domestic abuse and what he called “femicide,” the killing of women because they are women, often at the hands of current or former husbands or boyfriends.

headline: Again Away From Delaware, but Finally at Home
abstract: Elena Delle Donne once needed to find herself, and she did. Now she has the Chicago Sky in line for their first W.N.B.A. playoff berth in their eight-year history.
lead_paragraph: ROSEMONT, Ill. — Chicago trailed the Minnesota Lynx by 3 points late in the fourth quarter on Aug. 11. The game clock ticked under 10 seconds. Elena Delle Donne, a 6-foot-5 do-it-all rookie for the Sky, rose and fired a 3-point shot over two pairs of outstretched hands. Swish.

headline: McCain Takes His Work Home to Arizona, Promoting an Immigration Bill
abstract: In the state that is at the center of the fight against illegal immigration, Senator John McCain’s campaign for an overhaul faces an uphill battle.
lead_paragraph: TUCSON — For Senator John McCain, the Congressional summer recess has turned into a race against the clock, and against other Republicans. As the most senior member of the bipartisan Senate group that drafted the omnibus immigration bill pending in the House, he has spent his days prodding constituents to pressure Arizona’s Congressional delegation to support it.

headline: U.N. Team Arrives in Syria to Assess Possible Chemical Arms Use
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: President Bashar al-Assad and rebels seeking to oust him have accused each other of deploying chemical weapons.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A United Nations team arrived in Damascus on Sunday to begin a long-awaited investigation into the alleged use of chemical weapons in the civil war in Syria.

headline: Doctors Who Profit From Radiation Prescribe It More Often, Study Finds
abstract: The Government Accountability Office found that many doctors who recommended a common prostate cancer therapy had financial relationships with treatment providers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Doctors who have a financial interest in radiation treatment centers are much more likely to prescribe such treatments for patients with prostate cancer, Congressional investigators say in a new report.

headline: Second Act for the Temple of the Stars
abstract: A faded Los Angeles synagogue, built by Hollywood moguls on the eve of the Depression, is regaining its splendor with a dazzling $150 million reconstruction.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It was known as the Temple of the Stars: a soaring sanctuary capped by a 100-foot-wide Byzantine dome, built by Hollywood moguls on the eve of the Depression and splashed with the kind of pizazz one might expect at a movie palace rather than a synagogue.

headline: An Afghan Poet Shapes Metal and Hard Words
abstract: Many Afghans who have grown cynical after years of war have found a voice in a sharp-tongued poet who fixes trucks by day and writes by night.
lead_paragraph: KHOST, Afghanistan — The poet guided a strip of sheet metal into the ancient steel clippers, cutting shimmering triangles that fell with a dull clang on the shop floor.

headline: David Howard, Revered Teacher of Dancers, Dies at 76
abstract: Mr. Howard’s school in New York was frequented by the likes of Gelsey Kirkland, Patricia McBride and Mikhail Baryshnikov.
lead_paragraph: David Howard, who for nearly half a century was one of the most sought-after ballet teachers in the United States and far beyond, with a student roster that included Gelsey Kirkland, Patricia McBride and Mikhail Baryshnikov, died on Aug. 11 in Manhattan. He was 76.

headline: Al Jazeera America Promises a More Sober Look at the News
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Cable Television', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Television']
abstract: When the cable news channel begins broadcasting on Tuesday, “there will be less opinion, less yelling and fewer celebrity sightings,” its chief says.
lead_paragraph: Fourteen hours of straight news every day. Hard-hitting documentaries. Correspondents in oft-overlooked corners of the country. And fewer commercials than any other news channel.

headline: The Core of ‘Mind and Cosmos’
abstract: Why the theory of evolution, if it is to explain the existence of conscious life, must become more than just a physical theory.
lead_paragraph: This is a brief statement of positions defended more fully in my book “Mind and Cosmos: Why the Materialist Neo-Darwinian Conception of Nature Is Almost Certainly False,” which was published by Oxford University Press last year. Since then the book has attracted a good deal of critical attention, which is not surprising, given the entrenchment of the world view that it attacks. It seemed useful to offer a short summary of the central argument.

headline: Learn to Talk in Beggars’ Cant
keywords: ['Language and Languages', 'Cryptography, Codes and Ciphers', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Privacy']
abstract: In a time when speech is subjected to unprecedented scrutiny, the safest way to express a subversive thought is to clothe it in unfamiliar garb.
lead_paragraph: RULERS have long kept certain powers hidden from their subjects. But this summer’s disclosures concerning the surveillance practices of the National Security Agency have made it clear that today’s freedom of expression comes at the price of a new power: the state’s ability to burrow ever deeper, by technological means, into the private language of ordinary citizens.

headline: Misrule of Law
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Political Prisoners']
abstract: Xu Zhiyong’s fight made him one of China’s best-known human rights advocates, and it has now landed him in prison.
lead_paragraph: XU ZHIYONG, a lawyer for the underprivileged, knew he risked his freedom by challenging the Chinese Communist Party to fulfill its vows to fight corruption and promote the rule of law.

headline: A Flawed Background-Check System
abstract: The F.B.I. needs to be held to a higher standard when reporting on criminal histories in work-related background checks.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission has rightly intensified scrutiny of the companies that provide the criminal background checks used by most firms and corporations to screen job applicants. In too many cases, the reports are out of date and incomplete, causing job seekers who may have been arrested but never charged — or who have had their cases expunged or even dismissed — to be unfairly locked out of the job market.

headline: Bangladesh’s Workers Deserve Better
keywords: ['Rana Plaza Building Collapse, Bangladesh (2013)', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Reparations', 'Editorials', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: The families of those killed in the building collapse are still waiting for adequate compensation from the government.
lead_paragraph: Four months after a building collapse killed more than 1,100 factory workers in Bangladesh, their families are still waiting for adequate — and in some cases, any — compensation. This is a shocking lapse by Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina and her government.

headline: Wanted: Another Green Mayor
abstract: Candidates for mayor should promise to extend Bloomberg’s environmental record.
lead_paragraph: New York has been a dirty, gritty city practically forever, but it has also had farsighted leaders who qualify as green visionaries, going back to the 19th century. They preserved valuable real estate as irreplaceable public parkland; dreamed up an astonishing system of aqueducts to carry clean mountain water, unpumped and unfiltered, to city taps; and built a walkable, ridable, electric-train metropolis generations before “smart growth” and “transit-oriented development” were buzzwords.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Winning combinations for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Graying Prisoners
abstract: Beyond a certain point, retribution shades into vengeance.
lead_paragraph: MORE and more United States prisons resemble nursing homes with bars, where the elderly and infirm eke out shrunken lives. Prison isn’t easy for anyone, but it is especially punishing for those afflicted by the burdens of old age. Yet the old and the very old make up the fastest-growing segment of the prison population.

headline: More Friction Between Yankees and Rodriguez
abstract: Brian Cashman called Alex Rodriguez a liar, and Randy Levine said he needed to “put up or shut up.” Rodriguez and his camp, meanwhile, were planning to file a formal grievance against the Yankees.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Feeling betrayed and disappointed by his star player, Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman sat in the visitors’ dugout at Fenway Park on Sunday, calling Alex Rodriguez a liar and saying he no longer trusted Rodriguez enough to discuss any substantive matters with him. Yet when Rodriguez is in the batter’s box, Cashman roots hard for him to succeed.

headline: Questions on the Dual Role of a Clinton Aide Persist
abstract: The State Department says it allowed Huma Abedin, former Representative Anthony D. Weiner’s wife, to consult for private clients because she had “irreplaceable” expertise.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When news surfaced in May that the State Department had approved an arrangement that allowed Huma Abedin, a top adviser to Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, to take on work for private clients, officials at the department described it as nothing unusual.

headline: One Reform, Indivisible
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In looking at Obamacare, Republicans trip over the three-legged stool.
lead_paragraph: Recent political reporting suggests that Republican leaders are in a state of high anxiety, trapped between an angry base that still views Obamacare as the moral equivalent of slavery and the reality that health reform is the law of the land and is going to happen.

abstract: The BlueGreen Alliance says repairing and replacing pipelines will benefit the environment and American workers.

abstract: The mayoral candidates might learn a lesson or two from others’ blueprints, a reader says.

abstract: Physicians and others weigh in on the many hurdles in the path for immigrant practitioners.

headline: Israel Escalating Efforts to Shape Allies’ Strategy
abstract: An intensified campaign with foreign leaders and diplomats this week will press the case that there is no better hope to prevent further chaos.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel plans this week to intensify its diplomatic campaign urging Europe and the United States to support the military-backed government in Egypt despite its deadly crackdown on Islamist protesters, according to a senior Israeli official involved in the effort.

headline: Leaving Military Aid Intact, U.S. Takes Steps to Halt Economic Help to Egypt
abstract: The State Department has put aid on hold for economic programs that directly involve the Egyptian government, but not the much larger military aid on which Egypt’s generals depend.
lead_paragraph: CHILMARK, Mass. — The Obama administration has taken preliminary steps to withhold financial aid to the Egyptian government, officials said on Sunday, though it is curtailing economic assistance, not the much larger military aid on which Egypt’s generals depend.

headline: This Inning (First Pitch, Walk, Weather and Broadcast Booth) Is Brought to You by ...
abstract: A collection of on-air ads during one Yankees game.
lead_paragraph: A collection of on-air ads during one Yankees game.

headline: Fighting Crime With Pencil and Paper
abstract: Though police departments around the country are scaling back on creating composite drawings of suspects in an era of surveillance video, New York’s three-person Artist Unit stays busy.
lead_paragraph: It is one of the most recognizable tools of police investigations: the shaded and unsmiling face of a potential suspect on a flier. Yet around the nation, the police sketch can look like a dying art.

headline: Here’s the Pitch. But First, One From Our Sponsor.
abstract: What baseball game? With seemingly every type of play carrying a sponsor, radio announcers are increasingly reading ads that interrupt the action.
lead_paragraph: “Phelps painted the corner,” the Yankees radio announcer said, describing a strikeout pitch. “Painting at the corners is sponsored by CertaPro Painters. Because painting is personal.”

headline: Egypt Lashes Out at Foreign News Media’s Coverage
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: A correspondent for Al Jazeera is arrested while other journalists are scolded for failing to portray the crackdown in the government’s terms: as a war against violent terrorists.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Amid an international outcry over a bloody crackdown, the new government installed by Gen. Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi is putting concerted pressure on the only remaining news outlets in Egypt covering criticism of the violence: the foreign news media.

headline: Bare Trees Are a Lingering Sign of Hurricane Sandy’s High Toll
abstract: In storm-damaged neighborhoods throughout the city, trees, plants and shrubs have died or are dying by the thousands, the city parks department said.
lead_paragraph: When spring came, Ike Sinesi of Mill Island, Brooklyn, noticed something strange about the old weeping cedar on his front lawn. For the first time since it was planted, the powdery blue needles had not returned. His neighbors on this outcropping of land, surrounded on three sides by inlets off Jamaica Bay, saw similar signs.

headline: Jets’ Coples Is Sidelined Indefinitely
abstract: Linebacker Quinton Coples sustained a hairline fracture of his right ankle in Saturday night’s preseason game against Jacksonville.
lead_paragraph: The Jets lost a versatile and important piece of their defense when it was determined that outside linebacker Quinton Coples would be out indefinitely after sustaining a hairline fracture of his right ankle in Saturday night’s preseason game against Jacksonville.

headline: Pebble Beach Concours: 1934 Packard Wins Best of Show
abstract: Winner of Best of Show honors at the 2013 Pebble Beach Concours d’Élégance was a 1934 Packard with Dietrich bodywork.
lead_paragraph: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif. — A 1934 Packard 1108 Twelve Dietrich Convertible Victoria that spent much of its life in Puerto Rico — painted a garish red and orange and thrashed about as a taxi — was named Best of Show on Sunday at the Concours d’Élégance here.

headline: Leaving His Mark on the City’s Courts
abstract: Robert Garcia’s obsession has not faded in his years of playing in and organizing games on city park courts.
lead_paragraph: Life was no game for Robert Garcia in early 1987. He had just been cut from Wesleyan’s basketball squad — for the third time. Come spring break, he headed home and went straight to Goat Park at Amsterdam Avenue and 99th Street, where he had always practiced and studied hoops with fierce dedication. He was not tall or fast, but he was on fire.

headline: Drug War Apparently Has Mexican President’s Attention
abstract: President Enrique Peña Nieto has overseen the capture of two top drug bosses, suggesting he is no longer quite so opposed to the American-led strategy of taking down cartel kingpins.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Even before he took office in December, Mexico’s president, Enrique Peña Nieto, made clear that he saw the drug war as his predecessor’s problem: a political liability best pushed aside to make room for his sunnier plans to overhaul the economy, education and energy.

headline: Poverty Group Appoints City Official as New Chief
abstract: The Metropolitan Council on Jewish Poverty named David M. Frankel, the city’s finance commissioner, as executive director to replace William E. Rapfogel, who was fired last week.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Council on Jewish Poverty, an influential social-services organization, is reaching into the Bloomberg administration for new leadership, one week after its longtime executive director was fired amid allegations of financial misconduct.

headline: Paced by a Cool Rookie, Europe Beats the U.S. and Keeps the Solheim Cup
abstract: Charley Hull, at 17 the youngest player in the event’s history, defeated Paula Creamer on Sunday to start the European team on its way.
lead_paragraph: PARKER, Colo. — Before the first ball was struck in the Solheim Cup, Suzann Pettersen of Norway was asked what the Europeans could do to hand the United States its first loss on home soil.

headline: Cruz and Baas Are Injured Early, and the Giants’ Night Doesn’t Get Much Better
abstract: Victor Cruz bruised his left heel, David Baas sprained a knee and Justin Tuck incurred a hamstring injury in a dreary preseason loss to Indianapolis at MetLife Stadium.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Preseason N.F.L. games are for knocking the rust off and for restoring the rhythm and coordination among teammates. The Giants accomplished some of those goals in a dreary 20-12 loss to the Indianapolis Colts on Sunday at MetLife Stadium.

headline: Some Insights in Verse from John Hollander
abstract: Excerpts from works by the poet John Hollander.
lead_paragraph: From “Helicon,” in “Visions From the Ramble”

headline: New York City's Transportation Challenges
abstract: Trains, bridges, bikes and pedestrians. Where should the next mayor start?

headline: For Apologists, a Confessional Phone Line Is Reborn
abstract: A Brooklyn artist has revived a service that records the secrets and yearnings of callers, which fell silent after the death of its creator.
lead_paragraph: Late one night in the fall of 1980, Allan Bridge started illicitly slapping up eye-catching posters around TriBeCa — then a rough-edged neighborhood where artists predominated — encouraging wrongdoers to “get your misdeeds off your chest!”

headline: Penelope Casas, Spanish Food Author, Dies at 70
abstract: The 1985 cookbook by Mrs. Casas was among the first to chronicle for American readers the culinary tradition of tapas bars.
lead_paragraph: Penelope Casas, a Greek-American writer from Queens who was an authority on the foods of Spain, and helped introduce Americans in the 1980s to a continental Spanish cuisine distinctly different from its Mexican and South American counterparts, died on Aug. 11 in Manhasset, on Long Island. She was 70. The cause was complications of treatment for leukemia, said her daughter, Elisa.

headline: U.S. Workers Are Grounded by Deep Cuts
abstract: Tangible examples of the resulting spending cuts abound five months after lawmakers failed to reach an agreement on how to reduce the nation’s debt.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Geological visits to monitor volcanoes in Alaska have been scaled back. The defense secretary is traveling to Afghanistan two times a year instead of the usual four. For the first time in nearly three decades, NASA pulled out of the National Space Symposium, in Colorado Springs, even though representatives from France, Germany and China all made the trip.

headline: War on the Core
abstract: The right-wing campaign to keep America stupid.
lead_paragraph: I respect, really I do, the efforts by political scientists and pundits to make sense of the current Republican Party. There is intellectual virtue in the search for historical antecedents and philosophical underpinnings.

headline: Not Really Made in China (or the United States)
keywords: ['Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: The value created by new patterns of international trade may go largely to companies rather than to consumers, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Folbre is professor emerita of economics at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

headline: Tested Recipes for Kitchen Safety
abstract: Modern kitchen appliances and gadgets offer many opportunities for injury.
lead_paragraph: Today’s kitchens easily supplant the bathroom as the home’s most dangerous room. While scalds and falls on tile can inflict serious harm in the bathroom, modern kitchen appliances and gadgets offer many more opportunities for injury. Even a seemingly simple kitchen task can result in a devastating injury.

headline: What’s on Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 5:10 P.M. (MoreMax) JANE EYRE (2011) Mia Wasikowska, above, portrays Charlotte Brontë’s beleaguered governess, in flight from her employer and soul mate, Edward Rochester (Michael Fassbender), in this adaptation of the novel, set at Thornfield Hall on the misty moors of England. Jamie Bell is St. John Rivers, the clergyman who helps nurse Jane back to health; Judi Dench, the gossipy housekeeper; Sally Hawkins, the nasty aunt; and Imogen Poots, the rich girl who almost derails Jane’s chances at love. “This ‘Jane Eyre,’ energetically directed by Cary Joji Fukunaga (‘Sin Nombre’) from a smart, trim script by Moira Buffini (‘Tamara Drewe’), is a splendid example of how to tackle the daunting duty of turning a beloved work of classic literature into a movie,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “Neither a radical updating nor a stiff exercise in middlebrow cultural respectability, Mr. Fukunaga’s film tells its venerable tale with lively vigor and an astute sense of emotional detail.”

headline: Quotation of the Day for Monday, August 19
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, August 19
lead_paragraph: “A poet’s job is not to write about love. A poet’s job is not to write about flowers. A poet must write about the plight and pain of the people.”

headline: Hit by Pitch, Rodriguez Recovers, as Do Yanks
abstract: Alex Rodriguez’s home run started a comeback in a highly contentious and emotional game as the Yankees moved to seven and a half games back of the Red Sox in the American League East.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Alex Rodriguez has been at odds with Major League Baseball and the Yankees’ front office for weeks, but until Sunday night his battles were waged strictly off the field. Then came Ryan Dempster, who injected himself into the narrative with a 92-mile-per-hour fastball to Rodriguez’s rib cage.

headline: Target Practice With Mr. Lincoln
abstract: Why was the president shooting guns on the Washington Mall?
lead_paragraph: The old saying “You can take the boy out of the country…” was well suited to Abraham Lincoln. His log cabin “rail splitter” provenance is well known, and it helped make him hugely popular with average voters hungry for a new political hero. Despite his lack of family pedigree, fortune or schooling, Lincoln made a career of being underestimated, overcompensating with a brilliant, active intellect. The farmboy turned president especially loved innovations and inventions. He is the only American president to win a patent – No. 6,469, issued in May 1849 for a “Method of Buoying Vessels Over Shoals.”

But I’m very much in sympathy with their underlying view about the asymmetry between booms and busts; the question is why, exactly, it feels right.

lead_paragraph: An analysis of water, sediment and seafood samples taken in 2010 during and after the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico has found higher contamination levels in some cases than previous studies by federal agencies did, casting doubt on some of the earlier sampling methods.

headline: Tyne Daly to Star in New Terrence McNally Play on Broadway
abstract: Ms. Daly will play a mother who visits her dead son’s former lover in Mr. McNally’s new play “Mothers and Sons.”
lead_paragraph: The Tony and Emmy Award-winning actress Tyne Daly (“Gypsy”) will return to Broadway in the spring of 2014 to star in “Mothers and Sons,” a new play by the Tony Award-winning playwright Terrence McNally (“Love! Valour! Compassion!”). Sheryl Kaller, who in June directed the show’s premiere at the Bucks County Playhouse in New Hope, Pa., will reprise her duties for Broadway. Additional casting, run dates and a theater are to be announced.

headline: Prosecutors Are Contemplating More Arrests in $80 Million Art Fraud Case
abstract: More arrests are expected in the investigation into one of the most audacious art frauds in recent memory, a federal prosecutor told a judge on Monday.
lead_paragraph: More arrests are expected in the investigation into one of the most audacious art frauds in recent memory, a federal prosecutor handling the case against an obscure art dealer charged in the case told a judge on Monday. The prosecutor and the dealer’s lawyer also said they expected the case to be resolved soon.
