lead_paragraph: Answer the 10 questions below to see what you know about the people and events that made news this week.

headline: Another Shake-Up at NPR as Chief Steps Down
abstract: The departure of Gary E. Knell was unwelcome news at NPR, which experienced a series of leadership shake-ups before his arrival in 2011.
lead_paragraph: NPR, which has suffered a succession of leadership changes over the better part of a decade, needs a new chief executive again.

headline: MSNBC Brings ‘The Ed Show’ Back to Weekday Lineup
abstract: Only five months after he was switched to weekends, Ed Schultz will rejoin the network’s weekday lineup at 5 p.m.
lead_paragraph: After a slide in its prime-time ratings in recent months, MSNBC made a move on Monday to shore up the hours leading into prime time. The network is bringing back Ed Schultz, once its 8 p.m. anchor, to take over the 5 p.m. weekday slot now occupied by “Hardball.”

headline: The Wild Past of Domestic Cats
abstract: Domestic cats’ genetic profiles resemble those of the Near Eastern wildcat, and researchers theorize that domestication occurred in a region where there was a need for rodent control.
lead_paragraph: Q. What do scientists think is the ancestry of domestic cats?

headline: Chris Brown Cancels Concerts After Probation Ruling
abstract: Canada’s Energy Rush festival, which Mr. Brown was headlining, will be postponed until next year.
lead_paragraph: The singer Chris Brown has canceled four scheduled appearances in Canada, the CBC reported. Mr. Brown was to be the headliner at the Energy Rush festival, with stops in Halifax, Toronto, Saint John and Winnipeg. In a statement, Stephen Tobin, owner of Drop Entertainment Group, which is producing the events, said the decision was made “in light of the performer’s recent personal and health-related issues.”

headline: Climate Panel Cites Near Certainty on Warming
abstract: The panel found that human activity is almost certainly behind most temperature increases in recent decades.
lead_paragraph: An international panel of scientists has found with near certainty that human activity is the cause of most of the temperature increases of recent decades, and warns that sea levels could conceivably rise by more than three feet by the end of the century if emissions continue at a runaway pace.

headline: Dressing Up the Loaner Jacket
abstract: In this age of ever-more-casual dining, the jacket requirement for men has fallen by the wayside. But the holdouts loan out more coats than ever.
lead_paragraph: It was a humid day, but every man seated in the Grill Room of the Four Seasons was wearing a jacket.

headline: Comptroller Race Leaves Paterson Tongue-Tied
abstract: Former Gov. David A. Paterson endorsed Scott M. Stringer for comptroller, but Eliot Spitzer’s entry has complicated the situation for him.
lead_paragraph: Former Gov. David A. Paterson was, abnormally, at a loss for words.

headline: Christy Turlington Burns and Citizens of Humanity Promote Maternal Health
abstract: The model continues her crusade to raise awareness about women’s health issues by participating in the denim brand’s video series about inspirational figures.
lead_paragraph: The latest addition to “Just Like You,” a video series from the socially conscious denim brand Citizens of Humanity that highlights influential people doing inspirational things, is a two-minute spot by Christy Turlington Burns about her three-year-old women’s health nonprofit Every Mother Counts. The goal of the organization is to help “people understand that pregnancy and childbirth, even though it’s a joyous experience for so many women, really is a risky endeavor for millions of other women,” according to Erin Thornton, its executive director, who happens to be expecting right now herself. “To this day, hundreds of thousands of women will die in pregnancy and childbirth, but 90 percent of those could be prevented just with basic, simple access to health care.”

headline: Rio de Janeiro Makes Woody Allen an Offer
abstract: The mayor of the Brazilian city is offering to fully finance a Woody Allen film, if production takes place there.
lead_paragraph: Apparently Rio de Janeiro is not satisfied with being chosen as the site of the 2016 Summer Olympics and the host of the championship game of next year’s World Cup of soccer. Now Brazil’s most effervescent city also wants Woody Allen to make a movie there.

headline: Crowdsourcing, for the Birds
abstract: The online network eBird uses data turned in by tens of thousands of citizen scientists to create what may be the first real-time view of the world’s bird populations.
lead_paragraph: HELENA, Mont. — On a warm morning not long ago on the shore of a small prairie lake outside this state capital, Bob Martinka trained his spotting scope on a towering cottonwood tree heavy with blue heron nests. He counted a dozen of the tall, graceful birds and got out his smartphone, not to make a call but to type the number of birds and the species into an app that sent the information to researchers in New York.

headline: China Takes Aim at Western Ideas

lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Communist Party cadres have filled meeting halls around China to hear a somber, secretive warning issued by senior leaders. Power could escape their grip, they have been told, unless the party eradicates seven subversive currents coursing through Chinese society.

lead_paragraph: The Detroit Institute of Arts, whose world-class art collection has become a potential target for the city’s creditors in Detroit’s federal bankruptcy case, announced on Monday that it would not file an objection in court to the city’s eligibility for relief under Chapter 9. Monday was the deadline for objections to the city seeking bankruptcy protection.

headline: Being Printed, Living Tissue
abstract: At labs around the world, researchers have been experimenting with bioprinting, but there are many formidable obstacles to overcome.
lead_paragraph: At labs around the world, researchers have been experimenting with bioprinting, but there are many formidable obstacles to overcome.

headline: A Trophy Owner Also Familiar With Turmoil
abstract: While Jeff Bezos’s purchase of The Washington Post may be the product of trophy hunting, he has demonstrated the skills needed to navigate tumultuous environments.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Bezos’s purchase of The Washington Post raises the possibility that he acquired the paper as a trophy to celebrate his success as the founder and chief executive of Amazon.com. The acquisition comes after the purchase of The Boston Globe by John W. Henry, the owner of the Boston Red Sox and a trading firm billionaire. The purchases are part of a broader trend toward private ownership of media companies.

headline: Software That Exposes Faked Photos
abstract: Using algorithms to detect suspicious shadows, computer scientists say their software can sniff out doctored images.
lead_paragraph: Using algorithms designed to sniff out suspicious shadows, computer scientists from Dartmouth and the University of California, Berkeley, say they have developed software that can reliably detect fake or altered photos.

headline: New York Fringe Festival Report: ‘The Unfortunates’
abstract: This one-woman show imagines the life of a prostitute who ends up a victim of Jack the Ripper.
lead_paragraph: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat through the festival’s close on Aug. 25. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.

headline: Indoor Tanning Remains Popular, Despite Risks
abstract: Despite warnings about skin cancer, a study indicated that 30 percent of white female high school students had used a tanning bed in the previous year.
lead_paragraph: Despite warnings about skin cancer, about a third of the young and adult white women in a new study said they used tanning beds, and many were using them frequently. Tanning beds are widely believed to have played a large role in the increasing rates of skin cancer in recent decades. The most serious type, melanoma, has risen sharply among young white women in particular.

headline: Egyptians Share Gruesome Images of Dead Prisoners and Soldiers
abstract: The Egyptian government has acknowledged killing 36 Islamists in its custody on Sunday, and an attack by suspected militants in the Sinai peninsula left at least 24 police officers dead.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, 5:38 p.m. | As our colleagues David Kirkpatrick and Rod Nordland report from Cairo, Egypt has seen two grisly mass killings in the last 24 hours. The government has acknowledged killing 36 Islamist prisoners in its custody under circumstances that remain unclear, and an attack by suspected militants in a remote corner of the Sinai peninsula left at least 24 police officers dead and 3 injured.

headline: A Dry Pipeline for Psychiatric Drugs
abstract: With rare exceptions, it is hard to think of a single truly novel psychotropic drug that has emerged in the last 30 years.
lead_paragraph: Fully 1 in 5 Americans take at least one psychiatric medication. Yet when it comes to mental health, we are facing a crisis in drug innovation.

headline: At Home at Animal Farm: An Orwell Collection
abstract: A new collection of George Orwell’s letters shows the intimate side of a prescient literary light.
lead_paragraph: In a life that was relatively brief but exceedingly active, George Orwell was, among other things, a police officer in Burma, a dishwasher in France, a tramp in England, a combatant in Spain, a war correspondent in Germany and a farmer in the Hebrides. Like many people of his era — he was born in 1903 and died in 1950 — he was also a prolific letter writer, and a particularly captivating and thoughtful one at that, thanks partly to the wealth of experience he had acquired.

headline: Only Essential Travelers Remain, Warily, in Egypt

headline: Pill Can Prevent Fatal TB in H.I.V. Patients
abstract: A daily pill of the drug isoniazid can often fend off fatal tuberculosis in people with H.I.V., according to a large new study.
lead_paragraph: An inexpensive daily pill can often fend off a lethal bout of tuberculosis in people with H.I.V., according to a large new study.

headline: European Union Sets Emergency Session on Suspending Aid to Egypt
abstract: The Europeans have struggled to negotiate a political solution in the continuing military crackdown.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — European Union foreign ministers will meet in an emergency session on Wednesday to discuss suspending aid to Egypt, but the continuing military crackdown there has been a devastating blow to European efforts to negotiate a political solution and fill a vacuum left by Washington.

headline: Progress in Quest for a Reusable Rocket, and Teleporting Data
keywords: ['Space and Astronomy', 'Rocket Science and Propulsion', 'Global Warming', 'Black Holes (Space)', 'Private Spaceflight', 'Kepler Space Telescope', 'Science and Technology', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Recent developments in health and science news. Also this week: a rotating star provides clues about a black hole and an evolution experiment suggests a path for disease research.
lead_paragraph: Our theme this week is things that move in unexpected ways. In Texas, a rocket flew 800 feet in the air, then traveled sideways for 300 feet before returning to Earth. Elsewhere, two teams of researchers devised a method for teleporting small bits of information. And a wounded $600 million telescope is like a shopping cart with a broken wheel, says NASA. Onward and upward.

headline: G.O.P. Purity Control

lead_paragraph: After losing the 2012 election the G.O.P. engaged in a bit of soul-searching, and talked publicly about changing their image, if not their policies. That phase is definitively over. The Republicans are back to denouncing every utterance that strays from an absolutely rigid right-wing orthodoxy, and even ones that really don’t.

headline: At Sentencing Hearing, Lawyers for Manning Urge Leniency

lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md. — Pfc. Bradley Manning’s defense lawyers on Monday made a last-minute personal plea to the military judge hearing his court-martial, asking her to be lenient in sentencing and to allow Private Manning a chance to rehabilitate himself. A prosecutor in the case urged a 60-year sentence for disclosing hundreds of thousands of documents to WikiLeaks.

lead_paragraph: After a dispute over terms that stretched for most of the year, Simon & Schuster and Barnes & Noble said in a joint statement on Monday that they had “resolved their outstanding business issues.” Both parties “look forward to promoting great books by Simon & Schuster authors,” they said.

headline: Thompson Tries to Turn Caribbean Ties Into Votes

headline: 4 Officials Convicted of Negligence Over Russia Flooding
abstract: The officials failed to alert residents amid a deluge of rain last summer that left more than 170 people dead, a judge found.

The verdict came as Russia was coping with disastrous flooding again, this time in the country’s Far East.

headline: Listen Up | All Is Not Lost for the Civil Wars
abstract: The Nashville duo’s chart-topping second album came out last week amid rumors of their breakup. This exclusive behind-the-scenes video shows a happier time, and offers hope for the future.
lead_paragraph: The Civil Wars’ self-titled sophomore album, which was No. 1 on the Billboard 200 chart last week, tells the story of a duo in turmoil. Recorded earlier this year amid building tension between the bandmates Joy Williams and John Paul White (they abruptly halted a European tour last November because of “internal discord and irreconcilable differences of ambition”), the album is rife with allusions to heartache and regret, providing subtext for the two singer-songwriters’ own conflict.

headline: Harley-Davidson Unveils Project Rushmore Bikes

lead_paragraph: AFTER I finished interviewing roughly 200 women and men about their successes, failures and regrets for a book I was writing, the one thing I repeatedly heard was that most people wished they had traveled more.

headline: A Newcomer Asks Questions and Sketches Some Fresh Answers
abstract: Two seriously experimental pieces by Troy Schumacher and BalletCollective were the real discoveries at the Ballet v6.0 festival at the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: In “The Impulse Wants Company,” a new ballet by Troy Schumacher, the young dancer Harrison Coll, in profile, steps into arabesque. One arm stretches forward into space, one leg continues the line behind him — whereupon first his colleague Kaitlyn Gilliland, tall and mature, goes to support him, keeping him in that position. Next, other companions cluster around, partnering him, sharing and amplifying the gesture. This image coalesces before our eyes like a rapid coral formation. It’s a collective moment, and the company that performs it is called BalletCollective.

lead_paragraph: Auditors performed complete and correct audits of at least three brokerage firms last year, the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board said Monday.

headline: The Results of the Baby-Llama Naming Contest
abstract: Pastiche, Cusco and Camille are the winning choices.
lead_paragraph: When you’ve raised as many llamas as Richard Snyder has — hundreds, over several decades — naming the new babies can be a chore. This year Mr. Snyder, who was featured in a recent article about llama enthusiasts, invited Times readers to help name the three crias, or baby llamas, born on his farm in Milford, Pa., in May. There were two males and a female, and their parents’ names were given as inspiration.

headline: In Rome, a Melodic Nero Burns With Love
abstract: Monteverdi’s final opera, “L’Incoronazione di Poppea,” is a story of romantic intrigue in Nero’s court.
lead_paragraph: It did not take long for the medium of opera, as it coalesced in Italy in the first half of the 17th century, to discover the heady combination of glorious music put to the service of venality and vice. Monteverdi, a founding father, certainly had it down by the time of his final opera, “L’Incoronazione di Poppea,” which appeared in Venice in 1643.

lead_paragraph: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts said on Monday that it had hired a former chairman and chief executive of the Willis Group as a senior adviser, adding another veteran corporate boss to its roster of outside experts.

headline: Still Tough Mothers, if a Bit Warmer
abstract: In the Berkshires, Olympia Dukakis in “Mother Courage,” and Tina Packer in “The Beauty Queen of Leenane” soften harsh and mean maternal instincts.
lead_paragraph: LENOX, Mass. — Though they’re marginal improvements on Mrs. Bates, the lady who sent little Norman around the bend in “Psycho,” these are not mothers you could bring anyone home to meet. One is a conniving, endlessly itinerant businesswoman so hard-bitten that she’ll haggle over the price of her child’s life.

headline: A Surplus of Good TV? Try Depression Economics
abstract: A Television Adjustment Act would stop executives from offering more quality programming than viewers can handle.
lead_paragraph: Eighty years ago, President Franklin D. Roosevelt taught us what to do when confronted by a surplus of something: Pay people not to make any more of it. And what we have a surplus of right now is good television.

headline: In Fashion | Candylike Pastel Coats to Brighten Up Fall

lead_paragraph: Fall’s sugary pastels — lavender, pistachio, pale rose, butter cream — are a romantic respite from so much hard-working black and white.

headline: Rome’s Start to Architectural Hubris
abstract: In excavations outside Rome, at the site of the city-state Gabii, archaeologists think they are catching a glimpse of Roman tastes in monumental architecture 300 years before the Colosseum.
lead_paragraph: Granted that Rome was not built in a day, the unresolved question among scholars has been just how long did it take. How early, before Julius Caesar came, saw and conquered, did Romans begin adopting a monumental architecture reflecting the grandeur of their ambitions?

headline: Stravinsky’s Many Rites of Passage Are Distilled
abstract: The second weekend of the Bard Music Festival picked up chronologically where the first left off: Stravinsky asserting his place in Paris between the world wars.
lead_paragraph: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. — While Igor Stravinsky successfully cultivated the air of a rootless cosmopolitan during his long stretch as the 20th century’s most renowned composer, modern scholarship has firmly established his links to a broader tradition of Russian music and the debt many of his works owe to his culture and forebears. But with that facet of his multifarious career having been summarily addressed during the first weekend of this year’s Bard Music Festival, there was plenty more to cover during three more jam-packed days and nights.

headline: Even Ocean Dwellers Decorate for Company
abstract: For years, scientists were baffled by large circular patterns on the ocean floor. These “crop circles” of the ocean floor are created by male puffer fish in order to attract females.
lead_paragraph: For years, scientists were baffled by large circular patterns on the ocean floor. These “crop circles” of the ocean floor are created by male puffer fish in order to attract females.

headline: A Daughter’s Visit Turns Into a Family Stress Test
abstract: In “Old Cats,” a troubled daughter’s strained relationship with her elderly mother plays out in a Chilean apartment.
lead_paragraph: “Old Cats” takes place almost entirely in an apartment in Santiago, Chile, occupied by Isadora (Bélgica Castro); her second husband, Enrique (Alejandro Sieveking); and the felines of the title, a pair of roly-poly tabbies described by Isadora as “the kings of the house.” The enclosed space and the age of the couple — as well as Isadora’s increasingly frequent lapses of lucidity — may remind you, at first, of “Amour,” Michael Haneke’s unsparing end-of-life excursion. But “Old Cats,” written and directed by Sebastián Silva and Pedro Peirano (originally released in Chile in 2010, long before “Amour”), is less concerned with the austere reality of death than with the stress and mess of living.

headline: Where Words Mean as Much as Objects
keywords: ['Museums', 'APACHE INDIANS', 'Native Americans', 'Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: Apache tribes will be happy to take back their artifacts from the American Museum of Natural History. Just call them sacred relics.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, the American Museum of Natural History agreed to return to the Apaches 77 objects from its collection, including headwear, feathers, bows and arrows, medicine rings and satchels containing crystals and charms.

headline: Christie Signs Bill Outlawing a Gay ‘Cure’
keywords: ['Homosexuality', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Law and Legislation', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey waited until the last minute to make a decision on the bill, which would have become law automatically if he had not taken action by Monday.
lead_paragraph: BELLEVILLE, N.J. — Gov. Chris Christie signed a bill Monday outlawing therapy that aims to convert gay children to heterosexuals, making New Jersey the second state to ban the controversial practice.

headline: Superchunk and Tedeschi Trucks Band Release Albums
abstract: “I Hate Music” is the latest work from the longtime indie rockers Superchunk, while “Made Up Mind” is just the second studio album from the blues jamsters in the Tedeschi Trucks Band.
lead_paragraph: SUPERCHUNK

headline: Petition Wants Met Gala Dedicated to Gay Rights
abstract: An online petition calls for the Metropolitan Opera’s Russian-theme gala, led by two supporters of President Vladimir V. Putin, to be dedicated to gay rights.
lead_paragraph: The furor over Russia’s new law placing restrictions on the discussion of homosexuality has spread to the world of classical music, with some opera fans calling on the Metropolitan Opera to dedicate its opening-night gala performance of Tchaikovsky’s “Eugene Onegin” to the support of gay people.

headline: Pebble Beach Weekend: Galpin Unveils 1,024-Horsepower Ford GTR1
abstract: Powered by a twin-turbocharged 5.4-liter V-8, the GTR1 launches to 100 m.p.h. in just over six seconds.
lead_paragraph: CARMEL VALLEY, Calif. — Road-testing began Sunday for the Galpin Ford GTR1 – a modern-day interpretation of the classic Ford GT40 – that was revealed on Friday at the Quail Motorsports Gathering.

headline: Mets Give Rookie Catcher an Extended Stay
abstract: Dillon Gee topped the Twins in a makeup game from April 14, and Travis d’Arnaud learned the Mets plan to keep him on the major league roster for the rest of the season.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Shortly after learning the Mets planned to keep him for the rest of the season, the rookie catcher Travis d’Arnaud returned to his locker and found the veteran reliever LaTroy Hawkins standing in front of it talking to a reporter. Protocol and humility are vital for someone with only three days in the major leagues, so d’Arnaud, 24, asked Hawkins if he could slip by, careful not to offend his 40-year-old teammate.

headline: Web Site Down? How Dare You!
keywords: ['Computer Network Outages', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media']
abstract: Restraint was not universally exercised on Monday, when people ran to social media to voice outrage about a rare Amazon service hiccup.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — On occasion, I visit a small store in my neighborhood only to find a sign saying the store is closed for an hour or so. It’s mildly irritating, but it has never occurred to me that those moments are worth freaking out over.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Zuckerberg’s Facebook Page Hacked and McAfee’s Regrets
abstract: The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items. Monday’s selections include an attack on Mark Zuckerberg’s Facebook page to focus attention on privacy and security issues. Plus, McAfee, the Internet security firm, expressed concern over trying to quantify the total financial loss of cybercrime.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items. Earlier in the afternoon, Amazon.com went down. It came, as Nick Wingfield noted, after a week in which several of the Internet’s biggest companies went dark for a time.

headline: Prime Minister of Pakistan Open to Talks With Taliban
abstract: In his first televised policy speech since taking office, Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif also maintained the option of military action against militants.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — In his first televised policy speech to the country since assuming office in June, Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif on Monday hinted at his government’s inclination to hold talks with Taliban militants even while maintaining the option of military action against them.

headline: Germany: Police Foil Hostage Taker
abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel canceled a campaign appearance in the Bavarian town of Ingolstadt after a man armed with a knife and replica of a pistol took three hostages in the local city hall.
lead_paragraph: Chancellor Angela Merkel canceled a campaign appearance in the northern Bavarian town of Ingolstadt on Monday after a 24-year-old man armed with a knife and a realistic plastic replica of a pistol took three hostages in the local city hall. The police later stormed the building, freeing the hostages and wounding the suspect. It was unclear whether the episode had any connection with Ms. Merkel’s plans for an appearance in a nearby square. She was to proceed with a planned appearance in the nearby city of Regensburg later Monday. Ms. Merkel is seeking a third term in federal elections on Sept. 22. All three hostages were unharmed, said Günther Beck, a police spokesman. The suspect suffered a gunshot wound and was being treated by doctors, but he was expected to appear in a local court on Tuesday, Mr. Beck said.

headline: Seized Guns Offer Look at Pipeline From South
abstract: More than 250 weapons were recovered on their way into the city from North and South Carolina, which have looser firearms laws.
lead_paragraph: The guns often arrived by Chinatown bus, packed into patterned bags and destined for sale in a Brooklyn rap studio or in the backs of cars on the Lower East Side.

headline: Syria: Thousands Flee to Iraq
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: At least 29,000 Syrians have flooded into northern Iraq since Thursday, which the United Nations says is one of the largest cross-border migrations since the Syrian conflict began in 2011.
lead_paragraph: At least 29,000 Syrians have flooded into northern Iraq since Thursday, the United Nations refugee agency said Monday, calling it one of the largest cross-border migrations since the Syrian conflict began in 2011. Officials said 20,000 crossed over on Thursday alone. More than 1.9 million Syrians have already sought refuge in neighboring countries; more than 180,000 are now in Iraq.

headline: South Korea: U.S. Joins War Drills
abstract: South Korea and the United States began another round of military drills on Monday, but North Korea remained uncharacteristically silent.
lead_paragraph: South Korea and the United States began another round of military drills on Monday. In the past, North Korea denounced the drills as a rehearsal for an invasion, but on Tuesday its criticism was less harsh, which analysts said was a sign of the North’s interest in continuing diplomacy. The drills, which continue until Aug. 30, involve 30,000 American and 50,000 South Korean troops in computer-simulated war exercises.

headline: Prosecutor in Enron Case Expected to Be Named to Justice Dept. Post
abstract: The Justice Department is expected to name Leslie R. Caldwell, the former lead prosecutor in the Enron case, as the next head of its criminal division, according to people briefed on the decision.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department is expected to name Leslie R. Caldwell, the former lead prosecutor in the Enron case, as the next head of its criminal division, according to people briefed on the decision.

headline: At U.N., Labor Tensions Mar 10th Anniversary of Bombing
abstract: The commemoration of the bombing of the United Nations Baghdad offices was overshadowed by staff members who said internal labor practices had compromised their safety and security.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations commemorated the 10th anniversary of the single deadliest assault in the organization’s history on Monday, the bombing of its Baghdad offices that killed 22 people, with Secretary General Ban Ki-moon warning in a speech that since then “the attackers who target us have grown more sophisticated, more brazen and better armed.”

headline: Michigan: Many Object to Bankruptcy
abstract: About 100 objections to Detroit’s eligibility for bankruptcy were filed in federal court before a midnight deadline on Monday.
lead_paragraph: ﻿About 100 objections to Detroit’s eligibility for bankruptcy were filed in federal court before a midnight deadline on Monday. The challenges, most from individual city retirees or residents, contend that city officials did not prove insolvency or negotiate enough with creditors before seeking Chapter 9 protection last month. Unions also argued that the case should be dismissed because it will violate pension protections under the State Constitution. The state attorney general, Bill Schuette, who will defend pensioners in later bankruptcy proceedings, did not protest the city’s eligibility.

headline: As a Boom Slows, Peru Grows Uneasy
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Metals and Minerals', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: In a nation used to 6 percent annual expansion, something closer to 5 percent, which would be a reason for celebration elsewhere, is producing angst.
lead_paragraph: LIMA, Peru — From his office window, Henrik Kristensen, the chief executive of the company that runs Peru’s main port, can still look out at rows of newly arrived, shiny Kia automobiles from South Korea and shipping containers stacked four high, full of imported items like television sets and brand-name clothing bound for the growing number of malls that serve this country’s burgeoning middle class.

headline: Smith Feels Pressure as Sanchez Finds Comfort
abstract: Geno Smith knows that a good showing in Saturday’s game against the Giants is a critical factor in the Jets’ decision to choose him or Mark Sanchez as their starting quarterback.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — As much as Jets Coach Rex Ryan insists the quarterback competition is not over, the demeanor and words of the incumbent Mark Sanchez and the rookie Geno Smith on Monday appeared to hint at the more likely outcome.

headline: Obama Presses for Action on Bank Rules
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Administration officials and some lawmakers have expressed frustration that critical parts of President Obama’s financial overhaul, the Dodd-Frank act, remain unenforced.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama urged the nation’s top financial regulators on Monday to move faster on new rules for Wall Street, telling them in a private White House meeting that they must work to prevent a repeat of the 2008 financial crisis.

headline: Uncertainty Over a Palace of Parking
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Parking Garages and Lots', 'ARCHITECTURE']
abstract: In a country with 1.3 million recognized memorials, historically protected buildings and sites, the preservation of a sooty parking garage covered with graffiti is a tough sell.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The preservation of a sooty parking garage covered with graffiti is a tough sell in a city whose landmarks include fragments of the wall that for decades defined the cold war, a jagged church tower that stands as testament to the ravages of World War II and elegant Prussian palaces where German leaders host visiting dignitaries.

headline: Using U.S. Golf System to Help Defeat U.S.
abstract: The European team’s drubbing of the United States in the Solheim Cup was not considered a total disaster by the American team’s captain, Meg Mallon.
lead_paragraph: PARKER, Colo. — The Solheim Cup victory was another plume in what has become a tribal headdress for golfers from the other side of the Atlantic. A European team led by Charley Hull, an irrepressible 17-year-old from England, put the finishing touches on its record 18-10 drubbing of the Americans hours after another British teenager, Matthew Fitzpatrick, 18, became the first Englishman in more than a century to win the United States Amateur.

headline: Prime Lot, Empty for Years (Yes, This Is Manhattan)
abstract: The dormancy of a 6.4-acre parcel in Midtown Manhattan overlooking the East River is an enigmatic and confusing tale of ambition, infighting, personality conflicts and bad timing.
lead_paragraph: This hole in the ground is the length of three city blocks. It is a carpet of sand, weeds and prairie grass sloping down to the river, interrupted only by a low ridge of broken bedrock. Around it, a black chain-link fence catches the plastic cups, paper and other debris that roll along like tumbleweeds.

headline: Baas Is in Doubt for Giants’ Opener
abstract: The Giants’ center David Baas injured his knee during Sunday’s preseason loss to the Colts, and it could lead to a shake-up on the offensive line.
lead_paragraph: A knee injury to the Giants’ starting center, David Baas, will jeopardize his chances of being available for the team’s season-opening game Sept. 8, Giants Coach Tom Coughlin said Monday.

headline: Deaf Student, Denied Interpreter by Medical School, Draws Focus of Advocates
keywords: ['Deafness', 'Medical Schools', 'Disabilities', 'Translation and Interpreters', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: The case of a deaf medical student who was denied the use of an interpreter during his clinical training in Omaha, Neb., is to go to trial on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Speaking with the parents of a sick infant, Michael Argenyi, a medical student, could not understand why the child was hospitalized. During another clinical training session, he missed most of what a patient with a broken jaw was trying to convey about his condition.

headline: Egypt’s Media Cheers on Army Crackdown
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'News and News Media']
abstract: To justify a security crackdown, the Egyptian media has deployed the theme tune from “Rocky,” reworked anti-Obama conspiracy theories and even tossed in a reference to “Curb Your Enthusiasm.”
lead_paragraph: Updated, Tuesday, 5:32 p.m. | As my colleague David Kirkpatrick reports from Cairo, criticism of the deadly crackdown on Islamist protesters by security forces there has all but disappeared from the Egyptian media since channels that supported the Muslim Brotherhood were shut down last month.

headline: With a Little Help From My Friends
abstract: Once I started using my friends’ names in my novels, the characters suddenly became as real as the actual people.
lead_paragraph: My new technique was born of laziness and lack of imagination. I was trying to come up with a name for a character in my latest novel, “Swann Dives In.” He was a disbarred lawyer, a friend of the protagonist, Henry Swann, himself a money-obsessed skip tracer unafraid to cut a few corners. Rather than waste too much time, which as it happens is a specialty of many writers when it comes to writing, I slipped in the name of my friend Mark Goldblatt, as a place holder. He had no special significance to the story or the character. I would just use it, I thought, until I came up with something more appropriate.

headline: N.C.A.A. Restores Marine’s Eligibility to Play Football
abstract: The N.C.A.A. reversed course after declaring Steven Rhodes ineligible to play for Middle Tennessee State because of his participation in an organized football league.
lead_paragraph: Early this summer, Steven Rhodes sent tapes of himself playing football to college coaches around the country, hoping to be invited to join their practices. The tapes included footage from some games Rhodes participated in while at Air Station Miramar, the Marine Corps base in San Diego.

headline: Fallen Chinese Official’s Son Is ‘Denied Contact’ With Parents

lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Bo Guagua, the younger son of a fallen Communist Party leader scheduled to go on trial this week, made a rare public comment on the case on Monday, saying in a statement that he had been unable to communicate with his father or mother for a year and a half and drawing attention to their “clandestine detention.”

headline: False Choices on Egypt
keywords: ['Foreign Aid', 'United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Editorials']
abstract: The United States and the rest of the world cannot acquiesce to the military’s brutality.
lead_paragraph: A surprising number of world leaders and foreign policy experts have effectively acquiesced in the continued brutality of Egypt’s generals, arguing that support for the military is the only way to restore stability in the Arab world’s most populous state and limit wider regional turmoil. But this is just one of several false choices misinforming the debate and one that is certain to ensure more unrest, not less.

headline: Trifling With the Arts and Humanities
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Humanities', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Editorials', 'Culture (Arts)']
abstract: Vital endowment agencies are struggling to operate because of Washington’s inaction and severe budget cuts.
lead_paragraph: More than eight months ago, the high-wattage Broadway producer Rocco Landesman announced his departure as chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts. Mr. Landesman, who took the job in 2009, will be hard to replace but not impossible. The White House has taken too long to nominate a successor. It also needs a new leader for the National Endowment for the Humanities, which has been missing a permanent chief since May.

On June 29, Walter Calloway, 42, hanged himself in his cell. Just two weeks before that, another inmate, Paul Mannina, 58, cut his throat and bled to death.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Sundance) THE PLAYER (1992) In this film directed by Robert Altman, Griffin Mill (Tim Robbins), the head of production at a large Hollywood studio, tries to fend off a young genius (Peter Gallagher) rumored to have been hired as his replacement while figuring out who is writing him poison-pen postcards. When the hate mail’s author — a screenwriter (Vincent D’Onofrio) Griffin failed to get back to — turns up dead, he becomes a suspect, partly for falling in love with the writer’s girlfriend (Greta Scacchi, above, with Mr. Robbins). Whoopi Goldberg and Lyle Lovett play the detectives who make Griffin squirm. “As a satire, ‘The Player’ tickles,” Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times. “It doesn’t draw blood.” Mr. Altman’s most subversive message, he added, “is not that it’s possible to get away with murder in Hollywood, but that the most grievous sin, in Hollywood terms anyway, is to make a film that flops.” In “Short Cuts” (1993), at 10:15, Mr. Altman intertwines the experiences of Los Angelenos in adaptations of Raymond Carver stories. Mr. Robbins reappears as a philandering motorcycle cop who can’t be faithful to the woman (Frances McDormand) with whom he’s cheating on his wife (Madeleine Stowe). Lily Tomlin is a diner cook who hits a small boy with her car. Bruce Davison and Andie MacDowell are his parents; Mr. Lovett is the baker who makes his birthday cake. Fred Ward, Buck Henry and Huey Lewis are three pals who find a dead woman while fishing. And Jennifer Jason Leigh is a mother who supports her family by doing phone sex, sometimes while washing dishes or changing diapers. “The lives are often desperate and the characters inarticulate, but the group portrait is as grandly, sometimes as hilariously, realized as anything the director has ever done,” Mr. Canby wrote. “When future social historians want to know what the temper of life was like in one corner of America in 1993, ‘Short Cuts’ will be a mother lode of information. It’s also a terrific movie.”

headline: Butter Chicken in Ahmedabad

Mr. Desai, a tall, portly man who was born near the Gujarat city of Surat and grew up in Delhi, serves meat food— an uncommon choice in the state capital, especially for a Hindu. His friends advised him against it, pointing to the brisk business vegetarian food outlets did in Gujarat. “When KFC came to Gujarat, there were agitations,” said Mr. Desai, laughing. “My father taught us that eating meat did not make us lesser Gujaratis or lesser Brahmins.”

headline: Crespéu
abstract: A beautiful terrine made with stacked frittatas.
lead_paragraph: Crespéu is a traditional Provençal dish consisting of several frittatas layered one on top of the other. On my summer trips to Provence over the last few years I’ve noticed that the dish has become popular in charcuteries, baked in breadpan-shaped terrines and sold by the slice. These usually consist of three or four different types of frittata and they are different from the stack of thin frittatas that I learned to make years ago. Traditionally you would make these simply by making the frittatas, leaving them a little runny on the top and stacking them, then finishing the stack in the oven or just weighting it with a plate and chilling. But it’s easier and faster (though still quite time consuming) if you’re making the crespéu in a breadpan or tureen to cook the eggs and filling like runny scrambled eggs and layer each batch in a breadpan, then bake in a water bath. You can use 3 eggs in each batch instead of 4, but the layers will be thinner.

headline: They Can’t Handle The Health Care Truth
abstract: Youth and health are fleeting things.
lead_paragraph: Aaron Carroll talks about the Republican health care dilemma, and makes a good point: it runs deeper than the specific fact that Obamacare looks the way it does because it has to. At the most fundamental level, you can’t guarantee adequate health care to everyone unless the people who don’t need help right now — the young, healthy, and affluent — are induced, one way or another, to contribute to the care of those who do need help. You can do this purely with taxes, via a single-payer system (and maybe even by having the government act as provider), or you can do it, Swiss or Massachusetts style, via a combination of regulation, taxes, and subsidies. But some way of corralling the lucky healthy into contributing is necessary.

Six of India’s classical dance forms — Bharata Natyam, Odissi, Kathak, Kuchipudi, Mohiniattam and Kathakali — will be represented. The music includes Carnatic and Hindustani vocals and individual performances devoted to the tabla, sitar, flute and other instruments. Few of us in the West know nearly enough about these rich and compelling genres; I hope this festival recurs in years to come.

headline: 2009 And All That

They want a team player — and consider Yellen’s somewhat independent stance as a liability, even though she has been consistently right. They consider Yellen diminished because she wasn’t part of the team making policy in 2009 — when most people outside the WH don’t consider 2009 anything like a policy triumph.

headline: Laws of Attraction
abstract: No one can deny the youthful allure of French actresses Bérénice Bejo, Léa Seydoux and Marine Vacth, but when a woman’s experiences can be read on her face, one man argues, it is then that her true beauty appears.
lead_paragraph: I was at a party with the actor James Gandolfini about two weeks before he died. It was a wedding in Hollywood, and around midnight he was pouring shots of tequila for a group of men who would have laughed — slamming another Don Julio — to learn that the major preoccupation of our time is whether one is beautiful or not. Gandolfini himself was 51: he was grizzled, overweight, red in the face and complex in the soul, but to many people, men and women, he had never looked better in his life. (“I would,” a woman back at my table said.) In this not entirely fair world of ours, men, as they grow older, get to look distinguished, while women often feel they disappear. The actor toasted the stars and drank as if the only thing that told on you was your experience. He was near the end, God bless him, but he didn’t go out wishing he was somebody else.

headline: 36 Hours in Izmir, Turkey
abstract: This sunny seaside city offers everything from a traditional bazaar to bars to boutiques, and serves as a gateway to the ruins of ancient Ephesus.
lead_paragraph: “Infidel Izmir.” That’s the nickname that was long ago bestowed on Turkey’s third-largest metropolis. Known for most of its history as Smyrna, this port city was, in Ottoman times, a melting pot that included Greeks, Armenians, Jews, French and Italians. Today’s Izmir is largely Turkish, but the moniker lingers. For religious Turks, the label seems appropriate for this sunny, palm-fringed seaside city, with its relaxed attitudes and many nonobservant Muslims. For most residents, though, the nickname is proof of Izmir’s progressiveness. Reverential images of Ataturk, the founder of modern secular Turkey, are everywhere, and in June many in the city protested against Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan after his Islamist-inspired government cracked down on peaceful demonstrators in Istanbul who had mobilized to save a city park from developers. Izmir — which is among four international cities that are vying to hold the World Expo in 2020 — has much to offer visitors: a renovated waterfront, an ever-evolving night-life district and slick new design hotels. Meanwhile, a vast traditional bazaar and the spectacular nearby ruins of Ephesus bear witness to a rich past.

headline: Iran: Another Nuclear Official to Be Replaced
abstract: Iran’s longtime ambassador to the International Atomic Energy Agency will become the third senior Iranian nuclear official to be replaced under President Hassan Rouhani.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s longtime ambassador to the International Atomic Energy Agency will leave in September, news agencies reported Wednesday, making him the third senior Iranian nuclear official to be replaced under the new administration of President Hassan Rouhani. The ambassador, Ali Asghar Soltanieh, frequently criticized the agency, the nuclear monitoring arm of the United Nations, as well as what he views as Western bias against Iran. Mr. Rouhani, who took office this month, has vowed to pursue a more flexible approach toward resolving the dispute over Iran’s nuclear program, which many countries suspect is aimed at giving it the capability to produce nuclear weapons, despite Iranian denials. Last Friday Mr. Rouhani replaced the head of Iran’s Atomic Energy Organization, which runs the country’s nuclear facilities. On Tuesday state news media signaled that negotiations over the nuclear program would now be handled by Mr. Rouhani’s foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, an American-educated diplomat.

headline: England: Queen’s Swan Is Barbecued and Eaten
abstract: The charred carcass of one of Queen Elizabeth’s own swans was found after having been barbecued and eaten, according to the police and a charity called Swan Lifeline.
lead_paragraph: The charred carcass of one of Queen Elizabeth’s own swans was found on a riverbank near Windsor Castle after having been barbecued and eaten, according to the police and a charity called Swan Lifeline. The swan was one of about 200 that live on Baths Island and belong to the queen. Until 1998, under a law dating to the 12th century, killing or injuring a swan was classified as treason, and the crown retains ownership of all unmarked mute swans in areas along the River Thames. Wild swans are also protected under a 1981 act, and to injure or kill a swan — let alone eat one — is against the law. Wendy Hermon of Swan Lifeline said that “the whole breast had been removed, and it looked like it had been eaten for lunch.” There was “just a swan skeleton left,” she said. “It’s absolutely disgusting, I can’t imagine the kind of people that would do this.” She said the carcass, with its feathers still attached, was taken by her group to be cremated.

headline: Li Na, China’s Tennis Rebel
abstract: What she wants and what the Chinese government wants are not the same. This is the secret to her success.
lead_paragraph: The patch of Wimbledon grass known as the Graveyard of Champions was supposedly exorcised four years ago, when the blue-blazered gentlemen of the All England Lawn Tennis Club demolished Court 2, built a new grandstand in its place and, in 2011, renamed the haunted space Court 3. But the tennis fans watching the 2013 championships still knew. Li Na, China’s tennis rebel, knew, too. This was the same cursed court where top seeds like Pete Sampras and Serena Williams had suffered ignominious defeats, falling to unheralded players in the early rounds. Now Li, the former French Open champion and sixth-ranked player in the world, teetered one game away from a third-round loss to the Czech veteran Klara Zakopalova. “At that moment,” she told me later, “I suddenly saw myself with my bags going to the airport. headline: Generation B (For Bubble)
abstract: Loose money, or banks gone wild?
lead_paragraph: So, the flood of money into emerging markets now looks in retrospect like another bubble. For the moment, I don’t see a good reason to believe that the bursting of this particular bubble will be catastrophic — what made the Asian crisis of 1997-8 so bad was the high level of foreign-currency denominated debt, and that seems less of an issue now. In fact, the main danger, as Ryan Avent says, seems to be policy overreaction: countries raising interest rates to defend indefensible exchange rates, leading to unnecessary slumps. But I have to admit that I’m less certain than usual about my diagnosis, because I’m still coming up to speed on the Indian economy in particular.

headline: Sipping the Pleasures of Istria
abstract: On a trip around this Croatian peninsula, the author renews his romance with a regional wine and discovers another  culinary product to savor: local olive oil.
lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon, I found myself having lunch on a shaded patio about 20 feet from the banks of a placid river that empties out into the Adriatic Sea. The restaurant, Martin Pescador — named for the bird that skims the water’s surface in search of food — is in Trget, a fishing village in the region of northern Croatia known as Istria. I’d arrived there after a rough drive down a 10-mile road that hugs the Rasa River and then traverses railroad tracks and freight depots and lumberyards before dead-ending in Trget. Docked nearby were about 20 boats, the same number as residents of the village.

headline: Likely to Succeed
abstract: Amanda Ripley follows three Americans abroad to examine how and why other nations educate their students so much more effectively than we do.
lead_paragraph: “If you want the American dream, go to Finland.” These blunt words from a British politician, quoted by Amanda Ripley in “The Smartest Kids in the World,” may lead readers to imagine that her book belongs to a very particular and popular genre. We love to read about how other cultures do it better (stay slim, have sex, raise children). In this case, Ripley is offering to show how other nations educate students so much more effectively than we do, and her opening pages hold out a promising suggestion of masochistic satisfaction. “American educators described Finland as a silky paradise,” she writes, “a place where all the teachers were admired and all the children beloved.”

headline: Speaking Freely
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: Oliver Wendell Holmes’s evolution as a First Amendment hero.
lead_paragraph: The freedom-of-expression guarantee of our First Amendment will soon be celebrating its 100th anniversary. This may seem surprising to those who recall that its evocative words — “Congress shall make no law . . . abridging the freedom of speech, or of the press” — were ratified 222 years ago. But for a century and a quarter those words were essentially dead letters — until 1919, when Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes resuscitated them with a shocking dissenting opinion that ultimately became the theory of our Constitution and the law of the land.

abstract: The violinist Joshua Bell performed Tchaikovsky’s flamboyant showpiece, the songful Violin Concerto in D, with the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra on Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: Familiarity, they say, breeds contempt. But that maxim, however hoary, is not unassailable. Audiences for concerts of mainstream orchestral repertory have not yet grown tired of Tchaikovsky’s showy, songful Violin Concerto in D, composed in 1878 and now almost surely played somewhere on the planet every week of the year. New evidence came on Wednesday night in the boisterous applause that followed the work’s first movement, as the violinist Joshua Bell played the concerto with the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall.

headline: Employer Mandate, Delayed by Paperwork (and Efforts to Reduce It)
keywords: ['Fines (Penalties)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Small Business']
abstract: The challenge of writing regulations that put the Affordable Care Act’s requirements for employers into practice, and then getting computer systems to carry them out, proved too much, too soon.
lead_paragraph: Over the last several weeks, we’ve taken a close look at the Affordable Care Act’s employer mandate, which requires companies with at least 50 employees to provide affordable health insurance to workers or pay a penalty. We’ve examined, among other issues, how the mandate defines affordable, how it treats workers whose hours vary — even whether it could be used as catalyst for hiring formerly undocumented immigrants.

headline: A Salad With Farm-Stand Allure
abstract: A simple chicken dish and salad is a great accompaniment for German riesling.
lead_paragraph: The calendar is leaning into Labor Day, but that does not mean summer is over. There is still much at the greenmarket to recommend for a bottle of dry German riesling. Consider leafy herbs, the whisper of sweetness in fresh corn and summer squash and a ripe tomato, all brought together with a splash of lemon.

headline: The Summer I Discovered Suburbia
abstract: What city kid can resist the siren song of bowling alleys and Dairy Queens?
lead_paragraph: One preteen summer, I was sent by my parents to Kent, Ohio, to spend a few days with my cousins, Jessica and Anna. They were close to my age and looked like me: Norwegian, with blond hair and blue eyes. They, and their parents, a dental hygienist and geographer, were warm and easygoing. And yet, when I arrived at their cozy two-story house, it felt like touching down on an alien planet.

headline: Seasonal Variety in a Homey Setting
abstract: The thoughtfully designed menu at Trattoria 632 shifts with availability.
lead_paragraph: That Trattoria 632 looks like someone’s expanded residence is not surprising. This roomy restaurant, bar and lounge was cobbled together from two adjoining homes. Although the many walls that sheltered a few generations have been removed and the space repurposed for the building’s new life, this merging wasn’t a redo, it was a make-do, on what might have been a limited budget. The resulting layout is a tad awkward, and homey touches remain, but the mismatching sets the tone for informality and adds a bit of country charm.

headline: Oh, Yes, Saturday TV Is Ladies Night
abstract: Saturday night is increasingly known for TV movies with women in prominent roles, like the coming “Escape From Polygamy” and “After All These Years.”
lead_paragraph: There were television movies before “Sharknado,” and there continue to be television movies after “Sharknado.” Witness this Saturday night, when Lifetime offers a topical drama, “Escape From Polygamy”; Hallmark Channel provides a frothy romantic mystery, “After All These Years”; and Nickelodeon kicks in “Swindle,” a children’s caper movie modeled on the “Ocean’s” films.

headline: Yahoo Surpasses Google in Web Traffic, Somehow
abstract: For the first time since 2011, Yahoo had more unique visitors in a month than any other Web property, but why that happened remains unclear.
lead_paragraph: Without question, it has been a good month for Marissa Mayer, the chief executive of Yahoo. She was featured in a fancy fashion spread in Vogue magazine, Yahoo’s stock has continued to climb, and now, like a big cherry on top, the company beat Google to become the most visited Web property in America.

headline: Fools Rush In, With Camera
abstract: In Renny Harlin’s “Devil’s Pass,” American students investigate a Russian skiing disaster shrouded in mystery.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

headline: It’s Wagner’s Birthday, but We Get the Gifts
abstract: Classical music critics choose their favorite recordings of Wagner, including selected performances of “Tristan und Isolde” and “Lohengrin,” as well as parts of the “Ring”
lead_paragraph: Love his music or hate his personality, the one thing you can’t do with Wagner is ignore him, especially this year, as the music world celebrates his bicentenary. However petty and malicious the man could be, his artistic achievement was huge, not only in sheer physical bulk but also in ambition, imagination and invention.

headline: When It’s All About the Timing
abstract: Joe Swanberg’s new romance, “Drinking Buddies,” reveals, among other things, that passive-aggression is nowadays less a personal trait than a cultural norm.
lead_paragraph: A conventional way to describe Kate and Luke’s relationship would be to say they’re just friends. But “just” hardly captures the intensity of the bond between them. Co-workers at a thriving Chicago microbrewery, Kate (Olivia Wilde) and Luke (Jake Johnson) have an effortless, comfortable intimacy. They get each other’s jokes and never tire of each other’s company. Daily lunch companions, they often extend the nightly busman’s holiday of after-work beer-drinking until closing time. They snuggle up in booths and couches, sometimes dozing off, but more like puppies in a box than lovers in bed.

headline: Council Reverses Bloomberg Veto of Policing Bills
keywords: ['Search and Seizure', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The City Council voted Thursday to greatly increase oversight of the New York Police Department and of its widespread use of stop-and-frisk tactics.
lead_paragraph: The City Council voted Thursday to greatly increase oversight of the New York Police Department and of its widespread use of stop-and-frisk tactics.

headline: Triple Play: Make Your Picks for Week 22
abstract: Put your predictive skills to the test each week of the baseball season.
lead_paragraph: The Bats blog again tests our readers’ predictive skills with three questions about the coming week. Feel free to lean on research, tea leaves, your gut instinct or maybe just dumb luck.

headline: Privileged, but Wired Not to Find Comfort
abstract: “Thérèse,” set in 1920s France, revolves around an upper-class woman for whom happiness is elusive.
lead_paragraph: The rich are different from you and me, as F. Scott Fitzgerald wrote, sometimes nowhere more so than in French movies. In the United States, a Viking stove in the kitchen and a BMW in the driveway may be mere background noise in a sleek thriller; in France, such emblems of class privilege can be grounds for a date with the Widow (a k a the guillotine), metaphorically speaking. In “Thérèse,” a 1920s woman is driven to commit a terrible crime, for all sorts of nominal reasons, though, in truth, her paramount motive is the accident of her birth: she’s bourgeois.

headline: Q. & A. | Edgar Wright on the Autobiographical Inspirations Behind His Boozy Film
abstract: His newest film, “The World’s End,” is centered on an epic pub crawl, complete with an apocalyptic climax, and hits theaters tomorrow.
lead_paragraph: Edgar Wright’s latest gleefully genre-fusing meditation on English small-town life, “The World’s End,” in theaters tomorrow, charts an epic pub crawl led by the character of Gary King (played by Wright’s co-writer Simon Pegg), a roguish, charismatic drunk. King reunites a disbanded group of friends from his teen years to finally complete “The Golden Mile,” in which a stop is made at all 12 pubs in their hometown, a task they had conspicuously failed at 20 years before. As the group makes its way toward an apocalyptic climax, old wounds are reopened, lost loves are reunited, an alien invasion is uncovered, and many, many pints are consumed. Here, the writer and director talks about real-life inspiration for the film.

headline: Last Call for Friends to Grow Up
abstract: In “World’s End,” five British men reprise a pub crawl they had tried but failed to finish more than 20 years earlier as teenagers.
lead_paragraph: On a summer evening in 1990, five British teenagers attempted a heroic pub crawl in the town of Newton Haven, a feat of herculean imbibing known as the Golden Mile. Along the way, there were vomiting, fighting and drunken sex, but amid all that fun, the group failed to make it through the requisite 12 watering holes, the last of which was called the World’s End. Their second try, more than 20 years later, is the subject of Edgar Wright’s new movie.

headline: Still Keeping Time, Staying True to the Past While Living in the Present
abstract: The drummer Jimmy Cobb, 84, the last remaining musician to have played on “Kind of Blue,” led a quartet on Wednesday at Village Vanguard.
lead_paragraph: The urge toward retrospection runs strong among jazz musicians of a certain age, and to resist it requires stern commitment. But there’s also a way to be stubborn about honoring the past and its pull, making no disclaimers and leaving nothing to conjecture.

headline: Germany’s Rieslings on the Tip of the Tongue
abstract: The country’s dry rieslings capture a sense of place with more crystalline precision and delicacy than most others.
lead_paragraph: The topic today is German rieslings, and since I already know the first question, let me start with the answer: No, not all German rieslings are sweet. In fact, sweet German rieslings may soon be an endangered species.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Egypt, Syria, Zimbabwe and the Philippines.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Egypt, Syria, Zimbabwe and the Philippines.

headline: Brooke Astor’s Son Is Paroled
keywords: ['Probation and Parole', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Wills and Estates']
abstract: Anthony D. Marshall, 89, has been deemed so frail and sick that he will be let out of prison after serving about 60 days of his sentence of one to three years.
lead_paragraph: New York State’s parole board ruled on Thursday that Anthony D. Marshall, the 89-year-old son of the philanthropist and socialite Brooke Astor, had grown so sick and frail that he would be granted immediate parole after serving just eight weeks of his one- to three-year prison sentence.

headline: A Return to Nature
abstract: Environment trumped event as Julianna Barwick performed music from her third album, “Nepenthe,” at the Judson Memorial Church on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: There is an elusive quality to the natural light in Iceland, where long, white days of hazy luminosity don’t start and end so much as they seem to surreptitiously appear and, eventually, disappear. A similarly evanescent quality can be found in the music of Julianna Barwick, a singer and composer whose third album, “Nepenthe,” was issued by the Dead Oceans label on Tuesday. Ms. Barwick’s songs — chiefly wordless vocals, electronically looped — materialize out of ether, saturate a sonorous atmosphere, then dissolve. Environment trumps event.

headline: Egyptian Police Failed to Defend Churches, Rights Group Says
keywords: ['Christians and Christianity', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: A Human Rights Watch video report documents “simultaneous” attacks on churches across Egypt on the same day security forces violently dispersed two Islamist sit-ins in Cairo.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague Kareem Fahim reported from Nazla, Egypt, dozens of churches and other facilities connected to Egypt’s Christian minority have been attacked and burned in the last seven days by Islamists seeking revenge for the ouster of President Mohamed Morsi and a violent government crackdown that has left hundreds of his supporters dead.

headline: A Well-Traveled Table in a Majestic Setting
abstract: A sister of Mediterraneo in Greenwich and the latest addition to the Z Hospitality Group has a short menu but makes a big impression.
lead_paragraph: The owners of Mediterraneo, which opened in April at the new Hotel Zero Degrees in Norwalk, want diners to imagine that they have stepped into the dining salon of a large, majestic yacht. That explains the beautiful teak-and-holly floor that resembles a deck and the three enormous columns that punctuate the room.

headline: Havana Fantasies, Biology and Geography
abstract: Three teenagers plot to flee to Miami from Cuba in “Una Noche,” the feature directorial debut of Lucy Mulloy.
lead_paragraph: A bright red sports car, a stripper and knee-length 24-karat gold chains: those accouterments define the sweet life in Miami in the feverish fantasies of Raúl (Dariel Arrechaga), a hotheaded, hormonally overcharged Havana teenager in “Una Noche.” With his best friend, Elio (Javier Núñez Florián), and Elio’s twin sister, Lila (Anailín de la Rúa de la Torre), Raúl hopes to follow countless others and navigate the straits of Florida to America on a homemade raft.

headline: The Desert Foils Friendly Scheming
abstract: Friends are stranded in the desert in “Scenic Route,” directed by the brothers Kevin and Michael Goetz.
lead_paragraph: It isn’t easy to drum up sympathy for the two 30-ish buddies of “Scenic Route,” childhood friends who reunite for a road trip to hell. Through their own shortsightedness, they find themselves stranded in Death Valley on a nearly deserted road with only jelly beans to eat, a few swigs of water and no cellphone service.

headline: Style and Kinetics Triumph in a Turbulent China
abstract: Wong Kar-wai’s “Grandmaster” is a film about Ip Man, a 20th-century Chinese martial arts legend, but also an exploration of opposing forces like loyalty and love.
lead_paragraph: “The Grandmaster,” a hypnotically beautiful dream from the Hong Kong filmmaker Wong Kar-wai, opens with curls of smoke, eddies of water and men soaring and flying across the frame as effortlessly as silk ribbons. The men are warriors, street fighters with furious fists and winged feet, who have massed together on a dark, rainy night to take on Ip Man (Tony Leung), a still figure in a long coat and an elegant white hat. Even amid the violent whirlpools of rain and bodies, that hat never leaves his head. It’s as unyielding as its owner.

headline: A Surgical Center for Older Patients
abstract: Older patients can benefit from surgery, but doctors tend not to do full assessments of their ability to recover.
lead_paragraph: How well will a particular patient withstand the stresses of surgery? To make that determination, surgeons typically order cardiovascular tests. Is his heart pumping efficiently? Are her lungs providing enough oxygen? But Dr. Mark Katlic never found that sufficient for older patients.

headline: One of His Biggest Fights Was Outside of the Ring
abstract: “The Trials of Muhammad Ali” traces the road to Mr. Ali’s refusal in 1967 to serve in the Vietnam War, which cost him his license to box.
lead_paragraph: Muhammad Ali, born Cassius Clay, was not the only American to refuse to serve during the Vietnam War, but he was, by some measures, the most famous, the loudest and the baddest. Tracing the road to Mr. Ali’s act of defiance in 1967, Bill Siegel’s film “The Trials of Muhammad Ali” tries to recover the cultural éclat of the moment after decades of pop-history shorthand have reduced it to sound bites about the Vietcong.

headline: Clocks That Have Been Ticking Since Before the Revolution
abstract: The 18th-century clocks of Peter Stretch are the subject of a new book.
lead_paragraph: TICKING SINCE BEFORE

headline: How BlackBerry Handled Past Wealth
keywords: ['Stock Options and Purchase Plans', 'Executive Compensation', 'BlackBerry (Handheld Device)']
abstract: As the company’s fortunes spiral down, a look back shows little reward for loyal shareholders even in its heyday. But executives did well.
lead_paragraph: It started in an unlikely place, far from the headquarters of more established technology companies, and grew to become a dominant player. Along the way, investors piled in, undeterred by the company’s policy of never paying a dividend.

headline: Picking Up the Scent on the Road to Bliss
abstract: Life lessons that only a four-footed friend can teach.
lead_paragraph: One of my first boyfriends announced after our fourth date that he would never consider marrying or even living with a woman who smoked. I was devastated (although I didn’t smoke).

headline: What Happens When You’re Repeatedly Hit in the Head
abstract: The documentary “The United States of Football” follows retired players dealing with dementia and depression after a career of hard knocks.
lead_paragraph: “Would I allow my son to play football?” is the question that the sports journalist Sean Pamphilon positions at the center of “The United States of Football,” his documentary on the dangers of head injuries in that sport. He follows the stories of several retired N.F.L. players, living and dead, who had the degenerative brain disease chronic traumatic encephalopathy, which has been linked to repetitive blows to the head. Extreme dementia and depression set in before the disease slowly destroys the body. “What do you do with a 300-pound, 45-year-old person who’s out of control and is only going to get worse?” asks Lisa McHale, the widow of the Tampa Bay lineman Tom McHale.

headline: Jazz Listings for Aug. 23-29
abstract: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: They Probably Should Have Skipped This Dinner Party
abstract: “You’re Next,” by Adam Wingard, has masked killers with crossbows and a plot full of surprises.
lead_paragraph: Injecting the home-invasion thriller with fresh DNA, Adam Wingard’s “You’re Next” strays just enough from formula to tweak our jaded appetites. That it does so without spraying the gore to geyserlike excess says a great deal about Mr. Wingard’s sensibility. Never one to linger ghoulishly over violence — or to rely on bloodletting to plug a weak script — he prefers to strike and move on.

headline: Classical Music and Opera Listings for Aug. 23-29
abstract: A selected guide to classical music performances in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: The Fun Begins With the Name
abstract: Olive Lucy’s Kitchen Table has an affable staff, an upbeat attitude and a fruit punch to which customers can add their own wine.
lead_paragraph: Olive Lucy’s Kitchen Table is a pleasant place at which to pass a sultry summer evening. It has comfortable white-backed, tufted booths, pitchers of fresh fruit sangria and music that ranges from lively salsa to mellower Sinatra. Look around the room: people have fun here. A table piled with gift bags suggests a birthday or an engagement; Alan Valenti, the owner, in a phone conversation after my visits, said the restaurant, which opened last Valentine’s Day, was also a popular place for bachelorette parties.

headline: “Lightness of Being”
abstract: Playful sculptures abound in a group show at City Hall Park.
lead_paragraph: Playful sculptures abound in a group show at City Hall Park.

headline: Dance Listings for Aug. 23-29
abstract: A selected guide to dance performances in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Caretakers Needing Some Care Themselves
abstract: “Short Term 12” is set at a group home inhabited by troubled adolescents and workers with issues.
lead_paragraph: A delicate intensity of feeling shapes “Short Term 12,” a drama about young, lost people hoping to be found. These aren’t like the strays who anxiously drift through other contemporary American movies — whose lack of purpose is reflected both in the groping camerawork and the uncertainty of a budding filmmaker behind the camera. The young director of “Short Term 12,” Destin Daniel Cretton, may have adapted some of the techniques of low-budget independent features, including a suggestion of tentativeness in the hand-held cinematography. But he’s clearly thought through his choices and found a subject that has earned its heartache.

headline: People as the Big Game in an Alaskan Hunt
abstract: “The Frozen Ground,” starring Nicolas Cage, is a film about a serial killer and the investigator whose pursuit eventually pays off.
lead_paragraph: Does that worried look on the face of Nicolas Cage in “The Frozen Ground” signal his realization that he is trapped in a police procedural that is not as good as an average episode of “Law and Order: Special Victims Unit”? Could be, although the movie, the directorial feature debut of Scott Walker, is at least watchable, unlike recent debacles starring Mr. Cage, including “Stolen,” “Ghost Rider: Spirit of Vengeance,” “Trespass,” “Seeking Justice” and “Season of the Witch.”

headline: Pop Music Videos? I Want My YouTube!
keywords: ['Music', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'MTV Video Music Awards']
abstract: Thirty years after MTV’s first Video Music Awards, videos are as important as ever for music success. But it is now the YouTube hit that labels covet.
lead_paragraph: A LOT has changed since 1984, when MTV first televised the Video Music Awards. Thirty years ago, record labels often spent millions of dollars on videos by top directors to promote the sale of albums. Then label executives would submit the videos to MTV and pray that the network would put them in its rotation.

headline: That Fractious Couple, Sex and Religion
abstract: “Paradise: Faith,” the second film in a trilogy by the Austrian director Ulrich Seidl, examines the bleak relationship between a Roman Catholic missionary and her paraplegic Muslim husband.
lead_paragraph: Grotesquerie is in the eye of the beholder. That’s one lesson to be taken from the cinematic provocations of the Austrian filmmaker Ulrich Seidl, who, by presenting his characters as exotic specimens under a microscope, dares you to recoil.

headline: A Feast of the Eyes, Then a Treat for the Ears
abstract: The Indian dancers Sonali Mishra and Shambhavi Dandekar showcase the Odissi and Kathak forms as part of Drive East at La MaMa.
lead_paragraph: Drive East, a festival focusing on South Asian music and dance, continued on Wednesday with separate presentations exploring two dance forms: first, Odissi with Sonali Mishra, and later, Kathak featuring Shambhavi Dandekar. Even though La MaMa’s first-floor theater has the look of a grim church basement, there is a bright side to seeing classical Indian dance here. Details are given jewel-box prominence: the gaze, the subtle shift of a neck, the way fingers stretch and curve are as arresting as a stomp on the floor.

headline: ‘American Modern: Hopper to O’Keeffe’
abstract: MoMA’s show includes paintings, drawings, prints, photographs and sculptures by more than 50 artists, bringing together some of the museum’s most celebrated masterworks.
lead_paragraph: MoMA’s show includes paintings, drawings, prints, photographs and sculptures by more than 50 artists, bringing together some of the museum’s most celebrated masterworks.

abstract: Long Island producers won in nine of 32 classes of wines made from grapes in the New York Wine and Food Classic this month, and McCall Wines was named winery of the year.
lead_paragraph: Long Island producers won in nine of 32 classes of wines made from grapes in the New York Wine and Food Classic this month.
