abstract: A critical guide to the visual arts in New York and the region.
lead_paragraph: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Market Report | Blue Gets the Black and Gray Treatment
abstract: For early fall, designers introduce statement pieces laced with Yves Klein’s iconic shade of blue.
lead_paragraph: Designers have embraced Yves Klein’s iconic shade of blue in standout pieces for early fall. From tops (Victoria Beckham’s prim calf-hair coat and Jil Sander’s artistic turtleneck sweater) to bottoms (Roger Vivier’s flocked leather bootie and Manolo Blahnik’s signature stiletto) and everything in between (Christopher Kane’s color-blocked velvet dress and a calf-hair bag from Michael Kors), this deep indigo hue is being paired, accented and trimmed with black and gray to prove that the similar shades can, and should, be worn together. The pièce de résistance: Dior’s ladylike watch with baguette sapphires and bright diamonds.

headline: A Plumber Lends a Sympathetic Ear
abstract: In Noah Buschel’s “Sparrows Dance,” an agoraphobic actress is forced to call upon the assistance of a poetry-writing handyman.
lead_paragraph: To describe the setup of “Sparrows Dance,” Noah Buschel’s disarmingly offbeat romance, is to risk alienating audiences fatigued by too-quirky characters and low-budget contrivance. In one corner, we have an unnamed, severely agoraphobic actress (Marin Ireland); in the other, a saxophone-playing, poetry-writing plumber (Paul Sparks). Between them lies a tiny New York City apartment and a mental-health problem as vast as a football field.

headline: An Urban Park Dotted With Gardens of Whimsy
abstract: Playful sculptures abound in “Lightness of Being,” a group show at City Hall Park.
lead_paragraph: A certain pants-making company promoted its denim three years ago with the imperative “Be stupid.” This was an attempt at irony. It really meant, “If you are smart, you will buy our jeans.” Variations on that tag line explained: “Stupid might fail. Smart doesn’t even try”; and “Stupid creates. Smart critiques.” In other words, to be original and creative, you might have to be willfully ignorant of what passes for conventional intelligence — or, at least, appear to be so. Think of the seemingly naïve TV detective Columbo.

headline: When Fringes Became Fashion
abstract: “Hippie Chic,” now at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, raises the question of what should be expected from curators picking through clothes from the not-so-distant past.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — DOES anyone else remember that early episode of “All in the Family”? The one in which Archie Bunker, wearing a tie at his daughter’s urging, meets her boyfriend, Mike Stivic, who arrives in tie-dyed T-shirt and ripped bluejeans.

headline: Spare Times for Children for Aug. 23-29
abstract: A listing of cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: “iLuminate: Artist of Light”

headline: The Pentagon as Silicon Valley’s Incubator
abstract: Government experts on computer vulnerabilities are heading to Silicon Valley to create technology start-ups specializing in tools aimed at thwarting online threats.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In the ranks of technology incubator programs, there is AngelPad here in San Francisco and Y Combinator about 40 miles south in Mountain View. And then there is the Pentagon.

headline: Comfortable Old Friends
abstract: In its new show “American Modern: Hopper to O’Keeffe” the Museum of Modern Art tries to show that the museum did not ignore American artists during its early decades.
lead_paragraph: It’s sad. When the Museum of Modern Art isn’t jumping the shark with celebrity-performance art featuring the likes of Tilda Swinton, it can often be found paddling about in the lukewarm waters of the shallow end.

headline: Spare Times for Aug. 23-29
abstract: A guide to walking tours, street fairs, parades and other cultural events in New York.
lead_paragraph: Battle of Brooklyn Commemoration (Sunday) It was a Revolutionary War battle that George Washington and his troops would probably have liked to forget — they lost — but the Battle of Brooklyn, on Aug. 27, 1776, was the colonists’ first major confrontation with the British after declaring independence, giving the occasion a special place in history. Its 237th anniversary will be celebrated on Sunday, from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m., with events at one of the sites involved, what is now Green-Wood Cemetery, Fifth Avenue and 25th Street, Greenwood Heights, Brooklyn.

headline: Drunk, Ornery and With a Gun in His Hands
abstract: “Savannah” tells the story of a well-born Southerner who turns his back on privilege to hunt ducks with a former slave.
lead_paragraph: “Savannah,” a picturesque film based on a true story from the early-20th-century South, has a tone that leaves you expecting an outsize character to emerge and carry you to an ending that is the stuff of legends. But the man at the center of the story, Ward Allen (Jim Caviezel), turns out to be something less than that. He’s an interesting fellow but not particularly larger than life, at least as portrayed here.

headline: How the Daughter of an Ancient Race Made It Out of the Australian Outback
abstract: A 1971 article on Evonne Goolagong, the first Australian aborigine to play serious competitive tennis.
lead_paragraph: This article originally appeared in print on Aug. 29, 1971, and is excerpted, along with other tennis writing from the archives, in the Aug. 25, 2013, issue of the magazine.

headline: Arthur Ashe Has to Be Aware That He Is a Pioneer in Short White Pants
abstract: A 1966 article on the self-described “sociological phenomenon.”
lead_paragraph: This article originally appeared in print on Jan. 2, 1966, and is excerpted, along with other tennis writing from the archives, in the Aug. 25, 2013, issue of the magazine.

headline: Apology, but No Explanation, for Massacre of Afghans
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Sentences (Criminal)']
abstract: Staff Sgt. Robert Bales spoke out as a military jury weighed sentencing him to life in prison without parole for killing 16 Afghans.
lead_paragraph: JOINT BASE LEWIS-McCHORD, Wash. — Staff Sgt. Robert Bales offered a tearful apology on Thursday for gunning down 16 unarmed Afghan civilians inside their homes, but said he still could not explain why he had carried out one of the worst American war crimes in years.

headline: Borg vs. Tilden
abstract: A 1980 article about Bjorn Rune Borg, “the most doom-laden product of Sweden since Ingmar Bergman.”
lead_paragraph: This article originally appeared in print on Aug. 24, 1980, and is excerpted, along with other tennis writing from the archives, in the Aug. 25, 2013, issue of the magazine.

lead_paragraph: This article originally appeared in print on Sep. 9, 1928, and is excerpted, along with other tennis writing from the archives, in the Aug. 25, 2013, issue of the magazine.

headline: The Little Girl With the Big Racquet
abstract: A 1953 article about Maureen Connolly, then 18 years old and the top woman tennis player in the world.
lead_paragraph: This article originally appeared in print on Aug. 23, 1953, and is excerpted, along with other tennis writing from the archives, in the Aug. 25, 2013, issue of the magazine.

headline: Wheelies: The Hot Wheels Edition
abstract: According to the National Insurance Crime Bureau, the Honda Accord is still the most stolen vehicle in America.
lead_paragraph: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Former Windows Boss Goes to Andreessen, and Dear Miss Disruption
abstract: Wednesday’s highlights from around the Web include the announcement that Steven Sinofsky, the former head of Microsoft’s Windows division, has become a board partner of Andreessen Horowitz, a venture capital firm. Plus, a satire on the Silicon Valley state of mind.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Fiery Mayoral Debate Drew Few Viewers, Nielsen Says
abstract: NY1, the cable news channel that telecast the face-off on Wednesday, has a smaller audience than the network TV stations.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic mayoral debate televised on Wednesday night was filled with fireworks. But it turns out that relatively few voters actually saw them.

headline: This Week’s Movies: Aug. 23, 2013
abstract: The New York Times film critics on “The World’s End,” “The Grandmaster,” and “Drinking Buddies.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics on “The World’s End,” “The Grandmaster,” and “Drinking Buddies.”

headline: Surprise! No Rent Increases!
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)']
abstract: A decision to hold the line at 8 Spruce Street is not exactly being copied elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: A friend recently told me, breathless with excitement, that she was renewing her lease at 8 Spruce Street, the Frank Gehry-designed 76-story skyscraper, without any rent increase.

headline: Icahn Tweets Dinner Plans With Apple’s Chief, and Investors Applaud
abstract: Despite the hullabaloo over the Nasdaq stock market’s failure on Thursday afternoon, traders remained fixated squarely on Apple’s then-frozen stock price. Why? Because Carl C. Icahn had taken to Twitter again.
lead_paragraph: Despite the hullabaloo over the Nasdaq stock market’s failure on Thursday afternoon, traders remained fixated squarely on Apple‘s then-frozen stock price.

headline: For Borrowers, Many Questions
abstract: Afraid of risk, lenders ask for a barrage of information.
lead_paragraph: In this risk-averse lending climate, mortgage lenders are unabashed in their demands for detailed documentation of a loan applicant’s financial situation.

headline: Lone Star Flavor in New York
abstract: Options include Austin-style brisket and live music and a Tex-Mex-flavored roadhouse.
lead_paragraph: Those looking for a little Lone Star soul can feel plenty at home in New York. Between the thriving scenes at Hill Country, the West 26th Street outpost dedicated to Austin-style brisket and live music, and the long-running Rodeo Bar, a Tex-Mex-flavored roadhouse pretty much directly across town, that old saw from westerns about “this town isn’t big enough for the two of us” doesn’t seem to apply here.

headline: Sturgis Biker Reunion
keywords: ['Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'Road Trips', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Seth Kugel's summer road trip takes him to Sturgis, S.D., during an annual gathering of thousands of motorcyclists.
lead_paragraph: Seth Kugel's summer road trip takes him to Sturgis, S.D., during an annual gathering of thousands of motorcyclists.

headline: Motorcycles, Memorials and the Middle of Nowhere
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Budget Travel', 'Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters']
abstract: Reaching South Dakota in time for the Sturgis Motorcycle Rally, the Frugal Traveler samples a bit of biker culture, hits tourist highlights and discovers what remote really means.
lead_paragraph: It turns out I’ve been using the phrase “in the middle of nowhere” incorrectly my whole life. I used to mean it as a put-down, but I’ve discovered that it’s actually a good thing. And now that I’ve found the middle of nowhere, it turns out to be more remote than I could have imagined: on a rural mail route way outside of Philip, S.D., population 750.

headline: Walking and Talking Bed-Stuy
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Brownstones', 'ARCHITECTURE']
abstract: As Amzi Hill, Morgan Munsey blogs about Bedford-Stuyvesant.
lead_paragraph: Bedford-Stuyvesant has not quite peaked on the been-there, done-that gentrification bucket list, but it already has its own Boswell recording every permutation of the landscape. His name is Morgan Munsey, or for those more familiar with his comments on the blog Brownstoner, he is Amzi Hill, a sobriquet taken from an architect who built Italianate brownstones and Neo-Grec town houses in Brooklyn from 1860 to 1892 and dabbled, as does Mr. Munsey, in real estate.

headline: The Siren Call of the Adjustable-Rate Loan
keywords: ['Mortgages', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The upsurge in rates has breathed new life into adjustable-rate mortgages, which contributed to the housing collapse by trapping borrowers in loans they could not afford.
lead_paragraph: As if first-time home buyers were not having enough trouble getting into the market, now they have to contend with rising interest rates.

headline: Peak-Hour Pursuit
abstract: Looking for love on the way to Grand Central, a vacation request that causes doubts and other tough questions.
lead_paragraph: I am a daily commuter from suburban Connecticut to New York City. I have ridden the same train car with the same people for months (and sometimes years). I have grown enamored of a particular man I see most mornings, but I am not sure how to start a conversation with him — or whether to try. Any advice?

headline: Enter a Turkish Newcomer
abstract: At Mavi Grill and Deli, Turkish cuisine comes in large portions in an airy, spacious converted house.
lead_paragraph: Mavi Grill and Deli, a Turkish newcomer to Mount Sinai, is surprising, first for its location in a mostly residential area, and then for its setting, not the more typical storefront but an airy, spacious, converted house.

headline: American Tells of Odyssey as Prisoner of Syrian Rebels
keywords: ['Hostages', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Torture', 'Political Prisoners']
abstract: Matthew Schrier, a photographer, says he was held for seven months by jihadi fighters opposed to President Bashar al-Assad. After being robbed, tortured and accused of being an American spy, he escaped in July.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Schrier was helpless. An American photographer held in a rebel-controlled prison in the Syrian city of Aleppo, he and a fellow prisoner had been caught trying to gouge a hole in their cell’s wooden door. The captors took his cellmate, he said, beat him, and brought him back with blood-streaked ankles and feet.

headline: Now, You Can Follow Government Intelligence Agencies Back
keywords: ['Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: A new Tumblr blog from the Office of the Director of National Intelligence promises a more transparent look at surveillance practices.
lead_paragraph: If surveillance from government intelligence agencies has you concerned, now you can at least follow them back — if only on Tumblr.

headline: Why Is Obama Caving on Tobacco?
keywords: ['Smoking and Tobacco', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Trans-Pacific trade talks must not be used to weaken smoking regulation.
lead_paragraph: LAST year I endorsed President Obama for re-election largely because of his commitment to putting science and public health before politics. But now the Obama administration appears to be on the verge of bowing to pressure from a powerful special-interest group, the tobacco industry, in a move that would be a colossal public health mistake and potentially contribute to the deaths of tens of millions of people around the world.

headline: New Claims in U.S. Case Against SAC Ex-Trader
abstract: Federal prosecutors filed an updated indictment in the criminal insider trading case against a former SAC Capital Advisors portfolio manager, adding a claim that he received secret information about drug trials from a second doctor.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors filed an updated indictment in the criminal insider trading case against a former SAC Capital Advisors portfolio manager, adding a claim that he received secret information about drug trials from a second doctor.

headline: Kochs No Longer Interested in Buying Tribune Papers
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Newspapers', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Charles and David Koch, the brothers and billionaire industrialists who run Koch Industries, had concluded the acquisition was “not economically viable,” a spokeswoman said.
lead_paragraph: Charles and David Koch are no longer contemplating a purchase of the Tribune Company’s chain of newspapers, a spokeswoman for the billionaire industrialists said on Thursday.

headline: A Silicon Valley for Ad Agencies, Only in the Mountains
abstract: Project WorldWide is opening an agency in Boulder, Colo., which is developing a reputation as a home for advertising start-ups.
lead_paragraph: AN agency holding group with ambitious growth plans is setting up shop in a growing market for agencies.

headline: Yanks Add Some Luck to Their Streak, With Two Bad Calls on One Play
abstract: The surging Yankees took advantage of an umpire’s incorrect call to defeat the Blue Jays for the 12th time in the 13 games the two teams have played this season.
lead_paragraph: When luck is on your side, even the most absurd calls can go your way.

headline: GTT ★
abstract: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.
lead_paragraph: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Ad Revenue From Mobile for Pandora Increases
abstract: The company reported a loss of $7.8 million for the second quarter, but continues to experience rapid growth.
lead_paragraph: Pandora Media, the company behind the popular Internet radio service about to face major competition from Apple, reported on Thursday a loss of $7.8 million, or about 4 cents a share, for the second quarter but the company continues to experience rapid growth.

headline: Many Young El Pasoans Find They Can Go Home Again
abstract: El Paso, once one of America’s leading exporters of youth, is experiencing an influx of young people returning to their roots.
lead_paragraph: EL PASO — In 2009, Xochitl Rodriguez, a multitalented performer from a middle-class El Paso neighborhood, was Bhutan’s first-ever invited artist in residence. After leaving South Asia, she served another residency in Kansas City.

headline: Shortage of Doctors Tough to Fix
abstract: Even with new legislation and plans for two new medical schools, there seems to be no long-term solution for the looming shortage of physicians in Texas.
lead_paragraph: Texas lawmakers invested millions of additional dollars in the 2013 legislative session to address a looming physician shortage. Voters and university regents have rubber-stamped plans to open two new medical schools, in Austin and the Rio Grande Valley. But those moves have not placated the medical community, which remains concerned that Texas has no long-term solution to produce enough physicians, particularly in primary care, to support the surging population.

headline: These Walls Speak, Recalling Victims of Violence
keywords: ['Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Kidnapping', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: A hulking memorial that allows Mexicans to scribble or draw messages about grief and loss has set off of a debate about whether it should be a tribute to all the drug war’s victims or those subjected to abuses by the authorities.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The memorial to Mexico’s victims of violence looks like it has been dropped from the sky by an angry God. Welcoming it is not, with its rusted slabs the size of movie screens standing next to a busy intersection.

headline: Law Updated to Protect Some Who Do Roadwork
keywords: ['Roads and Traffic', 'Law and Legislation', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: An expansion of the Move Over Act requires drivers to slow down or move over when they see a Texas Department of Transportation vehicle on or near a roadway with its emergency lights flashing.
lead_paragraph: In 2003, Gov. Rick Perry signed the Move Over Act. It gave Texas drivers a new rule of the road when they came across a police car or other emergency vehicle parked on a shoulder with its lights flashing: slow down or move one lane over while passing.

headline: Gingrich Will Be Back in the ‘Crossfire’ on CNN
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Television', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: As a host of CNN’s revived “Crossfire,” Newt Gingrich will become a member of the news media that he once criticized. “And I hope to move it to the right,” he said.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Va. — In defeat, the 2012 Republican presidential hopefuls have mostly faded from view, in ways that seem true to type. Mitt Romney is a contented grandfather. Rick Santorum leads a Christian movie company. Michele Bachmann is retiring from the House, although her pants-on-fire oratory is likely to find a new home.

headline: Mexican Mass Grave May Be Tied to Abductions
abstract: Officials are investigating whether the victims are a group of young people kidnapped from a Mexico City bar in May.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — A mass grave has been found near here, the authorities said Thursday, and they are investigating whether the victims are a group of young people kidnapped en masse from a bar in May, a crime that shocked and perplexed a capital city not accustomed to such brazen violence.

headline: Moody’s Threatens to Cut Credit Ratings of Banks
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)']
abstract: If it follows through, Moody’s could reduce the ratings of Wall Street giants like Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and JPMorgan Chase as much as two grades.
lead_paragraph: Believing that the government is now more likely to let large banks fail in a crisis, Moody’s Investors Service threatened on Thursday to downgrade the credit ratings of several big financial firms.

headline: A Question of How Women’s Issues Will Fare, in Washington and Overseas
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'United States International Relations', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Some are questioning whether Catherine M. Russell, ambassador at large for global women’s issues, will see a less prominent role under Secretary of State John Kerry.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Catherine M. Russell’s portfolio includes half the population of the planet, roughly 3.5 billion women. But working with the 70,000 employees of the State Department to make women’s issues a permanent priority, she said, may be the “harder slog” in a difficult new job.

headline: In Markets’ Tuned-Up Machinery, Stubborn Ghosts Remain
keywords: ['Futures and Options Trading', 'High-Frequency and Flash Trading', 'Nasdaq Composite Index', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Today’s automated stock exchanges are fast and efficient, so long as the computers are working. When things go awry, chaos can emerge quickly.
lead_paragraph: A generation ago, when the stock market crashed on Oct. 19, 1987, the Nasdaq stock market appeared to have done much better than the New York Stock Exchange. While the Dow Jones industrial average fell 23 percent that day, the Nasdaq composite index was off just 11 percent.

headline: German Officers’ Biases Seen as Enabling Neo-Nazis
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Neo Nazi Groups', 'Police', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Minorities', 'Fringe Groups and Movements']
abstract: A parliamentary study found that prejudices played a role in the police’s failure to detect a neo-Nazi cell that carried out a string of attacks on immigrants for more than a decade.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Germany’s police and security services suffered from deeply rooted prejudices and a lack of cultural diversity, which allowed a neo-Nazi cell to carry out violent attacks against immigrants for more than a decade without being detected, according to a parliamentary committee report issued Thursday.

headline: League’s Format and Prizes Transform Street Skating
abstract: The Street League, whose Super Crown World Championship will be broadcast live on ESPN2 on Sunday night, has elevated street skating contests to dizzying new heights.
lead_paragraph: The first official street skateboarding contest, held in San Francisco in 1983, took place on an actual street. The course consisted of a few small wooden ramps and a parking block. Sixteen of the best street skaters alive competed for a first-place prize of $200.

headline: With Ships, Silt and a Giant Straw, a Beach in the Rockaways Is Reborn
abstract: Between now and next Memorial Day, a federal project will put 3.5 million cubic yards of sand on the beaches eroded by Hurricane Sandy, at a cost of $37 million.
lead_paragraph: It had taken every bit of nine months to pry the Beach 30th Street playground in the Rockaways from the death grip of Hurricane Sandy, but by Wednesday afternoon, it was back under the full control of the proper authorities: a mob of children, at full roar.

headline: A Limited Role for Cuomo as Obama Travels Upstate
abstract: Political veterans say President Obama and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo have a warm working rapport, one with layers of personal connections, political calculation and professional debts of gratitude.
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — When President Obama arrived here on Thursday morning, emerging from Air Force One to a crowd of avid fans and a Lake Erie gale, the first person to shake his hand was Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, smiling wide. The president smiled too, hugging Mr. Cuomo before moving on to chat with the governor’s three daughters.

headline: Quarterback? Jets Have Yet to Decide
abstract: The notion that the competition between Mark Sanchez and Geno Smith is, as the quarterbacks coach says, “too close to call” must be somewhat discouraging to the Jets.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — It is the eve of the Jets’ third preseason game, and according to the quarterbacks coach David Lee, they are not “near ready” to announce a starter. That sentence is presented without comment or judgment, merely a declaration of fact, but it is fair to consider Lee’s choice of words.

headline: Summer of the Big Dud
abstract: Will this summer’s string of bloated, mega-million dollar movie disasters stop Hollywood from making so many bad movies? Probably not.
lead_paragraph: You could hope, after some of the loudest, costliest and most joyless products of the entertainment-industrial complex bombed this summer, that Hollywood would be having its Detroit gas-guzzler moment. That is, the point when a cobwebbed institution realizes that its main product is yesterday.

headline: Britain’s Brussels Syndrome
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: What The Daily Mail hates is not Brussels, but today’s Britain.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The basic tenet of The Daily Mail is that Britain is not what it was (true enough, it isn’t) and that it would go a long way toward recovering its gritty greatness without wind farms, safety obsessions, green lunacy, overregulation and — above all — the European Union with its meddling bureaucrats.

headline: Young Immigrants Protest Deportations
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Deportation', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The protests are creating awkward dilemmas for Obama administration officials who are pressing the House of Representatives to pass broad immigration legislation this fall.
lead_paragraph: Young immigrants in the country illegally have escalated their protests against deportations this week, creating awkward dilemmas for Obama administration officials who are pressing the House of Representatives to pass broad immigration legislation this fall.

headline: This Age of Bubbles
keywords: ['Interest Rates', 'Credit and Debt', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Why do markets keep going wild? The answer is a variant on the same old story.
lead_paragraph: So, another BRIC hits the wall. Actually, I’ve never much liked the whole “BRIC” — Brazil, Russia, India, and China — concept: Russia, which is basically a petro-economy, doesn’t belong there at all, and there are large differences among the other three. Still, it’s hard to deny that India, Brazil, and a number of other countries are now experiencing similar problems. And those shared problems define the economic crisis du jour.

headline: Studio Has No Right to Bias, Court Rules
keywords: ['Photography', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The New Mexico Supreme Court said Thursday that the First Amendment did not permit a photography studio to reject a same-sex couple’s commitment ceremony.
lead_paragraph: The New Mexico Supreme Court on Thursday affirmed a decision against a photography studio that was sued after refusing to photograph a same-sex couple’s commitment ceremony in 2006, saying the First Amendment does not permit businesses that offer services for a profit to choose whom to serve.

headline: British Player Finds a Home as Stephens’s Hitting Partner
abstract: A promising junior, Andy Fitzpatrick has been forced to put his career on hold on several occasions for financial reasons. Now he earns a living as part of Sloane Stephens’s team.
lead_paragraph: Andy Fitzpatrick is not used to such plush surroundings. Fitzpatrick, a British player ranked 620th, acknowledged that he felt a little out of place in the pampered environment of a high-level WTA tournament as he assisted Sloane Stephens with her United States Open preparations at the New Haven Open this week.

headline: It’s All About Mao
abstract: The trial of the fallen Chinese official Bo Xilai highlights the urgent issue of whether China’s leaders will revive the disastrous tactics and policies of Chairman Mao.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The trial of Bo Xilai, the fallen Chinese Communist Party official and former member of the ruling Politburo, is attracting the world’s attention with its tales of corruption, sex, murder and political intrigue. But while such details are riveting, they divert attention from the real meaning of the case.

headline: Will a Boycott Help Russia’s Gays?
abstract: Responding to an Op-Ed article about the merits of boycotting Russian vodka, readers examine ways to change Russia’s antigay policies.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Golf’s Sound Check: At Tournaments, Loud Fans Are Getting Louder
abstract: Tournaments used to be quiet affairs. No more, as fans fill the silence after players’ swings with inane remarks that disrupt their concentration and grate on their nerves.
lead_paragraph: JERSEY CITY — For 12 days, the storm had been brewing. Not the thunder and lightning and rain that suspended play for six hours Thursday at Liberty National Golf Club. No, it was the outburst by Ian Poulter on Twitter after the P.G.A. Championship that some fans had been waiting to feast on, and at about dinnertime they finally got the opportunity.

headline: Iran Said to Pave Over Site Linked to Nuclear Talks
abstract: Iran put down asphalt over large sections of a military base, satellite images show, suggesting an attempt to sanitize a site where United Nations inspectors have tried to gain access.
lead_paragraph: Iran has paved over large swaths of a restricted military base that United Nations nuclear inspectors have sought unsuccessfully to visit for years because they suspect it was once a laboratory for testing weapons triggers, an antiproliferation monitoring group said Thursday in a study of new satellite imagery, suggesting the Iranians had tried to sanitize the site.

headline: Barclays Opens in 11-Hour Test for Woods
abstract: For Tiger Woods and the other golfers in the morning wave of the first FedEx Cup playoff event, the first round felt like the longest day of the year.
lead_paragraph: JERSEY CITY — Try telling the players with early tee times Thursday at the Barclays that the summer solstice was two months ago. For Tiger Woods, ranked No. 1, and the other golfers in the morning wave, the first round felt like the longest day of the year.

headline: A New F.B.I. Director Prepares to Take the Reins
abstract: James B. Comey is likely to spend the next year dealing with the impact of the automatic budget cuts, according to current and former senior F.B.I. officials.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — James B. Comey will begin shadowing the F.B.I. director, Robert S. Mueller III, next week as he prepares to take on the job himself.

headline: Doctors Seek a Partner to Keep a Hospital Open
abstract: Serious obstacles are anticipated in turning around Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Doctors from an embattled Brooklyn hospital are making a last-minute bid to take it over with the help of a white knight, a professional management company that they say would have the expertise to turn it around.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Suing the I.R.S. Back to Basics
keywords: ['Nonprofit Organizations', 'Internal Revenue Service Political Profiling', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: A lawsuit aims to end the charade that gives tax exemptions to partisan political groups posing as social welfare organizations.
lead_paragraph: The ease with which big-money donors are able to influence the nation’s politics is nowhere better illustrated than by the charade that gives tax exemptions to obviously partisan political groups posing as “social welfare” organizations. Representative Chris Van Hollen, a Maryland Democrat, thus merits thanks for his decision to sue the Internal Revenue Service to force it to end its controversial muddying of tax law that has allowed these groups to flourish.

headline: The Corpses in Syria
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations', 'Editorials']
abstract: A chemical attack, if proved, will require an aggressive response from the West.
lead_paragraph: The lifeless bodies depicted in photos and videos from Syria over the past two days suggest another chemical attack, quite possibly the deadliest single attack in more than two years of civil war. If the killings of an estimated 500 to 1,000 men, women and children outside of Damascus prove to be the work of President Bashar al-Assad’s cutthroat regime, as many suspect, the United States and other major powers will almost certainly have to respond much more aggressively than they have so far.

headline: A Federal Prod to Lower College Costs
abstract: President Obama’s proposal for a rating system, if properly designed, could make the cost of college more affordable.
lead_paragraph: President Obama has been accused of promoting small-ball ideas in his second term, but the proposal he unveiled on Thursday is a big one: using sharp federal pressure to make college more affordable, potentially opening the gates of higher education to more families scared off by rising tuitions. While there are questions to be answered about his plan, his approach — tying federal student aid to the value of individual colleges — is a bold and important way to leverage the government’s power and get Washington off the sidelines.

headline: ESPN Quits Film Project on Concussions in N.F.L.
abstract: Citing a lack of editorial control, ESPN ended its collaboration with the public affairs series “Frontline” on a two-part documentary set to run in October.
lead_paragraph: ESPN on Thursday ended its official association with “Frontline,” the public television public affairs series, on a two-part documentary about concussions in the N.F.L. that is scheduled to be televised in October. After 15 months on the venture, ESPN chose to strip its name, logo and credit from the films, “League of Denial: The NFL’s Concussion Crisis.”

headline: Area 51, Where Conspiracy Theories Never Get Old
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Extraterrestrial Life', 'Unidentified Flying Objects (UFO)']
abstract: C.I.A. released a classified report telling what everyone already knows: There is a secret military testing base at Groom Lake called Area 51.
lead_paragraph: C.I.A. released a classified report telling what everyone already knows: There is a secret military testing base at Groom Lake called Area 51.

headline: For This Farcical Romp, Use Your Allusion
abstract: At Penguin Rep Theater, “Drop Dead Perfect” playfully gives nods to 1950s television, pulp novels, Hitchcock and more.
lead_paragraph: You’ll never again look at a sandwich cookie in quite the same way — not after you see what happens to the ones served up in the seaside cottage of rich, dotty Idris Seabright. But don’t expect me to tell you why. The funniest lines and most outrageous moments in the new play at Penguin Rep Theater, Erasmus Fenn’s “Drop Dead Perfect,” can’t be properly described in a family newspaper.

headline: C.I.A. Acknowledges Area 51 Exists, but What About Those Little Green Men?
keywords: ['Extraterrestrial Life', 'Unidentified Flying Objects (UFO)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: Extraterrestrials’ big cultural moment may have come and gone, but for residents of a remote corner of Nevada, mysteries and conspiracy theories never go out of style.
lead_paragraph: RACHEL, Nev. — The Little A’Le’Inn has been an unlikely tourist destination in the Mojave Desert for nearly 25 years, selling souvenirs — from green alien coffee cups to E.T. Highway T-shirts — dedicated to the notion that we are not alone. Understandably.

headline: Can Egypt Learn From Thailand?
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat"]
abstract: Yingluck Shinawatra has made an unstable nation into a success story.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK was rocked by anti-government demonstrations earlier this month — once a depressingly familiar sight.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, August 23, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Friday, August 23, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “You have a very Rube Goldberg system. We’ve just put patches on it without attacking the basic problems.”

headline: Clock Is Ticking for Recess, and for a Deficit Deal
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy', 'National Debt (US)']
abstract: Talks between the White House and Senate Republicans have gone nowhere this summer, increasing the likelihood of a government shutdown this fall.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Budget talks between the White House and Senate Republicans have gone nowhere since Congress began its summer recess, increasing chances of a fiscal stalemate that could lead to a government shutdown in October or the threat of a government default later in the fall.

headline: ‘He’? ‘She’? News Media Are Encouraged to Change
abstract: News organizations were divided in their handling of a request that they now refer to Pfc. Bradley Manning as a woman.
lead_paragraph: It was an announcement that left typically agile news presenters, reporters and editors stumbling over their words on Thursday: the lawyer for Pfc. Bradley Manning told the “Today” show that his client would like to be considered a woman and referred to as Chelsea.

headline: Keeping Track of the Candidates for Mayor, One Parade at a Time
abstract: The New York City mayoral hopefuls’ more than 3,200 events suggest trends and personal preferences, as well as offer a window into the art of campaign scheduling.
lead_paragraph: For months now, about a dozen mayoral hopefuls have been running around New York City, popping up at candidate screenings, forums and subway stations. Recently, one candidate even passed out cookies at a senior center.

headline: Corrections: August 23, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on August 23, 2013.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Pack Your Bags
abstract: A lot of originality from Ian Livengood.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Happy Friday, everybody! This fresh puzzle from Ian Livengood is appropriate to kick off the weekend because it has all the ingredients of a getaway trip. There’s a string of clues about transportation, food, and exotic locales. Let’s take a look.

headline: Big Name Is Leaving Boies’s Firm After a Year
abstract: David M. Bernick will move to the Dechert firm, a transition that reflects a developing era of free agency in the once-stable world of corporate law, where partners commonly switch firms, sometimes for millions of dollars.
lead_paragraph: Last August, when the renowned trial lawyer David Boies announced the hiring of David M. Bernick, general counsel at the tobacco giant Philip Morris, he called the move a “huge step” for his firm, Boies Schiller & Flexner.

headline: U.S. Blacklists 4 Senior Hezbollah Officials

headline: Jimmy Connors, Ladies’ Man
abstract: He learned to play a “woman’s game” to beat men. Apparently it wasn’t enough to help him last more than one match as Maria Sharapova’s coach.
lead_paragraph: Technically, Jimmy Connors wasn’t the most overwhelming player. He was on the slight side; his serve was so-so, his forehand questionable. His only truly great stroke was his two-handed backhand. That he managed to win eight Grand Slam events (five U.S. Opens, two Wimbledons and one Australian Open), spend 160 consecutive weeks at No. 1 (1974-77) and rack up a record 109 career singles titles (John McEnroe and Roger Federer each have 77; Rafael Nadal has 58) is a testament, in large part, to a relentless and, at times, all-consuming will. This trait goes a long way toward explaining Connors’s most quietly astounding feat: for 16 years, he held a Top 10 ranking. In an era when tennis careers can flame out over a half-dozen seasons, Connors — who on his 39th birthday won a fourth-round U.S. Open match against the 24-year-old Aaron Krickstein in 4 hours 41 minutes — looks, in retrospect, more and more like a freak of nature or nurture or both.

Twice a day, they descend on unmarked bus stops off Main Street to secure a $15 seat to the Sands casino in Bethlehem, Pa. Many do not gamble. They make the trip solely for the free gambling and meal vouchers they receive when they arrive, coupons they sell on the black market. A half-day trip to the Sands can net around $40.

headline: Who Made That Picnic?
abstract: The evolution of the movable feast.
lead_paragraph: “It’s part of our DNA,” says Walter Levy, author of “The Picnic: A History,” who points out that “picniclike” events appear in the writings of Ovid, Plutarch and Seneca. The word “picnic,” however, is of more recent vintage. An early mention can be traced to a 1649 satirical French poem, which features the Frères Pique-nicques, known for visiting friends “armed with bottles and dishes.” In 1802, the term made a hop to Britain after a group of Francophiles in London formed a Pic-Nic Society to gorge, guzzle and perform amateur theatricals. Participants drew lots to determine who would supply which dish — from calf’s-foot jelly to blancmange. “Depending on your luck,” Levy says, “you might have to bring something expensive, like pie made from truffles.”

abstract: A 1935 article about that year’s U.S. Open in Forest Hills, Queens.
lead_paragraph: This article originally appeared in print on Sep. 1, 1935, and is excerpted, along with other tennis writing from the archives, in the August 25, 2013, issue of the magazine.

headline: Plays Tennis Like a Man, Speaks Out Like — Billie Jean King
abstract: A 1967 article about the 23-year-old who was then the No. 1 women’s tennis player in the world.
lead_paragraph: This article originally appeared in print on Aug. 27, 1967, and is excerpted, along with other tennis writing from the archives, in the Aug. 25, 2013, issue of the magazine.

headline: Twice Was Not a Charm for Bars Run by Stringer
abstract: Scott M. Stringer took over management of a Manhattan bar called Simon Sez in the fall of 1990, but it closed after a dispute with the landlord.
lead_paragraph: As a young man, Scott M. Stringer tried and failed to turn a ramshackle Manhattan saloon into a thriving establishment, eventually abandoning the effort in the wake of disputed bills and a displeased landlord.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: In researching “The Sports Gene,” David Epstein found a surprisingly prosaic explanation for Jamaica’s outsize domination in track.
lead_paragraph: COOL RUNNINGS: In “The Sports Gene,” David Epstein, a senior writer at Sports Illustrated, investigates whether there are natural-born athletes among us, just biologically built for speed and endurance. It’s a topic he’s been thinking about since he ran track in high school and college and was handily outpaced by Jamaican and Kenyan runners.

headline: Singapore Is The New Chile
abstract: Another free-market paragon bites the dust.
lead_paragraph: Remember the 2005 Social Security debate? George W. Bush had just been returned to office; his campaign was focused on national security and social issues — as I like to say, he ran as America’s defender against gay married terrorists — but as soon as the returns were in, he declared that he had a mandate to … privatize Social Security.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE GOOD LORD BIRD,  by James McBride (Riverhead, $27.95.) McBride’s romp of a novel, narrated by a freed slave boy who passes as a girl, is a risky portrait of the radical abolitionist John Brown in which irreverence becomes a new form of homage.

headline: Beyond Windows XP
abstract: Upgrading from Windows XP before security support ends.
lead_paragraph: Q. I keep reading warnings about Windows XP getting retired next year with no more security updates. I don’t like the look of Windows 8, but if I upgrade to Windows 7, how long will that system be supported?

headline: Thriving on Chaos, Manziel Shocks a Traditional System
abstract: Johnny Manziel’s style, rooted in improvisation and individualism, is challenging a tradition of institutional dominance valued by Nick Saban and Alabama.
lead_paragraph: AS BIG-TIME COLLEGE FOOTBALL has grown into a multisponsored, million-footed behemoth, the urge to reduce each season to a few personalities has become ever more absurd, and more necessary. You have to believe there are some actual people under all those piles of money.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review:  ‘The Smartest Kids in the World’ by Amanda Ripley
abstract: This week, Annie Murphy Paul on “The Smartest Kids in the World” by Amanda Ripley, and Cris Beam discusses “To the End of June,” her book about America’s foster care system. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Annie Murphy Paul on “The Smartest Kids in the World” by Amanda Ripley, and Cris Beam discusses “To the End of June,” her book about America’s foster care system. Pamela Paul is the host.

abstract: Ben Affleck moves back into blockbuster territory after focusing on smaller dramas, like the Oscar-winning best picture “Argo.”.
lead_paragraph: The fanboy corner of the Internet collectively fainted late Thursday when Warner Brothers put an end to wild casting rumors and said that Ben Affleck would play Batman in a “Man of Steel” sequel.

headline: Trouble in Mind
abstract: An 18-year-old plans a murder-suicide in Matthew Quick’s young adult novel.
lead_paragraph: On the morning Leonard Peacock, the high school narrator of Matthew Quick’s young adult novel, prepares a murder-suicide, he packs the Nazi pistol his grandfather brought back from the war and starts his school day with a plan. It is his 18th birthday. He is targeting his onetime best friend. Creeping through the morning with this secret knowledge, he attempts to reconcile the lives that have gone wrong around him, and to savor the freedom that comes from his imminent demise.

headline: Hidden Truths
abstract: Two books consider the lasting legacy of Leo Strauss.
lead_paragraph: When Leo Strauss died in 1973 he was virtually unknown outside the tiny academic circle that he inhabited. Forty years later his name and influence are known almost everywhere. His books and articles have been translated into nearly every European language and several Asian ones. Web sites — both pro and con — are devoted to him. International conferences debate his thought and legacy.

headline: Russia, With Love
abstract: Two young women become entangled in cold war intrigue.
lead_paragraph: When I lived in Moscow in my 20s, I’d often pass nervous young men standing in the metro station, holding flowers and waiting for their dates to show up. Meeting in the metro was a Russian tradition, and like Russia itself it seemed exotic, romantic and rife with drama. I arrived in tears to several of my own rendezvous because of confusion over the Cyrillic-only metro signs, and I missed others entirely.

headline: The Art of Fitting In
abstract: Two novels chart the difficult terrain known as high school.
lead_paragraph: Like the lead characters in two new books about navigating the dynamics of high school society — Caprice Crane’s “Confessions of a Hater” and Bridie Clark’s “Snap Decision: Maybe Tonight?” — I was a bit of a fish out of water as a teenager. But there’s something about those uncomfortable years that draws me, like many adults, back to them — at least as a reader. The perspective of these novels is subtle enough to be engrossing for both teenagers and adults for whom high school’s intense friendships and antipathies still resonate. And how could they not?

headline: What the Dickens
abstract: A reader responds to a recent review of Jenni Fagan’s “Panopticon.”

abstract: New books by Kate Christensen, Sheri Booker, Katie Hafner and Clare Balding.
lead_paragraph: BLUE PLATE SPECIAL  An Autobiography of My Appetites  By Kate Christensen  Doubleday, $26.95.

headline: Dreaming With Van Gogh
abstract: New apps include an enhanced version of the classic art-education text “Interaction of Color” and new ways to learn about Van Gogh.
lead_paragraph: Art and art history are two subject areas in which certain electronic textbooks are not only convenient, but sometimes more effective as learning tools. Who wants merely to read about pigment-mixing without trying it, or to squint at a tiny printed reproduction of a still life by Pieter Claesz — an artist who was sharing pictures of food centuries before Instagram was invented — instead of popping open a full-screen version to better study the composition?

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: EVERY LOVE STORY IS A GHOST STORY: A Life of David Foster Wallace,  by D. T. Max. (Penguin, $17.) Wallace, who committed suicide in 2008 at age 46, compiled a vibrant body of work: short fiction and novels — including the magnum opus “Infinite Jest” — as well as long-form journalism about subjects ranging from tennis to politics to lobsters. Max’s biography offers a deeply sympathetic appraisal, tracing Wallace’s success as a writer and his battles against depression and addiction.

headline: Away From Home
abstract: Cris Beam reports on America’s complicated foster care system.
lead_paragraph: Early in Cris Beam’s remarkable new book, she outlines what she calls the core questions at the heart of America’s foster care system: “Who decides the correct way to raise a child? Who makes the moves on the moral chessboard where a family’s right to privacy opposes a child’s right to protection from harm? And who should get to keep a child: the parents who nurse and tend to him, or the parents who brought him into this world?”

headline: Voice of the Voiceless
abstract: A memoir of living with autism, by Naoki Higashida, a Japanese 13-year-old.
lead_paragraph: Autism is an endless mystery, largely unknowable by its nature, yet there are dozens of books by or about autistic people determined to explain the lives of those affected. The newest is “The Reason I Jump,” popular in Japan since it was published in 2007. The author, Naoki Higashida, was 13 years old at the time he wrote the memoir, and nonverbal. He wrote by spelling out words on a Japanese alphabet letter board.

headline: Bookshelf: Dinosaurs
abstract: New picture books, including David Ezra Stein’s “Dinosaur Kisses.”
lead_paragraph: New picture books, including David Ezra Stein’s “Dinosaur Kisses.”

headline: Poetic Virtues
abstract: James Longenbach’s latest essay collection and Fani Papageorgiou’s first book of poems, “When You Said No, Did You Mean Never?”
lead_paragraph: The audience for poetry is like a vastly reduced version of the audience for college football — superstitious, gossipy and divided into factions no less fervent for having only an occasional idea of what’s going on outside their own campuses. It’s a hard crowd to write for, and the critic who sets himself up as a color commentator inevitably struggles to find a style that can please Peter without needlessly riling up Paul.

headline: Outside the Lines
abstract: From a Chinese master to rebellious crayons, these picture books affirm the inspirational power of art.
lead_paragraph: Ask a group of kindergartners how many of them are artists and every child will enthusiastically raise a hand. Ask that same question to progressively older groups of kids and the numbers of artists will diminish with each advancing grade, until in high school only a few ink-stained hands rise from the fringes.

headline: Bookshelf: Dinosaurs
abstract: New picture books include “Dinosaur Kisses,” in which an irrepressible baby dinosaur sets out on a mission.
lead_paragraph: DINOSAUR KISSES  Written and illustrated by David Ezra Stein. 32 pp. Candlewick Press. $15.99. (Picture book; ages 2 to 5)

headline: Solitary Creatures
abstract: The lonely heroine of this graphic novel finds a kindred spirit in Jane Eyre.
lead_paragraph: The first illustrations in the Canadian author Fanny Britt’s graphic novel, “Jane, the Fox and Me,” are of a school’s large campus, with buildings, stairways, paths, shadows, scattered trees, even a far-off forest and this line: “There was no possibility of hiding anywhere today.”

headline: Bookshelf: Sleep
abstract: “Lena’s Sleep Sheep,” by Anita Lobel, and more.
lead_paragraph: “Lena’s Sleep Sheep,” by Anita Lobel, and more.

headline: Bait and Switch
abstract: In “A Tap on the Window,” by Linwood Barclay, a private investigator in a small town finds himself in the middle of a political smackdown.
lead_paragraph: The term “thriller” usually triggers an image of some drooling serial killer who does unspeakable things to the women he holds captive on his pig farm. Or some mad hacker who has programmed a computer virus to reroute all your e-mails to Wiki­Leaks. Less likely to come to mind is a small town where high school seniors selling booze to underage juniors constitutes a crime wave. That’s the context of Linwood Barclay’s new mystery, A TAP ON THE WINDOW (New American Library, $25.95), and, yes, it’s a killer of a thriller.

headline: Bookshelf: Sleep
abstract: “Lena’s Sleep Sheep,” Anita Lobel’s book about a little girl helped to sleep by some woolly thinkers, and more.
lead_paragraph: LENA’S SLEEP SHEEP  A Going-to-Bed Book  By Anita Lobel.  24 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $11.99. (Picture book; ages 2 to 5)

headline: Bookshelf: Issues
abstract: “Noni Is Nervous,” by Heather Hartt-Sussman, and more.
lead_paragraph: “Noni Is Nervous,” by Heather Hartt-Sussman, and more.

headline: Bad Behavior
abstract: In four picture books, a menagerie of creatures teaches lessons on making friends and getting along.
lead_paragraph: No child (except yours and mine) is nice all the time. But we don’t look the other way anymore when children are mean. Four new picture books about bullying substitute animals for children. This charming menagerie lightens things up, allows us to laugh, and sometimes sneaks in — or rams through — a valuable lesson.

headline: Alpha Dogs, Underdogs
abstract: In two middle-grade novels, social position is a powerful weapon.
lead_paragraph: The movie “Mean Girls” is nearly a decade old, but the “burn book” at the center of Tina Fey’s screenplay remains an evergreen plot device. Mostly written by the popular girls, these burn books are public logs of carefully calculated insults lobbed at social rivals and undesirables. Like everything else in the past 10 years, the burn book has moved online, and Facebook and Tumblr are littered with hateful messages written by aggressive tweens.

headline: Meryl as Mary
abstract: Meryl Streep narrates the audiobook of Colm Toibin’s “Testament of Mary.”
lead_paragraph: “The Testament of Mary,” Colm Toibin’s novel and play about the mother of Jesus, has been blessed in its interpreters. When Fiona Shaw played the role on Broadway, Toibin praised her “commitment to theater at its most pure and risky and dangerous.” Now Meryl Streep has narrated the audiobook, due out Sept. 10. No word yet on whether Toibin’s work will also make it to the big screen or whether Shaw and Streep will compete for the part.

headline: Gifted and Talented
abstract: Six middle schoolers participate in a secret training program to fight evil.
lead_paragraph: I wanted to hate this book. After all, this was a book for children, and I don’t do children’s books. I was totally lost by Page 2 of the preface — wondering what a Zilchbot was (12 dozen of them were attacking Captain Marvelous and his friends) and why I should care about Kid Caliber or the Diamond Dame (heroes trapped in the Nulzone). As for Captain Marvelous, he seemed like a vanilla remake — a rip-off, really — of Superman, from the big red “M” on his chest to his ruby red cape and captaincy of the Legion of Justice. I am an authority on the Man of Steel, having written a full-fledged biography of him. “I know Superman, Superman is a friend of mine,” I was tempted to write to the author, John David Anderson, “and Mr. Anderson, Captain Marvelous is no Superman!”

headline: Family Stories
abstract: Three picture books capture the objects and incidents that form a child’s heritage.
lead_paragraph: What parent wasn’t thrilled to hear about the Emory University study suggesting that children who are told stories about their families’ pasts may develop a greater ability to cope with the vicissitudes of life? But most children’s books that convey a sense of family history and tradition — “All-of-a-Kind Family,” “Little House in the Big Woods” — are written with the older child in mind. Younger children are more likely to learn the day-to-day habits of rabbits, monkeys and bears. So it’s refreshing to find three new picture books that take as their subject the stories of human families, illuminating the ways certain rituals — along with sayings, jokes, pastimes and world views — get passed down through the generations.

headline: Escaping the Past
abstract: Fleeing her troubled homeland, a Liberian woman seeks refuge on an Aegean island.
lead_paragraph: Can the literary novel ever really get its arms around the problem of human evil? It keeps trying — a difficult assignment for the poor beast. In any case, an undaunted Alexander Maksik has brought his skills to this very problem. His second novel, “A Marker to Measure Drift,” recounts a season of homeless exile in the life of a 24-year-old Liberian woman fleeing an episode of gruesome violence incidental to the overthrow of the tyrant Charles Ghankay Taylor, in 2003. Maksik has produced a bold book, and an instructive one.

headline: Bookshelf: Issues
abstract: New picture books about facing concerns at the dawn of a new school year.
lead_paragraph: NONI IS NERVOUS  By Heather Hartt-Sussman.Illustrated by Geneviève Côté. 24 pp. Tundra Books. $17.95. (Picture book; ages 2 to 5)

headline: A Nose for Words
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'SAT (College Admission Test)', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Developing a love of language, with a little help from Stanley H. Kaplan.
lead_paragraph: The day John Lennon was shot, just across the park from where I attended high school, was also the day my P.S.A.T. scores came in. The news wasn’t good. The problem was my vocabulary; I didn’t know enough words. And so, while the rest of the world was laying flowers at the Dakota, I found myself at the Stanley H. Kaplan Educational Center, where, for 10 Sundays, I was enrolled in reform school.

headline: Constant Acquisition at Microsoft, and One Deal That Didn’t Close
abstract: By announcing his departure as Microsoft’s chief executive, Steven Ballmer has signaled an impending end to one of the most prolific deal-making streaks in technology over the past two decades. But his record is as much notable for its misses as its hits.
lead_paragraph: With his impending departure as Microsoft’s chief executive, Steven A. Ballmer has put an expiration date on one of the most prolific deal-making streaks in technology over the last two decades.

headline: Study Suggests Shift in Fed Bond-Buying
abstract: The Federal Reserve should keep buying mortgage bonds even as it stops buying Treasuries, and even as it sells off its existing holdings of both, two economists have concluded.
lead_paragraph: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo. — A new study finds that the Federal Reserve should keep buying mortgage-backed securities even as it stops buying Treasury securities, and even as it sells off its existing holding of Treasuries and mortgage bonds.

lead_paragraph: LONDON – The nationalized bank ABN Amro moved a step closer to the public markets on Friday after the Dutch government said it would seek an initial public offering for the bank.

abstract: Help to Buy, in which the government either offers interest-free credit or guarantees part of the property loan, has come under criticism from those who say it could create a real estate bubble.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Depending on where one stands in the debate on the rising cost of housing in Britain, Paul Thomas and Abigail Walker, first-time home buyers, are either part of the solution or part of the problem.

headline: A Guessing Game for Taxpayers on What They Owe
keywords: ['Federal Taxes (US)', 'Rebates and Refunds', 'ACCOUNTING AND ACCOUNTANTS', 'ALTERNATIVE MINIMUM TAX', 'Personal Finances', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Income Tax']
abstract: With the next estimated tax payment around the corner, here are some tips to avoid overpaying.
lead_paragraph: WHEN it comes to income taxes, my wife and I try to pay exactly what we owe. And by this I mean we try to calculate what we need to pay during the year so we do not overpay. We would rather owe a bit more in April than find out we are getting a refund.

headline: 50 Years After March, Views of Fitful Progress
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'National Mall (Washington, DC)', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: For Daniel R. Smith, 81, who attended the March on Washington in 1963, the country has a ways to go in realizing the dream of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Daniel R. Smith was born dirt poor more than three-quarters of a century ago, there were only about 20 other blacks in his small Connecticut town. His own father had been born a slave in Virginia in 1862. Mr. Smith served as a medic in Korea in the years just after the Army had been desegregated.

headline: Second Term Playbook: Impeach
abstract: Senator Tom Coburn is the latest Republican to muse idly about impeaching the president at a public forum.
lead_paragraph: The G.O.P. failed to unseat President Obama in last November’s election, and “birther” fantasies of invalidating his presidency on technical grounds have gone nowhere. So the Republicans have pulled out their second-term playbook from the Clinton years, and are now gossiping about impeachment.

lead_paragraph: The new Benjamin Franklin Museum opens on Saturday in Independence National Historical Park in Philadelphia, with 21st-century hands-on exhibits and computer simulations designed to animate the character and wisdom of the 18th-century sage.

headline: The Impala Regains Its Swagger
abstract: Chevy’s latest Impala harks back to the nameplate’s ’60s heyday, when it was the quintessential big, stylish American family car.
lead_paragraph: Chevy’s latest Impala harks back to the nameplate’s ’60s heyday, when it was the quintessential big, stylish American family car.

headline: For America’s Sedan, a Great Leap Forward
abstract: The Impala, once the darling of rental-car fleets, has been redesigned for 2014 and is now a car that can be seriously mentioned in the same context as the Toyota Avalon or Dodge Charger.
lead_paragraph: My wife used to work as a sales representative for Johnson & Johnson. Like many sales reps, she was provided a nondescript, inexpensive company car — in her case, a Chevrolet Impala. At some point, the “a” fell off the trunk badge and we began calling it the “Impal.” The Impal’s chief virtue was its huge trunk, which could conceal many cases of sample products — typically, Tylenol PM and K-Y jelly. Say what you want about the old Impala, but it sure could haul some K-Y jelly. General Motors should have made a bigger deal of that.

headline: Review: 2014 Chevrolet Impala
abstract: Chevrolet aims to rid the Impala of its rental-car reputation with distinctive new styling. Tom Voelk drives the 2014 model to see if the changes to this full-size sedan are more than skin deep.
lead_paragraph: Chevrolet aims to rid the Impala of its rental-car reputation with distinctive new styling. Tom Voelk drives the 2014 model to see if the changes to this full-size sedan are more than skin deep.

headline: For Two Female News Anchors, Morning Has Spoken
abstract: Their news shows may be over for the day, but for Gayle King and Mika Brzezinski, there’s still plenty to talk about.
lead_paragraph: When you wake up at 3:30 a.m. to go to a job that starts in the predawn hours, lunch comes early. So, on a recent weekday morning at 10:45, Gayle King, one of the hosts of “CBS This Morning,” and Mika Brzezinski, the sparring partner of Joe Scarborough on “Morning Joe” on MSNBC, came together at Gotham Lounge at the Peninsula Hotel, dressed in near-matching green sheathes and very high heels, to share a midday meal (burrata and chicken Caesar salad for Ms. King; burrata and hot-and-sour soup for Ms. Brzezinski; freshly squeezed orange juice for both) and to talk about the demands of morning television, the roles of male and female anchors and not knowing who Russell Brand is.

headline: The Jazzman With a Debt to Nashville
abstract: The Grammy-winning jazz vibraphonist Gary Burton has a new autobiography, “Learning to Listen,” and a new album.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH YARMOUTH, Mass. — There’s a moment in “Learning to Listen: The Jazz Journey of Gary Burton,” an autobiography due out on Sept. 3 from Berklee Press, that depicts the author’s earliest encounter with Miles Davis. It happened at a summer jazz festival in Mr. Burton’s home state, Indiana, and probably could have gone a little better.

headline: I Love You, Mom, but Hear My Record
abstract: On his latest, perhaps most personal album, “Sleeper,” Ty Segall switches from a raucous mood to the gently psychedelic.
lead_paragraph: It’s pretty easy to spot Ty Segall’s influences. This singer-songwriter, raised in Laguna Beach, Calif., has Neil Young’s name tattooed on his right arm and the logo from Black Sabbath’s 1972 album “Vol. 4” inked on his left. His music is likewise a recognizable combination of disparate sources, displaying a remarkable ability to synthesize different elements of pre-1980s rock — heavy ’60s garage-rock riffs, harmonies that evoke the Beatles or early Tyrannosaurus Rex, and a punk velocity — into fresh and catchy pop nuggets.

headline: 10 Weeks, 5,446 Entries: Reflections on the 2013 Summer Reading Contest
abstract: A thank you to the students and teachers who participated and the organizations that judged — and some logistical tips for students about how to prove you participated when you’re back in school.
lead_paragraph: We knew it was shaping up to be the most successful year yet for the New York Times Summer Reading Contest, but until we closed the final post and did the math, we didn’t realize just how successful.

headline: City’s Annual Cost Per Inmate Is $168,000, Study Finds
abstract: Over 12,000 people were held in New York City jails last year, according to the Independent Budget Office, with the city spending more per inmate than any other state or city.
lead_paragraph: New York City is an expensive place to live for just about everyone, including prisoners.

headline: How Fights Over Fixtures Can Derail a Closing
abstract: With significant sums about to change hands, last-minute negotiations can turn into a tug of war over what comes with a property and what doesn’t.
lead_paragraph: Even at their smoothest, residential real estate closings are not for the faint of heart. At stake is nothing less than the roof over the buyer’s head, but the repercussions can be primal when, just before the culmination of a deal worth hundreds of thousands or, in many instances, millions of dollars, weeks of negotiations unravel when the buyer and seller suddenly squabble over who gets custody of something as inconsequential as a $150 ceiling fan.

headline: New York City’s Jail Population: Who’s There and Why?
abstract: The New York City Independent Budget Office released findings on the prison population.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Independent Budget Office released findings on the prison population.

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Early on in the new movie “Short Term 12,” teenagers living in a group home gather, as Nate, a neatly dressed young counselor with a nervous smile, introduces himself.

headline: Hey, Ludwig, There’s an App for You
abstract: The Curtis Institute of Music offers an online course in Beethoven, and an app on the Ninth Symphony has sold hundreds of thousands of copies. Are purists embracing the computer?
lead_paragraph: At the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia, as at many schools around the United States, students will flock to classes this fall to begin a new academic year. Though “flock” may not be the right word for Curtis, with its minuscule current student body of 171.

headline: Roger Federer Can Still Get His Game Face On
abstract: But has tennis left him behind?
lead_paragraph: On the first Wednesday of Wimbledon this June, under a bright early-evening sky, Roger Federer trailed two sets to one in his second-round match against Sergiy Stakhovsky, a Ukrainian ranked 116th in the world and best known until that point for pulling out his cellphone during a match to take a photograph of a disputed ball mark. But Stakhovsky had played imposing serve-and-volley tennis, a style seldom seen nowadays, and as the fourth set unfolded on Center Court, it became clear that he was not going to succumb to nerves. Federer, 31 and seeking a record eighth Wimbledon title, would have to contrive an escape.

headline: When You Can’t Forget the Gifts You Didn’t Get
abstract: In the hierarchy of social transgressions, the wedding gift omission, for some, is a sin of the highest order, the cause of relationship breakdowns and resentment.
lead_paragraph: Lisa Kaas Boyle, an environmental lawyer in Los Angeles, knows exactly who gave her what for her February 1994 wedding. The silver serving utensils? Courtesy of Uncle Michael. The magnificent Waterford vase with the doors of Ireland etched into the crystal? That came from Jimmy Murakami, the Oscar-nominated animator.

lead_paragraph: NYT developers share their recommendations from around the web.
