abstract: Philip-Lorca diCorcia’s “Hustlers” photographic series, first shown at MoMA in 1993 and soon to be displayed in Chelsea, occupy a gray zone between fact and fiction.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1990s, the photographer Philip-Lorca diCorcia made five trips to Los Angeles to pick up male prostitutes in Hollywood. Cruising down a seedy stretch of Santa Monica Boulevard, where young men loitered suggestively by the curb, he would slow down in his rental car when he saw a likely prospect.

headline: Fantasy Football: Answers to Reader Questions
abstract: Is it time to take a running back, or a wide receiver? Jason and Justin Sablich answer such questions as readers prepare for their fantasy football drafts.
lead_paragraph: Jason and Justin Sablich will provide fantasy football advice throughout the 2013 season. Follow them on Twitter at @5thDownFantasy.

headline: Nixon’s Political Wisdom, Caught on Tape
abstract: The final batch of Richard Nixon’s secret and self-incriminating White House tape recordings have been released.
lead_paragraph: Our long audio nightmare is over. The final batch of Richard Nixon’s secret and self-incriminating White House tape recordings have been released. As in the 3,700 hours previously made public across the past 17 years, Nixon as president is there in all his cunning and self-pity —“Hamlet without the Prince,” in the description of Stanley Kutler, the historian who fought mightily to block Nixon and his loyalists from burying the tapes forever. They can be tedious listening, and it’s hard to judge what younger generations addicted to on-screen bursts of brevity will make of the 37th president’s schemes and maunderings amid the scandal known as Watergate. But they still offer an unparalleled voyeuristic fix, which had citizens lining up for hours to hear the initial batches played endlessly on 32 audio machines in Washington.

headline: Law School Applications Decline, Especially From Graduates of Elite Colleges
abstract: The decline in overall applications from 2008-12 was 17 percent, but among graduates of 20 top universities it was 28 percent.
lead_paragraph: We’ve written before about the declining interest in law school, as evidenced by the number of people taking the Law School Admission Test and the number applying to law schools. Over at the Associate’s Mind blog, Keith Lee notes that the number of applicants is down across the board, but the drop-off is particularly sharp among people who went to elite schools for their bachelor’s degrees.

headline: Popcast: Gary Burton, Resurgent Jazz Outsider
abstract: Ben Ratliff and Nate Chinen discuss the Grammy-winning jazz vibraphonist, who has a new autobiography and a new album.
lead_paragraph: If you’re only a casual listener to jazz, and not a vibraphonist, Gary Burton may not be a big name to you. But he’s probably had more to do with the development of jazz over the last 50 years than you think as a player (he developed the widely used four-mallet Burton Grip for the vibraphone); a mentor (to Pat Metheny, for starters); a conceptual inspiration (to Bill Frisell, among others, through the way he incorporated country and rock into his music during the late ’60s); and a longtime teacher and administrator at Berklee College of Music.

headline: Required U.S. Open Reading, Old and New
abstract: Great tennis writing from the magazine’s archive.
lead_paragraph: There is much to dread about late August: the heat, the humidity, those people who leave work at like 1 every Friday while you work normal hours. But there is at least one thing to look forward to: the magazine’s annual U.S. Open issue. You probably remember previous Open coverage from the magazine. There was John Jeremiah Sullivan’s article on Venus and Serena Williams, Andy Samberg’s re-enactments of iconic men’s championships and Dewey Nicks’s video gallery of women’s tennis stars. And then there’s the older stuff. Who could forget Harry Gordon on Arthur Ashe; Hal Higdon on Billie Jean King; or Allison Danzig on Helen Wills? Wait, did you forget them? Did you never know about them? Maybe that’s because those pieces, dating to 1928, do not exist on the Internet.

headline: Military Jury Convicts Army Psychiatrist on All 45 Counts in Fort Hood Rampage
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: A military jury convicted Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, an Army psychiatrist, on all counts in the 2009 shooting rampage at Fort Hood in which 13 people were killed and 32 wounded or shot at.
lead_paragraph: KILLEEN, Tex. — A military jury on Friday found Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan guilty of carrying out the largest mass murder at a military installation in American history.

headline: Some Stops on the March
abstract: In this 50th anniversary of a pivotal summer for racial equality, the Brooklyn Academy of Music has been offering A Time for Burning: Cinema of the Civil Rights Movement.
lead_paragraph: In this 50th anniversary of a pivotal summer for racial equality, the Brooklyn Academy of Music has been offering A Time for Burning: Cinema of the Civil Rights Movement, a series that wraps up with a well-known Hollywood movie and some less known historical offerings.

headline: Jacob’s Pillow, Ready for Rest
abstract: Dance lovers have one last chance to catch a performance at the Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival in Becket, Mass.
lead_paragraph: Dance lovers, you have one last chance, on Sunday, to catch a performance at the Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival in Becket, Mass., where the Martha Graham Dance Company and Kyle Abraham’s Abraham.In.Motion — both well worth a pilgrimage — close the season there.

headline: Bassoon Solos on the Water
abstract: The floating concert hall Bargemusic is possibly the cutest place in New York to hear music, and it is also one of the most adventurous.
lead_paragraph: The floating concert hall Bargemusic is possibly the cutest place in New York to hear music, and it is also one of the most adventurous; its Here and Now series is among the city’s most valuable homes of new and recent work. The programs are varied, the tickets reasonably priced, and the mood low key. The series gets a big showcase this week with its annual Labor Day festival, a motley assortment of sounds with an element of surprise. While a list of works has been published on the barge’s Web site, the program and performers will differ slightly for each of the four performances (Wednesday, Friday, Saturday at 8 p.m. and next Sunday at 2 p.m.).

headline: Sharp Lawyers, Willing to Cut
abstract: “Silk,” a “Masterpiece Mystery!” series beginning Sunday night on PBS, tracks, Martha Costello, a sharp-witted defense barrister in London portrayed by a crackling Maxine Peake.
lead_paragraph: It’s called “taking silk”: the merit-based appointment of a British lawyer as Queen’s Counsel, which confers the right to wear a specially designed silk gown in court (and, for ceremonial occasions, an even bigger wig). And in “Silk,” a “Masterpiece Mystery!” series beginning Sunday night on PBS, Martha Costello, a sharp-witted defense barrister in London portrayed by a crackling Maxine Peake, wants to take silk — badly. Already stretched thin, she strategically overloads on cases that could bolster her reputation and tutors an ambitious if occasionally bumbling pupil (Tom Hughes).

headline: Living Large at Yale Gallery
abstract: For such a populist, accessible and at times interactive artist, Red Grooms doesn’t get much respect or exposure these days.
lead_paragraph: For such a populist, accessible and at times interactive artist, Red Grooms doesn’t get much respect or exposure these days. His place in history rests mostly on his role in the invention of Happenings, less on his contribution as deviant, satirical Pop artist and latter-day American (art) Scene painter. Starting Friday, “Red Grooms: Larger Than Life” at the Yale University Art Gallery will feature Mr. Grooms’s forays into the history of modernism with a group of oversize paintings and drawings.

headline: Microcultures on the Island
abstract: Dance music is often depicted as some kind of monolith, and from a distance, Electric Zoo submits to the prevailing stereotype.
lead_paragraph: Dance music is often depicted as some kind of monolith, and from a distance, Electric Zoo — a multistage festival held on Randalls Island every Labor Day weekend, now in its fifth year — submits to the prevailing stereotype.

headline: In a Room to Talk
abstract: In times of crisis, it is perhaps better to listen to walls than climb them.
lead_paragraph: In times of crisis, it is perhaps better to listen to walls than climb them. Lauren Yee gives new and literal life to the hoary speculation “if only these walls could talk” in “The Hatmaker’s Wife,” which begins previews on Tuesday at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater. In it, a loquacious wall speaks up to offer advice and an, uh, ear to a commitment-challenged woman named Voice.

headline: A Conservative Catholic Now Backs Same-Sex Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: Joseph Bottum, in an essay in Commonweal magazine, writes about his change of heart on the issue, citing the “natural law” theology of Thomas Aquinas.
lead_paragraph: HOT SPRINGS, S.D. — In the past couple of years, conservative opposition to same-sex marriage has clearly started to erode. Prominent Republicans like Senators Rob Portman and Lisa Murkowski and former Secretary of State Colin L. Powell have come out in support of gay marriage. Even David Blankenhorn, the expert witness in the Proposition 8 trial in California and a Democrat, announced that he had changed his mind.

abstract: What a Russian official called evidence of Syria rebel propaganda on YouTube appears to be based on widespread confusion about how the video-sharing site, based in California, assigns dates to clips uploaded by users around the world.
lead_paragraph: Citing “reports circulating on the Internet,” a spokesman for Russia’s foreign ministry claimed on Friday that video posted online by opposition activists in Syria, said to show victims suffering from a chemical weapons strike outside Damascus on Wednesday, was fake.

lead_paragraph: Alpha Workshops trains New Yorkers with H.I.V. for jobs in artistic fields. A new wallpaper design, called Astral, shows just how spontaneous Alpha’s students can be. Artisans at the workshop fold 15-foot-long sheets of paper, then unfold them, spread them out, and apply paint with a sponge. The paint is caught in the peaks and valleys, and no two sheets are exactly alike.

headline: The Ad Campaign: Catsimatidis Goes on the Attack
abstract: Three weeks before the primary, John A. Catsimatidis has released two ads criticizing his main Republican rival, Joseph J. Lhota.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to his considerable fortune, John A. Catsimatidis has been a steady presence on television as he seeks the Republican nomination for mayor. His advertisements so far have touted his rags-to-riches biography and his commitment to public safety. Now, three weeks before the primary, he is going on the attack against his main Republican rival, Joseph J. Lhota. Mr. Lhota is the focus of a 30-second commercial, “3 Things,” that began airing Friday. A second new commercial, “Cares About Us,” also criticizes Mr. Lhota.

headline: Play Misty for Me
abstract: Casamista, a portable humidifier, is made of molded satin-textured plastic, has a purifying filter and will fit on top of any water bottle or glass.
lead_paragraph: When designing Casamista, a portable humidifier produced by Umbra, Alan Wisniewski said he began with the idea of things that smoke: tugboat funnels, automobile tailpipes and rooftop chimneys. He settled on the last. “I thought that a traveling house with a functional chimney was a little reminder of a home away from home,” he said. The humidifier, made of molded satin-textured plastic, has a purifying filter and will fit on top of any water bottle or glass. It can also be used with water-soluble essential oils. The device comes with a USB cable and can run on AAA batteries, which are not included. Available in avocado or black for $25. Information: (800) 387-5122 or umbra.com.

headline: Museum for African Art Broadens Its Mandate
abstract: After years of delays and stagnating fund-raising, New York’s Museum for African Art is assuming a new identity.
lead_paragraph: Soon after construction began in 2007 on the Museum for African Art’s new headquarters, engineers discovered a quicksand-like layer of sediment under the site, at Fifth Avenue and 110th Street. The structural problems were surmounted, but in other ways, the museum has had trouble finding stable ground since.

His 5-year-old grandson and namesake, however, moved a whole lot quicker, allowing his grandfather to catch up only when he stopped to pet the nose of a racehorse.

abstract: A prominent screenwriter working on a film about the Russian composer’s life set off a firestorm by questioning whether Tchaikovsky was homosexual.

lead_paragraph: A magisterial floor-through residence at 640 Park Avenue, an opulent limestone building designed by J. E. R. abstract: The John W. Engeman Theater’s production of “Nunsense” introduces Northport audiences to a 1985 Off Broadway musical about a convent, a fund-raiser and very bad vichyssoise.
lead_paragraph: The nuns seem to be everywhere at the John W. Engeman Theater at Northport. A few show up in the aisles even before the show begins, chatting up members of the audience. headline: Carpaccio at Its Beefy Best
abstract: Restaurant menus offer carpaccios of octopus, zucchini or heirloom tomato, but to some, the only true one is made with raw meat.
lead_paragraph: These days, on restaurant menus, you are likely to encounter carpaccio dishes made with anything but meat. There is octopus carpaccio, zucchini carpaccio or heirloom tomato carpaccio, not to mention dessert carpaccios like pineapple or mango.

headline: The Diary of Mrs. Tependris | Complicated Coats and Cabinets of Curiosities at Paris Couture, Part Two
abstract: Mrs. Tependris, the high-society doyenne (and fictional alter ego of the artist and T contributing editor Konstantin Kakanias) shares her thoughts on the Paris couture shows.
lead_paragraph: The Greek-born artist Konstantin Kakanias is known for his drawings of eccentric characters, the most enduring of whom is a big-haired, beak-nosed, fashion-crazed woman-of-a-certain-age named Mrs. Tependris. This summer, at T’s invitation, Kakanias took Mrs. Tependris to the couture shows in Paris, where she was scandalized by latex-clad, masked models at Maison Martin Margiela, seated amid an audience of Qatari princesses at Armani Privé and encased in one of the artist Marina Abramovic’s space-age jumpsuits for Net-a-Porter at the Palais de Tokyo. Mrs. Tependris, who last attended the Paris shows in the mid-’90s, has kept herself busy with a different type of global affair in the intervening years. “She had to join a lot of revolutions, do a lot of political acts,” Kakanias said. “She just couldn’t do couture for a while.” Immediately following the shows last month, Kakanias shared Part One of his heroine’s adventure. Here, he fills us in on the rest of what Mrs. Tependris saw and did.

headline: Three Decades of Conversations With Fire
abstract: An exhibition at Peters Valley School of Craft showcases work created over the last three decades in the school’s anagama kiln, which is valued for the unpredictability of its results.
lead_paragraph: The ceramist Akira Satake is not used to playing the role of foreman, but you wouldn’t know it from the relaxed demeanor he displayed recently while leading a crew wearing protective face shields and fire-retardant gloves at Peters Valley School of Craft in Layton, in Sussex County.

For three years, Adrian Zackheim, the publisher and president of three imprints at Penguin Random House, and Elizabeth Lunney, co-founder of ABC Languages, a foreign language school, fled Manhattan for weekends to the same house owned by Nancy Winston in Westport, Conn.

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in Hawaii; Kentucky; Munich
abstract: A weekly capsule of events around the globe curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Aloha Festivals, Oahu, Hawaii A celebration of Hawaiian culture and history through music, dance, cuisine and art will take place at various locations on Oahu during the 2013 Aloha Festivals from Sept. 12 to 28. Highlights include an opening ceremony featuring traditional chants and hula dancing, concerts, demonstrations, activities, displays of crafts, food booths, block parties and a parade with marching bands, floats with cascades of Hawaiian flowers, and pa’u riders (women on horseback), above. Many of this year’s events pay tribute to the ocean-voyaging culture of the islands’ ancestors. All events are free and open to the public.

headline: Betony Vernon’s Guardian Angel
abstract: The jewelry designer has a ceramic figure passed down from her grandfather that reflects its multifaceted owner.
lead_paragraph: Success is, of course, a beautiful thing, a gift of affirmation from the world that comes in a neat little box. The only problem is that if you want to keep this gift, you usually have to get into the box and stay there. In other words, the good news is that you get a niche. That’s also the bad news. If you don’t fit easily in your assigned compartment, you may get uncomfortable.

headline: London Lawyers Measure Themselves for New Robes
abstract: The BBC series “Silk,” coming to “Masterpiece Mystery!” on PBS, sets up two lawyers hoping to “take silk,” or earn the robes worn by the Queen’s Counsel.
lead_paragraph: Stories by lawyers about lawyers are often guilty of grandstanding for the jury (that’s us), and early in the first episode of “Silk” the barrister heroine is told, apropos of not much: “Fifteen years you’ve been doing this and you still believe, don’t you? Innocent until proven guilty.” Just in case we missed the point, it’s repeated by her a few minutes later: “Innocent until proven guilty. Four words to live by.”

headline: Go East Old Man: Off The Reservation
abstract: In the penultimate installation of his tiny motorcycle travel tale, Dexter Ford crosses through Indian country.
lead_paragraph: Dexter Ford is traveling from Southern California to upstate New York along mostly obscure roads, on a motorcycle that, by American standards, is quite tiny. This is the fourth of his occasional reports from the paths less traveled.

headline: Untangling a Mesh of Identities
abstract: In “Looking for Palestine: Growing Up Confused in an Arab-American Family,” Najla Said invites readers to explore her life as a “Palestinian-Lebanese-American Christian woman” who grew up as a Jew.
lead_paragraph: It’s tough enough to be a teenager in New York City. Try this formula for confusion: “I am a Palestinian-Lebanese-American Christian woman, but I grew up as a Jew in New York City. I began my life, however, as a WASP.”

headline: Playing Spy, Sans Violence
abstract: Tom Clancy’s Splinter Cell: Blacklist seems to be on the brink of saying something challenging about the war on terror. And then it appears to retreat.
lead_paragraph: “If you want to keep your hands, I want names,” an American spy growls at one point in the new video game Tom Clancy’s Splinter Cell: Blacklist. The man he is yelling at is on the ground, arms stretched, wrists trapped between the nearly closed legs of a folding chair. Our hero, the spy, whom we control in most of the game, is torturing this other man for information. He’s worried about another terrorist attack in the United States, which would be the second one in Blacklist.

headline: Car Bombs Kill Dozens in Lebanon

lead_paragraph: Two deadly explosions killed dozens and wounded hundreds in the largely Sunni Muslim city of Tripoli in northern Lebanon.

headline: Stopped Cold: Mercedes Sales Blocked in France
abstract: France has effectively blocked the sale of several new Mercedes models because of a battle over air-conditioner refrigerant, and neither side seems to be budging.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Even as showrooms in Europe prepare for the arrival of 2014 vehicles, authorities in France have sparked controversy with a drastic action: blocking the registration — effectively shutting down sales — of some popular new Mercedes-Benz cars, including the A-Class, B-Class, CLA and SL models.

headline: Your Earrings Remind Me of Grandma’s Gran Torino
abstract: Colorful dried paint that built up, layer upon layer, in automobile factories as part of the spray-painting process is now being turned into jewelry.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — With its layers of colors and psychedelic swirls, fordite resembles jasper or Mexican crazy lace. And though fordite is crafted into eye-catching jewelry, it is not a gemstone — rather, it is dried paint that built up, layer upon layer, in factories that built automobiles long ago.

headline: Wood That Proudly Wears the Marks of Previous Use

lead_paragraph: VENICE — “Those poles look so old,” my companion said, pointing to the striped “barber poles” lining the canals. “I wonder how long they last in that salt water?”

headline: Taking Beethoven on a Mashed-Up Quirky Adventure
abstract: Beethoven’s Septet in E-flat provided a springboard for the kind of quirky adventure that the International Contemporary Ensemble reliably provides.
lead_paragraph: We have come almost automatically to associate Beethoven with impressions of fist-shaking temperament and eternity-pondering quest. But during his lifetime, one popular work cast him in a different light not particularly to his liking. His Septet in E-flat (Op. 20), introduced in 1800 when he was 29, reportedly caused strangers to ask why he didn’t write more in its sunny, vivacious and genteel style.

headline: Richard Simmons, Internet Star?

lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — “Richard, honey, you’ve got lipstick on your teeth.”

headline: Joe on WNYC’s “Money Talking”: Aug. 23, 2013
abstract: Joe Nocera discuses the real impact of software malfunctions on financial markets and what regulators can do about it.
lead_paragraph: How vulnerable are financial markets to computer glitches? The Nasdaq stock exchange was paralyzed for more than three hours this week because of technical problem and Goldman Sachs reportedly lost $100 million after erroneous algorithmic trades. Joe Nocera of The New York Times and Rana Foroohar of Time magazine spoke with Heidi Moore of the Guardian on WNYC’s “Money Talking” about the real impact of software malfunctions on financial markets and what regulators can do about it.

headline: A Jazz Host Remembered as Inspiration

lead_paragraph: Marian McPartland, who died on Tuesday at 95, was an erudite jazz pianist whose career stretched back to the heyday of 52nd Street. But she will be best remembered for “Marian McPartland’s Piano Jazz,” the public radio show she hosted for more than 30 years, featuring duets and conversation with an array of musicians.

headline: Making the Rounds at Boxing and Brunch
abstract: The composer and lyricist William Finn, rather than seeking rest, looks for satisfaction in work and play.
lead_paragraph: The composer and lyricist William Finn lives on the Upper West Side of Manhattan and spends his summers at “Wasabi Gables.” That’s what he and his longtime partner, Arthur Salvadore, call their corner Victorian house in Pittsfield, Mass., for its exterior hue. Mr. Finn, 61, a two-time Tony Award winner, has been the artistic director since 2006 of the Musical Theater Lab at the Barrington Stage Company, up the block. There he was part of the team that developed and premiered “The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee” before its Off Broadway and Broadway success. After two years of revision, “Little Miss Sunshine,” by Mr. Finn and the librettist James Lapine, will open off Broadway this fall at Second Stage. On the last summer Sundays, Mr. Finn will socialize with Barrington Stage’s director, Julianne Boyd, and go to productions, when not serving as M.C. for “Mr. Finn’s Cabaret” at the theater. Rather than seeking rest, he looks for the joy in work and play.

One was cleaning up the spill. The other was defending the image of Thailand’s tourism industry, crucial to the country’s increasingly fragile economy.

headline: Strolling and Playing, but No More Saluting
abstract: Governors Island, whose cannons once protected New York Harbor, now has French carousels and a growing number of weekend visitors.
lead_paragraph: On a map, New York’s biggest summer playground looks just like an ice cream cone, shaped for the city’s enjoyment. Governors Island was an Army base until 1966, then used by the Coast Guard through the mid-1990s. It opened to the public in 2004, with guests first arriving in small numbers. But times change: on a recent weekend, 12,000 visitors took a free ferry from Brooklyn Bridge Park or the Beaux-Arts Battery Maritime Building in Lower Manhattan to enjoy the 172-acre island’s lawns, historic buildings, food carts and arts programs — all open Saturdays, Sundays and holiday Mondays through Sept. 29.

headline: The Fine Print of Dvorak’s Contract
abstract: Excerpts from the handwritten 1892 contract that brought Dvorak to America.
lead_paragraph: The contract that brought Antonin Dvorak to New York to lead the National Conservatory of Music of America allowed him to earn more than 25 times what he had been earning in Prague, and opened a very fruitful period of his career in which he wrote some of his best-loved works, including the “New World” Symphony and the Cello Concerto. While its details have long been known to scholars, one of the original signed contracts — discovered recently by the great-grandson of the conservatory’s founder, Jeannette Thurber, and purchased by the Dvorak American Heritage Association — will be displayed publicly for the first time on Sept. 8 at the Bohemian National Hall at 321 East 73rd Street in Manhattan.

headline: The Deal That Brought Dvorak to New York
abstract: The 1892 contract that Antonin Dvorak, the composer, signed to come to America and teach at a music school was recently found and will be displayed next month to mark his birthday.
lead_paragraph: It was an audacious act of Gilded Age New York. Jeannette Thurber, a wealthy patron trying to create not just a new American music school but, more broadly, a new American school of music, decided in 1891 to hire one of the greatest composers of the day: Antonin Dvorak.

headline: Editor’s Letter
abstract: There are, as always, many trends to choose from this fall. We pick what we think is the best, but only you can decide what, if any of it, speaks to you.
lead_paragraph: As this is a fashion issue, and there is plenty of alluring fashion in these pages, I thought I’d start the issue off with a short note about books. Well, about physical objects really. We photographed writers with forthcoming books — Jonathan Lethem, Edwidge Danticat, Richard Dawkins, Jhumpa Lahiri and Julian Barnes — at home in their work spaces. Quite frankly, none of the spaces look that remarkable; there are no bursts of design genius or eccentric collections. Just what one might expect: wood tables, crowded bookshelves, laptops, messy desks. But as you read each writer’s essay about their space, you understand the resonance these ordinary, simple things convey to each of them. Value is something we bestow upon objects — whether a picture tacked on the wall, a mess of papers, an old typewriter. We animate the inanimate through our memories, associations and desires.

headline: The Ugly American Telegram
abstract: The conviction that removing obstreperous foreign leaders facilitates Washington’s ability to steer events remains the most persistent — and dangerous — of illusions.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — ON Aug. 24, 1963, the American ambassador to South Vietnam, Henry Cabot Lodge, received a top-secret message with the bureaucratically anodyne title Deptel 243. But the content of the message was anything but routine. Hastily drafted and cleared over the course of a single day, with most of official Washington on vacation, Deptel 243, also known as the Hilsman telegram, signaled a major shift in American policy. A few days later Mr. Lodge remarked, “We are launched on a course from which there is no respectable turning back.”

headline: A Blunt Chief Justice Unafraid to Upset Brazil’s Status Quo
abstract: Joaquim Barbosa is the driving force behind a series of establishment-shaking rulings, turning Brazil’s highest court — and him in particular — into a newfound political power.
lead_paragraph: BRASÍLIA — Brazil’s highest court has long viewed itself as a bastion of manners and formality. Justices call one another “Your Excellency,” dress in billowing robes and wrap each utterance in grandiloquence, as if little had changed from the era when marquises and dukes held sway from their vast plantations.

lead_paragraph: A few months ago, a saleswoman at Macy’s tried to wheedle me into renewing my expired store credit card by offering a deep discount on the towels I was buying. So I dug it out of my wallet, where it was nestled between an expired press pass to the Texas State Capitol and an expired library card from Manchester, N.H., and happily handed it over.

headline: Apple and Microsoft, Then and Now
abstract: Under Steven A. Ballmer’s leadership for the last 13 years, Microsoft has struggled to transition from a PC-driven company, to a mobile-centric one. Apple, once its biggest competitor, has done the complete opposite.
lead_paragraph: If you picked up The New York Times in December 2000, you would have seen very different headlines than exist today. Microsoft was projected to generate revenue of $6.4 billion for the last fiscal quarter of 2000, whereas Apple, the company’s almost-lifeless competitor, was clawing to reach $1 billion in revenue.

headline: At a Fed Conference, Views Differ Sharply on Stimulus’s Effect
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Quantitative Easing', 'Mortgage-Backed Securities', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)']
abstract: At the annual meeting in Jackson Hole, Wyo., global policy makers expressed concern over the Federal Reserve’s stimulus campaign and the possible consequences when it ends.
lead_paragraph: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo. — There is still plenty of skepticism about the stimulus campaigns of the Federal Reserve and other central banks, and there is plenty of concern about the consequences. But for the first time in several years, there was also a general sense of optimism among the policy makers gathered here for an annual meeting at the foot of the Grand Tetons that things are going reasonably well.

headline: The Next Hurricane, and the Next
abstract: Seeing Sandy as a sign of calamities that await, a presidential task force wants federal money directed to preparing for the worst.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Sandy, the monster storm that hit the Atlantic Seaboard on Oct. 29, left at least 159 dead and caused $65 billion in damages. But as a presidential task force made clear this week, Sandy cannot be considered a seasonal disaster or regional fluke but as yet another harbinger of the calamities that await in an era of climate change. With that in mind, the report says that individuals, local governments and states that expect federal help cannot simply restore what was there but must adopt new standards and harden community structures to withstand the next flood or hurricane.

abstract: One million children are now refugees from the conflict raging in Syria, the United Nations reported Friday, calling it a “shameful milestone” in a crisis now well into its third year.
lead_paragraph: One million children are now refugees from the conflict raging in Syria, the United Nations reported Friday, calling it a “shameful milestone” in a crisis now well into its third year. Anthony Lake, executive director of the United Nations Children’s Fund, and António Guterres, the United Nations high commissioner for refugees, said in a joint statement that half of all refugees forced to flee Syria were children and that 740,000 of those children were younger than 11 years old. The statement also said that more than 7,000 children had been killed in Syria, where the total death toll in the conflict has surpassed 100,000.

lead_paragraph: The remains of five bodies pulled from a mass grave discovered this week in Tlalmanalco have been identified as members of a group of young people who vanished from a bar in May, the attorney general said Friday. Twelve people disappeared from the Heaven nightclub in a bustling neighborhood in Mexico City, where residents are not accustomed to the brazen acts of violence that have convulsed other regions of the country. Relatives of the victims have complained about the investigation’s slow progress. The mass grave, 30 miles east of Mexico City, contained 13 craniums, the attorney general’s office said.

headline: Flip a Coin
abstract: Kick-start your Saturday with this puzzle from Frederick J. Healy.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — The Zairian ZAIRE, a now-defunct currency that bore the portrait of Mobuto Sese Seko, was replaced in 1998 by the Congolese franc after the nation changed its name to Democratic Republic of Congo. The zaire was one of just a handful of world currencies whose name matched, or roughly matched, the name of the country that issued it. Other examples include Afghanistan’s afghani, Bolivia’s boliviano and of course the French franc. This currency club is as varied in membership as THE UN, which is itself one of several internationally oriented answers in the all-encompassing Saturday puzzle from Frederick J. Healy that manages to touch on geography in GHANA and animal species in ASIA.

headline: Tom Ewing’s Dirty War
abstract: General Order No. 11 and the horrific bush war on the nation’s western border.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Ewing Jr. was a conscientious man. Though never as flamboyant as his foster brother, William Tecumseh Sherman, Ewing was ambitious for political fame and fortune, as befitted the son of one of Ohio’s leading Whig politicians. His father had served both in the United States Senate and in the cabinets of Presidents William Henry Harrison and Zachary Taylor. Thomas Ewing Jr., or Tom, was his father’s personal secretary when the elder Ewing ran Taylor’s Department of the Interior.

headline: New York City Election Choices
abstract: The Times makes recommendations for the Democratic primary, for the public advocate and for the Manhattan and Queens borough presidents.
lead_paragraph: Public AdvocateThe job of public advocate is little more than a bullhorn, and sometimes not even that. The original purpose of this position was to give citizens a voice in City Hall and serve as a watchdog on the mayor and the city government. But the job’s influence has been whittled away by a succession of mayors, and its budget is a mere $2.2 million, barely enough to pay the electric bills and a few modest salaries. Its only real power comes if the mayor dies or resigns; the public advocate takes over until an election can be held in a few months.

headline: What’s On Saturday

lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) LIFE OF PI (2012) Based on the novel by Yann Martel and directed by Ang Lee, this tale chronicles the life of Pi Patel (Suraj Sharma, above), the son of an Indian zoo owner who becomes stranded on a boat in the Pacific and must fight not only dehydration and starvation, but also a Bengal tiger, to survive. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said that this film, which received four Oscars, including best director, best cinematography and best special effects, “unfolds in a setting that is one of the great achievements of digital cinema, and a reminder that the eclectic Mr. Lee is, among other things, an exuberant and inventive visual artist.” He added: “There are images in ‘Life of Pi’ that are so beautiful, so surprising, so right that I hesitate to describe them. headline: Maybe They’ll Never Figure It Out
abstract: A government program, hidden in plain sight.
lead_paragraph: Kathleen Geier points to some polling I’d missed: 39 percent of Americans agree that the government should stay out of Medicare, while only 46 percent disagree; the rest aren’t sure. She also points to the Suzanne Mettler work showing that many beneficiaries of Social Security and Medicare believe that they have never benefited from a government program.

headline: Scenes From the 50th Anniversary of the March on Washington
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'National Mall (Washington, DC)']
abstract: Video, images and voices of people who participated in the Saturday’s event commemorating the 50th anniversary of the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated | 9:24 p.m. As my colleagues reported, tens of thousands of people from across the country streamed onto the National Mall on Saturday for a daylong commemoration of the approaching 50th anniversary of the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom.

headline: Growth in Tennis? Tape Measure Is Telling
abstract: Nine of the top 32 men’s players heading into the United States Open stand at least 6 feet 5 inches, the tallest being John Isner, at 6-10.
lead_paragraph: One recent breezy evening in Montreal, Juan Martín del Potro traded powerful serves and thunderous forehands with Milos Raonic for two otherwise uninspiring sets, won by Raonic. This tale of tall tennis players highlighted what many have contended — and in some cases feared — will be the future of men’s professional tennis.

headline: In Race for N.L. M.V.P., Gomez Deserves Votes
abstract: The Brewers’ Carlos Gomez is no longer just a defensive whiz. Compare his numbers on offense and defense with the Pirates’ Andrew McCutchen’s and Gomez does fairly well.
lead_paragraph: For many years the basic formula for deciding who would win the Most Valuable Player award came down to the triple crown statistics — batting average, home run and runs batted in — and the record of the player’s team. There were occasional exceptions, but if a player had 140 R.B.I. for a first-place team, he had a good chance of receiving Major League Baseball’s highest single-season honor.

headline: Mandela’s Condition Remains Critical but Stable
abstract: The South African government said that former President Nelson Mandela’s health remained critical but stable, requiring “medical interventions.”
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — Former President Nelson Mandela’s health remains critical but stable, the South African government said Saturday, but doctors are required to make “medical interventions” when his health becomes unstable, according to a statement released by the office of President Jacob Zuma.

headline: Linebacker Settles In, at Last, With the Jets
abstract: After stints playing for three other N.F.L. teams, in the Arena Football League and in Canada, Garrett McIntyre has become a Jets starter.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Linebacker Garrett McIntyre exuded pride as he assessed a seven-year professional football career that has taken him to two countries, three leagues and six teams.

headline: Variety: Rainy Day Moods
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon share an acrostic that’s right as rain.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Today’s food for thought comes from the American writer David Mamet, who comments on the nature of man’s self-obsession and dramatization – going so far as to suggest that we all draw parallels between our internal lives and the weather. Since the “weather reflecting mood” trope is a common literary device, it’s entirely appropriate that this quote comes from a playwright.

headline: Signs of Chemical Attack Detailed by Aid Group
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare']
abstract: A United Nations official is pressing Syria to let investigators visit the site of the suspected chemical attack, an attack that Syria blames on rebels.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — An international aid group said Saturday that medical centers it supported near the site of a suspected chemical weapons attack near Damascus received more than 3,000 patients showing symptoms consistent with exposure to toxic nerve agents on the morning of the reported attack.

headline: What Happened to the Kandy-Kolored Tangerine-Flake Streamline Baby?
abstract: Popular automotive colors have changed over the years, but we have settled firmly into the lackluster trio of white, black and silver.
lead_paragraph: Have you looked at the cars around you recently? I mean, really looked at them? I guess it depends on where you live, but there’s a pretty good chance that many of the vehicles you see at any given time will be silver, black, white, gray or some sort of brown or muted blue.

headline: Game in Transition, Wozniacki Remains Relaxed and Confident
abstract: Caroline Wozniacki lost in the second round at the French Open and Wimbledon, but she has had promising results during the summer hardcourt season.
lead_paragraph: No one can accuse Caroline Wozniacki of lacking fighting spirit, on and off the court. She has landed her fair share of lashings from the news media over the years, but she isn’t afraid of giving as good as she gets, given a chance.

headline: Golf Couple’s Vows: To Love and to Honor, and to Read Greens
abstract: Patrick Reed, in his first full season, is the first golfer in 17 years to win on the PGA Tour with his wife — Justine Reed — as his caddie.
lead_paragraph: JERSEY CITY — Patrick Reed hit balls on the driving range while listening to the indie rock band Imagine Dragons on his MP3 player, which was in the left front pocket of his golf pants. Upon completing his warm-up, he pulled his ear buds out. For the rest of an abbreviated workday Friday at Liberty National Golf Club, Reed’s wife, Justine, was in his ear.

headline: Dean Meminger: The Dream Who Was a Delight to Coach
abstract: His teammate and friend Earl Monroe recalls how valuable Meminger was on the 1973 Knicks championship team.
lead_paragraph: What Willis Reed liked to call “Dean’s game” was remarkable not only because the Knicks handed the Celtics their first Game 7 playoff defeat on their home floor. It was also because the great Earl Monroe never got off the bench after Dean Meminger replaced him at the start of the second quarter.

headline: A New Book Offers a View of the Game That Tailgaters Rarely Encounter
abstract: The authors of “The System: The Glory and Scandal of Big-Time College Football” may never watch a game in the way they once did.
lead_paragraph: Getting inside the body of the college football industry and examining it, organ by organ, might be compared to an exploration of the human body. The resulting emotions range wider than the country in which the sport is played — amazement and anxiety, wonderment and worry.

headline: Aug. 24: Where the Candidates Are Today
abstract: The candidates’ daily campaign schedule at a glance.
lead_paragraph: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

headline: Guru of the Long Snap
abstract: Chris Rubio spends much of the year traveling the country to stage clinics where he preaches the gospel of long snapping to young players, whose abilities are highly valued by college coaches.
lead_paragraph: AUBURN, Mass. — Chris Rubio was dissecting the art of long snapping for the benefit of 23 teenagers and their parents on an unseasonably cool morning last month. He used words like “balance” and “extension” as he dabbled in the minutiae of a craft that he considers a science.

headline: Ignoring Qualms, Some Republicans Nurture Dreams of Impeaching Obama
keywords: ['Impeachment', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: While most Republicans are focusing on attacking the budget and the Affordable Care Act, a few are weighing impeachment proceedings against President Obama.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Kerry Bentivolio, a freshman Republican from Michigan, has a legislative dream. It is not to balance the federal budget, or find a way to help his ailing state or even take away money from the federal health care program, a goal that has so animated many other Republicans this summer.

headline: Be Yourself,  Redfin’s Glenn Kelman Says, Even if You’re a Little Goofy
keywords: ['Executives and Management (Theory)', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The chief executive of an online real estate site says individuality should be welcomed in a corporate world that is “pretty starved for personality.”
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Glenn Kelman, chief executive of Redfin, the online real estate site, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: For Red Bulls, First Place for the Taking
abstract: A win at Chivas USA on Sunday would give New York sole possession of the top spot in the Eastern Conference of M.L.S.
lead_paragraph: Only three points separate the top five teams in the Eastern Conference of Major League Soccer before games Saturday and Sunday. And the Red Bulls, a club that has lost only once in its past six games, is a prime position to take sole possession of the top spot.

headline: At the Coaches Car Wash
abstract: Fifty top college football coaches flock to ESPN’s headquarters to discuss the season. The event, known as the Coaches Car Wash, shows how the network has become as big as the games.
lead_paragraph: Fifty top college football coaches flock to ESPN’s headquarters to discuss the season. The event, known as the Coaches Car Wash, shows how the network has become as big as the games.

headline: College Football’s Most Dominant Player? It’s ESPN
abstract: Spending billions of dollars for TV rights and becoming partners with universities desperate for exposure, ESPN has emerged as a sport’s puppet-master and kingmaker.
lead_paragraph: The nation’s annual rite of mayhem and pageantry known as the college football season begins this week, and Saturday will feature back-to-back-to-back marquee matchups.

headline: Steve Ballmer, Meet Ibn Khaldun
abstract: The barbarians always take over in the end.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft is still a very profitable company; with some reforms, it will probably endure for a long time, sort of like the post-Diocletian Roman Empire. But you don’t need David Pogue to tell you — although it helps — that Microsoft missed the boat, big time, on major shifts in the technological landscape. And now the very network externalities that solidified its former dominance probably stand in the way of any attempt to return to past glories.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Blocking Health Reform
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Readers discuss Republican efforts to undercut Obamacare.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss Republican efforts to undercut Obamacare.

headline: Coaches Talk of Injuries, Trying to Slow the Spread
abstract: Coach like Alabama’s Nick Saban argue that spread offenses, because of their fast pace and more frequent number of plays and the way they limit defensive substitutions, lead to more injuries.
lead_paragraph: In recent seasons, programs across the country turned toward sped-up spread offenses, often without huddles, schemes found at the intersection between football and track and field. It was the latest craze.

headline: Where Sand Is Gold, the Reserves Are Running Dry
abstract: Storms, tides and a rising sea level are swallowing up chunks of beach along Florida’s coastline, but there is almost no sand left offshore to replenish the beaches.
lead_paragraph: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. — With inviting beaches that run for miles along South Florida’s shores, it is easy to put sand into the same category as turbo air-conditioning and a decent mojito — something ever present and easily taken for granted.

headline: A College President, Drawn to Uncertainties
keywords: ['Executives and Management (Theory)', 'Careers and Professions', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: The president of Shimer College says she has come to understand that she can’t pursue ideas alone, or strive to change the world unless she engages others.
lead_paragraph: I GREW up literally on the wrong side of the tracks in Paoli, Pa. My father was a printer — he fed paper into big presses; my mother sold Avon products and held various secretarial jobs. Because Paoli is adjacent to the more affluent Main Line of Philadelphia, I became sensitive at an early age to class differences and racial dissonance.

headline: Amgen Said to Be Near Deal to Buy Onyx for $10.5 Billion
abstract: The biotech giant Amgen is near a deal to buy Onyx Pharmaceuticals, a maker of cancer-fighting drugs, for about $125 a share, people briefed on the matter said on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Updated, Aug. 25, 7:38 p.m. | Amgen announced on Sunday that it has agreed to buy Onyx for $125 a share.

headline: Fresh Leadership for Stale Phillies
abstract: The Phillies, who fired Charlie Manuel as manager on Aug. 16, are struggling and in fourth place in the National League East.
lead_paragraph: Ruben Amaro Jr. has prepared for this moment since before he was born, in Philadelphia in the winter after the 1964 baseball season, when a pennant slipped away from the Phillies. His father was the shortstop.

headline: Thrill of Family Replaces Thrill of Game for Clijsters
abstract: Kim Clijsters has spent the year as a fan, particularly of her friend and fellow Belgian Kirsten Flipkens, who reached the semifinals of Wimbledon.
lead_paragraph: Last year’s United States Open was Kim Clijsters’s swan song. A three-time Open champion, Clijsters retired for the second time. This year, she will be watching the tournament from her home in Belgium, where she is expecting her second child, a boy, with her husband, the retired basketball player Brian Lynch. She has spent the year as a fan, particularly of her friend and fellow Belgian Kirsten Flipkens, who reached the semifinals of Wimbledon. She remains involved in tennis as a WTA ambassador for USANA Health Sciences, and is renovating and developing a tennis club and academy in her hometown, Bree. This interview was edited and condensed.

headline: Addicted to Apps
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Mobile Applications', 'Privacy', 'Search Engines', 'Artificial Intelligence']
abstract: We cannot rely on the makers of new technology to think about the moral and privacy implications.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — IN Silicon Valley, that fairy-tale land of robots and driverless cars, a deeply held belief motivates all: If you build it, they will come.

headline: Monopoly Goes Corporate
abstract: Monopoly, the board game, started as a critique of capitalism.
lead_paragraph: IT’S been a rough summer for Monopoly purists.

headline: Reindeer Games
keywords: ['Impeachment', 'Tea Party Movement', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A fake Santa seeks a real impeachment.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — ON the 50th anniversary of Martin Luther King Jr.’s “I Have a Dream” speech, Kerry Bentivolio, a Michigan congressman, has a dream, too: to impeach the nation’s first black president.

headline: A Different Kind of Division
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Discrimination', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: How racial politics have changed since the March on Washington.
lead_paragraph: THREE months before the 1963 March on Washington, whose 50th anniversary falls this week, officials in Birmingham, Ala., opened fire hoses and loosed dogs on civil rights protesters. Two months before the march, the civil rights organizer Medgar Evers was murdered outside his home in Jackson, Miss. And a few weeks after the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s “I Have Dream Speech” echoed down the Washington Mall, a bomb ripped open Birmingham’s 16th Street Baptist Church, killing four little girls.

headline: The Death Memo
abstract: How Supreme Court justices changed their view on capital punishment.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years ago this month, a young man and an older man sat down and began to plot the end of the death penalty in America.

headline: The Problem That Has Two Names
abstract: Like others wanting it both ways, I held on to my professional name while also taking on my husband’s.
lead_paragraph: FIFTY years after Betty Friedan’s “Feminine Mystique” and countless principled-but-unwieldy hyphenated names later, the problem of married versus maiden names should be good and solved. But many women are still caught in an in-between purgatory: why have to choose?

headline: Florian Ortkrass
abstract: A founder and the director of Random International on depressing books, world music and raising tadpoles.
lead_paragraph: Florian Ortkrass is a founder and director of Random International, a group of London-based artists who combine technology and natural elements to create temporary, interactive installations, including the recent “Rain Room” at the Musuem of Modern Art. Another work, “Tower,” an appearing and disappearing water structure, opened on Friday at the Ruhrtriennale international arts festival in Germany.

headline: Foreign Policy by Whisper and Nudge
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: In Egypt and the broader Middle East, the United States can only do so much without the support of the people.
lead_paragraph: IF you follow the commentary on American foreign policy toward Egypt and the broader Middle East today, several themes stand out: People in the region argue: “Whatever went wrong, the United States is to blame.” Foreign policy experts argue: “Whatever President Obama did, he got it wrong.” And the American public is saying: “We’re totally fed up with that part of the world and can’t wait for the start of the N.F.L. season. How do you like those 49ers?”

headline: I’m Thinking. Please. Be Quiet.
abstract: Noise is the supreme archenemy of all serious thinkers.
lead_paragraph: SLAMMING doors, banging walls, bellowing strangers and whistling neighbors were the bane of the philosopher Arthur Schopenhauer’s existence. But it was only in later middle age, after he had moved with his beloved poodle to the commercial hub of Frankfurt, that his sense of being tortured by loud, often superfluous blasts of sound ripened into a philosophical diatribe. Then, around 1850, Schopenhauer pronounced noise to be the supreme archenemy of any serious thinker.

headline: In Syria, America Loses if Either Side Wins
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: At this stage in Syria, tragically, stalemate is the only viable policy option left.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — ON Wednesday, reports surfaced of a mass chemical-weapons attack in the Damascus suburbs that human rights activists claim killed hundreds of civilians, bringing Syria’s continuing civil war back onto the White House’s foreign policy radar, even as the crisis in Egypt worsens.

headline: Working for Nothing
keywords: ['Internships', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Editorials', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Unpaid interns may be too busy making coffee to push for Labor Department oversight.
lead_paragraph: After graduating from school I despaired of finding a job and applied instead for unpaid internships, landing at The Paris Review, a literary magazine in Manhattan. I read through the slush pile, learned how to fact-check and performed light janitorial tasks, like emptying the dishwasher and taking out the trash. It was a fine four months. My parents lived in the city, so I didn’t have to pay rent; the editors were kind, smart people who seemed appropriately embarrassed by the trash situation.

headline: How Technology Wrecks the Middle Class
abstract: Technology is creating jobs — but at the upper and lower ends of the spectrum. The outlook for the middle class may rely on “new artisans” who combine technical and interpersonal skills.
lead_paragraph: In the four years since the Great Recession officially ended, the productivity of American workers — those lucky enough to have jobs — has risen smartly. But the United States still has two million fewer jobs than before the downturn, the unemployment rate is stuck at levels not seen since the early 1990s and the proportion of adults who are working is four percentage points off its peak in 2000.

headline: Public Policies, Made to Fit People
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Research', 'Children and Childhood', 'Domestic Violence', 'Medicine and Health', 'Reading and Writing Skills (Education)', 'Education (K-12)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A new White House initiative is intended to involve social and behavioral scientists in policy making.
lead_paragraph: I HAVE written here before about the potential gains to government from involving social and behavioral scientists in designing public policies. My enthusiasm comes in part from my experiences as an academic adviser to the Behavioral Insights Team created in Britain by Prime Minister David Cameron.

headline: Around the Nation: Players, Teams and Story Lines to Watch
abstract: Examining some of the to players and intriguing story lines this season.
lead_paragraph: Examining some of the to players and intriguing story lines this season.

headline: For a Chef, 41 Years in the Kitchen Takes Its Toll
abstract: Being a chef, like being an elite athlete, tends to be a young person’s game, with crazy hours and injury-inducing physical strain. For midlife chefs, the challenge is finding ways to adjust the pace.
lead_paragraph: STARTING as a dishwasher at the age of 17, the chef Mark Peel worked his way up at some of the great California restaurants: Ma Maison, Michael’s, Chez Panisse, Spago, Chinois and, finally, for more than two decades, Campanile, his own place in Los Angeles.

headline: New Jobs! If Only It Were True
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'Rural Areas', 'Unemployment', 'American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (2009)', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: The United States Department of Agriculture often trumpets the numbers of jobs that are expected to result from loans. Whether these jobs are actually created is another question.
lead_paragraph: CREATING jobs is an essential goal today, given our high unemployment rate. But when job programs rely on taxpayer backing, their success or failure should be clearly disclosed.

headline: Accounts of Syrian Prisons Describe a Volatile Mix of Chaos and Control
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Reports from former prisoners reveal partial breakdowns of order inside the country’s prisons and detention centers, laced with episodes of unpredictable cruelty.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Ahmed Hamadeh had spent a year in a jail in a Damascus suburb when guards chained him to fellow inmates, marched them to an outlying military checkpoint, and ordered them to dig trenches for the soldiers. He concluded that the government had “lost its mind,” he recalled later, not only because the move risked a jailbreak, but also because of the arbitrary violence that followed.

headline: Golden Rice: Lifesaver?
abstract: The fight over genetically modified crops has gone global. Is hysteria impeding science?
lead_paragraph: ONE bright morning this month, 400 protesters smashed down the high fences surrounding a field in the Bicol region of the Philippines and uprooted the genetically modified rice plants growing inside.

headline: Don’t Ask What I’m Writing
abstract: Want to lose a friend who’s a writer? Ask her, a month in, how it’s going.
lead_paragraph: No stage of the writing process — not the editor’s first response to the manuscript, not the review gauntlet — is as fraught for writers as those first few months of uncertainty: that miserable time when we think, believe, know with absolute assurance that we’ve found the key to the novel in our heads, though maybe, probably, definitely not.

headline: What Is Economics Good For?
abstract: A Fed leader has to know that economics is not yet a science, and may never be.
lead_paragraph: Recent debates over who is most qualified to serve as the next chairman of the Federal Reserve have focused on more than just the candidates’ theory-driven economic expertise. They have touched on matters of personality and character as well. This is as it should be. Given the nature of economies, and our ability to understand them, the task of the Fed’s next leader will be more a matter of craft and wisdom than of science.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, August 25
abstract: Notable quotes from business articles that appeared in The New York Times last week.
lead_paragraph: “There will be less opinion, less yelling and fewer celebrity sightings.”

headline: An Awkward Discovery at Work
abstract: In Googling a phone number, a reader finds a potentially embarrassing situation for a colleague — and asks the Workologist for help in sorting it out discreetly.
lead_paragraph: Dear Workologist:

headline: A Right Way to Be Wrong
abstract: After being charged too much for his college tuition for two years, a student seeks the Haggler’s help in getting a refund.
lead_paragraph: IF the Haggler had a dime for every time he’s said the real test of an organization is how it handles mistakes, the Haggler would now have four dimes. Maybe five. That may not seem like many dimes, especially now that a cup of coffee costs $2.50. But the Haggler does not enjoy repeating himself. Saying anything five times is excessive.

headline: A Proud Nation Ponders How to Halt Its Slow Decline
abstract: Europe is talking about “the French question”: whether the country’s Socialist government can prevent it from slipping permanently into Europe’s second tier.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — For decades, Europeans have agonized over the power and role of Germany — the so-called German question — given its importance to European stability and prosperity.

headline: Power, Precision and Years to Grow
abstract: The 5-foot-10 Madison Keys is gifted with height and natural power, but her coach says the 18-year-old still has room for significant improvement.
lead_paragraph: Madison Keys has begun her career with a bang, in large part because she begins points with a bang.

headline: 5 Days After Closing Border, Egypt Opens Crossing to Gaza
abstract: Egypt reopened its borders with the Gaza Strip on Saturday five days after closing the crossing, which had prevented people from entering or leaving the Palestinian enclave and deepened its isolation from the rest of the world.
lead_paragraph: GAZA — Egypt reopened its borders with the Gaza Strip on Saturday five days after closing the crossing, which had prevented people from entering or leaving the Palestinian enclave and deepened its isolation from the rest of the world.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Aug. 25
abstract: Civil rights leaders including Representative John Lewis and Andrew Young join the Sunday shows as Washington marks the anniversary of the 1963 March on Washington.
lead_paragraph: As the United States observes the anniversary of the 1963 March on Washington, the Sunday shows will feature interviews with civil rights leaders and lawmakers about the state of the nation 50 years after the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s “I Have a Dream” speech.

headline: Venus Williams Pushes Back, Hard, at the Twilight
abstract: Venus Williams, a two-time champion at the U.S. Open, is not yet prepared to give in to age and questions about her health.
lead_paragraph: During an appearance last week on “Good Morning America” to promote the United States Open, Venus Williams was barely a minute into the interview when the host committed an unforced error.

headline: Central Bankers Say Emerging Economies Will Be Ready for Fed Exit
abstract: The question of what other central banks are supposed to do about the Fed cutting its extraordinary asset purchases dominated the formal agenda here at the Kansas City Fed’s annual monetary policy conference. The answers were surprisingly mellow.
lead_paragraph: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo. — The stimulus campaigns of the Federal Reserve and the central banks of Europe and Japan, by depressing domestic interest rates, have helped to push trillions of dollars into developing markets in recent years.

headline: Commercial Banks As Creators of “Money”
abstract: A gem from James Tobin.
lead_paragraph: Thank you, Matthew Klein! In the course of critiquing Robert Hall’s paper for Jackson Hole, he mentions and links to another half-century-old paper by James Tobin, Commercial Banks as Creators of “Money” (pdf), that I had forgotten about, and is even more precisely on point than the Tobin-Brainard piece I’ve been citing.

headline: For Tennis Players, a Tech Lover’s Paradise
abstract: At an outdoor tennis lab near the beach, a longtime pro with an interest in biomechanics has perfected the gathering of video and digital data to use it to meticulously hone a swing.
lead_paragraph: BOCA RATON, Fla. — The frontier of tennis technology is cordoned by a chain-link fence and protected from the elements by a yellowed canopy, a stretch of it torn away by one or another tropical storm. It is an open-air tinkerer’s garage, a 20-minute drive west from the beach here.

headline: The Macroeconomics of Sisyphus
abstract: The stone rolls down again and again.
lead_paragraph: Simon Wren-Lewis is deeply annoyed at the IMF, and understandably so. How can you publish a paper about fiscal adjustment that explicitly takes no account of monetary policy, and claim that it has any relevance to current problems?

headline: At 17, a Two-Time Grand Slam Finalist
abstract: Ashleigh Barty, an Australian who reached the women’s doubles final of the Australian Open in January at age 16, played in the Wimbledon doubles final three months later.
lead_paragraph: With all the buzz around top players like Serena Williams and Tommy Haas playing well in their 30s, it might have been easy to overlook the teenage girl who made two Grand Slam finals this year.

headline: At 40, a Doubles Specialist Just Keeps Going
abstract: Danie Nestor, soon to turn 41, has been a mainstay on the Tour and for Canada’s Davis Cup team. He owns more than 1,000 victories in singles, doubles and mixed doubles.
lead_paragraph: When you have been on the tennis tour as long as the Canadian doubles specialist Daniel Nestor, there is no shortage of amusing stories, although the dates can get cloudy.

headline: Brooklyn Boy, 3, Shot in Head, Police Say
abstract: The child, who had been mauled by a pit bull earlier this summer, was in critical but stable condition at a hospital.
lead_paragraph: A 3-year-old boy was shot in the head in his Brooklyn apartment early Saturday, the police said. A man, 22, who was in the apartment at the time was being questioned by detectives on Saturday evening, the police said.

headline: Gilbert Enjoys Playing Name Games
abstract: The coach and broadcaster Brad Gilbert has a nickname for many of the top (and not so top) players on the tour.
lead_paragraph: Brad Gilbert is not necessarily the Chris Berman of professional tennis. He began experimenting with nicknames on the air seven or eight years ago, but his nicknames tend to be more off the cuff, more freewheeling, than preplanned. He does not always have carte blanche in sharing them.

headline: Aug. 24: Speech by Representative Lewis
abstract: Representative John Lewis of Georgia addressed the crowd during the 50th anniversary of the March on Washington.
lead_paragraph: Representative John Lewis of Georgia addressed the crowd during the 50th anniversary of the March on Washington.

headline: Duda Is Back With the Mets
abstract: Lucas Duda went on the disabled list June 23 and went on to lose his place as the club’s starting left fielder. He will primarily be a first baseman in his return.
lead_paragraph: The Mets on Saturday recalled Lucas Duda from the minors and optioned outfielder Mike Baxter to Class AAA.

headline: The Open’s Breakthrough of 1973
abstract: Billie Jean King unified her fellow players, won the Battle of the Sexes and secured equal purses at the United States Open. The game would never be the same.
lead_paragraph: Billie Jean King called it the year of insanity. She was talking about this year, when she has traveled around the world to promote the 40th anniversary of the Women’s Tennis Association and to publicize two documentaries about her life.

headline: Needed at Microsoft: A Catch-Up Artist
abstract: For Steve Ballmer’s eventual successor, the challenges are many. Some of the same factors that helped Microsoft in the PC market are working against it as it tries to catch Google and Apple.
lead_paragraph: TWO months ago, Bill Gates met with members of the New York Times editorial board and a few editors and reporters. Public health was on his mind, and he spoke eloquently about the progress being made to combat diseases like tuberculosis and malaria, and the work of the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.

headline: Capital Ls
abstract: Spend your Sunday breaking codes with Victor Barocas.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — It was right around the time that I came across the clue for John le Carré, the British writer who was once an employee of MI6, that I began to suspect that there was more to this Sunday puzzle than meets the eye. Was the mere inclusion of the author of spygame thrillers like “Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy” making me feel more paranoid?

headline: Egypt Widens Crackdown and Meaning of ‘Islamist’
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: Political abuses and politicized prosecutions are hardly new in Egypt, but since the military takeover last month, some rights activists say the authorities are acting with a sense of impunity.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Having crushed the Muslim Brotherhood, the Egyptian authorities have begun cracking down on other dissenters, sometimes labeling even liberal activists or labor organizers as dangerous Islamists.

keywords: ['Teachers and School Employees', 'Education (K-12)', 'Performance Evaluations (Labor)', 'Seniority Systems', 'Law and Legislation', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: A radical teachers’ group mobilized thousands of members in Mexico City last week, threatening to bring an already congested city to a halt in the coming days.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Mexico’s highly anticipated education overhaul program — intended to weed out poorly performing teachers, establish professional hiring standards and weaken the powerful teachers’ union — is buckling under the tried-and-true tactic of huge street protests, throwing the heart of the capital into chaos.

keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Consumer Protection', 'Credit and Debt', 'Credit Scores', 'Pawnbroking', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: As banks zero in on more affluent customers and close branches in poor areas, pawnshops are stepping into the void to offer an array of services.
lead_paragraph: Linda Ballard, 61, uses the word “love” to describe her banking relationship, lauding the ease of cashing her bimonthly paycheck, the convenience of text alerts about her balance and the features on the platinum card that she was upgraded to in July.

headline: Battling Superstition, Indian Paid With His Life
abstract: The killing of Narendra Dabholkar, a former physician who aimed to drive skepticism into India’s superstition, is the latest episode in a wrestling match between traditionalists and reformers.

headline: Father Knows Best: Romine Has Swing Coach Independent of Yankees
abstract: Yankees catcher Austin Romine and his father, who played seven seasons with the Red Sox, talk or text after every game and go over what he did at the plate.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Just by listening to his son’s games on the radio, Kevin Romine can tell what Yankees catcher Austin Romine might be doing wrong at the plate. Kevin Romine played seven seasons with the Boston Red Sox, from 1985 to 1991, and knows plenty about hitting, and even more about his son’s approach at the plate.

headline: Other Nations Offer a Lesson to Egypt’s Military Leaders
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat"]
abstract: A look at other Muslim countries that have struggled with democratic transitions provides a kind of warning to Egypt’s military leaders.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Is the era of the military big man back? In Egypt, where Gen. Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi led a populist putsch against the elected president, prison doors are swinging.

headline: With Pressure Off, Murray Still Expects Some Nerves at U.S. Open
abstract: A more relaxed Andy Murray, who won his first Grand Slam title last year at the United States Open, will play his first match as the defending Open champion.
lead_paragraph: On media day at the United States Open, when many top players appeared eager to impress — or to at least manage expectations — no one looked more at ease than Andy Murray, the defending men’s champion.

headline: Harvey Isn’t on His Game; With Scherzer Pitching, Neither Are the Mets
abstract: Matt Harvey gave up only two runs despite allowing a career-high 13 hits, but his Mets teammates again could not hold up their end of the bargain as Max Scherzer pitched six scoreless innings.
lead_paragraph: The indicators were plain: sliders that spun but did not swerve, fastballs that whizzed but failed to explode, changeups that floated along capricious paths.

headline: Woodland Tied With Kuchar Atop Barclays
abstract: With scores plummeting, Gary Woodland and Matt Kuchar are tied for the lead at 12 under par after three rounds at Liberty National Golf Club.
lead_paragraph: JERSEY CITY — The good news for Gary Woodland is he is tied for the lead at the Barclays with Matt Kuchar at 12-under-par 201. The better news is there is one round left to play in the first event of the FedEx Cup playoffs at Liberty National Golf Club, affording him a prime opportunity to reverse a disappointing trend.

headline: In Travers, Colt Finally Attracts Attention of People Besides His Trainer
abstract: Will Take Charge, trained by the Hall of Famer D. Wayne Lukas, pulled off an upset in the Travers Stakes at Saratoga.
lead_paragraph: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — No one was paying attention to D. Wayne Lukas and his colt as the spring turned to summer. If Will Take Charge had distinguished himself at all, it was for competing in all three legs of the Triple Crown. But he did not perform very well: he was beaten by a combined 45 ½ lengths in those American Classics.

headline: Cyberschools Grow, Fueling New Concerns
abstract: As the number of full-time cyberschools in Texas doubles this year, concerns are growing about online education’s influence, finances and overall academic quality.
lead_paragraph: The number of full-time cyberschools serving Texas public school students will double in the coming school year despite a history of lackluster performance and a new law limiting the number of online courses that public school students are allowed to take at the state’s expense.

headline: Ted Post, Director for Film and Television, Dies at 95
abstract: Mr. Post had a long, busy career making episodes of “Gunsmoke” and “Rawhide,” directing Clint Eastwood in two hit films, and winning praise for a Vietnam War movie, “Go Tell the Spartans.”
lead_paragraph: Ted Post, a prolific director who collaborated with Clint Eastwood on two hit films, directed hundreds of episodes of television series like “Gunsmoke,” “Peyton Place” and “Rawhide,” and made a low-budget film about the Vietnam War that was widely ignored when it was released in 1978 but is now regarded by many critics as one of the best in its genre, died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. He was 95. His son, Robert, confirmed the death.

headline: Under a New Law, the Police Can Act as Gun Dealers
abstract: A new Texas law will allow the state’s law enforcement agencies to bolster their budgets by selling confiscated guns to licensed weapons dealers.
lead_paragraph: For decades, weapons confiscated by the police in Texas were supposed to be used for law enforcement purposes — or else destroyed. Starting next month, police departments across the state will be allowed to sell some of them.

headline: Charles Pollock, Designer of Popular Office Chair, Dies at 83
abstract: Mr. Pollock was an industrial designer whose crowning achievement was an office chair characterized by a single aluminum band that held it together, structurally and visually.
lead_paragraph: Charles Pollock, an industrial designer whose vision of “a simple line in space” led him to develop sleek, functional chairs that became a hallmark of executive suites in the latter 20th century, died on Tuesday in a fire in South Jamaica, Queens. He was 83.

abstract: “Ain’t Them Bodies Saints” is a Texas film in many ways — the setting, the story, the director and two producers — yet most of it was shot in Louisiana.

This thriller, which stars Rooney Mara, Casey Affleck and Ben Foster, is set in Central Texas; was written and directed by the Dallas-based David Lowery; and its producers include Toby Halbrooks, also of Dallas, and James M. Johnston, of Fort Worth.

headline: Hamilton Earns Pole in Belgium
abstract: Lewis Hamilton left it to the last second to beat Sebastian Vettel’s time and secure his fourth straight pole position of the season at the Belgian Grand Prix.
lead_paragraph: Lewis Hamilton left it to the last second to beat Sebastian Vettel’s time and secure his fourth straight pole position of the season at the Belgian Grand Prix. In a frantic finish under heavy rain at Spa, the lead changed hands in a flurry of activity as first Nico Rosberg, Mark Webber and Vettel all beat one another’s times, only for Hamilton to go fastest for the fifth time this season.

headline: Making Some Effort, but North Texas Continues to Run the Water

headline: A Summer of Successes for America’s Young Stars
