lead_paragraph: It has been a summer of triumphs for America’s best young players: three have become grandmasters, three have become international masters, and several more have earned one of the three norms — a measure of performance — needed to claim those titles.

headline: Court Is ‘One of Most Activist,’ Ginsburg Says, Vowing to Stay
keywords: ['Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', "Women's Rights", 'AFFIRMATIVE ACTION', 'ABORTION', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Amid calls from some liberals that she step down in time for President Obama to name her successor, Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg said she was fully engaged in work.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, 80, vowed in an interview to stay on the Supreme Court as long as her health and intellect remained strong, saying she was fully engaged in her work as the leader of the liberal opposition on what she called “one of the most activist courts in history.”

headline: Few Answers in Game With No Real Winner

keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: In Iowa, which prides itself on its pivotal role in presidential campaigns, Republicans worry that the growing dominance of the conservative wing could render it less relevant.
lead_paragraph: AMES, Iowa — On the surface, Iowa’s Republican presidential caucuses seem healthier than ever: would-be candidates are flocking here mere months after the last White House race ended, drawing sizable crowds and ample news coverage. Senator Ted Cruz of Texas and former Senator Rick Santorum of Pennsylvania were in this central Iowa college town for a Christian conservative conference this month, and Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky has come to the state twice since May.

headline: Smith vs. Sanchez Quarterback Duel Just Got Worse
abstract: The Jets escaped the Giants but their quarterback situation became murkier as Geno Smith struggled and Mark Sanchez hurt his shoulder.

Maybe Geno Smith could have thrown four interceptions in his first seven drives Saturday night against the Giants, instead of only three. Maybe Mark Sanchez could have shredded both knees, instead of just injuring his right shoulder, playing in the waning minutes of a meaningless game after appearing to secure the Jets’ starting quarterback position by virtue of Smith’s struggles.

headline: Julie Harris, Celebrated Actress of Range and Intensity, Dies at 87

headline: Linda Ronstadt Is Ill
abstract: The singer Linda Ronstadt has revealed in an interview with AARP Magazine that she has Parkinson’s disease and that she is no longer able to sing as a result.
lead_paragraph: The singer Linda Ronstadt has revealed in an interview with AARP Magazine that she has Parkinson’s disease and that she is no longer able to sing as a result. Ms. Ronstadt, 67, received her official diagnosis eight months ago, although she had symptoms for the past eight years. “I couldn’t sing,” she said in the interview, “and I couldn’t figure out why. I knew it was mechanical. I knew it had to do with the muscles.” Her hands also began to shake, but she attributed that symptom to a shoulder operation. A neurologist then diagnosed Parkinson’s. “I wouldn’t have suspected that in a million, billion years,” she said. Ms. Ronstadt’s memoir, “Simple Dreams,” is to be released on Sept. 17 and chronicles her life and musical career. She has won 11 Grammy Awards and sold over 100 million records worldwide. But according to AARP’s Web site, the book does not discuss her diagnosis or the loss of her voice.

headline: Adrift on the Nile

abstract: America has leverage in Egypt. We’re just short of leadership.
lead_paragraph: IN May 2011, when the promise of the Arab Spring was still fresh and exhilarating, President Obama went to the State Department to proclaim an important reorientation of American policy in the Middle East. For decades America had defined its interests in utilitarian terms: regional stability, countering terrorism and nuclear proliferation (and, in the cold war years, Soviet influence), defending Israel’s security, assuring the free flow of oil and other commerce. That often meant alliances of convenience with brutal authoritarians.

headline: Federal Courts in Crisis

abstract: Irrational budget-cutting is doing grievous harm to the American justice system.
lead_paragraph: Observers of the federal court system cannot recall the last time such a thing has happened, if it ever has. Chief judges in 86 of the 94 Federal District Courts around the country — more than half of them Republican appointees — have now joined to sound an alarm about the grave damage to the nation’s justice system caused by years of flat financing followed by Washington’s lunatic across-the-board budget cuts known as sequestration. headline: Feeling For | A Sake That’s Perfect for Summer Sipping
abstract: Served cool, the traditional Japanese beverage can be the perfect rejoinder to hot, stifling nights.
lead_paragraph: For the uninitiated, drinking sake probably only means throwing back porcelain thimbles of scalding liquid that turns tepid before you know it. But the traditional Japanese beverage served cold can be a pleasant answer to less-than-comfortable summer nights. A particularly delicious variety that has been popping up at many of New York’s izakayas (the Japanese equivalent to a gastropub) and sake bars recently is the Tokubetsu Junmai from the gourmet sake brewery Nanbu Bijin. Its name translates to “southern beauty,” but Nanbu Bijin is actually located in northern Japan, in a region once controlled by the Nanbu clan of samurai. This junmai — a pure, full-bodied class of premium sake — has a bright, floral bouquet, almost like a lily blossom, and starts crisp before offering a sweet finish almost like honeydew. New Yorkers can find it at Decibel, in the East Village, and Sakagura, near Grand Central Terminal.

headline: ‘Heroin Chic’ Beauty for the Office?
abstract: A conversation with Lloyd Simmonds, creative director of Yves Saint Laurent Makeup, about how to interpret fall’s grungy beauty look for the professional woman.
lead_paragraph: Having always had a soft spot for grunge (for nostalgia reasons, including junior high years spent in a Seattle suburb) and spinoffs thereof, like “heroin chic,” the fall runways with their disgruntled ’90s air felt as familiar as a fuzzy mohair cardigan. In beauty, lip colors were jam-black at some shows (perhaps riffing on Drew Barrymore’s plummy lips during her wild child days), while others interpreted the bare-faced era more literally (slightly greasy skin and stringy hair like Kate Moss’s in the old Calvin Klein ads). But considering that the first time around I was a jobless teenager and that a shiny complexion and unwashed hair is probably not the best combination for the office, I looked to Lloyd Simmonds, creative director of Yves Saint Laurent Makeup, for a few pointers. After all, he had to interpret the very grungy Saint Laurent clothing designed by Hedi Slimane into a viable makeup collection. Here are some snippets from our conversation.

headline: Bacteria Study Offers Clues to Typhoid Mary Mystery
abstract: A new study sheds more light on how Salmonella typhi, the bacteria that cause typhoid fever, hide in the body.
lead_paragraph: Scientists are one step closer to explaining how Typhoid Mary could have infected dozens of New Yorkers over a 12-year career as a cook, killing at least three of them, without having ever been sick herself.

headline: Almost 5 Months Old, Bronx Native Makes Zoo Debut
abstract: A snow leopard was born in April to Maya and Leo, who was brought to New York from Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: A 17-pound snow leopard, born this spring at the Bronx Zoo, is now on display, the first son of an orphaned snow leopard from Pakistan.

headline: Remembering Muriel Siebert, an ‘Icon’ for Women
abstract: Ms. Siebert’s pragmatic approach to effecting change on Wall Street characterized many of her accomplishments, her admirers said.
lead_paragraph: For a generation of women on Wall Street, Muriel F. Siebert was more than just a leader in finance; she was their point of reference.

headline: Bring Your Lunch to Work
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Microwave Ovens', 'Lunch Boxes and Bags']
abstract: Somehow one of our oldest and sanest traditions has become a laughingstock: it’s not hip to pack a work lunch. Let’s try to fix that.
lead_paragraph: There are few brown-baggers in the building where I work. This is not because the food in the neighborhood is so great (it isn’t), or because the cafeteria is Google-like (it isn’t), but because many people are either “too busy” or too embarrassed to bring their lunch. Somehow one of our oldest and sanest traditions has become a laughingstock: it’s not hip to bring lunch.

headline: Lew’s Letter to Congress About the Debt Limit
abstract: Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew informed House Speaker John A. Boehner that the government is likely to reach its borrowing limit in mid-October.
lead_paragraph: Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew informed House Speaker John A. Boehner that the government is likely to reach its borrowing limit in mid-October.

headline: Oppressed Becomes Oppressor
abstract: In Fraser Grace’s “Breakfast With Mugabe,” the president of Zimbabwe, Robert Mugabe, sees a psychotherapist, and colonialism is put on the couch.
lead_paragraph: To his critics in the West, Robert Mugabe, president of the politically and economically troubled Zimbabwe, is a tyrant, an election rigger, a thug who uses past victimhood to justify further oppression.

headline: Weekly Ticket Sales Drop Under $1 Million for Broadway’s ‘Spider-Man’
abstract: A spokesman for the production linked the drop in sales to the recent injury of one of the performers.
lead_paragraph: For the first time since performances began in November 2010, the Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” took in less than $1 million for a standard eight-performance playing week, with last week’s gross totaling $966,952. While ticket sales have been softening since last fall for the $75 million musical, the most expensive in Broadway history, a spokesman on Monday linked last week’s total to “fallout” from a well-publicized foot injury suffered by the cast member Daniel Curry during the Aug. 15 performance.

headline: His Links Severed, Ackman Sells Stake in J.C. Penney
abstract: William A. Ackman sold his roughly 18 percent stake in J.C. Penney at $12.90 a share on Monday, severing all ties to the retailer two weeks after he resigned from the board. At that price, his stake was valued at $504 million, saddling him with a loss of about $473 million.
lead_paragraph: Updated, Aug. 27, 6:32 a.m. | William A. Ackman sold his roughly 18 percent stake in J.C. Penney at $12.90 a share on Monday, severing all ties to the retailer two weeks after he resigned from the board. At that price, his stake was valued at $504 million, saddling him with a loss of about $473 million.

headline: A Syrah to Pair With Lamb Shanks
abstract: This tender dish with a fruity North African accompaniment requires something soft and not very tannic.
lead_paragraph: Bordeaux is the classic pairing for lamb, but that would be true of a simpler Western dish: chops or a roast, for example. This dish of meltingly tender lamb shanks with a fruity North African accompaniment requires something softer and less tannic. I would reach for a syrah from the northern Rhône Valley, like a St.-Joseph, a Crozes-Hermitage or even those rare syrah-based Côtes du Rhônes, like Éric Texier’s Brézème.

headline: James Purdy, a Fabulist Haunting the Fringes
abstract: The publication of a complete collection of short stories by James Purdy has refocused attention on his unflinching and wildly original style.
lead_paragraph: When he died in 2009, at 94, James Purdy was a forgotten man. He had always been a cult writer, held in almost worshipful regard for his wildly original, sometimes shocking novels and stories that worked the margins of American society, fringe territory populated by small-town folk, failed artists and tormented gay men.

headline: Reinvigorating a Chestnut With Clarity, Not Sizzle
abstract: In his revival of “Anna Christie” at the Berkshire Theater Group, the director David Auburn finesses Eugene O’Neills creaky plot with a calm, persuasive production.
lead_paragraph: STOCKBRIDGE, Mass. — As perhaps suits a tale of the sea, Eugene O’Neill’s “Anna Christie” is encrusted with layer upon layer of barnacles. The last, daring word in modern theater and modern subject matter when it opened on Broadway in 1921, this Pulitzer Prize-winning drama of a prostitute’s redemption now seems all but buried in quaintness, myth and exotica.

headline: Obama Honors Soldier for Bravery Under Fire, and Afterward
abstract: Back in the United States after losing too many comrades in Afghanistan, Staff Sgt. Ty Michael Carter has become a symbol of the courage not only to face the enemy, but to face what comes next.
lead_paragraph: For generations, soldiers have been honored at the White House for valor under fire. And no one questions the heroism of Staff Sgt. Ty Michael Carter, who raced through a hail of bullets to rescue a wounded comrade and helped keep Taliban fighters from overrunning a combat post in Afghanistan.

headline: Second Avenue, Repaved as Memory Lane
abstract: In “Still Jewish After All These Years,” at Stage 72, Avi Hoffman offers songs and life lessons from decades in the Yiddish theater.
lead_paragraph: Until a few days ago, I had no idea who Menasha Skulnik was. Now I want Avi Hoffman to do a show about him.

headline: Dollop of Romance Is Added to Intrigue at Former Chinese Politician’s Trial
abstract: Bo Xilai said his former top deputy and his wife, both of whom provided evidence against him, had a passionate relationship with each other.
lead_paragraph: JINAN, China — Concluding a trial that has riveted China, Bo Xilai, the former elite Communist Party official, attacked elements of the prosecution’s case on Monday and said his former top deputy and his wife, both of whom provided evidence against him, had a passionate relationship.

headline: What Joseph Bottum Wants
keywords: ['Christians and Christianity', 'Homosexuality', 'Marriages', 'Protestant Churches', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Sex']
abstract: On the conservative Catholic’s case for same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Bottum’s essay in Commonweal making what’s advertised (and what the Times has covered) as “a conservative Catholic’s case for same-sex marriage” is so deliberately discursive — to the point of obscuring, at times, exactly what kind of argument the former First Things editor is making — that it’s hard to know exactly where a response would best begin. But I thought I would pluck out the following passage, which is an aside in the essay but a suggestive one, I think, in terms of understanding both Bottum’s personal motivations in writing this piece and some of the larger issues in play as well. He’s writing here about anti-Catholicism in American life, and he pauses to note how surprising it would be, from the vantage point of earlier eras and debates, that the church’s attitude toward homosexuality would have ended up giving fuel to an anti-Catholic fire:

headline: Video Shows U.N. Inspectors in Syria Interviewing Survivors of Suspected Chemical Attack
abstract: Antigovernment activists posted video to YouTube that showed United Nations inspectors in blue helmets and body armor arriving at a cramped rebel clinic, where they interviewed witnesses and survivors of a suspected chemical attack.
lead_paragraph: As my colleagues Michael Gordon, Alan Cowell and Rick Gladstone report, United Nations weapons inspectors visited two hospitals in the Syrian countryside outside of Damascus on Monday to interview survivors of last week’s suspected chemical weapons attack and collect patient samples, despite a volley of sniper fire that disabled the lead vehicle in their convoy.

headline: Once an Outcast, Iranian Minister Carries Hope of Easing Tensions
abstract: Mohammad Javad Zarif seems near certain to lead Iran’s delegation in nuclear talks — further indications, analysts say, that the new leadership is serious about a new policy.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Until this summer, Mohammad Javad Zarif, one of Iran’s most accomplished diplomats, was an outcast, exiled from the government by ultraconservatives for working too closely with the West. Rather than presenting the Iranian case to the world, as he had done so effectively throughout a 35-year diplomatic career, he was spending his days teaching at the Foreign Ministry’s training center on a quiet, leafy campus in North Tehran.

headline: In Performance: Sarah Lemp
abstract: Sarah Lemp plays Mama in “The Cheaters Club,” Derek Ahonen’s new play set at a haunted inn in Georgia. The dark comedy, being mounted by the Amoralists, is at the Abrons Arts Center.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Lemp plays Mama in “The Cheaters Club,” Derek Ahonen’s new play set at a haunted inn in Georgia. The dark comedy, being mounted by the Amoralists, is at the Abrons Arts Center.

headline: Big Sean and Albert Heath and Friends Release Albums
abstract: New statements arrive from the worlds of hip-hop and jazz.
lead_paragraph: BIG SEAN

headline: Driving the 2014 Cadillac XTS Vsport
abstract: Cadillac’s flagship XTS Vsport is faster than the base model, but get a load of the Elmiraj concept.
lead_paragraph: When I think Cadillac, my mental archive scrolls back to that crisp black and white image of Muhammad Ali, sitting next to his mother and looking over his shoulder from the driver’s seat of a new Cadillac. For many people then, the first stop upon arrival at success was probably a Cadillac dealership. Frank Sinatra had one; Elvis owned many over the years.

headline: Hunger Muggles’ Occult Dystopia
abstract: Samantha Shannon’s debut novel, a dystopian portrait of London in the year 2059, has already been optioned for film and was the first pick of the “Today” show’s new book club.
lead_paragraph: The book club craze may have hit its nadir. The big moment came a week ago when the NBC morning show “Today” announced that it, too, was starting a book club, presumably because so many of its competitors have them, and anointed Samantha Shannon’s novel, “The Bone Season,” its first pick. Seated in front of a backdrop on which the words “Call me Ishmael” were clearly visible, the “Today” team explained how a debut novel by a 21-year-old unknown had snagged this distinction. Not one bit of the five-minute segment concerned exactly what Ms. Shannon has written.

headline: Examined, the Virtual Life Is Worth Living
abstract: The release of the 25th-anniversary edition of Madden NFL prompts a question: can sports video games count as sports?
lead_paragraph: The habit of insisting that the virtual life is somehow not part of real life has diminished with time. Few people regard, say, online magazines as fake magazines anymore. And more than one politician has been felled by a scandal involving sex that was purely digital. So even though it wasn’t physical, it must have been real. Right?

headline: A World Traveler Is Harmless, Yet Suspect
abstract: Fred Richards, global creative director at the Brand Union, has passport stamps, a birth place and a legal name that make security people uneasy.
lead_paragraph: I THINK I’m a friendly person, but once I get on an airplane I barely speak to anyone. I’m traveling so much, predominantly throughout the United States, Asia and Europe, that sometimes I’m not even quite sure of my itinerary.

headline: Vines and Vintner Beautify a Tuscan Hill
abstract: Archea architects of Florence have built a new headquarters for Antinori winemakers in Tuscany.
lead_paragraph: BARGINO, Italy — For all its beauty, Italy has suffered reckless development. Travel outside any big city, and you’ll come across aging sprawl: unplanned wastelands of shopping malls, factories and housing projects, many from the 1960s and ’70s. Florence, a dozen or so miles from here, is no exception. The city started devolving into a mess of shabby suburbs years ago; nearby towns like Tavarnelle and Poggibonsi added industrial parks to historic centers.

headline: Tracing the Steps That Led Up to the March on Washington
abstract: A documentary on PBS goes behind the scenes of a major episode in civil rights history in 1963.
lead_paragraph: Outside of natural disasters, few of history’s momentous events happen spontaneously. The March on Washington may, through the haze of 50 years, have come to seem as if it were a magical bit of serendipity, but just like D-Day or the lunar landing, it required considerable planning and was the culmination of a string of events and decisions.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Google’s Schmidt Responds to Ellison, and Autocomplete’s Genesis
abstract: Monday’s highlights from around the Web include Google’s chairman, Eric Schmidt, responding to claims from Larry Ellison that Google pilfered ideas and technology. Plus, the back story of how the company’s search autocomplete function was born.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items. Here’s what we noticed today:

headline: Growth in Global Disputes Brings Big Paychecks for Law Firms
keywords: ['ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Legal Profession', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Some legal heavyweights in the United States are benefiting from a growing number of clashes over complex international deals.
lead_paragraph: Debt woes, broken contracts and soured business deals may cost global investors billions in losses and create seemingly never-ending headaches for policy makers. But there is a set of specialists profiting from such geopolitical problems: arbitration lawyers.

headline: Youth at the Head of the Classroom
abstract: Charter schools are developing what amounts to a youth cult in which teaching for two to five years is seen as acceptable, and even desirable.
lead_paragraph: Charter schools are developing what amounts to a youth cult in which teaching for two to five years is seen as acceptable, and even desirable.

headline: The Ad Campaign: Quinn Highlights Endorsements
abstract: Christine C. Quinn’s new ad highlights her editorial-page endorsements by The New York Times, The New York Post and The Daily News.
lead_paragraph: Moving quickly to highlight newspaper editorial-page endorsements she had just collected, Christine C. Quinn, a Democratic candidate for mayor, released her third English-language television advertisement on Monday. Called “It’s Unanimous,” the ad spotlights her endorsements by The New York Times, The New York Post and The Daily News.

headline: Bethanie Mattek-Sands Makes Fashion Statements With Her Hair
abstract: Bethanie Mattek-Sands, often called the Lady Gaga of tennis, will walk onto the court at the United States Open on Monday with bright purple hair.
lead_paragraph: She is known for her knee socks, war paint, tattoos and, of course, her tennis ball fringe jacket from Wimbledon 2011. But this summer, Bethanie Mattek-Sands, often called the Lady Gaga of tennis, has been making fashion statements with her hair. At Wimbledon, she wore a blue, lime green and yellow updo after a brief flirtation with a more subdued look (blond ponytail, black knee socks) at the French Open.

headline: More Painful Memories for a Slovene in New York
abstract: Aljaz Bedene lost in the first round of the United States Open on Monday; last year in New York, he had his appendix removed.
lead_paragraph: Aljaz Bedene lost in the first round of the United States Open on Monday. But at least he did not end up in the hospital.

headline: The McMansion Man
abstract: Joe Farrell, the largest real estate developer in the Hamptons, is changing the look of the elite beach destination.
lead_paragraph: Joe Farrell, the largest real estate developer in the Hamptons, is changing the look of the elite beach destination.

headline: Hamptons McMansions Herald a Return of Excess
abstract: There is no surer sign that the big-spending ways of the pre-financial crisis era have returned to the Hamptons than the similar looking mansions across the landscape.
lead_paragraph: BRIDGEHAMPTON, N.Y. — Porsche ads clog the local radio here, houses are renting at close to the million-dollar range — for the summer — and Uber, an app that lets you order car service, reports that its new Hamptons luxury S.U.V. business is booming, $50 minimum fares and all.

headline: Officer Is Indicted on Charges of Lying About Photographer’s Arrest
keywords: ['Photography', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: The officer, Michael Ackermann, claimed that Robert Stolarik’s camera flash interfered with a girl’s arrest last year, but evidence later emerged that no flash had been used.
lead_paragraph: A New York City police officer who had arrested a photographer working for The New York Times has been indicted on three felony counts and five misdemeanors accusing him of fabricating the reasons for the arrest, the Bronx district attorney announced on Monday.

headline: In Jeter’s Return, a Missed Chance for Celebration
abstract: Phil Hughes lasted only four and two-third innings and Ichiro Suzuki dropped a fly ball in a three-run fifth to spoil Derek Jeter’s return to the team.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Derek Jeter was back on the field playing alongside Alex Rodriguez in a game for the first time all season Monday, facing a Toronto Blue Jays team the Yankees had thrashed and battered in almost every previous encounter in 2013. Jeter managed to remain healthy and Rodriguez even homered in the game. What could possibly go wrong to prevent a win?

headline: Party Leader in India Becomes Ill After Speech
abstract: Sonia Gandhi, 66, whose health has been a subject of speculation, left a parliamentary session and was admitted to a cardiology unit.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Sonia Gandhi, leader of the Indian National Congress Party, was released from a hospital in the capital early Tuesday after she became ill during a Monday parliamentary session and was briefly admitted to a cardiology unit.

headline: Pennsylvania’s Capital Files Plan for Finances With Court
abstract: A receiver turned in a detailed document showing how Harrisburg can escape from a mountain of debt and avoid filing for Chapter 9 bankruptcy.
lead_paragraph: A receiver overseeing the finances of Pennsylvania’s distressed capital, Harrisburg, filed a detailed plan on Monday showing how the city will sell or lease assets and raise new revenue as it seeks to escape from a mountain of debt and restore financial stability.

headline: Treasury Prods Lawmakers on Raising Debt Ceiling
keywords: ['National Debt (US)', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Treasury Department said that the government would lose the ability to pay all its bills in mid-October if Congress failed to act.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Unless Congress raises the debt ceiling, the Treasury Department said on Monday that it expected to lose the ability to pay all of the government’s bills in mid-October.

headline: Third Point Hedge Fund Increases Sotheby’s Stake
abstract: Daniel S. Loeb’s hedge fund, Third Point, is now one of Sotheby’s biggest shareholders, with a 5.7 percent stake, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
lead_paragraph: The activist investor Daniel S. Loeb disclosed on Monday that he had acquired a large stake in the auction house Sotheby’s, sending its shares up 3 percent.

headline: Seeking Asylum in Australia, Refugees Find a Policy in Flux
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Smuggling']
abstract: Accounts from some who have fled their countries for Australia describe dangerous sea voyages that can lead to deportment to Papua New Guinea and long waits for resettlement.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — In January, Naqsh Murtaza had had enough of war-torn Afghanistan. Mr. Naqsh, a 27-year-old Afghan, fled with his mother and two younger brothers across the border into Pakistan, the first stop on a risky journey whose ultimate destination was Australia.

headline: Zajick Pulls Out of ‘Dolores Claiborne’
abstract: Dolora Zajick, the acclaimed mezzo-soprano, has withdrawn from the title role of the San Francisco Opera’s production.
lead_paragraph: Dolora Zajick will not be Dolores Claiborne after all.

headline: A Soft Sell for Air Fresheners, With Joan Rivers in Reality Show Spoofs
abstract: Seven planned episodes of a Web series featuring Joan Rivers will spoof “The Bachelorette” and other romance-centric reality competition shows.
lead_paragraph: CAN a frank, bawdy comedian and her equally outspoken daughter find happiness selling air fresheners? And can a maker of air fresheners find happiness with such seemingly unlikely pitchwomen? When the product-peddling aspects of the advertising can be soft-pedaled — as now occurs increasingly on Madison Avenue, in a trend known as content marketing — the answer may be “yes.”

headline: For a Day at Least, British Fans Have More Than Murray to Cheer
abstract: The British qualifier Daniel Evans upset No. 11 Kei Nishikori, and Laura Robson, seeded for the first time at a major, beat Lourdes Dominguez Lino.
lead_paragraph: In the eyes of the ever-sensationalist British news media, the opening day of the United States Open was about two players, and they were not Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal.

headline: Malicious Software Poses as Video From a Facebook Friend
abstract: Attackers are using built-in features of the Chrome and Firefox Web browsers to install malicious software that can see everything stored in the browser, including saved passwords for e-mail and social network accounts, according to Italian security researchers.
lead_paragraph: A piece of malicious software masquerading as a Facebook video is hijacking users’ Facebook accounts and Web browsers, according to independent Italian security researchers who have been investigating the situation.

headline: Ryan Refuses to Revisit Quarterback Situation
abstract: After taking responsibility for playing Mark Sanchez late in Saturday’s preseason game, Jets Coach Rex Ryan did not want to answer questions Monday about Sanchez or Geno Smith.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The Jets are listing Mark Sanchez as day to day, and he believes that is a fair characterization of his health. It is better than being week to week, which would eliminate him from consideration to start the Sept. 8 season opener, but not nearly as good as not having an injured right shoulder in the first place.

headline: Pierre-Paul and Rolle Join Practice
abstract: Giants defensive end Jason Pierre-Paul was taken off the physically unable to perform list Monday, and safety Antrel Rolle joined him at practice.
lead_paragraph: A day after the Giants’ defense took a major step backward when safety Stevie Brown was placed on injured reserve, the unit took two major steps forward. Jason Pierre-Paul, a defensive end who was nearly unstoppable when he recorded 16 ½ sacks and helped the Giants win the Super Bowl two years ago, was taken off the physically unable to perform list Monday. He was joined in practice by safety Antrel Rolle, who had been sidelined since Aug. 12 with a sprained ankle.

headline: Five Years After TARP, Misgivings on Bonuses
abstract: Henry Paulson on bonuses paid during the 2008 financial crisis: “There was such a total lack of awareness from the firms that paid big bonuses during this extraordinary time.”
lead_paragraph: “There was such a total lack of awareness from the firms that paid big bonuses during this extraordinary time.”

headline: N.S.A. Phone Data Collection Is Illegal, A.C.L.U. Says
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The American Civil Liberties Union’s motion in a federal suit cited the warnings of George Orwell in arguing that the National Security Agency’s collection of Americans’ phone call data violated the Constitution.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a detailed legal attack on the National Security Agency’s collection of Americans’ phone call data, the American Civil Liberties Union argued in court papers filed Monday that the sweeping data gathering violates the Constitution and should be halted.

headline: The Two Cultures of Educational Reform
abstract: Online teaching — its possibilities and its deadly caveats.
lead_paragraph: About halfway through his magisterial study “Higher Education in America,” Derek Bok, twice president of Harvard, identifies what he calls the “two different cultures” of educational reform. The first “is an evidence-based approach to education … rooted in the belief that one can best advance teaching and learning by measuring student progress and testing experimental efforts to increase it.” The second “rests on a conviction that effective teaching is an art which one can improve over time through personal experience and intuition without any need for data-driven reforms imposed from above.”

headline: Britain’s Furor Over Fracking
abstract: Prime Minister David Cameron has championed shale gas. But with next to no public debate, he may have done more harm than good.
lead_paragraph: BALCOMBE, England — The lovely green hills of the High Weald are Tory country, a corner of West Sussex full of affluent residents who commute to London and like their golf and ambles and thatched cottages. So it is a surprise, in this conservative heartland, to stumble on an encampment of hundreds of activists, foraging in the hedgerows for edible greens, sawing wood for fires, playing flutes and generally enacting a kind of mini-Woodstock.

headline: Prosecution of Ex-Marine for 2008 Iraq Shooting Sets Off Debate
abstract: Cpl. Wilfredo Santiago’s gun went off, wounding and leaving a medic partly blind. Now the Manhattan federal prosecutor is acting where military officials did not.
lead_paragraph: When the gun went off inside the trailer at a Marine outpost in Iraq in 2008, the bullet pierced the left temple of a Navy hospital corpsman who was seated on his cot, rupturing his left eye and exiting though his right cheek. He survived, but was left partly blind.

headline: The Risk Pool
abstract: At the start of another school year, parents, remember: if we never give our children permission to get things wrong, they’re unlikely to ever learn how to get things right.
lead_paragraph: BELGRADE LAKES, Me. — THIRTY-SEVEN years ago this week my friend Pearce Bunting was at the wheel of my Volkswagen and I was in the passenger seat when he drove the car off a road in suburban Philadelphia. It bounced off a fire hydrant and then plunged into a small ravine. I remember thinking, as we flew through the air, that I was about to find out whether there was life after death. I heard the crash as if from a distant room. Then a vague blue blob spoke. “Are you all right?” it wanted to know, and then said, more reassuringly, “You’re going to be all right.”

headline: Egypt’s Journalists, Still Under Siege
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Since the beginning of my career, I have faced accusations of blasphemy and death threats. It’s as if terrorism will never end in Egypt.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — I LOOKED on, astonished, as a man a few yards away told protesters that he would slaughter me.

headline: Gorky Park, Once Drab, Now Glows
keywords: ['Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: The park has transformed over the past two years into an extravagant urban recreational space that offers Muscovites a respite from the intense political pressures of Russia.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The runners and bikers arrive first, gliding along the bank of the Moscow River. Later come the legions of in-line skaters, parents pushing baby strollers, children on scooters, brides tottering on high heels.

headline: At Charter Schools, Short Careers by Choice
abstract: Charter networks are developing what amounts to a youth movement in which teaching for two to five years is seen as acceptable, even desirable.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Tyler Dowdy just started his third year of teaching at YES Prep West, a charter school here. He figures now is a good time to explore his next step, including applying for a supervisory position at the school.

headline: At 35, Not Quite Ready to Give Up the Dream
abstract: After playing professional tennis for 15 years and with retirement a possibility, Michael Russell, ranked 92nd, lost again in the first round at the United States Open.
lead_paragraph: There is only so much jet lag that the human body can be expected to endure. Only so many locker rooms and hotel rooms and practice courts. We won’t even get into the emotional scars of losing week after week after week for all but the chosen few.

headline: The Ideas Behind the March
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Discrimination']
abstract: What Randolph, Rustin and King believed.
lead_paragraph: As we commemorate the 1963 civil rights march on Washington, it’s worth remembering how close it came to not happening at all. When A. Philip Randolph and Bayard Rustin started shopping the idea, the Urban League declined to support it, the N.A.A.C.P. refused to commit one way or another, and Martin Luther King and the Southern Christian Leadership Conference were too busy with other challenges to get engaged. President John Kennedy argued that the march would hurt the chances of passing legislation.

headline: Dangerous Ticks
abstract: More research is needed to control Lyme disease and other tick-borne illnesses.
lead_paragraph: Residents of the Northeast and the Midwest know that ticks can carry the bacteria that cause Lyme disease. What most don’t know is that the same family of black-legged ticks can also cause other diseases that are even more dangerous.

headline: Responding to Syrian Atrocities
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations', 'Editorials']
abstract: Any military response by President Obama should be carefully targeted and backed by international support.
lead_paragraph: There is little doubt now that President Obama is planning some kind of military response to what the administration says without equivocation was a chemical weapons attack by the Syrian government that killed hundreds of civilians. On Monday, Secretary of State John Kerry began forcefully making the case for action.

headline: Inside Donald Trump’s University

lead_paragraph: Amid the devastating storms of recent years, the experience has grown familiar in some corners of Long Island — fallen wires, power poles tumbling to street level and electricity that disappeared in a flash.

headline: Vermont Yankee Plant to Close Next Year as the Nuclear Industry Retrenches
abstract: The company just won a legal fight to keep the reactor open, but said a long depression in natural-gas prices had pushed the wholesale price of electricity so low it was losing money on the plant.
lead_paragraph: The Vermont Yankee nuclear reactor, one of the oldest nuclear plants in the country and the subject of heated battles over the decades, will close late next year, the company that owns it announced on Tuesday, less than two weeks after winning a protracted legal fight against the State of Vermont to keep it open.

headline: Image of the Day: August 27
abstract: A 200-year-old gold watch was on display in an exhibition in Kolkata, West Bengal.

headline: The Plight of the Black P.O.W.
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Discrimination', 'Prisoners of War', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Slavery']
abstract: African-American soldiers captured during the Civil War faced harrowing, often deadly treatment at the hands of the Confederates.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who saw the film “Glory” remembers the powerful closing scene in which, after failing to take Fort Wagner, members of the all-black 54th Massachusetts Volunteer Infantry and their white officers are buried together on the South Carolina beach. While the film leaves the viewer with a powerful image of the sacrifice of African-American soldiers and their white officers, it does not address the fate of those members of the 54th Massachusetts who were captured that July day in 1863. The entrance of black troops into the Civil War following the Emancipation Proclamation placed the Confederate authorities in a difficult dilemma: what to do with African-Americans in Union blues taken prisoner on the battlefield?

headline: Ex-President of Germany, Onetime Merkel Ally, to Be Tried
abstract: Christian Wulff, a onetime ally of Chancellor Angela Merkel, faces charges of accepting favors while he was governor of Lower Saxony.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Christian Wulff, a former German president and a onetime ally of Chancellor Angela Merkel who quit over allegations of accepting favors from wealthy friends while serving as a governor, will become the first former head of state in the country’s postwar history to stand trial.

headline: A New Waldorf in Ras al-Khaimah
abstract: The new Waldorf Astoria Ras Al Khaimah features design elements evoking an Arabian palace.
lead_paragraph: One of the seven United Arab Emirates, Ras al-Khaimah calls itself a “rising emirate.” Now it has a new luxury hotel — the Waldorf Astoria Ras al-Khaimah — to support the tourism claim.

headline: When We Were Frosh
abstract: Stories from the magazine’s staff about our wacky — and beloved — freshman college roommates.
lead_paragraph: Many soon-to-be college students are packing up now and in the coming weeks, getting ready to move into dorm rooms with perfect strangers. That got us thinking here about our own memories of our freshman roommates.

headline: Obama Weighs ‘Limited’ Strikes Against Syrian Forces
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: President Obama is exploring a range of military actions against Syria designed to “deter and degrade” the ability of President Bashar al-Assad’s regime to launch chemical weapons, officials said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama is considering military action against Syria that is intended to “deter and degrade” President Bashar al-Assad’s government’s ability to launch chemical weapons, but is not aimed at ousting Mr. Assad from power or forcing him to the negotiating table, administration officials said Tuesday.

headline: Headphones Combine Good Sound and Sleek Design
abstract: Aimed at the higher end of the consumer market, KEF’s M500 on-ear headphones provide style, comfort and sound.
lead_paragraph: The British audio company KEF has been making speakers and studio monitors for more than 50 years, but it only recently turned its attention to headphones.

headline: Across China, Skyscrapers Brush the Heavens
abstract: China is home to 60 of the world’s 100 tallest buildings now under construction, but the scale and speed of the projects have caused concern.
lead_paragraph: CHANGSHA, China — China is slowing down, but the buildings keep going up — until now.

headline: An Ambitious Construction Schedule Using Prefab Modules, With Questions
abstract: The Broad Group, a construction company, wants Sky City to be not only the tallest jumbo skyscraper when it opens but also the most rapidly built.
lead_paragraph: CHANGSHA, China — The 202-story Sky City project is not the tallest building on the drawing boards around the world. That distinction belongs to the Kingdom Tower, a project in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, that is supposed to be 532 feet taller — the first building to reach a full kilometer.

headline: Forget the Punching Bag, Try the Robots
abstract: A new toy called Battroborgs simulates boxing in the vein of Rock ’Em Sock ’Em Robots.
lead_paragraph: Battroborgs, an electronic update of the old Rock ’Em Sock ’Em Robots toy, are a lot of fun, and hardly need the hype that the marketing team for the toy has thrown at it.

headline: Cooking With a New Computer
abstract: Unless a specific program is needed — say, one for creating a cookbook — choosing between Mac or Windows is a matter of preference.
lead_paragraph: Taste Largely Decides

headline: It’s Chelsea Manning From Now On in The Times
abstract: The soldier who leaked documents identifies as a woman and The Times will respect her wishes.
lead_paragraph: The Times will begin immediately to call the former Bradley Manning by her preferred name – Chelsea Manning.

headline: Why a Conservative Christian Took a Shine to Vladimir Putin
abstract: Bryan Fischer, a director at the American Family Association, commended Russia’s anti-gay laws.
lead_paragraph: It used to be that the American right was staunchly opposed to Russian Big Brother oppression. It is an article of faith among Republicans that Ronald Reagan’s implacable hostility to the Kremlin brought down the Berlin Wall in particular and Soviet Communism in general. Nor are Republicans particularly keen on President Vladimir Putin, the spiritual heir of 70 years of Soviet communism.

headline: After Ackman’s Exit, J.C. Penney Remains a Hedge Fund Play
abstract: Several of William A. Ackman’s rivals in the hedge fund world aren’t bailing out of the troubled retailer just yet.
lead_paragraph: William A. Ackman may have severed all ties to J.C. Penney on Monday, after selling off his 18 percent stake at an estimated $473 million loss.

headline: Wheelies: The Bye Bye Bus Edition
keywords: ['Auctions', 'Automobiles', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Vans']
abstract: After 56 years, Volkswagen ends production of the Type 2 Kombi van in Brazil, and a gold-plated Cadillac that may have belonged to Liberace is headed for auction.
lead_paragraph: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: A Record Skyscraper for China
abstract: Work has begun in Changsha, the capital of Hunan province in south-central China, on a skyscraper that would be the world’s tallest.
lead_paragraph: Work has begun in Changsha, the capital of Hunan province in south-central China, on a skyscraper that would be the world’s tallest.

headline: The Young Developer’s Guide to Debugging JavaScript
abstract: Your strongest debugging tool is the one between your ears. All the arcane debugging knowledge in the world is no substitute for understanding what you’re coding.
lead_paragraph: We recently completed our internship program here at The Times, and it’s made me wonder what I would have liked to have known when I was a young developer. The answer: I wish I’d known more about debugging.

headline: Nudged to the Produce Aisle by a Look in the Mirror
keywords: ['Supermarkets and Grocery Stores', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Fruit', 'Vegetables', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: Researchers out to promote healthier eating habits are using gentle cues, like strategically placed mirrors, to steer shoppers toward fruits and vegetables.
lead_paragraph: EL PASO — Samuel Pulido walked into his local grocery store on a sweltering day, greeted by cool air and the fantasy-world ambience of the modern supermarket.

headline: A Chef in the Field | Sungold and Heirloom Tomatoes
abstract: The delicate, sweet flavor of little, warm Sungold tomatoes, which are aplenty in farmers’ markets this time of year, gets paired with the meatier texture of cool heirloom tomatoes in this seasonal dish.
lead_paragraph: This series by the chef Jeff Schwarz and the photographer Greg Kessler traces the trajectory of seasonal food — from its original source to a place on your table.

headline: Ickes Returns to Democratic Committee’s Rules and Bylaws Panel
abstract: Harold M. Ickes has rejoined a panel tasked with setting the guidelines governing the presidential nominating process.
lead_paragraph: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — The Democratic National Committee’s summer meeting here late last week was starkly different from the gathering of its Republican counterparts earlier in the month. There were no surefire news-making speakers like Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey or former Speaker Newt Gingrich, nor was there consideration of any made-for-cable-news resolutions, like one that tried to bar a pair of television networks from sponsoring future presidential debates.

headline: Scenes From a Wildfire Near Yosemite
abstract: Firefighters continue to battle a large blaze near Yosemite National Park.
lead_paragraph: Firefighters continue to battle a large blaze near Yosemite National Park.

headline: Vigilantism and Its Discontents
abstract: Self-defense groups have emerged throughout Mexico because of government failure, and the government’s response is another kind of failure.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — On Aug. 18, during a ceremony in the public square of Xaltianguis, a town of fewer than 10,000 near Acapulco, more than 100 women — housewives, traditional doctors, traders — were handed out rifles.

headline: 10 Questions for Jacob Lew
abstract: The Treasury secretary spoke to John Harwood about extending government funding past Sept. 30, dealing with the so-called budget sequester and raising the federal debt limit.
lead_paragraph: Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew has been part of Washington’s fiscal battles for three decades, since he served as an aide to then-House Speaker Thomas P. O’Neill. But soon he will be the Obama administration’s point man on an unusual convergence of fronts: extending government funding past the end of the current fiscal year on Sept. 30, dealing with the so-called budget sequester and raising the federal debt limit.

headline: In Choice of Hands, Nadal Is Not Alone
abstract: Jurgen Melzer and Angelique Kerber are also among the top tennis players who are naturally right-handed but swing a racket with their left hands.
lead_paragraph: A European player belting tennis balls on Court 7 drew onlookers to his midday practice Sunday. Sprinting to his left, he hit a topspin forehand like he had done for as long as anyone could remember. He scampered to his right and smacked a two-handed backhand that jumped off the court. He is naturally right-handed but makes his living hitting the ball primarily with his non-dominant hand.

headline: Facebook Releases Report on Government Requests
abstract: Facebook on Tuesday for the first time released a report showing the number of requests about its users from government agencies around the globe, noting that a vast majority of requests relate to criminal cases, though some include national security issues.
lead_paragraph: Facebook on Tuesday for the first time released a report showing the number of requests about its users that it has received from government agencies around the globe.

headline: Federer and Kvitova Pass First-Round Tests, but Janowicz Does Not
abstract: Roger Federer and Petra Kvitova won their opening matches at the United States Open, while the qualifier Máximo González ousted 14th-seeded Jerzy Janowicz.
lead_paragraph: When highly ranked players begin to struggle in early matches at the United States Open, the radar goes on alert for those vulnerable to an upset, to separate them from those with mere short-term issues: perhaps getting used to the shifting winds at the National Tennis Center, fighting off nerves, or just rebounding from a particularly hair-raising car ride from Manhattan.

headline: Mets Pitching Prospect Suspended for 50 Games
abstract: Chase Huchingson, a left-handed relief pitcher for the Mets’ Class AA team in Binghamton, was suspended for 50 games after a second violation for a drug of abuse under baseball’s drug program.
lead_paragraph: Chase Huchingson, a left-handed relief pitcher for the Mets’ Class AA affiliate, was suspended for 50 games after a second violation for a drug of abuse under baseball’s drug program, the league announced Monday night.

headline: Bank Executive Admits to Using Bailout Money to Buy Condo
abstract: Darryl Layne Woods, the former chairman of Mainstreet Bank in Missouri, used a good portion of the $1 million in bailout money that his bank received to buy himself a luxury vacation condo in Florida.
lead_paragraph: In November 2008, during the depths of the financial crisis, Darryl Layne Woods, a bank executive in Missouri, applied to the United States Treasury for bailout money. His bank received $1 million.

headline: U.S. Open Food Review: Heading to the Hill
abstract: Today’s U.S. Open food review: Hill Country BBQ’s pit-smoked turkey sandwich.
lead_paragraph: Because eating at the United States Open is a high-stakes game, we will feature a daily review of items available at the food courts at the National Tennis Center.

headline: Q. & A.: Cassandra Clare on ‘The Mortal Instruments’
abstract: Ms. Clare discusses the movie adaptation of the first volume of her best-selling series of fantasy novels.
lead_paragraph: “City of Bones,” the film adaptation of the first book in Cassandra Clare’s young adult fantasy series “The Mortal Instruments,” opened last week. In a recent phone interview, Ms. Clare spoke about the film, her forthcoming middle-grade series, writing with Holly Black (author of “Doll Bones” and “The Spiderwick Chronicles”) and what readers can expect from “City of Heavenly Fire,” the final novel in the “Mortal Instruments” series, due  next May. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: A Tale of Two Drag Racing Legends: ‘Snake & Mongoose’
abstract: Don Prudhomme and Tom McEwen set many N.H.R.A. records, but a Hollywood red carpet is a new experience for the drag racing duo.
lead_paragraph: HOLLYWOOD — Don Prudhomme and Tom McEwen set many records while racing on the dragstrip. They probably never contemplated walking down the red carpet.

headline: First Shots Are Fired in Britain After Debate on a Badger Cull
abstract: Protesters set up camp as sharpshooters began killing 5,000 animals over six weeks, a move intended to slow the spread of tuberculosis among cattle.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The sharpshooters came by night, with high-powered rifles and cages. Their foes came, too, with candles and masks and bright yellow slickers.

headline: Mollie Katzen Is Still Cooking
abstract: Even at this point in her career, Ms. Katzen still feels the need to be clearing up Moosewood myths.
lead_paragraph: Even at this point in her career, Mollie Katzen still feels the need to be clearing up Moosewood myths.

headline: Trains, Not Lines, Foil U.S. Open Fans on Day 2
abstract: Delays on the 7 train Tuesday morning led to scenes of sweaty tennis fans waiting on train platforms, frustrated Tweets and much watch-checking.
lead_paragraph: They came by car, they came by bus, they came by plane. But the tennis fans who had it worst on Day 2 of the United States Open were those who came by train. The 7 train that connects Midtown Manhattan to the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center, to be precise.

headline: Restored Film of an Ill-Fated Mt. Everest Expedition to Show at London Festival
abstract: “The Epic of Everest,” which follows the 1924 British expedition in which two famed climbers died, has been restored.
lead_paragraph: A newly restored version of a film documenting an early attempt to climb Mount Everest will be shown as part of this year’s BFI London Film Festival, the British Film Institute announced on Tuesday. “The Epic of Everest,” directed by the British explorer Capt. John Noel, followed the 1924 expedition led by George Mallory, in which both Mallory and another climber, Andrew Irvine, died.

headline: From Fashion to Crashing at County Fairs
keywords: ['State and County Fairs', 'Budget Travel', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Nearing the end of his summer road trip, the Frugal Traveler stops in Minnesota where he sits runway-side for a fashion show and catches his first demolition derby.
lead_paragraph: New York’s fall Fashion Week starts in a few days, but you won’t find me staking out Lincoln Center to steal a glimpse of a model or designer. I’ve already had my fill of runway glamour this summer, at the Cloverbud division of the 4-H Fashion Revue at the Becker County Fair in Detroit Lakes, Minn. Better yet, I didn’t have to flash press credentials: there was no security at the red-and-white striped tent. And there were plenty of places to sit — comfy bales of hay instead of chairs crammed onto risers — and watch the kids (kindergartners through third graders) show off the ensembles they’ve put together (that is, bought at the mall).

headline: Minnesota County Fairs
keywords: ['Road Trips', 'State and County Fairs', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Agriculture and Farming']
abstract: Seth Kugel winds down his summer road trip at county fairs, where livestock competitions and pig races are just part of the action.
lead_paragraph: Seth Kugel winds down his summer road trip at county fairs, where livestock competitions and pig races are just part of the action.

headline: Drinking in Istanbul and Bangkok
abstract: The writer Lawrence Osborne talks about trying to decipher the drinking cultures of the two cities.
lead_paragraph: Following the publication of his book “The Accidental Connoisseur: An Irreverent Journey Through the Wine World” in 2004, the English writer Lawrence Osborne was offered what was, at first, a plum assignment: being flown around the world to write about wine and spirits.

headline: Restaurant Report: Meat Mission in London
abstract: Munching through this burger spot’s menu is indeed a mission of meat, one that channels London’s current culinary infatuation.
lead_paragraph: Forget fish and chips: London’s current culinary infatuation is with the American hamburger, with blogs and apps serving the city’s new obsession. Until recently, the high temple of British burgermania was the dark, no-reservations Meat Liquor, near Oxford Circus. But in December, its owners, Scott Collins and Yianni Papoutsis, opened Meat Mission, in trendy Shoreditch, with such diner-friendly features as reservations and enough wattage for guests to see what they are eating.

headline: At Grand Canyon, a New Mule Trip on the East Rim Trail
keywords: ['National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: For the first time, mules will take riders along the rim of the south canyon at Grand Canyon National Park.
lead_paragraph: Mules, which have been transporting Grand Canyon visitors since 1887, just got a new job. Starting this week, Grand Canyon National Park’s “long-eared taxis” will start taking riders along the south rim of the canyon for the first time.

headline: Before Byrd’s T-Shirt Night, the Mets Trade Him and Buck
abstract: The Mets on Tuesday traded Marlon Byrd and John Buck to Pittsburgh for a minor-league infielder and a player to be named.
lead_paragraph: About 500 people bought ticket packages to the Mets’ game Tuesday night that included T-shirts bearing right fielder Marlon Byrd’s name and number on the back. But as fans made their way to Citi Field, Byrd’s locker in the clubhouse was being cleared out and wiped down.

headline: Hotel Review: James Royal Palm in Miami Beach
abstract: Reopened under the James’s ownership in November, this property exudes laid-back luxury and offers a host of amenities.
lead_paragraph: Rates

headline: Red Sea and Aliens Explored, Again
abstract: “The Unexplained Files,” a new television series on the Science Channel, looks at some puzzles of existence.
lead_paragraph: Humans are hard-wired to want answers, explanations, solutions. We can’t just accept that Jimmy Hoffa walked into an intergalactic wormhole in the Detroit suburbs and is now living somewhere in the constellation Orion; we have to keep looking for him. We can’t just dump the contents of a jigsaw puzzle box onto a table and admire the colorful chaos; we have to waste hours assembling it.

headline: Soho Rep Announces New Season
abstract: The downtown theater’s new season includes the New York premiere of David Adjmi’s “Marie Antoinette” and Branden Jacobs-Jenkins’s “Octoroon.”
lead_paragraph: Soho Rep has big ambitions for its small new season. On Tuesday the downtown theater company announced it will mount two full productions in 2013-14: the New York premiere of David Adjmi’s “Marie Antoinette,” and “An Octoroon” by Branden Jacobs-Jenkins.

headline: Sudden Burst of Residential Activity in an Overlooked Slice of TriBeCa
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Condominiums']
abstract: On a four-block stretch of Broadway, between Worth and Walker Streets, nine new residential projects are in the works, bringing more than 430 new condominium units to the area.
lead_paragraph: The area of lower Broadway south of Canal Street in Manhattan has long been characterized by nondescript discount stores and lunchtime counters packed with city workers. It has been mostly ignored by the wave of gentrification to the west that has flooded TriBeCa over the last decade, bringing with it baby carriages, designer boutiques and restaurants.

headline: Cocky, Aggressive and Into Gangs: Meet Tokyo’s Streetwise Toughs
abstract: The documentary “Tokyo Waka” examines how some 20,000 crows living in Tokyo adapt to the area’s human population of 13 million.
lead_paragraph: “Tokyo Waka,” a new documentary by John Haptas and Kristine Samuelson, describes itself as a “city poem,” which is certainly accurate. The film is a short, nimble consideration of the collision between the wildness of nature and the orderly bustle of modern urban life. It is also an essay on ornithology, Japanese culture and the challenges of pest control.

headline: Retro Report: Season Two Preview
abstract: A preview of the documentary series Retro Report, which re-examines leading stories of decades past. New documentaries will be released every Monday this fall on The Times’s Web site.
lead_paragraph: A preview of the documentary series Retro Report, which re-examines leading stories of decades past. New documentaries will be released every Monday this fall on The Times’s Web site.

headline: A New Vintage Online Boutique Caters to the Downtown Set
abstract: Total Pleasure, a new secondhand e-commerce destination that went live last month, caters to a very niche market with vintage finds like velvet bustiers and pants covered in flames or Mountain Dew logos.
lead_paragraph: “We do party wear, casual Sunday statement pieces and birthday outfits,” said Hally Erickson about Total Pleasure, the online vintage boutique that she and her business partner Laura Kim started last month. (Their launch event was attended by the likes of Devonté Hynes and the ATL Twins.) She described the boutique’s selection — Velvet Baby Doll Dress, Mountain Dew Pants, Snake Skin Boy Band Jacket and other somewhat seductive and playful sundries — as being comprised of pieces that “you can relax and be casual in, but there’s still an element that makes it stand out and talks to people, without being high heels and a glittery top.”

headline: Living in Dumbo, Brooklyn
abstract: A creative energy lends vibrancy to a neighborhood that now has enough of its own shops and parkland to rival neighboring Brooklyn Heights.
lead_paragraph: A creative energy lends vibrancy to a neighborhood that now has enough of its own shops and parkland to rival neighboring Brooklyn Heights.

headline: At Israeli Resort Town, Ignoring the Strife to Soak Up the Sea
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Crowds still flock to Eilat, at the southern tip of Israel, even when tensions with neighbors are on the rise.
lead_paragraph: EILAT, Israel — About 100 Israelis, mostly families with young children, piled onto a glass-bottomed boat one recent morning for a two-hour cruise around the bay of this lively Red Sea resort at the southern tip of Israel. The main attractions: the underwater coral reserve, the dolphin reef and sightseeing along the border with Egypt’s Sinai Peninsula.

headline: Some Scientists Cast Doubt on Finding of Origins of a Virus
abstract: A report last week that linked a dangerous new coronavirus to Middle Eastern bats has been criticized for its small sample size.
lead_paragraph: Since scientists announced last week that they had tracked a dangerous new coronavirus to bats in Saudi Arabia, a debate has emerged among virologists as to whether there really is enough evidence to back up the claim.

headline: After a Brush With Death, the Terror Is Still Palpable
abstract: In “Surviving Evil,” a series on Investigation Discovery, victims and witnesses describe harrowing criminal attacks.
lead_paragraph: Investigation Discovery’s biggest discovery has been that there is enough real-life crime to fuel an entire cable channel. Its lineup is full of tales constructed of narration by the people involved — victims, witnesses, police officers — and rickety re-enactments.

headline: Dumbo, Brooklyn: How Noir Looks When It’s Polished
abstract: A creative energy lends vibrancy to a neighborhood that now has enough of its own amenities to rival neighboring Brooklyn Heights.
lead_paragraph: Neighborhood lore, at least as related by an oft-cited local history, has it that “Dumbo,” an acronym for Down Under the Manhattan Bridge Overpass, was coined in the late 1970s by a few artists hoping that an odd name would deter development.

headline: Johannsson Is Happy He Chose U.S.
abstract: Aron Johannsson, born in the U.S. to parents from Iceland, is the newest addition to the U.S. men’s national soccer team.
lead_paragraph: As the United States national team prepares to resume World Cup qualifying after a successful three games in June in which it surged into first place in its regional qualifying group and then won the Gold Cup, the team received a boost with the addition of AZ striker Aron Johannsson.

headline: Slow-Smoked Texas Barbecue at Morgans, and More Restaurant Openings
abstract: A pitmaster who worked at the Franklin Barbecue in Austin will serve up brisket, turkey, sausage and more in Prospect Heights.
lead_paragraph: Headliner

headline: Chemical Attack Evidence Lasts Years, Experts Say
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Forensic Science', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Weapons experts say the Syrian government would have a hard time hiding physical evidence if it did indeed use chemical weapons against civilians in a large-scale attack last week.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have discovered that sarin, a deadly nerve agent, can be detected long after its use on the battlefield. In one case, forensic experts went to a Kurdish village in northern Iraq four years after Iraqi warplanes had dropped clusters of bombs there. The experts found a unique chemical signature of the lethal toxin in contaminated soil from bomb craters.

headline: A TV Speaker System Heard but Not Seen
abstract: The Cynema Soundfield, from Niles, is a sound bar for TVs that is mounted flush to the wall, with a grille that can be painted to disappear into the décor.
lead_paragraph: The Niles Cynema Soundfield in-wall sound bar may not be the ultimate in home theater surround-sound equipment, but it does one thing other sound bars do not: it fits flush to the wall, with no unsightly cabinet, and has a grille that can be painted to disappear into the décor.

headline: With Disney Infinity, a Virtual Toy Box
abstract: Disney Infinity embraces an “anything goes” attitude with a video game that incorporates physical toys from five Disney properties to start.
lead_paragraph: When the executives at Disney conceived of Infinity, they imagined a video game that resembled a toy box: random toys could be pulled out for any adventure.

headline: How to Legitimize Intervention in Syria
abstract: President Obama can’t expect much from Congress, but he should still secure backing from legislative leaders.
lead_paragraph: British Prime Minister David Cameron has summoned Parliament back from summer holiday so lawmakers can discuss — and vote on — a response to the chemical attack in Syria. American lawmakers are also on recess, until next week, but it’s doubtful that they will follow Britain’s lead in returning to Washington early to take up the question of intervention. In recent years, Congress, especially the Republican-led House of Representatives, has proven so dysfunctional and riven by partisanship that it has done little legislating on even the most important issues.

headline: French Court Lifts an Environmental Ban on Mercedes-Benz Sales
abstract: Sales had been suspended in France since July in a dispute over the German carmaker’s decision not to equip certain models with a new, more environmentally friendly refrigerant.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Daimler, the German maker of Mercedes-Benz cars, may resume sales in France after the country’s highest administrative court temporarily lifted a ban on Tuesday.

headline: Soba Noodles at Cagen, a Honey Pot for Rosh Hashana and More
abstract: Florence Fabricant’s recommendations for the week of Aug. 27.
lead_paragraph: To Admire: At His Restaurant, He Does It Himself

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Syria, Afghanistan, Portugal and Kenya.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Syria, Afghanistan, Portugal and Kenya.

headline: A Simple Solution That Made a Hard Problem More Difficult
keywords: ['Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Executive Compensation', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: Dodd-Frank required companies to compare their chief executive pay with that of their employees, but the provision may cost millions to put in place.
lead_paragraph: Congressional leaders, in their rage against ever-rising executive compensation and income inequality, have created more murkiness.

headline: Zakopalova Stays at Zero
abstract: No. 31 Klara Zakopalova lost in the first round on Tuesday, falling to 0-10 at the United States Open.
lead_paragraph: The first seed to fall on Day 2 of the United States Open was No. 31 Klara Zakopalova, but it might have been an overstatement to call her defeat an upset.

headline: To Reach Out, Befriend and Kill When Necessary: An Ever Trickier Terrain
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: “The Tender Soldier,” by the journalist Vanessa M. Gezari, examines the military’s “Human Terrain” teams, which operate as quasi-social scientists in Iraq and Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: The wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, among other things, were stark reminders of how little Americans know about the rest of the world. A vast majority of new recruits had never left the United States before deploying for combat, and even many field commanders were clueless about the people they were expected to live among, protect and kill.

headline: Betony
abstract: Inside the Midtown restaurant that bears a family resemblance to Eleven Madison Park.
lead_paragraph: Inside the Midtown restaurant that bears a family resemblance to Eleven Madison Park.

headline: A Testament to Flavors Clear and Pure
abstract: At Betony, which opened in Midtown Manhattan this spring, the food is fussed over, but it isn’t fussy.
lead_paragraph: Chances are you haven’t seen a picture of the roasted chicken at Betony. If you have, you’ve probably forgotten it, because it is just a gracefully tapering triangle of meat with golden skin. A purple-stemmed dandelion leaf lies on top of it, chanterelles and Hakurei turnips huddle at its side, a pool of jus gathers around it on a bone-white plate. In the race to become the most photographed cooked bird in the history of New York, it is no threat to the one at the NoMad.

headline: Pennsylvania Museum Selling a Hopper to Raise Endowment for Contemporary Art
abstract: The Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts will sell a 1934 Edward Hopper painting, “East Wind Over Weehawken,” which is estimated to bring $22 million to $28 million.
lead_paragraph: The Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts is putting up for sale a painting by Edward Hopper from its collection to start an endowment fund to buy contemporary art. The 1934 painting, “East Wind Over Weehawken,” one of two Hopper paintings the academy’s museum holds in its collection, will be sold at auction at Christie’s in New York in December with a presale estimate of between $22 million and $28 million, the academy said.

headline: In London, the Walls Have Eyes
abstract: In “Closed Circuit,” by John Crowley, two London lawyers’ professional lives become muddied by a shared past.
lead_paragraph: “Closed Circuit,” a slick, tasty slice of late-summer nonsense from Britain, comes soaked in gunmetal blue and paranoia. The anxiety is well founded: they’re watching us. A lot — especially through the ubiquitous closed-circuit television cameras that dot London like neighborhood constables or plague sores, depending on your view of life in the surveillance state. Millions of these cameras watch over Britain, at least half of which seem as if they’d been tapped for this movie to lord down from lampposts and buildings over the little people below, including a concerned-looking yet manly Eric Bana and an equally fretful, fetching Rebecca Hall.

headline: Compensation for Your Travel Troubles
abstract: It pays to know the rules: If your flight is canceled or your luggage is late, you may be able to collect a payment.

When I called to rebook, the agent offered a flight two hours earlier, which meant my boyfriend and I had to drop everything and race to Heathrow. The payoff came a month later, when the airline sent a check for $787 (300 euros each), compensation for our inconvenience.

headline: The United Colors of Benetton, and the World
abstract: Luciano Benetton, the father of the Italian sportswear label, displays 200 of his commissioned works, each the size of a business card, at the Venice Biennale.
lead_paragraph: Luciano Benetton, the father of the Italian sportswear label the United Colors of Benetton, embraces and encourages a multi-culti global perspective through his company’s clothes and ad campaigns, and, now, through art. “I have always been a strong believer that people may not speak to each other because of economic or political issues, but I’m pretty sure that even those countries which aren’t speaking to each other can through art,” said Benetton, who recently curated the exhibition “Imago Mundi” (“Images of the World”) at the Querini Stampalia Foundation in Venice. The show is an extension of the Venice Biennale and includes over 1,000 works from his personal collection, by artists from Australia, India, Japan, South Korea and the United States.

With 10 more homers he will match Willie Mays, who hit 660 home runs in his 22-year career. The home run also brought Rodriguez within reach the first of a series of five, $6 million bonuses.

headline: Bomb Syria, Even if It Is Illegal

abstract: As in Kosovo, the United States must justify intervention on moral grounds.
lead_paragraph: EVANSTON, Ill. — THE latest atrocities in the Syrian civil war, which has killed more than 100,000 people, demand an urgent response to deter further massacres and to punish President Bashar al-Assad. But there is widespread confusion over the legal basis for the use of force in these terrible circumstances. As a legal matter, the Syrian government’s use of chemical weapons does not automatically justify armed intervention by the United States.

headline: Cano Leaves Game After Taking a Pitch Off His Hand

headline: Boo Rodriguez or Cheer Him? It’s Oh So Complicated
abstract: Yankees fans, so well-versed in booing, are now faced with cheering a player they no longer like because he’s boosting the team they still love.
lead_paragraph: Booing Alex Rodriguez has become so reflexive that it’s easy to forget what exactly we’re booing him for. Because he cheated? He’s not alone in that, certainly not in recent Yankees history and not even among his current teammates. Because he lied about cheating? Other athletes have ferociously denied allegations, and pursued their accusers, for far longer and with far more false indignation. Because, despite receiving the baseball equivalent of a death sentence (a 211-game suspension), he simply refuses to disappear? Or because in his return to action that few wanted — not Major League Baseball, certainly, or his team’s top officials — Rodriguez is actually lifting the faltering Yankees back into playoff contention?

headline: What Happened to Jobs and Justice?
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: The March on Washington was so successful that we often forget, 50 years later, that it occurred in a political environment not so different from our own.

Its impact on American politics was tremendous: in addition to building support to pass the civil rights bill that President John F. Kennedy had recently proposed, marchers succeeded in strengthening and expanding the scope of the bill far beyond what the president had envisioned.

And in the North Woods, Glenn Phillips, executive director of New York City Audubon, counted 23 bird species in the first of five forays, among them a Wilson’s warbler and American redstarts, prized fall migrants.

headline: Russia: Security Official Killed on Highway in Ingushetia
