lead_paragraph: Unidentified assailants killed a prominent security official on Tuesday in the troubled North Caucasus region, which has a simmering Islamic insurgency. Akhmed Kotiyev, the head of the regional Security Council for the Ingushetia Republic, and his driver were killed by automatic fire from a passing car on a highway near Nazran, the republic’s capital, Russian state television reported. Yunus-Bek Yevkurov, the leader of Ingushetia, said that Mr. Kotiyev was known for negotiating with rebel fighters to abandon the insurgency, and that he was probably killed for that reason.

headline: France: Government Proposes Changes in Pension System
abstract: President François Hollande announced the outlines of a pension reform bill, aimed at preserving an underfunded system but which is likely to be seen by some as insufficient.
lead_paragraph: The government of President François Hollande announced Tuesday the broad outlines of a much anticipated pension reform bill, aimed at preserving a generous but underfunded system but which is likely to be seen by some European officials as insufficient. The bill will seek to stem a $28 billion deficit with increases in withholdings from workers and employers and, beginning in 2020, a gradual increase in the pay-in time required to receive a full pension. A reform in 2010 raised the minimum retirement age from 60 to 62 and increased the pay-in time to 41.5 years; the new bill would raise the pay-in time to 43 years by 2035. Unions and company representatives said they were disappointed.

headline: 36 Hours in the Brandywine Valley
abstract: Just a couple of hours from Manhattan, this area offers everything from Revolutionary War history and art by the Wyeths to rolling hills and manicured estates.

headline: Holidays, High and Low
abstract: Three new picture books about the Jewish holidays Rosh Hashana, Yom Kippur and Sukkot.
lead_paragraph: With the start of the school year come three Jewish holidays: Rosh Hashana, Yom Kippur and Sukkot. In “What a Way to Start a New Year!” Jacqueline Jules imagines what Rosh Hashana might be like for a young family whose new year is starting in a new house in a new town. Dina, who is about 7, finds nothing is as it should be: the friends she liked to visit for the holiday are now hours away, and her home is a mess of packing boxes. “It doesn’t feel like Rosh Hashana here,” she complains. “We don’t even have a round challah.” A series of mishaps makes the phrase “What a way to start a new year!” a common refrain in the house, until a colleague of Dina’s father suggests the family join him at the temple he attends. Though the holidays are different than Dina remembers, she learns something about making friends and embracing change. Judy Stead’s illustrations, rich with festive pinks, greens and purples, are attractive and cheerful even when her characters’ expressive faces register disappointment or impatience. “What a Way to Start a New Year!” is notable in that Jules assumes a basic understanding of the holiday; making this amusing and less obviously didactic book a pleasure to read.

headline: Building a Bridge From Combat to Civilian Life
abstract: The military knows how to turn on hypervigilance. A transition center at Ramstein Air Base in Germany teaches service members how to turn it off.
lead_paragraph: Small things kill in combat. This truism is as old as war itself, but it proved especially correct in Iraq and Afghanistan, where a new pile of dirt or the glint off a wire in the desert sun could be the sole indication that a bomb lay beneath your feet. So at its heart, military training — from the first day of boot camp to the final predeployment war game — has always really been about paying attention to details. The military knows how to turn on hypervigilance. The question is how to turn it off.

headline: On Syria, a Drumbeat With Some Echoes of Iraq
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Some veterans of the period of the Iraq invasion are expressing qualms about a push for military action in Syria, but there are a number of differences 10 years later.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A grim-faced secretary of state reading a bill of charges against a rogue Arab leader. The White House promising intelligence that will provide proof about weapons of mass destruction. Frenetic efforts to piece together a coalition of the willing. Breathless news reports about imminent bombing raids.

headline: Countdown to Fashion Week: Model Casting About for Character
abstract: Designers of Tome label assemble a cast of models for a runway show.
lead_paragraph: Designers tend to speak in code. Often they don’t speak at all. That was the case last Thursday when Ramon Martin and Ryan Lobo, partners in Tome, a three-year-old fashion label, began scrutinizing the parade of comely young women filing into their studio on West 25th Street.

headline: A Coach Joins a Short List by Announcing He’s Gay
abstract: Simon Thibodeau, 40, said his women’s tennis players at U.C.-Santa Barbara greeted his announcement mostly with shrugs, but for him it was freeing.
lead_paragraph: SANTA BARBARA, Calif. — Once Simon Thibodeau convinced himself that it was all right to be gay, and then to be open about it in front of others, he gathered his women’s tennis team in May at the University of California, Santa Barbara. The dozen players in the room wondered why their head coach was so nervous.

headline: Escape From Times Square
abstract: It was the moment to buy a place. And to enjoy a quieter, less crowded neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: Since 2007, when she arrived in New York from Texas, Christina LaScalea had lived in a high-rise rental building on West 42nd Street. She occupied the bedroom while her roommate — she went through three — had the converted living room. The rent started at $3,100 a month, dipped and rose again. The most Ms. LaScalea ever paid for her share was $1,800.

headline: U.S. Government Issues Warning About Security on Android Phones
abstract: Google’s Android is the most widely used mobile software system in the world, and as a result it is becoming an increasingly big target for makers of malicious software, similar to Microsoft’s Windows. The American government has issued a warning about the potential security threat for Android.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:51 a.m. | Adding Google’s response.Google’s Android operating system is the most widely used mobile software system in the world, which makes it a big target for makers of malicious software, the way Microsoft Windows system is. Now the American government has issued a warning about the potential security threat of Android.

lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia has made its opposition to military intervention in Syria vehemently clear. The foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, warns daily about the risk of an escalating conflagration. A deputy prime minister said the West dealt with the Islamic world like “a monkey with a grenade.” A few commentators on the fringe have warned of World War III.

headline: Should Hasan Get the Death Penalty?
abstract: There’s no doubt he killed 13 people at Fort Hood, yet there’s still a case to be made that he should not be executed.
lead_paragraph: A military jury on Wednesday sentenced Maj. Nidal Hasan to death, surprising no one. Major Hasan never denied killing 13 people and wounding dozens at the Fort Hood military base in 2009. He refused representation and can’t really be said to have defended himself. He said he’d killed Americans in the name of Islamic insurgents abroad.

headline: Goodbye, Gus
abstract: Video of Gus, a polar bear at the Central Park Zoo, from the Wildlife Conservation Society. Gus was euthanized after medical professionals found an inoperable tumor. He was 27.
lead_paragraph: Video of Gus, a polar bear at the Central Park Zoo, from the Wildlife Conservation Society. Gus was euthanized after medical professionals found an inoperable tumor. He was 27.

headline: A Survivor of a Play Resurfaces
abstract: Donald Margulies’s play “Model Apartment” is reintroduced, after “a very dispiriting turn of events” that went on for decades.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Papp, who as artistic director of the sprawling Public Theater had several performance spaces at his disposal, wasn’t known for mothballing projects. Rising young playwrights don’t typically rewrite their endings because the actors would rather not say the lines. And plays tend not to lose their leading men the day after the reviews come out, especially when the reviews are good.

headline: What I Learned Driving Through the Heartland
keywords: ['Budget Travel', 'Travel and Vacations', 'State and County Fairs', 'Road Trips']
abstract: This summer, the Frugal Traveler drove from Louisiana to North Dakota, crossing into a number of states for the first time. What did he discover? Some lessons from the road.
lead_paragraph: “The udder on this cow just keeps getting better and better as the day goes on,” remarked Barry Visser, Kandiyohi County Fair dairy cattle judge, over the PA system. A boy led his prizewinning Holstein away as a friendly crowd of western Minnesotans, and one out-of-place New Yorker, looked on from the modest stands. The dairy cow competition was nearing its end; the rabbits, hens and pigs had already had their days of judgment — no udders required — and were unwinding one building down. Up the hill, workers prepared rides and games and funnel cake stands to open.

headline: Your Road Trip Discoveries
abstract: Readers share stories of what they found during drives in America.
lead_paragraph: Readers share stories of what they found during drives in America.

lead_paragraph: Hedge fund titans are making a $170,336 bet that Christine C. Quinn is the best candidate to run New York.

lead_paragraph: Photos from Israel, Jordan, Iraq and India.

headline: Something in the Way He Moves Attracts Listeners
abstract: The pianist Taka Kigawa, playing at Le Poisson Rouge, manifested wonder and joy in his performance of demanding works.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to put your finger on just what it is that makes the pianist Taka Kigawa a phenomenon, but there’s no denying that he’s something special. True, other pianists have made a specialty of the demanding modernist works that Mr. Kigawa favors. Webern, Boulez, Xenakis and Stockhausen are among his staples. (Bach, too.) And in his considerable technical prowess, Mr. Kigawa is not without peers.

headline: The Ad Campaign: Speaking in Support of Weiner
abstract: A new ad from Anthony D. Weiner features the first time he has deployed surrogates — not himself — to make his campaign pitch.
lead_paragraph: After soaring to the top of the Democratic mayoral primary field in some polls earlier this summer, former Representative Anthony D. Weiner is now struggling, and viewed as a long shot to make it to a runoff. But one asset he still has is a robust campaign war chest, so this week, he released three more television commercials. Perhaps the most notable one is “Choices,” because it represents the first time he has deployed surrogates — not himself — to make his campaign pitch.

headline: All Around the World in Just Two Film Roles
abstract: For actors like Daniel Brühl, the new globalism in film has brought opportunities that were almost unimaginable in the middle of the last decade.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The actor Daniel Brühl, who is Spanish and German, will soon have a global moment in Toronto.

headline: Richard Eyre to Direct ‘Figaro’ at the Metropolitan Opera
abstract: Mr. Eyre will direct a new production of Mozart’s “Nozze di Figaro” that will open the Met’s 2014-15 season, scrapping plans to use a recent Glyndebourne production by Michael Grandage.
lead_paragraph: Opera companies have long been accustomed to changing casts around, sometimes at the last minute. Now the Metropolitan Opera, which has been placing a premium on theatrical values in recent years, is growing adept at switching directors, too.

headline: That ’40s Pas de Deux? You Can Still Catch It
abstract: The New York Public Library for the Performing Arts holds seldom-seem dance treasures in its archives.
lead_paragraph: On my first day in New York, I struck gold. It was 1979; I’d become a dance critic the year before and was here to learn; but at 23, I knew nothing about the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center. Fortunately, a man I met in line that morning for standing-room tickets to see the New York City Ballet kindly led me there, in particular to the Jerome Robbins Dance Division on the library’s third floor, and showed me how to find my way around its incomparable archive of dance on film.

headline: U.S. Victory at World Youth Open Championships
abstract: At the 3rd World Youth Open Championships in Atlanta, the final of the Junior Knockout Teams was between Australia and one of the United States teams.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — At the 3rd World Youth Open Championships here this month, the final of the Junior Knockout Teams was between Australia and one of the United States teams.

headline: The ‘Other’ Server Makers Are Gaining Ground
abstract: Two research reports had troubling news for well-known makers of computer servers: The lesser-known Chinese and Taiwanese manufacturers are shipping enormous volumes, probably to cloud-computing companies that don’t want high-end equipment.
lead_paragraph: This quarter’s market-share reports on computer server shipments and sales from Gartner and IDC are an unusually eloquent statement about the world’s transition to cloud computing and commodity machines that don’t command a big profit margin.

headline: Despite Pledge, France Lags in Hunt for Looted Art
keywords: ['Art', 'Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: A new promise by the French government to press for art seized by the Nazis in World War II to be returned to its owners has so far gone unfulfilled.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — When France’s culture minister, Aurélie Filippetti, handed over six looted 18th-century paintings to a Boston man in March, she declared a new “proactive approach” to tracking the original owners of recovered artworks that were stolen by the Nazis.

headline: A Men’s Fall Wardrobe That Women Can Use, Too
abstract: The way we see it, many of this fall’s wardrobe ideas for men and women are remarkably similar.
lead_paragraph: The way we see it, many of this fall’s wardrobe ideas for men and women are remarkably similar. There is the statement coat, which can serve as an instant fix-me-up (er … cover-up) for almost any outfit. There are upgraded sweats (always cool when worn under good outerwear), new laid-back backpacks and, as always, reimagined staples. This selection is geared to the menfolk, but, ladies, you might want to get your hands on some of it, too.

headline: Argentine Technology Firm Plans I.P.O. on N.Y.S.E.
abstract: Globant, an Argentine software and information technology services company, has filed to go public on the New York Stock Exchange, in a move to broaden its reach.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil – Globant, an Argentine software and information technology services company, has filed to go public on the New York Stock Exchange, in a move to broaden its reach.

headline: A New Home Décor Magazine, but Why?
abstract: Starting a magazine may seem folly these days, but Pamela Pierce has faith that her Milieu will succeed.
lead_paragraph: Next month, Milieu, a quarterly magazine about home décor, will make its first appearance on newsstands, showcasing international houses and gardens the old-fashioned way: on thick, glossy paper. Its founder and chief editor is Pamela Pierce, 63, an interior designer in Houston who is embarking on her first publishing venture. Speaking to a reporter recently, she sounded self-assured, but didn’t shy away from the word “crazy.”

headline: Knock Twice for Offbeat Design
abstract: In San Francisco, an architectural firm opens an unconventional shop.
lead_paragraph: Studio O+A, a San Francisco design firm, is expert in nontraditional offices, having created workplaces for Facebook and PayPal. So imagine what kind of office it would make without a client breathing down its neck.

headline: Irene Neuwirth’s Eight Great Days in Greece
abstract: The jewelry designer shares her impressions of the island of Patmos, where she savored the the beaches, the colors and the fried cheese.
lead_paragraph: Irene Neuwirth, the fine jewelry designer whose colorful statement pieces are red carpet regulars and top sellers at Barneys New York, calls herself a seasoned traveler. Yet after her long flight from Los Angeles to London to Athens, and then her eight-hour overnight boat ride from Athens to Patmos, she said, “I was proud of myself for making the trip. The cabin was disgusting, and people were drunk and sleeping on the stairs. I got there and was like, ‘Maybe I made a mistake coming here.’ And then you drag your bags down, and you’re waiting in the bottom of the boat where they let the cars out, and it opens out into paradise. It’s so gorgeous.”

headline: It’s Enough to Give You Hiccups
abstract: Rita Motta designs bubble-inspired carpets for Tai Ping.
lead_paragraph: “When you say something is bubbly, you’re talking about something that is light and free,” said Rita Motta, an Italian-born interior and product designer who has made spherical forms a signature. Ms. Motta — a founder, with her husband, Michael Perez, of the Miami design studio Mr. O — first put bubbles on cabinets and side tables. Now they have been hand-sheared into rugs for Tai Ping. The wool and silk rugs come in effervescent colors like magenta, vermilion (shown), citron and violet. Following their introduction last winter at Design Miami, Ms. Motta said the jewel tones stood out among the neutrals favored in showrooms.

headline: Nobody Knows the Crumbs They’ve Seen
abstract: A suite of colorful products for cleaning all of your devices.
lead_paragraph: Who thinks to regularly wipe down all the electronic gadgets that run our lives? Not me, for sure, at least not until several eye-pleasing cleaning tools appeared on my desk. AM, a Copenhagen company that started in the 1970s with cleaners for vinyl records and record players, has just released a suite that includes brightly colored microfiber-wrapped atomizers for both spraying and wiping phones and computers (about $15 to $35, depending on size); miniature microfiber sponges that can squirm between the Z and X keys on a crumb-filled keyboard (about $15 for five); and wet wipes, which the company says are free of harsh chemicals and can safely clean any screen (about $10 for 18).

headline: Using a Garden to Great Advantage
abstract: Advice on adding plants or flowers to increase a home’s overall appeal.
lead_paragraph: Q. Are there any particular kinds of plants or flowers I should add to my garden before putting my house up for sale?

lead_paragraph: Agate bookends, originally $199, are $139 at Nest Interiors to Wednesday; 172 Ninth Avenue (West 21st Street), (212) 337-3441, nestinteriorsny.com.

headline: Vases That Make a Statement
abstract: Whether or not you put flowers in them.
lead_paragraph: What’s the point of a vase? Many people would say that vases are mainly for holding flowers.

headline: Linda Ronstadt on Her Memoir and Parkinson’s
abstract: “Simple Dreams” is less an autobiography than an artist’s bildungsroman. In it, Ms, Ronstadt recalls her musical journey phase by phase, beginning with her childhood in the Sonora desert.
lead_paragraph: “Simple Dreams” is less an autobiography than an artist’s bildungsroman. In it, Ms, Ronstadt recalls her musical journey phase by phase, beginning with her childhood in the Sonora desert.

headline: The Scandinavian Way
abstract: A Norwegian trio designs their first product: a chair called Oslo.
lead_paragraph: Jerry Helling, president of Bernhardt Design, makes a habit of boosting the careers of young designers. His latest protégés are Christoffer Angell, Oyvind Wyller and Simen Aarseth, founders of AWAA, a Norwegian studio, whom he met at a cocktail party and asked to create a side chair with arms. They returned with Oslo, a chair that will be introduced at the London Design Festival on Sept. 18. The trio, who had never designed a commercial product, focused first on the chair’s skeletal structure, creating a sturdy frame of solid walnut. They added a sling seat and a back that is attached to the frame with buttons. The look reminds Mr. Helling of a messenger bag; others see it as a faithful homage to Scandinavian modern.

headline: The Fire-Escape Nursery
abstract: A gardener in a Queens apartment wards off the landlord and the squirrels.
lead_paragraph: My friend Tonice Sgrignoli is growing two Early Moonbeam watermelons in a 12-inch clay pot on her fire escape in Long Island City, Queens. This is not easy, considering how much water and nutrients melons require. It’s also illegal.

headline: The Plant Whisperer
abstract: In Los Angeles, one woman lives in a miniature botanical garden of her own creation, with fruit trees and a turtle named Ting.
lead_paragraph: In Los Angeles, one woman lives in a miniature botanical garden of her own creation, with fruit trees and a turtle named Ting.

headline: A Haven for Making Music With Plants
abstract: An artist transforms a garage and sunbaked backyard into a bohemian oasis.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Mileece Petre, a 35-year-old English artist and musician known professionally as Mileece, is a plant whisperer of sorts. In a digital-age spin on “The Secret Life of Plants,” the 1973 book that suggested plants are sentient, she attaches electrodes to leaves. The electromagnetic current is fed into software she wrote that turns the data into musical notes, so a garden becomes an orchestra (she especially likes philodendrons; their hearty leaves offer better support for the electrodes).

lead_paragraph: Lucinda and David Schiff will tell you that the recent redo of the midcentury barn in Sagaponack, N.Y., that is their home each August was the product of a summer romance.

keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Iraq War (2003-11)']
abstract: The issue is suffused with memories of the war in Iraq and the later discovery that Saddam Hussein did not possess weapons of mass destruction.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As they move toward military action in Syria, possibly within days and presumably without the backing of a United Nations Security Council resolution, the United States, Britain and France find themselves enmeshed in a debate over practical and moral questions regarding the necessity of a solid legal rationale for armed intervention.

headline: Free to Be... Isaac Mizrahi
abstract: With Xcel in charge of his brand, Isaac Mizrahi is even busier: writing a TV pilot, giving cabaret shows and marrying.
lead_paragraph: In less than a week, New York Fashion Week will officially roll into town, turning a wide swath of the city into a carnival of journalists, buyers, bloggers, label-obsessed shoppers and — most notably — anxious designers wondering if their latest collections will be greeted with praise (“he’s a genius”), disdain (“well, that was interesting”) or just a shrug of the shoulders (“um, where are we doing lunch?”).

headline: Partying After MTV’s Video Music Awards
abstract: The fun was just starting when the stars gathered at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn. Afterward, almost everyone fled back to Manhattan to continue the party.
lead_paragraph: Brooklyn may have been the putative star of Sunday night, when the MTV Video Music Awards came to the Barclays Center for the first time in the event’s 30-year history, but the minute the show ended, almost everyone fled back to Manhattan to party.

headline: ‘The Most Dangerous Negro’
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: Martin Luther King was dangerous not to the country, but to the status quo.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s “I Have a Dream” so disturbed the American power structure that the F.B.I. started spying on him in what The Washington Post called “one of its biggest surveillance operations in history.” The speech even moved the head of the agency’s domestic intelligence division to label King “the most dangerous Negro of the future in this nation from the standpoint of Communism, the Negro and national security.”

headline: After a Recession in Portugal, the Tiny Green Fruits of Success
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Olive Oil', 'Small Business', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Gross Domestic Product']
abstract: Recent data suggest that the country is indeed hitting its export stride, but the balance sheets of the nation’s banks could weigh on the fragile economic comeback.
lead_paragraph: MOURA, Portugal — Portugal is finding that increasing exports is the way to pull its economy out of a recession.

headline: East by Far East: Vladivostok Rocks
abstract: More than 40 acts played free shows over four days last week at V-Rox in Vladivostok, Russia, in the first rock festival of its kind in the country.
lead_paragraph: VLADIVOSTOK, Russia — “Ilya! Ilya!” came the chant from the crowd of thousands in the central square here on a recent night. Clad in a retro-futuristic silver suit, Ilya Lagutenko, this city’s hometown star and the frontman of one of the country’s most popular bands, Mumiy Troll, flipped his hair and sang, in English and Russian, about love, sailors and other matters of local pride.

headline: Summer’s Last Call: Saturday Night in Montauk
abstract: With Labor Day fast approaching, young revelers in the Hamptons pursue a final chance at “Montauk love.”
lead_paragraph: There was a small, sharp bite in the air on the East End of Long Island last Saturday night, the second to last of the season. It may not have been cold enough to stay inside one’s summer share with a fire and some Netflix, but the hint of autumn provided an easy excuse to get a little closer to a stranger (or two) for some body heat.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: A Separation at Google and Twitter Conversations
abstract: Wednesday’s highlights from around the Web include developments in the love life of the Google co-founder Sergey Brin and an update from Twitter to help streamline conversations on its service.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

abstract: Bethanie Mattek-Sands went purple last week for the United States Open; while Venus Williams won her first round Monday in fuchsia and pink braids.
lead_paragraph: She is known for her knee socks, war paint, tattoos and, of course, her tennis ball fringe jacket from Wimbledon 2011.

headline: Shannon Plumb, a Brooklyn Life on the Big Screen
abstract: A film about a Brooklyn woman is made by someone who knows the part.
lead_paragraph: At six o’clock on a summer evening, Shannon Plumb and her young son Cody slowly opened the door of their Brooklyn home. There was a touch of déjà vu for the first-time visitor: the open-plan first floor of the Victorian town house was immediately recognizable as the setting for “Towheads,” an independent movie written, directed and starring Ms. Plumb.

headline: Streaming for a Good Beat That’s Just to Your Taste
abstract: Online music services let users create their own “radio stations” that play the kind of songs they like, and will suggest similar music.
lead_paragraph: Remember the radio? It was the best way to hear new music when I was a boy. My friends and I would listen to the songs that made the weekly charts and we’d talk about the great tracks and the terrible tracks at school the next day.

headline: Double-Decker Buses, for Many in City, Are the Height of Irritation
abstract: The vehicles’ proliferation in New York has been met less with nostalgia than with anger, because of traffic jams and insistent sales pitches.
lead_paragraph: More than a century ago, there were double-decker trolleys, rising like wedding cakes over Broadway, with horses in the neighboring lane. Many years later, diners boarded a two-tiered bus operated by the restaurateur Vincent Sardi Jr., who hoped to connect patrons at Sardi’s East, on 54th Street, to the theater district.

headline: A Sheep Is Saved, and Celtic Wins
abstract: Glasgow Celtic overcame a 2-0 deficit from the first leg to advance to the Champions League group stage after beating Shakhter Karagandy on Wednesday.

headline: Deficit Talks Resuming, but Few Sound Hopeful

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As tensions mount and expectations slip lower for any bipartisan consensus on a long-term deficit-reduction plan, a group of Republican senators will resume talks on Thursday with senior presidential advisers at the White House after a lapse that has lasted weeks.

headline: Where an Iraqi Artist Can Paint, and Exhale
abstract: Bassim al-Shaker, 28, who was beaten and abused because of his love of art, has found refuge in Phoenix, which has one of the largest Iraqi communities in the United States.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — First, the men cursed him, loyalists of Iraq’s Mahdi Army militia furious at the slender barber who dared to sketch pictures of nude women. Then, they spat on him, blindfolded him and punched him as they took him through a busy neighborhood market in his native Baghdad, where someone grabbed a pair of scissors and cut his long hair.

headline: Twitter Buys a Referee in the Fight Over Online TV Chatter
abstract: The social network has bought Trendrr, a research firm that recently published a study on the importance of Facebook, Twitter’s arch-rival, as an online platform for people to discuss television shows while they are airing.
lead_paragraph: The hottest fight in social media right now is between Twitter and Facebook over which platform is a better host for online conversation — and advertising — around live television shows. Both companies are vying to persuade consumer brands to run ads targeted at users who are chatting online about popular TV shows while they are airing.

headline: A View of What’s Missing From the Classroom

lead_paragraph: THE Advertising Council and the United States Army, hoping to lower absenteeism in schools across the country, are introducing a public service campaign this week aimed at helping parents keep track of their children’s absences.

headline: Concussion Case Nears Key Phase for N.F.L.
abstract: In a closely watched case, a judge is expected to decide soon whether to dismiss a lawsuit brought by retired players alleging that the N.F.L. intentionally misled them about the dangers of head injuries.
lead_paragraph: Before the N.F.L. regular season begins next Thursday, the league will get a clearer picture of what may be its biggest worry: the lawsuit brought by more than 4,500 retired players alleging that the N.F.L. intentionally misled them about the dangers of head injuries.

She will serve one year of probation, do 100 hours of community service and write an apology to Circuit Judge Kenneth Lester Jr. The deal allowed Ms. Zimmerman, a nursing student, to plead guilty to a less serious perjury charge rather than the original felony charge. In fact, they had received more than $130,000 in donations from a Web site Mr. Zimmerman set up for his defense against a murder charge in the death of Trayvon Martin. headline: What’s on Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 4:30 P.M. (HBO) GLICKMAN (2013) In 1936, the Bronx-born Marty Glickman, above, a national sprinting champion, earned a spot on the United States Olympic track team as part of the 400-meter relay. But in Berlin, with Hitler in the stands, Mr. Glickman and Sam Stoller — the only Jews on the relay team — were replaced the day before the event by Jesse Owens and Ralph Metcalfe, ostensibly because “secret” German runners were expected to challenge for the gold. (Mr. Glickman, who died in 2001, maintained that anti-Semitism was at work.) The Americans won the race; the Germans finished a distant fourth. After returning to the United States, Mr. Glickman eventually found his niche in basketball and football broadcasting. Despite being rejected for a “more Midwestern” announcer when the N.B.A. finally signed a network contract, he became the voice of the Giants during the 1950s and ’60s and the Jets in 1972. This documentary from James L. Freedman, who produced Mr. Glickman’s late-night radio show as a high school senior, brings to light some of his pioneering techniques, phrases and programming innovations. Marv Albert, Bob Costas, Bill Bradley, Frank Gifford and Larry King weigh in.

Even at  31, five years after “flying solo” from China’s state sports system, Li still possesses the punishing work ethic inculcated by her Chinese coaches. Two years ago, she fired a foreign coach because, she said with a laugh, “he was way too nice.” Rodriguez is gentle on the outside, too. But the wiry Rodriguez, an Argentine, who coached the former world No. 1 Justine Henin for 15 years, is renowned for his insistence on peak physical and psychological fitness. With “Kaluosi,” as she calls him (a transliteration of “Carlos”), Li knew she was signing up for pain. She just didn’t know how much.

lead_paragraph: Clearly, Julie lied. She did not spend the weekend on a college-inspection visit to Wesleyan.

headline: Saving Grace
abstract: In J. M. Coetzee’s starkly narrated new novel, a man takes a child under his protection in an unnamed country.
lead_paragraph: Like J. M. Coetzee’s richly symbolic early novels “Waiting for the Barbarians” and “Life and Times of Michael K,” his starkly narrated new novel plunges us at once into a mysterious and dreamlike terrain. But where those books evoke Coetzee’s native South Africa and the madness of apartheid, immersing the reader in situations of nearly unbearable intensity, “The Childhood of Jesus” is set in a possibly posthumous limbo in which a haze of forgetfulness has enervated most of the characters, as in a paralyzing smog. We arrive by boat in a city called Novilla, in an unnamed but possibly southern European country, in the company of a man named Simón, who has taken under his protection a child named David — “Not my grandson, not my son, but I am responsible for him.” It would appear that the travelers are refugees: they have come from a “camp,” a place called Belstar, where they were given Spanish lessons and two passbooks. The child has been separated from his parents. Simón seems to have no family at all. Having, like all his fellow travelers, been shorn of his memory on the voyage to Novilla, Simón arrives in unknown territory and must establish himself; he must find shelter and he must find work to support himself and the boy. If Simón has had a profession or a trade in his former life, he can’t recall it; he is grateful to find work as a stevedore, for which he is barely qualified. It will be Simón’s obsession to locate David’s mother, whose name he doesn’t know and of whom he knows nothing, not even whether she has arrived in this strange, nameless country.

headline: Taste of Persia NYC
abstract: Inside the takeout counter tucked into a corner of a pizzeria in the Flatiron district.
lead_paragraph: Inside the takeout counter tucked into a corner of a pizzeria in the Flatiron district.

headline: Finding Happiness in Paradise
abstract: A takeout counter tucked into a pizzeria’s front window offers Persian stews that change daily.
lead_paragraph: The scent of rose water is imperceptible at Pizza Paradise, obscured by pepperoni’s more flagrant bouquet. Nevertheless, rose water is here, in a corner of this otherwise utilitarian pizzeria on 18th Street, alongside fenugreek, pomegranate molasses and black limes, sour and smoky from having been slaked with boiling water and left in the sun.

headline: Detroit Electric Pushes the Pause Button
abstract: Detroit Electric, which was planning to produce electric cars in Michigan, said on Thursday that it would first make cars in the Netherlands.
lead_paragraph: The reborn Detroit Electric definitely has one thing in common with the original company, which went out of business in 1939 — it ran into problems trying to sell battery-powered vehicles. Detroit Electric is the latest in a long series of companies to have had difficulty realizing big dreams in the electric marketplace.

headline: U.S. Open Food Review: The Sandwich Revolution
abstract: Today’s U.S. Open food review: the pulled chicken torta at Fresca Mexicana in the main food court.
lead_paragraph: Because eating at the United States Open is a high-stakes game, we will feature a daily review of items available at the food courts at the National Tennis Center.

headline: The Gloire To Come
abstract: The forgotten French advantage.
lead_paragraph: A very belated reaction to Steven Erlanger’s piece on French decline, on fears that the proud nation is slipping into second-tier status. One point one should always note here is Roger Cohen’s: the French have been morose for decades now, yet the country remains a pretty good place to live. Maybe some discounting is called for?

headline: Articles of Faith
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: A number of contemporary Jewish writers are engaging with religious belief in their works.
lead_paragraph: In January, The New Yorker’s Shouts & Murmurs blog serialized a lighthearted novella called “Sell Out,” by Simon Rich, about a religious Jewish immigrant in 1912 Brooklyn who falls into a vat of brine at a pickle factory. Emerging intact a century later, he meets his hipster great-great-grandson and ultimately draws him back to some version of faith.

headline: Bringing the Wine to Portland, Ore.
abstract: Vintners are moving their operations to the city, complete with tasting rooms.
lead_paragraph: Portland, Ore., has a new thing to call local, and it’s wine. Vintners are moving their operations from wine country in the Willamette Valley to the city, pairing on-site facilities with tasting rooms that offer a window into winemaking. At least 10 urban wineries have opened within city limits in recent years, making up what might be called one of the country’s first urban wine trails.

headline: Tour Iran? Operators Hope So
abstract: Iran’s new president is promoting international tourism as part of his plan to fix the country’s economy, but United States officials continue to warn against travel there.
lead_paragraph: At the top of the agenda of Iran’s new president, Hassan Rouhani, is fixing the country’s crumbling economy, and promoting international tourism is part of his solution.

headline: Cornelia Street Café Presents ‘Fruits of Labor’
abstract: On Friday night, aesthetes in Greenwich Village will ponder a Labor Day theme and the Rubin Museum of Art will screen “Black Narcissus.”
lead_paragraph: If most of the hallowed haunts that made Greenwich Village synonymous with bohemia are gone or transformed beyond recognition, one spot tucked within the neighborhood’s winding lanes still cultivates the freewheeling exchange of art and ideas — not to mention serving a darned good sangria.

headline: At Google, a Love Triangle and a Departing Executive
abstract: Silicon Valley is abuzz over the separation of Google’s co-founder, Sergey Brin, and his wife, a tech entrepreneur. And with the departure of a key Android executive, the personal drama has spilled over into Google business.
lead_paragraph: When summer turns to fall, the Silicon Valley gossip scene is usually tantalized by the next iPhone. But this year, it is Google’s secrets, not Apple’s, that have people abuzz.

headline: Conversations With Andy Murray: Spending Free Time
abstract: After his first-round victory Wednesday night, Andy Murray spoke with Straight Sets about how he spends his time away from the court.
lead_paragraph: Andy Murray (and his first-round opponent, Michael Llodra) had to wait longer than any other singles players to begin their campaigns at the 2013 United States Open. They did not begin their first-round match until 9:55 p.m. Wednesday. After his relatively straightforward 6-2, 6-4, 6-3 win over Llodra, Murray spoke with Straight Sets about how he spends his time away from the court.

headline: Explaining the N.F.L. Settlement
abstract: Questions, and answers, about the proposed $765 million settlement between the N.F.L. and the more than 4,500 retired players who sued the league.
lead_paragraph: The size and scope of the proposed $765 million settlement between the N.F.L. and the more than 4,500 retired players who sued the league, claiming it had hid information about the dangers of head trauma, are likely to be debated. But, as in other such deals, each side had ample reason to compromise.

headline: U.S. Sets Roster for Two September World Cup Qualifiers
abstract: Coach Jurgen Klinsmann on Thursday announced his 23-man roster for coming matches at Costa Rica and against Mexico.
lead_paragraph: Only a disaster of cataclysmic proportions can keep the United States from advancing to next summer’s World Cup in Brazil. Still, there are four regional qualifying matches to be played between now and the end of October.

headline: Guitarist and His Friends Make for a Diverse Week
abstract: Fred Frith’s week at the Stone provides a concise overview of his broad range, including solo improvisation, chamber-music configurations, a duo set with John Zorn, and a rock trio.
lead_paragraph: When John Zorn first opened the Stone, his humble, no-frills East Village performance space, in 2005, the booking policy indicated his credo: artists first. Mr. Zorn, a celebrated composer, improviser and bandleader, is among New York’s foremost community builders, having stitched together an impressive range of friends and peers into an estimable aesthetic bloc.

headline: The Art of Propaganda, Repurposed
abstract: The exhibition “Leonid Sokov: Ironic Objects,” which explores how the artist responded to politics and consumer culture, is under way at the Zimmerli Art Museum at Rutgers.
lead_paragraph: There is an entire body of scholarly writing around the word “irony” as it relates to literature. There is not as much for art objects. But irony seems to flourish in periods when political repression is high and artists resort to registering their protest through humor or subversive imitation. Such is the case in “Leonid Sokov: Ironic Objects” at the Zimmerli Art Museum in New Brunswick.

headline: Start-Up Judging: Data, Interviews and Hunches
abstract: An inside look at how one technology reporter tries to figure out which companies are worth covering — and which ones can be ignored.
lead_paragraph: Divining the potential of a start-up is a technology reporter’s constant task.  We spend a lot of our time trying to figure out which companies, both large and small, are newsworthy and why.

headline: Overcoming the Orthodoxy of Abstraction
abstract: A selection of Alex Katz’s work from the Whitney Museum of American Art is at the Nassau County Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: The standard narrative in 20th-century art history is that painters had to struggle against tradition and conservative institutions to forge a new language of abstraction. But then abstraction itself became an orthodoxy, and those who wanted to paint nature or the human figure found themselves swimming against the tide of earlier revolutions. The career of Alex Katz, who successfully made this transition, is one example. A selection of about 45 of his works from the collection of the Whitney Museum of American Art is on view at the Nassau County Museum of Art in Roslyn Harbor.

headline: His Workout: Beating People Up
abstract: Jack Reacher returns in Lee Child’s “Never Go Back” for a cross-country pursuit full of surprises and a possible love child.
lead_paragraph: Lee Child’s bodacious action hero, Jack Reacher, has already tramped through 17 novels and three e-book singles. But his latest, “Never Go Back,” may be the best desert island reading in the series. It’s exceptionally well plotted. And full of wild surprises. And wise about Reacher’s peculiar nature. And positively Bunyanesque in its admiring contributions to Reacher lore.

headline: Not Crying for Argentina but Fearful of a Ruling
keywords: ['Government Bonds', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Hedge Funds', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The U. S. and the International Monetary Fund are concerned about a decision that would force Argentina to pay all its creditors equally and hold processing banks responsible if the country did not.
lead_paragraph: In the world of sovereign debt defaults, it is hard to imagine a less sympathetic debtor than Argentina. It has defaulted again and again for nearly two centuries, with few apologies. After the country’s most recent default, in 2001, it refused to negotiate for four years and then offered creditors a deal worth about 30 cents on the dollar — and vowed that those who refused would receive nothing.

headline: Risks Aside, ARMs Gain Ground
abstract: For those in the habit of keeping a loan for a short time period, adjustable-rate mortgages offer substantial savings.
lead_paragraph: With mortgage rates inching up and homeowners often refinancing before the end of their loan terms, adjustable-rate mortgages are becoming more enticing to more borrowers.

headline: The ABC’s of Your DNA

abstract: Four French TV dramas serve up the most common themes — crime, war, sex and the occult — in fresh and unexpected ways.
lead_paragraph: It may be a small world, but it’s remarkable how many barriers remain to easy viewing.

lead_paragraph: WHEN I suggested to my children that we visit the National Museum of Mathematics in Manhattan a few weeks ago, they collectively grimaced.

headline: A Cosmos of Matter, Enshrined in Her Art
abstract: Michelle Stuart brings art into the landscape, and vice versa, as seen in a survey of her work at the Parrish Art Museum.
lead_paragraph: “HOW better to know a place than to know the earth of a place?” Michelle Stuart asked recently, as she held court in the expansive, light-filled SoHo loft that has been her home base since 1971. Furnished with textiles, antiques and artworks, it is also brimming with collections of seeds, bones, photographs, neatly labeled bottles of soil and other souvenirs of her travels.

headline: Putting Labor Back in Labor Day
abstract: Fast food corporations benefit from the status quo. Their workers don’t. That’s why they’re going on strike.
lead_paragraph: The fast food strikes that began last November in New York City with walkouts by 200 workers expanded and spread to other cities in the spring and summer. On Thursday, thousands of workers in 60 cities went on a one-day strike. The demands were the same, only amplified — higher pay, to $15 an hour, and the right to organize without retaliation.

headline: Modern Influences Collide in Tibetan Art
abstract: “Anonymous: Contemporary Tibetan Art” at the Dorsky Gallery in New Paltz, N.Y., expands upon the 2010 exhibition at the Rubin Museum in New York, and features many of the same artists.
lead_paragraph: There was no McDonald’s in Lhasa when the Rubin Museum in New York mounted an exhibition of contemporary Tibetan art in 2010. In a catalog essay accompanying that show, however, H.G. Masters wrote that it wouldn’t be so shocking to see a fast-food restaurant in that cultural center of Tibetan Buddhism. After all, the “collision of traditional architecture, culture and commerce with the aesthetics, iconography and branding of an arch-modern corporation is one of the defining experiences of 21st-century life.”

headline: Meet the Boys: A Mutual Lovefest
abstract: Morgan Spurlock’s concert film about the British-Irish boy band One Direction features shirtless torsos and backstage performances and a taste of each performer’s persona.
lead_paragraph: The popularity of the British-Irish boy band One Direction has been fueled largely by extraordinarily active Twitter fans, mostly tween and teenage girls. But seeing “One Direction: This Is Us” is a chance to experience that high-pitched hysteria viscerally as the girls in the theater call out for their favorite band members. Affections seem equally divided, except for one member, Harry Styles, the obvious heartthrob, who resembles a less gnomish Mick Jagger.

headline: And Now, a ‘Spider-Man’ Tell-All
abstract: A new memoir, to be published in November, details backstage maneuvering and insults in the development of this $75 million musical.
lead_paragraph: THE most expensive, debated and derided musical ever on Broadway — the $75 million “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” — now has a dishy insider memoir. It chronicles the ugly slide of the once close creators, the director Julie Taymor and the composers Bono and the Edge, of U2, into a morass of betrayals, lawsuits, and petty slaps, like a producer’s yanking Ms. Taymor’s tickets for the show’s opening night.

headline: Twins, Except Architecturally
abstract: Two behemoths went up and were felled at the same time. Today, only one, the Singer Building, is lamented.
lead_paragraph: The demolition of the 47-story Singer Building at Broadway and Liberty Street is still viewed as one of the great tragedies of New York architecture. Its bulbous Beaux-Arts top was one of the landmarks of the New York skyline from the moment it opened in 1908 until it fell for 1 Liberty Plaza in 1967.

headline: Heart and Soul in Every Stroke
abstract: “Brush Writing in the Arts of Japan,” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is an ode to the art of handwriting once used for even the briefest of notes.
lead_paragraph: “Brush Writing in the Arts of Japan,” at the Metropolitan Museum, is the perfect place to mourn the lost art of handwriting. Here, among the medieval Zen monks, the 11th-century literati and the courtesans of the Edo-era “floating world,” it’s impossible to separate language from gesture and composition from performance.

headline: Glass Ceilings Can Be Cutting
abstract: Rachel McAdams and Noomi Rapace negotiate a dangerous office environment in Brian De Palma’s “Passion.”
lead_paragraph: “There’s no back-stabbing here. It’s just business.” That line is uttered twice in Brian De Palma’s “Passion,” once disingenuously, once sarcastically, even though it is, literally speaking, true. A slashed throat is not the same as a stabbed back. And the kinky, convoluted plot is all about business if you expand the definition to include romantic obsession, sexual jealousy and sadomasochistic mind games.

headline: A Walk Along the Boundaries of Faith and Flesh
abstract: The White Box gallery in Lower Manhattan displays a series of late-in-life paintings by Hyman Bloom, a popular midcentury artist, that feature Jewish leaders with Torahs.
lead_paragraph: The contemporary art world is a forgetful place. It can stay aware of only a limited number of artists, so as exciting names emerge, formerly celebrated phenomena fall down the memory hole. They don’t necessarily disappear, though. Many continue to make interesting art and enjoy lives of quiet fulfillment. Hyman Bloom (1913-2009) was one of those, and an exhibition of paintings of rabbis that he made late in life, at White Box gallery in Lower Manhattan, offers surprisingly much to ponder.

headline: Singing in the Rain in Tribute to Richard Tucker
abstract: A panel discussion and an outdoor concert were among events celebrating the centennial of the tenor Richard Tucker.
lead_paragraph: During a symposium in Juilliard’s Peter Jay Sharp Theater on Wednesday afternoon, audience members listened intently to a 1947 recording of the tenor Richard Tucker singing the Jewish prayer “Yiru Eineinu,” his voice hauntingly expressive and soulful as he sang the melismatic music.

headline: Want to See the Wife Again? Just Follow Directions
abstract: In “Getaway,” a former professional racecar driver’s wife is kidnapped, and he is warned that he will never see her again unless he steals a vehicle and follows instructions.
lead_paragraph: One can only guess why Ethan Hawke felt compelled to make a high dive from the sublimity of “Before Midnight” into the twisted rubble of “Getaway.” What other reason could there be for a star to attach his name to a mindless demolition derby but the payday? Furthermore, Mr. Hawke is only the nominal star of a movie whose driving force is the ultimate muscle car — an armored Ford Shelby GT500 Super Snake — that runs amok in the streets of Sofia, Bulgaria.

headline: Match of Teenagers Provides Glimpse of Future
abstract: The second-round match between the 19-year-old Laura Robson and Caroline Garcia was an opportunity to check on the progress of two promising young players.
lead_paragraph: Teenagers like Tracy Austin and Martina Hingis used to turn in dominant seasons on the women’s tennis tour. Today major success tends to arrive later. The talented 19-year-olds Laura Robson and Caroline Garcia are not yet seriously challenging for Grand Slam titles or the top ranking. But their second-round United States Open match Wednesday night was an opportunity to check on the progress of two promising young players.

headline: Sisters, Cracking Wise or Sweetly Harmonizing
abstract: Liz and Ann Hampton Callaway return with their sister show, “Sibling Revelry,” at 54 Below.
lead_paragraph: Was it 5 or 10 years ago that Liz and Ann Hampton Callaway first performed “Sibling Revelry,” spoofing sisterly show business competition? Actually, it was 18 years ago. These sisters, from Chicago, introduced this musical-comedy comfort food at Rainbow and Stars in 1995. Now, years after that club closed, the show is back (at 54 Below), essentially unchanged with the same director (Dan Foster) and arranger-pianist (Alex Rybeck).

headline: Rwanda Warns Congo After Shells Hit Its Territory

headline: Just Holding on Through the Curves
abstract: As I became involved with one young woman, I learned how profoundly the child welfare system could fail its teenagers.
lead_paragraph: My daughter just turned 30. How is this possible when it seemed like only a week before she was a scrappy, sassy teenager? Like mothers everywhere, I don’t think I’m old enough to have delivered a baby girl who could hit such a milestone.

headline: Photo Op
abstract: Etiquette questions regarding a photo opportunist, a mother who wants her child home for the holiday, when to say “I’m sorry” and those Labor Day blues.
lead_paragraph: I went to a dinner party while my wife and daughters were on an exotic vacation. A woman asked about them, so I gave a quick update and opened the photo file on my iPhone and showed her a picture of them riding camels. I expected her to pass the phone around the table. Instead, she began thumbing through all of the other photos on my phone — some of which were extremely revealing. Panicking, I retrieved the phone by saying, “You don’t want to see all of those.” The woman made a snarky comment about my obviously having something to hide. Was I wrong to give her the phone? Don, Cincinnati

headline: Democrats See Value in Texas in Candidacy for Governor
abstract: State Senator Wendy Davis of Texas, who rocketed to fame with her 11-hour filibuster to block an anti-abortion bill, is considering a campaign for governor even though she is thought to be a long shot.
lead_paragraph: FORT WORTH — Early this month, Wendy Davis, the unknown Texas state senator who rocketed to fame this summer with her 11-hour filibuster to block an anti-abortion bill, met with strategists of the Democratic Governors Association at their K Street offices in Washington. They were urging her to run for governor next year, even though Texas is not among their realistic targets for flipping a Republican-held executive mansion.

headline: California: Veterans Center Lease Ruled Illegal
abstract: A judge ruled Thursday that the Department of Veterans Affairs violated federal law in leasing for commercial use parts of its campus in West Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Judge S. James Otero of Federal District Court ruled Thursday that the Department of Veterans Affairs violated federal law in leasing for commercial use parts of its campus in West Los Angeles. The ruling was in response to a class-action lawsuit on behalf of four homeless veterans, who objected to the lease when homelessness among veterans was high. Judge Otero ruled that Congress permitted such lease agreements only if the property was going to be used to provide health or other services for veterans. The campus has been leased for, among other things, a laundry for a luxury hotel.

headline: Massachusetts: Ex-Official Refunds Contributions
abstract: Former Lt. Gov. Timothy P. Murray on Thursday agreed to refund $50,000 and pay a $30,000 fine to settle accusations that he accepted illegal campaign contributions.
lead_paragraph: Former Lt. Gov. Timothy P. Murray on Thursday agreed to refund $50,000 and pay a $30,000 fine to settle accusations that he accepted illegal campaign contributions. Attorney General Martha Coakley said Mr. Murray received $50,000 in contributions illegally solicited by two public employees. One of them, Michael McLaughlin, an ex-housing official serving a three-year sentence for lying about his income to federal authorities, was indicted Thursday on charges of unlawfully soliciting campaign contributions from state employees.

headline: Massachusetts: Bomb Suspect’s Classmate Charged
abstract: Robel Phillipos, a classmate of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the Boston Marathon bombing suspect, was indicted on two counts of making false statements during the investigation.
lead_paragraph: A classmate of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the Boston Marathon bombing suspect, was indicted Thursday on two counts of making false statements during the investigation. The man, Robel Phillipos, 19, is accused of concealing from investigators the fact that he accompanied two of Mr. Tsarnaev’s other friends, Dias Kadyrbayev and Azamat Tazhayakov, to Mr. Tsarnaev’s dormitory at the University of Massachusetts Dartmouth days after the bombing. Investigators say that the men removed items including a laptop and a backpack, and that Mr. Kadyrbayev disposed of the backpack. Mr. Phillipos could face up to eight years in prison on each count and a $250,000 fine. Mr. Kadyrbayev and Mr. Tazhayakov have been charged with obstruction of justice.

headline: 2 Guantánamo Detainees Transferred to Algeria

lead_paragraph: The Pentagon announced on Thursday that it had transferred two Algerian detainees from the military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, to their native country. The two men, Nabil Said Hadjarab and Mutia Sadiq Ahmad Sayyab, who have spent more than a decade incarcerated without charges, were the first detainees to leave the prison since President Obama renewed his pledge to close it in May.

Curated by David Chang and his Lucky Peach team, this year’s two-day sold-out symposium was dedicated to guts — meaning both innards and courage. Chang introduced the theme literally, however, by bringing out the butcher Dario Cecchini, who proceeded to carve a pig on the stage. Between events, Michael, the chef and owner of Ink in Los Angeles, and Bryan, the executive chef of Volt restaurant in Maryland, caught up with fellow chefs and friends. abstract: The recently opened eatery Vinatería is a case study in sustainable interior design that’s simply chic, rather than conspicuously eco-conscious.
lead_paragraph: We can all agree on the value of reuse, repurposing, recycling, upcycling. But too often in interior design projects, these processes are treated as ends rather than means, with results that are usually more earnest than elegant. At Vinatería, a Harlem restaurant that opened in April, almost every material has had a previous life (or lives), but that’s not what you notice about the room. Instead, you see a subtle layering of color and form and sophisticated details. Yes, the design is environmentally friendly. But above all, Vinatería is chic.

headline: Pynchon’s Gravitational Pull
abstract: Jonathan Franzen once wrote about Thomas Pynchon in a letter: “The better he is the more I want to hate him but the less I can.”
lead_paragraph: In an essay in the September issue of Harper’s, Jonathan Franzen quotes — at what he concedes is “embarrassing length” — from letters he sent to his fiancée when he was 22. “I recognize Pynchon as my major precursor,” the young, besotted Franzen wrote. “The better he is the more I want to hate him but the less I can.” In an interview with The Paris Review in 2010, Franzen described discovering “Gravity’s Rainbow”: “It was like getting the flu to read that book. It was like I was fighting off some very aggressive infection.” He wrote to his then-fiancée: “I’ll get over Pynchon somehow. Maybe through criticism, some discontinuity, some dialectic, that will enable me to forget him.” His future wife proved a stronger motivation than any dialectic. About his “Pynchonian” love letters, Franzen told The Paris Review, “I think it’s significant that she hated those letters and made her hatred of them known, and that I steered away from that voice.”

headline: Stay of Execution
abstract: A landmark decision reignited the death penalty debate.
lead_paragraph: Furman v. Georgia is among the oddest Supreme Court cases in American history. Decided in 1972, it struck down every death penalty statute in the nation as then practiced without outlawing the death penalty itself. The ruling, based on the constitutional protection against “cruel and unusual punishment,” stunned even the closest court watchers. The death penalty seemed impregnable. It was part of the bedrock of America’s legal system, steeped in the intent of the founders, the will of most state legislatures and the forceful — if occasional — rulings of the courts.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: INSIDE SCIENTOLOGY: The Story of America’s Most Secretive Religion,  by Janet Reitman. (Mariner/Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $15.95.) This is a meticulous history of the Church of Scientology, from its birth as a 1950s self-help system in the science fiction imagination of L. Ron Hubbard (1911-86) to its current status as a worldwide movement. Reitman, who spent five years piercing the walls Scientologists put up against outsiders, has rendered what our reviewer, Garry Wills, called “the most complete picture of Scientology so far.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE SMARTEST KIDS IN THE WORLD: And How They Got That Way,  by Amanda Ripley. (Simon & Schuster, $28.) A look at countries that are outeducating us (Finland, South Korea, Poland) through the eyes of American high school students abroad.

headline: Arbor Day
abstract: Readers respond to a recent essay about Joyce Kilmer’s “Trees.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Southern Discomfort
abstract: Wilton Barnhardt’s humorous novel concerns a family and a region coming apart.
lead_paragraph: “Tell about the South,” his Harvard classmates beseech Quentin Compson in “Absalom, Absalom!” You’ll notice he doesn’t have to be asked twice. Sensitive Southerners — and Southern writers most of all — seem to love nothing better than explaining themselves and their region to outsiders (or to themselves, if no outsider is handy). There are exceptions, though, and Wilton Barnhardt would stand at the head of any list: though born and reared in the South, he has, over the last two decades, produced three well-regarded novels that almost never stray south of the Mason-Dixon line. There ought to be a prize for such forbearance. Or maybe he was just biding time, stockpiling ammunition. Because at long last he has tackled the South head on. Lacerating but affectionate, as exuberant as it is shrewd, “Lookaway, Lookaway” is a Southern novel so sure-footed the only real question for Barnhardt is, “What took you so long?”

headline: His Favorite Wife
abstract: A memoir looks back on the life of the fifth and final Mrs. Getty.
lead_paragraph: I’ve often wondered what it takes to be the wife of a captain of industry. What combination of boundless optimism and self-delusion is necessary to live with someone whose real lover is his work, who cannot turn off his competitiveness when he walks through the door, whose wealth means his opportunities and temptations with women are somewhere between “a lot” and “infinite,” and whose children and wife exist as a beautiful backdrop to what he considers his real accomplishments?

headline: Island Magic
abstract: A Haitian girl vanishes in Edwidge Danticat’s novel.
lead_paragraph: At first, I resisted what appeared to be the fablelike delicacy of ­Edwidge Danticat’s new novel, “Claire of the Sea Light.” Was it going to be too precious? Would her lyricism camouflage or ennoble Haiti’s life-or-death struggles? But it quickly became apparent that her hypnotic prose was perfectly suited to its setting, the tragic and yet magical seaside town of Ville Rose.

headline: Will the Mile-High Club Shut Down?
abstract: The first college Meh List; Mario Batali’s Labor Day drink recipe; how Eric LeGrand stayed positive after paralysis.
lead_paragraph: The first college Meh List; Mario Batali’s Labor Day drink recipe; how Eric LeGrand stayed positive after paralysis.

headline: There Are No Sound Moral Arguments Against Performance-Enhancing Drugs
abstract: There is, however, an ethical argument.
lead_paragraph: The argument against performance-enhancing drugs in sports is that the drugs give players an unfair advantage. But how do P.E.D.’s differ from Tommy John surgery? Or pre-emptive Tommy John surgery? What about rich kids? Is their access to superior coaching, facilities and equipment a similarly unfair advantage? In a society that embraces plastic surgery, Botox injections, Viagra and all kinds of enhancements, what moral line do P.E.D.’s cross? LYNN MOFFAT, SLEEPY HOLLOW, N.Y.

headline: Two (Sucked) Thumbs Up
abstract: For the self-identified cineaste, new parenthood doesn’t mean just seeing a lot fewer movies; it means no longer trusting your judgment about the rare movies you do get to see.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, on the day my wife, Liz, would give birth to our first child, we sat down to watch “The Avengers.” She’d already seen it, and it wasn’t something I was particularly dying to see — superhero movies aren’t usually my thing. My cinematic taste generally tends to the somewhat obscure and the challenging — I’d much rather rewatch anything by Rainer Werner Fassbinder than sit through any of the “Fast and Furious” sequels. But Liz had started to feel the fluttering of early labor, and our birth-class instructor had advised us that this particular stage could last for several hours. The best thing to do, she said, was find a distraction: go for a walk, play cards or watch a dumb movie. As it turned out, there wasn’t going to be a need for any distractions. Within minutes, that fluttering became what Liz described, with some understatement, as cramps. What followed was such an incredibly compressed labor that there’s actually a special name for it: precipitous labor, which happens less than 3 percent of the time. Our son, Jack, was born an hour and a half later, at home, in our bed. I still haven’t seen “The Avengers.”

headline: Googling Yourself Takes on a Whole New Meaning
abstract: The latest in high-tech eyewear.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you see if you look at my face: a skinny titanium headband stretched across my forehead. It looks like a futuristic pair of sunglasses, minus the lenses. On my right-hand side there’s a computer, a metal frame with a small, clear cube of plastic perched just over my eye. When I tilt my head upward a bit, or run my finger along the side of the frame, the cube lights up. What I see, floating six inches in front of me, is a pinkish, translucent computer screen. It gives me access to a few simple apps: Google search, text messaging, Twitter, a to-do list, some hourly news headlines from CNN (“See a Truck Go Airborne, Fly Over Median,” “Dolphin Deaths Alarm Biologists”). Beside the screen is a teensy camera built into the frame of the glasses, ready to record anything I’m looking at.

abstract: Previously unpublished pictures of Billie Holiday, Duke Ellington, Dizzy Gillespie and more.
lead_paragraph: Previously unpublished pictures of Billie Holiday, Duke Ellington, Dizzy Gillespie and more.

abstract: Readers respond.

headline: Who Made That Traffic Radar?
abstract: Playing cop on the Merritt Parkway.
lead_paragraph: “He kept the lights off, because he didn’t want anyone to see in,” says John L. Barker of the rooms his father rented to test a radar system he was making for the U.S. military. John L. Barker Sr. — then an engineer at Automatic Signal Company — had been working on traffic lights in the 1930s, but during World War II, he dedicated himself to military research. “He pointed the machine out a window, and he tested it on cars that drove through an intersection.” Barker was about 8 years old at the time and admits that his memories are hazy. “I have no idea why I was even involved,” he says.

headline: Thomas Menino Is a Cranberry-Juice-Drinking Workhorse
abstract: The mayor says that Boston has changed — but he hasn’t had to.
lead_paragraph: There’s an old maxim that politicians are either show horses or workhorses. After 20 years as mayor of Boston, you’ve won a reputation as a workhorse. What do you think the show horses can learn from the workhorses?  Well, a mayor has to be a workhorse. You can’t be a show horse, because people depend on you. We see our constituents every day. You go buy a newspaper, go to a coffee shop, buy gas for our car — you see them.

headline: A Brief Vacation From Myself
abstract: What becomes of a man when his slate is wiped temporarily clean?
lead_paragraph: I was looking in my closet, choosing a shirt, when I lost my mind.

headline: Alternate Realms
abstract: A story collection encompasses the mythic and the everyday.
lead_paragraph: In Aimee Bender’s short stories, the value of life is measured in terms of goodness, succulence and simplicity, all qualities that can be tasted, chewed and ultimately swallowed by the mouth or the mind. In “Appleless” (one of this new book’s many parable-like fictions), the nameless narrator distrusts a girl who doesn’t appreciate the bright-hued, hand-clutched density and watery meat of apples — and the narrator goes on, with the help of others, to devour every last apple in sight. The overachieving seamstress of “Tiger Mending” isn’t satisfied with simply stitching up cut lips and handkerchiefs; she eventually takes a job in a faraway country sewing the stripes back on ruptured tigers (who apparently yawn too widely for their own good). And in one of Bender’s best stories, “The Red Ribbon,” a bored wife can’t enjoy sex with her husband unless he pays her. She likes to keep track of their accumulating ecstasies in a ledger: “ ‘I need a specific amount, each time,’ she said, ‘or,’ clearing her throat, ‘I feel I will melt into nothingness.’ ”

headline: Big Brother
abstract: A man attempts to reconcile with his estranged older sibling in this novel set in Toronto.
lead_paragraph: Dennis Bock’s third novel, “Going Home Again,” begins ominously: “On the Friday evening before Kaj Adolfsson was killed, I was actually feeling pretty good about things.” But readers expecting Nordic noir will be disappointed. The murder, when we finally hear about it in the last few pages, is a minor plot point. This is not a whodunit but a story about reckoning with the past.

headline: Free Range
abstract: A poet whose work inhabited a variety of subjects and forms.
lead_paragraph: Major poets, like trick-or-treaters, tend to arrive in pairs or small groups (whether this is a matter of fate or academic convenience may be debated). And yet from roughly 1930 to 1950, British and Irish poetry seemed to fall under the sway of a single writer: W. H. Auden. Auden was hardly a solitary figure, of course — his compatriots included Louis MacNeice, Stephen Spender and Cecil Day-Lewis (father of Daniel), and the four writers were once thought to be so intimately related that the poet Roy Campbell referred to them as “MacSpaunday.” But it wasn’t a relationship of equals: the MacSpaunday poets were usually considered notable not because of how closely they resembled one another, but because of how much the other three looked like Auden.

headline: Fascist Designs
abstract: A biography of the nationalist poet Gabriele d’Annunzio, whose theatrical sense of political style influenced Mussolini.
lead_paragraph: As capitalism transformed European economies during the second half of the 19th century, the rise of the masses revolutionized political life. Searching for identity and purpose in a confusing and changing world, many took refuge in nationalism — a continentwide phenomenon that found its most virulent expression in newly created countries like Germany and Italy, where it soon upended culture along with everything else.

headline: Land of Mystery
abstract: Two books explore the reasons for North Korea’s confounding survival.
lead_paragraph: A quarter-century ago, North Korea seemed to teeter on the brink of collapse. The end of the cold war in the late 1980s and the disintegration of the Soviet Union in 1991 suggested that the era of reclusive Communist dictatorships was over. How, asked hopeful observers around the world, could Kim Il-sung’s Stalinist wasteland possibly survive under the pressure of its spectacular economic failures and the tide of democracy and capitalism rising around its borders?

headline: Winter’s Bane
abstract: “How the Light Gets In,” Louise Penny’s latest mystery featuring the honorable detective Armand Gamache, takes place in a secluded Canadian hamlet.
lead_paragraph: A four-day blizzard has left the village of Three Pines looking like a toy town sheltered under a snow globe. But this secluded Canadian hamlet, tucked away in a valley deep in the mountains, contributes more than its picturesque setting to Louise Penny’s latest mystery, HOW THE LIGHT GETS IN (Minotaur, $25.99). You might even say Three Pines is the hero of the novel.

headline: Bon Courage
abstract: Memories afflict a woman as her brother struggles with AIDS.
lead_paragraph: In Paris, during his sabbatical in the early 1980s, a dear friend proposed we meet not for drinks at the Café de Flore but for ice cream at Berthillon. “The doctors have forbidden me alcohol,” he said. “In France! Can you imagine?” He’d been having odd health problems, one after the other, that they couldn’t explain. Months later, he developed Pneumocystis pneumonia and got his explanation. He died soon thereafter; our naïve days were at an end.

headline: Small-Town Savant
abstract: An Irish village oddball tells the story of a tragic friendship.
lead_paragraph: Ten years ago, when Mark Haddon’s “Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time” turned up on the best-seller list and won a number of literary awards, the novel’s autistic narrator beguiled readers with his unconventional point of view. Today, even as controversy surrounds the revised classification of autism in the latest version of the American Psychiatric Association’s Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, the quirky yet remarkably perceptive points of view of autistic narrators have become increasingly familiar in every category of fiction, from young adult to science fiction to popular and literary fiction.

lead_paragraph: THROUGH THE NIGHT  By Stig Saeterbakken  Translated by Sean KinsellaDalkey Archive, paper, $15.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Marisha Pessl, whose occult thriller “Night Film” is No. 6 on the hardcover fiction list, says, “There’s a question of whether we can feel real fear in this day and age.”
lead_paragraph: Dark Corners: Marisha Pessl made a lot of noise with her first novel, “Special Topics in Calamity Physics” — it spent three weeks on the hardcover fiction list in 2006, and was named one of the Book Review’s 10 Best Books of the year. Her follow-up, “Night Film,” hasn’t collected quite the same level of praise; in the daily New York Times, Janet Maslin cited a “haunting suspicion” that the book “was more exciting to write than to read.”

headline: For Girls in India, the Pressure to Conform Comes From Family
keywords: ['Culture (Arts)', 'Families and Family Life', 'Grandparents', 'Parenting', 'Women and Girls', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: “If you can say ‘no’ to persistent Indian grandparents, you can say ‘no’ to anyone.”
lead_paragraph: I recently watched the remarkable Malala Yousafzai speak at the United Nations to commemorate a day that is named after her. The 16-year-old who was shot by the Taliban, and has since become a celebrated activist for education and women’s rights, said that Malala Day was for “every boy and every girl who have raised their voice for their rights.” She bravely reinterpreted Islam and accused the extremists of being afraid of books, pens and education. “The power of the voice of women frightens them,” she said.

headline: Call It Beyrouth: Beirut With a French Accent
abstract: Beirutis returning from France bring a craving for Parisian life, while the young embrace a Franco-flavored hybrid.
lead_paragraph: I was finishing an aperitif on the porch at Villa Clara while other guests tossed pétanque balls in the nearby yard. The hotel’s 4-year-old namesake cozied up to her papa, showing off her latest crayon creation. “Oh, c’est magnifique,” said Olivier Gougeon, a French chef and an owner of the property with his wife, Marie-Hélène, an editor of a French-language home décor magazine.

lead_paragraph: One of the things you always heard, back when we were actually talking about stimulus rather than fighting a rearguard action against destructive austerity, was the claim that stimulus spending would inevitably end up becoming a permanent fixture of the economy. This was always said with an air of worldly wisdom — of course that’s how these things work! — even though history said very much the opposite.

headline: New Uses for Cucumbers
keywords: ['Recipes', 'Cucumbers', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Medicine and Health']

lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV – As Labor Day weekend approaches, hundreds of thousands of bus passengers, eager to savor summer’s last gasp, will pass through the Port Authority Bus Terminal. As baffling as some tourists – and even New Yorkers – find the place, imagine that sort of human traffic scurrying through a labyrinth of oddly placed stairways and market stalls. Picture that in your mind’s eye, and you’ll know what it’s like to travel by bus through Tel Aviv.
