headline: A Quiet Beauty Flying By
abstract: Many New York City shorelines afford a chance to stand with your boots in the mud, surrounded by the sights, smells and sounds of North American shorebirds’ journeys.
lead_paragraph: Each summer, a quiet migration gets under way for North American shorebirds. Measured in sheer numbers, the volume is astounding as millions of birds collect along the Atlantic coast. What is both miraculous and unnerving is that the North Atlantic Flyway guides them directly through some of the densest population centers on earth virtually unnoticed. Except for delighted bird watchers and worried managers at local airports, most New Yorkers are unaware that outside their windows, birds are coursing along an ancient migration route.

headline: The ‘Black Budget,’ Revealed
keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: Why are intelligence agency budgets classified? Is the government worried about national security, or the accountability that comes with disclosure?
lead_paragraph: For budget-watchers, it was a voyeuristic thrill to read through the Washington Post’s article today exposing the secret details of the intelligence community’s “black budget.” The world now knows that the C.I.A. gets the biggest chunk of intelligence spending at $14.7 billion for 2013, and that a little-known agency, the National Reconnaissance Office, gets $10.3 billion, almost as much as the National Security Agency. (The reconnaissance office builds spy satellites, which are apparently rather pricey.)

Especially when it rains. For them, the Mojito Bar and Restaurant has provided sit-down dining and people-watching outside Arthur Ashe Stadium since 2003 (the year that Andy Roddick, now retired, won). The restaurant, which serves Latin-influenced fare, was redesigned this year to evoke South Beach. It’s Florida à la Flushing, punctuated by red and gold patio umbrellas on the terrace and artsy chandeliers inside.

headline: Work, Work, Family, Work
abstract: Even on Sundays, Ban Ki-moon’s work as secretary general of the United Nations doesn’t stop.
lead_paragraph: Ban Ki-moon, 69, has been the secretary general of the United Nations since 2007. A South Korean, Mr. Ban spent his childhood in a war-torn country and later experienced its rebirth as an industrial power in Asia. His job never stops, so on Sundays he works, taking calls on his BlackBerry and responding to queries from his staff or heads of state. Mr. Ban lives with his wife, Yoo Soon-taek, 68, in a United Nations town house on Sutton Place, where visits from their three grown children and four grandchildren offer a break from the rigors of trying to solve the world’s problems.

headline: The Summer After the Storm

lead_paragraph: LONG BEACH, N.Y. — There was Jonathan Goldman one perfect August afternoon, happily traipsing down the Long Beach Boardwalk, dispensing wisdom to unsuspecting strollers and leaving snippets of rimshot patter floating in the salty air.

headline: Low Ratings for ‘Low Winter Sun’
abstract: AMC’s dark new drama “Low Winter Sun” has not benefited from the success of its lead-in, “Breaking Bad.”
lead_paragraph: AMC’s “Breaking Bad” has been one of the summer’s great ratings success stories, a testament to the power of binge watching and word of mouth.

headline: Malevich’s Burial Site Is Found, Underneath Housing Development
abstract: The burial site of the artist Kazimir Malevich, near Moscow, has been covered in concrete by a real estate developer.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The burial site of the Russian avant-garde artist and theorist Kazimir Malevich, in a field near Moscow, has been covered in concrete by a real estate developer to make way for luxury housing, says an enthusiast who spent years looking for the site.

headline: Changing It Up in the Bedroom
abstract: If you’re watching a channel called Discovery Fit & Health and someone starts talking about “the lifestyle,” you might assume the reference is to a triathlon training regimen or a vegan diet.
lead_paragraph: If you’re watching a channel called Discovery Fit & Health and someone starts talking about “the lifestyle,” you might assume the reference is to a triathlon training regimen or a vegan diet. Not on a new show the channel offers on Saturday. The lifestyle in question involves spouse swapping and other alternatives to monogamy. The show, a four-part reality series, is called “Secret Sex Lives: Swingers,” and it looks at five couples who like to mix things up occasionally in the bedroom. And they could be that ordinary-looking couple next door.

headline: Identity Puzzles From U.S. and Iran
abstract: More than ever, tension among forces of cosmopolitan democracy, religious traditionalism and militaristic order roil the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: More than ever, tension among forces of cosmopolitan democracy, religious traditionalism and militaristic order roil the Middle East. So Asia Society’s “Iran Modern,” an exhibition of more than 100 artworks made in Iran in the two decades before the revolution of 1979, should be something to see. Modern art was starting to thrive then, as artists explored new possibilities of identity. It opens Friday. (Through Jan. 5, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, asiasociety.org.)

headline: In Store | The Wythe Hotel’s New Concept Shop Is a Family Affair
abstract: Opening in time for Fashion Week, the curated boutique gathers artisanal, handmade products from the Brooklyn creative community and beyond.
lead_paragraph: To some, the Wythe Hotel in Williamsburg may represent the way Brooklyn is changing, but it’s sticking with the borough’s tradition of keeping it in the family. Opening next Tuesday is a new boutique known as the Shop, with a theme and offerings chosen by one local mastermind, which will change every four to six months. The first curator is the fashion designer Caron Callahan, whose label is based in the neighborhood. (Her husband, Sean Rembold, is the executive chef at the restaurant Marlow & Sons, owned by Andrew Tarlow, who is also the man behind the Wythe.) “They were looking for something that gave a little energy to that nook,” Callahan said. “There’s so much happening here, and the taste level is super-high.”

headline: It’s Pre-Season at Poisson Rouge
abstract: This week three ambitious artists come to the stylish Bleecker Street nightclub Le Poisson Rouge.
lead_paragraph: The fall season is looming, but plenty of ambitious artists are not content to wait for any official starter’s pistol to sound, and this week three of them come to the stylish Bleecker Street nightclub Le Poisson Rouge. Two are coming together. On Tuesday, the excellent young pianists Ran Dank and Soyeon Kate Lee present an evening of works for piano duo, including the premiere of Frederic Rzewski’s “Four Hands,” as well as Brahms’s 16 Waltzes, Op. 39 and an arrangement of Stravinsky’s “Rite of Spring.”

headline: Exploring Gender and Sexuality
abstract: Sex, in all its variety, some of it explicit, is the main subject of NewFest, the New York L.G.B.T. Festival.
lead_paragraph: With the Supreme Court overturning the Defense of Marriage Act, and gay marriage being legalized in one state after another, the struggle for sexual equality has taken precedence over the fact of sexuality in the gay, lesbian and transgender liberation movement. But sex, in all its variety, some of it explicit, is the main subject of NewFest, the New York L.G.B.T. Festival.

headline: Putting Poetry Above Politics
abstract: The songwriter Mohsen Namjoo stirs things up in Iran.
lead_paragraph: The songwriter Mohsen Namjoo stirs things up in Iran. Mr. Namjoo, who performs Saturday at the Asia Society, plays the setar, a long-necked lute, and is steeped in Persian classical and literary traditions. But in Iran, where Western music was banned in 2005, Mr. Namjoo decided to fuse Persian music with rock and jazz and to sing — in a voice that can push from the nuances of Persian improvisation to the rougher attack of the blues — about the conditions facing his generation: unemployment, repression, violence. Though he was not allowed to perform in public or licensed to sell CDs, his music spread in private events, on the black market and via YouTube and radio.

headline: A Broader Look at the War Across Syria
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']

lead_paragraph: Uncertainty about how an outside attack could affect Syria’s civil war is one of the factors leading to disagreement among Western countries about how to respond.

headline: Road Trip to New Fringe
abstract: The 16-day Fringe Festival gets under way on Thursday in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: It’s a sleepy week for dance in New York; most theaters are dark, and the late-summer lull has set in. For ambitious dancegoers, a road trip might be in order, namely to Philadelphia, where the 16-day Fringe Festival gets under way on Thursday. Formerly known as the Philadelphia Live Arts Festival and Philly Fringe, a restructured entity, FringeArts, presents this year’s thoroughly interdisciplinary mix.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Skype a Decade Later and Why There Aren’t Enough Women in Tech
abstract: Friday’s selections from around the Web include an argument for why Microsoft isn’t doing justice to Skype and an eye-popping collection of sexism horror stories from women in the technology industry.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: A Rebuilt Revis Is Looking Ahead, Not Back
abstract: Darrelle Revis, traded by the Jets in April, knows that the Buccaneers are taking a chance that he can recover fully from a torn knee ligament. “But I’m betting on myself. Wouldn’t you?” Revis said.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Darrelle Revis leaves his waterfront residence downtown every morning and drives to an office whose entrance is flanked by palm trees. It is always warm, always sunny, and even if it isn’t, it still seems that way to Revis. Sometimes, he said with a laugh, he has to tell himself that he is not on vacation.

abstract: A 19-foot-high cast-bronze sculpture by the artist Ursula von Rydingsvard now stands in front of the Brooklyn arena.
lead_paragraph: A 19-foot-high cast-bronze sculpture by the artist Ursula von Rydingsvard now stands in front of the Brooklyn arena.

headline: In Des Moines, a Bonanza That Not Everyone Wants
abstract: A class-action suit resulted in $40 million in refunds on fees that courts deemed an illegal tax. But some residents want City Hall to keep the money.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Nearly a decade ago, Lisa Connett, newly divorced and struggling on a tight budget, decided to fight City Hall over its “franchise fee” on residents’ utility bills. Now, as a result of her class-action suit, consumers here stand to collect some $40 million in refunds on fees that courts deemed an illegal tax.

headline: Turning Chaos Into Theater, With a Cast of 200
abstract: The Public Theater’s musical adaptation of Shakespeare draws on unconventional performers from the five boroughs, including ex-offenders, nannies, children and the elderly.
lead_paragraph: Donald Gray, who will make his theatrical debut in a musical version of Shakespeare’s “Tempest” in Central Park next weekend, has taken an unconventional route to the stage. Mr. Gray, 53, was arrested for the first time at age 15, for selling drugs, and spent the next decades running the streets or in prison.

headline: All Eyes on Her
abstract: A nearly 12,000-pound sculpture called “Ona,” by Ursula von Rydingsvard, now stands greeting the public at Barclays Center.
lead_paragraph: “She” has arrived.

headline: To Sleep, Perchance to Dream Another’s Reality
abstract: Three characters are trapped in reveries and in search of what is real in “The Awake,” by Ken Urban.
lead_paragraph: “I read in some crazy book you bought me that ‘weird’ comes from the Anglo-Saxon word for ‘wise.’ ”

headline: Another Kind of Music
abstract: The singer and songwriter Paul Simon admires the musicality of Seamus Heaney, who died on Friday.
lead_paragraph: I was in the audience at the Abbey Theater in Dublin on June 9, 1991, when Seamus Heaney read from his new book of poems, “Seeing Things.” I know the exact date because he kindly inscribed his book for me and dated it. But I wouldn’t have forgotten that night, with or without the month and year. Seamus gave a mesmerizing, witty and emotional performance, and it was a rare opportunity for me to hear the sound of his words spoken with their true accent.

headline: Microsoft Cuts Deal With Activist Shareholder to Avoid Fight
abstract: The saga of Steve Ballmer’s exit from Microsoft deepened on Friday with an agreement between Microsoft and an activist shareholder, ValueAct Capital, that averts a potentially nasty battle over the company’s lagging performance.
lead_paragraph: The saga of Steve Ballmer’s departure/retirement from Microsoft continued Friday with an agreement between Microsoft and an activist shareholder, ValueAct Capital, that averts a potentially nasty battle over the company’s lagging performance.

headline: Knockout Teams at World Youth Open
abstract: At the 3rd World Youth Open Championships, in the Youngsters (under 21) Knockout Teams, eight teams qualified for 32-board quarterfinals, semifinals and final.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — At the 3rd World Youth Open Championships here this month, in the Youngsters (under 21) Knockout Teams, eight teams, three Chinese and five American, qualified for 32-board quarterfinals, semifinals and final.

headline: A Musical Homecoming
abstract: Will Sheff, front man for the rock band Okkervil River, shows reporter Larry Rohter around his small New Hampshire hometown, which inspired the band’s forthcoming album, “The Silver Gymnasium.”
lead_paragraph: Will Sheff, front man for the rock band Okkervil River, shows reporter Larry Rohter around his small New Hampshire hometown, which inspired the band’s forthcoming album, “The Silver Gymnasium.”

headline: Capturing Rhythms of Nature in Poems
abstract: Regardless of a poem’s subject, there are continuities in Seamus Heaney’s work, including an awareness of mortality and the precariousness of life.
lead_paragraph: In his Nobel acceptance speech, Seamus Heaney said that he prized the sort of poem that provides not just “a surprising variation played upon the world,” but “a retuning of the world itself” — delivering a visceral surprise, “like the impatient thump which unexpectedly restores the picture to the television set, or the electric shock which sets the fibrillating heart back to its proper rhythm.”

headline: Lower Labor Day Gas Prices
abstract: Despite turmoil in the Middle East and potential Western involvement in the Syrian crisis, the price of oil has been relatively stable and the price of gas this weekend will be lower than it was in the last two years.
lead_paragraph: Despite turmoil in the Middle East and potential Western involvement in the Syrian crisis, the price of oil has been relatively stable and the price of gas this weekend will be lower than it was in the last two years.

headline: A Treasure Map of a Childhood, Filled With Magic and Newts
abstract: Will Sheff has drawn on his childhood in New Hampshire for his band Okkervil River’s new record, “The Silver Gymnasium.”
lead_paragraph: MERIDEN, N.H. — The singer, songwriter and multi-instrumentalist Will Sheff founded the indie-rock band Okkervil River in Austin, Tex., in 1998 and now lives in Brooklyn. But memories of his years growing up in this bucolic New England hamlet in the 1980s have never been far from his mind, so when it came time to make a new CD, he decided to return home — in song and in person.

headline: Minnesota Orchestra Calls in Big Gun in Dispute
abstract: George J. Mitchell, the former senator and Mideast envoy, is trying to mediate the Minnesota Orchestra’s bitter labor dispute.
lead_paragraph: He brokered peace in Northern Ireland and spent two frustrating years as an envoy in the Middle East. Now George J. Mitchell, the former senator from Maine, is trying to bring peace to the Midwest, as the mediator in the Minnesota Orchestra’s bitter labor dispute.

headline: Have You Met the Bergers? Of Course, You Have
abstract: The National Asian American Theater production of Clifford Odets’s “Awake and Sing!” easily makes its point that human realities trump ethnicity.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes you walk into a thimble-size theater where the stage is just the floor, flanked by 50 or so chairs, and you think, Lord, this is going to be way too cozy.

headline: Violin and Bass Trombone Finally Meet, and It’s Love
abstract: Social links and unusual combinations of instruments make the annual Labor Day Festival at Bargemusic an engaging event.
lead_paragraph: The first concert of this year’s Labor Day Festival of contemporary music at Bargemusic included four world premieres. But the composer of one, David Del Tredici, insisted that his “Dynamic Duo ‘Farewell’ for Violin and Bass Trombone” was more than that: a “civilization premiere,” the first pairing — ever, anywhere — of those two instruments.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Aug. 30

lead_paragraph: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a boat club on Newtown Creek, the race for mayor and a baby snow leopard at the Bronx Zoo,

headline: Friday Night Music: Missing the Civil Wars
abstract: Beauty we probably won’t see again.
lead_paragraph: The Civil Wars have a new, and presumably final album. It’s lovely; but I haven’t been able to bring myself to post any of the official videos, because I keep thinking of what we lost when they had their falling out. What I always loved most was the magic of those live performances, and it doesn’t look as if we’ll have those ever again.

headline: Seven Days of Chic | Fashion Pills and Furry Shoes
abstract: From taxidermy footwear to a fashion week invitation in the form of a prescription, ten fashion developments in the week that was.
lead_paragraph: 1. “Girls” GirlJemima Kirke’s druid-chic getup at the VMAs was amazing. Totem-pole-printed gauze atop a “She’s All That”-style little red dress? Sure, why not?

headline: Evangelist’s Flock Keeps the Faith After His Brush With the Law
abstract: A young Alabama preacher reaches out from jail, where he was sent on charges of impersonating a law officer.
lead_paragraph: TRUSSVILLE, Ala. — Inside a darkened, sweltering room here one night this week, the evangelist Matt Pitt roused a couple hundred members of his young congregation in between raucous songs and a skit about prom dates.

headline: Making the Safety Net More Visible in Philadelphia
abstract: Philadelphia has initiated an effort called Shared Prosperity that offers “one-stop shopping” in local outreach centers to help poor people get all the assistance they need.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Like many poor people in this city, Gladys James did not know she was entitled to free home help or discounted water bills. She had no idea she was eligible to re-enroll for food stamps after being cut off last year because of a misunderstanding.

headline: Judge Says Search Warrants for E-mails Must Be ‘Limited’
abstract: In the age of big data, beware the temptation to rifle through everything, says a ruling by a federal judge, citing the Constitution.
lead_paragraph: Can law enforcement obtain a search warrant to dig through a vast trove of e-mails, instant messages and chat logs because they have reasonable suspicion that the owners of those accounts robbed computer equipment from a private company?

headline: Giants Take Wait-and-See Approach After Brown’s Injury
abstract: The Giants have decided to wait on the test results of the fracture in Andre Brown’s left leg to determine their course of action.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants have lost so many starting players during the preseason that after another key contributor went down Thursday night, it did not discernibly rattle the mood inside the team’s locker room the next day.

headline: Yankees Keep Hughes in Rotation, Just Not Against Orioles
abstract: The Yankees tweaked their rotation Friday so that the slumping Phil Hughes would avoid facing the Baltimore Orioles, a team the Yankees trail in the wild-card chase, in a crucial series this weekend.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees tweaked their rotation Friday so that the slumping Phil Hughes would avoid facing the Baltimore Orioles, a team the Yankees trail in the wild-card chase, in a crucial series this weekend. Originally scheduled to pitch Sunday, Hughes will switch with Andy Pettitte, who was originally set to pitch Monday against the Chicago White Sox. Pettitte will now pitch Sunday, and Hughes will pitch Monday.

headline: For News From Syrian Battleground, a Reliance on Social Media
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Social Media', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The dangers of news organizations reporting in Syria have kept most journalists outside the country’s borders and heightened the need for third-party video.
lead_paragraph: When Secretary of State John Kerry delivered the United States’ report on Friday about the use of chemical weapons in Syria, he noted that “all hell broke loose in the social media” just 90 minutes after the alleged attack. As evidence of atrocities, the report cites thousands of social media updates and videos, along with reports from intelligence agencies, journalists and medical personnel.

headline: Gay and Married Couples in New Land of Taxation
keywords: ['Federal Taxes (US)', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Wills and Estates', 'Income Tax']
abstract: The Internal Revenue Service set down the rules that will cost or save a particular couple money, including how those who live in the 37 states that do not sanction same-sex marriages will fare.
lead_paragraph: It’s now official: same-sex married couples across the country are allowed to check one of the “married” boxes on their federal tax returns, even if their own state doesn’t recognize their union.

headline: A Colored Man’s Constitution
abstract: A mysterious document offers a rare glimpse into the mind of a former slave living through the Civil War.
lead_paragraph: Patrolling the streets of New Orleans on the evening of Sept. 1, 1863, a police officer found a small sheaf of handwritten papers. They were hard to read, written mostly in halting, misspelled English. Glancing over a page, the policeman may have seen at first only snatches of apparently incoherent prose: “Carrige Drivers preachers of the Gospel the best Soldiers the united States Can Raise but the tel lies Sometimes and so dos all negro traders the get Drunk and lawiers and merchants.”

headline: The Luck of an Unlicensed Barber Runs Out
abstract: A police inspection of a barbershop in Ridgewood, Queens, turns up a suspect in a vicious assault in a Mexican restaurant.
lead_paragraph: Three or four barbers were working that Thursday evening at Corner Cuts in Ridgewood, Queens, when the police walked in.

headline: L.I.R.R. Train Kills Dog in Queens, Disrupting Service for 45 Minutes
abstract: One day after two subway lines in Brooklyn were out for 90 minutes because of runaway kittens, an escaped pit bull was run over in Queens.
lead_paragraph: For the second time in two days, pets forced the suspension of service on a major transit line in New York City. On Thursday, two kittens were rescued from the tracks of a Brooklyn subway station. But on Friday, the escape of a dog from a Queens yard turned into a pet owner’s nightmare: The dog, a female pit bull, was struck and killed by a Long Island Rail Road train, and her owner was grazed trying to get her back.

headline: Fallen Official’s Defense: He Was Obeying Orders
abstract: Bo Xilai said at his trial that he had been ordered to cover up his police chief’s flight to an American Consulate, according to a court observer’s record.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Bo Xilai, the fallen Communist Party official, said in secret testimony during his recent trial that he was obeying orders from a powerful party agency in charge of security when he took steps to cover up the flight of his police chief to an American Consulate, according to a court observer’s written record of trial statements.

headline: Syracuse-Penn State Game Is Drawing Mostly Shrugs
abstract: Sluggish ticket sales for the Syracuse-Penn State game show the difficulty in capturing New Yorkers’ interest in college football.
lead_paragraph: When the first full day of the college football season kicks off Saturday afternoon, The Ainsworth bar in Manhattan’s Chelsea neighborhood will undoubtedly be ready. Reservations for more than 250 seats started being taken two weeks ago and were sold out by Thursday. Forty flat-screen televisions will be tuned to football.

headline: U.S. Moves Ahead on Plan to Sell Plum Island, Home of a Research Laboratory
abstract: The possibility that the federal government would sell the property off Long Island for private development has alarmed some elected officials and environmental groups.
lead_paragraph: MONTAUK, N.Y. — It has figured in conspiracy theories involving government experimentation with odd hybrid animals, à la Dr. Moreau. It was mentioned in “Silence of the Lambs” as the one place fit for the serial killer Hannibal Lecter. In real life, it was home to a high-security federal laboratory that did important research on contagious animal diseases.

headline: Vows: Adam and Kendall
abstract: As in their professional lives, Adam Ostrow and Kendall Aliment started their personal relationship online. After numerous tweets, Instagram photographs and G-chat sessions, they are getting married.
lead_paragraph: As in their professional lives, Adam Ostrow and Kendall Aliment started their personal relationship online. After numerous tweets, Instagram photographs and G-chat sessions, they are getting married.

abstract: At protests on Friday, there was less talk of restoring the ousted president and more denunciation of tactics used against Muslim Brotherhood supporters.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The continuing protests against the military takeover here showed signs on Friday of shifting into a movement against the authoritarian tactics of the new government rather than one demanding the return of the ousted president, Mohamed Morsi.

lead_paragraph: The Department of Agriculture on Friday approved four Chinese poultry processors to begin shipping a limited amount of meat to the United States, a move that is likely to add to the debate over food imports.

headline: Relief, but Disappointment, for Plaintiffs in N.F.L. Case
abstract: One day after the announcement of a $765 million settlement in a concussion lawsuit, some former players and their families expressed mixed feelings.
lead_paragraph: Years ago, the symptoms started. Forrest Gregg would drag his left foot when he walked. He would thrash and kick and scream in the night, a nightmare running in his head. He would comb his hair with his right hand while his left hand trembled.

headline: A Shave in Prison Is Expected for Hasan

lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, the military psychiatrist sentenced to death this week in the shooting rampage at Fort Hood in November 2009, will be forced to shave his beard on death row, Army officials announced on Friday.

headline: Cumulus Media Will Buy a Radio Syndicator
abstract: The deal would let Cumulus beef up its syndication business with programs from the National Football League, the Olympics and Nascar, as well as news and entertainment.
lead_paragraph: In a deal that could heighten the competition in radio against Clear Channel Communications, long the industry’s dominant player, Cumulus Media has agreed to buy Dial Global, a syndicator of sports, talk and music programming to thousands of stations, for $260 million.

headline: Puzzling Through (A Love Song)
abstract: If you can succinctly explain what your song is about before you’ve written it, it may not be worth writing.
lead_paragraph: In the beginning stages of writing a new batch of songs, before they are performed and recorded, my ideas are unfaithful. They can be coy or stubborn, refusing to go where I want them to — this is as it should be.

headline: With Huge War Chests, Activist Investors Tackle Big Companies
abstract: Activist hedge funds have grown more ambitious, taking on larger companies and seeking long-term change over short-term profit, unlike raiders of the past.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft executives faced an unusual challenge in April when a $12 billion hedge fund, ValueAct, announced that it had bought a nearly $2 billion stake in the company with the intention of shaking things up.

headline: Hewitt Upsets del Potro; Murray and Djokovic Rebound
abstract: Lleyton Hewitt stunned sixth-seeded Juan Martín del Potro, and Andy Murray rebounded after dropping a set to Leonardo Mayer at the United States Open.
lead_paragraph: Two former United States Open champions, both strong-willed competitors and veterans of the spotlight, carried on late into Friday night in one of the most dramatic contests of the early stages of the Open.

headline: Britain Cites Grave Risks in Leaked Data It Seized
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: A court extended police powers to analyze data taken from David Miranda, whose partner, Glenn Greenwald, has led the reporting on material leaked by Edward J. Snowden.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A standoff between the British government and The Guardian over national security and press freedom entered its latest round on Friday when the high court extended police powers to analyze encrypted material seized from the partner of one of the newspaper’s journalists this month.

headline: Why India’s Economy Is Stumbling
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: India’s problems have deep and stubborn origins of the country’s own making.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — FOR the past three decades, the Indian economy has grown impressively, at an average annual rate of 6.4 percent. From 2002 to 2011, when the average rate was 7.7 percent, India seemed to be closing in on China — unstoppable, and engaged in a second “tryst with destiny,” to borrow Jawaharlal Nehru’s phrase. The economic potential of its vast population, expected to be the world’s largest by the middle of the next decade, appeared to be unleashed as India jettisoned the stifling central planning and economic controls bequeathed it by Mr. Nehru and the nation’s other socialist founders.

headline: Support Slipping, U.S. Defends Plan for Syria Attack
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare']
abstract: Facing faltering support in foreign capitals and Congress, the Obama administration made an aggressive push to justify military intervention in Syria on the grounds that American credibility was at stake.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Facing faltering support in foreign capitals and Congress for a strike against Syria, the Obama administration on Friday made an aggressive and coordinated push to justify a military intervention on the grounds that American credibility was at stake.

headline: Jailed for Journalism
keywords: ['Freedom of the Press', 'News and News Media', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Libel and Slander']
abstract: Liberia doesn’t deserve its reputation for press freedom.
lead_paragraph: MONROVIA, Liberia — IT’S not uncommon in African countries like Zimbabwe and Ethiopia for newspapers to be shut, and their editors jailed. But the newspaper I edit doesn’t operate in a dictatorship. We are in Liberia, the West’s poster child for postwar democracy building. Our president, Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, is a Nobel laureate who is celebrated by the likes of Bill Gates, Warren E. Buffett and Bono and has positioned herself as a champion of a free press.

headline: Politically, Our Next Big Thing
abstract: Parties don’t always manage to recruit serious candidates for Senate races. That’s where you come in.
lead_paragraph: It is time to start thinking about running for the U.S. Senate. Allow me to explain.

headline: Stuyvesant Principal, Now Retired, Mishandled Cheating Case, Report Says
abstract: The report said that after Stanley Teitel was tipped off by a student about the cheating, he set up a sting to catch the ringleader when he should have tried to pre-emptively thwart the cheating.
lead_paragraph: The principal of Stuyvesant High School, one of New York City’s top public schools, mishandled the investigation into a large cheating operation there last year from the moment he was tipped off to it until state education officials became aware of it more than a week later, a city report issued on Friday said.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Lottery numbers for Aug. 30 for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: For New York City Council
abstract: The Times makes recommendations for six contested races in the Democratic primary.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s 51-member City Council ideally gives each neighborhood a voice in the complicated politics of City Hall. headline: What’s on Saturday

lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) LES MISÉRABLES (2012) Hugh Jackman (above, who earned an Oscar nomination for his role in the film), Anne Hathaway (who won for best supporting actress), Russell Crowe, Amanda Seyfried and Eddie Redmayne sing their hearts out in this adaptation of the Victor Hugo novel about an inspector’s pursuit of a convict and the love between a young woman and a firebrand of the French Revolution. “The artful grunge layered onto the cast can be a distraction, as you imagine assistant dirt wranglers anxiously hovering off camera,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. Ms. Hathaway, though, as Fantine, “the factory worker turned prostitute turned martyr, and singing the showstopping ‘I Dreamed a Dream,’ her gaunt face splotched red and brown,” she wrote, “holds you rapt with raw, trembling emotion.” But while the director, Tom Hooper, demonstrated in “The King’s Speech” that he can be very good with actors, his “inability to leave any lily ungilded — to direct a scene without tilting or hurtling or throwing the camera around — is bludgeoning and deadly,” she added. “By the grand finale, when tout le monde is waving the French tricolor in victory, you may instead be raising the white flag in exhausted defeat.”

Some are requests for corrections or assignments, which can be sent to another desk. But a bunch, maybe two dozen, are legitimate topics for investigation or exposition. As my crack assistant, Meghan Gourley, does triage on the e-mail, I pick a subject for a blog post that seems timely, important and of broad interest — The Times’s use of anonymous sources, particularly on that day’s front page — and start reporting it.
